notes: a total of 335 detainees escaped from niamey prison here late on tuesday during a riot over alleged police corruption, the official anp news agency reported wednesday. the republican guards in charge of the prison did not use their weapons, said anp. the breakout followed revelations over the past few days by the national conference on the future of niger, that police were involved in the trafficking of heroin. the police had been given authority by former president seyni kountche to sell 14 kilos of heroin, seized in 1987, to pharmaceutical laboratories, and use the money to buy materiel. instead, the heroin was sold for profit on the nigerian drug market. the prisoners claimed police leaders were not punished while small time traffickers were hit with heavy sentences.

sources: women protest against being blamed for drought the associated press, july 16, 1992, thursday, am cycle, international news, 109 words duke sails press association, july 17, 1992, friday, home news, 280 words the washington post, protest in niger, ns, july 17, 1992, friday, final edition, first section; page a16; around the world, 77 words ;
notes: hundreds of women marched thursday to protest being harassed by people who blame them for a shortage of rainfall in this impoverished nation on the fringes of the sahara desert. the march was organized by the niger women s association and the niger human rights association after some young women wearing short skirts were blamed for the drought and stripped in public. men who falsely claim to be muslim holy men, known here as marabouts, have asserted that the women s dress was responsible for the lower than normal rainfall this year. about 5,000 women marched through niger s capital niamey in a protest against attacks by a muslim sect which claims mini skirted women are causing a drought. police in the west african country have arrested several members of the izala sect after a wave of attacks on women wearing provocative attire, reuters reported.

notes: gangs of between 50 and 100 high school students on tuesday set ablaze the headquarters of at least four of the nine political parties in niger s presidential coalition, witnesses said. the fires were rapidly put out and police, firemen and witnesses questioned by afp said they were aware of no casualties. by late morning, niamey streets were calm and riot police were out in search of the arsonists. the pupils were objecting to a government decision to close down secondary schools and write off the current academic year. the first attack came when students, some on motorcycles, smashed in the doors of the headquarters of president mahamane ousmane s democratic and social convention cds , hurled petrol bombs inside and fled before police arrived. nineteen students arrested more than a month ago have been acquitted but refused to leave jail until a niger court hands down its verdict on six of their colleagues, their usn union said monday. the usn said the verdict on the six, who include two union leaders, was expected on tuesday. they were arrested during a violent demonstration on may 18 when the niamey headquarters of four political parties in the ruling coalition were set ablaze. the 19 others were detained five days later.

sources: soldiers mutiny in niger in protest over wages agence france presse english, 374 words rebelling soldiers in niger take 11 hostages including top army official agence france presse english, 374 words rebelling troops release hostages agence france presse english, 374 words ;
notes: soldiers demanding overdue wages staged a brief mutiny in central niger saturday, taking control of zinder town and its airport before returning to their barracks, a local correspondent for niger s national radio said. the source, contacted by telephone, however told afp that the soldiers warned they would resume their action if their demands were not satisfied within 48 hours . they were demanding to be paid three months overdue wages and pressing for the cancellation of budget cuts made by the niger government last month, according to the source. mutinous soldiers in niger on tuesday ignored an appeal for calm by president mahamane ousmane and took 11 hostages, including the deputy head of the army s general staff, moussa moumouni djermakoye. colonel djermakoye and others were taken hostage in zinder, niger s second city 750 kilometres 470 miles east of niamey, informed local sources told afp. soldiers from three of niger s main army garrisons began a revolt saturday and said they will not release their hostages until financial and political demands are met. soldiers at the garrison in maradi 550 kilometres 340 miles east of niamey also joined the mutiny tuesday, according to local witnesses contacted by telephone. mutinous soldiers at five garrisons on late tuesday freed all of the military and civilian hostages they had been holding in a dispute over financial and political demands, interior minister ousmane oumarou said. mutinous troops, who began their action on saturday, had insisted they would not free their captives until their demands had been satisfied, namely the payment of back wages, cancellation of budgetary austerity measures and the resumption of patrols suspended june 10 against taureg rebels in the north.

sources: schoolchildren rampage though niamey in grants protest agence france presse english, 467 words students attack international school in niger the associated press, january 11, 1994, tuesday, pm cycle, international news, 106 words ;
notes: hundreds of high school students rampaged through niamey on tuesday, ransacking buildings and erecting burning barricades, on the second day of a strike called over a grants dispute and the closure of the city s university. they ransacked public buildings in the centre of the city and set fire to a police post, also attacking the capital s french high school, the lycee la fontaine, which had refused to join the strike. riot police had regained control by around 1:00 p.m. 1200 gmt as the protestors fled their barricades. police arrested numerous demonstrators but no injuries were reported. pupils of all public and private schools in niamey began an indefinite strike monday, calling in particular for the payment of five months worth of overdue grants. the protest is backed by the main educational trade union, usn, which called tuesday in a statement for a greater mobilisation to maintain union action until the demands are met. the riot was the latest in what have become daily disturbances by students upset with the cash strapped government s failure to pay education grants for the past nine months. the government closed niamey university last week because of the unrest.

notes: a student died friday of injuries sustained in campus clashes with niger police that left four other students wounded, students told the official anp news agency. the general secretary of the ueu students union, ousmane abdourahamane, confirmed the report to afp, adding that the fatal casualty, tahirou harouna, 25, was hit right in the face by a teargas canister. four of his colleages were injured, two seriously, abdourahamane added. the police had intervened when several hundred students demonstrated for several hours late thursday in protest against the government s failure to pay grants that had become several months overdue. the police threw tear gas canisters and sought to dismantle barricades of blazing tyres put up by the students, who responded by hurling stones, abdourahamane said. the government of niger agreed late wednesday to study the grievances of students who earlier gave the government 48 hours to punish those responsible for killing a student here last friday. students are also demanding backpayment of grants in arrears since 1992, and an increase in the basis grant to compensate for january s devaluation of the cfa franc. the government had already paid in full the grants owing from last year and the year before, which had cost 2.8 billion cfa francs four million dollars , and would pay grants outstanding for the first trimester by this week, he said.

notes: three people were killed and 38 injured when two niger army soldiers threw grenades into the crowd at a pro tuareg rally at agades, 750 kilometres 470 miles north east of niger s capital niamey, a tuareg leader said sunday. rebel leader mano dayak told afp that the grenades, of which he said there were three, were thrown during a rally organized saturday by the union for democracy and social progress udps , which is essentially a pro tuareg organization. the town is situated deep inside tuareg rebel held territory in the northern central belt of the country which has been the scene of clashes between autonomy seeking rebels and government forces since 1991. a grenade attack killed six people during a rally of tuaregs, the ethnic group seeking greater autonomy in niger, the interior ministry said monday. three more people died of their wounds sunday and monday at a hospital, authorities said. this protest is believed to have at least 100 people, since 36 people were injured; the response is coded as ignore because the killings from the grenade are not clearly from the government.

notes: thousands of muslims gathered in the capital s main mosque and demanded the government halt an aids education and prevention campaign. in the meeting saturday, islamic groups said the radio, television, and poster campaign would encourage adultery, and they threatened to tear down posters that have been put up in villages nationwide. the radio and the television belong to the people of niger, and we will not tolerate the western destruction of the moral and religious codes of our society, said a statement after the meeting. the groups are particularly angered by the campaign s encouragement of the use of condoms to prevent acquired aids. more than 5,000 muslims gathered at the grand mosque in niger s capital yesterday to denounce condoms and the government s anti aids and birth control campaigns. the muslims, who oppose secularization of their 98 per cent muslim country, said promoting the use of condoms to fight aids encourages debauchery among the young. they gave the government what they called a final warning to stop publicizing condom use and also to ban the screening of pornographic films. niger has experienced a surge of muslim fundamentalist protests ranging from the smashing of billboards that promote family planning to attacks on girls in miniskirts.

notes: niger s main human rights movement on wednesday staged a march to back a hunger striker from neighbouring nigeria, who was detained a year ago and accused of masterminding an air hijack. niger police say they suspect him of being behind the hijacking of a nigerian airways aircraft to niamey in october 1993, though he was not aboard the jet when it was diverted from an internal flight. launching his hunger strike, yussuf wrote to top police authorities alleging that he had been physically and mentally tortured in a bid to drive him insane. he stated that he had been beaten by police, deprived of visits and reading materials, and fed like a dog. about 100 demonstrators responded wednesday to the appeal from the anddh, which issued a copy of yussuf s letter, and marched on government buildings in niamey to call for an immediate end to his arbitrary detention .

sources: police use tear gas to break up student protests in niamey agence france presse, january 09, 1997, international news, 147 words ;
notes: police in niger s capital used tear gas thursday to disperse students marching towards parliament in protest against the non payment of grants, witnesses told afp. some students were detained, said the witnesses, who reported no injuries in the incident, which involved around 500 students. police used tear gas grenades to break up the protest as the students approached the parliament building. as well as the payment of several months of grant arrears, the students are also demanding the grants be increased and the conditions for eligibility be revised.

sources: police break up niger protests; three under house arrest agence france presse, january 11, 1997, international news, 604 words police fire tear gas to disperse niger protesters associated press international, january 11, 1997; saturday, international news, 184 words ;
notes: niamey, jan 11 afp police used truncheons and teargas saturday to break up a demonstration mounted by eight opposition parties in niamey, the capital of niger. hours later, three top opposition leaders were put under house arrest in niamey, a source close to the opposition, reached by telephone, told afp s abidjan bureau. police were seen rounding up and arresting dozens of demonstrators after authorities in niamey banned the protest, saying it was subversive. after the demonstration was broken up saturday, protestors scattered through the capital and set fire to car tyres on several crossroads, blocking traffic in the town. issoufou, president of the nigerian party for socialism and democracy, told a private radio station: this struggle is going to continue until democracy is restored. thousands of anti government protesters clashed with riot police saturday who fired tear gas after the demonstrators forced their way past barricades and tried to stage a march. protesters armed with rocks and sticks set up burning barricades of tires and tree branches in the roads, creating massive traffic jams in the capital.

sources: protesters in niamey demand release of opposition trio agence france presse, january 18, 1997, international news, 151 words ;
notes: more than 2,000 people took part saturday in a rally in niger s capital to demand the unconditional release of three opposition leaders who were arrested on tuesday. the rally, organized by women members of the opposition coalition front for the restoration and defense of democracy, had been authorized by the police. niger s president, general ibrahim bare mainassara, announced thursday on national television the release of the main opposition leaders and their supporters.

sources: students take to the streets of niger s capital capital agence france presse english english niger; niger s students demonstrate against rebel activity africa news, november 24, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 763 words, all africa press service ;
notes: thousands of students and schoolchildren took to the streets of niger s capital thursday to press demands for unpaid allowances as well as for more teachers and classroom space. space. riot police were deployed in the town centre and near the university, blocking the path of other students hoping to join the demonstration. the schoolchildren say they need more classrooms because many of the straw huts used have been destroyed by rain and roaming animals. riot police were deployed in the town centre and near the university, blocking the path of other students hoping to join the demonstration. they later stormed the campus, firing tear gas grenades and beating up several students before withdrawing, but leaving 10 students injured, ibrahim saley, a student leader, told newsmen.

sources: niger students demonstrate as teachers resume strike strike agence france presse english english ;
notes: some 1,000 students demonstrated for payment of scholarship arrears in niger s capital monday, while schoolteachers went on strike to demand unpaid backpay. early in the morning, students blocked a key bridge over the niger river, forcing some commuters to make the crossing by canoe and prompting gendarmes to deploy to prevent students reaching the city centre, where president ibrahim bare mainassara was due to inaugurate an exhibition at the national museum.

sources: students protest on anniversary of niger killings agence france presse english ;
notes: students and school pupils on monday gathered in their hundreds in niger s capital to commemorate the gunning down and wounding of several of their number during a pro democracy rally eight years ago. the students and children boycotted classes to meet near niamey s kennedy bridge and shout slogans against successive governments for failing to deal with security force members who shot three students dead and seriously wounded several others on february 9, 1990.

sources: mutinous soldiers hold officers, civilians hostage in niger niger niger agence france presse english english english army mutiny spreads in niger niger niger agence france presse english english english army mutiny spreads in niger, new hostages taken taken taken agence france presse english english english ;
notes: mutinous soldiers in eastern niger have taken several officers and civilian officials hostage, travellers from the region said here monday. among those held by soldiers who mutinied in the diffa region saturday to protest their living and working conditions were the deputy commander of the region and senior local administrative officials, the same sources said. the mutinous soldiers arrived saturday in diffa region, 1,150 kilometers 720 miles east of niamey, the sources said. the hostages were being held in a military camp in bosso, near the chadian border, the sources said. a high level military delegation was due to travel to diffa to negotiate with the mutineers, but bad weather prevented their aircraft taking off, informed sources in the capital said. residents of diffa, where the soldiers imposed a curfew tuesday night, said calm had returned although three gunshots were heard in the town s barracks an hour after the curfew began. the mutineers in diffa, located 1,150 kilometers 720 miles east of niamey, on wednesday released three of at least four civilian officials and army officers they had held since saturday, tounkara said. speaking from diffa, home to some 20,000 people, a civil servant said: residents were very frightened tuesday evening and laid low after sunset. given that soldiers were able to take over a region of 20000, this protest is assumed to have at least 50 soldiers participating. aside from their salary demands, the mutineers in diffa want two of their superior officers to be relocated. mutineers in diffa, 1,150 kilometers 720 miles east of niamey, who rose up a week ago, on saturday freed two civilian hostages; the sub prefect of diffa and secretary general of the prefecture, whom they had been holding since the start of the rebellion, informed sources in diffa said. however the mutineers were still holding three superior officers, namely the diffa battalion commander, a captain and the commander of the nr.3 defence zone based in zinder, who was seized after going to diffa with money to pay wage arrears. this protest is recorded as ending on march 1st because it seems to go past february 28th, but does not have a clear end date; the fact that they released many hostages on the 28th implies that the protest ended soon after.

sources: army mutiny spreads in niger niger niger agence france presse english english english soldiers in two niger garrisons end mutiny: prefect prefect prefect agence france presse english english english ;
notes: soldiers in northern niger mutinied wednesday in apparent solidarity with army colleagues who at the weekend took control of an area in the far east to demand settlement of back pay. gunshots were heard in agadez, where mutineers seized the region s prefect, lieutenant colonel mai manga oumara, and two other officers, defence minister yahaya tounkara said in the capital. the mutineers in agadez, located 750 kilometers 470 miles northeast of the capital, joined colleagues in diffa, n gourti, bosso and n guima, near the borders with chad and nigeria, who since saturday had been demanding back pay settlements and other allowances. the mutiny has strong support across the country, implying that there were likely at least 50 soldiers participating. troops in two of at least four mutinous garrisons in niger ended their protest and released five hostages friday after military authorities paid some of the salary arrears that fuelled the uprising, one of the freed hostages told afp. the mutineers demands, which were purely material, have been met, said oumar, who added that a curfew imposed by the soldiers in agadez had been lifted. the national press agency reported officers from the capital had delivered half of four months of salary arrears as well as other allowances to the troops.

sources: army mutiny spreads in niger, new hostages taken taken taken agence france presse english english english niger garrisons end mutiny, free most hostages hostages hostages agence france presse english english english ;
notes: an army mutiny in the impoverished former french african colony of niger spread thursday to the country s second city zinder where soldiers demanding back pay stormed a radio station. also thursday, disgruntled soldiers took three new hostages in the northern mining centre of arlit. soldiers in zinder, a regional army command centre 750 kilometers 470 miles east of the capital, niamey, stormed a radio station to press demands for settlement of four months unpaid wages and imposed a dusk to dawn curfew on the city, where residents reported gunshots in the morning. mutinous troops in a southeastern niger military command centre ended their uprising saturday and released four hostages as they began receiving half of the salary arrears which fuelled their protest, an official there told afp. a military official said the mutineers in zinder, 750 kilometers 470 miles east of the capital, had returned to their barracks and that calm had returned to the previously panic striken town. it was not clear, however, whether the backpay demands of gendarmes who joined the protest were being met. given that soldiers were able to take over the second largest city in the country, this protest is assumed to have at least 50 participants.

sources: several injured in clash at political rally in northern niger agence france presse english report: police, demonstrators clash in niger s fourth city associated press international, april 13, 1998; monday, international news, 256 words ;
notes: several people were seriously injured monday in northern niger during a violent clash between opposition militants and security forces at a political rally, the opposition charged. there were several serious injuries and many arrests in the incident in tahoua, 400 kilometers 250 miles northeast of here, a local opposition official told the private radio station r and m broadcast from niamey. demonstrators took several security officers hostage demanding the release of their arrested colleagues, the spokesman said. the official said the eight parties belonging to the opposition coalition, the front for the restoration and defense of democracy frdd , organized the rally calling for the resignation of president ibrahim bare mainassara. several policemen and civilians were reportedly injured and several arrests were made during the clashes in tahoua, about 550 kilometers 330 miles northeast of the capital, the radio station known as rm fm said monday. the protesters were demanding the ouster of nigerien president ibrahim bare mainassara, the radio station said citing anonymous government officials. due to the several people being injured as well as the number of opposition parties in the coalition, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people participating.

sources: several injured in niger as police clash with protesters agence france presse english ;
notes: several people were injured saturday in the southern niger town of maradi as security forces used teargas to break up an opposition demonstration, corroborating sources said. the demonstrators in the town, 550 kilometers 340 miles east of the capital, were carrying clubs and slingshots, placed burning tyres on several crossroads and ransacked several kiosks, the sources said. since last weekend, niger s opposition has held demonstrations across the country, calling for mainassara s resignation. given widespread opposition support, the several people injured, and the police response, this protest is believed to have at least 50 participants.

sources: opposition militants hold new demonstrations in niger agence france presse english the washington post, opposition to niger s leader turns violent, april 20, 1998, monday, final edition, a section; pg. a14; world in brief: africa, 120 words ;
notes: opposition militants in niger barricaded roads with flaming tires, tree trunks and electricity pylons sunday in the towns of zinder and maradi, state radio reported. in zinder in the center, the country s second city, the demonstrators set fire to the headquarters of president ibrahim bare mainassara s rally for democracy and progress party rdp . in maradi in the south, demonstrators jostled rdp officials there for an afternoon meeting, including party secretary general colonel abdulrahaman saidou, whose bodyguard was injured and hospitalized, the radio said. several people were injured in maradi on saturday when police used teargas to break up an opposition demonstration. sources said the demonstrators, carrying clubs and slingshots, placed burning tyres on several crossroads and ransacked kiosks. opposition activists took to the streets of niger s second largest city, zinder, setting fire to a police station and to the regional headquarters of the ruling party, officials said. in the town of maradi, supporters of an eight party alliance demanding the resignation of president col. ibrahim bare mainassara ransacked buildings, built barricades and burned tires during a turbulent weekend. but officials and witnesses said the ruling rally for democracy and progress proceeded with a meeting there in support of mainassara, protected by a heavy police turnout. this protest is believed to have at least 50 participants due to the levels of violence and the widespread opposition support.

sources: niger police break up opposition demonstration in niamey agence france presse english afr: political violence flares in niger capital aap newsfeed, april 27, 1998, monday, nationwide general news; overseas news, 140 words the washington post, anti government protests held in niger, april 27, 1998, monday, final edition, a section; pg. a12; world in brief: africa, 51 words ;
notes: security forces on sunday broke up an opposition demonstration in several working class parts of niger s capital niamey, witnesses told afp. private radio said clashes between protesters and security forces left several injured, adding that many arrests were made. street protests have been held over the past two weeks demanding the resignation of president ibrahim bare mainassara. opposition militants set up barricades of burning tyres at major streets in niamey today in a flare up of political violence in the niger capital, witnesses said. paramilitary police fired teargas at several locations to break up groups of demonstrators protesting at the rule of president ibrahim bare mainassara, they said. police chased and arrested several protesters. an unknown number of people were wounded, the witnesses added.

sources: opposition holds rally in niger agence france presse english ;
notes: opponents of president ibrahim bare mainassare in niger, one of the world s poorest countries, staged the latest in a series of protest rallies in the second city of zinder on saturday. demonstrators built barricades of burning tyres and tree trunks to block roads in the city but refrained from attacking property, and police did not intervene, a local official said. the rally was the latest to be organised by the front for the restoration and defence of democracy, an opposition umbrella group. the group has organised a wave of protests since mid april, some of which have turned violent.

sources: troops seize ivory coast s second city in pay protest agence france presse english, january 6, 2017 friday 8:08 pm gmt, 654 words;

sources: gunfire in abidjan as ivory coast mutiny spreads agence france presse english, january 7, 2017 saturday 5:45 pm gmt, 738 words;
notes: shots rang out at a military base in abidjan on saturday as a mutiny by disgruntled troops appeared to spread to ivory coast s economic capital despite government efforts to defuse the crisis. the widening unrest came after troops seized control of bouake, the country s second city, firing rocket launchers in the streets in an angry protest over pay. the unrest erupted in the early hours of friday morning with troops demanding hefty pay rises, and the protests quickly spread to other cities, including man in the west.

sources: social discontent grips ivory coast as economic gains pass many by international new york times, march 28, 2017 tuesday, world, 1056 words, sean lyngaas;
notes: hundreds of students like mr. bamba took to the streets in january, according to local news reports, to protest the halt in classes, angry over the possibility of putting off a diploma and a ticket to earning a living. the workers grievances include overdue back pay, poor retirement conditions, and limited freedom for unions. the government has addressed most of those concerns, but there is still the core issue of more than 400 million in back pay the workers say they are owed.

protesteridentity: soldiers at a number of ivory coast s military bases
sources: shots fired in army dispute; around the world, daily mirror, may 13, 2017 saturday, news; pg. 12, 44 words; ivory coast soldiers revolt over pay dispute, the washington post, may 13, 2017 saturday, a section; pg. a10, 417 words, reuters; ivory coast soldiers mutiny, blockading a city, the new york times, may 14, 2017 sunday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 14, 584 words, by reuters; ivory coast sends forces to quash a violent military mutiny, the new york times, may 15, 2017 monday, section ; column 0; foreign desk; pg. , 613 words, by sean lyngaas;
notes: soldiers at a number of ivory coast s military bases have been firing into the air and blocking streets in several cities in protest over a pay dispute. heavy gunfire was heard in the commercial capital abidjan amid the dispute over delayed bonuses pledged by the state. oldiers left their barracks and blocked streets in several towns and cities across ivory coast on friday, including the commercial capital, firing gunshots into the air as their protest over a pay dispute gathered momentum. the soldiers were revolting over delayed bonus payments, promised by the government after a nationwide mutiny in january but which it has struggled to pay following a collapse in the price of cocoa, ivory coast s main export. on thursday, a spokesman for 8,400 soldiers who took part in the january rebellion had said they would forgo demands for more money after meeting with authorities in abidjan. that s not what they were meant to say, said one leader of the january mutiny who had remained in bouake and spoke on the condition of anonymity, referring to the thursday statement. in bouak , soldiers fired on a group of demobilized former rebels, seriously wounding one of them, according to their spokesman and a local lawmaker. sgt. seydou kone, a spokesman for the mutineers, said the former rebels, who went through a disarmament program after the country s 2011 civil war, were planning their own protest, as they did earlier in the week, and his men had opened fire to stop them. we do not want to negotiate with anyone, sergeant kone said by phone from bouak , in the center of the country. we re also ready to fight if we are attacked. we have nothing to lose. a standoff between mutineers and security forces took place friday in abidjan, the country s commercial capital. mutineers also took to the streets in the northern cities of korhogo and odienne, among others, according to residents. tensions remain high in korhogo, but the other two cities were calm as the weekend ended. note: the actual number of protesters was not provided in the sources, and is based on prior coding decisions.

location: Grand Bassam, a beach resort town near Abidjan
protesteridentity: demonstrators demanding the release of election results
sources: police teargas protesters demanding i.coast election results, agence france presse english, october 15, 2018 monday 11:16 am gmt, 340 words, abidjan, oct 15 2018
notes: riot police fired teargas overnight to break up crowds of demonstrators demanding the release of results from a tense weekend election in ivory coast, a candidate and witnesses said. a number of people were injured during the incident which occurred overnight in grand bassam, a beach resort town near ivory coast s main city abidjan and followed a day of tension over saturday s elections that were marred by clashes which left one man dead. people had gathered outside the police headquarters to demand that the results be declared, georges ezaley told afp, a candidate with the ivory coast democratic party pdci . at around 1:00 am, the police broke up the crowd by firing tear gas, many people were wounded, mainly older people, he said, his words confirmed by a local resident. the people were surrounding the police headquarters to wait for the results, they were teargassed, the resident said, speaking on condition of anonymity. the results were validated on sunday morning by the independent electoral commission and signed off by the representatives of all the candidates but by sunday evening, they still hadn t announced them, ezaley said. by monday morning, the results had still not been published. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: demonstrators organized by ceeci, the national students union, protesting a violent attack by prison guards on students at a nearby university
sources: i.coast pupils protest at prison guard assault on campus, agence france presse english, november 30, 2018 friday 4:14 pm gmt, 328 wordsbouak , ivory coast, nov 30 2018
notes: schools in ivory coast s second city remained closed again on friday in protest over a violent attack by prison guards on students at a nearby university. at least eight students were wounded on wednesday evening, five of them by gunfire, when a group of prison wardens invaded a campus in bouake and opened fire following a scuffle in a bar, the city prosecutor said. ceeci, the national students union, put the figure at 11, saying some of them had been shot while other had sustained injuries from knives or machetes . following the violence, the organisation blocked classes at two high schools and a number of primary schools, urging pupils to join them in a protest which extended into friday. ceeci is demanding the government relocate bouake prison and its wardens lodgings which are situated opposite a campus of alassane ouattara university in the western part of the city. we have ordered the students and school children to go home. classes will resume on monday, ceeci head moustapha ben diomande said on friday. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to the issuing of an arrest warrant for ex rebel leader and presidential hopeful guillaume soro
sources: ivory coast issues arrest warrant for presidential candidate, associated press international, december 24, 2019 tuesday 8:37 am gmt, international news, 315 words, alexis adele, associated press, abidjan, ivory coast
notes: abidjan, ivory coast ap authorities in ivory coast have issued an arrest warrant for guillaume soro, prompting the ex rebel leader and presidential hopeful to divert his plane to another country instead of returning home. the arrest warrant is certain to escalate political tensions ahead of the 2020 election in the west african nation. soro s supporters took to the streets monday to protest and police used tear gas on them. soro, who served as prime minister from 2007 to 2012, had planned to return home after more than six months abroad. public prosecutor adou richard announced on state television monday night that soro was accused of presumption of an attack on state security, without giving details. soro also is suspected of embezzling public funds and money laundering, richard said. the charges were announced hours after several of soro s top associates were detained by security forces following a news conference in abidjan. arresting soro won t resolve the problem, the crisis in ivory coast, said soro supporter bernard koffi. on the contrary, it makes the crisis worse because we don t know what wrong he is supposed to have done. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: two demonstrators die and 30 wounded as riot police move in agence france presse english, 347 words death toll from opposition protests mount to 12 agence france presse english, 574 words guinea opposition charges 63 killed, hundreds wounded in protests associated press worldstream, october 06, 1993, wednesday, international news, 352 words ;
notes: conakry, sept 28 afp two demonstrators were killed and about 30 others wounded tuesday when riot police tried to prevent a political protest from taking place, opposition parties here said. the deaths resulted from bullet wounds, they added. witnesses said there had been numerous arrests and several policemen were also wounded, although official figures have not yet been released. mamadi mara, the president of the national democratic forum, a grouping of about 30 opposition parties, said riot police tried to stop the demonstrationtaking place. the protest in guinea s capital was one of a series of demonstrations demanding that a transitional government of national unity be set up. witnesses said the police lined up at conakry s market and stadium the protest venue and let off tear gas and sprayed the crowd with water after demonstrators hurled stones at them. police reinforcements patrolled outlying conakry streets and shops failed to open thursday as hospital staff said the death toll from two days of anti government protests had risen to 12. more than 70 people were hurt as security forces cracked down tuesday and wednesday on opposition demonstrators and rioters, medical staff said. eight of those hospitalised died overnight wednesday. guinea s ruler, gen. lansana conte, has said that 18 people died and 198 were injured in three days of protests last week in conakry, the capital.

sources: world in brief soldier stabbed the globe and mail canada , december 20, 1993 monday, 106 words, reut ;
notes: conakry opposition militants protesting against guinea s presidential election yesterday stabbed a soldier to death in the capital, the interior ministry said. journalists said at least three civilians were killed in clashes between the opposition and supporters of the ruling party in this west african country. the opposition had urged president lansana conte to postpone guinea s first multiparty election, but when its plea fell on deaf ears it vowed to disrupt the poll. witnesses said polling stations in conakry s hafiya district were burned down saturday night and those in sangoya and cig madina were attacked yesterday morning. reuter

sources: ten dead in clashes during guinea teachers strike agence france presse english, june 12, 2006 monday 6:17 pm gmt, 498 words ;
notes: ? seven of the dead, most of them students according to witnesses, were killed in the capital and three died in the northern town of labe, some 400 kilometres 250 miles north of conakry, all from live ammunition fired by the military. several others were wounded, various witnesses contacted by afp said, as an indefinite nationwide industrial action called by the country s largest unions entered its its fifth day. the government of president lansana conte last week warned that while it would not forbid a mass work stoppage over rising poverty called by trade unions, it would deal mercilessly with any troublemakers during the strike action.? ? ? witnesses in the capital said that five people there had died after a soldier from guinea s presidential guard unit opened fire on a crowd in enta suburb. opposition leader sydya toure told afp that two others were killed in bixinn suburb of conakry. earlier in the day police and military had used fired tear gas to disperse angry high school students who tried to stage street protests after the teachers strike had kept them from sitting their final exams. students barricaded streets with school desks, chairs and tyres outside the largest examination centre in conakry s kipe suburb, then tried to march on conte s palace downtown. clashes between students and police were also reported in labe town, where tear gas was used to crush the demonstrations. in pita some 350 kilometres 220 miles north of the capital, restive students raided the local education authority s office and threw documents onto the streets, according to witnesses reached by telephone.? ? ? baccalauret examinations, the final pre university tests, did not start despite promises by the education minister that they would go ahead despite the job stoppage.? ?

notes: the number of protestors grew as the protesting continued. beginning in the hundreds, it made its way into the thousands. originally there was crowd dispersal and arrests. as the protesting continued, shootings and killings occurred. by the 23rd, the unions were in talks with the government. however, since the protesting continued, the other actions did as well. by the 24, it appeared the violence had ended. finally, on the 26, streets were calm again. therefore, i code that the protesting ended on the 25. ? police fought demonstrators and made dozens of arrests monday in guinea s capital conakry as a general strike launched last week against president lansana conte turned violent. armed police and gendarmes fired tear gas at protestors who threw stones at them and put up barricades in the simbaya, dar es salam and bambeto districts of the capital. several dozen protesters were taken into custody. the demonstrators later dispersed, leaving the three neighbourhoods of the port city largely deserted, while the business and administrative quarter was also mainly empty.? ? ? police fired tear gas monday into a crowd of several hundred protesters demanding the president of this tiny west african nation step down. it marked the fourth day of a strike in the guinean capital, sparked by president lansana conte s decision to halt the trial of two men accused of stealing millions of dollars euros from the state.? ? ? one person was killed and several wounded when police in guinea fired on protesters thursday on the ninth day of a general strike against president lansana conte s rule, medical workers said. a young man was killed by gunfire when police dispersed demonstrators at mamou, 280 kilometres 175 miles east of conakry, a health official told afp, without giving further details. in similar circumstances, five people sustained gunshot wounds, including a nine year old girl, in suburbs of the west african country s capital, guinean red cross official mamadou samba doumbaya said? ? ? witnesses in kissidougou said several thousand people joined a rally before it was broken up, and residents reported a similar demonstration in kankan.? ? ? in spite of the crackdown, thousands of people held protest marches in towns across the west african country, where 20 deaths have now been reported in nearly two weeks of the third mass strike in 12 months.? ? ? guinea s embattled leaders resumed crisis talks with the labour movement, in the absence of ailing president lansana conte, a day after a bloody repression of anti conte protests. conte had been expected at scheduled emergency talks with labour leaders behind a crippling strike aimed at removing him from office, but a union official said the president instead sent his wife henriette to ask the unions to return to negotiations.? ? ? police let the peaceful march in kankan proceed, just four days after the security forces shot dead 34 demonstrators in a crackdown on rallies and during running battles in conakry s suburbs, where some youths were armed with stones.? ? ? the streets of the guinean capital conakry were calm friday following protests earlier in the week,? ?

sources: fresh violence in guinea agence france presse english, february 9, 2007 friday 8:36 pm gmt, 477 words, mouctar bah ;
notes: ? fresh violence wracked guinea on friday as thousands of protesters went on the rampage in the north of the country calling for embattled president lansana conte to step down. the strikers set up barricades on the streets, overpowered police, torched two police stations and freed prisoners days ahead of a deadline for conte to name a new prime minister or face a repeat of the recent general strike. there were 11 injured, one by gunfire, during clashes between demonstrators and security forces, a red cross official told afp by telephone from duinguiraye, 400 kilometres 250 miles northeast of conakry. ? a resident of duinguiraye said that there were between 3,000 and 4,000 people on the streets on friday. police attempted to disperse the crowd by firing teargas but were overwhelmed by the sheer number of demonstrators in the town, the resident said.? ?

notes: since the clashes were large enough to shut down the markets, and the violence was seen in a variety of towns across guinea, this is coded as 50 and national while there is no direct evidence of crowd dispersal via tear gas or batons, the fact that there were clashes leads me to believe that there was an attempt to get the protesters to dissolve their demonstration. clashes occurred in conakry and other towns between police and demonstrators who saw the unexplained dismissal of minister and government spokesman justin morel junior late thursday as a move against prime minister lansana kouyate. no to a return to the old ways. we don t want corruption back, youthful protesters shouted in parts of the west african country s capital, where they burned tyres, barricaded suburbs and fought police who used tear gas, an afp journalist reported. the violence led to the closure of conakry s central madina market. residents reached at nzerekore in the southeast and kankan, the main eastern town, told afp of similar disturbances and market closures in those towns. the situation was calm throughout the country on saturday.

sources: guinea vows to pay protesting soldiers back wages agence france presse english, may 27, 2008 tuesday 6:45 pm gmt, 374 words, mouctar bah rebel guinea soldiers wound top officer agence france presse english, may 27, 2008 tuesday 8:26 am gmt, 60 words guinea soldiers stage fresh revolt over unpaid wages agence france presse english, may 27, 2008 tuesday 3:02 am gmt, 437 words guinea president meets soldiers to end crisis: military source agence france presse english, may 30, 2008 friday 7:57 pm gmt, 274 words guinea mutiny reveals rift between top brass and ordinary soldiers agence france presse english, june 5, 2008 thursday 3:22 pm gmt, 562 words, malick rokhy ba ;
notes: since there were clashes, it appears that the presidential guard was trying to disperse the protesting soldiers. following the demands formulated by the soldiers, the government has decided on the following measures: the gradual payment of 5 million guinean francs 785 euros, 1,234 dollars per person, the government said in a statement. ? the dismissal of kouyate was one of the soldiers grievances, as they said they had nobody to address their grievances since his departure from office. soldiers demanding the payment of years of wage arrears shot and wounded a top officer during protests in the guinea capital, military sources said tuesday. the officer was named as major korka diallo, who is in charge of military finances. the protesting soldiers have captured the army s chief of staff and took to the streets of conakry on monday. gunfire was also heard for the first time since the protests started in kindia, 130 kilometres 80 miles further inland, which houses one of the country s biggest army garrisons it was the first meeting between conte and the soldiers since the start of the payprotest, which has since grown to include other demands, including the departure of top generals military sources on friday said 10 people were injured on both sides in fighting on thursday, when protesting soldiers clashed with the presidential guard. thursday marked the first clash between soldiers and the presidential guard, which is loyal to conte, since the start of the protests. the first payments came on may 30 and since that time the protests have died down. each soldier is set to get one million guinean francs about 146 euros, 226 dollars quickly. in total they are owed some five million guinean francs per soldier and the rest is due to be paid gradually, the government promised.

sources: guinea police take superiors hostage in pay protest: agence france presse english, june 16, 2008 monday 11:27 pm gmt, 451 words, mouctar bah soldiers fire into the air in response to guinea police strike associated press international, june 17, 2008 tuesday 1:17 pm gmt, international news, 239 words, by maseco conde, associated press writer guinea soldiers attack police camp to end strike associated press international, june 17, 2008 tuesday 9:07 pm gmt, international news, 368 words, by maseco conde, associated press writer guinea calm after soldiers put down police strike associated press international, june 18, 2008 wednesday 11:29 am gmt, international news, 244 words, by maseco conde, associated press writer more than 10 killed in guinea unrest: rights group agence france presse english, june 19, 2008 thursday 2:41 pm gmt, 304 words guinea military chiefs hold emergency meeting on police strike the associated press, june 19, 2008 thursday 12:18 pm gmt, international news, 369 words, by maseco conde, associated press writer ;
notes: originally, the government did not respond to the striking police. by the 17, the soldiers of the government shot into the air as a way of quieting the police. ? guinean police officers took a dozen of their superiors hostage in the capital conakry on monday as part of a pay protest, officials said, just a week after a deadly pay protests by soldiers. as long as our demands are not met, we will not free them, an angry police officer told afp. the new protests came amid increasing political uncertainty in guinea and heightened social tension over rising food prices in the poor west african country.? ? our chiefs told us to open up the roads where police are striking, said ahmadou sylla, a member of the army s paramilitary police force. the gunfire is our way of dissuading our striking comrades. soldiers in guinea attacked the main police base the capital tuesday to put down a two day strike by police officers protesting poor working conditions and low pay, witnesses said. an associated press reporter who toured the base after shooting on both sides saw the body of one uniformed policeman. a truck carried the corpse to a local morgue. the overall number of casualties was not known but at least seven people were treated for gunshot wounds at a hospital, medical official aminata toure said. a dozen police vehicles were riddled with bullet holes. the city was calm wednesday, and there was no sign of police on the city s roads wednesday, but the strike appeared unresolved. soldiers arrested 100 policemen during clashes and took them to an army camp, but on thursday police sources said all the officers taken were released. military chiefs held emergency meetings thursday in guinea to resolve grievances with striking police and other security officers, officials said.

sources: anti junta demonstrators battle police in guinea agence france presse english, august 27, 2009 thursday 3:35 pm gmt, 361 words guinea police use tear gas on anti coup protesters associated press international, august 27, 2009 thursday 6:21 pm gmt, international news, 102 words ;
notes: youths urging guinea s junta leader to stand down immediately after elections next year held a demonstration thursday in conakry, which led to violent clashes with police and paramilitary gendarmes. a new group calling itself the dadis must go movement in reference to junta chief captain moussa dadis camara marched with placards, burned tyres and threw stones on the le prince boulevard leading from the inner suburbs to the city centre. we want the leader of the putschists to quit power after the elections of january 2010, in which he can t be a candidate, one of the demonstrators told afp. the protesters demanded that camara does not stand as a candidate in the elections and also called on his junta colleagues in the national council for democracy and development cndd to abstain in the polls. at least two people were slightly hurt, one by a stone and the other by a riot baton, and police made about a dozen arrests, including that of a local television reporter, according to journalists at the protest. the demonstrators also caused a huge traffic jam before police and gendarmes dispersed them and chased them into the suburbs of hamdallaye and dar es salam. in conakry, the capital, on sunday, groups of young men burned tires and blocked traffic. some shouted dadis must go! before they were dispersed by police.

sources: guinea anti junta rally outside us embassy agence france presse english, august 30, 2009 sunday 5:56 pm gmt, 272 words ;

sources: guinean capital paralyzed in opposition protest xinhua general news service, february 18, 2013 monday 12:03 am est, world news; political, 236 words ;
notes: due to the peacefulness of the protest, there was no response by the government other than to ignore it. additionally, since the capital was more or less shut down, and the protest was supported by three opposition parties, i conclude it is at least greater than 50 people the guinean capital conakry was paralyzed on monday morning amid the protest called by the west african country s opposition parties. local schools and most of businesses were shut down. the transport sector was affected by the demonstration that began at around 9:00 a.m. local time gmt . the protest was launched by three opposition parties including the alliance for democracy and progress adp , the association of parties for finalization of the transition and the club of republicans cdr . president conde later approved the march by the opposition in protest against dysfunction of the national independent electoral commission ahead of the may 12 legislative elections.

sources: policeman killed, 51 hurt in guinea pre poll clashes agence france presse english, september 23, 2013 monday 2:04 pm gmt, 538 words ;
notes: opposition protesters shot dead a trainee policeman and wounded two other officers as renewed violence broke out monday in guinea s capital conakry, five days ahead of elections, the government said. the demonstrators opened fire as the police were breaking through one of numerous barricades put up across the city as the anti government protestsspiralled out of control, an administration spokesman said in a statement. hundreds of teenage activists from the main opposition union of democratic forces of guinea barricaded roads and pelted police vehicles with rocks in the latest clashes, shouting revenge , an afp journalist witnessed.

sources: opposition supporters detained in guinea the associated press, october 8, 2013 tuesday 05:41 pm gmt, international news, 142 words ;
notes: a security official in guinea says 30 young opposition supporters have been detained for staging an unsanctioned protest against alleged irregularities during the country s legislative elections. alpha barry, spokesman for a special elections related security force, said the demonstrators gathered tuesday to denounce the disappearance of a ballot box in conakry s administrative district where the office of the president is located.

sources: guinea police disperse opposition protest the associated press, november 16, 2013 saturday 02:29 pm gmt, international news, 133 words ;
notes: guinean riot police fired tear gas to disperse opposition activists protesting the supreme court s confirmation that the ruling party won the country s divisive elections. police lieutenant facinet kouyate told the associated press that police responded friday night to stone throwing demonstrators protesting the court s decision that president alpha conde s party won 53 of 114 parliamentary seats. the clashes occurred in conakry s hamdallaye neighborhood, an opposition stronghold.

sources: teen protester shot dead by guinea police: father agence france presse english, november 25, 2013 monday 5:41 pm gmt, 325 words ;
notes: police shot dead a teenage protester on monday as an anti government demonstration flared into violence, according to medical sources and relatives. the 19 year old was hit by a bullet to the neck fired by a police officer in the west african nation s capital conakry, his father mamadou dian barry told afp. at least 17 civilians were wounded, including four by gunshots. they have been sent to three hospitals, alimou souare, a doctor treating some of the protesters, told afp. he said other protesters had suffered broken ribs or had been kicked and beaten by batons.

sources: thousands protest after youth beaten to death in guinea agence france presse english, december 16, 2013 monday 4:37 pm gmt, 300 words;
notes: at least two people, including a law enforcement officer, were killed on monday when thousands of demonstrators marched in guinea against the death of a youth said beaten by police, witnesses and medical sources told afp. the police used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, opening fire on looters and injuring around 20 people, many of whom sustained gunshot wounds, according to hospital officials contacted by afp. large crowds gathered in the streets and hundreds of youths ransacked and set fire to a police station, killing an officer, national police spokesman mamadou alpha barry told afp. one civilian victim was declared dead after apparently having been shot, one source said, while several others were seriously wounded.

sources: guinea opposition calls for anyone but conde agence france presse english, january 22, 2015 thursday 6:57 pm gmt, 316 words;

sources: one dead, several injured by gunfire in guinea anti government protests agence france presse english, april 13, 2015 monday 11:01 pm gmt, 797 words several protesters shot in guinea riots agence france presse english, april 13, 2015 monday 6:32 pm gmt, 781 words;
notes: one protester was killed and several others shot and wounded monday as guinean police battled to control violent demonstrations in the capital conakry against the regime of president alpha conde. rioting broke out around 9:30 am 0930 gmt in several suburbs including simbaya and hamdallaye, with protesters throwing stones and setting fire to tyres as the police responded with tear gas. at least seven youths were treated for gunshot wounds, according to the opposition, which had called for the demonstrations against a lack of stability it blames on conde s government. earlier, a hospital doctor speaking on condition of anonymity said the security forces had shot three protesters during clashes in hamdallaye guinea s opposition boycotted parliament in march in protest over the timetable for a presidential election, accusing conde of using the ebola epidemic as an excuse to postpone voting.

sources: guinean capital rocked by second day of violent protests agence france presse english, april 14, 2015 tuesday 5:08 pm gmt, 579 words;

notes: more than 20 people were wounded monday in clashes between anti government protesters and police in guinea, the opposition said, as the regime of president alpha conde clamped down on nationwide demonstrations. clashes broke out between youths and security forces in the capital conakry as demonstrators burned tyres and threw stones at police, who responded with tear gas, witnesses said. the opposition has recorded 26 injured, around a dozen by gunshots, spokesman mamadou mouctar diallo told afp, accusing police of looting homes.

sources: clashes, protests hit guinea over vote timing agence france presse english, may 7, 2015 thursday 10:52 pm gmt, 339 words;

sources: rape video prompts outcry in guinea agence france presse english, november 4, 2015 wednesday 7:18 pm gmt, 266 words;

sources: guinea media seeks justice for journalist killed in clashes agence france presse english, february 8, 2016 monday 4:56 pm gmt, 309 words;
notes: hundreds of people joined a march in conakry monday in memory of journalist el hadj mohamed diallo who was shot dead last week in clashes outside the offices of an opposition party. five media associations called for justice and a press free day on tuesday in honour of diallo who died on friday after receiving a bullet to the chest in the capital conakry. the four hour march by some 300 journalists, civil representatives and ordinary citizens took place without incident and ended up in front of the justice ministry building. the protesters demanded justice for diallo, who worked for the private guinee7 news website and the weekly l independant.

sources: at least half million people join guinea opposition protest agence france presse english, august 16, 2016 tuesday 7:04 pm gmt, 305 words police in guinea break up demonstration, killing 1 person associated press international, august 16, 2016 tuesday 9:11 pm gmt, international news, 140 words;

protesteridentity: teachers and opposition parties demanding results from municipal council elections
sources: in guinea, wave of protests leaves at least 11 dead, the new york times , march 14, 2018 wednesday 19:30 est, world; africa, 649 words, jaime yaya barry;
notes: a wave of unrest in the west african nation of guinea has left at least 11 people dead as protesters have poured into the streets nearly every day over several weeks to demand raises for teachers and the results of long awaited municipal elections. thousands have turned out for demonstrations in conakry, guinea s capital, and other major cities, and security forces have responded with tear gas and tanks. violence has broken out at several rallies, and several journalists and news media outlets have been attacked. the 11 victims include a police officer, amnesty international said. some people died of gunshot wounds, according to local news media reports, and the police officer was killed after being hit in the head with a rock. this year, nationwide demonstrations by teachers seeking better pay had closed schools for five weeks. on wednesday, the teachers suspended their protests after getting government assurances that their salaries would be increased. millimouno fara boka, a teachers union member, said the sheer volume of protesters mothers and students had joined in the demonstrations had proved persuasive to the government. mariama magasouba, 38, a mother of four, said she had joined in the demonstrations because she was tired of seeing her children sitting at home. schools reopened on wednesday, though many teachers and students did not return to class immediately, fearful because of the other protests still going on. most of those rallies are led by opposition parties demanding results from municipal council elections held last month. president alpha cond s party is claiming victory, but the official winners have not been announced, and opposition party members say they suspect fraud. note: the actual start date of the event was not provided in the source, and is determined by the description of the start of the event provided in the source

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to a 25 percent hike in oil prices

notes: a 22 year old man was killed on tuesday on the second day of protests in the guinean capital conakry, concurring sources said. ibrahima bah, from the dalaba region, was shot dead in the conakry suburb of ratoma, relative elhadj saikou told afp. he was shot in the chest by a member of the anti crime squad bac , he said. police spokesman boubacar kasse confirmed the death but said he did not know the circumstances surrounding it. after the body was transferred to a conakry hospital, tension mounted in ratoma as youths hurled stones at the security forces, who replied with teargas. five people were arrested on monday, the first day of a two day campaign aimed at bringing conakry to a standstill. security minister alpha ibrahima keira said on state television rts that instructions had been given to the security forces to act firmly. the protests were sparked by disputed local elections on february 4 that opposition leaders condemned as fraudulent. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters claiming that president alpha conde s government has reneged on a deal to install new officials elected in the contested february 4 municipal ballot
sources: guinea police fire tear gas on banned demo in conakry, agence france presse english, october 23, 2018 tuesday 4:31 pm gmt, 355 words, conakry, oct 23 2018
notes: guinea police clashed with hundreds of youths tuesday in the capital conakry and the opposition leader claimed his car was shot at during a banned rally over disputed elections. they wanted to assassinate me, cellou dalien diallo claimed after he said his vehicle was hit by a police bullet as he was on his way to the protest. after protesters attempted to block traffic in conakry s cosa district, they lobbed stones in clashes with police who responded with tear gas, an afp reporter said. tensions have been high in the poor west african country since the death on october 16 of a protester during a two day campaign aimed at bringing conakry to a standstill. diallo, a former prime minister and key opponent of president alpha conde, accused the gendarmerie of targeting his vehicle. afp could not immediately confirm police had fired live rounds. a police spokesman declined comment when asked by afp about diallo s allegations. the opposition on monday had urged supporters to go ahead with the protest despite a ban by local authorities citing safety concerns for schools in the area. the opposition claims conde s government has reneged on a deal to install new officials elected in the contested february 4 municipal ballot, the first such vote since the end of a military dictatorship a decade ago.

protesteridentity: protesters against opposition leader cellou dalein diallo s claims that his car was struck by a police bullet a day earlier during a banned rally over disputed municipal elections
sources: at least 30 hurt in guinea clashes: medical source, witnesses, agence france presse english, october 24, 2018 wednesday 5:04 pm gmt, 382 words, conakry, oct 24 2018
notes: at least 30 people were injured in clashes between opposition supporters and security forces in central guinea, medical sources and witnesses said on wednesday, after an opposition leader said his car was hit by gunfire a day earlier. opposition leader cellou dalein diallo, a chief rival of president alpha conde, on tuesday said his vehicle was struck by a police bullet during a banned rally in the capital conakry over disputed municipal elections. police denied diallo s allegations, but a teenager was later killed during clashes between opposition youths and police in the capital. his family said he had been shot by police. protests erupted on wednesday after a meeting of diallo s ufdg party in labe, his hometown and an opposition stronghold, 400 km 248 miles north of conakry, local party officials said. there are at least 30 wounded among the demonstrators who we first received at the party headquarters before sending them to the regional hospital or private clinics, said dr. saliou malal barry, who runs a private clinic in the town. youths set up barricades and burned tires on several main routes in labe to protest what diallo had called an attempt to assassinate him. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: guinea police stop opposition leader from joining demonstration, agence france presse english, october 30, 2018 tuesday 4:13 pm gmt, 244 words, conakry, oct 30 2018; protester killed as guinea police block opposition march and its leader, agence france presse english, october 30, 2018 tuesday 6:26 pm gmt, 362 words, conakry, oct 30 2018
notes: police in guinea surrounded the home of the country s main opposition leader, cellou dalein diallo, on tuesday preventing him from joining a new anti government protest in the capital conakry. at least five of diallo s supporters were injured tuesday in clashes near his home with police armed with clubs, shields and grenade launchers, an afp correspondent at the scene reported. rivals of president alpha conde, who has held power since 2010, called for tuesday s march a week after a banned demonstration during which diallo alleged that police had tried to assassinate him a claim police have denied. the political opposition has been protesting against what it considers a violation by the authorities of an agreement reached in august over the appointment of local government officials elected in a hotly disputed vote on february 4. a young protester in guinea was killed tuesday in clashes with police who broke up an anti government march and prevented the opposition leader from leaving his home. my brother was killed by a policeman who shot him in cold blood, mariama dalanda, in tears, told afp. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: guinea police block women s protest march, agence france presse english, november 1, 2018 thursday 8:11 pm gmt, 290 words, conakry, nov 1 2018
notes: guinean police blocked several hundred women from marching through the streets of the capital conakry in an opposition protest to demand justice for those killed during a series of bloody crackdowns on demonstrations. the women carried placards alleging brutality by security forces, in the latest eruption of discontent in conakry, which was brought to a standstill on monday by a dead city strike called by the opposition. assembled near a mosque in the city suburbs, scores of women chanted justice for our dead, death to the assassins as they prepared to march into the city to protest in front of the ministry of security. but the group was prevented from marching by unarmed female gendarmes, who created a roadblock to hinder their passage. we want to go to shout our anger in front of the minister... who protects the killers, said maimouna diallo, of the main opposition ufdg party, told reporters. note: the actual start and end dates of the event were not provided in the story, and are based on prior coding decisions
