sources: 2 dead in continuing unrest in w. african country of guinea, associated press international, november 8, 2018 thursday 6:26 pm gmt, international news, 173 words, by boubacar diallo, associated press, conakry, guinea
notes: two young men were fatally shot amid continuing political unrest following the disputed results of this west african country s first municipal elections in 13 years, authorities said thursday. the two were killed at a demonstration in the capital city of conakry on wednesday night, according to police and opposition officials. protesters have called on the government to release what they consider to be the true results of the poll. after years of waiting, the municipal elections were held in february. more than 100 people have died in the ongoing political violence following that vote. the party in power stole the opposition voices. these are the voices we are demanding, said cellou dalein diallo, a guinean opposition leader. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters against what they consider a violation by the authorities of an agreement reached in august over the appointment of local government officials elected in a hotly disputed vote on february 4
sources: guinea police use tear gas to break up opposition demo, agence france presse english, november 29, 2018 thursday 6:09 pm gmt, 235 words, conakry, nov 29 2018
notes: policemen fired tear gas and used batons on thursday to break up an anti government protest by hundreds of opposition supporters in the heart of the guinean capital conakry. the political opposition has been demonstrating against what it considers a violation by the authorities of an agreement reached in august over the appointment of local government officials elected in a hotly disputed vote on february 4. an afp correspondent said police cordoned off the area around parliament in the morning and warned demonstrators that they would be tear gassed if they breached the barricades. some 500 mostly youth demonstrators tried to force their way in but were beaten back with batons and had tear gas fired on them. four of them suffered light injuries, an afp correspondent said.

protesteridentity: opposition supporters, civil society groups and trade unionists
sources: 4 dead as guineans protest president s bid to extend power, associated press international, october 14, 2019 monday 6:32 pm gmt, international news, 655 words, by boubacar diallo, associated press, conakry, guinea; guinea opposition calls for new protests after six dead, agence france presse english, october 15, 2019 tuesday 11:28 am gmt, 323 words, conakry, oct 15 2019
notes: at least four people have been killed in guinea s capital after police fired tear gas and bullets monday to disperse thousands of opposition supporters, civil society groups and trade unionists gathering in conakry and across the country to protest the president s bid to extend his time in office, guinea s red cross said. president alpha conde s mandate ends in december 2020, but he is seeking a referendum to allow a third term in the west african nation. the four young men killed in conakry monday were all under the age of 24, guinea s red cross said monday, which also said 20 others were wounded by bullets. guinea s government said a gendarmerie was killed in mamou, and only one person was killed in conakry. residents in the wanindara district of the capital, conakry, told the associated press that two young men were wounded by bullets shot by men in national gendarmerie uniforms. young people and gendarmes were fighting. the gunshots that hit them were fired from the van of these gendarmes. both young people fell, said resident ousmane sow. he said one was hit in the foot and the other in the back. sporadic shooting could be heard in other suburbs. demonstrators burned tires and barricaded roads as police deployed around the capital. most businesses were closed and residents stayed indoors. babanou timbo camara, a protester in the matoto municipality, said police used tear gas and arrested a number of demonstrators. guinea s opposition alliance on tuesday called for a new round of protests against president alpha conde, a day after five civilians and a policeman died in clashes.

sources: new clashes in guinea after six die in protests, agence france presse english, october 15, 2019 tuesday 12:53 pm gmt, 376 words, conakry, oct 15 2019
notes: violent protests erupted in the guinean capital conakry on tuesday, a day after five civilians and a policeman died in clashes, an afp reporter and witnesses said. hundreds of youths in rundown districts on the edge of the city erected barricades, burned tyres and hurled stones at police, who responded with teargas, they said. residents in cosa, koloma and bambeto districts said that troops and police had entered the areas to carry out arrests. earlier, an opposition alliance of unions, opposition parties and civil society groups urged the public to pursue protests against president alpha conde, whom they accuse of seeking to lift constitutional blocks on a third term in office. the national front for the defence of the constitution fndc , on social media, called on guineans to continue demonstrating until the scheme for a third term is completely dropped and the electoral masquerade is stopped.

protesteridentity: national front for the defense of the constitution
sources: 9 dead as guineans protest president s bid to extend power, associated press international, october 16, 2019 wednesday 3:16 pm gmt, international news, 470 words, by boubacar diallo, associated press, conakry, guinea
notes: at least nine people have been killed in three days of protests in guinea against the president s bid to extend his time in power, while hospitals are overwhelmed with scores of people wounded, a doctor told the associated press on wednesday. some of the bullet wounds indicate that people were shot at close range, dr. diallo mamadou bella said. he is volunteering to treat the more than 70 wounded protesters at a hospital in the suburbs of the capital, conakry, where many of the protests have been taking place. it is not clear how many people have been killed and wounded overall in the protests, which have drawn thousands of people into the streets. president alpha conde s mandate ends in december 2020 but he seeks a referendum to allow a third term in the west african nation of some 12 million people. the national front for the defense of the constitution, a coalition group, called for the demonstrations. its leader, abdourahmane sanoh, and at least five others have since been arrested and were in court on wednesday, charged with acts to compromise public security and disrupt public order. the group, anticipating a crackdown by security forces, had encouraged youth to protest in their districts instead of gathering all in one place. it had called on security forces, which have had a history of violence, to show restraint. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: mass protest held in guinea against president, agence france presse english, october 24, 2019 thursday 6:51 pm gmt, 407 words, conakry, oct 24 2019; thousands of guineans protest president s bid for 3rd term, associated press international, october 24, 2019 thursday 5:39 pm gmt, international news, 416 words, by boubacar diallo, associated press, conakry, guinea
notes: crowds of protesters marched through the guinean capital of conakry on thursday in the latest round of demonstrations against president alpha conde, accused of trying to circumvent a bar on a third term in office. organisers said a million participants took part, while police put the number at 30,000. local media said there were hundreds of thousands of people. the march unfolded peacefully after previous protests that led to deadly clashes, an afp reporter saw. police mobilised in large numbers but kept a low profile. many demonstrators wore red in honour of those killed in protests last week. the opposition says 10 people died, while the authorities put the toll at eight, plus a gendarme. we will not allow it! and down with dictatorship! , they cried as they rallied in the seaside capital. we are tired of the lies, the false promises, and above all the fact that he conde is no longer capable of meeting the expectations of the people. ten years in power is long enough, said souleymane kamagathe, a baker. we simply want president alpha cond to agree to give up his plans to amend the 2010 constitution, said fode oussou fofana, the vice president of main political opposition party union of democratic forces of guinea. he said they want conde to give way to a new president.

sources: mass protest held in guinea against president, agence france presse english, october 24, 2019 thursday 6:51 pm gmt, 407 words, conakry, oct 24 2019
notes: crowds of protesters marched through the guinean capital of conakry on thursday in the latest round of demonstrations against president alpha conde, accused of trying to circumvent a bar on a third term in office. organisers said a million participants took part, while police put the number at 30,000. local media said there were hundreds of thousands of people. the march unfolded peacefully after previous protests that led to deadly clashes, an afp reporter saw. police mobilised in large numbers but kept a low profile. many demonstrators wore red in honour of those killed in protests last week. the opposition says 10 people died, while the authorities put the toll at eight, plus a gendarme. we will not allow it! and down with dictatorship! , they cried as they rallied in the seaside capital. we are tired of the lies, the false promises, and above all the fact that he conde is no longer capable of meeting the expectations of the people. ten years in power is long enough, said souleymane kamagathe, a baker. protests were also held in the towns of labe, mamou and pita, in central guinea, where government authorities accused demonstrators of throwing stones at a police station. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters demanding justice for those killed in recent anti government demonstrations
sources: teenager killed as clashes erupt at guinea protest funeral march, agence france presse english, november 4, 2019 monday 7:30 pm gmt, 547 words, conakry, nov 4 2019
notes: a teenage mourner was shot dead and several others were wounded in clashes between guinean police and protesters at a funeral march for those killed in recent anti government demonstrations, the opposition and the victim s family said. violence erupted as hundreds marched in the capital conakry carrying coffins of people killed in unrest since mid october that has shaken the poor west african country. demonstrators have taken to the streets over suspicions that president alpha conde is seeking to prolong his rule. according to an opposition toll around 15 protesters have been killed during the weeks of bloody clashes with security forces, with dozens injured. the government has said one police officer was killed, but have not given an updated number of casualties. at monday s march, hundreds of people including relatives and opposition figures marched on foot or by motorbike through the bambeto neighbourhood, bearing aloft the coffins of 11 of those killed since october 24 draped in the national flag. the marchers chanted justice for the dead and alpha, killer as they made their way from the hospital where victims remains had been held and a mosque where pre burial prayers were planned. clashes broke out on the route, with youths hurling stones at riot police who responded with tear gas. witnesses said they also fired live rounds into the crowd.

protesteridentity: protesters demanding the release of government critics imprisoned since the beginning of anti government unrest
sources: fresh protests held in tense guinea capital, agence france presse english, november 7, 2019 thursday 2:21 pm gmt, 326 words, conakry, nov 7 2019
notes: thousands of guinean protesters took to the streets in the capital conakry thursday november 7th, in fresh demonstrations days after deadly clashes marred a funeral march for those killed in recent anti government marches. the poor west african country has been shaken by deadly clashes during weeks of protest over suspicions that president alpha conde is seeking to prolong his rule. demonstrators on thursday vowed to march peacefully and demanded the release of government critics imprisoned since the beginning of the anti government unrest. tensions in the capital are high just days after the deaths of three youths, who the opposition says were shot by the security services as they attended a funeral march for 11 people killed in unrest since mid october. at least 16 civilians and a police officer have been killed during the weeks of bloody clashes with security forces, according to the opposition, with dozens injured and dozens more arrested. the national front for the defence of the constitution fndc , an alliance of opposition groups that is behind the protests, plans further rallies in other parts of the country. unlike the first demonstrations, these have obtained the green light from authorities.

protesteridentity: national front for the defense of the constitution
sources: guinea police kill three in anti conde protest: hospital, agence france presse english, november 15, 2019 friday 1:35 pm gmt, 293 words, conakry, nov 15 2019
notes: guinea security forces killed three people on thursday during a protest against president alpha conde, opposition and doctors said. doctors initially said police had shot dead one teen, but on friday, the opposition and hospital sources said three people died. the update brings to the protest death toll in the west african state to at least 20 since october 14. one gendarme has also been killed. guineans wearing the red colours of the opposition flooded conakry s streets again thursday after a call by the national front for the defense of the constitution fndc , the alliance leading the protests. clashes erupted along the route of the march and spread to several neighborhoods. the fndc said alpha souleymane diallo, abdouramane diallo, and 32 year old amadou oury barry, were killed by security forces during raids outside the area of the protest. another 66 people were injured, including 26 shot by police, abdoulaye oumou sow, an fndc leader told afp. all three deaths were confirmed by a medical source at the sino guinean friendship hospital. police used water cannon and tear gas to break up the protests, and a bus was torched during clashes, images from the scene showed. the security ministry said the police action came after the demonstrators threw stones at security forces. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters against embattled president alpha conde
sources: guinea opposition supporters in massive new protest, agence france presse english, november 26, 2019 tuesday 5:52 pm gmt, 266 words, conakry, nov 26 2019
notes: guinean protesters thronged the streets of the capital conakry on tuesday in fresh protests against embattled president alpha conde. the crowds, most wearing opposition t shirts, formed a sea of red the colour of the opposition with lawmaker fode oussou fofana estimating their numbers at more than a million . afp could not independently verify the figure. protesters carried placards reading no to dictatorship, death to murderers and free the heroes . the poor west african country of some 13 million has seen rolling demonstrations since last month over suspicions that the 81 year old president is manoeuvring to seek a third term in office. at least 20 civilians have been killed since mid october and one gendarme has also been killed. a guinean court handed down jail terms to several opposition leaders in october. on tuesday, opposition leader cellou dalein diallo could be seen in the middle of the crowd on the hood of a 4x4 vehicle. leading civil society members including a top lawyer and a former defence minister took part in the protest. schools and shops were shut across much of capital, and security officers were out in force, although they maintained a low profile, an afp journalist said.

sources: guinea hit by fresh anti government rallies, agence france presse english, december 10, 2019 tuesday 7:05 pm gmt, 268 words, conakry, dec 10 2019
notes: guineans took to the streets en masse on tuesday, in the latest round of mass anti government protests to hit the fragile west african state. around one million people protested against embattled president alpha conde in the capital conakry, opposition mp fode oussouba said. afp could not independently verify the figure, however. there were no reports of violence on tuesday, however, which also saw thousands of people protest in regional cities in the centre and north of the country, according to witnesses.

location: Regional cities in the centre and north of Guinea
sources: guinea hit by fresh anti government rallies, agence france presse english, december 10, 2019 tuesday 7:05 pm gmt, 268 words, conakry, dec 10 2019
notes: guineans took to the streets en masse on tuesday, in the latest round of mass anti government protests to hit the fragile west african state. around one million people protested against embattled president alpha conde in the capital conakry, opposition mp fode oussouba said. afp could not independently verify the figure, however. there were no reports of violence on tuesday, however, which also saw thousands of people protest in regional cities in the centre and north of the country, according to witnesses. note: the exact protest locations were not provided in the source

location: Conakry; Labe; Pita; Dalaba; Mamou; Boke; Kankan
protesteridentity: national front for the defence of the constitution fndc , an alliance of opposition groups
sources: fresh anti government protests in guinea turn violent, agence france presse english, january 6, 2020 monday 5:22 pm gmt, 444 words, conakry, jan 6 2020
notes: thousands of guineans took to the streets on monday in a new anti government protest, with partisan violence injuring at least 12 people in the country s east. the west african country has been hit by rolling protests since mid october over concerns president alpha conde plans to stay in office for a third term. on monday, tens of thousands marched from the suburbs of the capital conakry to the city centre, an afp journalist said. wearing the opposition colour red, protesters carried placards reading no to a new constitution and no to a third mandate for alpha conde . conde, 81, announced a new draft constitution last month, but which critics fear he will use to pursue a third term. major opposition figures, including former prime ministers cellou dalein diallo and sidya toure, protested in conakry on monday. abdourahmane sanoh, the coordinator of national front for the defence of the constitution fndc , an alliance of opposition groups behind the protests, said there were plans to increase the number of rallies from january 13. demonstrations also took part in regional cities such as labe, pita, dalaba, mamou and boke, witnesses told afp. but the protests turned violent in the conde stronghold of kankan in the east of the country, as the president s supporters attacked protesters.

protesteridentity: national front for the defence of the constitution
sources: one dead in guinea as sweeping anti govt rally starts, agence france presse english, january 13, 2020 monday 4:35 pm gmt, 424 words, conakry, jan 13 2020; two dead in guinea at start of sweeping anti government rally, agence france presse english, january 13, 2020 monday 9:21 pm gmt, 413 words, conakry, jan 13 2020
notes: two youths were killed in guinea s capital conakry on monday at the start of open ended protests against president alpha conde. the west african country has been wracked by demonstrations since mid october over concerns conde intends to use a planned constitutional reform to extend his mandate. scuffles broke out on monday between young people and the police, an afp journalist said. a student elhadj mamadou sow, 21, was killed in the unrest, according to his uncle, who declined to be named. the uncle said he was shot by a security officer who was chasing a group of young people. we heard gun fire pah, pah, pah, and suddenly we heard screams and all the young people gathered around my nephew who was on the ground, wounded in the chest, he added. a doctor confirmed that mamadou sow had died and told afp he was shot at close range. after months of organising mass protests, the national front for the defence of the constitution fndc , an alliance of opposition groups, raised the stakes last week and called for huge and open ended demonstrations. the political opposition is convinced that conde put forward a draft constitution last month intending to keep himself in office for a third term. the current constitution in the former french colony stipulates two presidential terms. shops and schools were shut across conakry on monday, an afp journalist said, while streets were mostly empty of traffic. the fndc s call for resistance is being widely followed in several cities in guinea, the opposition group said in a statement. this has resulted in a total paralysis of the main roads, the closure of shops and businesses, it added. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters with suspicions that president alpha conde wants to prolong his rule via constitutional change
sources: guinea police stations burned down by anti govt protesters, agence france presse english, january 14, 2020 tuesday 8:13 pm gmt, 362 words, conakry, jan 14 2020
notes: protesters burned down two police stations in central guinea on tuesday, witnesses and the government said, in fresh confrontation with the government in the west african country. in unrest over suspicions that president alpha conde wants to prolong his rule via constitutional change, protesters pelted the police stations in the city of pita with stones before burning them down, according to the security ministry. hundreds of thousands of guineans have been protesting since mid october over concerns that conde intends to use a constitutional reform to seek a third term in office. but protest organisers have raised the stakes by urging people, starting from this week, to take part in huge and open ended demonstrations throughout the country. on tuesday, protesters in the central city of pita hurled stones at a police and a gendarmerie station, a guinea security ministry statement said. they then looted them and burned them down. several hundreds of people took advantage of the situation to steal guns and food supplies, including sacks of rice, a witness to the events, who requested to remain anonymous, told afp. there were scuffles between protesters and police officers in the capital conakry on tuesday too, an afp journalist said. however, schools and businesses in the city, which had closed on monday, were beginning to open again on tuesday. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters with suspicions that president alpha conde wants to prolong his rule via constitutional change
sources: guinea police stations burned down by anti govt protesters, agence france presse english, january 14, 2020 tuesday 8:13 pm gmt, 362 words, conakry, jan 14 2020
notes: protesters burned down two police stations in central guinea on tuesday, witnesses and the government said, in fresh confrontation with the government in the west african country. in unrest over suspicions that president alpha conde wants to prolong his rule via constitutional change, protesters pelted the police stations in the city of pita with stones before burning them down, according to the security ministry. hundreds of thousands of guineans have been protesting since mid october over concerns that conde intends to use a constitutional reform to seek a third term in office. but protest organisers have raised the stakes by urging people, starting from this week, to take part in huge and open ended demonstrations throughout the country. on tuesday, protesters in the central city of pita hurled stones at a police and a gendarmerie station, a guinea security ministry statement said. they then looted them and burned them down. several hundreds of people took advantage of the situation to steal guns and food supplies, including sacks of rice, a witness to the events, who requested to remain anonymous, told afp. clashes also broke out in other cities on tuesday, the security ministry said, including in lelouma, in the north, where a police officer was shot and two gendarmes were wounded by stones. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters with suspicions that president alpha conde wants to prolong his rule via constitutional change

notes: protesters burned down two police stations in central guinea on tuesday, witnesses and the government said, in fresh confrontation with the government in the west african country. in unrest over suspicions that president alpha conde wants to prolong his rule via constitutional change, protesters pelted the police stations in the city of pita with stones before burning them down, according to the security ministry. hundreds of thousands of guineans have been protesting since mid october over concerns that conde intends to use a constitutional reform to seek a third term in office. but protest organisers have raised the stakes by urging people, starting from this week, to take part in huge and open ended demonstrations throughout the country. on tuesday, protesters in the central city of pita hurled stones at a police and a gendarmerie station, a guinea security ministry statement said. they then looted them and burned them down. several hundreds of people took advantage of the situation to steal guns and food supplies, including sacks of rice, a witness to the events, who requested to remain anonymous, told afp.

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to the prevention of opposition deputies from protesting against a referendum they say would let president alpha conde run for a third term
sources: clashes erupt as guinea deputies barred from anti referendum protest, agence france presse english, february 22, 2020 saturday 4:44 pm gmt, 376 words, conakry, feb 22 2020
notes: clashes broke out saturday in central guinea after opposition deputies were prevented from protesting against a referendum they say would let president alpha conde run for a third term. violence erupted in several parts of mamou after news of the authorities action spread, witnesses said. the union of democratic forces of guinea and other opposition groups are contesting a referendum to be held on march 1, alongside parliamentary elections, that could allow conde to run again for president after he finishes his second and final five year term under the current constitution. ufdg deputies were confined to a hotel by security forces and could not attend a protest rally organised by the country s leading opposition party. shop owner and activist amadou diallo told afp that after hearing the news demonstrators barricaded major intersections and burned tyres, and for the moment no vehicles are moving through the city. security forces fired tear gas to disperse the protesters, but the city is big and hotspots can be seen everywhere so it is complicated, he added. on saturday, the authorities deployed two trucks of security agents before the hotel, where ufdg deputy and vice president fode oussou fofana was staying, he told afp by telephone. we are now sequestered. they also barricaded the site where we were supposed to hold the rally, he said, adding that two other ufdg deputies were blocked along with him inside the hotel. a security agent at the site told afp: we have instructions to let no one enter or leave the hotel. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to constitutional reforms which critics fear will allow president conde to stay in power for a third term
sources: guinea police clash with protesters days before referendum, agence france presse english, february 27, 2020 thursday 8:01 pm gmt, 361 words, conakry, feb 27 2020
notes: guinea police clashed with opposition protesters and the army was put on alert on thursday, three days before a tense referendum on president alpha conde s contested reforms. months of protests have rocked guinea over the constitutional reforms which critics fear will allow conde to stay in power for a third term in the west africa country. youths erected barricades, burned tyres and threw rocks at police who responded with tear gas in the opposition stronghold of wanindara in the suburbs of the capital conakry, witnesses said. alpha, you have divided guineans, time to go, thank you, enough, chanted a group of female protesters, dressed in the red of the opposition, who gathered in another conakry area. similar clashes took place in pita, 350 km 217 miles north of conakry, residents told afp by telephone. both the 2010 constitution and the new draft constitution limit presidential mandates to two terms. but critics say a new constitution would mean a new republic, in effect resetting the presidential term counter to zero and allowing conde to run again. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to postponement of the referendum on changing the constitution
sources: guinea opposition urges president to scrap delayed referendum, agence france presse english, february 29, 2020 saturday 7:16 pm gmt, 757 words, conakry, feb 29 2020
notes: guinea s opposition on saturday called for the cancellation of a referendum on changing the constitution, as fresh protests against president alpha conde s government broke out in the capital conakry. conde on friday announced the referendum, planned for sunday, would be postponed possibly for two weeks following growing domestic and international criticism over the ballot. the referendum will decide whether to adopt a new constitution, which includes bans on female circumcision and underage marriage in the west african country. but the proposal has sparked huge protests since october over fears that it will reset presidential term limits allowing conde to run for a third spell in office later this year. the draft constitution would extend the presidential terms to six years, potentially permitting conde, 81, to govern for another 12. opposition leaders promised to keep up the protests despite the postponement. in opposition districts in conakry on saturday, fresh protests broke out following the postponement of the election. groups of youngsters blocked one of the city s main thoroughfares, the route le prince, and hurled rocks at security forces, who zipped around in armoured cars. wearing riot gear, gendarmes fired tear gas canisters from rifles, or from vehicle mounted gun turrets, into the narrow dirt roads leading off from the highway. but an fndc protest observer, who declined to be named for security reasons, said people were protesting because of the macabre project of the new constitution. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: 12 hurt as government supporters attack opposition march agence france presse english, 498 words burkina faso protest leaves dozens hurt the globe and mail canada , october 1, 1991 tuesday, 239 words, reut ;
notes: at least 12 people were injured here monday and the headquarters of a key opposition movement were set on fire, as supporters of burkina faso president blaise compaore attacked opposition demonstrators calling for a national political conference, witnesses and hospital sources said. when a crowd of some 3,000 gathered for the start of the meeting, youths wearing t shirts bearing compaore s portrait drove up on a truck and started hurling stones at the demonstrators. security forces, who had blocked access to the building, did not appear to have intervened other than to appeal for calm. dozens of people were injured in burkina faso yesterday when paramilitary police lobbed tear gas and fired into the air to scatter demonstrators demanding a pro democracy conference, witnesses said. thousands of protesters clashed with supporters of president blaise compaore before being blocked by security forces as they marched on the presidential palace in the capital, ouagadougou.

sources: opposition reports arson bid on headquarters agence france presse english, 263 words ;
notes: reported oct 31, 1991 dateline: ouagadougou a number of opposition leaders have said they fear for their life since security forces on tuesday used tear gas to break up a demonstration here by about 10,000 people organised by the confederation of democratic forces, which groups a score of opposition movements. the demonstrators were protesting at the refusal of president blaise compaore to stage a national conference on the west african state s future. a number of opposition chiefs are boycotting december s presidential poll as a result.

sources: police use tear gas to disperse university protest associated press international, february 01, 1997; saturday, international news, 130 words burkina student leaders released agence france presse, february 09, 1997, international news, 148 words ;
notes: agence france presse, february 09, 1997, international news, 148 words police fired tear gas saturday to break up a sit in by hundreds of university students protesting the arrest of a student activist in earlier demonstrations. seni koanda, president of the burkinabe students national association, was arrested friday night and accused of threatening to kill a fellow student who did not support him. koanda has led a strike since tuesday by students demanding more scholarship money and buses to carry them to campus. the university has been closed since tuesday because of the unrest, and on saturday roads leading to government buildings were heavily patrolled by soldiers. the morning sit in took place outside the national radio station. four student leaders arrested for spearheading strikes were released sunday, national radio reported, citing burkina faso s higher education minister maurice melegue traore.

sources: police use teargas to break up student demo in ouagadougou agence france presse, february 04, 1997, international news, 171 words burkina student leaders released agence france presse, february 09, 1997, international news, 148 words ;
notes: police used teargas here tuesday to break up a demonstration by students demanding the release of colleagues detained after similar disturbances over the weekend, an afp correspondent reported. hundreds of secondary school high school students blocked main roads in the capital tuesday morning to demand the release of national student union of burkina aneb leader andre tibiri. four student leaders arrested for spearheading strikes were released sunday, national radio reported, citing burkina faso s higher education minister maurice melegue traore.

sources: thousands protest death of burkina faso journalist associated press international, december 15, 1998; tuesday, international news, 210 words 10,000 protest in burkina faso over death of journalist agence france presse english, 374 words request for inquiry into death of burkina faso newspaperman agence france presse english, 158 words ;
notes: thousands of people took to the streets of this dusty capital city tuesday to protest the death of a prominent journalist. crowds began forming early tuesday morning at the home of norbet zongo, owner of the weekly newspaper the independent and one of the most outspoken critics of president blaise compaore s regime. the crowds began with just a few hundred university students but quickly swelled to thousands of chanting people accusing the government of killing zongo. at one point, the crowds stormed the offices of the ruling congress for democracy and progress party, breaking windows and furniture, and also destroyed two buses owned by the party. they were eventually dispersed by riot police firing tear gas and a heavy police presence remained on the streets thursday afternoon. plainclothed police could also be seen rounding up students. it was not immediately known how many students were arrested in the mayhem. burkina faso s governing party, the congress for democracy and progress cdp , called thursday for an investigation into the death of norbert zongo, publisher of the weekly l independant.

sources: thousands in burkina faso clash with police in protest over dead journalist the associated press, december 16, 1998, wednesday, am cycle, international news, 244 words request for inquiry into death of burkina faso newspaperman agence france presse english, 158 words ;
notes: thousands of people clashed with police in the west african nation of burkina faso on wednesday, the second straight day of violent protests over the death of a prominent journalist. angry mobs set fire to the local headquarters of the ruling party, the congress for democracy and progress, a local radio report said. at least 10 demonstrators were wounded by police gunfire, a doctor with koudougou health hospital said by telephone. burkina faso s governing party, the congress for democracy and progress cdp , called thursday for an investigation into the death of norbert zongo, publisher of the weekly l independant.

sources: burkina faso police clash with protesters over journalist s death the associated press, january 3, 1999, sunday, bc cycle, international news, 215 words ;
notes: police fired tear gas sunday at hundreds of demonstrators outside a roman catholic cathedral who were calling for an investigation into a prominent journalist s death. one demonstrator was injured when he was hit by a tear gas canister in the west african nation. police first confronted the demonstrators during morning services, but backed off when cardinal jean marie compaore demanded they stop. hours later, after the service was over, police again fired tear gas into the crowd of about 500. the crowd was scattered and at least a dozen demonstrators were arrested.

sources: protestors start march against impunity in burkina faso agence france presse english, 97 words ;
notes: at least 3,000 people began a march against impunity in burkina faso s capital on saturday, according to organisers, while security forces said about 1,000 people were taking part. demonstrators demanding that light be shed on unpunished political crimes in the west african country shouted enough is enough! as they paraded through ouagadougou streets. saturday s action was the latest in a series of protests and strikes since the suspicious death in december of investigative journalist and critic of president blaise compaore s government, norbert zongo.

sources: police disperse rioting students in burkina faso capital associated press international, may 10, 1999; monday, international news, 402 words, brahima ouedraogo students and police clash in burkina faso capital agence france presse english, 213 words ;
notes: riot police arrested several students monday after dispersing a noisy anti government demonstration in the capital s main streets. the youths were transported to ouagadougou s central police station after the demonstration, which lasted only a few hours before the arrival of the heavily armed police. they lobbed tear gas into the crowds, sending the students scattering for cover. the demonstrators, mostly university and high school students, began gathering early in the morning. chanting we want justice! and never this kind of crime again! they headed directly for the main city center where they set up barricades, smashed traffic lights and threw burning tires and stones. they offered no resistance to the police intervention and there were no immediate reports of casualties. in yet another series of protests against authorities here, angry students in ouagadougou on friday burned tyres and threw rocks at police who tried to break up their demonstrations with tear gas.

sources: police and high school students clash in burkina capital agence france presse english, 222 words secondary students protest, backed by university counterparts agence france presse english, 286 words ;
notes: the arrests cited in the second article from ? last tuesday? ? are from the protests on this day police in burkina faso s capital fired tear gas at several hundred students who were protesting tuesday against the expulsion of 22 classmates from a school some 80 kilometres 50 miles west of ouagadougou. police began to chase students who had gathered outside zinda secondary school, the biggest school in ouagadougou, an afp reporter saw. the students threw rocks in retaliation. at marien n gouabi, another secondary school here, an anti riot vehicle entered the main courtyard and police sprayed tear gas at several dozens of student demonstrators. the students are calling for the release in sabou of 22 of their comrades who had been expelled because of alleged discipline problems. an association of supporters of norbert zongo, a burkinabe journalist killed last december in suspicious circumstances, said the students were expelled after protesting against zongo s death. the journalist, who was a staunch critic of the government, was assassinated last december 13. his murder sparked protests and strikes and has fuelled perceptions of impunity enjoyed by authorities here. no arrests or injuries were immediately reported, although sources told afp that six students had been taken into custody after two previous protests,on monday and last tuesday.

sources: source: students and police renew clashes in burkina capital agence france presse english, 261 words secondary students protest, backed by university counterparts agence france presse english, 286 words ;
notes: the arrests cited in the second article ? from monday? is from the first day of this protest the 29th anti riot police clamped down monday on restive students here who were protesting against the recent expulsion of 22 students from a school 80 kilometres 50 miles west of ouagadougou. the police riding motorcycles fired tear gas at secondary school students from zinda and nelson mandela, two of the biggest high schools in the capital. the protesters had erected barricades, throwing rocks and other missiles at the police, an afp reporter saw. no injuries were immediately reported. it was the second such protest that led to clashes within a week. the students are also calling for reforms in criteria for obtaining high school diplomas. anti riot police in burkina faso s capital clamped down on another protest tuesday by high school students, whose university counterparts backed them by launching a two day strike. for the second day in a row, motorcycle police tried to disperse students outside ouagadougou s two largest secondary schools, zinda and nelson mandela. no arrests or injuries were immediately reported, although sources told afp that six students had been taken into custody after two previous protests,on monday and last tuesday.

sources: demonstration against closure of burkina faso university agence france presse english, 123 words ;
notes: some 5,000 students and school pupils demonstrated tuesday against the closure of burkina faso s university in ouagadougou. demonstrators marched around the capital for around an hour before ending up in in the city s main square. we want to show our solidarity with the teachers and students for the immediate reopening of the university, protest leader halidou ouedraogo told afp. the demonstrators also denounced proposed reforms for the future running of the university, which is due to reopen december 1.

sources: protesting pupils clash with police in burkina faso agence france presse english, 242 words ;
notes: since the police needed tear gas to disperse students, i have coded this as a protest with 50 protesters police used tear gas to disperse demonstrating high school pupils on wednesday in burkina faso s capital ouagadougou, where protests over planned academic reforms disrupted many classes. some of them who had gathered for a meeting at the zinda secondary school, the biggest in the west african capital, hurled stones at the police, an afp correspondent said, but no arrests or injuries were reported. we are demonstrating to say no to a reform that would close the doors of the university to us, one of the students said, adding that several of his classmates had been detained on tuesday. the authorities seek to make access to the most sought after disciplines in university dependent on the grades of high school examination results, but pupils argue that this would create a two tier academic system. police neither confirmed nor denied the reported arrests, but paramilitary units in riot gear remained stationed round the zinda college. protests first broke out in the city on monday

sources: schoolboy killed by burkina faso security forces agence france presse english, 211 words burkina faso bans highway demonstrations after protester killed associated press international, december 7, 2000; thursday, international news, 320 words ;
notes: since 10 people were detained, and there was a need for security forces to use guns in the clashes, it appears this protest is greater than 50 people police in burkina faso shot dead a 12 year old schoolboy in the centre of the country, during violent clashes between security forces and demonstrators, the security ministry said thursday. flavien nebia was killed during clashes between security forces and demonstrators at the bousse secondary school on december 6, said a ministry statement. bousse is 50 kilometres 30 miles north of the capital ougadougou. security forces were defending the high commissioner s residence from demonstrators from the school who had just set fire to part of the residence, the statement continued. ten people were detained in the unrest. according to a local rights movement, they were teachers accused by the government of inciting their pupils toprotest. the government of this west african country banned all public demonstrations after a schoolboy was killed in a protest against new university admissions measures which students consider too restrictive.

sources: burkina unions use may day to call strike for may 28 and 29 agence france presse english, may 1, 2002 wednesday, international news, 138 words ;
notes: since the article says the protest was similar on april 23 and 24, it appears that the size of the protest would also be similar unions in the west african country of burkina faso used may day celebrations wednesday to announce they are calling a 48 hour national strike at month s end to protest rising prices. some 2,000 workers staged a protest in the capital to mark may day, during which they announced they had called a general strike on may 28 and 29. workers staged a similar action on april 23 and 24, paralysing the capital ouagadougou as they pressed for a rise in wages and a drop in income tax.

sources: burkina faso workers protest hardships under imf programme agence france presse english, july 18, 2002 thursday, international news, 161 words ;
notes: since this articles notes nearly 2000 , it sounds as if the protest numbers did not quite reach 2000. therefore, it has earned a category of 1000 1999 and 2000 as the number of protesters involved. nearly 2,000 striking workers took to the streets of ouagadougou on thursday demanding higher wages to cope with hardships caused by burkina faso s structural adjustment programme. the protesters marched on the employment exchange and handed over a memorandum addressed to prime minister ernest yonli pressing their demand for a 25 percent salary increase.

sources: burkina faso authorities detain student leader agence france presse english, november 25, 2002 monday, international news, 256 words ;
notes: due to the amount of violence and destruction reported, i concluded the number of protesters was greater than 50. gendarmerie police in burkina faso have been holding the leader of the national students association, bertrand meda, and five other students accused of vandalism for three days, police said monday. meda, the president of the national burkina students association aneb , and his colleagues were arrested after a violent demonstration friday in the capital, gendarmerie major alain serge ouedraogo said. the six were due to be brought before the state prosecutor later monday to face charges of acts of vandalism , ouedraogo said in a television broadcast. students had demonstrated around the university of ouagadougou campus to protest against the doubling of academic registration fees from 7,500 to 15,000 cfa francs 23 euros dollars . ouedraogo said some of the protesters went on a rampage and burned or smashed at least five vehicles owned by the state and by non governmental organisations.

sources: source: shopkeepers rampage in burkina faso, protesting police violence agence france presse english, february 13, 2004 friday, international news, 457 words tension reigns after riots over burkina faso market s fate agence france presse english, february 14, 2004 saturday, international news, 517 words, boureima hama police arrest 75 after protests in burkina capital agence france presse english, february 16, 2004 monday, international news, 318 words ;
notes: since the second articles notes it was a massive demonstration, i considered this protest to have 50 people. since there were riot police at the ready, this is also coded as crowd dispersal as following the coding rules. stallkeepers in burkina faso went on the rampage friday, incensed over what they see as government plans to hand the city s sprawling central market to commercial interests and protesting police violence. carrying sticks and rocks, a mass of young people swarmed through the southern district of gounghin, smashing traffic lights, ripping down billboards and halting traffic with barricades of burning tires. they blocked the main kadiogo highway leading to the southern suburbs over a distance of about three kilometers. stores pulled down their shutters, but the central commercial district was spared the violence. witnesses said calm had returned to the city by the evening. the rioters went home but the security forces are still there, one resident in the affected neighborhood told afp by telephone. in contrast with the previous evening, riot police did not intervene during the trouble. detachments of helmeted officers in trucks laden with tear gas canisters waited under the shade of trees with helmets, firearms and grenade launchers at the ready. a massive demonstration erupted in ouagadougou on friday to protest government plans to hand over the sprawling central rood wooko marketplace to commercial interests widely believed by west african merchants to be lebanese traders once it is rebuilt and reopened. the rampage was also to protest the police violence and tear gas that greeted a meeting a day earlier aimed at preparing a response to the government plans for rood wooko s future.

sources: burkina faso: thousands hold demo in ouagadougou to protest fuel price hike bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, may 24, 2006 wednesday, 136 words burkina faso: striking workers ignore government s sanction threats bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, may 25, 2006 thursday, 276 words ;
notes: since there appeared to be no action taken by the state even though police reported on the number the state response for this protest is coded as ignore. just like everywhere else numbers of demonstrators vary depending on the source: demonstration organizers say 10,000 people while the police say less than 2,000 people held a march in ouagadougou yesterday 24 may on the first day of a 48 hour strike by civil servants. the civil servants are demanding a salary increase after walking out of negotiations at the beginning of the month after the government announced an increase in fuel prices. the price of petroleum has increased to 705cfa francs 1.38 dollars per litre. the strike is also being observed by various public and private sectors. several public institutions like the post office are closed and taxis have also stopped working. in burkina faso, taxi drivers have joined the strike embarked on by the main trade union organization to protest the uncontrolled fuel price increase and to demand better working conditions.

sources: burkina faso women protest at murdered journalist s grave agence france presse english, august 13, 2006 sunday 4:39 pm gmt, 245 words ;
notes: around 50 women dressed in black prayed at the grave of a murdered journalist on sunday to protest the scrapping of a case against a security official who is the sole suspect accused in the killing. the participants from the campaign group women in black of burkina faso prayed for half an hour at the tomb of norbert zongo, former director of the weekly independent magazine.

sources: overnight clashes between police, soldiers in burkina faso leave 4 dead associated press international, december 21, 2006 thursday 7:48 pm gmt, international news, 312 words, by brahima ouedraogo, associated press writer ;
notes: firefights between soldiers and police in burkina faso s capital killed four people overnight, an official said thursday. shooting erupted in the capital of ouagadougou late wednesday and lasted into the early hours of thursday as scores of troops took to the streets after police killed a soldier. an associated press correspondent saw more than 100 soldiers in the streets during the night while automatic weapon fire rang out in the capital of ouagadougou. the shooting continued until just after dawn thursday. defense minister boly yero said two more soldiers and two police officers were killed in the violence. he confirmed that police headquarters and a military barracks burned in the clashes. at least a dozen soldiers were hospitalized with bullet wounds. burned cars could also be seen outside police headquarters thursday. the fighting started after policemen shot dead a soldier tuesday night. a government statement issued following tuesday s shooting confirmed that police killed one soldier and injured three others, but did not offer further details. yero said he met with a group of the soldiers late thursday and they agreed to lay down their weapons. he said many argued that their readiness to take up arms stemmed from anger about poor working conditions and inadequate accommodation. yero said he had promised to try to address these issues.

sources: 3,000 demand reopening of dropped murder case of burkina journalist agence france presse english, february 3, 2007 saturday 2:21 pm gmt, 327 words ;
notes: an estimated 3,000 people demonstrated saturday in the streets of ouagadougou to demand the reopening of the probe into the murder eight years ago of prominent journalist norbert zongo. some demonstrators also called for light to be shed on the death of former president thomas sankara, who was killed in the 1987 coup which brought compaore to power.

sources: army in burkina faso demands better pension, service extension associated press international, october 8, 2007 monday 9:27 pm gmt, international news, 353 words, by brahima ouedraogo, associated press writer ;
notes: since the soldiers were prevented from entering the building in the capital by security forces, i have coded the state response as crowd dispersal, since they took action against the protesters from continuing their meeting. a day after dozens of soldiers rallied in the capital, army officials said monday the servicemen s demands for an extension of their service and better pensions were illegal. their claims are illegal ... we are in a law abiding state where all demonstrations are regulated by law, said col. amadou pingrenoma zagre, the deputy chief of staff of burkina faso s army. zagre said the soldiers, who had been in talks with the army over their retirement age and benefits, broke off the discussion two weeks ago and have not returned to the negotiating table. on sunday, an estimated 100 soldiers met noisily in ouagadougou, the capital, threatening to organize rallies and use force if their demands were not met. they attempted to hold a meeting in a building in the capital, but were prevented from entering by security forces. a tense standoff ensued. it ended with the soldiers shouting out their demands in the street.

sources: more than 100 arrested after burkina faso demo clashes: minister agence france presse english, february 21, 2008 thursday 9:03 pm gmt, 392 words 200 arrested after burkina faso demo clashes: minister agence france presse english, february 26, 2008 tuesday 9:13 pm gmt, 195 words ;
notes: this is a correction from 2008 protest 1. originally, this had been coded as a protest in a single city. it should be have been coded as national since the protest began in bobo dioulasso and spread to other towns such as banfora and ouahigouya by the second day. additionally, it was originally coded with the state response solely being arrests. however, since the article notes violent clashes alongside arrests, it would appear that the police were present and engaged in dispersing protester, which resulted in arrests. the wording implies the arrests occurred after the clashes. more than 100 people have been arrested in burkina faso s second city after a protest against rising living costs ended in violent clashes, the interior minister said thursday. the clashes in one of africa s most impoverished nations left one protestor seriously injured , according to clement pegwende sawadogo, whilst roads and service stations were trashed, he said. the demonstration and arrests in bobo dioulasso on wednesday sparked similar protests in other burkina towns, including banfora and ouahigouya, on thursday and looked set to continue friday, witnesses told afp. by thursday evening tensions remained strong in bobo dioulasso, with banks, shops and the main market closed. hundreds of youths burned tires on the main public highway, whilst others threw stones at government vehicles including those of the ministerial cortege. some 200 people have been arrested in the poor west african nation of burkina faso after a protest against rising living costs ended in violent clashes, the government said tuesday.

sources: 184 arrested in burkina faso after protest over rising costs of basic goods associated press international, march 4, 2008 tuesday 12:05 am gmt, international news, 396 words, by brahima ouedraogo, associated press writer burkina faso court jails 45 for protests over prices agence france presse english, march 12, 2008 wednesday 10:18 pm gmt, 484 words ;
notes: a government spokesman said that 184 people have been arrested in burkina faso following violent demonstrations over the spiraling cost of basic goods. phillipe sawadogo told reporters monday that thibault nana, the leader of an opposition party who organized a key protest in ouagadougou is among those arrested. the arrested protesters have been transferred to the capital s central prison. he was arrested and questioned, said sawadogo. nana is accused of sedition for having called for the destruction of property in the thursdaydemonstrations, he said. the demonstrators were operating in groups of 15 to 20, attacking 50 neighborhoods in the capital, sawadogo said. there was an organized desire to destroy things, says sawadogo. nana called for the dead city day protests in ouagadougou, asking shopkeepers and transportation workers to bring the capital to a standstill inprotest of the increasing cost of living. protesters claim the government has added new taxes to basic goods. the protests quickly spiraled into violence, as they did in other towns, including bobodioulasso, the country s second largest city, as well as in banfora in the west and ouahigouya in the north. the monday edition of the state owned newspaper sidwaya reported that 29 people have been sentenced to prison terms, ranging from three to 36 months for protests that began feb. 20 in bobodioulasso. the protests erupted in ouagadougou and the economic capital bobo dioulasso and sparked similar unrest in other burkinabe towns, including banfora and ouahigouya, which lasted for two days. protester group: de

sources: burkina faso unions call for strike over cost of living agence france presse english, march 15, 2008 saturday 5:20 pm gmt, 339 words ;
notes: several unions in burkina faso called for a general strike next month as tens of thousands staged protest marches saturday against the high cost of living in the west african country. the declaration signed by the leaders of six unions and some 15 independent organisations was read by sagnon following a peaceful demonstration in ouagadougou over high prices, corruption and fraud in one of the world s poorest countries. similar marches, conducted with the permission of authorities, were held in some six cities around the nation drawing tens of thousands of people to the streets, local residents told afp.

sources: tens of thousands protest against food price hikes in burkina faso agence france presse english, may 14, 2008 wednesday 12:10 pm gmt, 246 words ;
notes: since the protesters were watched by police force, it sounds as if they were on the ready to disperse the crowd if they got out of control. therefore, this has been coded with a state response of crowd dispersal. tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets in several towns in burkina faso, one of the world s poorest countries, on wednesday to protest the rising cost of living as part of a three day general strike. in the capital ouagadougou demonstrators started marching from the headquarters of the main unions and the city centre, under the watchful eyes of a large police force. the protesters were to return to the union headquarters later for a meeting of a coalition of some 20 unions and civil organisations united against the price hikes. people carrying pots and pans and empty sacks of rice shouted slogans like no to the freezing of salaries and pensions and no to the rising cost of living . similar protests brought together several thousand people in the central town of koudougou, bobo dioulasso west and fada ngourma, to the east, local residents and union leaders told afp.

sources: thousands protest new tax in burkina faso agence france presse english, march 31, 2010 wednesday 6:25 pm gmt, 128 words ;
notes: thousands demonstrated in ouagadougou wednesday against a new district tax that has seen unions declare a 48 hour strike in the poor west african nation. the new tax is aimed at boosting the coffers of districts in burkina faso. protesters chanted slogans such as no to unjust charges and taxes , the people are hungry, it must end and yes to lower cereal and fuel prices . heeding the call of central trade unions, some 15 independent unions, civil society organisations and human rights bodies, protesters swarmed the main arteries of the capital before holding a meeting at ouagadougou s labour market. no incidents were reported by police.

sources: 4 killed in burkina faso student protests the associated press, february 24, 2011 thursday 03:58 pm gmt, international news, 126 words ;
notes: since there were clashes, i have coded this as crowd dispersal, since it would appear that the police were trying to control the crowd and disperse it, as oppose to ignoring it. burkina faso s government and a witness say four people have been killed in clashes between police and demonstrators in the center of the landlocked west african nation. a government statement issued thursday said demonstrations started tuesday in the city of koudougou over the death of a jailed student. the government said he died of meningitis while in police custody. fellow students say he died because he received bad treatment. a local journalist says he saw bodies of a demonstrator and a policeman. the government says two were killed and two policemen were wounded. demonstrators also looted and torched government buildings and vehicles.

notes: given the amount of destruction that occurred, it should be safe to assume that at least 50 protesters were in the streets in yako, koupela, gourcy and dori. it is the second article, which is referring to this protest, which solidifies the fact that the students were protesting the death of the student in police custody. around 20 prisoners escaped in burkina faso on monday after teenagers set four police stations on fire to protest against violent clashes that killed four students last month. defying a government order to return to classes, middle and high school students set fire to a police station in yako, 100 kilometres 60 miles north of the capital, letting a dozen detainees loose, a police officer told afp. others burned down another police station in koupela, 140 kilometres 85 miles to the east, allowing nine prisoners to escape, residents said. there is nothing. everything is gone, even the prisoners, a local teacher said. now children are playing in the remains of the police station, he added. protesters also set fire to police stations in gourcy in the north and in dori in the northeast, said a resident. in both towns prisoners had been transferred from the police stations to other locations before violence broke out. six people, including four students and a policeman, were killed in riots in late february in the town of koudougou, 100 kilometres 60 miles west of ouagadougou, after a student died in disputed circumstances. the government sacked a regional governor following the riots. the violence erupted after the death of a 24 year old man who authorities said died of meningitis but demonstrators said had been abused by police after an interrogation. elsewhere in the country, peaceful protests took place monday in bobo dioulasso, burkina faso s second city, and six other towns. the national student association called for a massive rally friday after days of unrest across the country in which students torched government buildings and freed prisoners from a police station to protest a young man s death

sources: thousands of students march in burkina faso the associated press, march 11, 2011 friday 01:11 pm gmt, international news, 120 words ;
notes: authorities have used tear gas to disperse thousands of students marching in burkina faso after the death of a young man in police custody. witnesses said there were injuries friday, and national television reporters were beaten and their cameras taken away by demonstrators. smoke rose from burning tires at the scene. demonstrations began late last month in the west african country after a jailed student died in custody. the government said he had meningitis, but accusations of mistreatment have fueled deadly protests, killing at least six others. students are demanding that the government fire the ministers of health, security and justice. already a head of police and a governor have been fired by the government.

sources: burkinabe soldiers loot and shoot against sex scandal ruling agence france presse english, march 23, 2011 wednesday 11:21 am gmt, 334 words burkina faso leader battles mutiny agence france presse english, april 15, 2011 friday 6:36 pm gmt, 701 words ;
notes: since the soldiers were joined by soldiers in other barracks on their rampage through town, it would appear that the numbers would have swelled past 50, especially considering the amount of destruction and looting mentioned. burkinabe soldiers left their barracks, firing gunshots into the air and looting shops on tuesday night to protest the conviction of five soldiers in a sex scandal, a military source said wednesday. the shooting started at around 10 pm 2200 gmt in the sangoule lamizana military camp in goughin, a suburb in the west of the burkina faso capital. the soldiers left the barracks, making their way towards the country s main camp guillaume ouedraogo in the heart of ouagadougou where they were joined by other troops, residents told afp. weaving a trail of distruction around the central market, firing their weapons in the air, the soldiers looted shops attached to petrol stations and other boutiques. in the morning traders protested the pillaging, burning tyres on the highway. compaore, himself a former army captain, met members of the armed forces after the incidents and said the crisis was over after the talks.

sources: thousands of burkinabes protest compaore regime agence france presse english, april 8, 2011 friday 5:56 pm gmt, 323 words ;
notes: organisers said tens of thousands of people across burkina faso marched friday in protest against the regime of president blaise compaore. there was an impressive turn out in the capital ouagadougou, an afp journalist witnessed, the biggest in many years. the marches were organised by the national coalition against the high cost of living ccvc , an alliance of trade unions, consumer organisations, rights groups and small businesses. we came out in the tens of thousands today to shout out that we have had it up to here with the high cost of living, said ccvc coordinator tole sagnon, who also heads up the burkina general confederation of labour cgt b . the protesters also wanted to express their anger at what he said was the regime s multiple crimes , he added. marches also took place in 10 other towns across the country, with unions and local residents saying that there had been thousands of people in the streets.
