protesteridentity: people organized by the national coalition against costly living ccvc , a grassroots group opposed to higher fuel prices
sources: general strike in burkina faso over fuel prices hike, agence france presse english, november 29, 2018 thursday 3:16 pm gmt, 385 words, ouagadougou, nov 29 2018
notes: several thousand people took the streets of burkina faso s capital ouagadougou on thursday as workers downed tools in a nationwide strike over higher fuel prices. petrol and diesel prices have shot up 12 percent over the past three weeks, sparking a wave of protest. a grassroots group, the national coalition against costly living ccvc , called the strike and protest, with a march from the chamber of commerce to the trade ministry in the heart of the capital of this west african country. no to the impoverishment of the citizens read one of the slogans alongside others reading: bread and freedom for the people .

sources: burkina medics seek better work conditions, threaten strike, agence france presse english, june 24, 2019 monday 6:25 pm gmt, 230 words, ouagadougou, june 24 2019
notes: hundreds of doctors and nurses demonstrated monday in the burkina faso capital ouagadougou to protest against declining health facilities and to demand better working conditions. the main doctors union also warned it would stage a general strike from june 30 to july 7 to demand concrete responses to their grievances. health professionals staged a series of strikes at the end of may, seriously disrupting work at health centres in the poor west african country. we are... asking health authorities not to underestimate the health crisis, said alfred ouedraogo, general secretary of the union of burkina doctors. for several months, there have been recurring breakdowns in laboratories, he said. in most health centres, there are no x ray films. the protesters marched to the health ministry and submitted their demands. health worker idrissa compaore said that ever since the introduction of free medical care for children under five and pregnant women, basic goods were regularly lacking at health facilities. the doctors also want the implementation of an accord signed with the government in 2017 promising better working conditions which they say remains only on paper.

protesteridentity: trade union groups and civil society organizations
sources: unions, civil societies maintain nationwide street action in burkina faso, xinhua general news service, september 16, 2019 monday 7:42 pm gmt, international news, 158 words, koffi
notes: many trade union groups and civil society organizations have maintained on monday a nationwide street demonstration against the government, despite the government s prohibition of the demonstration in the capital ouagadougou. demonstrators have defied burkina authorities that prohibited the demonstration based on security issues in the terrorist attack prone country and on non compliance with procedures. this monday morning, demonstrators have been heading to the gathering point bourse du travail from where the demonstration started. firstly, it is a question of demanding the commitment of the government to take measures to ensure the right of the population to security, to stop immediately mass and targeted assassinations, to dismantle death squads, to bring justice to victims of the assassinations, and also to demand the withdrawal of foreign military forces from our territory , organizers said. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: thousands of burkina faso civil servants protest bonus tax, agence france presse english, march 7, 2020 saturday 11:57 pm gmt, 247 words, ouagadougou, march 7 2020
notes: thousands of burkina faso civil servants took to the streets of ouagadougou on saturday to protest against a new tax on bonus payments. between 10,000 20,000 took part in the demonstrations, some singing the national anthem and chanting bread and freedom for the people , an afp reporter saw. the government in february extended an exceptional tax on civil servants bonuses. according to authorities it was needed to bring civil servants into line with private sector workers. of the country s 200,000 civil servants, 190,000 saw their salary in february decrease by 1,000 5,0000 west african cfa francs 1.5 7.5 euros, 1.7 8.5 . workers are being crushed by so many taxes. this new tax will not change anything in the country as long as the leaders do not make the competent management of the public good a priority, health worker sayouba compaore, 43, told afp.

sources: liberian soldiers fire at protesters the toronto star, june 27, 1990, wednesday, final edition, news; pg. a5, 362 words, reuter troops in liberia open fire on anti doe demonstrators the new york times, june 28, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 16, column 6; foreign desk, 169 words, reuters ;
notes: monrovia, liberia reuter liberian troops opened fire at random today to break up a demonstration of several thousand people calling on president samuel doe to resign. people ran for cover as troops with m 16 automatic rifles opened fire. witnesses in monrovia reported seeing protesters fall. the capital still crackled with automatic gunfire more than an hour later as soldiers disobeyed military police orders to cease fire. more than 5,000 trade unionists and students shouting doe step down! marched toward general doe s mansion overlooking the atlantic ocean. the march was the second in two days. but when the marchers tried to pass the army s barclay training center, soldiers in battle dress began firing and beating them.

sources: merchants protest price rise in liberia united press international, september 15, 1993, wednesday, bc cycle, international, 523 words riots over price hikes hit liberian capital the associated press, september 16, 1993, thursday, am cycle, international news, 502 words, by nyenati allison, associated press writer ;
notes: thousands of merchants from more than 22 marketplaces around liberia s capital took to the streets wednesday and invaded a government office to protestthe high cost of products sold to them by importers. the merchants, mostly women, chanted no government intervention, no market, and no selling until government talks, in a demonstration that forced lebanese traders to bolt their doors and speed away to safety. one woman was arrested, which further inflamed the demonstrators anger. they mobilized and within minutes thousands of market stalls became bare of goods and a stream of people kicking up dust began moving toward the city center, blocking traffic and creating havoc. the merchants have accused the ministry of commerce of conniving with the importers. but the ministry has denied the charges. tens of thousands of liberians enraged by rising food prices looted shops and stoned police on thursday, paralyzing a capital city already battered by civil war. riot police and troops from a west african coalition army, sent to liberia three years ago to put down a rebellion, used whips and tear gas to clear streets choked with rioters. no immediate reports emerged of deaths or serious injuries. the liberia marketing association, which organized the protest, issued a statement that was broadcast on state radio, urging its supporters to call off thedemonstration and conduct business as usual as the government looks into their grievances.

sources: angry protesters set up roadblocks agence france presse english, 387 words ;
notes: april 05, 1996 05:13 gmt more than 500 angry demonstrators friday disrupted normal traffic in monrovia s sinkor district by setting up roadblocks to protest the looting of their properties by fighters of a liberian militia group. a spokesman for the protesters told reporters fighters loyal to the ousted leader of the krahn wing of the united liberation movement, ulimo j, roosevelt johnson last night looted our properties worth thousands of dollars after government ordered us out of the area thursday. the spokesman also blamed authorities for failure to provide protection for their homes, and demanded that johnson leave their area. we will maintain these roadblocks until government can guarantee protection for our homes, and only vehicles belonging to the african peacekeepers ecomog will be allowed to go through, a spokesman for the angry protesters said. ecomog troops backed by tanks and armoured vehicles took up positions at street corners to prevent any violent action. the peacekeepers later brought in reinforcement as the crowd grew larger.

sources: refugee protest dispersed by liberian police associated press international, april 13, 1998; monday, international news, 285 words ;
notes: riot policemen used batons and whips to disperse an angry demonstration by liberian war survivors protesting against the impending closure of refugee camps in the capital. about 1,000 refugees from 35 camps around the capital of monrovia descended on the city center to fight a decision by president charles taylor s government to close some 35 camps and stop issuing food. several officials of the state run liberian refugees repatriation mission reportedly suffered minor injuries in attacks by protesters. the attacks could not be independently confirmed. authorities say they want to encourage the refugees many of of whom fled from rural villages during liberia s 1989 96 civil war to leave the scarred, bullet riddled capital and return to their original homes. the director of the liberian refugees mission, alexander kulu, said authorities had decided to end all talks with the refugees as a result of the protest. food deliveries would also come to an end, he said. those wishing to return to rural areas of the country would be given tools and building materials, kulu said.

sources: monrovia shooting incident spreads panic near defence ministry agence france presse english rioting ex soldiers storm defense offices in monrovia associated press international, may 05, 1998; tuesday, international news, 286 words one found dead in monrovia after ex soldiers protest agence france presse english ;
notes: soldiers fired warning shots near the liberian defence ministry tuesday, sending residents fleeing and prompting the west african peacekeeping force ecomog to seal off the area, an afp correspondent reported. one eyewitness said a soldier was shot in the leg as the troops fired briefly around 1:00 p.m. 1300 to disperse a protest staged by retired and demobilised soldiers demanding outstanding benefits. the shooting lasted about five minutes and the area around the ministry remained tense, the afp correspondent on the scene reported. hundreds of retired and demobilized soldiers demanding government benefits stormed defense ministry offices tuesday, brandishing knives and throwing stones. the crowd charged into the city s military barracks before moving to the main defense ministry building, where they broke into offices, destroyed furniture and threw stones at officials. government security officers fired into the air to try to disperse the crowds. the ex soldiers didn t leave, though, until tanks moved into the neighborhood. gunshots echoed across monrovia late tuesday, the day more than 2,000 retired and demobilised troops of the armed forces of liberia afl stormed the defence ministry, prompting security forces to fire warning shots that spread panic among residents, shopkeepers and schoolchildren who fled the area.

sources: former civil war fighters riot in liberia associated press international, august 31, 1999; tuesday, international news, 237 words ;
notes: about 300 former fighters rioted tuesday in monrovia to call attention to their plight three years after the end of liberia s civil war. the protesters, who belong to an association of ex combatants injured during the seven year war, spilled into the street in front of their headquarters and brought traffic to a standstill in downtown monrovia, police said. using sticks, stones and crutches, they attacked the car of an agriculture ministry official parked in front of the nearby ruling national patriotic party headquarters. the official, who authorities did not identify, was inside the building at the time and was not injured, police said. witnesses said police shot in the air to disperse the crowd, but police spokesman singe johnson denied there was any shooting. three people were arrested and charged with disorderly conduct, johnson said. the disabled former fighters have staged similar violent demonstrations in the past, saying they have been ignored by the government of warlord turned president charles taylor and international organizations. many now live in an overcrowded building provided by the state and survive on paltry government handouts.

sources: several students wounded in protest march in liberian capital agence france presse english, 201 words ;
notes: riot police in liberia s capital on wednesday wounded several students demonstrating in the streets for better educational facilities. police brandishing canes chased after and flogged students, who numbered at least 700. witnesses said hundreds of angry students began barging into private schools, disrupting classes and chanting: no public schools, no private schools, and pay our teachers. meanwhile education minister evelyn kandakai appealed to students to remain calm while the government made efforts to address your concerns. you have spoken, and made your point loud and clear, but let us not use violence as a means of solving our problem, she told students who had gathered at her ministry.

sources: source: liberian students protest schoolmate s murder by senior policeman agence france presse english, 172 words liberian police kill student during protest: press agence france presse english, 324 words ;
notes: more than 2,000 liberian students staged a violent protest in the central town of gbarnga to protest the killing of a schoolmate by the region s police chief, press reports said wednesday. the students, armed with sticks and machetes, marched through the town tuesday and burnt the car of the local police chief, commander isaac railey. they screamed we want justice, reports said. liberian police director paul mulbah had to go personally to gbarnga, about 160 kilometres 100 miles from monrovia, to quell the protest. upon his return, mulbah said: the bong county police commander isaac railey has been disrobed and suspended while a full investigation into the matter has been initiated. the pro government guardian newspaper said one student, morris johnson, was killed when officers of the liberia national police opened fire on the demonstrators.

sources: riot police use violence to break up student demonstration deutsche presse agentur, october 2, 2002, wednesday, politics, 200 words ;
notes: since the students were able to seize the building, it would appear that their numbers were greater than 100. therefore, to code conservatively, this has simply been coded as 50 protesters on monday, the students peacefully walked to the education ministry where they seized the building and locked in education and transport ministry workers who work at the nine storey building. the action ended with the arrival of the education minister, who requested a meeting with student leaders and told the students the ministry was making every effort to get the teachers back to the classroom.

sources: liberian police chief leads attack on school pupils agence france presse english, october 2, 2002 wednesday, international news, 173 words ;
notes: since there was a need for riot police, it would be safe to assume that this protest has 50 protesters. however, there is no indication that it would range greater than 100, so the conservative approach is applied and therefore the involvement is left at 50 . liberia s police chief paul mulbah on wednesday led riot police in whipping school pupils to break up a peaceful protest in monrovia, journalists at the scene reported. they said riot police whipped, kicked and punched the student protesters in front of the education ministry where they had gathered to complain to the minister, evelyn kandakai, about a strike by schoolteachers.

sources: going into liberia the globe and mail canada , july 4, 2003 friday, editorial; pg. a14, 484 words ;
notes: it is uncertain what the author of the article implied when he said large crowds , but i feel it is safe to assume that there are at least 50 people involved in this protest. large crowds took to monrovia s streets yesterday in protests designed to pressure liberian president charles taylor into resigning and leaving the country, a key demand of rebel forces in exchange for a truce.

sources: rebels push toward the heart of the capital in liberia the new york times, july 20, 2003 sunday, section 1; column 1; foreign desk; pg. 3, 819 words, by somini sengupta civilians flee as rebels attack liberian capital; taylor government again in jeopardy the washington post, july 20, 2003 sunday, a section; pg. a15, 1071 words, karl vick, washington post foreign service ;
notes: earlier in the day, as rebels were still beyond the city limits, thousands of civilians flooded the streets, angrily confronting government militias to demand an end to the fighting and looting. the midmorning demonstration brought out desperate liberians with nothing left to lose. they ran toward monrovia s port, buoyed by a false rumor that west african peacekeepers had arrived. when they learned the disappointing truth west african peacekeepers are not ready to deploy they ran up and down a street bristling with militiamen, shouting for peace, threatening to run to the front line to push back the rebels themselves and angrily taunting pro taylor forces. disappointed, the demonstrators outside the port headed back toward town, but some proved more insistent, not turning back until police fired in the air and broke out their bullwhips. as the protesters retreated quickly, they shouted a new chant: no soldier! they all want to loot!

sources: women demand an end to violence in liberia the independent london , november 21, 2003, friday, foreign news; pg. 15, 220 words, jonathan paye layleh in monrovia ;
notes: hundreds of women marched through liberia s capital yesterday demanding swift disarmament of fighters who have preyed on women throughout the west african country s 14 years of civil war. we the women of liberia will no more allow ourselves to be raped, abused, misused, maimed and killed, shouted leymah gbowee, the protest sorganiser, in front of monrovia s city hall at end of the march. about 800 women took part in the noisy demonstration, many wearing white to symbolise their hope for peace. protesters waved placards bearing slogans such as women of liberia say yes to disarmament and disarm, disarm, disarm .

sources: ritual killings frighten and anger people in liberia s capital agence france presse english english, 607 words, terence sesay ;
notes: while there is not a sure way to tell how many women exactly are protesting here, since they are gathered under a specific name, and they were able to gain attention to present a statement to unmil and the transitional government, this appears to be at least 50 women. a series of ritual killings in the liberian capital monrovia is scaring and angering residents who have already endured successive wars which only ended in the west african country last year. women marched through the capital friday in protest at the murders in and around the coastal city and urging the police to take action against kidnappers known as heartmen , who make charms from body parts cut from their victims. gathered in the name of the women in peace building network, they later presented a statement to the transitional government and unmil urging them to put a stop to the ugly practice. the government s silent posture in the face of unfolding developments has the tendency to plunge the country into mob justice over the rule of law, the jpc noted in a statement friday.

sources: students riot over delays in reopening of state university deutsche presse agentur, march 24, 2004, wednesday, politics, 232 words ;
notes: do to the arrests and need for a breaking up of the protest, i conclude that the protest size was greater than 50 participants police broke up a demonstration in monrovia wednesday during which students rioted over delays in reopening the state university, closed since early 2003. eyewitnesses said three students were injured while two others were arrested when demonstrators attempted to access the justice ministry to express their grievances. police director clarence massaquoi has however denied breaking up the protest or arresting the students, saying thedemonstration was peaceful . student paul bordoe said the riot started when a meeting convened by the students to hear government reasons for the continued closure of the university turned sour, with transitional chairman gyude bryant reportedly raining insults at the students. i did not bring a bag of money to share, student bordoe quoted bryant as saying. the angry students are reported to have stopped bryant s convoy from leaving the university campus until he gave them a date for the reopening of the university of liberia.

sources: liberian rebels rampage to protest planned removal of finance minister agence france presse english english, 502 words ;
notes: since the article says the unmil brought the riot under control, this has been coded as a state response of crowd dispersal since unmil was brought it, in addition to accommodation, since there was discussion with lurd commanders. fighters from liberia s largest rebel group have run riot in the town of tubmanburg, northwest of the capital, to protest at a plan to remove finance minister luseni kamara from office, reports reaching monrovia said wednesday. a group of leaders of the rebel liberians united for reconciliation and democracy lurd decided at the weekend to replace kamara with director general of the cabinet soko sackor. on tuesday, lurd fighters rampaged in tubmanburg, waving automatic rifles and rocket propelled grenades and chanting no luseni, no disarmament. unless the decision to remove kamara was reversed, the disgruntled rebel fighters threatened to reoccupy areas they once controlled but which are now under control of the united nations mission in liberia unmil . she said it took almost a day before the pakistani contingent of unmil deployed in the area and brought the riot under control. she said unmil brought the situation under control following discussions with lurd commanders.

sources: un police break up liberian student demo agence france presse english english, 180 words ;
notes: united nations police and their liberian counterparts used tear gas friday to break up a protest in monrovia by thousands of students calling for salary arrears to be paid to their teachers, witnesses said. stores, supermarkets and other businesses in the capital of the west african state shut down as the students began throwing stones. but police from the un peacekeeping mission in liberia, known as unmil, along with the liberian police, intervened swiftly and threw tear canisters among the rampaging students. after they were dispersed from central monrovia, the students regrouped and proceeded towards the presidential mansion, but upon arrival on capitol hill, the seat of the presidency, legislature and supreme court, unmil police dispersed them again with tear gas.

sources: liberian market workers go on rampage, burn down monrovia ghettos deutsche presse agentur, september 13, 2004, monday, politics, 118 words ;
notes: thousands of market workers and street peddlers in the war battered liberian capital monrovia on monday rioted in protest of rising crime in the overcrowded city. armed with sticks and other crude instruments, stallholders and peddlers raided and burnt down ghettos in central monrovia and beat suspected criminals. the riot was sparked by the invasion of the central waterside market by a criminal gang early monday to settle scores for the killing of a colleague by marketers.

sources: ethnic mistrust sparks protest over liberia university appointment agence france presse english, september 15, 2004 wednesday 1:36 pm gmt, 426 words, zoom dosso ;
notes: students and teachers in monrovia have ramped up protests against the appointment of a new president for liberia s university, which has revived old ethnic tensions in the war battered west african state. more than 1,000 students armed with sticks, stones and iron bars flooded the streets of the capital outside the university of liberia on wednesday to protest the appointment of al hassan conteh as the new president of the institution. both teachers and students have strongly championed that the acting head of the university, james kollie, remain in place. teachers have also threatened to strike should their demands go unheeded. we have always said that we cannot accept someone who has not been in the country for so many years to become the president of the university, the teachers union said in a statement about conteh, a 1977 graduate of the university who went into voluntary exile in 1997 when charles taylor became president.

sources: ex soldiers riot as peace starts to slip away; with funds scarce and unemployment out of control, monrovia is on the brink of another downward spiral into violence south china morning post, october 8, 2004, news; pg. 13, 726 words, karen palmer in monrovia ;
notes: since this article notes that rioting has been going on the last few days, this has been coded as a two day protest. there is not enough information other than the plural days to allow me to code this as anything greater than two days. however, it may be the case that this protesting began before the october 7. due to the number of soldiers who have been taking part in disarmament, the dozens of soldiers is likely to be greater than 50. rioting has rocked liberia s crumbling capital, monrovia, in the last few days as dozens of ex soldiers demand the government live up to its promises. the former soldiers had laid down their guns in exchange for cash payouts and the chance to go to school. every day in liberia there is rioting because the combatants want to get into school, but we don t have the money we need for funding, said molley paasewe, spokesman for the national commission on disarmament, demobilisation, rehabilitation and reintegration.

sources: thousands of soldiers demonstrate in liberia to demand back salaries associated press international, december 21, 2004 tuesday, international news, 235 words, jonathan paye layleh; associated press writer ;
notes: thousands of soldiers demanding three months back pay from liberia s government threw up roadblocks and stoned cars during a demonstration in the capital on tuesday. between 8,000 and 9,000 unarmed troops in civilian clothes flooded central monrovia. they tore down street lamps and rolled rocks into the streets to erect barricades outside the defense ministry building. before the day ends, money will be here, shouted deputy defense minister joe whyllie to the crowd. the soldiers hissed, booed and pelted whyllie s car with stones as he drove away.

sources: extra u.n. troops deployed in southern liberia following protests over alleged ritual killings associated press international, january 25, 2005 tuesday, international news, 211 words ;
notes: since there was a need to impose a curfew, as well as bring in extra troops, i assert that this protest over saturday and sunday was greater than 50 protesters. since extra troops were deployed and a curfew imposed, i have coded the state response as crowd dispersal, as these are actions taken to ensure protesting does not continue. u.n. peacekeepers deployed extra troops to southeastern liberia tuesday to monitor a dusk to dawn curfew imposed following protests over alleged ritual killings. dozens of ethiopian reinforcements arrived in maryland county, 300 kilometers 185 miles southeast of the capital, monrovia, to help monitor the curfew imposed late monday by liberia s transitional government. saturday and sunday, citizens attacked and vandalized a police station, angry at the release of alleged ritual killing suspects, u.n. military commander joseph owonibi told the associated press.

sources: liberian civil servants strike in demand of salary arrears deutsche presse agentur, january 27, 2005, thursday, politics, 169 words ;
notes: since police looked on to ensure there was no violence, i have coded this as crowd dispersal, since it appears they were ready to disperse the crowd if necessary. additionally, since there was a need for this police force, i assert the number of protesters was greater than 50. strikers, some of whom are owed more than a year s pay, sealed off monrovia s main broad street and diverted traffic as police looked on to ensure there was no violence. civil servants are not getting an increment, and yet the prices of commodities have continued to skyrocket, said the president of the civil servants association, jefferson elliot.

sources: payments distributed to liberian military after riots agence france presse english, june 17, 2005 friday 7:45 pm gmt, 339 words ;
notes: the liberian government on friday began distributing back pay to former soldiers in the national army after hundreds of them rioted in the capital to demand their salary arrears. we have started giving two months salary to each soldier since friday morning, defense minister daniel chea told afp. we will finish distributing the payments within the next two weeks. hundreds of angry armed forces of liberia soldiers erected barricades throughout central monrovia on tuesday to demand their back pay. they looted the barclay training center barracks near the executive mansion but confined their vandalism to that outpost. armed with rocks and sticks, they held chea hostage for about an hour, dispersing only after the intervention of un peacekeepers helping to restore stability to the war torn country after 14 years of civil war.

sources: thousands march to protest weah loss in liberia elections agence france presse english, november 11, 2005 friday 3:07 pm gmt, 472 words u.n. forces, protesters clash; female politician looks set to win ap worldstream, november 11, 2005 friday, international news, 455 words, todd pitman; associated press writer liberia: weah supporters protest election results agence france presse english, november 12, 2005 saturday 5:33 pm gmt, 343 words third day of protests and boycott threat over liberian election agence france presse english, november 14, 2005 monday 6:30 pm gmt, 644 words ;
notes: thousands of supporters of liberian presidential candidate george weah hit the streets of monrovia friday to denounce vote results they claim were fraudulent that look to give his opponent ellen johnson sirleaf the win. police officers from the un peacekeeping mission in liberia shared patrol duties with liberian national police clad in riot gear, keeping the marchers confined to one side of the road that bisects the city. they waved branches and signs, and chanted no weah, no peace . we have been cheated, said a young man who would only give his first name, james. the people of liberia have been cheated and we cannot accept it. the protest follows a petition by weah s congress for democratic change party to the liberian supreme court to stop counting votes from tuesday s run off, which gave johnson sirleaf a 59.1 percent lead and a likely win. u.n. forces fired tear gas and used batons to beat back rock throwing supporters of a soccer star candidate who claims his harvard educated female rival stole liberia s presidential runoff. carrying signs proclaiming no weah, no peace and democracy in liberia is a lie , more than 1,000 of his supporters marched without him for a third day on monday. we marched on friday and got gassed, then marched on saturday, and are marching today again, said j onesimus nimely, palm fronds wrapped around his head and stuffed in his nostrils in anticipation of more tear gas following a clash outside the us embassy on friday with jordanian officers of the un force.

sources: liberia: weah supporters protest election results agence france presse english, november 12, 2005 saturday 5:33 pm gmt, 343 words third day of protests and boycott threat over liberian election agence france presse english, november 14, 2005 monday 6:30 pm gmt, 644 words ;
notes: since the un peacekeepers were keeping watch, this is coded as a state response of crowd dispersal since they were at the ready to intervene if the situation became violent. supporters of trailing liberian presidential candidate george weah gathered before the national elections commission nec saturday to protestpreliminary results that give victory to weah s opponent, ellen johnson sirleaf. about 500 protesters carried signs and banners reading: our vote, our future. please, give us what we voted for, and the elections were not fair. united nations peacekeepers, who kept a steady watch over the fans of former soccer star cum presidential candidate weah, reported no incidents of violence. carrying signs proclaiming no weah, no peace and democracy in liberia is a lie , more than 1,000 of his supporters marched without him for a third day on monday. they delivered copies of their complaints, already filed with the national elections commission, to the economic community of west african states ecowas and the ghanaian embassy before reaching the us mission in the militarized mamba point area. we marched on friday and got gassed, then marched on saturday, and are marching today again, said j onesimus nimely, palm fronds wrapped around his head and stuffed in his nostrils in anticipation of more tear gas following a clash outside the us embassy on friday with jordanian officers of the un force.

sources: liberian war widows demand benefits owed to husbands deutsche presse agentur, december 5, 2005, monday, politics, 170 words ;
notes: more than three hundred widows of soldiers who died during liberia s civil war blocked the entrance to the presidential mansion in monrovia on monday to demand the payment of benefits. the protestors held up traffic in the capital for hours, refusing to leave the street despite pleas from defence minister daniel chea and justice minister kabineh jan eh. chairman gyude bryant has heard about your problem and has asked us to discuss with you how you will be paid, chea told the group. the protesters were among 3,120 widows of armed forces of liberia afl soldiers who died in combat during the country s 14 year civil war. the first protest by a group of war widows took place in february his year.

sources: supporters of liberia election loser clash with peacekeepers, u.n. boosts security the associated press, december 12, 2005, monday, bc cycle, international news, 367 words, by jonathan paye layleh, associated press writer ;
notes: supporters of a former soccer star who lost liberia s first postwar presidential elections clashed with police and u.n. peacekeepers, prompting the u.n. mission monday to step up security across the capital. george weah, who claims the november elections were fraudulent and refuses to concede defeat, fired up hundreds of supporters in a speech late sunday, saying ellen johnson sirleaf s inauguration in january would not take place. weah s supporters later attacked u.n. and liberian police in the streets of monrovia, injuring several security officials, the u.n. said in a statement. police detained 40 of weah s supporters accused of rioting, the u.n. said.

sources: ex soldiers riot in liberia over pensions agence france presse english, april 25, 2006 tuesday 8:03 pm gmt, 453 words liberia s ex soldiers intercept presidential convoy over pensions agence france presse english, november 13, 2006 monday 7:45 pm gmt, 390 words peacekeepers in liberia fire weapons skyward to scatter demonstrators associated press international, april 25, 2006 tuesday 5:40 pm gmt, international news, 340 words, by jonathan paye layleh, associated press writer ;
notes: at the time of the protest, un peacekeepers attempted to disperse the soldiers; in the third article, it appears that the protesters were arrested by the un peacekeepers. in the second article, dated from november, it appeared that the president had started paying out the soldiers? request. hundreds of former government soldiers rioted in the liberian capital monrovia over pension payouts tuesday, injuring several people including two un peacekeepers. united nations peacekeepers fired into the air to disperse the angry soldiers who disrupted normal activities and the flow of traffic in the city centre, forcing banks and businesses to shut. the ex soldiers set up a barricade, burnt tyres and hurled stones outside the defence ministry office in the central business district. they stopped defence officials from leaving and smashed windscreens of vehicles belonging to united nations mission in liberia unmil . an afp reporter saw two wounded peacekeepers and a woman civilian being taken away in ambulances. most of the soldiers, numbering over 400, were in neighbouring countries when others were demobilised and registered for severance pay last year. others were demanding salary arrears. rectifying the previous government s negligence, sirleaf s government has started paying out the arrears. the u.n. troops could be seen detaining suspected rioters, but it wasn t known how many arrests were made by the force providing security in liberia after its 1989 2003 civil war. there were no casualties reported among the protesters.

sources: liberia s ex soldiers intercept presidential convoy over pensions agence france presse english, november 13, 2006 monday 7:45 pm gmt, 390 words ;
notes: the state response has been crowd dispersal followed by accommodation. at first, the security tried to move the protesters from the street, the president intervened and addressed the crowd and promised the meeting to come with their representatives. thousands of liberia s former government soldiers monday intercepted president ellen johnson sirleaf s convoy of cars as it drove through the capital demanding retirement benefits, an afp reporter witnessed. brandishing placards reading we want our benefits, some 2,000 former armed forces of liberia afl fighters and widows of late soldiers blocked a city centre road while sirleaf was on her way to preside over an official ceremony at monrovia city hall. as the presidential security tried to forcefully drive the ex soldiers from the street, sirleaf stepped out of her car to speak with the former combatants. the un united nations told us that the government was responsible for our insurance, death benefit, and retirement benefits. this is the reason we have decided to come and meet you, madame president, said a retired colonel narrison keyon, spokesperson of the group. and this is the only way our grievances can be addressed, he said. sirleaf, who is also the commander in chief of the afl, calmed down the angry ex soldiers warning them not to resort to mounting roadblocks to air their grievances. i want you people to be very peaceful as you come out to express your grievances, said sirleaf, passionately referred to by her supporters as the iron lady of liberia. i will be meeting with your representatives this evening. the un head, defence officials and relevant agencies will be present at that meeting so we can find a solution, she promised before the group dispersed.

sources: liberian students protest in solidarity with unpaid teachers agence france presse english, november 15, 2006 wednesday 5:54 pm gmt, 357 words pupils riot over teacher pay brings liberian city to a halt agence france presse english, november 16, 2006 thursday 5:05 pm gmt, 396 words liberia; student demonstrations in lofa africa news, november 17, 2006 friday, 625 words, the analyst pay promised for liberian teachers to end strike and riots agence france presse english, november 17, 2006 friday 9:22 pm gmt, 338 words ;
notes: in the first day of the protest, nothing was done to the students ? they were ignored. by day 2, the un peacekeepers moved in and dispersed the students as the police force was underequipped to deal with them. by friday, the education minister accommodated. hundreds of students took to the streets wednesday in the north of war devastated liberia, in solidarity with school teachers who have been boycotting classes over unpaid salaries. our teachers have put the chalk down because the government has not paid them, students spokesman ebenezer kpehe told afp by telephone from voinjama, the main town of lofa county, about 250 kilometres 155 miles from the capital monrovia. so if we cannot go to school, no government worker will go to work, said kpehe adding that hundreds of junior and high school students dressed in their uniforms had barricaded the main streets of voinjama. war devastated liberia s northern city of voinjama came to a standstill thursday as hundreds of school pupils rioted for a second successive day in solidarity with school teachers striking over unpaid salaries. an afp correspondent saw the pupils dressed in uniform, armed with stones and clubs, destroy a police station, public buildings and vegetable markets. less than a dozen unarmed policemen watched helplessly as scores of pupils broke windows and doors, and tear documents at the town s only police station. un bangladesh peacekeepers later moved in stop to riots and restore order, lifting away the barricades on the streets. the demonstrations are reported to be simultaneously taking place in the cities of voinjama and kolba, known as kolahun, where local authorities are trying to calm the situations. following two days of violent student riots, liberia s education minister promised on friday to pay one month s worth of salary arrears to teachers who have been striking for a month.

protesteridentity: former liberian army soldiers, police, special security and immigration officers
sources: liberian on high alert after violent demos agence france presse english, september 18, 2007 tuesday 5:00 pm gmt, 180 words ;
notes: heavily armed un military peacekeepers patrolled the streets of the liberian capital on tuesday alongside local and un police after demobilised soldiers staged violent protests overnight. witnesses said hundreds of former liberian army soldiers, police, special security forces and immigration officers took to the streets overnight demanding payout of their benefits. the angry demonstrators mounted barricades along the streets using rocks and logs or lighting fires in the middle of streets, disrupting the flow of traffic. they were dispersed by local police backed by un military and police force. police said only three protestors were arrested.

sources: police foil illegal demonstration by ducor residents the analyst, august 19, 2010 thursday, 723 words ;
notes: it would appear, due to the scale and amount of violence, that this protest is 50 . however, there is no way to indicate if this protest reaches 100 , so in an attempt to be conservative, this has been coded as 50 . officers of the liberian national police lnp yesterday foiled attempts by residents of the rock hill community to stage what was termed illegal demonstration which they residents wanted to use to present a petition to the national legislature to call their legislators attention to the current situation they are experiencing with the liberian government over ownership of the land they are currently occupying. the residents who have defied the government s orders on many occasions to vacate the community in order to give way to the renovation of the ducor palace intercontinental hotel grouped and marched down town to the capitol building before they were encountered by police officers led by deputy director for operation al karley who told angry residents they could not continue the demonstration in the absence of a permit from the liberian government. the decision by the police to stop the residents from continuing their demonstration irritated them claiming that it was their rights under the law to demonstrate freely as citizens of liberian, but the police deputy chief though acknowledged their concerns, insisted that they could not do so without a permit. according to our reporter, the situation became very violent few minutes later when the illegal demonstrators insisted on carrying on the demonstration despite the understanding provided by the police, and that in the process scuffle erupted between them and the police officers on hand wherein it is said the police used excessive force. i saw police kicking and beating pregnant women, old folks and children. even, they arrested a lot of them, leaving many with wounds, rep. kummeh claimed. according to the lawmaker, few days ago, ducor palace residents, who were ordered by the government to vacate the premises, approached him that they wanted to meet the honorable house of representatives to explain their continued resistance, adding that following the residents request, he rep. advised them to reduce their complaints into a petition statement and present it to the leadership of the legislature. rather, he admitted to the claims that some of the residents were arrested for violating the law of the nation, and added that the police had gone to the trouble spot to quell those he referred to as rioters and illegal demonstrators as part of the police normal routine to safeguard lives and properties.

protesteridentity: widows of the armed forces of liberia
sources: afl widows on rampage the analyst, october 20, 2010 wednesday, 626 words, h. mccarey marshall afl widows meet pres. sirleaf the analyst, october 28, 2010 thursday, 416 words ;
notes: although there was no evidence in the former article, due to the fact that the women apologized for resorting to violence in the second article, this protest has been coded as yes for protester violence. women claiming to be widows of officers, enlisted men, and wartime recruits of the armed forces of liberia afl yesterday crowded the interception of benson and lynch streets, in demand of the benefits of their spouses reportedly acknowledged by defense ministry authorities as missing in action. the demonstration staged by the women caused traffic jam between the two streets, prompting fear stricken shop owners to shut down in expectation of more trouble. but riot police arrived onto the scene as the traffic jam caused widespread frenzy across the city and as the queues of commuters lengthened at bus stops. as some of the so called widow demonstrators prostrated before riot police and lamented their plight and their inability to go to school, others confronted the police, raining insults and threatening violence if any attempt was made to disperse them. the police however managed to keep the riot from expanding and attracting other belligerent groups, which was the fear of many. president ellen johnson sirleaf has authorized the bureau of veteran affairs to look into the grievances of the afl widows following a meeting during which the widows apologized for resorting to violence in demand of their claims.

sources: several students arrested new democrat monrovia , march 23, 2011 wednesday, 457 words ;
notes: between 15 to 20 students will be dragged to court this week on charges of vandalism and disorderly conduct, amongst others, for their role in tuesday s violent disturbances in the city, police have disclosed. police deputy inspector for operations, al karnly, told this paper tuesday that the students, mainly from the monrovia consolidated school system, will face other charges, including assaulting police officers and inflicting bodily harm. on the other hand, eye witnesses told this paper that several students were brutalized by the police, leaving some with blood all over their bodies in the streets, while others were taken to hospital. hundreds of students from mcss the monrovia consolidated school system including tubman high and g.w. gibson, protesting for better conditions of service for their teachers, tuesday clashed with anti riot police after the aggrieved students besieged the capitol by pass and several streets in sinkor. we want to learn, but no teacher. we are protesting because our teachers have left our classrooms, saying no pay and government must increase their salaries. police authorities affirmed arresting some of the students who, chanting slogans, turned violent and threw stones at officers of the police support unit psu . the students, who were also mobilized from various government schools here, said government s protracted failure to address their teachers plight, which according to them, include low salaries and delayed payments, has left the instructors to desert classes.

sources: on eve of election, liberia protests turn violent the new york times, november 8, 2011 tuesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 4, 1217 words, by simon akam and emily schmall political tensions dampen liberia s runoff vote the new york times, november 9, 2011 wednesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 6, 818 words, by emily schmall; josh kron contributed reporting from nairobi, kenya cdc, police tune down tension the analyst, november 10, 2011 thursday, 950 words riot suspects released new democrat monrovia , november 10, 2011 thursday, 165 words, peter n. toby ;
notes: notes: hundreds of protesters clashed with the police and united nations peacekeepers here in the liberian capital on monday afternoon, leaving at least one person dead the day before a presidential runoff that the opposition has vowed to boycott. businesses shuttered and pedestrians fled the streets as united nations armored vehicles roared down tubman boulevard, monrovia s main artery. a running battle developed outside the headquarters of the chief opposition party, pitting its supporters against peacekeepers and liberian security forces, who fired tear gas and live rounds. claiming fraud in the first round of elections last month, the opposition candidate, winston tubman, has vowed not to take part in tuesday s runoff against president ellen johnson sirleaf, who won the nobel peace prize in the midst of a heated re election campaign. mother ellen johnson sirleaf, she s responsible, said george weah, a former international soccer star who is the opposition s vice presidential candidate. for shooting innocent liberians, it s wrong. the opposition headquarters were crammed with frenzied supporters after the clashes, and the body of a young man shot through the head was laid out in an upstairs room with other wounded. liberia s justice minister, christiana tah, said the elections would go ahead on tuesday as scheduled. she confirmed that one person was dead and three were injured. but at the city s catholic hospital, there were at least seven people injured from the clashes, five with gunshot wounds. we were dancing in the road; they started beating us, said solomon gardea, 30, an unemployed opposition supporter who said a bullet skinned the back of his head as he turned to run away. we were just marching for peace. hundreds of demonstrators supporting mr. tubman s boycott took to the streets on monday, throwing rocks and setting tires ablaze. the liberian national police responded with tear gas and gunfire, chasing demonstrators off the main road. about 50 people were taken into police custody, said a police spokesman, george bardue. police said the party had violated the prohibition and not only chose to hold unauthorized vigil and rallies but also allowed some of its partisans to stray unto the streets and set up roadblocks thereby hampering the free flow of traffic and the movement of pedestrians. it is not clear why the party chose to organize the event without a permit to do so, but its executives said the assembly was simply a peace vigil designed to draw international attention to the fraud in the first round of voting and that it was not a march, or demonstration, for which it should have obtained a permit. cdc officials negotiated the release of 84 of their partisans arrested following a riot that left one person killed.

protesteridentity: youth of congress for democratic change
sources: defiant cdc roam new democrat monrovia , november 22, 2011 tuesday, 515 words, boima j.v. boima & peter toby ;
notes: since there were police were overlooking the march, i have coded this as crowd dispersal, as they were ready to do such. between 400 to 500 youthful partisans of the opposition congress for democratic change cdc monday roamed through some streets of monrovia, blocking traffic and chanting with a coffin symbolizing one of their members killed during their 7 november riot and encounter with the police. police sources told this paper that the march went ahead without the party obtaining a police permit as is required. but some cdc leaders, who later told a local radio station that they were not marching on monday, insisted that they don t need to obtain a permit before engaging in a peaceful march . we are not marching. those cdcians on the streets are mobilizing others to gather at the party s headquarters since we cannot afford resources such as vehicles like the ruling establishment to bring our partisans here. permit or no permit, the cdc has the right to engage in a peaceful march, said samuel tweh, cdc campaign spokesman. the zealot cdc youths, clearly in potential violent mood, unleashed insults at onlookers and police officers on hand to ensure law and order.

sources: lawmakers to empower police new democrat monrovia , december 29, 2011 thursday, 222 words, boima j. v. boima ;
notes: a joint committee of the national legislature, in an emergency session, on thursday began probing the mayhem caused last week thursday and friday in monrovia and its environs during a protest by vacation job students over pay packets, according to house press and public affairs. he said the first branch of government would also investigate whether unscrupulous individuals infiltrated the protest that caused havoc and left the city vandalized. tens of thousands of youths under the cloak of vacation students besieged monrovia burning and damaging government and private vehicles and infrastructure worth thousands of dollars in protest over delay by the monrovia city corporation to pay them for a temporary christmas job scheme.

sources: police, protestors in feud over snowe;s alleged immorality the analyst, february 1, 2012 wednesday, 685 words, by alex yomah ;
notes: the capitol building ground which plays host to the liberian legislature was yesterday seen in intense feud when units of the liberia national police lnp tried to stop protestors from entering the fence. the protestors whose figure was put over 1,000 persons displayed varying categories of placards over representative edwin snowe s alleged immorality, a conduct liberian women say is disrespectful and disgraceful against womanhood. edwin melvin snowe, montserrado county district 6 representative elect, has come under increased tension from the liberian public over his alleged immoral act that was reportedly carried out during the bachelor s eve night of mr. patrick honnah, deputy station manager of the truth fm radio. notwithstanding, the issue took a different dimension yesterday, january 31, 2012 when several pro democracy groups presented their petitions to the 53rd national legislature to look into the matter. the groups which included the citizens united to promote peace and democracy in liberia cuppadl , the center for trauma counseling and conflict resolution ctccor and the anti crime activists aca liberia called on the legislature to investigate the matter and vowed to get down to the root causes of an act they described as naked party saga. yesterday s demonstration was in furtherance of a 30 day action that the protest groups say would compel concrete action from relevant stakeholders, including the national legislature aimed at getting to the bottom of the alleged naked funfair.

sources: ag besieged new democrat monrovia , november 19, 2012, 462 words ;
notes: students from several universities in monrovia, who on friday besieged the offices of the general auditing commission gac and demanded the immediate resignation of ag robert kilby for recently dismissing over 40 employees of gac, threatened to continue their protest today. mr. kilby s claim of budgetary constraints as his reason for dismissing the employees has been refuted by the dismissed employees who said they were sacked and branded as morlu surrogates. the students, headed by mr. parick saweh, standard bearer of the student unification party, besieged to the offices of the gac friday to press their demand.

protesteridentity: widows and kin of deceased and mia afl soldiers
sources: afl widows demand over u.s. five million the analyst, january 07, 2013, 1006 words ;
notes: as estimated 3,765 liberian women claiming to be widows and daughters of afl mias, last week, began an indefinite sit in action on the sidewalk opposite the ministry of foreign affairs, which houses the offices of the president of liberia. the sit in action, which observers say is actually a siege of the president s office, is part of the group s recurrent demand upon the government. last year the group, along with other afl interest groups, blocked the main greater monrovia sinkor thoroughfare, demanding to meet with the president. the meeting with the president resulted in certain understanding and concessions, the details to which this paper is not privy. the sirleaf administration might have met the terms of the concession or dismissed it as a non priority, as no part of its 2012 2013 annual national budget contains appropriation for compensation for kin of mias. she said they were staging the siege in demand of more than us 5.0 million government owed them. according to her, each widow or child of an mia is entitled to us 1,500, neglecting to say how many mias there were and whether the expected recipients qualified as family heads or individual family members. though, the oldma has been seen us sitting on this sidewalk for the past days and has done nothing, we will continue to come here as early as 6:00 am daily until she makes a stop and address us since her protocol would not allow us to see her, the spokesperson said.

sources: ul tuition hike sparks protest new democrat monrovia , january 29, 2013, 681 words ;
notes: this event is coded separately from protest 2 because this protest 3 for 2013 is a protest of university of liberia students, whereas protest 2 for 2013 is a protest by the students of cuttington university. additionally, this is about the reduction of services by is about the hike in price in tuition at uofl, whereas protest 2 is about a reduction in services at cuttington university. angry students of the university of liberia stormed the streets on capitol hill yesterday, barricading the road in protest against an increase in tuition. the nearly 700 protesters blocked the two entrances to the main campus of the university on capitol hill, causing a huge traffic jam. waving placards with inscriptions no tuition increase, the president must intervene , the angry students shouted varying political slogans, accusing the university administration of increasing tuition in an unprecedented fashion. he gave no clear indication as to when the tuition will be increased. but the students, for their part, have already staged what has been described as a preemptive strike, and it remains to be seen whether or not there would be a compromise in resolving the matter if the ul decides to go ahead with its tuition increment.

sources: gov t in scholarship arrears new democrat monrovia , february 21, 2013, 721 words ellen urges students to change mindset the news monrovia , february 21, 2013, 922 words ;
notes: this event is coded separately from protest 3 because this protest 2 for 2013 is a protest of cuttington university students, whereas protest 3 for 2013 is a protest by the students of the university of liberia. additionally, this is about the reduction of services by cuttington university, as protest 3 is about the hike in price. this is coded as 50 because the article references only ? some? students. while it clearly drew the attention of the president and the administration of the university, since it was only noted as some, 50 is a conservative estimate of the protester participants. president ellen johnson sirleaf has admitted that her government owns higher learning institutions scholarship arrears through government s subsidy but promised that through the budget committee the arrears will be settled. the president did not say the exact time the arrears will be paid but said amidst competing demands that government has to settle its obligation to higher institutions of learning across the country to enable them provide quality education as was done in the past. the scholarship program is a scholarship program meant for scholars, meant for those who excel in education, and for those who are taking training in the area where they will serve their country best, she emphasized. in a release from the executive mansion, the president made the statement during an interactive engagement with students of the cuttington university during a recent stop over. the appeal came on the heels of a violent demonstration staged on january 28, by some students in demand for services that were reduced due to financial constraints facing the university. earlier, the president of the cuttington university student union cusu , david fekpolo, on behalf of the students, appealed to president sirleaf to increase government subsidy to the university as well as intervene in lifting the moratorium on the county s madam suakoko scholarship fund for deserving students.

sources: crackdown on protesters the news monrovia , february 14, 2013, 448 words ;
notes: since these protesters were described as huge numbers, this appears to me to have at least 50 people. reports from pleebo, sodoken district in maryland county say the emergency response unit eru of the liberia national police have dispersed a protesting crowd in the district. the news newspaper s correspondent in the area said the eru moved in to disperse the demonstrators who had taken to the streets for the second day on wednesday, february 13, 2013, in protest to what they described as bad labor practice by sifca. youth from villages and towns in pleebo sodoken district began their street protest tuesday, february 12, 2013, against the concession company. the placards toting youth blocked the entrance leading to the offices of sifca insisting that the liberian government intervene. the protesters in huge numbers were reportedly prevented by the emergency response unit of the liberia national police and officers of the armed forces of liberia afl from entering the company s compound. the protesters are claiming that they are not feeling the impact of the plantation since sifca took over. the cavalla rubber corporation crc and maryland oil palm plantation mopp are subsidiary companies of sifca group operating the cavalla rubber plantation in gedetarbo and former decoris oil palm in gbolobo. they said aliens are in top managerial positions that liberians should be occupying, something which they said violates the labor law of liberia. they stated that the protest will last for one week until relevant authorities step in. as they began their discussions, maryland county police commander amos darpoh and the regional commander mccarthy chelerk requested the protesters to vacate the city hall, a request the youth did not reject. the correspondent said the angry youth later moved on the side of the street opposite the pleebo city hall to discuss but the eru was called to disperse them. in the process of dislodging the protesters, four persons were arrested and taken in police custody.

sources: citizens demand forh resignation students mount demonstrations at his residences the analyst, march 11, 2013, 363 words ;
notes: since these were noted to be major demonstrations, the protests at forh? s residences have been coded as 100 . the chair of the legislative caucus of the county, edward forh, is now particularly feeling the pinch of the ghost as groups of students of the borough of new kru town stormed two of his homes and threatening more actions in demand for his immediate resignation. nathaniel rogers walker reports a group calling itself borough university students union busu is calling on the representative forh to resign immediately. subu on saturday alone staged major demonstrations at the two residences of representative forh for what the group s chairman, a. nimley chea, called their lawmaker s lack of moral credential to continue representing them. the students leader clarified that they were not paid by any group or individual to stage the demonstration, but they were acting based upon their passion for accountability and transparency and to see the district developed compared to other communities in montserrado. representative forh is yet to officially comment on the issue, as he could not be reached for a response up to press time.

sources: 300 teachers in grand gedeh protest new democrat monrovia , may 08, 2013, 326 words ;
notes: schools in g gedeh county were monday paralyzed when about 300 teachers laid down their chalks demanding salary arrears. the educational board of grand gedeh county had to intervene to calm down the protesters. he gave a 10 day period to the teachers to hold their peace, but the period elapsed without the teachers receiving their pay. the situation was so serious that some teachers in zwedru, the provincial capital, hired motorbikes to reach to other teachers in the surrounding villages and ask them to also join them in demanding their seven month pay. we want our pay, we want our pay. this is unacceptable. how does the government expect us to pay our bails and feed our children when it is still delaying our pays, the teachers grumbled while leaving the classrooms. following the intervention of superintendent peter solo, the protesting teachers resumed classes on condition that their plight would be addressed within seven days.

sources: group protests against public works minister the inquirer monrovia , june 03, 2014, 396 words, jefferson d. tweh ;
notes: on monday, hundreds of youths staged a protest at the entrance of the ministry of public works on lynch street. the youths in strong words, demanded the immediate dismissal of madam weeks for failing to carry out her mandate as minister of public works.

sources: crowds protest over ebola center at e.l.w.a. the inquirer monrovia , july 24, 2014, 374 words, edwin g. wandah ;
notes: angry residents in elwa, a suburb of paynesville, yesterday barricaded one of the main entrances of the elwa hospital in the community, protesting against the erection of ebola center in the compound of the elwa hospital. the residents, mainly, women, men and youths were seen in their numbers with posters and placards at the entrance of the elwa hospital s first entrance protesting that the deadly disease, ebola should not be sheltered in the community. ebola is evil; it should not be built in this community, the residents chanted. when this paper visited the scene of the protest action, it observed that the protesters were unhappy and frustrated over the government of liberia and its partners desire to build an ebola center in the community. shortly after the arrival of district 6 representative, edwin m. snowe, and as the crowd grew bigger they demanded the immediate intervention of representative snowe, while, some of them were seen in tears as they cried that the ebola situation may affect them one way or the other. our reporter who was on the scene vividly saw a group of protesters gathering in their numbers with some of them using profane languages against almost everybody, the government of liberia, samaritan purse, and even elwa hospital, as well as rep. snowe for allowing an ebola center to be erected in the community.

sources: christians, muslims protest the news monrovia , april 02, 2015, 423 words, alloycious david;
notes: the provincial city of bong county in central liberia, gbarnga was reported to have been tensed on wednesday over a proposal to make liberia a christian state. some members of the muslim and christian communities staged a back to back protest that nearly resulted into violent clashes in gbarnga city over the proposal of liberia becoming a christian nation, which the muslims vehemently opposed. according to our reporter covering the event, businesses owned by muslims and christians in gbarnga were forced to shut down on wednesday as the protest nearly turned violent. a contingent of unmil nigerian military and police moved into quell the protest. the proposition resulted into two separate protests on wednesday between christian and muslim delegates which nearly turned violent; prompting the nigerian contingent of the united nations mission in liberia unmil to restore calm. the protest forced businesses to shut down as the two sides were engaged in bitter exchanges of words.

notes: during the appearance of minister werner, students of various high schools assembled on the grounds of the capitol building to protest the reported proposal by minister werner. the students displaying placards with different inscriptions said the proposal to close schools is untimely. the students called on the legislature to ensure that such plan should be opposed.

sources: the students protest and the president s decision is there any lesson from last thursday s protest? column the inquirer monrovia , july 06, 2015, 1381 words, atty philip n. wesseh;
notes: as rightly reported with all kinds of headlines, normal traffic in parts of the city of monrovia, mainly the capitol hill came to a standstill for hours as students staged a protest against recent policies of the education ministry to regularize the school calendar after the devastating ebola caused a stoppage in academic activities it was in the wake of these policies that the students last thursday staged the protest action, obstructing normal traffic in the capitol hill. the situation led to president sirleaf who was returning from the monrovia city hall in honor of dr. amos sawyer to disembark from her vehicle that was blocked or barricaded by the students, some of whom lay in the streets the students insisted that president sirleaf would not leave until circumstances surrounding the closure of schools on july 31, 2015 are adequately addressed. the students took over the main road from the monrovia city hall to the ministry of foreign affairs where the president is temporarily displaced as the protesters grew in numbers, a reinforcement of the police support unit psu of the liberia national police were immediately deployed to assist the executive protective service eps contain the situation. the situation which lasted for nearly an hour was brought under control later with the arrival of the psu officers and also when president sirleaf invited the leadership of the group of students to meet her at her office.

sources: protest for water at lwsc the news monrovia , august 17, 2015, 537 words, necus m. andrews;
notes: a civic group under the banner, water, sanitation and hygiene network on friday staged a sit in action at the offices of the liberia water and sewer corporation lwsc in monrovia. the citizens, mostly young people with placards said are demanding concrete action to improve service, governance and financing for water, sanitation and hygiene. they told reporters that their decision to gather at the lwsc was to express their opposition to the hash water, sanitation and hygiene condition being experienced every day by the population due to the corporation and other line ministries and agencies inability to live up to their statutory responsibilities receiving the group s petition, the acting managing director of the lwsc awedjie ibe dioha reaffirmed the entity s commitment to ending water poverty in the country. madam dioha promised that the group s statement will be taken seriously and will not be put under the carpet, adding that every necessary action will be taken to address issues raised by the campaigners.

sources: liberian teachers stay strong in anti privatisation struggle us official news, april 30, 2016 saturday, 367 words;
notes: on tuesday, 19 april, lucsed visited the capitol building to witness minister werner s appearance before the plenary of the lower house to address the ppp issue. members of the group used the opportunity and met with government representatives, who welcomed and supported its advocacy efforts and promised to thoroughly scrutinise the ministry s decision. while attending the session of the house of representatives and meeting with individual lawmakers, some teachers held a peaceful protest outside the capitol building holding anti ppp posters and a banner in opposition to government s attempt to outsource public primary schools in the country.

protesteridentity: business owners and civil society groups
sources: liberia bars official travel for two months to cut costs agence france presse english, february 7, 2017 tuesday 3:05 pm gmt, 277 words;
notes: liberian president ellen johnson sirleaf has barred all official visits abroad for two months, following protests over soaring prices as the local currency depreciates, the information minister said tuesday. the decision came a week after business owners and civil society groups staged a protest demanding that parliament take action to stop a surge in prices as the liberian dollar depreciated to the us dollar.

protesteridentity: protesters demanding the participation of their candidate in the upcoming elections
sources: supreme court besieged , the news monrovia , august 02, 2017, 182 words, james k. kadi, jr.;
notes: a group of supporters of rejected representative aspirant abu kamara on tuesday besieged the temple of justice demanding the participation of their candidate in the upcoming elections or else there will be no voting in their district. emmanuel karmo, spokesperson of the protesters, told reporters that they will continue their peaceful protest until kamara is allowed to contest the elections. karmo said after being denied by the supreme court, kamara resigned his position at the ministry of post & telecommunications and paid the requisite fine to the national elections commission for being in violation of the code of conduct. he argued that kamara is not the only person to have violated the code of conduct. karmo said in its recent ruling, the supreme court admitted that liberty party vice standard bearer harrison karnwea violated the code of conduct but requested nec to fine him rather than barring him from the process. he warned that if kamara is not allowed to contest the pending elections, they will ensure that there will be no election held in district 15 of montserrado county. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and was determined based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters demanding justice in a case involving general services agency director mary broh and a private citizen sheik a. kouyateh
sources: protestors attack chief justice, new democrat monrovia , september 06, 2017, 380 words, p. nas mulbah;
notes: angry protestors tuesday, september 5, stormed the grounds of the temple of justice and physically attacked chief justice francis korkpor, while demanding justice in a case involving general services agency director mary broh and a private citizen sheik a. kouyateh. the protestors who were supporters of mr. kouyateh blocked the main entrance of the temple of justice singing slogans such as we want justice; no justice no entrance for the chief justice. chief justice korkpor sat in his vehicle for more than twenty minutes while his securities and police tried to curb the demonstration but their effort was fruitless as the protestors resisted every force from the police and other security personnel. the protest erupted when magistrate j. kennedy peabody of the monrovia city court dismissed the case against defendant broh who was facing multiple criminal charges including simple assault, criminal solicitation, official oppression and criminal facilitation. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and was determined based on prior coding decisions

location: The Fendell Campus of the University of Liberia
protesteridentity: students who were reportedly denied by authorities of the public university to complete their registration process
sources: ul students, police clash, the news monrovia , november 16, 2017, 255 words, a. omaska jallah;
notes: normal academic activities on the fendell campus of the university of liberia were on wednesday disrupted when students and riot officers of the liberian national police clashed. the riot began when thousands of students were reportedly denied by authorities of the university to complete their registration process. the head of the affected students williams dee said it is frustrating for the ul administration to close the registration process, after the students have paid their fees at various banks, waiting to complete the registration process. student dee said their quest for administration to reopen the process has been peaceful. he said it is unacceptable for the administration of the university to deny thousands of students the opportunity to acquire education, adding that education is the right of all liberians. they have come to suppress us of our rights; this is unfair; since we used the diplomatic means and they refused, we will not relent until our quest is met; we must get our education, dee said during the protest, the administration of the university invited the riot police to help arrest the situation, something that led students to go on the rampage, thus disrupting normal activities on the campus. the riot police were seen using tear gas in an attempt to restore calm on the campus, which led to several students sustaining bodily wounds.

location: The campuses of the University of Liberia  UL  including the Capitol Hill Main Campus and the Fendall Campus
protesteridentity: protesters opposed to denying several students the opportunity to enroll this academic year
sources: protest continues at ul, the news monrovia , november 21, 2017, 254 words, a. omaska jallah;
