notes: normal academic activities on the campuses of the university of liberia ul including the capitol hill main campus and the fendall campus were monday disrupted by protesting students. the ul students have been protesting since the university authorities closed the registration process, thus denying several students the opportunity to enroll this academic year. during monday s protest, the students disrupted classes and vowed to continue their protest until the president of the university, dr. ophelia weeks can resign. the disenchanted students accused the ul administration of closing the registration process when thousands of students have not registered, having paid fees at various banks. the students leadership claims that there are more than five thousands students, who have not completed their registration process, due to the early closure of the process. the spokesperson of the university of liberia student union ulsu , jeremiah testimony barclay told newsmen that dr. weeks is the problem of the state owned university and she must immediately resign, something he said will restore a smooth learning atmosphere on the university. barclay said dr. weeks refusal to resign as president of the school will leave the students with no other option but to take the protest to president ellen johnson sirleaf s office at the ministry of foreign affairs in monrovia. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

location: Main and Fendell campuses of the University of Liberia
protesteridentity: protesters opposed to the closing the registration period when more than 8,000 students have not registered, though they have already paid their fees to the bank.
sources: weah intervenes in ul standoff, the news monrovia , february 08, 2018, 218 words;
notes: president george manneh weah has approved additional expenditure intended to enhance banking operations on the main and fendell campuses of the university of liberia to facilitate the late registration of students that missed earlier deadline set. according to an executive mansion release, the liberian leader further requested for the semester to be extended by one month in order to accommodate the late registration students due to the loss in time as a result of protests. meanwhile, president weah has urged students at the state run university to remain calm as his administration ensures their concerns are addressed. recently, there has been series of protests on the main campus of the university of liberia by students demanding the resignation of the university s president dr. ophelia weeks. the students accused the ul authorities for closing the registration period when more than 8,000 students have not registered, though they have already paid their fees to the bank. they accused dr. weeks of being insensitive to the plight of struggling students, most of whom are self sponsored. the protest by the students turned violent monday leaving several of their colleagues injured by several vehicles including the official vehicle of the speaker of the house of representatives, dr. bhofal chambers. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters against rising prices and corruption
sources: thousands protest price hikes, corruption in liberia, agence france presse english, june 7, 2019 friday 8:09 pm gmt, 656 words, monrovia, june 7 2019; thousands descend on liberia s capital to protest president, associated press international, june 7, 2019 friday 3:31 pm gmt, international news, 402 words, by jonathan paye layleh, associated press, monrovia, liberia; liberia president offers talks after protests, agence france presse english, june 11, 2019 tuesday 6:18 pm gmt, 341 words, monrovia, june 11 2019
notes: thousands of people took to the streets of liberia s capital monrovia friday to protest rising prices and corruption, posing a key political test for president george weah. the football icon is being challenged over the same issues on which he campaigned in his rise to the presidency of the impoverished west african state just 18 months ago. about 10,000 people took part in the demonstration, according to an afp estimate, while a police official put the turnout at around 4,000. some held aloft placards reading: we are tired of suffering and we want better living conditions. the mood was upbeat, with people dancing and singing. but in a country traumatised by years of civil war, many braced for possible clashes, and some stocked up on food, fearing prolonged disruption. in the event, the demonstration passed off peacefully, but protesters were unable to present their grievances as they had wanted to weah. instead they were told they should present them to vice president jewel howard taylor, ex wife of former warlord and president charles taylor, although she failed to show up. housands of demonstrators descended on liberia s capital on friday to protest former soccer star turned president george weah and the sinking economy while critics accused the government of blocking social media. liberian president george weah on tuesday invited opponents to round table talks to seek solutions to the country s economic woes, four days after thousands protested against rising prices and corruption. weah made his offer to leaders of political parties, civil society groups, elders, religious leaders, our traditional leaders, student leaders and the business community, in a speech aired on national radio. he suggested a round table discussion to afford them the opportunity to present their alternative views, or their suggestions on the economy . a protest coalition on sunday gave weah a string of demands with a four week deadline. they include improvements in areas such as human rights and corruption, as well as the prosecution of finance minister samuel tweah and central bank governor nathaniel patray in connection with financial problems at the central bank of liberia which led to price hikes. the coalition also called for weah and all of his officials to declare their assets.

protesteridentity: a group, including roots fm, that is critical of president george weah
sources: liberia shuts radio station critical of president, agence france presse english, october 10, 2019 thursday 5:53 pm gmt, 298 words, monrovia, oct 10 2019
notes: liberian police on thursday closed a radio station critical of president george weah, accusing it of inciting violence, and used tear gas to disperse people protesting against the move. roots fm, owned by henry costa, is one of the leaders of a group that organised a large anti government street protest on june 17, paralysing several areas of the seaside capital monrovia. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: civil society associations, including youth activists called the council of patriots cop
sources: hundreds protest in liberia over price hikes, corruption, agence france presse english, july 31, 2019 wednesday 4:31 pm gmt, 446 words, monrovia, july 31 2019
notes: hundreds of demonstrators clashed with liberian police in monrovia on wednesday during a march against corruption and economic mismanagement under former footballer turned president george weah. police fired tear gas to stop the demonstrators from approaching the parliament building in the capital, an afp reporter at the scene said, while protesters threw stones and bottles at officers. the protesters in the second major rally since thousands gathered on june 7 called on the government to improve living conditions amid spiralling inflation. police arrested at least five protesters. the demonstration involved dozens of civil society associations, including youth activists called the council of patriots cop who helped weah, 52, come to power.

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to the government closure of roots fm, a radio station critical of president george weah
sources: liberia shuts radio station critical of president, agence france presse english, october 10, 2019 thursday 5:53 pm gmt, 298 words, monrovia, oct 10 2019
notes: liberian police on thursday closed a radio station critical of president george weah, accusing it of inciting violence, and used tear gas to disperse people protesting against the move. roots fm, owned by henry costa, is one of the leaders of a group that organised a large anti government street protest on june 17, paralysing several areas of the seaside capital monrovia. heavily armed police riot units ringed the radio station building on thursday morning, making it impossible for workers to move in and out. they also fired tear gas on the station s supporters gathered outside. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: thousands march in liberia to protest falling economy, associated press international, january 6, 2020 monday 8:11 pm gmt, international news, 571 words, by jonathan paye layleh, associated press, monrovia, liberia; liberia police fire tear gas, water cannon to clear protests, agence france presse english, january 6, 2020 monday 6:25 pm gmt, 302 words, monrovia, jan 6 2020
notes: police fired tear gas and water to disperse some 3,000 liberians who had gathered in the capital monday to demand that president george weah take decisive action to improve the economy. dozens of riot police had been deployed in monrovia, the capital, earlier in the day. the government had assured security for the protesters. roads were deserted and many civil servants stayed off work as thousands marched. in the early evening, the police took action in the city center, firing tear gas in front of the headquarters of the press union of liberia. it was just an attack unprovoked said mo ali, secretary general of council of patriots, the pressure group that organized the demonstration. he said at least one person had been injured. the demonstrators want the president to fire his entire economic management team, said protest organizer h enry costa, who is the head of the group called the council of patriotsa. they have performed dismally and created the worsening economic situation we are in, costa told the associated press.

sources: liberian journalists protest alleged police brutality, agence france presse english, march 12, 2020 thursday 2:57 pm gmt, 381 words, monrovia, march 12 2020
notes: liberian journalists rallied in the capital monrovia on thursday, and some newspapers darkened their front pages, in protest at alleged harassment they face from security forces. the protest follows the death last month of liberian broadcaster zenu koboi miller, in circumstances which sparked outrage in the impoverished west african state. miller was allegedly manhandled by president george weah s bodyguards while covering a football tournament, and was admitted to hospital not long afterwards. he died of hypertension and stroke, medical staff told miller s family, which has accepted the explanation. some liberian journalists though believe he succumbed to injuries sustained during the bodyguard incident. on thursday, scores of journalists marched through monrovia toting placards bearing slogans such as stop beating me while i am doing my work and journalists are not your drums .

sources: sierre leone sees protest in favour of female circumcision agence france presse, september 10, 1996, international news, 182 words ;
notes: hundreds of women who practice female circumcision marched through sierra leone s capital tuesday calling on the government to halt all discussion against female genital mutilations in the media. the demonstrators, members of the bundo society, which specializes in genital mutilation, called for the outright ban of both local and international organisations advocating an end to the practice. the women carried banners denouncing organisations opposed to the practice, a move observers here said the government is unlikely to accept. a similar demonstration took place over the weekend in the provincial city of bo in which hundreds of women supported the practice, calling it a cultural heritage that should be preserved.

sources: sierre leone sees protest in favour of female circumcision agence france presse, september 10, 1996, international news, 182 words ;
notes: this protest is with regards to the first protest mentioned in the article hundreds of women who practice female circumcision marched through sierra leone s capital tuesday calling on the government to halt all discussion against female genital mutilations in the media. the demonstrators, members of the bundo society, which specializes in genital mutilation, called for the outright ban of both local and international organisations advocating an end to the practice. the women carried banners denouncing organisations opposed to the practice, a move observers here said the government is unlikely to accept. a similar demonstration took place over the weekend in the provincial city of bo in which hundreds of women supported the practice, calling it a cultural heritage that should be preserved.

sources: sierra leone stall holders protest trading restrictions agence france presse, january 15, 1997, international news, 228 words ;
notes: hundreds of market traders in the sierra leonean capital wednesday took to the streets to protest a government ban against petty trading in parts of the city s business district. chanting we want a place to sell and carrying banners reading trading is our own livelihood, the demonstrators, mainly women, surrounded police headquarters and the town hall. another group were seen marching towards state house, the seat of government, but was intercepted by police who diverted the protesters to police headquarters where inspector general of police teddy williams appealed to them to disperse and assured them their grievances will be looked into. wednesday was the deadline imposed by the government for the stall holders to stop trading in 14 main streets in freetown, in a move to end traffic congestion and prevent possible health hazards in the affected areas.

sources: sleone journalists demonstrate against draconian press law law agence france presse english english ;
notes: dozens of journalists demonstrated outside parliament here tuesday denoucing a new draft press law as draconian and urging president ahmad tejan kabbah not to sign it into law. parliament should recall the law on the press. press. kabbah don t sign press bill. stop this draconian law on the freedom of the press, read some of the placards carried by protestors.

sources: student killed on freetown campus amid crackdown on demo agence france presse english ;
notes: freetown, aug 19 afp at least one student was killed in a shootout with freetown police patrolling to stop an anti junta demonstration, state radio reported tuesday, adding that 35 people had been arrested. the incident took place monday at the campus of a nursing school in the capital, where seven students shot at a passing security vehicle, which returned fire, according captain abubakarr kamara of the defence department. some 35 people were detained and taken to the capital s maximum security jail, state radio said. witnesses said it was unclear which side started the fighting or whether the students were armed. both police and students accused the other of shooting incidents on monday. student leaders had called for a demonstration against the junta which seized power in a may 25 coup, but beefed up security seemed to have deterred most would be protesters from taking to the streets.

sources: sierra leone police disperse student demo with tear gas agence france presse english, february 28, 2005 monday 7:58 pm gmt, 245 words ;
notes: sierra leone police used tear gas monday to disperse a spontaneous protest by students from freetown s furah bay college angered about their exam schedule and the government s failure to pay their stipends. some 200 students, after hearing their exams scheduled for monday had been cancelled, marched to the office of the education ministry and then continued on to the main government complex in the western part of the atlantic coastal capital. upon arrival, they were barred entry to the complex by police who launched teargas to disperse them, eyewitnesses told afp. in response to the police action, the crowd, which swelled to include non students, set upon the gates with sticks and stones. police spokesman kruschev kargbo said many arrests were made but did not say whether it was of mostly students or other protestors.

sources: sierra leone police fire tear gas to disperse supporters of arrested opposition leader ap worldstream, december 7, 2005 wednesday, international news, 173 words ;
notes: it would appear that these supporters were against his arrest, and therefore are protesting the political process behind it. police fired tear gas wednesday to disperse stone throwing supporters of a sierra leone opposition politician, breaking up a crowd that gathered after authorities had detained and charged the politician with conspiring against the public order. some 500 supporters of charles margai gathered in front of a station house in the capital, freetown, where authorities held margai and 11 others. but police tear gas canisters scattered the crowd, which included some who hurled rocks at the security forces.

sources: secondary school pupils riot in sierra leone over arrest of leader agence france presse english, february 10, 2006 friday 3:50 pm gmt, 172 words ;
notes: since the police needed reinforcements and were able to overpower and burn the police station as well as six cars, i have determined there were at least 50 participants. police in sierra leone have despatched armed reinforcements to the small town of mile 91, after rioting secondary school students burnt a police station and six cars on thursday, a police chief said friday. there were no casualties, but eight students have been arrested, inspector general brima acha kamara told journalists. eyewitnesses said the riots started when a magistrate in the town ordered the arrest of a senior prefect at yonibana secondary school, alimamy kanu, for reporting to court late to answer charges of assaulting the school head s daughter. students reportedly attacked the town s police station, overpowered officers on duty and set the station ablaze. kamara said calm had returned to the town, some 120 kilometres 75 miles east of the capital, but definitely policing in that area would be adversely affected. this rebellious attitude by the students is a cause for concern, he said. traffic was disrupted for more than 10 hours thursday due to the riots in the town, which stands on a key highway.

sources: students attack station in support of unlicensed biker agence france presse english, may 30, 2006 tuesday 7:35 pm gmt, 268 words ;
notes: students wielding sticks set light to a police station in sierra leone and damaged two cars in protest at the treatment of an unlicensed motor cyclist, police said tuesday. deputy inspector general of police tamba gbekie said a man riding an unlicensed and uninsured motor cycle had ignored a police warning to stop and fled into a nearby secondary school compound. he then mobilised support from the students, who grouped and marched to the police station, chased out the personnel and set the building alight, gbekie explained at a news conference. the pupils also damaged two cars parked in the complex and destroyed a new police office complext under construction, in the town of lumpa, 20 miles 30 kilometres east of the capital. eyewitnesses told afp police fired repeated rounds of tear gas to quell the affray, which left one policeman with a broken leg and several students slightly injured. gbekie said quite a number of arrests have been made but failed to give details saying investigations are still ongoing. parents and relatives estimate that 30 students and 26 bike riders are in police custody and have been refused bail.

sources: source: five ex combatants arrested after sierra leone protest agence france presse english, september 1, 2009 tuesday 4:30 pm gmt, 267 words ;
notes: security officials in sierra leone said tuesday they have detained five ex combatants classified as mentally and chronically ill after a violent protestoutside the defence ministry. the five are being investigated by the police, defence spokesman brigadier yirra koroma told afp by telephone. he gave no further details, but added that benefits demanded by a total of 311 ex fighters who took part in monday s demonstration are being processed by the finance ministry . the leader of the ex combatants, corporal sam bestman, said they had been declared mentally and chronically ill by a medical board in 2006, and since then have been advocating for their benefits to be paid. bestman claimed that some men were wounded on monday when security forces broke up the demonstration but authorities have denied the statement.

sources: kono women denounce rape concord times freetown , march 8, 2010 monday, 495 words, mohamed massaquo ;
notes: over seven hundred women and school girls in the eastern district town of kono thursday took to the streets to denounce what they considered as an increase in sexual and gender based violence in the district. women clad mostly in black and white clothes and displaying hundreds of placards, processed through the major streets of koidu town to protest against the death of a 12 year old pupil who was allegedly raped to death by a 56 year old man, abu bakarr singatae. a resident of kono, singatae was alleged to have sexually assaulted the late girl, a situation that led to the protest by the woman, who are demanding a thorough investigation into the matter. hasanatu mansaray, one of the protesters, bawled that much has not been done by the government and other stakeholders to protect women against sexual abuse and ill treatment meted out on them by their men folks.

sources: sierra leone s graft war comes alive daily champion lagos , april 25, 2010 sunday, 957 words, tony okerafor ;
notes: since there were riot police stationed inside the courtroom in order to quell any potential disruption of peace, this is coded as crowd dispersal. very few people inside sierra leone had expected that president ernest bai koroma would take his anti corruption crusade into the highest echelon of political power in his otherwise impoverished country. since his all people s congress a.p.c came to power in 2007 following nationwide elections, president koroma has been speaking regularly about adopting a zero tolerance policy towards corruption. several times in the past, he s warned members of his government of the consequences of fraudulently enriching themselves. he had warned his officials that no longer shall we have sacred cows in the campaign against graft and that he would not prepared to stand in the way of the anti graft body if it indicted anyone for mismanagement or outright embezzlement of the national coffers, no matter how highly placed the accused is. if anyone was surprised to see mrs. kabbah in the dock a number of weeks ago, it would have been because she is a very senior member of the current a.p.c. controlled government in freetown. mrs. kabbah s high profile case pits her against the powerful anti corruption commission. crucially, too, she is a high ranking member of the governing party, and her friends came from all over the country to put on a visible reminder. outside the premises of the court, there were scenes that easily resembled a political rally, as dozens of women clad in red were chanting slogans and calling on the a.p.c. to intervene on behalf of one of their own. inside the courtroom proper, several riot policemen stood guard, in part, to put paid to any planned breach of the peace.

sources: lecturers strike may provoke student unrest concord times freetown , june 27, 2011 monday, 565 words, alusine sesay ;
notes: since the students who are unsatisfied and affected are from a number of different majors and departments, i have coded this protest as 100 . fears have been expressed by some students and authorities on campus that the sit down strike action by lecturers of fourah bay college fbc , university of sierra leone, if allowed to drag on, may provoke a student riot as there appears to be no end to the seeming standoff between the academic staff association asa and the ministry of education fbc administration. the strike action, now entering its third week, is becoming unbearable to students who had paid their fees to the college administration but getting no lectures at the moment despite exams just around the corner, according to information emanating from the fbc campus. debate among students on the unending impasse is said to be reaching feverish heights as nobody could tell when a compromise would be reached to allow normalcy to once again return to the campus. the situation is not helped by the fact that other departments like engineering and economics are taking full lectures while students from other faculties idle all day long without any sight of their lecturers. asa are demanding salary increment and a general review of the conditions of service of lecturers and the demands were backed by a twenty one day ultimatum to the college administration, starting friday 20th may 2011. the lecturers had threatened to withhold their services until their demands were fully met.

protesteridentity: students of the concerned students union
sources: 72 hr ultimatum for gov t fbc students to storm state house concord times freetown , june 29, 2011 wednesday, 396 words, alusine sesay ;
notes: since the source notes dozens of protesters, this has been coded as 50 . as there appears to be no end to the fourah bay college fbc lecturers salary strike, dozens of students yesterday staged a peaceful protest on campus, declaring a 72 hour ultimatum for the government to resolve the stalemate or they march to state house. since the fbc students union government was dissolved by the college administration in early may this year, the situation on campus remains unstable and fragile as there is no figure head among the student body. to ensure proper coordination of student activities on campus in the absence of a union, some students came together to form a body called concerned students union csu , providing temporal leadership to champion the course of their colleagues. thomas dixon, a second year student of the mass communication department and coordinator of the csu, said they had staged the peaceful protest to inform the college authorities about their concerns and also to announce a 72 hour ultimatum for government to resolve the issue relating to the strike action by lecturers. reacting to the concerns of the students, vice chancellor of the university of sierra leone, professor jonas redwood sawyer assured them of an amicable resolution of the strike action before monday. he further informed the concerned students that subsequent meetings have been held to resolve the matter within the course of the week.

sources: cottage nurses fear patients protest for safety concord times freetown , august 31, 2011 wednesday, 267 words, alusine sesay and patrick j. kamara ;
notes: since this is noted as dozens of nurse are in fear, it is implied to me that these statements came from women at the demonstration dozens of nurses at the princess christian maternity hospital pcmh known mostly as cottage say they now fear patients who harass and intimidate them as a result of the introduction of the free healthcare initiative. based on an alleged assault on a nurse by a mother whose child was awaiting admission into the hospital, nurses on monday august 29 hosted a peaceful demonstration to voice their grievances. ms. kamara alleged that since some mothers have taken to abusing the free initiative and do rain insults on nurses whenever they are at the hospital for treatment or even force their way into the hospital after they had been stopped by security personnel at the entrance, the government needs to deploy police officers at the facility to guarantee the workers safety.

sources: state house snubs free healthcare protest concord times freetown , december 20, 2011 tuesday, 437 words, ibrahim jaffa condeh ;
notes: a group of about 150 beneficiaries of the free health care scheme launched by the government barely a year ago on friday staged a peaceful protestmarch in the compound of the state house to express their grievances over a reduction in the budget of the ministry of health and sanitation which stakeholders say will have an adverse effect on the initiative countrywide. the peaceful protest that was expected to be addressed by president ernest koroma, a principal architect of the free health initiative, however ended in discontent as a state house senior official told the protesters that president koroma was unable to see them due to other pressing engagements. some of them blamed state house security for having prevented them from having an audience with the president.

sources: kailahun women demand equality in governance concord times freetown , may 16, 2012 wednesday, 404 words, mohamed massaquoi ;
notes: since this article notes that it was a host of women? s organization, i take that as an implication of 50 women in the streets. a host of women s organizations in the eastern district town of kailahun on saturday took to the streets in protest of what they considered as the continuous marginalization of women from participating in mainstream politics ; a development they said is also restricting them from making meaningfully contribution to the socio economic and political development of the country. a community based organization, the kailahun women in governance network, has partnered with the social enterprise development send to develop what is known as the kailahun district women s manifesto for 2012 , specially designed for female candidates contesting the forthcoming presidential, parliamentary and local council elections. the women of kailahun said they are strongly determined to make history by influencing the electorates to cast their votes for women candidates as well as political parties whose manifestos demonstrate faithful commitment to promoting gender equality.

sources: football fans storm state house in protest blast political interference in slfa election concord times freetown , july 30, 2013, 483 words, mohamed massaquoi ;
notes: this is noted as crowd dispersal because officials did not allow the protesters to give their protest letter to the president. hundreds of football loving youths yesterday stormed state house in protest against what they referred to as political interference by the government into the election of the sierra leone football association slfa , thus calling for the immediate resignation of sports minister paul kamara, whom they claimed had prejudiced the outcome of the election by openly declaring his support for one of the aspirants, mrs. isha johansen, against her opponents. the irate youths, who were solidly behind sierra leone footballing icon, mohamed kallon, staged a peaceful protest against the sierra leone football association slfa normalization committee s decision to disqualify kallon, rodney michael and others from contesting the presidency and other positions in the association s august 3rd elective congress. though the protest was peaceful, the group was, however, prevented from crossing the security post leading to state house to present a protest letter to president koroma. we want to talk to president koroma about what his minister and others have done to put our candidates out of the contest in favour of isha. the minister is working with senior members of government to deprive our candidates; we will continue to protest until appropriate actions are taken, one of the protesters, michael kamanda, told concord times in the environs of state house.

sources: ebola protest; world news in brief the sunday times london , march 29, 2015 sunday, news; pg. 30, 21 words world digest: march 28, 2015 the washington post, march 29, 2015 sunday, a section; pg. a08, 470 words;
notes: police in sierra leone fired tear gas at crowds protesting against a national lockdown that is intended to end the ebola epidemic. no location

sources: flood victims accused government of discrimination as thousands left stranded protestnovember 18, 2015 concord times freetown , november 18, 2015, 551 words, hassan gbassay koroma;
notes: over one thousand flood victims yesterday 16 november stormed the streets of freetown as they protested against alleged neglect and discrimination by government to relocate them to a new settlement. heavy rains in september caused flooding in freetown, leaving a humanitarian disaster as more than 5,000 became homeless, while properties worth millions of leones were destroyed. the government temporarily relocated the victims, mostly from slum areas in freetown, at the national stadium and the brima attouga mini stadium respectively. the government also promised to permanently relocate all the victims to a location outside the capital. almost two months after the humanitarian disaster, government on sunday 15 november started relocating some of the victims to makeshift houses at six mile, just outside freetown. but it appears not all of those who had sought refuge in the two stadia are happy with how the relocation process was planned and executed.

sources: three injured in sierra leone ebola clashes agence france presse english, january 26, 2016 tuesday 10:01 pm gmt, 439 words;
notes: witness fatu jalloh told afp: temper flared up this morning when the police tried to enforce the no trading order and dozens of youths and women rushed into the streets, hurling sticks and stones at police search teams. angry youths allegedly burnt down a police post in the northern village of barmoi luma, reports said, as police fired tear gas to disperse angry crowds. witnesses told afp by telephone that three youths were seriously hurt, with one shot in the head and another in the leg.

sources: sierra leone s president urged to sign safe abortion bill; president ernest bai koroma under pressure from rights groups to follow parliament s lead by signing bill, despite protests from religious leaders the guardian, february 3, 2016 wednesday 11:17 am gmt, global development, 920 words, umaru fofana in freetown and liz ford;
notes: but last week, hundreds of people joined religious leaders in marching to parliament in the capital, freetown, to petition mps to withdraw the controversial abortion bill. a parallel demonstration by dozens of mostly middle class women held placards calling on the president to sign the bill.

sources: wai soldiers threaten mayhem concord times freetown , march 02, 2016, 381 words, hassan gbassay koroma;
notes: over 500 demobilised wounded in action wai soldiers of the sierra leone armed forces yesterday stormed ministry of defense headquarters demanding document detailing payment of their terminal benefits. meanwhile, the cds assured the protesters that he had forwarded the documents to officials at the ministry of finance to process the severance payment, and pleaded with the men to exercise patience.

sources: sierra leone ebola survivors protest government inaction agence france presse english, april 4, 2016 monday 7:54 pm gmt, 425 words;
notes: ebola survivors jostled with police in sierra leone s capital on monday as they protested perceived government inaction over their care in a health system badly hit by the virus. several hundred protesters in freetown gathered in the city centre calling for the free health care and scholarships for their children they said had not been delivered. police pushed back male protesters while women and children stood behind barricades waving placards and shouting slogans. a smaller protest in the city of makeni attracted around 100 people, who delivered a petition to local government officials.

protesteridentity: sierra leone commercial motor bike riders union
sources: as police declares one wantedbike riders demand justice for death of members concord times freetown , june 13, 2016, 872 words, alus e sesay;
notes: the sierra leone commercial motor bike riders union has called on the relevant authorities to speedily investigate and come out with report on the circumstances leading to the untimely death of two of their members, and to bring their killers to justice. the commercial motor bike riders last thursday spearheaded violence in the capital, freetown, burning tires on the newly constructed hillside bypass road and the road leading to fourah bay college, attacking the new england ville police station at night and burning five motor bikes parked at the station.

sources: schoolboy shot dead by police at sierra leone protest agence france presse english, august 16, 2016 tuesday 6:18 pm gmt, 370 words;
notes: a secondary school student and a street seller were shot dead by security forces in northern sierra leone tuesday during a demonstration by youths angered by the relocation of a job training centre. police in kabala, koinadugu district, said youth activists set fire to homes, burning two to the ground, while the protesters spoke of a peaceful rally attended by dozens that was fatally halted by bullets fired into the crowd.

sources: as students demo at law courttheresa & co. put on le100 million bail concord times freetown , november 22, 2016, 470 words, patrick jaiah kamara;
notes: hundreds of students yesterday stormed the precinct of law court building, protesting and demanding the release of their colleagues who were arrested and charged to court for allegedly sharing a post on social media platform, which the police had considered to be an incitement and had the tendency to create chaos in the country. protesters were asked to stay outside the court premises. they were holding placards with inscriptions like: free theresa , we stand in solidarity with theresa , freedom of speech under threat among others.

sources: rival slpp factions clash at law court unknown protester shot womanjanuary 10, 2017 concord times freetown , january 10, 2017, 555 words, patrick jaiah kamara & hassan g. koroma;
notes: an unknown gunman who had apparently joined scores of sierra leone peoples party slpp protesters around the law court building on siaka stevens street in freetown yesterday allegedly shot one alfreda yeama kassay on the foot. it could recalled that a faction in the main opposition party had filed an application in the high court alleging that lower level elections were marred by serious irregularities that threaten the party s structure. the protesters, who marched towards the court building gates on state avenue and siaka stevens street, were prevented from entry by the police, who cordoned off the entrance of the court premises

sources: student dies in violent sierra leone university protests agence france presse english, march 24, 2017 friday 1:58 pm gmt, 367 words;
notes: a student has been killed and several others injured at a university near sierra leone s southern city of bo after police fired tear gas and live bullets during protests over a lecturers strike, police sources told afp. lecturers at njala university have been on strike since october, the beginning of the academic year, over unpaid wages and pensions, triggering protests there and in three other cities on thursday.

location: President Ernest Bai Koroma s mansion
protesteridentity: residents of one of the government emergency camps
sources: survivors of sierra leone mudslide face eviction from emergency shelters; government help has been slow to reach hundreds of families displaced by the disaster in august, who fear they will have nowhere to go, the guardian london , november 21, 2017 tuesday 7:00 am gmt, global development; version:1, 941 words, cooper inveen in freetown;
notes: the government of sierra leone has started closing down the emergency camps housing hundreds of families displaced by august s deadly landslides, despite many people saying they still have nowhere to go. after heavy rains triggered floods and a landslide in freetown on 14 august, killing an estimated 1,000 people and displacing three times that number, survivors moved into temporary camps while awaiting permanent resettlement, as promised by the sierra leonean government. most of the 98 families living in the two official government camps, largely funded by uk aid and the world food programme, had received financial assistance prior to the closure of the shelters on 15 november. but nearly 500 other families were staying in four unfinished buildings that had served as an informal refuge for three months. despite most having been approved for relocation assistance, the majority said they had yet to receive it. on 20 november the ons announced that verified survivors who had not received their aid packages would be permitted to continue sleeping in the formal and informal shelters until they did. that decision followed a police crackdown on a protest outside president ernest bai koroma s mansion by residents of one of the government camps, who claimed the ons was forcing them on to the streets without financial support. several people were injured, including a breastfeeding mother. note: the actual number of protesters was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions. note: the actual event start date was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: pro government demonstrators protesting what they said was a stolen presidential vote
sources: tensions flare ahead of s.leone presidential vote result, agence france presse english, april 4, 2018 wednesday 8:40 pm gmt, 245 words, freetown, april 4 2018
notes: hundreds of pro government demonstrators gathered wednesday in sierra leone s capital to protest what they said was a stolen presidential vote, hours before official results are expected. the outcome of the march 31 ballot pitting opposition challenger julius maada bio against the ruling all peoples congress apc candidate samura kamara was due to be announced at the start of the week. but the country s electoral commission had to interrupt the ballot count after a dispute over the method of tallying results left votes from 11,000 polling stations across the poor west african nation uncounted. kamara supporters marched in freetown wednesday evening, tearing down bio posters and alleging foreign meddling in the vote, an afp reporter said. security forces erected a cordon around bio s slpp party headquarters, where hundreds of supporters had already begun celebrating victory ahead of the expected official result announcement at around 2100 gmt.

protesteridentity: protesters demanding improvements to sierra leone s judicial system with regard to violence against women
sources: soaring sexual violence pushes s.leone to face rape culture , agence france presse english, january 14, 2019 monday 3:19 am gmt, 957 words, freetown, jan 14 2019
notes: mary was nine years old when her childhood abruptly ended. three men fed her sedatives then raped her. the family reported the attack to the police and identified the rapists, but no charges were ever brought. thousands of children and young girls were raped last year in sierra leone a silent epidemic of suffering in one of the world s poorest countries. mary and her family plucked up the courage to report the crime: many do not. we have a culture of rape in sierra leone, admitted chernor bah of the un s global education first initiative at a demonstration in freetown last month where more than 500 black clad protesters took to the streets over violence against women. those looking for an explanation of sierra leone s rape crisis often turn to the country s violent recent past. sexual violence against women and girls is a prevalent and destructive practice that still has deep roots in the country, despite various initiatives to eliminate it, commissioner of sierra leone s law reform commission rhoda suffian kargbo nuni told afp. many attacks go unpunished, and those that are reported often fail to end in indictments or make it through sierra leone s judicial system, rights groups and police say. court records show that in 2018, only 26 rape cases were successfully prosecuted and led to a conviction. some cases fail to make it to court due to a lack of adequate facilities to carry out dna tests to secure the necessary evidence. sierra leone s human rights commission in 2017 highlighted systemic failures, including inefficiencies and corruption in the judicial system for many cases being settled out of court or never going to trial. legally, rape is a criminal offence which carries a jail term of between five and 15 years, according to the sexual offences act of 2012 a law that sierra leone reworked and toughened specifically to combat sexual predators. but such sentences are rare. note: the actual start and end dates of the protest were not provided in the story, and are based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to the arrest of a former minister for alleged corruption
sources: s.leone ex defence minister released amid arrests, agence france presse english, december 31, 2018 monday 8:38 pm gmt, 364 words, freetown, dec 31 2018
notes: police in sierra leone fired tear gas and rubber bullets monday at supporters of the opposition all peoples congress apc party, injuring one, during protests following the arrest of a former minister for alleged corruption. dozens of people were arrested during the protest for disorderly conduct at the headquarters of the opposition apc party on monday , police said. police fired teargas canisters into our party office and one of our supporters was severely wounded , karamo kabba, a senior apc member told afp, adding the protest had been peaceful. we are not inciting anybody to perpetuate violence against the government, but we are against witch hunting of former government officials , apc secretary general alhaji osman yansaneh told afp. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: supporters of the opposition all peoples congress apc party
sources: clashes, arrests after s. leone court unseats 10 opposition mps, agence france presse english, may 31, 2019 friday 8:49 pm gmt, 333 words, freetown, may 31 2019
notes: the sierra leone high court on friday revoked the parliamentary seats of ten leading opposition party legislators, wiping out their majority in the chamber and prompting clashes with police on the streets of freetown. the court took the action against 10 of the 16 deputies of the he opposition all peoples congress apc who were being prosecuted for alleged breaches of electoral law linked to the legislative elections which took place in march 2018. the court also ordered an election re run for a parliamentary seat near freetown. nine of the deputies were kicked out immediately and replace by candidates of the ruling sierra leone peoples party slpp who had come second in last year s elections. the tenth will be replaced in a by election. apc lawyers said they intended to take the case to the supreme court. just minutes after the court ruling, violence erupted between apc supporters and police at the party headquarters in freetown. dozens of people were arrested for rioting, including senior party executives and former ministers, according to a police source. our supporters were teargassed in our party office for hours, by the police, the main opposition party s secretary general alhaji foday yanssaneh told afp. our party office was also vandalised and looted during the riot by the police. it s is very sad day for our democracy, yanssaneh added.

sources: ghanaian university students protest against compulsory meal xinhua general news service, june 10, 1991, monday, 208 words ;
notes: it would appear that the students protesting the compulsory meal are also, at the same time, protesting the hike in vacation rent. hundreds of students of the university of ghana today held a three hour demonstration on the campus here demanding for the withdrawal of compulsory meal at the university. the students also blocked a main road in front of the university and burnt lorry tyres, causing a halt to traffic. last week, the university authorities expressed concern at the high incidence of nutrition related complaints being reported at the university clinics and consequently decided to provide one meal a day for each student. the cost of the compulsory meal involved is to be charged against student loans meant for feeding and purchase of books. in a resolution presented to professor d.a. akyeampong, vice chansellor of the university, the students said the present system under which students have a free choice of where and what to eat should be maintained. the students, who claimed they had started a hunger strike and would boycott examinations, were also protesting against a 600 percent hike in their vacation rent. the university authorities called a meeting this afternoon to discuss the students demands. the students asserted that they would go on another demonstration, if the meeting did not come out with proposals acceptable to them.

sources: ghanaian government reappraises economic policies xinhua general news service, february 18, 1993, thursday, 182 words ;
notes: the ghanaian government held a top level meeting in capital accra on wednesday to reappraise its economic policies following an anti government protest on tuesday. according to reports reaching here today, thousands of ghanaians protested in accra on tuesday against some of the measures unveiled by president jerry rawlings in a budget report last month, particularly a jump in prices of petroleum products. under the measures, the price of petrol per gallon increased to 3.42 u.s. dollars from 2.28 dollars. the ghanaian government has accused four opposition parties of masterminding the protests. the pour parties have consistently put president rawlings to task for his economic policies. according to the budget report for 1993, ghana s economic growth slowed down from 5.3 percent in 1991 to 3.9 percent last year, mainly because of an unfavorable international climate and domestic difficulties. ghana s economy is a showpiece of the international monetary fund and the world bank for their structural adjustment program designed to revamp battered economies in africa

sources: university of ghana shut after clash xinhua general news service, march 26, 1993, friday, 106 words ;
notes: for the school to close, we would assume that at least 50 students made it to one of these protests. since a date is not given, i have assumed this protest to only have lasted a single day. the date i have included is that of the day the university was shut down, the 24 of march. the university of ghana in the country s capital of accra was closed down indefinitely on wednesday following clashes between demonstrating students and police, said reports reaching here today. the academic board of the university ordered all students, except foreign ones, to leave the campus and stay away until further notice. the students started to boycott lectures last week to demand an increase in their annual bursary loans from 90,000 ceids about 145 u.s. dollars to 200,000 cedis about 320 dollars . they had presented a petition to the education authorities during one of such demonstrations in accra last week.

sources: ghanian students protest lecturers strike associated press worldstream, november 16, 1994; wednesday, international news, 195 words ;
notes: hundreds of students from ghana s three main universities marched through the streets of the capital wednesday to demand the government and professors resolve a pay dispute that has delayed the start of classes. students from the university of ghana, the university of science and technology, and the university of cape coast presented a letter to the education minister and parliament speaker. university professors and lecturers went on strike oct. 1, just before the start of the academic year, to demand higher salaries. the government says their union s demand for an annual salary of 6.4 million cedis dlrs 6,400 is too high. they currently earn about dlrs 3,160 per year. students say they ll have to repeat the year if universities don t reopen by the end of the month.

sources: unions protest in support of 96 percent pay claim agence france presse english, 227 words ;
notes: civil servants in ghana are considering industrial action in support of a 96 percent wage increase claim following a spontaneous demonstration in accra, union officials here said thursday. a further demonstration is planned for april 19, according to tensson foli, branch chairman of the civil servants association. the ghanaian government has offered the civil servants between 23 percent and 26 percent. on wednesday over 500 civil servants marched around ministry buildings for around 45 minutes chanting in support of their claims. they have warned the government that they may take strike action if their demands are not met by april 30.

sources: two dead, 17 wounded in shooting at demonstration associated press worldstream, may 11, 1995; thursday, international news, 350 words, gilbert ayittey, associated press writer ghana, despite its successes, is swept by anti tax protests the new york times, may 23, 1995, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 6; column 3; foreign desk , 472 words, by the new york times government suspends unpopular vat agence france presse english, 307 words ;
notes: the demonstrations, the biggest in ghana in more than a decade, were in protest against worsening economic conditions. they turned violent following a clash between groups for and against the government of president jerry rawlings. it was not immediately clear how the shooting began or who was firing. police had fired warning shots several times to control the situation. hospital nurses confirmed the report of casualties. thousands of demonstrators chanting anti government slogans brought central accra to a standstill. as demonstrators, many of them wearing red arm and head bands and carrying branches and sticks, paraded through the streets, all shops in central accra closed to prevent looting. there was a strong military and police presence to prevent clashes between the anti government demonstrators and a pro government group, which also called a demonstration for thursday. armoured cars were deployed and road blocks set up at several vantage points. a helicopter hovered above as the demonstrators marched singing, beating drums and dancing. the placards criticized the government s economic policy, particularly the valued added tax, which has been blamed for huge price hikes in the west african country. civil servants and workers under the trades union congress recently mounted protests for pay increases. several opposition politicians called the demonstration under the name alliance for change, saying the economic situation in the country was getting out of hand. protesting civil servants demanding a 70 percent pay increase shut down the ministry of finance last week. then on may 11, 5 people were killed and 17 wounded when a pro government mob clashed with a crowd of about 10,000 marching on accra s large central market. the ghanaian government announced that it was suspending wednesday a controversial value added tax vat which has sparked demonstrations and the break up of the governing coalition.

sources: thousands demonstrate against cost of living in ghana associated press worldstream, may 25, 1995; thursday, 248 words, gilbert ayittey, associated press writer government suspends unpopular vat agence france presse english, 307 words ;
notes: commercial activities in ghana s second largest city were paralyzed thursday following a massive demonstration against the high cost of living in the west african nation. more than 20,000 people bearing protest signs took part in the four hour, peaceful demonstration that forced schools, banks and shops to shut down in kumasi, about 150 north of the ghanaian capital, accra. during a similar demonstration in accra earlier this month, shooting broke out and five people were killed. thursday s demonstration was organized by the alliance for change, a coalition of opposition parties protesting against the worsening economic conditions and the government of president jerry rawlings. many people are fed up with the government s economic policies, particularly a value added tax, which has been blamed for huge price hikes. the demonstrations are the largest since rawlings seized power dec. 31, 1981, in a military coup. his leadership was legalized with a big victory in multi party elections in november 1992, when he won nearly 60 percent of the votes. the ghanaian government announced that it was suspending wednesday a controversial value added tax vat which has sparked demonstrations and the break up of the governing coalition.

sources: students demonstrate over government education plans agence france presse english, 187 words ;
notes: several hundred placard waving students were restrained by police in the ghanaian capital tuesday as they tried to force their way into the offices of two government ministers. the demonstrators were taking part in a nationwide protest at government plans to make students pay university fees. around 700 students tried to enter the offices of the ministers of education and finance in accra. we see a conspiracy to make tertiary education a commodity for the rich in society, the national union of ghana students said in a statement signed by its president, emmanuel newman. the government of president jerry rawlings has proposed to make students pay university fees, typically of 500,000 to 1,500,000 cedis 430 to 1,290 dollars per year, as well as increase the interest rates on student loans.

sources: opposition demonstration in western ghana agence france presse english, 214 words ;
notes: around 5,000 people chanting anti government slogans marched thursday in the western ghanaian port of takoradi, a police source told afp by telephone from the town. dubbed wie me preko , or finish me now in the local fanti language, the demonstration was organised by the opposition alliance for change afc as part of a series against the economic policy of the government led by president jerry rawlings. the crowd at takoradi, 180 kilometres 110 miles west of accra, marched for three and a half hours singing and chanting anti rawlings slogans, the police source said.

sources: students demonstrate against university stoppage agence france presse english, 254 words ;
notes: some 4,000 university students staged a five hour demonstration here wednesday to protest at a dispute which has paralysed higher education in ghana for four months. the students marched from kwame n krumah circle, a major accra landmark, to the ministry of education in support of a call for the replacement of education minister harry sawyer. students attempted to force their way into the minister s office but were held back from police. police wielding truncheons and armed with tear gas canisters accompanied the marchers, but there was little violence, although a group of angry students broke the roof of a shed and tore up flowers near the minister s office. the president of the national union of ghana students, emmanuel newman, told the crowd sawyer should consider himself dismissed.

sources: rioting over ghana land sale leaves one dead agence france presse english, 319 words ;
notes: one woman was shot dead and four men were injured in riots by angry people in western ghana seeking to get rid of the chief for the alleged sale of communal land, police said on monday. the clashes sunday between an angry armed mob and police and soldiers also caused extensive property damage, police said. the mob was demanding the ouster of their chief, nana ababio, who was accused of selling their land at fiapre near sunyani, in the brong ahafo region of ghana about 440 kilometers 275 miles northwest of accra. fiapre townspeople alleged that the chief had sold their only arable land to the roman catholic church to build a university. the chief denied the allegation, asserting that the land was vested in the government. but the mob, armed with various weapons, stormed his palace and slaughtered two sheep to signify his unseating from his honorific stool. police said that, sensing danger, the chief and his family sought refuge in the roof. the mob, chanting war songs and determined to smoke the chief out, set fire to his room and fuelled the fire with dried peppers in a bid to suffocate him, but he would not budge. once the mob started vandalising the palace, a combined military police contingent as well as fire services were despatched from sunyani to rescue the chief. but the mob turned on the security forces and set about them with stones. they destroyed the windscreen of a military vehicle, and a policeman sustained head injuries. police said that in their attempt to gain access to the palace, the security personnel fired back and a stray bullet hit yaa sikayena, 25, and the three others. police said a pistol had been retrieved from the ringleader, kofi duku, who was arrested. a number of people suspected to have taken part in the attack have also been rounded up, while security forces were patrolling a deserted fiapre, police said.

sources: one dies, 11 injured as ghanaian football fans riot agence france presse english, 215 words ;
notes: february 08, 1999 date published since this notes that the match was boycotted on sunday as a result of the violence, i have coded it as taking place on the saturday beforehand, since the article is unclear as to what day the protest took place besides sometime during the weekend. coding it for saturday would imply the players had time to decide to boycott the match for sunday. one person died and eleven others were injured at the weekend when guards opened fire on angry football fans who tried to storm the palace of ghana s ashanti king at the weekend, police told afp monday. some 2,000 fans rushed to the asantehene s residence in kumasi, 200 kilometres 120 miles northwest of accra. the crowd was protesting the imminent nomination of the kotoko football club s chairman. the king, who is the life patron of the kotoko football club, has final say in nominating the chairman of the board of directors. when rumours circulated that the fans preferred candidate, herbert mensah would not be named to the post, the protestors decided to storm the palace. as a result of the violence, kotoko players boycotted their league opening away match away on sunday against challenger dwarfs.

sources: police, university students clash agence france presse english, 350 words ghana offers angry students 1.2 million dlrs to counter higher fees agence france presse english, 282 words ;
notes: according to the second article, about a week after the protest occurred, money was offered to offset the fees. university students protesting against an increase of fees of more than 500 percent clashed with a police striking force unit friday on the road leading to offices of president jerry rawlings. the students numbering about 700 sought to present a petition to the president on the controversial fee hike. they said they decided to present the petition personally because deputy education minister mohammed ibn chambas refused to meet with them when they sought to present it to him on monday. students forced their way through a human shield mounted by the police to prevent them from gaining access to the president s office. police used tear gas, water cannon and warning shots to disperse the crowd after students set fire to lorry tyres. they also burnt a coffin with the inscription j.j. rawlings initials rest in peace. ghana s government offered restive students more than a million dollars on monday to help to pay for higher tuition fees, following violent protests last week against the hikes.

sources: university students in ghana protest, boycott lectures agence france presse english, 332 words ;
notes: some 300 students at the university of ghana in accra demonstrated on campus and boycotted lectures thursday over hikes in tuition fees. classes were largely empty after student leaders reiterated their rejection of a government offer of 1.2 million dollars to help counter increases in school fees of up to 500 percent. meanwhile, the president of the students representative council, nii narku dowuona seized the opportunity thursday to criticize the government for its plan to pay 17 million dollars to lease a presidential jet. the provision for needy students is woefully inadequate. how can the government then get money to spend on something irrelevant like a presidential jet costing millions of us dollars, dowuona told afp. the university s vice chancellor, ivan addae mensah, said classes would be open for the small number of students who attended.

protesteridentity: opposition parties the npp, pnc, cp and ugm
sources: opposition parties in ghana march against government agence france presse english, 271 words ;
notes: about a thousand opposition supporters took to the streets of ghana s capital thursday to protest against the government s political and economic policies, in particular against layoffs and hikes in medical fees. the demonstrators, from five opposition parties, carried placards which read: is there any future for ghanaian youth? , young men are dying of poverty, and j.j. president jerry rawlings you have failed. they marched through the city s downtown area and headed to accra s parliament where five party leaders deposited a petition to the house speaker. police, armed with ak47 assault rifles, tear gas, truncheons and water cannons, followed the crowd but no incidents were reported. the opposition called on parliament to withdraw recent hikes in hospital user fees and to freeze public sector layoffs which have increased since the privatisation of many state owned enterprises. the opposition parties participating in the march were the new patriotic party npp , the peoples national convention pnc , the convention party cp the national reform party nrp and the united ghana movement ugm .

sources: ghanaian workers hold another pay demo deutsche presse agentur, february 25, 2003, tuesday, politics, 474 words ;
notes: this is the third protest in a series of protests within the week. however, there is not enough information about the first two events to code it efficiently following the coding rules we do not have a specific date or the city of the first or second protest . therefore this is the only protest in the series of three which is coded. angry workers staged a four hour demonstration in accra tuesday to protest against a controversial new minimum wage as the government faced its third such march by workers in a week. the accra workers, following demonstrations by their colleagues in the industrial city of tema to the east and the ho to the northeast marched with placards protesting against low wages. the government and workers were on collision course after several weeks of negotiation for a new minimum wage ended last friday without achieving a result. the workers in a resolution read by michael osei akoto, secretary of the accra district council of labour, criticised the government for announcing a new minimum wage while negotiations were ongoing. they called on the government to reconvene the tripartite committee meeting of labour, the government and employers and come out with an acceptable minimum wage or the council will advise itself on the next line of action to take . the workers described the new minimum wage, as woefully inadequate saying this cannot cushion them against the debilitating effects which usually accompany price increases . they said they were protesting against the manner in which government has been handling labour issues especially on wage increases, which is always treated as an afterthought and only compelled by labour agitation .

sources: ghanaians stage anti war demonstration xinhua general news service, april 2, 2003, wednesday, world news; political, 220 words ;
notes: some 5,000 people staged a five hour demonstration in the ghanaian capital of accra on wednesday against the us led war on iraq and called for an end to it, ghana news agency reported. the demonstrators, under the umbrella organization anti war campaign, marched to the parliament house, the us embassy and the british high commission and converged at the ministry of foreign affairs where they presented protest letters to ghanaian foreign minister hackman owusu agyemang. two protest letters were for us president george w. bush and british prime minister tony blair. a third letter was to protest against the ambivalent position of the government of ghana in connection with the illegal war against iraq. the protest letters said that the war had no basis in legality and international morality and that its objective was to promote the parochial interests of the america oil oligopoly. the demonstrators, who were from the socialist forum, the national reform party, the international socialists organization and the association of pan islamic cooperation, carried placards, some of which read: stop the war, oil not democracy, and the world needs peace. owusu agyemang said ghana is sad about the war and the government will soon come out with a statement on the issue.

protesteridentity: supporters of the national democratic congress
sources: ghana s ex president rawlings leads anti government protest in accra agence france presse english, may 6, 2003 tuesday, international news, 573 words, ben ephson ;
notes: ghana s former ruler jerry rawlings tuesday led a noisy but peaceful protest against president john kufuor s government to denounce spiralling prices, corruption and fiscal mismanagement during its two years in power. some 5,000 supporters from the national democratic congress ndc of rawlings, kufuor s predecessor, marched through the streets of the capital, accra, hurling insults at the new patriotic party npp government. the route of the march, from accra s kwame nkrumah square, named after ghana s first post independence president, to the bustling central market district, was lined with armed policemen. at some points the police had deployed water cannons. several shops along the route did not open during the three hour march, fearing it could degenerate into violence.

sources: ghana opposition stage second march against fuel price hike deutsche presse agentur, march 17, 2005, thursday, politics, 104 words ;
notes: thousands of ghanaian opposition supporters, including former president jerry rawlings, on thursday staged the second march in as many weeks against a 50 per cent increase in fuel prices. the protest organisers the committee for joint action, an umbrella group of opposition parties, said the west african country s cost of living was unbearable. former vice president john atta mills, who lost against president john kufuor for the second time in december last year, said the protests would continued until fuel prices were lowered.

sources: ghanian workers oppose sale of bank xinhua general news service, september 14, 2007 friday 5:30 pm est, 137 words ;
notes: ghanian workers on thursday staged a demonstration against the proposed sale of the central bank s 48 percent share in the agricultural development bank adb , as pressure mounted on the government to abandon the proposal, reported the ghana news agency. scores of members of the tema district council of labor tdcl of the trades union congress started the demonstration at tema and ended in the capital of accra. the demonstrators, accompanied by brass band music, presented a petition protesting against the proposed sale of the shares to nana akomea, minister of manpower, youth and employment. chairman of the tdcl wilson agana was quoted as saying that previous sales of state enterprises such as ghana airways had not yielded any dividends and adb must not be allowed to suffer the same fate.

sources: violent protest over ghana poll results agence france presse english, december 31, 2008 wednesday 8:40 pm gmt, 281 words ;
notes: notes: ghanaian police fired water cannon late wednesday on ruling party supporters who besieged the country s electoral commision in protest at presidential election results, witnesses and local media said. dozens of angry protesters wielding machetes and sticks attacked passing vehicles and local journalists after partial results from the run off vote gave the opposition candidate a lead. the demonstrators only dispersed after the regional minister for greater accra addressed the crowd and assured them of victory after the decisive vote in a remote constituency which has emerged as decisive. the protest lasted roughly two hours, according to security sources at the scene. an afp reporter saw broken glass and other debris in the aftermath of the demonstration. electoral commission officials at the scene refused to comment.

sources: protests herald new road tolls ghanaian chronicle accra , february 2, 2010 tuesday, 1034 words, stephen odoi larbi and michael boateng ;
notes: commuters and commercial drivers who ply the accra tema motorway and kasoa road have vehemently protested against the new road toll which has shot up from an initial gp0.08 to a record high of gh 1.00, representing about 500 percent increase. they argued that the new tariffs were going to worsen the plight of motorists, who are already walloping in abject poverty. we are the ones going to suffer at the end of the day. these commercial drivers are going to pass the cost onto us, noted cecilia owusu, a trader who uses the kasoa accra road for her daily transactions. commuters plying the kasoa accra road in the early hours of monday were left stranded, as commercial drivers embarked on a sit down strike to register their protest against the government on the new road user fee. the commercial drivers also threatened to increase their fares, should government go ahead with the new tax, in order to meet their daily sales . commuters, for fear of being late to work, had to pay exorbitant fares to their various destinations in the capital city, accra. others walked long distances to join commercial vehicles that had managed to a make a u turn on the opposite side of the toll both. a local radio station based in kasoa, pink fm, reported about how some commercial drivers blocked the main kasoa accra road, and threatened to burn car tyres, but for the timely intervention of some policemen who came to rescue the situation. this resulted in heavy traffic along the road.

sources: atimatim residents protest against bad road network ghanaian chronicle accra , february 16, 2010 tuesday, 279 words, frank mensah ;
notes: this is coded as a february 15 protest because this article does not give a date of the demonstration. therefore, following coding rules, it has been coded as one day, for the fifteenth of the month. residents of atimatim and nearby communities, including maase, besease and ampabame near nkukua buoho, have protested against the bad nature of the road network in the area. backed by a non governmental organisation ngo , operation save the suffering masses, and the assembly member, akwasi abeyie, the residents registered their protest with a demonstration through the streets of the communities, from atimatim junction through to buoho. some of the placards read: atimatim people are dying of dust and air pollution ; bad road not credible transportation system; and atimatim is part of ghana, save it from dust. the spokesperson to the group, who is also the chief of besease, nana kwasi kwarteng, indicated that the main road from pankrono junction, through the various communities, has remained un tarred for years. according to him, efforts to draw the attention of governments, past and present, have not yielded the required result, an indication that the area had been neglected. he said even though the government had been petitioned through the ministry of roads and highways, nothing had come out of it.

sources: massive protests over tema demolition exercise ghanaian chronicle accra , june 17, 2010 thursday, 581 words, richard attenkah ;
notes: a demolishing exercise, jointly undertaken by the tema metropolitan assembly tma and the tema development corporation tdc , to pull down structures in certain parts of the metropolis which have been built on lands believed to be portions of land on the ramsar site at klagon, along the ashaiman nungua main road, has attracted mixed feelings from tema residents. while some of the residents commended the two bodies for embarking on the exercise, others were of the opinion that the exercise was uncalled for, irrelevant, and unnecessary, especially given the fact that the organisers of the exercise did not give ample notice and time to allow owners of the structures to organise themselves properly. i am not saying tma should not embark on the demolition exercise, what i don t like, is the fact that they pasted a notice about the exercise last saturday, and on tuesday they were there demolishing peoples buildings, she stressed. though 216 structures were earmarked for demolition, only 16 were eventually pulled down, following a massive protest by land landguards protecting the property. the land guards which our sources say were smuggled from nima, maamobi and accra new town numbering over 100, started throwing stones, sticks, and other dangerous implements at the police and military personnel who were supervising the exercise. while some of the affected developers were explaining that they were not given any notice about the intended exercise, others declared that they were only served with notices last saturday. this, they claimed, was not enough to give them time to organise themselves for the exercise, adding that they had documents to cover the lands in question, and therefore saw no reason why the two bodies were bent on demolishing their buildings. the tma and tdc on the other hand, claimed that they had given sufficient time to the developers about the exercise, and do not understand why residents in the area should pretend they knew nothing about the exercise.

sources: northern chiefs unhappy over poor roads ghanaian chronicle accra , december 18, 2010 saturday, 392 words, edmond gyebi ;
