notes: because no date is given for this protest, following coding rules, this protest has been assigned to the 15 of december. the refusal of successive governments to pay attention to the extremely poor road networks in the northern region, has stirred the chiefs and people in 12 deprived communities along the yendi bimbilla road, to desperately remind the government to walk its talk of ensuring a better ghana for all. the irate chiefs and their people, with support from some community based organisations cbos , including the ghana development community association gdca , have therefore, embarked on massive demonstrations to back their demand for the immediate construction of the yendi bimbilla road. they complained that this particular road had been captured in almost every national budget without any work commencing on it, but the 2011 budget, recently read by the finance minister, dr. kwabena duffuor, according to the people, did not mention the yendi bimbilla road, which they said was a ploy by the government to deprive them of their share of road development. however, the protestors, including the chiefs, wielded tree branches and placards displaying inscriptions like no road no vote ; our foodstuffs are rotting in the bush ; 2011 budget is incomplete and where is the better ghana? among others. the aggrieved chiefs and people are therefore demanding that the ruling government commence and complete the construction of the road before the 2012 general elections, or risk losing their votes.

sources: gcb workers fight management ghanaian chronicle accra , february 10, 2011 thursday, 629 words, stephen odoi larbi ;
notes: workers of the ghana commercial bank gcb are up in arms against the management of the bank for imposing a 25 income tax on their consolidated allowances for the month of january, 2011. however, representatives of the various branches, numbering over hundred and clad in red armbands, stormed the headquarters of the bank in accra, to signify their seriousness over the issue. they threatened to lay down their tools, giving february 11, 2011 as the deadline, if the management failed to heed their call. but, in a move to bring down the tension, the public relations manager of the bank, j.k.a. duncan, told the chronicle in an interview, that the management was working hard round the clock to address the grievance of the workers, in order for peace to prevail. the management will not allow for a strike action. currently, they are in a discussion with the union of industry, commerce & finance unicof and the professional and managerial staff union pmsu , the umbrella bodies of the workers, to bring the matter to a close, he noted. he assured the general public and the customers of the bank that there will not be a strike action, since management has resolved to address the issue as soon as possible.

sources: gcb workers fight management ghanaian chronicle accra , february 10, 2011 thursday, 629 words, stephen odoi larbi ;
notes: workers of the ghana commercial bank gcb are up in arms against the management of the bank for imposing a 25 income tax on their consolidated allowances for the month of january, 2011. the workers, numbering over 2,500 nationwide, on wednesday embarked on a peaceful internal demonstration to demand a refund of their monies, claiming the deductions had affected their expenses badly. but, in a move to bring down the tension, the public relations manager of the bank, j.k.a. duncan, told the chronicle in an interview, that the management was working hard round the clock to address the grievance of the workers, in order for peace to prevail. the management will not allow for a strike action. currently, they are in a discussion with the union of industry, commerce & finance unicof and the professional and managerial staff union pmsu , the umbrella bodies of the workers, to bring the matter to a close, he noted. he assured the general public and the customers of the bank that there will not be a strike action, since management has resolved to address the issue as soon as possible.

sources: teachers hit the streets and abandon kids to their fate ghanaian chronicle accra , march 4, 2011 friday, 1571 words, issah alhassan ;
notes: isaac akwetey okunor also reports from the eastern regional capital, koforidua, that the regional minister and the regional director of education, dr. kwasi appea kubi and rene owusu boakye boateng respectively, were subjected to, what could be described, as a life threatening embarrassment by teachers from both the first and second cycle schools in the new juaben municipality yesterday. according to information reaching the paper, the teachers, who were clad in red head and wrist bands, amid red attires with inscriptions such as we are not fools , government cannot cheat us again , stormed the koforidua jackson s park, where school children, drawn from the municipality, were undergoing rehearsals for the forthcoming independence day celebration parade. the furious teachers, upon reaching the park where the celebrations would take place, asked the children to stop the rehearsals, since the government had not fulfilled its promise of the single spine salary structure ssss . they were made up of teachers from the ghana national association of teachers gnat and the national association of graduate teachers nagrat within the municipality. the minister told metro news that nobody had any malicious intention to treat the teachers unfairly, but he was sure there was a mistake somewhere that would be rectified as soon as possible. the regional minister and regional director of education, in a swift response, moved to the park, pleading with the teachers to allow the children continue with the rehearsal. they were, however, met with what could be termed as positive defiance. as if it was rehearsed, the angry teachers spontaneously booed at the minister and his entourage, saying we don t need you here , to the surprise of on lookers. the professional and high tactical approach displaced by the police personnel, led by the regional police commander and his deputy, to calm tempers down, was ignored by the teachers, who said they had no leaders. even though the teachers managed to bring the rehearsal to an abrupt end, the police were able to avert what could have been a possible clash between the teachers and the latter. however, one policeman, whose name was not readily established, was nearly lynched by the aggrieved teachers, when he was alleged to have passed an abusive comment at the teachers. the teachers became charged, and chanted all die be die upon seeing the police personnel advancing towards them.

sources: zongo youth, baptist church in near bloody clash ghanaian chronicle accra , may 18, 2011 wednesday, 496 words, chris twum madina rioters bailed ghanaian chronicle accra , may 24, 2011 tuesday, 628 words, ivy benson ;
notes: the second article provides evidence that the protest occurred on may 17. the timely intervention of the police averted what could have been a bloody clash between the zongo community at madina, a suburb of accra, and the baptist church in the same community, over a parcel of land that the two groups are claiming ownership of the dispute over the land was said to have travelled to the courts, where the baptist church won, but the local community would not accept the ruling, and rather went to the land in contention and locked up the church and school situated there, disrupting academic work for the morning. the leadership of the baptist church reported the incident to the madina police, who immediately responded, and came to remove the locks and barricades, before the pupils could have access to their classrooms, and the teachers their offices. this incurred the wrath of the protesting community residents, who had already gathered on the parcel of land in dispute. the protestors, mostly made up of the youth, pelted the police with stones, mounted road blocks, and smashed the windscreens of cars, including two police vehicles. efforts by the police to disperse the crowd, which had by this time become unruly, resulted in the firing of tear gas canisters and use of water cannons. in the ensuing confrontation, the police managed to arrest 22 members of the mob, who were later detained at the madina police station. the youth then retreated, re strategised and again invaded the madina police station. the prosecutor noted that on may 17, 2011, at about 7:00am, the police was informed that the road leading to the zongo township had been blocked and the demonstrators have gathered at the zongo junction. according to him, the police went to the scene and requested to know if they had formerly informed the police about the demonstration, but there was no answer from them. dsp blagodzi said the assemblyman arrived at the scene when everything seems to have calmed down, and the police had put off the fire set up by the demonstrators. suddenly, several people emerged throwing stones and other missiles at the police, damaging the windscreens of two police vehicles driven by two policemen with registration number 35363g cpl. emmanuel okerye and number 40249 l cpl. mahama adams, who were among the team of policemen, the prosecutor told the court. they entered the school premises and destroyed properties belonging to the school and individuals, while students were writing their wassec examination. the demonstrators matched to the madina police station and threw missiles and stone at the police, compelling the police to call in re enforcement to attend to the situation, the prosecutor emphasized.

protesteridentity: students of the university of ghana
sources: students spit fire over killer fees ghanaian chronicle accra , july 28, 2011 thursday, 718 words, daniel nonor ;
notes: students of the university of ghana, yesterday, took to the streets of accra in protest against the arbitrary increase in the fees of students of the university for the next academic year. the university of ghana recently adjusted user fees upwards to over 45 per cent for the next academic year, and this, the students say, is unjustified and extremely exorbitant, and are demanding an immediate reduction. the students, numbering over 600 and clad in red chanted, songs that denoted their displeasure at university authorities, especially, the vice chancellor, over what they term his hard headedness in listening to reason. some of the placards displayed by the students during the demonstration read: v.c must go, education war in ghana, we no go pay, sakawa fees, legon is not for v.c, atta, please call v.c to order, how can we be future leaders, if we can t pay fees among many others. smart business minds were also at play at the justice park, when traders took advantage of the occasion to cash in on the sale of vuvuzelas, which became a major feature of the demonstration. the demonstrators blew the vuvuzelas as they virtually run through the streets of accra as though it was a marathon, putting police personnel to a test of their fitness level. at the ministry of education, the hitherto peaceful demonstration was nearly marred, when the students demanded they be allowed to enter the premises of the ministry to present their petition, instead, they were met on the street by the mr. ayariga to receive the petition. they, however, attempted break into the yard, but were repelled by the police.

sources: police crackdown on ho demonstrators ghanaian chronicle accra , august 4, 2011 thursday, 1059 words, samuel agbewode ;
notes: a much publicised demonstration organised by the youth for action group, a pressure organisation allegedly affiliated to the national democratic congress ndc at the volta regional capital, ho, came to abrupt end yesterday, after armed policemen descended heavily on the defenseless demonstrators and arrested their leaders. the demonstrators were calling for the removal of the regional minister, mr. joseph amenowode, for what they termed as his poor leadership style, which is making the region lag behind in development. the demonstration began peacefully from the r.t.c park near the ho main market, through the principal streets of the town. the otherwise peace event turned into chaos from an attack by the police when the demonstrators got to the municipal hospital road, which is about 300 metres away from the regional coordinating council. in the ensuing confusion, the leaders of the demonstration, together with other members of the group, were arrested and pushed into a police vehicle and taken to the volta regional police command, leaving the rest who took cover in nearby buildings and kiosks. those arrested include alhaji bello, leader of the group, mr. idikoko, former ho central chairman of the ndc and mr. winfred agbemakpledo.

sources: ahonkyire demo shakes accra ghanaian chronicle accra , september 7, 2011 wednesday, 542 words, daniel nonor ;
notes: hundreds of ghanaians mostly the youth yesterday joined the young patriots in a demonstration dubbed ahonkyere na double double against what they say is the harsh economic conditions prevailing in the country. according to the group, despite the president s promise of a better ghana, more people continue to fall behind the poverty lines compounded by the high cost of living under his leadership. the young patriots further contended that though the president declared this year as an action one, harsh economic conditions have rather been inflicted on the people. they also mentioned the incidence of frequent gas shortages, unbearable utility tariffs, and what they termed as the fast track return of ghana to hipc status through a strange appetite for unplanned loans borrowings and the unmatched high levels of corruption of the ndc government . the demonstration began peacefully and slowly from the obra spot at the kwame nkrumah circle until they got to the trade unions congress when the demonstrators charged on a policeman who they say was writing down the registration numbers of taxis that were involved in the demonstration. the procession came to a standstill for over thirty minutes as the police manning the demonstration tried to quell the charged atmosphere.

sources: funsi residents hit the streets in protest over lack of development ghanaian chronicle accra , january 19, 2012 thursday, 400 words, sebastian r. freiku ;
notes: reports from the upper west region indicate that hundreds of residents from various parts of the funsi district, last week monday, took to the streets inprotest against neglect. the residents trooped from the various communities to the district capital to participate in the peaceful demonstration, which brought activities in the town to a standstill. the demonstrators, who are citing lack of development in the district, joined the leadership of the old students association of funsi osaf for the agitation. the police and other security agents deployed to maintain peace and order had no problem handling the protestors, as they comported themselves, and followed the approved routes. according to them, the government was being insensitive to the plight of the residents of funsi. the protesters alleged that the district assembly was not functional, because the staff were complaining of the unavailability of electricity, good roads, and potable water, which was affecting productivity.

protesteridentity: youth of aflao in the ketu south district
sources: massive demonstration turns violent at aflao ghanaian chronicle accra , february 23, 2012 thursday, 635 words, samuel agbewode ;
notes: since over 300 police were brought in from other towns, i have noted this protest as 100 . the youth of aflao in the ketu south district have gone on a demonstration to protest against the deletion of aflao from the list of the newly created municipalities in the country. the demonstrators, who started the street protest from the aflao border in the early hours of friday, carried placards, some of which read, enough is enough, aflao needs a face lift; we need municipality; ndc ketu south will become a rural bank; aflao deserves better; eva glo, ndc, do you want a change; and ndc please fulfill your promises to the people among others. the demonstration, which, according to some observers in the area, was the biggest ever in the history of the traditional area against a ruling government, brought economic activities in the border community to a halt for hours, as many business men and women left their goods to join the large crowd. over 300 police personnel from ho, anloga, tongu and the ketu north and south divisions were mobilised to supervise the demonstration. the police, initially, were in full control of the crowd, but when the demonstrators were returning from the denu junction to finally converge at the victoria park at aflao, they were overtaken by events, as some of the demonstrators became violent, forcing the security personnel to arrest seven of them. the protestors were however not deterred of the arrests, and demanded that their colleagues be released from custody, to which the police obliged in the name of peace. when contacted, the volta regional police commander, deputy commissioner of police dcop alexander bedie, who was at the aflao police station at the time, refused to comment on the violent and the shooting incident by the police, following the arrest of the seven demonstrators.

sources: ashanti potag lays down tools ghanaian chronicle accra , february 28, 2012 tuesday, 543 words, issah alhassan ;
notes: because this is the only article that mentions the sit down strike, i have coded the date of the article as the end date. however, it is possible that this sit down strike lasted past tuesday the 28. since it appears a large amount of if not the entire teaching body at kumasi polytechnic is on a sit down strike, it appears safe to assume the participants are greater than 100. academic work at the kumasi polytechnic k poly is expected to suffer yet another serious setback, following the decision by the teaching body to embark on a sit down strike, which began on friday. the ashanti regional branch of the polytechnic teachers association of ghana potag has asked all its members to suspend all forms of academic activities, in protest against what it describes as a total disregard for the association by the government and the fair wages and salaries commission fwsc . their decision follows what they view as the blatant refusal of the fair wages and salaries commission to accede to their request to place its members on the right level under the single spine salary structure ssss . the polytechnic teachers are demanding what they term salary parity to that of their colleagues in the universities, since they all have similar job delineations.

sources: jomoro youth on rampage over relocation of gas plant ghanaian chronicle accra , march 2, 2012 friday, 530 words, ivy benson ;
notes: the location of the gas processing plant is determined by the government of ghana. the agitation of the jomoro youth association against the relocation of a gas processing plant from domunlinu to atuabo, in the ellembelle district of the western region, seem to have no end in sight as vigorous moves have been hatched to scuttle the transfer. the jomoro youth have warned that they will cause pandemonium and disorder towards any attempt to take away the gas processing plant from the people of jomoro, as they staged another demonstration yesterday, following a similar one organized some few days ago. in an interview with the chronicle, the president of the jomoro youth association, mr. mark asmah arthur, emphatically expressed the resolve of the youth in jomoro to boot for boot match any body or group of persons, who would be involved in the relocation of the gas processing plant from jomoro. meanwhile, government has indicated that people whose lands become affected in jomoro, would be adequately compensated.

sources: gimpa students demonstrate over new levy ghanaian chronicle accra , april 10, 2012 tuesday, 200 words ;
notes: since the rector told them their concerned would be addressed at an emergency meeting, this has been coded as ? accommodation? . since there is no date or day mentioned in the article, in accordance with the coding rules, this has been coded as the first of april. hundreds of students of the ghana institute of management and public administration gimpa have pulled down the back gate of the institution to express their anger over a new levy introduced by management of the school. according to the students, an amount of gh 50 imposed on them by management is a rip off and are calling for it to be scrapped. this followed several hours of a meeting between the management and the students representative council src which hit a deadlock. the students after tearing off the gate, beseeched the office of the rector who asked them to present a list of their concerns, which would be later addressed at an emergency management meeting. there were shouts of away and open the gate when the rector was addressing the students, who according to citifmonline.com sources boycotted lectures all in a bid to ensure that their grievances are duly addressed. this current agitation comes on the back of a milder one where the students protested an amount of gh 300 which is supposed to be paid by students who were re sitting papers they had failed in previous exams. the police were called in to curb any further damage to school property

sources: police arrest ken agyepong npp stages demo at police headquaters ghanaian chronicle accra , april 17, 2012 tuesday, 336 words ;
notes: since the protesters were able to able to block the way of the police van, i have noted this demonstration of being 100 a cloud of tear gas, live bullets and water canon could not disperse the crowd of mainly new patriotic party supporters massed up in front of the criminal investigations department of the ghana police headquarters in accra, as the chronicle went to press last night. it followed police decision to detain mr. kennedy agyapong, npp member of parliament for assin north, for allegedly inciting the population of this country. the vociferous member of the house had reported to the police voluntarily, following an invitation extended to him to report to help the police in their investigations into a statement he was alleged to have made on oman fm, the radio station he owns. when npp supporters heard of what was initially reported as an arrest of the mp, they jammed the entrance to both the cid and police headquarters. as with many such events, party faithful began arriving in singles and doubles until it became a flood. the chronicle learnt that when mr. agyapong was put in a police van ready to whisk him away to a location, likely to be the bureau of national investigations headquarters, they blocked the way. the police then fired tear gas in an attempt to disperse the crowd to no avail.

sources: farmers demand compensation from gov ghanaian chronicle accra , november 16, 2012, 798 words, stephen odoi larbi ;
notes: since no date was provided in this article, this demonstration has been coded for november 15, as per coding rules. incensed by the raw deal meted out to them, john cudjoe, madam adobea and mr. dorme joined hands with over two hundred people affected by the project to stage a demonstration against the government at okorase in the eastern region, demanding for the immediate release of their compensation packages. the demonstrators mounted blockade to halt all vehicular movement on the project road. clad in red and black attire and displaying placards with inscriptions like; pay us now , respect us , no pay, no vote , dust is killing us , we need our compensation or... . the demonstrators chanted war songs as they went round the blockade, in an attempt to prevent the police dispatched to the area from disrupting their movement. no amount of words from the security personnel could convince the demonstrators to back off from their actions. it took the intervention of the suhum kraboa coaltar municipal chief executive, samuel fleitcher to arrest the situation by ordering for armed police re enforcement, since in his opinion, the actions of the demonstrators was illegal. after succeeding in removing the blockade, mr. fleitcher arranged for a meeting with the affected persons at the town council, to settle the matter amicably.

sources: farmers protest against gha ghanaian chronicle accra , november 30, 2012, 538 words, stephen odoi larbi ;
notes: project affected persons along the accra kumasi highway lot 6, kwafokrom apedwa junction, yesterday took to the streets for the second time, and also went to the office of the municipal chief executive mce for suhum kraboa coaltar, to demand the immediate payment of their compensation packages promised them by the government. the demonstrators, numbering over two hundred, said they could no longer wait until after the elections, since they did not know what might happen when there is a change of government. a fortnight ago, the project affected persons took to the streets and mounted a blockade at okroase, a town near suhum, to prevent vehicular movement on the accra kumasi highway to demand for their compensation packages. following their engagement with the mce, some payments have been made to farmers whose farmlands were affected, as a result of the road construction, but the rest of the group members said the action of the government was not enough, until all of them had been paid. the amount paid is not immediately known, but the project affected person are entitled to gh 23,114,404.60 as compensation package. they termed the government s action as selective payments of compensation package, and warned to continue with the demonstration until they were fully sorted out .

sources: work on ashaiman roads resumes ghanaian chronicle accra , july 01, 2013, 293 words ;
notes: barely 24 hours after a section of the youth and commercial drivers in ashaiman hit the streets to demonstrate their dissatisfaction over the poor nature of roads in the municipality, work on the most deplorable stretch has commenced. the tema file discovered on its arrival at the area that an earth moving machine was busily spreading laterite, which was not there before thedemonstration on the bad stretch.

sources: bost workers demonstrate against board ghanaian chronicle accra , october 07, 2013, 619 words, richard attenkah ;
notes: the unionised workers of bulk oil storage and transportation company limited bost have embarked on a demonstration at the afram plains depot, near the former kpone police barrier, to pour out their grievances concerning the conduct of the board of directors of the company. the workers have, therefore, appealed to the government to immediately dissolve the board to prevent the company from collapsing, and also urgently appoint a substantive managing director md to manage the day to day affairs of the company. addressing a section of the media after the demonstration on tuesday, mr. daniel toah said another reason for staging the demonstration was a result of the poor utilisation of assets on the part of the board and management of the company.

protesteridentity: kiosk and container owners of official town
sources: ashaiman container and kiosk owners go wild ghanaian chronicle accra , october 11, 2013, 498 words, richard attenkah ;
notes: kiosk and container owners at official town, a suburb of ashaiman, on wednesday hit the streets to protest against the imposition of gh 100 as new permit fees by the ashaiman municipal assembly ashma . the angry property owners, clad in red head gear, t shirts and arm bands, said they were very unhappy over the development, especially the fact that they were not consulted before the decision was arrived at.

location: Suhum Municipality, Suhum Kraboa Coaltar district
sources: killer property rates demo hits suhum assembly ghanaian chronicle accra , november 01, 2013, 473 words, isaac akwetey okunor ;
notes: since this article notes the demonstration as taking place last thursday, i have coded it for october 24. had the article said thursday, or this past thursday, i would have coded it as taking place on october 31. the timely appeal by the mce follows a mammoth demonstration that greeted the area after thousands of residents in the suhum municipality of the eastern region poured onto the streets last thursday to register their displeasure over what they described as killer property rates. the residents, including old men and women who were led by executives and landlords association of suhum las started their peacefuldemonstration from the suhum roundabout as early as 6 o clock in the morning.

protesteridentity: anti merchant bank ghana sale protestsers
sources: anti merbank demo hits accra ghanaian chronicle accra , january 17, 2014, 551 words, mohammed awal ;
notes: a group of anti merchant bank ghana mbg sale protesters took to the streets of accra yesterday to register their displeasure in bank of ghana bog and the social security &national insurance trust ssnit decision to sell merchant bank to fortiz equity fund. the protesters, numbering not more than 200, displayed placards with inscriptions such as: tuc boss toothless , give us merchant bank , create loot and share , snnit account for our deductions , jdm heed the cries of pensioners , tony lithur can go to hell and ndc must go , among others. the government must reverse the sale of merchant bank, joseph otoo, a demonstrator told the chronicle. we are not opposed to the sale, he admitted to the chronicle, but it was disposed off so cheap and that is my concern, he revealed. the sale was simply ghastly said a 50 year old demonstrator, suleman mamma. why should i sit unconcerned to watch this illegality being perpetrated, he queried in an interview with the chronicle.

sources: police open fire on demonstrators ghanaian chronicle accra , february 04, 2014, 342 words ;
notes: two persons are feared dead and several others sustained various degree of gunshot wounds, when a team of police personnel from the striking force unit opened fire on demonstrators, who were protesting against the deplorable nature of the kenyase abirem road yesterday morning. about 60 police personnel, armed to the teeth, resorted to the firing of live bullets and tear gas into the thick crowd, to scare the demonstrators who had completely blocked the main road linking the kenyase antoa kumasi road. the youth were protesting against the terrible state of the kenyase road, which has not received any attention over the years from authorities, despite several calls. they prevented vehicles from moving to and fro, compelling passengers and commuters to trot to work. though the police defended their action by insisting they fired rubber bullets, some of the exhibits retrieved from the scene clearly revealed the security personnel fired live bullets. the security personnel also claimed they were compelled to fire the shots after the crowd attacked one of their men.

sources: bolga residents demonstrate against police ghanaian chronicle accra , february 25, 2014, 498 words ;
notes: hundreds of residents of bolgatanga, on thursday, demonstrated against what they termed as the unprofessional attitude of some police officers , regarding an exercise intended to enforce road traffic regulations. according to them, some police officers, whether they had been detailed to carry out the exercise or not, were now in the habit of impounding vehicles and motorbikes anywhere, and at anytime. ... and in what is a clear case of extortion, they demand that owners of the arrested vehicles part with an amount of money on the spot, or be ready to go court.

protesteridentity: metro mass transit mmt limited workers
sources: metro mass workers demonstrate against board chair ghanaian chronicle accra , january 14, 2015, 471 words, bernice bessey;
notes: it was a difficult task for dzifa ativor, minister of transport, to calm the tempers of metro mass transit mmt limited workers, who embarked on a one day nationwide demonstration yesterday, to express their discontent over some missing buses at some of the company s regional depots the irate workers were demonstrating against the board chairman, osabarima ansah sasraku iii, and deputy managing director john awuku dzuazah of the company, and called on government to remove from office after the transport minister had finished a marathon meeting with the union leaders, the angry workers made it practically impossible for her to address them, as they screamed and shouted. she, however, assured the workers that the incident that led to the missing buses would be investigated and the perpetrators brought to book. the irate workers were demonstrating against the board chairman, osabarima ansah sasraku iii, and deputy managing director john awuku dzuazah of the company, and called on government to remove from office.

sources: when a mad man marches against dum so mahama ought to indict himself for honouring the butcher of banjul ghanaian chronicle accra , february 20, 2015, 1335 words, ebo quansah;
notes: the party faithful were joined on the streets by thousands of ordinary ghanaians feeling the pinch of mismanagement that have combined with wrong policies to reduce this once proud nation into a land of want and depravity. the wanton dissipation of public funds and excessive borrowing have combined to send ghana back into the highly indebted poor countries bracket without the official proclamation. after several years of verbal protestations, the npp called their numbers unto the streets of the national capital. there is talk of a second demonstration in kumasi on february 24, obviously to be followed by other protests in the other regional and district headquarters across the country.

protesteridentity: movement for change mfc & new patriotic party
sources: demo stalls life in kumasi ghanaian chronicle accra , february 26, 2015, 575 words, richard owusu akyaw;
notes: the much talked about demonstration by the movement for change mfc , a kumasi based pressure group finally came to pass yesterday, as thousands of people poured onto the principal streets of the ashanti regional capital to remonstrate against the insensitivity of the national democratic congress ndc government. the demonstrators, who were clad in red clothes called for the resignation of president mahama, citing the erratic power supply which has left many people jobless in ghana as their reason hundreds of new patriotic party npp members joined the protest in solidarity with the organizers of the demonstration. addressing demonstrators at the abbey s park in kumasi, the executive chairman of mfc, dr. anthony nsiah asare said they intend to tell president mahama not to destabilize ghana after the hardship he has brought onto ghanaians.

sources: propaganda fails to fly, as dum so vigil pulls crowd ghanaian chronicle accra , may 18, 2015, 1052 words, pascal kafu abotsi;
notes: contrary to predictions that the dum so vigil will not succeed, thousands of ghanaians, mostly young people and celebrities, poured onto the legon tetteh quashie road in accra to register their dis satisfaction over the acute power outages the country has been plunged into for over three years the march, which started around the legon overpass at 4:30 p.m., saw the demonstrators, mostly clad in black t shirts, having the inscription dum so must stop embossed on them, making a peaceful procession, amidst singing, dancing and shouting of words of aggravation and disappointment at the mahama led administration over his inability to fix the never ending energy crisis. the police, who were dispatched to the scene to ensure peace, came out in their numbers, with about 200 of them guiding the protestors as they took to the streets.

sources: the washington post, june 21, 2015 sunday, a section; pg. a12, 569 words;
notes: bulldozers razed hundreds of homes and businesses in the impoverished sodom and gomorrah neighborhood of ghana s capital, accra, on saturday so authorities can start widening a lagoon to prevent a repeat of this month s deadly floods. some residents said security forces sprayed them with tear gas after they threw stones to protect their livelihoods from the bulldozers. by evening, thousands were stranded in the rain amid rubble and household goods that had been strewn for more than a mile. flood control has become an urgent problem for president john mahama s government since more than 50 people drowned in torrents caused by blocked drains three weeks ago. the same night, 96 people sheltering at a downtown gas station died when it exploded.

sources: nkoranza rebels against bog, gov t over closure of micro finance coys ghanaian chronicle accra , september 02, 2015, 586 words, michael boateng ;
notes: the irate customers of the suspended microfinance institutions have incessantly been organizing demonstration and invoking curses amidst the threat to boycott the local level elections the group continued their agitations against government and bank of ghana bog with a massive demonstration in nkoranza on friday, august 27, 2015 to reaffirm their threat that the powerful deities must deal with everyone who moves out to cast his or her ballot come september 1, 2015. size is unclear but massive implies there were at least hundreds of people.

sources: organised labour has genuine case ghanaian chronicle accra , january 22, 2016, 600 words;
notes: last wednesday, workers across the country, otherwise known as organized labour, embarked on a nationwide demonstration to drum home their dissatisfaction over the energy sector levies act 2015, as well as hikes in electricity and water tariffs. across the country, from tamale, wa, kumasi, takoradi, ho, sunyani, aflao, cape coast to accra and tema, ghanaian workers, clad in red t shirts and red bands poured onto the streets to demonstrate. the demonstration, according to kofi asamoah, secretary general of the trades union congress tuc was to impress upon the government to come out with practical solution to the problems the two parties government and organized labour had tabled for discussion.

sources: five detained over jb danquah s death ghanaian chronicle accra , february 11, 2016, 1071 words, pascal kafu abotsi;
notes: unknown assailants stabbed the generous mp to death at his east legon residence in accra, yesterday. the police had already picked 5 people for questioning. as early as 7am, hundreds of supporters of the npp, mainly from akyem tafo in the eastern region, had pulled in at his premises to commiserate with the family, who would not contain the untimely demise of their bread winner. they invoked curses on the perpetrators of the heinous crime, even as they appealed to the police to act with dispatch in investigating the matter.

sources: kojo bonsu s name pops up ... in the tafo disturbances ghanaian chronicle accra , february 29, 2016, 704 words, pascal kafu abotsi;
notes: when the chief instructed his men to pull down the wall, they were met with a fierce protest from the muslim community. two people died in the process. following the clash, the next day, scores of young people in the area gathered in front of the chief s palace, in anticipation of possible attacks from the muslim youth in the area. that was after the police had confirmed the arrest of one person who was firing gunshots indiscriminately in the company of a gang.

sources: i won t allow my subjects to be maltreated otumfuo ghanaian chronicle accra , march 08, 2016, 527 words, issah alhassan;
notes: his assurance follows a peaceful protest held jointly by some youth of tafo and agogo last week, upon his arrival from abroad, pleading with him to intervene to help resolve the conflicts plaguing the two communities. he, however, called for calm and restraints from aggrieved residents and urged them to abide by rules and regulations, rather than taking the law into their own hands.

protesteridentity: kayayes, traders, teachers, nurses, and students
sources: accra demo victim pops up in kumasi ghanaian chronicle accra , april 07, 2016, 258 words, issah alhassan kumasi demonstrators warn mahama, ec no retreat, no surrender ghanaian chronicle accra , april 07, 2016, 1055 words, issah alhassan;
notes: justice adjekuma made a surprise appearance in kumasi yesterday. adjekuma, who lost his left eye after being brutally assaulted by security men detailed to maintain law and order, once again joined the demonstration in kumasi to demand a credible register. people from all walks of life, including kayayes, traders, teachers, nurses and students took time off their busy schedule to participate in the well attended programme, which saw thousands of people parading the principal streets of the metropolis.

sources: ghanaian chronicle accra may 19, 2016 tema shipyard workers call for gpha take over byline: inusa musah length: 495 words dateline: tema;
notes: last tuesday, scores of workers of tema psc shipyard staged a vociferous demonstration when the minister for transport, fifi kwetey, paid the company a working visit. displaying placards, some of which read: our right has been denied , md must go and dissolve psc management , the demonstrating workers, led by samuel attram, said most of their customers had relocated to cote d ivoire, where they repair their vessels, following tunde s mismanagement and irresponsible and poor customer relation.

sources: world bank on fire ghanaian chronicle accra , august 18, 2016, 456 words;
notes: the youth of kpenoe, hodzo and takla in the ho municipality embarked on massive demonstration at ho yesterday to protest against the poor road network in the area. they carried placards, some of which read; our roads are bad , no road no vote , who is our mp in ho central , are we also not ghanaians , we are tired of empty promises from politicians , among others.

sources: donkokrom police station burnt down over escape of suspected police robbers ghanaian chronicle accra , august 19, 2016, 436 words, isaac akwetey okunor;
notes: the escape of two police personnel who were allegedly involved in the attack on the gcb bullion van at donkorkrom in the eastern region has angered residents of the area who launched an attack on the local police station, burning it down in the process. though the police fired tear gas and live bullets among others to ward off the threat from the residents, resulting in some of the irate residents sustaining injuries, they police were still overpowered and their barracks burnt down. some cars parked around the police station were also set ablaze by the mob.

sources: responding to racism debate, ghanaian campus intends to move gandhi statue; the government of ghana has agreed to remove the statue, a gift from india, and will move it elsewhere to protect the symbol of friendship between the two nations. the christian science monitor, october 7, 2016 friday, world, 497 words, rowena lindsay staff;
notes: ghana s foreign ministry intends to remove a statue of mohandas gandhi from a university campus, after a group of professors and students at the university of ghana protested the installation, claiming that the indian civil rights leader held racist views and should not be held up as a ghanaian hero. more than 1,000 people have signed a petition in support of its removal. although concerned about the bitterness unearthed by the campaign, the government has agreed to remove the statue and will move it elsewhere to protect the symbol of friendship between the two nations.

protesteridentity: youth of somanya in the eastern region
sources: somanya on fire over ecg bills, ghanaian chronicle accra , may 30, 2017, 563 words, isaac akwetey okunor;
notes: the youth of somanya in the eastern region, yesterday took the law into their own hands, by burning lorry tyres and blocking some of the roads in the town, in protest against the arrest of mr. jonas tetteh a.k.a dendenden , assembly member for the sawer electoral area. last week friday, a section of the townsfolks invaded the local offices of the electricity company of ghana ecg , and caused damage to assets of the state owned utility company. the residents accused the ecg of giving them outrageous bills, which did not match the actual power they had consumed. the police, after bringing the situation under control, arrested jonas tetteh on monday for allegedly instigating the residents to invade the ecg offices. the arrest, the chronicle understands, infuriated the people who poured onto the streets yesterday. the police, in response, fired tear gas, including warning shots, to disperse the rampaging youth, who were bent on causing mayhem. a gentleman from salosi, a suburb of somanya, was reportedly hit by stray bullets and was rushed to hospital. seven of the demonstrators were arrested. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: ghanaians protesting a deal that would give the united states military an expanded role in ghana
sources: deal with u.s. military sets off protests in ghana, the new york times , march 28, 2018 wednesday 19:51 est, world; africa, 951 words, dionne searcey and eric schmitt;
notes: thousands of ghanaians rallied in the streets of their capital on wednesday to protest a deal that would give the united states military an expanded role in ghana. as part of the agreement struck last week, the united states would invest about 20 million in equipment and training for the ghanaian military, carrying out joint exercises with ghana and using the nation s radio channels and runways. ghanaian officials said the agreement was an extension of a two decades long relationship between the united states and ghana, a west african nation that has been a regular host of bilateral and multilateral military exercises. it s the same arrangement we ve had in times past, said kojo oppong nkrumah, the deputy minister of information. he said that resistance to the deal was largely driven by the political motivations of opposition lawmakers. but the deal struck a nerve in ghana, which is in a region where the expansion of the american military has received increasing scrutiny. in accra, the capital, more than 3,000 people gathered in the streets to protest the agreement. having partaken in the struggle and fight towards our independence, we can never sit unconcerned when it comes to an agreement which has the tendency of compromising our sovereignty and integrity, said frank amoako hene, president of the national union of ghana students, who was among the protesters.

location: Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology in Kumasi
protesteridentity: students protesting what they termed the high handedness of the authorities
sources: ghana shuts down kwame nkrumah university over riots, xinhua general news service, october 23, 2018 tuesday 6:10 pm gmt, international news, 252 words; ghana s gov t orders re opening of university after riots, xinhua general news service, october 26, 2018 friday 3:58 am gmt, international news, 280 words
notes: protest by students on the campus on monday over what they thought was the high handedness of authorities in dealing with students turned violent with properties including motorbikes, motor vehicles, school structures among others vandalized by the rampaging students. this happened after around ten students who were part of a vigil being kept by students on friday night were arrested by the police. however, the students representative council described the action by the authorities as repressive and so organized the monday protests. hundreds of police personnel drawn from all over the region were deployed on the campus to restore calm. the regional security council took the decision late monday to close down the school indefinitely after a meeting with school management. all students except foreign students were given up to noon on tuesday to vacate the school premises. the government of ghana announced actions here on thursday to restore peaceful academic activity on the campus of kwame nkrumah university of science and technology knust . the school was closed down on tuesday by the ashanti regional security council regsec following violent riots by students who were protesting what they termed the high handedness of the authorities. the government announced its decision which included the dissolution of the university council here by a press statement after receiving advice from the fact finding committee that was dispatched to the school located in kumasi, ghana s second largest city, 280 km north of the capital. government has dissolved the knust council and, in its stead, put in place a seven member interim council. it has also directed that the university reopens within fourteen days to enable academic work to continue, the statement announced. although the regsec had imposed a dusk to dawn curfew on the school, the government ordered the reopening of the university within 14 days to enable academic work to resume. on why the governing council was dissolved, the statement explained that that council was not in a position to review its own processes and decisions affecting the student body to guarantee peace. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the stories, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters attempting to persuade leaders to act against environmental disaster
sources: schoolchildren throng streets in vast global climate strike, agence france presse english, september 20, 2019 friday 7:44 pm gmt, 785 words, new york, sept 20 2019
notes: huge numbers of children skipped school friday to join a global strike against climate change that teen activist greta thunberg hopes will mark a turning point in persuading leaders to act against environmental disaster. chanting slogans and waving placards, youngsters and adults filled the streets of cities across the world in what was expected to be the biggest ever protest against the threat posed to the planet by warming temperatures. about 200 marched in ghana s capital accra, where some 44 percent of the country s population has not heard of climate change, according to a study by afrobarometer. developing countries like ghana are the most affected. we don t have the resources to adapt to climate change, said 26 year old protest organizer ellen lindsey awuku.

sources: anti government protesters attack police stations, burn cars the associated press, october 6, 1990, saturday, pm cycle, international news, 174 words togo protests the independent london , october 6, 1990, saturday, foreign news page; page 10 , 73 words togo riot the independent london , october 8, 1990, monday, foreign news page; page 12 , 73 words ;
notes: hundreds of protesters attacked two police stations, set several government vehicles ablaze and burned down part of the main market in this west african capital. the demonstrators turned violent friday when soldiers forced them out of a courtroom during the trial of two people accused of distributing tracts that were deemed hostile to the military government of gen. gnassingbe eyadema. eyadema seized power in a coup in 1967 and rules this nation as a one party state. the content of the tracts was not immediately available, but many african countries have been hit by a wave of unrest this year as demonstrators demand multiparty democracy. the protests had not touched togo, however. those expelled from the court spread out across town, with two groups attacking two police stations and others stoning and setting fire to government vehicles. other protesters set stalls ablaze in the main market. calm returned in the middle of the day after soldiers were stationed at intersections and othe strategic points in the capital. lome reuter anti government rioters rampaged through the streets of togo s seaside capital, attacking police stations and burning official cars. witnesses said it was the most serious outbreak of political unrest in the tiny west african country for 20 years. several thousand protesters, led by students but including many unemployed youths, chanted slogans against president gnassingbe eyadema s authoritarian one party regime. lome ap togolese security forces opened fire on protesters as they attacked police stations and set government vehicles on fire. the government said that four people were killed and 34 injured in the incident. the demonstrators went on a rampage after soldiers forced them out of a court during the trial of two people accused of distributing pamphlets attacking the one party rule of the president, general gnassingbe eyadema.

sources: police clash with student demonstrators, two dead the associated press, march 16, 1991, saturday, am cycle, international news, 243 words togo moves toward democracy president strives to save regime the globe and mail canada , march 19, 1991 tuesday, 379 words, reut ;
notes: the student demonstrations began tuesday with demands for better conditions at school and the immediate implementation of multiparty democracy. president gnassingbe eyadema s government ordered soldiers to end the demonstrations and banned further protests. the general has ruled togo as a one party state since he seized power in a coup in 1967. reuters news agency lome the president of togo, moving to save his 24 year old regime from a powerful array of opponents, caved in yesterday to their main demands. after more than five hours of negotiations with 10 opposition leaders, president gnassingbe eyadema agreed to sweeping pro democracy reforms in the small west african country. in principle, all our demands were resolved during the meeting, the chairman of the anti government coalition, yawo agboyibo, told reporters and cheering supporters.

sources: police clash with student demonstrators, two dead the associated press, march 16, 1991, saturday, am cycle, international news, 243 words togo moves toward democracy president strives to save regime the globe and mail canada , march 19, 1991 tuesday, 379 words, reut ;
notes: soldiers and police fought stone throwing student protesters with tear gas and truncheons on saturday, and government sources said one policeman and an infant were killed in the violence. the sources said five officers were injured, but did not say whether any students were hurt. opposition sources said the home of lawyer yawo agboyibor, who heads an organization of informal groups supporting multiparty democracy, was firebombed. two of his cars also were set on fire, the sources said. reuters news agency lome the president of togo, moving to save his 24 year old regime from a powerful array of opponents, caved in yesterday to their main demands. after more than five hours of negotiations with 10 opposition leaders, president gnassingbe eyadema agreed to sweeping pro democracy reforms in the small west african country. in principle, all our demands were resolved during the meeting, the chairman of the anti government coalition, yawo agboyibo, told reporters and cheering supporters.

sources: police fight protesters in togo for second day the new york times, march 17, 1991, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1; page 12; column 4; foreign desk, 97 words, reuters togo moves toward democracy president strives to save regime the globe and mail canada , march 19, 1991 tuesday, 379 words, reut ;
notes: the police fought anti government protesters in the capital of the west african nation of togo today for the second successive day. a boy died as a result of the violence, and dozens of people were injured, witnesses and first aid workers said. a commission of representatives from the opposition coalition and eyadema appointees will work out details, the front said. protests began on march 12 with students demanding multiparty democracy and improved campus conditions. the front, which includes the students association, had called for a general strike starting wednesday. reuters news agency lome the president of togo, moving to save his 24 year old regime from a powerful array of opponents, caved in yesterday to their main demands. after more than five hours of negotiations with 10 opposition leaders, president gnassingbe eyadema agreed to sweeping pro democracy reforms in the small west african country. in principle, all our demands were resolved during the meeting, the chairman of the anti government coalition, yawo agboyibo, told reporters and cheering supporters.

sources: togo may allow opposition parties the associated press, march 18, 1991, monday, am cycle, international news, 232 words togo moves toward democracy president strives to save regime the globe and mail canada , march 19, 1991 tuesday, 379 words, reut ;
notes: opposition and student leaders in togo decided today to press ahead with a campaign of street protests in a bid to end president gnassingbe eyadema s 24 year one party rule. a policeman and a 12 year old boy were killed on saturday on the second day of violent clashes in lome, normally one of the most tranquil capitals in west africa. as the president remained silent on the unrest, the country s worst since independence from france in 1960, opposition members said student leaders had decided to hold another illegal pro democracy march on monday. reuters news agency lome the president of togo, moving to save his 24 year old regime from a powerful array of opponents, caved in yesterday to their main demands. after more than five hours of negotiations with 10 opposition leaders, president gnassingbe eyadema agreed to sweeping pro democracy reforms in the small west african country. in principle, all our demands were resolved during the meeting, the chairman of the anti government coalition, yawo agboyibo, told reporters and cheering supporters.

sources: two killed in clash with police during togo protests the associated press, april 6, 1991, saturday, am cycle, international news, 195 words ;
notes: although there were killings, the live ammo shot by the riot police was over the crowd s heads and not into the crowd, making it appear that they were not intending to kill anyone police killed two people during a protest by roman catholic students demanding the ouster of president gnasingbe eyadema, officials reported. information minister kwaovi beni johnson announced the deaths on state run television late friday. the violence broke out as hundreds of students marched through the streets of the capital to the headquarters of the ruling rally of the togolese people party. the students, reportedly joined by unemployed young men, called for the resignations of eyadema and lome archbishop robert dosseh anyron. the crowd also attacked party headquarters, trashed several offices, broke windows and tried to tear down a statue of eyadema, authorities said. riot police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd, witnesses said, then shot live ammunition over their heads. at least two people were struck by bullets and killed. it was not immediately clear if they were students. the tiny west african country, ruled by eyadama since he took power in a 1967 military coup, has been the site of frequent unrest recently as citizens demand greater democracy.

sources: protest disrupts lome the independent london , april 9, 1991, tuesday, foreign news page; page 9 , 148 words ;
notes: lome afp more than 1,000 demonstrators urging togo s military ruler, general gnassingbe eyadema, to resign took control of the main working class district of be in the capital yesterday. they barred access to the district with barricades of burning tyres, rocks and wood.

sources: world in brief unrest in togo the globe and mail canada , april 10, 1991 wednesday, 26 words, reut togo riots the independent london , april 10, 1991, wednesday, foreign news page; page 10 , 48 words ;
notes: lome riot police fought for most of yesterday with thousands of youths demanding the resignation of togo s president gnassingbe eyadema, witnesses said. reuter lome reuter hundreds of togolese youths calling for the resignation of president gnassingbe eyadema threw stones at police and set fire to official vehicles in the capital. violent demonstrations a month ago forced general eyadema to agree to demands for multi party reforms.

sources: togo rioters win pledge of reform the guardian london , april 11, 1991, 370 words, by mark huband in abidjan ;
notes: thousands of students battled with riot police yesterday in the second day of demonstrations demanding president eyadema s resignation. two demonstrators were killed outside the ruling party headquarters last friday when police opened fire on a crowd.

sources: president promises multiparty democracy soon in bid to stem unrest the associated press, april 11, 1991, thursday, am cycle, international news, 511 words, by combiete combey, associated press writer ;
notes: president gnassinge eyadema promised to turn his one party state into a multiparty democracy by friday, accelerating reforms to try to survivedemonstrations by thousands of people demanding his ouster. eyadema s nationwide address followed the recovery of 22 bodies thursday from a lagoon in the capital of this west african nation. news about the discovery of the dead, including a mother and a baby strapped to her back, prompted mass anti government rallies. demonstrators took a small truck with some of the cadavers to the u.s. embassy, where they shouted anti eyadema chants until troops dispersed them by firing tear gas. the bodies showed evidence of beatings. the protesters blamed eyadema s security forces for the killings and cried for revenge and the end of eyadema s 24 year rule. the protests subsided thursday night.

sources: togo radio reports three dead, 41 hurt in civil unrest agence france presse english, 183 words three dead in togo clashes after ruling party is abolished agence france presse english, 657 words, crosby quist ;
notes: the radio also said that a large demonstration had taken place in the kara region to protest at tuesday s decision by the transitional legislature to abolish the former totalitarian togolese people s rally party rpt of president gnassingbe eyadema. the president is from the kara region. the demonstrators occupied the local radio station, national radio said. the radio reported that demonstrations in support of the rpt took place in kara, 500 kilometres 300 miles north of lome, in general eyadema s home region.

sources: police protest cuts in togo, fire in air, pillage some bars the associated press, march 25, 1992, wednesday, am cycle, international news, 270 words, by combiete combey, associated press writer ;
notes: police fired into the air and vandalized bars and gas stations today in a second day of protests to demand higher pay. hospitals reported at least 14 people injured, 11 of them policemen. witnesses said many of the injuries resulted from collisions between civilian vehicles and cars commandeered by police. dozens of police drove around the capital of the west african nation, firing occasionally into the air, witnesses said. some set up roadblocks, and got into fights with city residents who opposed their action.

sources: gunmen wound opposition candidate in togo, military ruler accused the associated press, may 6, 1992, wednesday, am cycle, international news, 459 words, by combiete combey, associated press writer ;
notes: at least three other opposition leaders died tuesday in the ambush of olympio s convoy on a mountainous road in northern togo. the assasination attempt sparked a protest wednesday by thousands of angry citizens who forced their way into government buildings shouting, eyadema! murderer! olympio supporters claimed that gen. eyadema, who has boasted of killing olympio s father the first president of togo also plotted the death of his son.

sources: lome boils after olympio assassination bid agence france presse english, 640 words ;
notes: an angry crowd of 15,000 people gathered here on friday to protest against the attempted murder of togo s presidential hopeful gilchrist olympio, some of them calling to be given weapons. banners at their head demanded the resignations of togo s military ruler, general gnassingbe eyadema, and interim premier joseph kokou koffigoh, a lawyer appointed by a national conference last year to oversee a transition to multi party democracy.

sources: lome boils after olympio assassination bid agence france presse english, 640 words ;
notes: after the demonstration, some 2,000 people went to the interior ministry, demanding to see the minister yao komlanvi, who was absent, and calling for the release of a jailed csi leader. police let them into the ministry grounds and were not much in evidence elsewhere in the capital.

sources: demonstrators protest assassination the associated press, july 30, 1992, thursday, pm cycle, international news, 373 words, by combiete combey, associated press writer ;
notes: young demonstrators set up roadblocks today to protest the assassination of an opposition leader they claim was killed as part of a campaign to eliminate critics of togo s military president. tavio amorin, 34, was cut down in a hail of gunfire in downtown lome a week ago and died of his wounds in a paris hospital wednesday night, the government said. during today s protest in lome, anti riot police fired tear gas to disperse demonstrators and dismantled their roadblocks. at least two policeman were injured, witnesses said.

sources: togo killings the independent london , january 26, 1993, tuesday, international news page; page 10 , 102 words ;
notes: lome afp at least 12 people were killed yesterday and 25 injured when police fired on an anti government demonstration here as a franco german mediation team tried to end togo s long standing political crisis. togo radio said the shooting occurred after demonstrators turned on security forces on patrol near parliament. burning barricades had been thrown up in the city centre and in working class areas, as armed police deployed in strength. witnesses reported seeing corpses at private clinics in lome, while hospital sources said 25 people were being treated, mainly for gunshot wounds.

sources: thousands demonstrate to back opposition leader s presidential bid agence france presse english, 414 words ;
notes: lome, aug 19 afp several thousand supporters of opposition leader gilchrist olympio demonstrated in lome thursday to back his bid to stand as a candidate in togo s presidential election of next wednesday, witnesses said. olympio, the son of the country s first president sylvanus olympio, killed in a coup d etat in 1963, has been disqualified as a candidate by the supreme court. the supreme court last week rejected olympio s candidacy on technical grounds. the elections come amid a severe political crisis lasting some years between togo s long standing military ruler, gnassingbe eyadema, and the opposition.

sources: rival demonstrators throng capital over election agence france presse english, 667 words ;
notes: lome, aug 23 afp thousands of rival demonstrators gathered in the togolese capital on monday to oppose or support the holding of a presidential elction on wednesday. at the same moment, in southern parts of lome, thousands of opposition followers assembled at three different places to stage a march on the offices of the national electoral commission. special security force units were standing by. the only noticeable tension was on the western outskirts at the border post where the capital adjoins neighbouring ghana. togolese refugees trying to get back for the vote were arguing with ghanaian customs officers. citing irregularities in the compilation of the electoral register and distribution of voting cards, the opposition wants the poll put off until september 5. the demonstrations to change the date were organised by the party of yao agboyibo, who is one of the candidates challenging eyadema in the presidential race, by the party of gilchrist olympio who was barred by the supreme court 12 days ago from standing, and by the party of djibo boukari, who is not a candidate.

sources: tens of thousands march in support of government in togolese capital capital agence france presse english english ;
notes: kwassi went on to warn opposition leaders, who drew some 3,500 supporters to the streets of lome on saturday, against the temptation to renew febrile political agitation which could nullify the government s efforts towards economic growth. saturday s march was organised by the action committee for renewal car , an opposition grouping with 33 of the 81 seats in parliament, to stronglyprotest against the many obstacles the rpt uses to prevent the opposition expressing itself.

sources: organizational problems plague togo s presidential elections elections agence france presse english english ;
notes: lome, june 21 afp organisational problems surrounding presidential elections in togo on sunday meant dozens of voting stations opened late or were still closed early afternoon, provoking voters in the capital lome to protest in the streets. in lome several polling stations had yet to open by the start of the afternoon, leading to protests in the streets by discontented voters who had been waiting from as early as 5.30 a.m. a city official said earlier that the delays stemmed from a lack of materials for the elections, in which president gnassingbe eyadema, who is seeking a final five year mandate after 31 years in power, faces five challengers. about a thousand mostly young voters, furious at a long and so far fruitless wait in the sun, marched through lome chanting we want to vote.

sources: organizational problems plague togo s presidential elections elections agence france presse english english ;
notes: lome, june 21 afp organisational problems surrounding presidential elections in togo on sunday meant dozens of voting stations opened late or were still closed early afternoon, provoking voters in the capital lome to protest in the streets. another group of 200 whistle blowing protestors walked through lome later in the afternoon.

sources: lome youths protest stolen election election agence france presse english english, michele leridon leridon ;
notes: hundreds of youths on wednesday took to streets of lome s working class be district, a hotbed of opposition defiance, to protest what they called president gnassingbe eyadema s stolen election victory. all afternoon, they torched cars, threw stones and scattered rubbish under the watchful eye of riot police and gendarmes. togo s opposition has rejected the announcement of eyadema s reelection, believing instead that gilchrist olympio, of the union of forces for change, won the vote. vote.

sources: re election of togo s eyadema sparks opposition protests protests agence france presse english english, michele leridon leridon togolese president re elected; thousands protest the associated press, june 24, 1998, wednesday, am cycle, international news, 407 words, by combiete combey, associated press writer ;
notes: togo s general gnassingbe eyadema has been re elected president, the interior and security minister said wednesday, as the opposition demonstrated in rejection of the declaration, claiming it was based on false figures. according to general seyi memene, general eyadema, who has been in power in this west african state for more than three decades, won 52.13 percent of votes cast in sunday s poll. the announcement prompted cries of foul from opposition candidates, including gilchrist olympio, who claimed he won the poll and whose union of forces for change ufc took to the streets in a demonstration attended by more than 1,000 people crying eyadema, thief. thief. police were deployed to prevent the protesters approaching the interior ministry or the town s main market. setting tires, trash and cars alight, thousands filled the streets of togo s capital on wednesday to protest the declared election victory of president gngassigbe eyadema. riot police fired tear gas and swung clubs, injuring at least one protester.

sources: protests rage after disputed elections; opposition threatens more the associated press, june 25, 1998, thursday, am cycle, international news, 378 words, by brahima ouedraogo, associated press writer ;
notes: opposition supporters poured onto the streets of togo s capital for a second day thursday, shouting anti government slogans and threatening an uprising after the president s much disputed re election victory. heavily armed riot police cruising in armored cars and vans dispersed the throngs of protesters, who scrawled graffiti on monuments and government buildings. no violence was reported, although opposition leader gilchrist olympio s party, union of forces for change, promised to disrupt president gnassigbe eyadema s government with a campaign of mass protests.

sources: protests mount as challenge launched against togo government the associated press, june 26, 1998, friday, am cycle, international news, 327 words, by combiete combey, associated press writer;
notes: security forces burned the offices of togo s main opposition leader and attacked one of his aides friday, witnesses said, while activists demanded the president s ouster after his disputed re election. eyadema thief! gilchrist president! protesters chanted in the capital, lome. security forces responded to friday s demonstrations by setting olympio s campaign offices on fire. witnesses, speaking on condition of anonymity for fear of retribution, also said soldiers and police attacked bob akitani, vice president of olympio s party. one person was reported killed in violent anti government demonstrations in the central town of afagnan. security forces dispersed the protests in lome with clubs and tear gas grenades. there were no reports of injuries there. eyadema has ruled this small french speaking country for 31 years since taking power as a military dictator. according to figures released by the ruling party, eyadema won 52 percent of the vote sunday and olympio had 34 percent. olympio s supporters had claimed a majority.

sources: protests mount as challenge launched against togo government the associated press, june 26, 1998, friday, am cycle, international news, 327 words, by combiete combey, associated press writer ;
notes: security forces burned the offices of togo s main opposition leader and attacked one of his aides friday, witnesses said, while activists demanded the president s ouster after his disputed re election. security forces dispersed the protests in lome with clubs and tear gas grenades. there were no reports of injuries there. eyadema has ruled this small french speaking country for 31 years since taking power as a military dictator. according to figures released by the ruling party, eyadema won 52 percent of the vote sunday and olympio had 34 percent. olympio s supporters had claimed a majority.

protesteridentity: supporters of opposition leader gilchrist olympio
sources: police disrupt protests of anniversary for africa s longest leader associated press international, january 12, 2000; wednesday, international news, 915 words, ebow godwin ;
notes: police used teargas to disperse some 2,000 opposition demonstrators wednesday on the eve of state celebrations marking 33 years in power for africa s longest ruling leader. the supporters of opposition leader gilchrist olympio were scattered by riot police and armored vehicles shortly after the demonstrators began marching near olympio s party headquarters in the capital, lome. street sellers fled, abandoning their stalls. police continued to patrol the capital in the evening and streets were mostly abandoned. in the village of kegue, on lome s outskirts, however, thousands turned out to hear former military dictator turned president gnassingbe eyadema speak at a state celebration on the eve of the 33rd anniversary since he took power. organizers of thursday s protest said they were trying to draw attention to alleged corruption, persecution of political opponents and vote rigging under eyadema, who has won two elections since 1993.

sources: ten hurt as security forces break up togo demo agence france presse english, 473 words ;
notes: ten people were hurt saturday when security forces in the west african state of togo moved in to break up a demonstration by the opposition action committee for renewal car . although the interior ministry said only 100 or so people took part, the car statement said between 5,000 and 10,000 demonstrators attended. the demonstrators had intended to march through the capital s main streets but police pushed them back towards their party s headquarters, where scuffles broke out. towards 0900 gmt, activists tried to break through the police cordon of about 50 well armed police officers lined up beside their vehicles and backed up by staff from police headquarters nearby. police used tear gas on the crowd and shortly afterwards the demonstration broke up in confusion, an afp correspondent noted. those injured in the violence were treated at car headquarters. demonstrators were expressing support for the findings of an international commission of inquiry into alleged massacres in togo in 1998, published wednesday. the investigation, carried out jointly by the organisation of african unity oau and the united nations, concluded that there had been systematic human rights violations. the government has already dismissed its findings.

sources: seven togolese students arrested as police break protest march agence france presse english, 143 words ;
notes: since there were enough students to illicit a police force to break up the march which resulted in 7 arrests, i have deemed this protest as involving 50 people. seven togolese students were arrested here saturday as police broke up a protest march demanding the payment of scholarship arrears and an end to police presence in campuses. the students gathered at the main market of lome at around 7:00 a.m. to stage a march through major arteries of the togolese capital. police arrived quickly, fired tear gas shells and arrested seven demonstrators. the student problems should be addressed in university campuses and not the markets of lome or in public places, the togolese interior minister, general sizing walla, told afp, confirming the arrests. the protesters held banners saying: no more poverty for togolese students, pay us our arrears, and get the forces of order out of the campus. the students say they have not been paid scholarships and financial aid for 16 months.

sources: togolese turn out in lome to protest electoral reforms agence france presse english, 355 words ;
notes: at least 1,500 togolese demonstrated here saturday against government backed changes to electoral laws that will prevent a key opposition figure from standing in legislative polls due next month. togo s six main opposition parties, including key opposition leader gilchrist olympio s union of forces for change ufc , had called the protest, attended by between 1,500 and 2,000, according to journalists estimates. under a light police presence, the peaceful protesters marched on the capital carrying placards reading togolese people, democracy in danger and eyadema must dissolve the assembly. they also called for the release of jailed opposition leader yaovi agboyibo, charged last september with complicity with criminals.

sources: violence erupts in togo capital after opposition protest associated press international, november 9, 2002 saturday, international news, 396 words, ebow godwin; associated press writer ;
