notes: protesters set tires ablaze in the streets, smashed car windows and attacked shops in the capital of this west african country saturday after a march by opposition parties criticizing a recent election victory by togo s president. around 1,000 people demonstrated to protest against the party victory of president gnassingbe eyadema, africa s longest ruling leader, in parliamentary elections last month. opposition parties boycotted the oct. 27 polls. demonstrators tried to enter the city center but were blocked by riot police. later, some supporters went on the rampage in one of the city s southeastern neighborhoods, while journalists watched. leading opposition parties had urged voters to shun the polls, citing what they and international rights groups have called a lack of free and transparent voting under eyadema.

sources: eighteen injured in togo in student clashes with police agence france presse english english, 272 words ;
notes: reported on saturday may 1. officers used tear gas on friday to disperse the university of lome students, who had called a general assembly to demand that funds earmarked for students be disbursed. the youths struck back, hurling rocks at officers, and a total of 16 policemen and two students were injured, according to a police count. a bus and two motorcycles were also set ablaze and several other vehicles seriously damaged in the unrest, police added. one ranking togolese police officer said 35 people including 11 non students had been arrested. some of the detainees admitted to being recruited by the political opposition and had deliberately provoked the authority s crackdown so that it would end in bloodshed , he said. togo minister for higher education charles kondi agba said friday the protesters wanted the government to pay out over a year s worth of subsidies earmarked for individual students.

sources: togo police use tear gas to break up opposition rally agence france presse english, february 11, 2005 friday 10:11 am gmt, 249 words three killed in clash with police as togo answers ecowas summons over coup agence france presse english, february 12, 2005 saturday 10:47 pm gmt, 597 words thousands of demonstrators clash with togolese police in second day of protests the associated press, february 12, 2005, saturday, bc cycle, international news, 691 words, by bryan mealer, associated press writer at least one demonstrator killed by police during national strike in togo s capital, official says associated press international, february 14, 2005 monday, international news, 750 words, bryan mealer; associated press writer ;
notes: be is in southern lome.. police on friday used tear gas to break up an opposition rally in togo s capital lome organised to protest the controversial installation of faure gnassingbe as the country s new president. the rally, attended by several hundred people, had technically been banned by an edict this week by the togolese government. police dispersed the crowd, gathered in the heart of the downtown area, scattering protesters into the narrow streets of the neighborhood, a traditional stronghold of the opposition in the west african state. three protestors were killed saturday and three people seriously injured, including two policemen, in an opposition demonstration against the assumption of power by the son of togo s late ruler gnassingbe eyadema, officials said. police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd of some 3,000 demonstrators who had answered a call by six opposition parties for a protest march in the be neighborhood, in defiance of a government ban. in these circumstances of legitimate defence, two security force members used their weapons to make warning shots to free themselves. these warning shots unfortunately led to three deaths, of which two were on the site of the demonstration and one in hospital, the statement said. three people were also seriously hurt, including two policemen, and there had also been substantial damage, it said. thousands of demonstrators clashed with riot police in the capital for a second day saturday, protesting against togo s recent army appointed president in what many are calling a coup d etat. three people were reportedly killed and dozens wounded when police fired at demonstrators. an estimated 3,000 protesters hurled rocks and jagged pieces of metal at police, and set garbage fires to block their vehicles. security forces fought back with tear gas, batons and stun grenades, attempting to quell a growing opposition against the appointment of president faure gnassingbe. police killed at least one person as an opposition long used to repression tried to step up protests to the army s installation of the late dictator s son as president. togo s interior minister akila esso boko said one demonstrator was killed monday as he attempted to steal an officer s gun. the killing took place in the restive neighborhood of be, an opposition stronghold, where mobs of young people blocked roads and taunted security forces. the latest slaying brought to four the official death toll during three days of protests. opposition leaders said 11 people were killed by security forces monday. those claims could not be verified.

sources: thousands protest against togo president despite election pledge agence france presse english, february 19, 2005 saturday 1:05 pm gmt, 677 words ;
notes: : thousands of people protested in togo s capital saturday against the new president installed by the military after his father s death, despite a promise to hold new elections within 60 days. in the biggest opposition rally since faure gnassingbe took office two weeks ago, an estimated 25,000 people gathered in the opposition stronghold neighbourhood of be, chanting slogans and carrying placards. the opposition rally, which started in the opposition stronghold neighbourhood of be more than doubled in its original size as more people joined as it made its way through the city. it later broke up peacefully. security forces kept a low profile during the protest

sources: togo s people take to streets after latest change at the top agence france presse english, february 26, 2005 saturday 11:26 am gmt, 629 words ;
notes: foes and supporters of togo s short term ruler faure gnassingbe, who has quit office the better to fight elections in two months time, took saturday to the streets of the capital in separate demonstrations. in the be district, six opposition parties rallied people to demand a total return to constitutional legality in the small west african state, which was plunged into crisis by the death of longtime ruler gnassingbe eyadema. the opposition union of forces for change ufc of gilchrist olympio, the son of togo s slain first president and long in exile, and the action committee for renewal car led by yawovi agboyibo, urged their supporters to demand a total return to the constitution as eyadema had left it. opposition hardliners argued that the regime had failed to go far enough, insisting that the only way to restore full constitutional rule was to make the former parliamentary speaker fambare natchaba ouattara, who was abroad when eyadema died, interim head of state. youths at their rally waved banners reading we want clearer elections and natchaba is and remains constitutional legality . what we want is a whole and not stray bits and pieces, ufc leader secretary general jean pierre fabre told afp. we want the restoration of constitutional legality and natchaba s installation. moreover we want a political agreement to discuss the conditions for organising free, transparent and democratic elections without exclusive conditions.

sources: togolese women stage pro democracy demonstration as elections loom agence france presse english, february 27, 2005 sunday 3:25 pm gmt, 224 words ;
notes: thousands of women from togo s six opposition parties staged a pro democracy demonstration in lome sunday, calling for a return to government based on the country s constitution after power was seized temporarily by the son of togo s late longtime ruler. the women, all dressed in red, marched peacefully through the streets of the togolese capital, watched over by the city s security forces. we are dressed in red because democracy is in danger, it must be saved, said brigitte adjamongbo johnson, one of the organizers of the march. late friday faure gnassingbe gave up the presidency he had seized with military backing after the death of his father, gnassingbe eydema, on february 5.

sources: police fire tear gas at demonstrators protesting against togo s new president the associated press, february 27, 2005, sunday, bc cycle, international news, 499 words, by ebow godwin, associated press writer ;
notes: demonstrators protested against togo s new president on sunday, lighting flaming barricades in the capital s streets and throwing rocks at riot police who fired tear gas to keep crowds from moving toward government buildings. hundreds of demonstrators marched toward central lome s administrative offices from the opposition stronghold of be, where burning truck tires closed roads. security forces turned the marchers back with tear gas when they began throwing stones. demonstrators said the unannounced march was prompted by anger at friday s selection of bonfoh abbass as interim president of togo until nationwide elections can be held in the coming months. demonstrators said the succession was unconstitutional. the law, they claimed, should have gone to the parliament speaker a ruling party loyalist who was fired after he refused to return to the country in the early days of the crisis.

sources: thousands rally in rival demonstrations ahead of togo elections agence france presse english, march 26, 2005 saturday 5:52 pm gmt, 268 words opposition marches to demand delay in togo elections; ruling party supporters insist vote go ahead as planned the associated press, march 26, 2005, saturday, bc cycle, international news, 455 words, by ebow godwin, associated press writer ;
notes: thousands of supporters of rival camps in togo held separate rallies in lome saturday, with the opposition demanding the postponement of presidential elections due on april 24, and backers of ruling party candidate faure gnassingbe saying they should go ahead. an opposition leader said the deadline was too short for the elections to choose the successor to togo s late dictatorial president gnassingbe eyadema to be free and transparent. he also said the policemen who were attacked did not fight back. togolese security agents have strict orders not to react even in the face of extreme provocation during protest marches, boko told the associated press. but this should not be taken as a sign of weakness.

sources: election date row sparks rival marches and clashes in togo agence france presse english, april 6, 2005 wednesday 6:05 pm gmt, 485 words police fire tear gas at protesters demanding togo elections be postponed associated press international, april 6, 2005 wednesday, international news, 449 words, ebow godwin; associated press writer ;
notes: police used teargas wednesday to disperse firebrand youths while thousands of supporters from rival camps in togo held separate rallies for and against holding a presidential poll in less than three weeks. the opposition union of forces for change ufc rallied separately to protest that the date was too early for a fair poll following the death in february of africa s longest ruling leader, gnassingbe eyadema, and several weeks of turmoil afterwards. the opposition did not release any figures on injuries among their supporters. the police crackdown took place on the sidelines of the rival demonstrations in lome, when gendarmes used teargas against youths claiming affiliation with the opposition, who set up barricades and burned tyres in the working class be and dekon districts in an opposition rally to demand a poll delay. police fired tear gas at ufc demonstrators who were demanding voter cards on the fringe of the rpt demonstration as security forces were out in force on lome s streets to try to keep the two sets of supporters from clashing. the april 24 vote is considered likely to confirm faure gnassingbe, the former president s son, in the office he tried to hijack with army backing after his father s death on february 5. police fired tear gas to disperse opposition protesters who responded by hurling stones and setting tires ablaze during a demonstration to demand a postponement of elections to choose togo s first new president in 38 years. about 2,000 opposition protesters had gathered wednesday, chanting no to fraudulent registration of voters, and claiming the ruling party was rigging electoral lists.

sources: one person shot dead, five injured at opposition demo in togo agence france presse english, april 8, 2005 friday 9:41 pm gmt, 282 words in togo, youths fight police over vote plan the new york times, april 9, 2005 saturday, section a; column 1; foreign desk; pg. 6, 388 words, reuters protesters in togo demand revision of voters lists ahead of elections to replace military leader associated press international, april 11, 2005 monday, international news, 345 words, ebow godwin; associated press writer ;
notes: earlier friday, police in lome used teargas to break up a demonstration by thousands of members of the opposition. clashes broke out in central lome when mainly ufc members marched on the city hall to demand voters cards for the presidential election. some 2,000 protesters wearing yellow t shirts and scarves tried to march on the town hall in lome to demand voting cards for the april 24 election, but the police blocked the protest by firing tear gas. yellow is the color of the main opposition party. hundreds of opposition supporters poured into the streets in ongoing protests to demand a revision of allegedly rigged voters lists for elections to replace togo s military ruler of 38 years, with one leader warning a failed election could affect all of west africa.

sources: one person shot dead, five injured at opposition demo in togo agence france presse english, april 8, 2005 friday 9:41 pm gmt, 282 words ;
notes: based on other anti election demonstrations that have occurred, i have noted this demonstration of being 100 , as a conservative estimate, since all other protests thus far have been in the thousands. togolese security forces shot dead one person and wounded five others friday at an opposition demonstration on the first day of the election campaign in the small west african country, an opposition leader said. the demonstrators in tabligbo 80 kilometers 50 miles north of the capital lome, were calling for a delay to the april 24 election, said jean pierre fabre, secretary general of the main opposition party union of forces for change ufc .

sources: togo s opposition supporters rally in capital agence france presse english, april 11, 2005 monday 1:09 pm gmt, 251 words ;
notes: several thousand togolese opposition demonstrators rallied monday in the capital in protest at the handling of a previous march in which one person was shot dead, ahead of this month s presidential poll. the protestors, mostly young people, set off from the district of be, a traditional opposition stronghold in lome, to gather in the city centre. no incidents were reported.

sources: three killed, amid claims of fraud in tense togo election agence france presse english, april 25, 2005 monday 2:13 am gmt, 765 words son of former togo dictator wins presidential elections, sparking clashes the associated press, april 26, 2005, tuesday, bc cycle, international news, 638 words, by bryan mealer, associated press writer ;
notes: at least three people were killed and 20 others injured in togo as voting ended in tense presidential elections marred by claims of massive fraud. late on sunday tensions ran high in areas of the tiny western african state s capital, where opposition supporters wielding machettes and clubs had erected barricades to protest alleged irregularities. witnesses also said that police opened fire in four districts. hundreds of opposition supporters rioted in the streets sunday, angry at reports the ruling party stole ballot boxes or stuffed them with votes for gnassingbe. a foreign diplomat said three men were shot to death near lome s airport, but it was unclear by whom.

sources: gnassingbe wins togo vote, violence erupts on lome streets agence france presse english, april 26, 2005 tuesday 3:43 pm gmt, 715 words at least 22 reported dead in togo s post poll violence officials agence france presse english, april 27, 2005 wednesday 6:33 pm gmt, 477 words street clashes between togo security forces and protesters dying down the associated press, april 28, 2005, thursday, bc cycle, international news, 781 words, by bryan mealer, associated press writer ;
notes: based on the number of wounded, i have coded this event as greater than 100. faure gnassingbe, candidate of the party that has ruled togo for four decades, has won the presidential poll, officials said tuesday, sparking immediate street violence and opposition charges of fraud. angry youths and police clashed in lome, where barricades were set alight in the city centre within moments of the radio announcement of gnassingbe s win in sunday s troubled election. enraged youths, who consider the election rigged by a regime entrenched during 37 years of tough rule by gnassingbe s father gnassingbe eyadema until he died in february, set up roadblocks of burning tyres, many yelling: they ve stolen our victory! police and soldiers moved in with tear gas, afp journalists saw, while from ghana long time exiled opposition leader gilchrist olympio said there had been massive fraud and we reject this result. it will be very difficult to control our young supporters in lome, he warned. angry opposition supporters battled riot police for the second day running wednesday in the capital of the tiny west african country. official and hospital sources said at least 22 people had been killed and more than 100 hurt. deadly street clashes between security forces and protesters angered by the presidential win of the son of togo s late dictator largely subsided thursday though sporadic violence continued in the capital where soldiers beat residents, some of them old women.

sources: togo taxi drivers strike protesting police arrests and fines associated press international, august 1, 2006 tuesday 5:59 pm gmt, international news, 22 words ;
notes: hundreds of taxi drivers in togo s capital went on strike tuesday, protesting alleged illegal fines and arbitrary arrests by police. the taxi drivers blocked lome s main roads with their cars, temporarily bringing the city s traffic to a standstill. the strikers said police made random arrests and charged exorbitant fines amounting to 10us euro7.84 in the west african country where one third of the population lives below the poverty line. the drivers staged a sit in and shouted slogans protesting against the government. we are poor. the authorities must allow us to work freely without interference, said kwadwo mawuli, a spokesman for the drivers. a spokesman for the transportation ministry said he would not comment until after a meeting to negotiate with the drivers had ended.

sources: togo blames antiretroviral drug stock crunch to delivery delay xinhua general news service, november 23, 2007 friday 1:18 am est, 180 words hundreds of hiv aids patients march against discrimination in togo xinhua general news service, november 26, 2007 monday 1:16 am est, 184 words ;
notes: repeated delays in the delivery of stocks is the major cause for the lack of sufficient antiretroviral drugs in the country, the togolese authorities have announced. we are experiencing delays in the delivery of these drug, said assih mamessile, director of the center for the purchase of essential and generic drugs on thursday while addressing a group of people living with hiv aids, who are camping outside the togolese national assembly since wednesday. the problem is caused by delays in the delivery of the drugs by the supplier and they have even depleted our reserve stocks , mamessile told the people who were gathering to protest against the lack of the cheap life saving drug. the orders, which have been made since june, have not been delivered on the agreed time, mamessile said adding that new stocks would be delivered by wednesday next week. last week, hundreds of patients protested in front of the parliament against the lack of enough anti retroviral drug arv in togo.

sources: hundreds of hiv aids patients march against discrimination in togo xinhua general news service, november 26, 2007 monday 1:16 am est, 184 words ;
notes: because this is noted as over the weekend, i have noted it as occurring on saturday the 24, as this is the start of the weekend. more than 500 hiv aids patients held a demonstration here over the weekend to protest against the discrimination against them, according to local press. this was the first protest march by aids patients in togo. demonstrators, wearing t shirts with messages such as stop stigmatization and discrimination, walked for more than two hours in the streets. it is high time people living with hiv aids come out of the closet to denounce certain abuses, augustin dokla, president of the togolese network of people living with hiv aids, said on sunday, adding there are laws in place, but they are not being respected. lawmakers adopted in december 2005 a law protecting hiv positive people. according to this law, no person shall be made to suffer from isolation, detention, or quarantine on the basis of his her positive status.

protesteridentity: jean pierre fabre union of forces for change

notes: police used teargas saturday to break up an opposition protest in togo led by presidential candidate jean pierre fabre who has claimed victory in a disputed election, police and witnesses said. several hundred youths and fabre were dispersed with teargas in the centre of the capital lome, they said. the commander of 6,000 strong election security forces, colonel damehane yark, told afp that teargas had been used. a togolese police spokesman says officers have fired tear gas on some 200 protesters angry that the opposition party is trailing in the hotly contested presidential election. security forces in togo fired teargas on hundreds of protesters on sunday as the opposition vowed to contest the results of an election won by the incumbent president faure gnassingbe. jean pierre fabre, the main defeated candidate in the poll who was at the protest, took shelter in the headquarters of his union of forces for change ufc party along with other opposition leaders after armed riot police moved in. there were between 200 and 300 opposition supporters at the protest.

sources: togo s opposition, pro government backers face off agence france presse english, march 13, 2010 saturday 4:12 pm gmt, 536 words ;
notes: thousands of opposition supporters and rivals backing president faure gnassingbe faced off in lome on saturday, staging competing rallies nine days after gnassingbe s disputed reelection. security forces intervened to form a barrier as rival marches bore down on a central square in the capital, averting potentially violent clashes amid a tense standoff. supporters of the ruling rally of the togolese people party quickly quit the scene. but opposition marchers remained, vowing to regularly stage rallies in this tiny west african nation, ruled for 38 years by gnassingbe s father, gnassingbe eyadema. following his death, gnassingbe took power in 2005. opposition leader jean pierre fabre claims that he was robbed of victory by gnassingbe in the march 4 presidential and supporters of his union of forces for change ufc turned out in force for the protest, donning the party colour yellow.

notes: thousands of opposition supporters took to the streets of togo s capital on saturday to protest against the re election of president faure gnassingbe, with his opponent claiming the vote was stolen. his main rival in the march 4 poll, jean pierre fabre, led the peaceful protest along with other officials from the opposition union of forces for change ufc . the march, which began at 1000 gmt at the popular be district where the ufc headquarters is located, moved through the city s streets and then to the beach where a meeting was held. on saturday, more than 7,000 protesters made their way through togo s capital. one demonstrator s sign read: return our stolen verdict. the protesters later dispersed peacefully.

sources: togo universities shut after student protests agence france presse english, december 9, 2011 friday 10:31 am gmt, 213 words ;
notes: since both universities were closed, i have coded this as taking place in both kara and lome. authorities in togo have temporarily shut down the country s two public universities after security forces fired teargas to break up student protests over a new bursary policy, they said late thursday. a government statement announced the temporary closure of the university of lome and another one in kara, some 420 kilometres 260 miles north of the capital. given the gravity of the protest acts on the two campuses, and in order to prevent the situation from degenerating, the government decided as of today on the temporary closure of the universities of lome and kara, said a government statement broadcast on national television thursday night. students said security forces fired teargas to disperse them on thursday when they gathered to protest against a new financial aid policy. the government last month introduced a new policy awarding payouts only to brilliant students instead of all scholars as was in the past. authorities said the protests led to the destruction of public and private properties in kara.

notes: witnesses say police used tear gas to disperse some 20,000 protesters in the west african nation of togo. tuesday s protests, which began as peaceful demonstrations against the adoption of a new electoral code, left at least 20 people injured and witnesses said at least five people were arrested. togo is due to hold legislative and municipal elections in october. but togolese opposition parties have expressed disagreement about a new formula for the redrawing of boundaries for constituencies. the protest was organised against the adoption by the national assembly in may of modifications to the electoral law. another law was adopted a week later increasing the number of deputies in the next legislature by 10 to 91. opposition figures accused the ruling party of having unilaterally modified the electoral law. the coalition has promised to protest over three days, having begun on tuesday. police clashed with protesters in the togolese capital lome thursday, firing tear gas after thousands took to the streets to protest against electoral reforms, local media reported. following protests organised on june 12, 13 and 14 by the group of associations and political parties named the let s save togo collective, deliberate violence, destruction and damage were committed against individuals and public and private goods, a statement from prosecutors said.

notes: togolese authorities fired tear gas tuesday to disperse a protest by several thousand people in the capital lome, the latest such move in the volatile build up to parliamentary polls expected in october. one protest organiser said a number of people were detained and injured, but could not provide figures. it was the first of three days of planned protests by let s save togo, a coalition of opposition and civil society groups. organisers said a new march followed by a sit in at independence square would go ahead wednesday. the tear gas was fired some 10 minutes after the start of the protest. some of the opposition are seeking a delay in the polls to let reforms take effect first, while some also want changes to the electoral code passed by parliament to be repealed on the grounds that they were not made properly. togolese security forces clashed with protesters in the capital lome for a second straight day wednesday, with officers firing tear gas on demonstrators who responded by throwing rocks and burning tyres. roughly 2,000 people gathered in lome for the second day of anti government demonstrations organised by let s save togo, a coalition of civil society and opposition groups, ahead of parliamentary elections expected in october

notes: since the demonstration was watched by security forces, i have coded this as crowd dispersal as there was the potential for it. thousands of protesters marched without incident in the togolese capital lome on saturday after two days of rallies earlier in the week that saw clashes between demonstrators and police. the opposition coalition let s save togo said more than 100 people were injured and 125 arrested during the rallies tuesday and wednesday that were dispersed with tear gas, with some demonstrators throwing rocks and burning tyres in response. saturday s march began in lome s be kpota neighbourhood and proceeded peacefully to a city beach as security forces looked on. protesters have been seeking a delay in parliamentary elections to allow reforms to first take place, as well as the repeal of changes to electoral laws that they say the government pushed through.

notes: the combat for political change cap 2015 , togo s main opposition grouping, on saturday organised a peace march in the capital of lome to demand an end to the past month s rises. thousands of opposition supporters and civil society groups took to the streets for several hours, chanting anti government slogans and holding a rally. security forces watched over the demonstration but it passed off without incident after a previous protest in february turned violent, leaving one person dead and several others injured.

sources: protesters demand term limits for leader, the gazette montreal , september 7, 2017 thursday, world; pg. n4, 118 words; regimes increasingly shut down internet to control protests, the globe and mail canada , september 11, 2017 monday, news; pg. a4, 725 words, geoffrey york, staff;
notes: thousands in togo took to the streets wednesday to demand presidential term limits as anger grows in the small west african nation over the 50 yearrule of the gnassingbe family. internet and phone service were sporadic, but that didn t stop the scheduled demonstrations aimed at preventing president faure gnassingbe from running for a fourth term in 2020 elections. while gnassingbe has not said he would run again in 2020, the opposition has said it suspects he will not quit power unless compelled to step down. after 50 years of repressive rule by the same family, the people of togo rebelled. the regime responded with a strong arm tactic that has become increasingly popular among the world s autocracies: it shut down the internet, making it almost impossible for its opponents to use social media to organize. on sunday, for a sixth consecutive day, the shutdown was still in effect. the togolese people had no access to facebook, whatsapp or any other internet services on their mobile phones the main way in which africans gain access to the internet although there were reports late on sunday night that service was finally being restored. last week, protesters took to the streets of togo to demand a two term limit for the president and other reforms, but police dispersed the protests with tear gas and violence.

protesteridentity: protesters mainly calling for the restoration of the country s 1992 constitution, which imposes term limits
sources: one family has ruled togo for 50 years. protests are shaking its grip on power., the washington post, september 15, 2017 friday, a section; pg. a13, 723 words, max bearak;
notes: the protests that filled the streets of lome, togo s capital, last weekend were probably the biggest in the nation s history. protesters mainly called for the restoration of the country s 1992 constitution, which imposes term limits. chants of faure must go and liberate togo filled the air. note: the actual number of protesters was not provided in the source, and is based on prior reporting of the size of national protests as well as prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters demanding the release of protesters jailed after demanding the resignation of president faure gnassingbe
sources: hundreds march in togo for release of protesters, agence france presse english, november 3, 2018 saturday 7:37 pm gmt, 210 words, lome, nov 3 2018
notes: over one thousand people marched in togo s capital of lome on saturday to demand the release of protesters jailed after demanding the resignation of president faure gnassingbe. at the call of the citizen front togo debout fctd , an umbrella organisation of civil society groups, the demonstrators converged on a public square. some leaders of the main coalition, including veteran opposition leader jean pierre fabre, attended the beginning of the protest. according to the opposition, some 50 people are still jailed after taking part in protests to demand the resignation of gnassingbe, who has been in power since 2005 after taking over from his father, who ruled for 38 years. gnassingbe has opposed changes to the constitution that would put a limit on presidential terms, sparking the nationwide uprising. those still in detention must be released immediately and unconditionally, said front spokesman david dosseh. the fctd has also spoken out against elections scheduled for december 20. we don t associate ourselves with this sham electoral process, said dosseh.

protesteridentity: togolese opposition supporters demanding a halt to preparations for december 20 polls
sources: new demos in togo ahead of elections, agence france presse english, december 1, 2018 saturday 5:50 pm gmt, 361 words, lome, dec 1 2018
notes: several thousand togolese opposition supporters held a third demonstration in a fortnight on saturday in and beyond the capital lome to demand a halt to preparations for december 20 polls. the main opposition coalition in the western african nation which has seen more than a year of unrest has vowed to boycott the elections alleging the process is fraudulent. the 14 party coalition, which suspended its rallies for several months amid efforts at dialogue brokered by the ecowas regional grouping is demanding the resignation of president faure gnassingbe. but the polls are set to go ahead without the coalition parties with togo s constitutional court having cleared only 12 other parties and approved 17 independent candidates to contest the election. we do not want elections as elections are never clear in togo. we are tired of this regime and we want change, said shakira yacoubou, a supporter of the pan african democratic party. note: the actual start and end dates of the protest were not provided in the story, and are based on prior coding decisions

sources: opposition supporters clash with security forces in togo, agence france presse english, december 8, 2018 saturday 3:39 pm gmt, 367 words, lome, dec 8 2018
notes: a young child was killed as opposition supporters clashed with security forces in togo s capital, lome, on saturday, the security minister said, after the government banned protests about upcoming elections. a child was shot dead by individuals travelling in a 4x4 without a number plate. a search is under way to find the vehicle and its occupants, general yark damehane told afp. damehane added that the child was aged about eight, although on social networks the victim was said to be about 11. the minister said there had been reports of another death but there was no official confirmation. a statement on the latest situation will be published this evening, he added. a coalition of 14 opposition political parties this week announced a series of 10 new protests in the run up to parliamentary elections planned for december 20. the opposition is boycotting the polls because of alleged irregularities in its organisation but this week the government banned the marches on security grounds. in several areas of the capital, in particular the agoes suburb, youths set up barricades and burned tyres. security forces reacted by firing teargas and chased protesters. two people were killed as opposition supporters clashed with security forces in togo s capital, lome, on saturday, the government said, after protests were stopped elsewhere in the country. a statement read on national television said the two bodies were found in quick succession in the agoe zongo area of the city at about 1:00 pm 1300 gmt . the first body was that of a young man aged about 17. he had an open wound in his left eye indicating a bullet entry wound, it added. the second body, of a man aged about 30, showed no trace of bullet wounds. the government, which had earlier said the first victim was a young child, said it appeared unidentified gunmen in a black 4x4 type vehicle were shooting in the area. four members of the security forces were injured and 28 protesters were detained, it added. the opposition also said there were two deaths as well as several injured. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: opposition supporters clash with security forces in togo, agence france presse english, december 8, 2018 saturday 3:39 pm gmt, 367 words, lome, dec 8 2018
notes: a young child was killed as opposition supporters clashed with security forces in togo s capital, lome, on saturday, the security minister said, after the government banned protests about upcoming elections. a coalition of 14 opposition political parties this week announced a series of 10 new protests in the run up to parliamentary elections planned for december 20. the opposition is boycotting the polls because of alleged irregularities in its organisation but this week the government banned the marches on security grounds. in the northern cities of sokode and bafilo, 350 kilometres 220 miles north of lome, opposition supporters attempted to assemble for a demonstration. but they, too, were dispersed with teargas. sokode is a stronghold of the pan african national party pnp of tikpi atchadam, who was behind the first countrywide street protests but is now thought to be in exile in ghana for his own safety. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: demonstrator dies during togo protest: security minister, agence france presse english, april 13, 2019 saturday 5:41 pm gmt, 198 words, lome, april 13 2019
notes: a demonstrator died saturday in bafilo, northern togo, during an opposition rally for presidential term limits, the minister for security told afp. a group of youths were marching towards the centre of the town when they were dispersed by security forces, general yark damehame said. unfortunately, we registered a death. at the moment, the circumstances of his death have not been elucidated, he added, while insisting that the protester had not been shot dead. local inhabitants reached by afp said the victim had been beaten to death by paramilitary gendarmes. one witness who asked to remain anonymous said: he was arrested by security forces while we were marching, and beaten to death. the panafrican national party had called for protests across the country, but security forces quickly locked down sites that had been selected, witnesses said. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: six killed in political demonstration in cameroon xinhua general news service, may 27, 1990, sunday, 100 words ;
notes: six people were killed and 10 others wounded in clashes between demonstrators and security forces in bamenda, northwest cameroon on saturday, cameroon radio and television announced this evening. in response to a call for political reform in bamenda, more than 20,000 residents of the city took to the street demanding political pluralism in defiance of an order prohibiting such demonstrations, the local press reported.

notes: meanwhile, some 400 yaounde university students left campus today to hold demonstrations in support of the demonstrators in bamenda, the cameroon radio and television said.

sources: press trial sparks cameroon riots the guardian london , january 22, 1991, 450 words, by mark huband in abidjan ;
notes: since no exact date is given, the protest is dated to take place the previous sunday, as the only dating indication is last week ? the rioting was ignited by the trial of two journalists who had refused to submit for censorship an article critical of the government. while allowing an independent media, non government newspapers often appear with censored articles blacked out on the page. after a two day trial, they were cleared of insulting the president but found guilty of insulting the national assembly and other institutions. they were fined pounds 800 and given a six month suspended jail sentence. last week s trial bore out the claims of the sceptics. as police helicopters hovered over the court room in the economic capital, douala, and troops charged crowds numbering up to 5,000 with tear gas and batons, the trial threatened not so much the democratic process as the incumbent government. at least two, and possibly three, people were killed in similar demonstrations in the northern town of garoua. the town is the birthplace of the former president, ahmadou ahidjo, who retired in 1982 but led a failed coup against the biya government in 1984.

notes: a march by 2,000 people, mainly students, on tuesday marked the resurgence of vocal public demands for rapid political change in the country, which has been ruled as a one party state by president paul biya since 1982. five hundred students were arrested.

sources: unemployed and students riot against cameroon single party the guardian london , april 4, 1991, 353 words, by mark huband in abidjan ;
notes: students and unemployed workers clashed with police in the cameroon capital yaounde yesterday during a demonstration demanding rapid political reform. witnesses in yaounde said up to 3,000 people marched through the city at around 9 am and set up barricades when riot police used teargas to disperse them. at least one bus was set on fire as the police launched baton charges against demonstrators.

notes: thousands of protestors agaisnt president paul biya s one party rule paralysed the cameroon town on bamenda, an english speaking opposition stronghold.
