sources: cameroon s president confident about pluralism prospects at home agence france presse english, 215 words ;
notes: several hundred cameroonian students used the occasion sunday to protest what they called the blatant violation of human rights in their country.

sources: world in brief five killed in protests the globe and mail canada , may 18, 1991 saturday, 35 words, reut ;
notes: since there were 5 deaths, i have coded it as 50 because in many other cases when there are deaths, at least 50 protesters were present while there were deaths, we cannot be certain that anyone government related had anything to do with this protest. the deaths could be a result of group clashing or just being trampled by a crowd. there is no indication here that government forces did anything. yaounde fresh violence flared in cameroon yesterday, the second day of a strike against president paul biya, after official media reported that at least five people were killed in anti government protests. reuter

sources: world in brief cameroon protest the globe and mail canada , may 20, 1991 monday, 59 words, reut cameroonian troops block pro democracy protest the toronto star, may 20, 1991, monday, home delivery two, news; pg. a12, 141 words, reuter ;
notes: douala, cameroon street protests against the one party government of president paul biya went on long into the night after the army stopped and then allowed an opposition march to proceed. about 50,000 people marched yesterday to a square where opposition leaders vowed the protest would continue until mr. biya resigns or holds a national conference. reuter the marchers were demanding the ouster of president paul biya. troops with rifles and police with riot shields formed a cordon to block the march by about 50,000 people, who chanted biya, thief. the march is part of a campaign organized by opposition leaders to force biya to convene a national conference to discuss the end of his nine year, one party rule.

protesteridentity: social democratic front and the national union for democracy and progress
sources: arrest of opposition officials sparks demonstration agence france presse english, 209 words ;
notes: since they are referred to as a large crowd, and in other circumstances a large crowd is usually at least 50 people, if not more, this has been coded as a protest that meets our criteria. violent demonstrations broke out in cameroon on wednesday in ngaoundere, i,000 kilometres 600 miles from the capital, when two officials from opposition parties were arrested on the orders of provincial governor bernard minelli elomo, informed sources said. a large crowd marched on the governor s office to protest at his refusal to release the local officials from the social democratic front and the national union for democracy and progress. security forces fired warning shots in the air and used tear gas to turn the demonstrators back. the sources here said tension remained high.

sources: followers rampage after opposition chief wounded agence france presse english, 81 words ;
notes: the police response here appears to have taken place prior to the 5000 taking to the streets, and actually is the cause for the violence. there is no reported response to the 5000. an estimated 5,000 people took to the streets and set vehicles on fire when police fire wounded opposition leader john fru ndi in western cameroon, according to reports reaching the capital thursday. ndi, head of the social democratic front, was slightly hurt in an ankle in the town of bafoussam as he tried to stage a march of party militants which the provincial authorities had banned. police said he was probably hit by a rubber bullet as they broke up the gathering.

sources: cameroon: at least 20 people held at journalists demonstration agence france presse english, 239 words ;
notes: at least 20 people were arrested wednesday in douala, cameroon s economic capital, during a demonstration by journalists against censorship and the suspension of several independent magazines, a well informed source said here. those held included the editors of le messager and la nouvelle expression, two of the five private weekly magazines ordered to suspend publication last the demonstrators were dispersed by police using teargas, said the source.

sources: seventeen badly injured at cameroon pro democracy demo agence france presse english, 211 words ;
notes: seventeen people were seriously hurt wednesday in cameroon when fierce clashes erupted during an opposition demonstration for democratic reforms, cameroon radio reported. the violence at bamenda in the english speaking northwestern region broke out when police tried to stop the demonstrators from marching on liberty square a traditional rallying point for the local opposition, the radio said.

sources: world in brief protesters beaten the globe and mail canada , october 27, 1992 tuesday, 84 words, reut ;
notes: riot police in cameroon scattered hundreds of anti government protesters with tear gas yesterday and arrested about 50 people, beating them severely, witnesses said. the demonstrators, in the economic capital douala, were angry at results that gave president paul biya a slim victory in cameroon s first free elections on oct. 11. opposition parties accuse mr. biya of massive rigging.

sources: thousands rally to protect cameroon opposition leader the associated press, december 28, 1992, monday, am cycle, international news, 336 words, by derald everhart, associated press writer police in cameroon disperse supporters of a leading foe the new york times, december 29, 1992, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 8; column 4; foreign desk, 95 words, ap ;
notes: police fired tear gas to disperse thousands of protesters monday who barricaded streets in a northwestern town after rumors that an anti government activist would be moved from house arrest to prison. state radio said at least 30 people were hurt in clashes in bamenda, where protesters blocked roads with cars, burning tires and tree limbs. the demonstrations erupted after rumors that opposition leader fru ndi, who is under house arrest in the town, was about to be transferred to a prison in the capital, yaounde, about 175 miles southeast. police officers fired tear gas today to disperse thousands in a northwestern town who were demonstrating after having heard rumors that an opposition leader under house arrest would be imprisoned. the state radio said that at least 30 people had been wounded in clashes in the town, bamenda, where the protesters blocked roads with cars, burning tires and tree limbs.

protesteridentity: l union pour le changement union for change upc
sources: clash between police and demonstrators in cameroon xinhua general news service, march 19, 1993, friday, 80 words ;
notes: cameroon s security forces thursday used tear gas to disperse opposition demonstrators in several places in the country. the demonstrations were organized by the opposition coalition, l union pour le changement upc , to dispute the outcome of last october s presidential election in which president paul biya was re elected. the upc claimed government fraud in the election. nine people were injured in the clash, and police made a number of arrests, said the opposition.

sources: cameroon: two shot dead in anti government demonstrations ips inter press service, march 25, 1993, 550 words ;
notes: two people were shot dead and 16 others seriously wounded when security forces opened fire on opposition demonstrators in the north western provincial capital town of bamenda today. the demonstrations were part of the weekly thursday protest marches called by the opposition coalition, the union for change, led by john fru ndi. similardemonstrations were reported in the pro opposition commercial capital douala, the western provincial town bafoussam and in limbe in the south west province. in the capital yaounde, security forces used tear gas to disperse some two thousand demonstrators that had gathered for a similar protest march. stalls and shops around the central market remained closed for most of the day. sources close to the police say a few people were arrested while a others sustained minor injuries from police beatings. among the arrested was lucas akwa, a photographer for the government owned daily cameroon tribune who came to cover the event. asked why he had been arrested as he was being led away by eight armed policemen, akwa managed only to say: they just heard me speaking english and said i was one of fru ndi s people.

sources: cameroon: riot police clashes with demonstrators ips inter press service, october 12, 1993, tuesday, 358 words ;
notes: riot police today clashed with a group of parents who were protesting over a delay in their children s examination results. the police used tear gas after they had failed to disperse the demonstrators with water cannons. one person was seriously injured on the right eye. another sustained an injury on his back, according to eye witnesses. the clash occured when about 1,500 parents gathered at the premises of the ministry of education demanding the government to speed up marking the general certificate of education gce examinations before the new term begins oct. 21. the police action angered the parents who complained that francophone cameroonians, who dominate the country s political power, were discriminating against the anglophone community.

sources: university courses suspended after unrest agence france presse english, 320 words ;
notes: academic authorities suspended courses at the yaounde ii university on thursday following clashes between cameroon police and students the previous day, official sources said. police used water cannon to drive off 100 students marching on the prime minister s office here on wednesday to protest against the death of 10 students killed in a road accident. some students also set fire to the university vice chancellor s offices to object to a decision to transfer courses for 15,000 students to the new yaounde ii premises, where there are neither drinking water nor canteen facilities. students are also calling for transport to be laid on. for lack of buses, they are often forced to hitch rides on trucks carrying sand on the road from yaounde to sao, 13 kilometres eight miles from the capital, where the university lies.

sources: cameroon politics: villagers up in arms as military kills 50 ips inter press service, february 25, 1994, friday, 424 words ;
notes: in the wake of the burning down of sarena and the arrests that followed, thousands of people turned out in the town of kousseri feb. 23 to demonstrate against what they view as government victimization of villagers. they have called on government to set up a commission of inquiry and are demanding that the offending soldiers be punished. no official reaction has come from the capital yaounde, sparking widespread speculation that government may have ordered the raid.

sources: rights group: government attacking opponents associated press worldstream, november 02, 1994; wednesday, international news, 324 words ;
notes: the league said the crackdown began oct. 15 when the coalition front of allies for change held a peaceful march that was violently dispersed by police who arrested six people. all six belong to fru ndi s social democratic front, the group said in a statement. on oct. 24, supporters gathered outside the courthouse of bafousam to demand that the detainees be freed. police attacked them. some had ribs broken, others gashes cut into their heads, and 33 of them were arrested and jailed without any medical care, the league alleged. it described the attack as a return to basic barbarism and flagrant violation of liberties. provincial governor philippe menye has said in radio broadcasts that police acted because the march was illegal and that those arrested will be brought before the courts.

sources: three dead, 16 injured in cameroon protest agence france presse english, 146 words three dead, 16 injured in cameroon protest agence france presse english, 254 words ;
notes: three people, including a policeman, were killed and 16 injured during a demonstration friday organised by cameroon s main opposition social democratic front party, sdf and hospital sources said. the demonstration, in the southeastern town of limbe, was held to protest the imposition of government appointees in place of elected mayors in the country s 20 biggest municipalities. the casualties happened when police used tear gas to break up the demonstration which had been banned by the authorities and chased the protestors through the town, the sources said. among the four who died on friday were two police, one lynched by the mob. the demonstration was held to protest the imposition of government appointees in place of elected mayors in the country s 20 biggest municipalities. neither national radio or television had reported the incident by saturday afternoon. the casualties happened when police used tear gas to break up the demonstration which had been banned by the authorities and chased the protestors through the town, when gunfire broke out, the sources said.

sources: cameroon security forces move in against separatists agence france presse english, 433 words 23 secessionists detained in english speaking cameroon: report agence france presse english, 468 words ;
notes: this is coded as political process first and secondarily social restriction. the social restrictions imposed upon the english speaking cameroons are why they wish to secede from the country. security forces were deployed in large numbers thursday after secessionist demonstrations and arrests in cameroon s mainly english speaking south west province, witnesses said. residents of buea and limbe, reached by telephone, said that security forces were posted at strategic points in the two towns following the arrest of several secessionist activists at the weekend. members of the southern cameroon national council scnc held marches in the towns, using the flag of cameroon from the first years after independence, with two stars signifying federalism and a bilingual republic. today, english speakers contest francophone domination. a source close to the security forces said two or three people were arrested at the weekend, but a source close to the scnc said that a dozen people were detained and remain unaccounted for since. security forces have detained 23 members of the separatist southern cameroon national council scnc over secessionist rallies in towns in english speaking parts of the country, a press report said monday. the scnc militants were arrested last week in the south west province after marches held on january 8 and 9 in the towns of buea and limbe to press a call for independence, the independent thrice weekly paper the herald said.

sources: over 100 students arrested in campus clashes in cameroon agence france presse english, 274 words ;
notes: several student protesters were injured and more than 100 were arrested during clashes with police in cameroon s economic capital douala, students and hospital officials said friday. one student was in a critical condition after the violence thursday on the city s university campus, a hospital official said. angry students went on to set fire to several classrooms. the students had called wednesday for a boycott of classes in a protest over increased costs, exam conditions and grant payments.

sources: three secessionists killed protest in cameroon agence france presse english, 188 words clashes in cameroon between police, secessionists leave three dead associated press international, october 1, 2001 monday, international news, 286 words, emmanuel tumanjong; associated press writer ;
notes: the second article alludes to the fact that the two protests were planned together by the secessionist movement. this is coded as political process first and secondarily social restriction. the social restrictions imposed upon the english speaking cameroons are why they wish to secede from the country. three english speaking secessionists were killed and five injured on monday when security forces broke up a demonstration in the northwestern town of kumbo, hospital sources told afp. hundreds of demonstrators had gathered in the streets of bamenda, 400 kilometers 300 miles west of yaounde, and kumbo, 110 kilometers north of bamenda, carrying the blue and white flag of cameroon s english speaking secessionists, according to witnesses who spoke to afp by telephone. they said that in kumbo, security forces manhandled demonstrators and fired shots which resulted in the deaths and injuries. cameroon s communications minister jacques fame ndongo told afp that security forces were responding to attacks by demonstrators armed with guns the secessionist southern cameroons national council defied a government ban on public protests and organized marches in the french speaking nation s only two english speaking provinces. nfor nfor, vice president of the secessionist movement, told the associated press that police fired on a crowd of about 500 demonstrators in kumbu, about 430 miles 700 kilometers west of the capital, yaounde, killing three civilians and wounding five others. a senior police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed police and paramilitary forces fired on the crowd in kumbu to try to break up thedemonstration. he said 40 people had been arrested there. nfor spoke by cellphone from a jail in bamende northwest of kumbu where he had been arrested with about 100 other secessionist advocates who also took to the streets to protest. nfor said four civilians had been wounded in clashes between police and secessionists in bamende.

sources: at least three killed in cameroon violence agence france presse english, july 9, 2003 wednesday, international news, 280 words police civilian clash sparks rioting in cameroon, 2 killed associated press international, july 9, 2003 wednesday, international news, 169 words ;
notes: at least three people were killed and about 50 injured wednesday during violent demonstrations in cameroon s largest city of douala sparked by allegations that a police officer had killed a taxi driver, hospital sources said. by wednesday evening calm appeared to have returned to the city after the day long riots, and demonstrators had withdrawn street barricades erected earlier, afp journalists said. but tension remained in one district where protesters had attempted to torch a police station. one demonstrator told afp that the taxi driver had died after being hit on the head by a piece of wood during an altercation with a police officer at a checkpoint late tuesday. after hearing of the rumours, taxi drivers clashed with police, setting fire to cars and police posts, witnesses said. hospital sources said three people were killed and about 50 injured, some of them seriously, in wednesday s protests. the sources refused to say how the casualties occurred, but witnesses said some of the victims were shot. national radio said police fired into the air to disperse rioters who tried to set fire to the police headquarters of the city s 6th district. hundreds of angry bystanders stormed a nearby police station. paramilitary police used water canons and fired shots in the air to disperse the crowd. police reported 40 arrests around the city

sources: murder of politician shuts down town for protest in cameroon agence france presse english, august 23, 2004 monday 3:01 pm gmt, 299 words protest over cameroon politician s murder shuts down town again agence france presse english, august 24, 2004 tuesday 3:54 pm gmt, 347 words thousands march to protest cameroon politician s murder agence france presse english, august 27, 2004 friday 4:17 pm gmt, 311 words ;
notes: some 4,000 people held a march monday in bamenda in northwest cameroon in protest at the election year murder of a local opposition politician they blamed on the mayor, police reported. the demonstrators shouted slogans hostile to president paul biya, his political party, and the local tribal king, after social democratic front sdf politician john khontem was killed on thursday night. we ll march in bamenda every day and make it a dead town until the chief of balikumbat, responsible for the murder of john khontem, is arrested and put on trial, sdf leader john fru ndi vowed on monday. some 8,000 people held a march on friday in bamenda in northwest cameroon to protest the election year murder of a local opposition politician they blamed on a tribal leader, police said. the march was the biggest so far of protests held in bamenda every day since monday to protest the killing last week of the opposition social democratic front sdf member john khontem. the protestors, led by sdf president john fru ndi, marched through the town carrying a coffin which they later burned, a local journalist told afp, adding that shops had been closed for the demonstration.

sources: two cameroon students killed in clash with police agence france presse english, april 29, 2005 friday 1:38 pm gmt, 260 words ;
notes: two students of the university of buea were killed thursday during clashes outside the campus, higher education minister jacques fame ndongo said in a statement, adding that a legal investigation had begun. the students were demonstrating to press for the release by police of a number of their comrades arrested on wednesday, when a strike for better academic facilities began, accompanied by violence. about 200 of us decided to march on the police station where the students were being detained when police charged at us and killed two of our comrades with their weapons, a student witness reached by telephone told afp.

sources: clashes between cameroon students, security forces kill one, residents and officials say associated press international, may 25, 2005 wednesday, international news, 225 words cameroon students call off strike after deal with government agence france presse english, may 27, 2005 friday 3:45 pm gmt, 574 words ;
notes: the second article indicates that this protest on 24 of may exceeded 50 participants. the first article notes the initial government response was violent. as noted in the second article, by friday the government had accommodated the students by lowering tuition students striking over school fees clashed with security forces at a university in southern cameroon, leaving one dead, residents and officials said wednesday. fighting sparked tuesday at the university of buea when students who have been skipping class to protest tuition payments they deem excessive demanded security forces leave the campus, residents said. innocent mbunwe, a local journalist in buea reached by the associated press, said security forces shot a cab driver in the chest, killing him. violence broke out twice in buea, initially on april 28 when two students were shot dead during clashes with police, then last tuesday when one person was killed and about 50 injured in a further confrontation between youths and security forces sent on to the campus, according to hospital sources. on friday, the minister reportedly agreed to a lowering of academic fees in buea and official recognition of a student representative body.

sources: cameroon security forces fire on protestors, killing one agence france presse english, november 10, 2007 saturday 12:31 pm gmt, 125 words ;
notes: since there was a need for crowd dispersal, i have considered this protest to be greater than 50 participants. one person died and five were injured after security forces fired on a crowd protesting after a two week long power cut in the west african nation of cameroon, state radio and witnesses said saturday. the incident occurred on friday in kumba, about 300 kilometres 185 miles north west of the capital yaounde, when locals took to the streets to protest the arrest of four high school students following an earlier demonstration. the crowd, incensed by the firing, torched the municipal office, a police station and the local office of cameroon s state electricity provider aes sonel.

sources: leading trade unionist arrested in cameroon demo: leader agence france presse english, november 28, 2007 wednesday 6:36 pm gmt, 135 words ;
notes: police arrested a top cameroon trade unionist and a colleague wednesday during a banned protest by civil servants demanding pay rises, the union leader said. about 300 people met for a sit in outside the national assembly when police dispersed us and i was arrested along with a colleague, jean marc bikoko, head of the umbrella civil servants union csp, told afp by telephone from a police post. the csp, which unites a dozen trade unions, called the three day strike to press for higher wages and the chance to retire at 60 instead of 55.

sources: tear gas fired into cameroon constitution demo agence france presse english, february 23, 2008 saturday 11:19 pm gmt, 139 words ;
notes: since no location is given for this, it has been coded as the capital, as that is where it is datelined from. police in cameroon fired tear gas and water cannon saturday at a crowd of several hundred gathered for an outlawed demonstration against president paul biya s constitutional reform plans.

sources: 2 killed during protest in cameroon associated press international, february 25, 2008 monday 12:30 pm gmt, international news, 264 words, by emmanuel tumanjong, associated press writer ;
notes: at least two people were killed as police clashed with demonstrators calling for the reopening of a tv station that had been critical of the government and was shut down by anti riot police last week, police said monday. police said hundreds of protesters gathered saturday on the northern outskirts of douala, cameroon s economic capital, mounting barricades and blocking traffic. they shouted liberate equinoxe, and said equinoxe tv was closed because of its reporting, particularly on protests against president paul biya s amending of the constitution to extend his stay in power. police shot at the protesters as they threw rocks at security forces, state radio reported. a 70 seater passenger bus and two gas stations were set on fire and two people were shot dead, said a police officer who spoke on condition anonymity because he did not have permission to speak to the press

sources: cameroon clashes claim more lives after strike ends agence france presse english, february 27, 2008 wednesday 4:57 pm gmt, 639 cameroon transport strike ends, but violence continues agence france presse english, february 27, 2008 wednesday 11:14 am gmt, 355 wordswords, fanny pigeaud protest turns violent in cameroon associated press international, february 27, 2008 wednesday 9:57 pm gmt, international news, 398 words, by emmanuel tumanjong, associated press writer protests mount in cameroon, at least seven killed deutsche presse agentur, february 28, 2008 thursday 6:13 am est, politics, 151 words cameroon drops taxes, raises salaries after violence agence france presse english, march 7, 2008 friday 9:21 pm gmt, 159 words cameroon government raises violence death toll to 40 agence france presse english, march 10, 2008 monday 6:14 pm gmt, 524 words ;
notes: it is the fourth article which gives the information regarding the sequence of demands made by the protesters. the fifth article notes that the government later accommodated the issues with essential good prices. the use of water cannons as a means of crowd dispersal led to a number of deaths, which has led me to code this as ? killings? as well. it is unclear as to when the arrests occurred, so they have been coded under the sequence section as occurring during the actual protest as well as after, through the accommodation period. renewed violence broke out wednesday in cameroon, where the mayor of the western town of njombe reported eight more deaths in clashes, after a two day transport strike triggered unrest. eric kingue, a member of the ruling cameroon people s democratic rally, told private canal 2 television that two people were killed on wednesday morning in njombe itself, and six others died on tuesday night in loum, further north. strife over the price of fuel and essential products erupted on monday and tapped into opposition protests against a proposal to change the constitution to enable president paul biya to run for office again in 2011. the latest reports of violence brought the death toll to 17 since an opposition protest in douala on saturday, according to an afp tally. the economic and political unrest has been accompanied by looting and vandalism. witnesses reported further clashes between protestors and riot police in several districts of the western port city of douala, the central african country s economic capital. national radio reported that unions representing transport workers had won a small cut in petrol prices, appealed for calm and called off the strike they launched on monday. the roman catholic archbishop of yaounde, christian tumi, also called for an end to the unrest, after the unrest spread tuesday to the capital itself, east of douala and in the heart of the country. gunfire again broke out in the bonaberi district of douala, a stronghold of opposition to biya, as riot police took up positions on the main bridge over the wouri river in the city, where streets were empty of traffic. witnesses said that the police on the bridge turned water cannon on protesters there and some people fell into the river. there were also reports of gunfire and columns of smoke in the southwestern town of buea. though road haulage unions decided to call for a return to work after the government agreed to cut petrol prices, the unrest comes against a background of protest at the cost of living and a crackdown on the opposition. protest banners carried in several towns since have combined protests at the cost of living with calls for biya s resignation. it was the third successive day of clashes that have so far killed eight people across the central african country, according to an afp tally. thousands of people holding placards blocked intersections in yaounde, ransacking cars that attempted to pass. police used tear gas and rubber batons to beat back demonstrators. in both cities, government offices and private businesses were looted and some were set ablaze. the protests began against the fuel price increases but continued even after the government rolled them back. the demonstrations then turned against president paul biya s desire to change the constitution to lengthen his term. taxes on essential goods have been dropped and civil service salaries are to rise by 15 percent, cameroon national radio announced friday following violent protests last week. around 1,500 arrests were made and 50 people have been found guilty and sentenced in yaounde for looting or ransacking property or cars, the government said last week, without giving details. a group of demonstrators was trapped on the wouri bridge between security forces stationed at both ends. many people leapt into the water. eighteen bodies have been recovered by now, she said, adding that fishermen have been threatened if they talk.

sources: cameroon police block journalists rally agence france presse english, may 3, 2010 monday 3:41 pm gmt, 397 words ;
notes: while the police were able to keep the protesters from getting to their planned spot to stage their sit in, eventually they staged it on a street corner, so this is still a codeable protest. police used billy clubs on the demonstrators as they tried to reach a planned sit in in front of the prime minister s office in yaounde, an afp correspondent reported. between 200 and 300 people had heeded a call by the cameroon journalists union to mark the day by protesting the death last month of bibi ngota, managing editor of the cameroon express, in kondengui prison in yaounde. the government said he died of an infection linked to the hiv virus, which the editor s family has rejected. ngota had been jailed in march on fraud charges and media rights groups charged that he was denied medical attention for prior problems with high blood pressure and a slipped disc. police blocked monday s protest because the journalists had not given proper notice of a public rally, said city official martin motassi, a claim the journalists union denied. the protesters eventually staged their sit in at the street intersection where they were stopped, waving banners saying free all the journalists still in prison! .

sources: two dead in cameroon prison mutiny: official agence france presse english, september 9, 2010 thursday 3:47 pm gmt, 241 words ;
notes: two prisoners were killed and two warders injured during a two day mutiny at the prison in bamenda, the chief town of the english speaking northwest part of cameroon, a prison official said thursday. two inmates were killed and two warders were seriously wounded in a mutiny, said the official in the state office for penal administration, who asked not to be named. the mutiny broke out on monday night. it went on during the day of tuesday, the source added. the prisoners attacked warders because they wanted the replacement of the prison director, nganjo mama, and were protesting against their conditions of detention. some of the warders fought back, the source said. after this uprising, justice minister amadou ali sacked the director and named an interim successor, francis musi mac tata, several anonymous sources told afp.

sources: cameroon police arrest nine in pay protest agence france presse english, november 11, 2010 thursday 4:33 pm gmt, 279 words ;
notes: since the police were present at arrested individuals, it is implied crowd dispersal also took place, or had the potential to take place. additionally, the police presence implies that there were greater than 50 people present. cameroon police arrested at least nine people thursday during a banned demonstration for higher pay and for equality in the retirement age in the public service. the nine members of the public sector union confederation csp could be seen being taken into detention while preparing what the csp called a peaceful mobilisation outside the offices of the prime minister , philemon yang. csp leader jean marc bikoko, who was one of the people taken into custody, was hit on the head by a policeman during the demonstration, the afp journalist saw.

sources: cameroon s ex employees stage protest against non payment of dues xinhua general news service, august 9, 2011 tuesday 5:10 pm est, world news; political, 319 words ;
notes: thousands of former employees of in cameroon staged a protest in the capital yaounde to press for the immediate payment of their retrenchment benefits, dues and pension allowances, their spokesman told xinhua said on tuesday. the protesters were sacked by privatized, liquidated and restructured public and parastatal companies following the economic crisis that hit the country in the 1980s and 1990s. they began a sit in in front of the ministry of finance on monday to demand the payment. there are altogether about 56,000 of them from 47 liquidated or restructured public and para public companies. they have not been paid any retrenchment dues, retirement benefits and pension allowances since they were forcefully laid off duty 17 to 22 years ago, their spokesperson rene david moukoundo told xinhua.

sources: cameroon: 50 arrested in independence march the associated press, october 1, 2011 saturday 03:14 pm gmt, international news, 128 words, by emmanuel tumanjong, associated press cameroon: 126 arrested over independence protest the associated press, october 2, 2011 sunday 03:13 pm gmt, international news, 131 words, by emmanuel tumanjong, associated press ;
notes: this is coded as political process first and secondarily social restriction. the social restrictions imposed upon the english speaking cameroons are why they wish to secede from the country. an official and an activist say police arrested 50 protesters seeking independence for english speaking cameroon. the police official says activists from the southern cameroons national council demonstrated saturday in the city of buea. he asked for anonymity because he is not authorized to speak to journalists. protester patrick siani confirmed the demonstration and arrests.

sources: twins cut out of dead mother with razorblades on street leads to public outcry in cameroon; monique koumate s family are raising money to help pay for her funeral the independent united kingdom , march 30, 2016 wednesday 4:34 pm gmt, africa, 548 words, serina sandhu;
notes: mobile phone footage of the incident was shared on social media, and a few days later march 15 , residents of douala protested against the country s healthcare system outside the state runhospital. one protestor told the kamervibe website: we cannot continue to let cameroonians die. it is unacceptable that those who do not have money, die in our hospitals. that ends today, we mobilised this protest to express our dissatisfaction.

sources: cameroon police detain 60 regime opponents agence france presse english, march 29, 2016 tuesday 9:09 pm gmt, 228 words;
notes: police in cameroon on tuesday detained around 60 members of the opposition who had gathered in yaounde to protest any attempts to change the constitution to extend the 34 year rule of president paul biya opponents told afp. the police blocked the site of the press conference, which was called to denounce any bid to change the constitution, and used tear gas on the opponents as they tried to disperse, said emmanuel simh, vice president of the movement for the rebirth of cameroon mrc .

sources: bamenda lawyers protest adoption of new penal code cameroon tribune yaound , june 27, 2016, 234 words, choves loh;
notes: the barristers on june 23, 2016, took to the streets to raise their voices against some aspects of the document. lawyers reject any bill or law that incriminates landlord tenant relationship, lawyers reject any law or bill that protects the rich against the poor, we reject the continuous manipulation of the constitution of cameroon, etc. the lawyers trekked about 2.5 km from the up station appeal court premises down to city chemist roundabout in downtown bamenda. they told those who cared to listen that they were on a peaceful protest to raise awareness on the need for everybody to be subject to the law.

sources: bamenda common law lawyers take to the streets cameroon tribune yaound , november 09, 2016, 335 words, liengu etaka esong;
notes: the protest of november 8, 2016, was to demand the respect of the bi jural and bi cultural nature of cameroon. street demonstrations, protest messages and tear gas by security officers summed up the protest by common law lawyers in bamenda on november 8, 2016. the day was early to break for the lawyers who assembled in the premises of the north west court of appeal. the over 500 lawyers were both from the north west and south west regions. they thereafter marched from the court of appeal through commercial avenue to t junction, then food market and back to the city chemist roundabout.

sources: violent clashes in english speaking cameroon agence france presse english, november 23, 2016 wednesday 1:56 pm gmt, 348 words riots erupt in cameroon daily mirror, november 24, 2016 thursday, news; pg. 6, 45 words;
notes: violent clashes between police and protesters from cameroon s english speaking minority broke out early this week in the northwestern city of bamenda, two people were shot dead monday and tuesday in violence between police and protesters. a third person was killed during fighting between rival groups. police stepped in when the demonstrators set fire to tyres on the streets. the protesters first demanded that the government delegate or government appointed mayor be sacked but then demanded the position itself be abolished. at least 100 people have been arrested after days of protests against the use of french in courts and schools in english speaking parts of cameroon.

sources: two dead in clashes in cameroon s anglophone region: tv agence france presse english, december 8, 2016 thursday 8:20 pm gmt, 410 words cameroon frees anglophone youths in bid to end protests agence france presse english, january 10, 2017 tuesday 6:26 pm gmt, 355 words;
notes: at least two people were killed in clashes between police and protesters from cameroon s english speaking minority in the country s northwest on thursday, state television reported. a group of youths were trying to block a meeting for the ruling people s democratic movement cpdm of president paul biya in the city of bamenda before police shot at them, opposition social democratic front sdf spokesman denis nkemlemo said. the youths were detained on december 8 during violent clashes between protesters and security forces in the opposition stronghold of bamenda which left at least two people dead and saw nearly 60 arrested.

protesteridentity: protesters addressing issues of governance and calling for freedom
sources: bamenda life returns in town, cameroon tribune yaound , september 25, 2017, 730 words, choves loh; buea calm after agitations, cameroon tribune yaound , september 25, 2017, 813 words, nkeze mbonwoh;
notes: it was business as usual over the weekend after the friday, september 22, 2017 demonstrations. issues of governance were central in peaceful protests that took some persons to the streets of bamenda and neighbourhoods on friday, september 22, 2017. the day was early to break for the protesters who defied ordinances by the north west and mezam administrations, prohibiting public manifestations. the bamenda regional hospital roundabout, t. junction and foncha street junction were take off points for the people that soon stormed the streets in different directions. they moved to the palaces of nkwen and mankon and attempts to move towards the administrative area of up station were frustrated by the forces of law and order . carrying peace plants and chanting songs, the protesters featured placards with various messages. they raised concerns about living together in a union which they claim is built on falsehood. taxis and commercial motorcycles on regular business activities were quick to retreat from the streets while shops remained shut the whole day. security forces conspicuous at major junctions conducted themselves in a manner appreciated by all for professionalism. the whistle blowing protesters spent a good part of the day on the streets. the protests came on the heels of an explosion following the detonation of an improvised devise at the gateway into the bamenda regional hospital on september 21, 2017. three policemen on duty suffered serious injuries from the explosion. the protests announced for september 22 were not to help matters and it was against this backdrop that north west governor, adolphe lele lafrique on the strength of regional order no 022 of september, 21, 2017 prohibited the movement of persons from one division to the other in the region for 24 hours from thursday september 21 at midnight to friday september 22 at midnight. meanwhile, in another decision, the mezam sdo, songa ren pierre prohibited the movement of persons from 10 pm to 5 am up to october 3, 2017. calm has returned to the north west region and normal activities are on course after last friday s social upheavals by some people who stirred disorder. on behalf of the government we condemn the incidents during which some casualties were registered with some forces of law and order suffering injuries while some lost their property. in batibo some school children were threatened and their property burnt and some looting took place. some vandals also went to the regional hospital and threatened a police officer on duty. it was reported to me that a corpse was taken to the regional hospital on that day but we are still investigating the circumstances. we have set up an inquiry commission to investigate the situation following the upheavals. how was the situation managed? before the demonstrations, administrative and security measures were taken to prevent any disturbances of public order but despite some people, largely in the minority marched in the towns and villages of the region resulting in some acts of vandalism, looting and burning. those on the streets were asking for freedom and the release of some people remanded in custody. i think you cannot be talking of freedom while behaving as agents of disorder characterized by acts of anarchy. that cannot be condoned and the forces of law and order worked in a very professional way to maintain public order. road circulation, markets and shops regained activities in the weekend following street protests observed on september 22, 2017. calm has returned to buea, capital city of the south west region, following last friday s upheaval with hundreds taking to the streets in protest marches. the governor of the region, bernard okalia bilai, called for calm and asked parents to keep their children at home or at school preventing them from going to the streets to cause havoc. the city of buea, capital of the south west region, awoke to a protestmarch friday, september 22, 2017. the protesters trooped in from the ekona end pulling the muea participants. they were joined at molyko with those from mutengene gathering along their mates of dibanda and bolifamba. the protesters held fresh branches, leaves and placards calling for freedom . the protesters swelled in numbers drawing curiosity from dwellers who lined up by roadsides to observe. the divisional officer for buea, kouam wokam paul, and the elements of the police and the gendarmerie were seen strategically positioned at great soppo apparently to contain the protesters and prevent escalations into the administrative quarters. initially no physically violent acts were observed in the early hours of the day. but by mid day, the protesters hauled stones on the main road from the entrance to buea mile 17 bus station to the clerks quarters on a close to 10 kilometre distance. a vehicle was set on fire in front of the bilingual grammar school molyko and a house at the molyko check point was also put to flames. in the same vicinity, five cars parked in the yard of the residence of ekema patrick, mayor of buea, were crushed with stones. the glass windows and balcony of ekema s house were also shattered with stones. the situation was equally tense elsewhere in divisional headquarters like kumba, menji, mamfe, limbe, and other hot spot areas like ekona, mutengene, muyuka. ekondo titi and mbonge. protesters marched up to administrators in many areas, and reportedly started to down the national flag and hoist what they called the ambazonia flag . note: the number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

location: Bolifamba; Bomaka; Buea; Kumba; Menji; Kupe; Tombel; Limbe; Ndu; Oku; Ashong; Bambalang; Balikumbat; Kumbo
protesteridentity: demonstrators looking to hoist the ambazonia flag; southern cameroonian united front
sources: buea safe from protesters, cameroon tribune yaound , october 02, 2017, 398 words, narcisse mouelle kombi; north west governor salutes respecting safety, cameroon tribune yaound , october 03, 2017, 430 words, choves loh; deaths and detentions as cameroon cracks down on anglophone activists; dozens die and hundreds jailed in unrest after calls for english to be used in regions schools and courtrooms, the guardian london , january 3, 2018 wednesday 5:00 am gmt, world news; version:1, 1014 words, ruth maclean in yaound ;
notes: the central city of buea, capital of the south west region, remained calm yesterday, october 1, 2017 amidst threats of hoisting the ambazonia flag. meanwhile periphery quarters like bolifamba, bomaka and muea were under agitations by mid day. the forces intervened to keep order without any major incident reported. repeatedly, young people came out like a cat and mouse game to block the roads between the bus station at mile 17 and muea and the forces quickly cleared the barricades. reports from kumba headquarters of meme division, talked of agitations organised in periphery spots without affecting the central town. confrontations were reported between the forces and the protesters on several sites in kumba. in menji, a crowd came out in protest but at press time no major confrontation with the forces was reported. in kupe muanenguba paul elung che, minister delegate at the ministry of finance, had spent time educating the people on the falsehood in dreaming of a separated state. the efforts seemed to pay off as only minor agitations reported in tombel. limbe remained relatively calm with some standoff reported in mile four, kassava farm and new town. in general the authority of the south west region had pre empted an agitated day of october 1, 2017 and taken measures to include the closure of drinking places, restricted movements from one town to another. equally, groupings of more than four persons had been banned and borders with neighbouring country closed as well as stopped any public manifestation. north west governor, adolphe lele lafrique has urged the population to remain confident and stand by the head of state who is committed to go the extra mile in seeking lasting solutions to the anglophone problem rocking the south west and north west regions. twenty four hours after the october 1st, 2017 street protests that threatened to jeopardize social peace in the north west region, the governor has congratulated the population for respecting administrative recommendations that largely kept people and property safe. he told cameroon tribune on october 2, 2017 that casualties of the protests left some six people dead in ndu, oku, ashong, bambalang and balikumbat following confrontations between the forces of law and order and some armed persons who attempted to defy state authority, burnt and destroyed public emblems. elsewhere in kumbo, the governor revealed that some four inmates were shot after burning the prison to facilitate their escape. the lot in casualties includes, the burning of the car of the sdo of boyo division, attacks on some gendarmerie brigades and police stations, injuries suffered by some four gendarmes and four policemen, some protesters and the seizure of three guns ,some 18 motorcycles and some machetes by the forces of law and order while some arrests were carried out and remanded in custody with bamenda emerging without any death at press time. after months of bellicose rhetoric, cameroon s long time president, paul biya, appeared to hold out something of an olive branch to the anglophone regions in his new year s address, saying dialogue was the best way of resolving the crisis and promising to decentralise power so that people could manage their own affairs. however, he added: all those who have taken up arms, who perpetrate or encourage violence should be fought relentlessly and held accountable for their crimes, before congratulating the security forces for their bravery, determination, restraint and professionalism. he made no mention of the 40 people killed and 100 injured surrounding the peaceful protests of 1 october, when activists from the southern cameroonian united front symbolically declared the two anglophone regions the independent republic of ambazonia. the government closed borders to the anglophone regions before deploying the army s rapid intervention brigade, a unit that is normally found fighting boko haram in another of the country s crises, that of the northern lake chad region. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the sources, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: women protesting against abuses committed against women in months of fighting between the government and anglophone separatists
sources: women protest abuses in cameroon anglophone separatist fight, associated press international, september 7, 2018 friday 1:20 pm gmt, international news, 373 words, bamenda, cameroon
notes: hundreds of women gathered for an angry protest in cameroon on friday against abuses committed in months of fighting between the government and anglophone separatists. with some singing, weeping, crying out or praying, the women described the rapes of their daughters and killings of family members as civilians are caught in the crossfire. nearly 200,000 people have fled. the women who gathered in a stadium in bamenda city in the heart of the conflict called for an urgent dialogue on peace. they say they want to leave their homes and go without fear to the market and fields as before. they say they cannot remain silent and want to denounce what they call a dirty war. the unrest in the southwest and northwest is a major issue as largely french speaking cameroon faces elections in october, with 85 year old president paul biya, in power since 1982, running again. tensions rose further in bamenda on thursday when a headmaster and three teachers were kidnapped by armed men. we are calling on the powers that be that women want peace, said a protest organizer, adah mbah. we do not have any hidden agenda anywhere. we are tired. for more than two years, we cannot be quiet. many women at the protests carried leafy branches of so called peace plants. others clutched rosaries or dressed in black. they sat on the ground. the women are the ones mourning. the women are the ones managing their homes ... they are struggling in all ways to survive, said another organizer, akouoh aline. we want our leaders to see our pain. note: the primary protester demand is coded as political behavior, process because the story does not specify whether the government is the source of the violence against women

protesteridentity: opposition supporters protesting the results of a presidential election
sources: cameroon opposition militiants freed, others detained, agence france presse english, october 28, 2018 sunday 2:47 pm gmt, 249 words, douala, oct 28 2018
notes: cameroon authorities have released around 50 opposition supporters detained in douala, but also arrested others on sunday in yaounde, their party said. they were freed, a member of maurice kamto s party, movement for the rebirth of cameroon mrc told afp in reference to those arrested saturday during an unauthorised march called to protest the results of a presidential election on october 7. kamto placed second in the poll with 14.23 percent of the vote behind president paul biya, who has ruled cameroon for 35 years and was credited with 71.28 percent. one of those arrested on saturday was taken to hospital after he fell from a police vehicle , a relative said. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters against the re election of president paul biya
sources: cameroon police arrest dozens amid anti government protests, associated press international, october 27, 2018 saturday 4:05 pm gmt, international news, 145 words, yaounde, cameroon
notes: an official in cameroon says anti riot police have arrested at least two dozen people who staged peaceful protests saturday against the re election of president paul biya. territorial administration minister paul atanga nji said among the arrested is a lawyer who represented opposition candidate maurice kamto who said he won the oct. 7 election. nji said the government wouldn t tolerate acts to undermine cameroon s security as it prepares to inaugurate 85 year old biya for his seventh term in the coming week or so. cameroon s constitutional council declared biya s win with 71 percent of the votes followed by kamto with 14 percent. the government on friday announced that it had banned all protests and public demonstrations. hundreds gathered saturday and promised to continue demonstrations until biya, who has led since 1982, leaves power.

protesteridentity: supporters of opposition leader maurice kamto, who disputes the results of october presidential elections, protesting against president paul biya
sources: cameroon police arrest 19 opposition protesters, agence france presse english, november 4, 2018 sunday 5:43 pm gmt, 185 words, douala, nov 4 2018; cameroon police arrest 38 opposition protesters, agence france presse english, november 5, 2018 monday 9:46 am gmt, 296 words, yaound , nov 5 2018
notes: police in cameroon arrested 19 supporters of opposition leader maurice kamto, who disputes the results of october presidential elections, at protests against president paul biya on sunday, local authorities and witnesses told afp. the arrests happened at two different places in the town of bafoussam in the country s west where kamto backers were picketing, they said. kamto, who according to official results came second with 14 percent of the vote behind incumbent biya with seven percent, called friday for an independent vote recount. he claimed victory in the october 7 polls, and has been declared an outlaw by the government. but kamto, one of seven candidates seeking to unseat biya who has ruled the west african country for 36 years, insists the process was marred by widespread fraud. members of kamto s movement for the rebirth of cameroon mrc posted images on social media sunday of their protest against what they called an electoral hold up . a senior mrc official, emmanuel simh, said 38 people were arrested on sunday during protests in the western town of bafoussam. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the stories, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters supporting cameroon opposition leader maurice kamto, who still claims victory in october s election
sources: three injured at cameroon opposition rally: party officials, agence france presse english, january 26, 2019 saturday 2:40 pm gmt, 254 words, douala, jan 26 2019; cameroon opposition figure charged with rebellion: lawyer, agence france presse english, march 8, 2019 friday 2:04 am gmt, 329 words, yaound , march 8 2019
notes: at least three people were shot and wounded saturday at a protest for cameroon opposition leader maurice kamto who still claims victory in october s election, party officials said. several people were wounded at saturday s rally in douala, the country s economic capital, paul eric kingue of the opposition rebirth of cameroon mrc party told afp by telephone. cameroon s ruler paul biya, in power for more than three decades, won the election with 71.2 percent but the poll was marred by fraud allegations, low turnout and violence. kamto of the mrc won 14.23 percent of the vote to place second, but his party has held sporadic protests since then to dispute the result. a mrc municipal council member michele ndoki was among the three injured on saturday, according to photographs posted on social media. another party member confirmed three people had been injured, though it was not immediately possible to confirm the seriousness of their injuries or how the injuries had happened. the three victims were transported to hospital in douala, sources said. a prominent lawyer close to detained cameroon opposition leader maurice kamto was charged thursday with rebellion, her lawyer said, after the country shrugged off international concern over a wave of arrests targeting government critics. michele ndoki was placed in custody and charged with the same offences as kamto, who is being held for insurrection, hostility to the homeland and rebellion, according to her lawyer emmanuel simh. ndoki was detained following a protest in the country s economic capital douala on january 26 in support of kamto, who was subsequently arrested along with some 150 supporters. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: supporters of opposition leader maurice kamto, who claims to have been cheated out of the presidency in elections last year
sources: cameroon opposition leader maurice kamto arrested: party, agence france presse english, january 28, 2019 monday 11:32 pm gmt, 381 words, yaound , jan 28 2019
notes: cameroon opposition leader maurice kamto, who claims to have been cheated out of the presidency in elections last year, was arrested in the country s economic capital douala on monday, a senior party member said. the arrest is the latest political turbulence to hit the west african country and comes after several recent eruptions of violence over the october vote, which saw kamto come second behind paul biya, who has ruled for more than three decades. on saturday 117 people were arrested during protest marches in several towns. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: supporters of opposition leader maurice kamto, who claims to have been cheated out of the presidency in elections last year
sources: cameroon opposition leader maurice kamto arrested: party, agence france presse english, january 28, 2019 monday 11:32 pm gmt, 381 words, yaound , jan 28 2019
notes: cameroon opposition leader maurice kamto, who claims to have been cheated out of the presidency in elections last year, was arrested in the country s economic capital douala on monday, a senior party member said. the arrest is the latest political turbulence to hit the west african country and comes after several recent eruptions of violence over the october vote, which saw kamto come second behind paul biya, who has ruled for more than three decades. mr kamto was arrested at the home of supporter albert dzongang, said emmanuel simh, vice president of the opposition movement for the rebirth of cameroon mrc , confirming information from a source in douala. following kamto s arrest, around 300 people gathered outside dzongang s house, according to an afp reporter, flanked by about 50 police officers. shots were fired into the air to disperse the crowd.

protesteridentity: movement for the rebirth of cameroon mrc
sources: 100 cameroon opposition members freed: party, agence france presse english, june 6, 2019 thursday 6:08 pm gmt, 312 words, yaound , june 6 2019
notes: a hundred members of the opposition movement for the rebirth of cameroon mrc were freed thursday following their arrest during demonstrations last week, the party told afp. however mrc vice president mamadou mota, who was also detained on june 1, remains in detention, the same opposition party source said. today 100 of our members, arrested on saturday... have been freed, said lawyer christopher ndong, secretary general of the mrc. in all, 351 mrc supporters were arrested during protests which took place in several towns throughout the country, including nkongsamba, in the west, and yaounde, according to the party s figures. there are still 251 people incarcerated in prison cells, said ndong. at least 30 of those arrested, including mota, have been transferred to yaounde s main prison. the prison also houses mrc head maurice kamto, the country s main opposition figure who has been detained since january. saturday s protests called for the release of kamto and other party supporters who were arrested after another protest in january. such protest marches are banned by cameroon.

sources: crackdown, separatist uprising inflame cameroon prisons, agence france presse english, july 24, 2019 wednesday 2:46 pm gmt, 766 words, libreville, july 24 2019; cameroon detainees tortured after riot: human rights watch, agence france presse english, august 20, 2019 tuesday 3:23 pm gmt, 309 words, libreville, aug 20 2019
notes: crushed inside disease ridden cells, with no beds, little food and even less hope, inmates in cameroon s prisons were already tense before an influx of political detainees and anglophone separatists stirred up an explosive mix. at an overcrowded central prison in the capital yaounde this week, hundreds of prisoners revolted against their poor conditions in an upsurge of violence broadcast on facebook. on monday, videos spread across social media of prisoners ransacking and burning the kondengui jail library and a sewing workshop before security forces crushed the munity. filming on their phones, inmates posted parts of their protest, chanting: we want more to eat than porridge, and we want to go to trial. a day later, security services had reestablished control. cameroonian authorities detained and tortured more than 100 prisoners, including suspected members of the country s anglophone separatist movement, after a jail riot last month, human rights watch hrw said tuesday, august 20th. the prisoners were taken to a military detention facility the morning after rioting broke out in the central prison in the capital yaounde on july 22, the rights group said. they were held incommunicado, beaten by gendarmes and guards and interrogated at gunpoint, it said, citing interviews with 14 detainees and several lawyers. the gendarmes put a piece of cloth on my nose and beat me. i was tortured like this, beaten badly several times on my legs and back, hrw said, quoting a 37 year old man from the city of bamenda. the rioting in central prison had been sparked by anger at overcrowding, living conditions and delays in bringing detainees cases to court, hrw said. many of those held there were suspected anglophone rebels, whose movement has declared a separate state for english speaking rebels in the majority francophone country, its report said.

protesteridentity: women protesting against gender violence and inequality on international women s day
sources: women fill streets of world s cities with call for justice, associated press international, march 9, 2020 monday 2:22 am gmt, international news, 1187 words, by amy guthrie, associated press, mexico city
notes: women filled the streets of the world s largest cities sunday to protest gender violence and inequality on international women s day, with the mothers of murdered girls leading a march in mexico city and participants in paris inveighing against the virus of the patriarchy. while many protests were peaceful celebrations others were marred by tension, with security forces arresting demonstrators at a rally in kyrgyzstan and police reportedly using tear gas to break up a demonstration by thousands of women in turkey. safety was in short supply at some events to mark the day. the detonation of explosives triggered panic at a ceremony in bamenda, an english speaking town in the northwest of cameroon. suspicions focused on separatists who had vowed to disrupt the events. no one was killed or wounded. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: 2 killed in northern nigeria in a clash over islamic law the new york times, january 8, 1992, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 9; column 1; foreign desk, 98 words, ap ;
notes: the nigerian police broke up a demonstration by militants calling for islamic law in a northern state, and at least two people were killed and 29 injured, the police said today. the fighting broke out on sunday when hundreds of shiite muslim youths tried to take over the central mosque in katsina, more than 700 miles northeast of lagos. officers prevented the shiites from entering the mosque and opened fire when the demonstrators attacked them, police officials added.

sources: fuel riots erupt in nigeria s biggest city the new york times, may 14, 1992, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 4; foreign desk, 666 words, by kenneth b. noble, special to the new york times lagos swept by riots over fuel shortages the independent london , may 15, 1992, friday, international news page; page 11 , 141 words, by karl maier 100 feared dead as christians battle muslims in nigerian city the toronto star, may 19, 1992, tuesday, metro edition, news; pg. a19, 355 words, reuter ap ;
notes: enraged by a gasoline drought in this major oil producing country, gangs of militant anti government demonstrators skirmished with riot policemen today, leaving at least three people dead and hundreds hurt. the street violence, the worst in years, was viewed by many here as possibly upsetting the schedule that nigeria s military leader has offered for transferring power to elected civilians by next year. though the anger of the demonstrators was also directed at economic policies like recent price rises and a 43 percent currency devaluation, the catalyst was the lack of gasoline, which forced reductions or suspension of taxi, bus and truck service. the shortage, it was explained, was brought about by administrative decisions to simultaneously shut down three of the country s four refineries for what was described as routine maintenance while the fourth was not operating because of a fire s effects. for brief periods today, large areas of northern and western lagos were taken over by bands of marauding youths, some several hundred strong. they set up burning barricades on roads and bridges leading to the main business district and attacked vehicles. the riots followed a call by university students for a general strike to protest the worsening economic hardships and fuel shortages. the riot policemen, using tear gas and raw force, ultimately managed to retain control of lagos, nigeria s principal city. but reports persist of clashes elsewhere in the country. lagos youths attacked banks and offices in lagos s main business district yesterday on the second day of rioting over fuel shortages and soaring inflation, writes karl maier. but it was apparently not related to the two days of riots in lagos and nine other cities last week that were set off by gasoline shortages throughout the sprawling west african nation of 88.5 million people.

sources: nigerian protests erupt in violence the new york times, july 6, 1993, tuesday, late edition final correction appended, section a; page 3; column 4; foreign desk, 540 words, ap lagos explodes in violent protest over election veto the times, july 6, 1993, tuesday, overseas news, 367 words, by elizabeth obadina in lagos and kate alderson army issues ultimatum as nigerian protests spread the times, july 7, 1993, wednesday, overseas news, 577 words ;
notes: lagos, nigeria in the first serious unrest here since results from the june 12 presidential election were voided last month, the city was torn by violence today as tens of thousands of protesters turned out to denounce the decision. the violence broke out hours before a scheduled march to protest the decision by gen. ibrahim babangida, the military leader, as demonstrators set fire to barricades, looted shops and hijacked cars. protesters built barricades of buses and tires and set them ablaze, sealing off the central business district in the sprawling capital of 1.3 million. similar protests stopped business in the southwestern city of akure, but the rest of nigeria appeared calm. the police responded by firing tear gas from helicopters and on the ground, but they appeared to confront the violence only when they felt threatened. an accurate casualty count as difficult to determine, although there were reports of scattered injuries. the election, which was apparently won by moshood abiola, a businessman, was held to restore civilian rule in this country of about 90 million people. about 10,000 people took part in the march, which ended at the gates of mr. abiola s compound in lagos. he climbed to the top of one of the compound s walls and addressed the crowd, urging nigerians to be calm without abandoning their commitment to change. thousands of people lit bonfires, stole cars and looted shops in the streets of lagos yesterday after weeks of simmering tension erupted in protest at general ibrahim babangida s decision to annul last month s presidential election. the unrest, the first to hit nigeria s biggest city since the polling, broke out hours before a democracy march that had been organised by the campaign for democracy pressure group. general abacha issued the order to michael otedola, governor of lagos state, on the second day of demonstrations against the cancellation of last month s presidential elections.

sources: nigerians protest arrest the new york times, june 24, 1994, friday, late edition final, section a; page 2; column 4; foreign desk , 96 words, reuters ;
notes: hundreds of people marched through central lagos this evening, demanding the release of moshood abiola, the opposition leader who was detained early today after addressing a rally wednesday. he was the undeclared winner of last year s presidential election, which was annulled. nigeria s current ruler is gen. sani abacha. abacha must go, release our president now! chanted the marchers, mostly young people.

sources: nigeria protest broken up the new york times, june 25, 1994, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 5; column 1; foreign desk , 108 words, reuter ;

notes: reuter: a pro democracy group said yesterday that 52 of its members were arrested after protesters demanding an end to military rule clashed with police in ibadan, the second largest city in nigeria. sylvester odion akhaine, general secretary of the campaign for democracy, said many people were injured. newspapers said the trouble began when demonstrators attacked a convoy of vehicles carrying the military administrator of oyo state.

sources: 20 are reported killed during protests in nigeria the new york times, july 19, 1994, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 6; column 2; foreign desk , 257 words, reuters ;
notes: at least 20 people were killed today in pro democracy demonstrations in lagos, the biggest city in strike bound nigeria, the leader of a democracy group said. at least 20 people were killed during protests in different locations in lagos today, beko ransome kuti, president of the campaign for democracy, said. there was no official confirmation of the deaths. riots flared early in the day in several parts of the sprawling city of six million people, and the police fired tear gas to disperse the crowds who were calling for an immediate return to democracy.

notes: hundreds of people scattered in panic in the centre of lagos yesterday as police fired guns in the air and used tear gas to disperse protesters calling for the resignation of the nigerian military junta. the lagos demonstration was the second day of clashes between youths and police in the city. many people were arrested. one eyewitness said: people were protesting against the government and the police fired many bullets into the air and everyone just ran for their lives.

sources: nigerian opposition leader on trial; protests grow violent the new york times, july 29, 1994, friday, late edition final, section a; page 8; column 3; foreign desk , 533 words, ap ;
notes: this protest is in relation to the one mentioned here in lagos. the protest about abuja is coded as protest 6 for 1994. a peaceful pro democracy protest during the hearing turned violent when youths set up burning barricades in a main intersection in abuja. the police opened fire, killing at least 5 people and wounding 15. similar protests broke out in lagos. youths looted markets, rampaged through bus terminals, lit bonfires and barricaded an expressway. riot police broke up the demonstrations with tear gas. about 50 people were arrested and the campaign for democracy, a human rights coalition, said one of its workers was killed.

notes: the dateline for this is aug 1. since the police had to fight the rioters for several hours and needed tear gas this protest is deemed as 50 rioters fought the police in lagos today as a strike by oil workers broadened into a vast protest against the military government. looters rampaged through the main business district, where most offices and shops were closed because of transportation and fuel shortages caused by the strike. the police used tear gas and fought the rioters for several hours. no figures were available on injuries or arrests.

notes: at least five people were killed yesterday after police in lagos opened fire on demonstrators calling for the release of the detained opposition politician moshood abiola, pro democracy activists said. the clashes with the police came on the first day of a general strike aimed at securing chief abiola s freedom, they said.

sources: 5 killed in nigeria as strike against military junta grows the new york times, august 4, 1994, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 2; column 3; foreign desk , 421 words, ap ;
notes: police officers fired on peaceful protesters and battled youths today as nigeria s biggest labor federation joined a strike aimed at toppling the military junta. two marches that drew a total of 7,000 people collapsed in chaos when the police moved in to break them up. reporters saw police officers shoot and kill at least two people. three other people died when youths armed with machetes tried to keep shop owners from doing business in the open markets of central lagos in defiance of the nationwide strike.
