sources: angry students stop presidential motorcade in gabon. associated press international. may 22, 1998 ; friday : 246 words.;
notes: students angry over unpaid scholarship allowances stopped a motorcade carrying the presidents of gabon and burkina faso. at least 10 students were seriously injured in the ensuing clash with security forces, state run radio said. a car was also reportedly set ablaze in the thursday confrontation.

sources: tepid response to strike call in gabon. agence france presse english. 227 words. november 18, 1998 14:38 gmt ;
notes: a few hundred strikers demonstrated in the capital, according to an afp correspondent there.

sources: gabon police use tear gas against student demo agence france presse english, 85 words ;
notes: the dateline on this article is january 14, which gives me the date for this demonstration, as it was a thursday. police in the gabonese capital used tear gas thursday to break up a demonstration by hundreds of students protesting campus conditions. the students set up barricades across some of libreville s main streets, where they also turned over several cars and started a number of fires, according to an afp correspondent on the scene. calm was restored late in the afternoon.

sources: government closes gabon s main university associated press international, january 23, 1999; saturday, international news, 147 words ;
notes: considering the last protest over the university was 100 and this event seemed to draw even more people, i consider it safe to assume this protest was also 100 authorities closed gabon s main university and its secondary schools after protesters rampaged through streets and torched government buildings. three police officers and a student were seriously wounded in friday s melee, radio reports said. higher education minister lazare dibombe ordered the indefinite closure later friday. authorities also issued an ultimatum to students to abandon their protest by midnight saturday. two months of intermittent demonstrations escalated this week after government workers and secondary school students joined students at omar bongo university to demand the re opening of the campus restaurant and the creation of an internet website.

sources: two killed in attack on police station in gabon agence france presse english, september 9, 2004 thursday 10:13 pm gmt, 274 word ;
notes: the defense ministry said the protesters attacked the police station after learning thursday that one of their number had died after being injured a few days earlier during a security forces operation aimed at breaking down barricades set up for a local protest. the defense ministry said reinforcements were deployed late thursday to help restore order in the southern region of the west african country. the barricades were erected on september 2 in a protest action to demand the resumption of electricity supply to several villages in nyanga province, the largest of which is makongonio. the villagers are also demanding that the government supply school furniture. during an operation to dismantle the barricades, 12 gendarmes and two civilians were wounded in unclear circumstances, the police statement said. the defense ministry said that a group of protesters armed with 12 caliber guns who were hostile to the presence of security forces threw projectiles at the gendarmes and opened fire, adding that the gendarmes fired warning shots in the air and used tear gas.

sources: bongo s reelection in gabon sparks street violence agence france presse english, november 30, 2005 wednesday 4:48 pm gmt, 571 words ;
notes: since scores of youths are noted in the article, this has received a conservative estimate of 50 protesters omar bongo s re election as gabon s president led to overnight violence, protests and arrests in the economic capital of port gentil after the opposition cried fraud, witnesses said wednesday. after the interior ministry announced that president bongo, in power since 1967, was back in office for seven more years, scores of youths went on the rampage in the port city in the southwest of the oil rich central african country. witnesses and an afp correspondent said they smashed cars, erected street barricades and burned tyres, hurling stones at riot police and troops who went in and tear gassed them. soldiers in port gentil told afp that most youths they clashed with were aged between 15 and 20, while police said they had arrested several youths but refused to give figures.

sources: gabon police break up protest as bongo declared winner agence france presse english, december 1, 2005 thursday 8:52 pm gmt, 424 words ;
notes: police in gabon clashed thursday with protesters called into the streets by opposition leaders disputing president omar bongo s re election for another seven year term. several hundred people began the march outside a libreville hotel where pierre mamboundou and zacharie myboto told a press conference they refused to recognize the validity of the election held on sunday. a few hundred metres yards from the hotel, police in riot gear attacked marchers, including women, with batons and tear gas, an afp correspondent said. police made 23 arrests, a judicial source told afp later, adding that a number of people were injured. two journalists were also briefly detained, including an afp correspondent.

sources: retired gabonese servicemen demonstrate over pensions agence france presse english, march 8, 2006 wednesday 5:12 pm gmt, 329 words ;
notes: due to the number arrested, i have coded this as 50 retired military personnel set fire to trucks and barricaded a road in a town near the gabonese capital in protests over their pensions that lead to 20 arrests, the government said wednesday. police moved in tuesday to clear barriers erected by retired servicemen on national highway number one in nkoltang, 30 kilometres 20 miles east of the capital libreville, communications minister rene ndemezo obiang told afp. some 15 to 20 people were arrested in the demonstrations in which 10 large trucks were burned, he added. former servicemen accuse the government of not listening to their demands for re evaluation of their pensions and other benefits they claim are due to them. as well as the re evaluation of their pensions, protestors demand that a rule be enforced allowing them to get specially reserved jobs and a bonus for services rendered .

sources: gabonese demonstrate against food prices agence france presse english, april 22, 2008 tuesday 5:06 pm gmt, 232 words gabonese police attack fresh protests at soaring prices agence france presse english, april 25, 2008 friday 10:18 pm gmt, 161 words gabon suspends import taxes following price hike demos bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, april 26, 2008 saturday, 69 words gabon fixes rice, flour profit limits to curb soaring prices agence france presse english, may 6, 2008 tuesday 1:36 pm gmt, 243 words ;
notes: it is the third article that illustrates that the government suspended food taxes and that other goods had profit margins capped roughly a hundred people demonstrated in gabon s capital tuesday under pounding rain against the high cost of food and other commodities in the latest such protest to hit africa. the protesters marched on the senate and national assembly in libreville with the women protecting themselves from the deluge with symbolically empty shopping baskets, before being peacefully dispersed by police. police violently broke up fresh protests on friday against soaring food prices in the capital libreville, witnesses and organisers said, a day after gabon decided to suspend food taxes temporarily. police violently dispersed the protesters, of whom there were more than a hundred , ibrahim tsendjiet mboulou, president of the gabonese consumer organisation ogc , said. he added that he and two others were questioned by police for an hour , and then released. witnesses also said police harassed three journalists who were present at the arrests and confiscated thier camera equipment. last month gabon suspending import duties for six months on basic foodstuffs including milk, flour and rice to curb inflation. gabon yesterday experienced its fourth demonstrations in as many days against the high cost of living. three people were arrested. the government has decided to suspend import taxes for six months to safeguard gabonese citizens purchasing power

sources: clashes at gabonese demo against defence minister agence france presse english, august 7, 2009 friday 4:44 pm gmt, 429 words ;
notes: this is coded as removal of a politician primarily because they want the defense minister to resign, and secondarily as political process because it is not something that he is doing wrong that is the cause for this removal, but instead the fact that he is also running for presidency. thousands of demonstrators clashed with police in gabon friday at a rally calling for defence minister ali ben bongo to resign because he is in the running to succeed his late father as president. several people were injured in skirmishes during the rally, which was attended by several other candidates to succeed bongo s father, omar bongo ondimba, who ruled the country for 41 years. friday s unrest erupted after police used tear gas on protesters throwing stones ahead of the march, which had been called by several of the candidates. as the march gathered momentum the crowd swelled to about 10,000 in democracy square, according to an estimate by an afp correspondent.

sources: police tear gas opposition protest in gabon associated press international, september 3, 2009 thursday 10:22 am gmt, international news, 421 words ;
notes: police used tear gas to disperse opposition protesters thursday as squabbling officials prepared to announce the winner of gabon s first presidential election since dictator omar bongo died. thousands of opposition supporters who had camped out in the square outside the electoral commission overnight were forced to flee when security officers began pelting the square with tear gas canisters. the government had been expected to release results wednesday evening, three days after voters went to the polls, but it was delayed when the election commission disagreed on how to review province by province results. during the night, opposition members dragged a coffin to the center of the square affixed with a sign that said, homage to ali bongo the late president s eldest son, who is one of the front runners in the race. tensions were high as security forces fanned out across libreville while helicopters hovered overhead.

location: Port Gentil, Ogooue Martitime Province and Libreville, Estuaire Province
sources: unrest rocks gabon after bongo wins disputed vote agence france presse english, september 4, 2009 friday 1:10 am gmt, 706 words, coumba sylla police break up protests over disputed poll victory; gabon the times london , september 4, 2009 friday, news; pg. 42, 552 words, jonathan clayton fresh violence flares in gabon agence france presse english, september 5, 2009 saturday 10:19 pm gmt, 660 words, patrick fort gabon threatens emergency powers to quell unrest agence france presse english, september 6, 2009 sunday 10:22 pm gmt, 644 words, ousmane niapa and patrick fort ;
notes: gabon slapped an overnight curfew on its economic hub port gentil as opposition supporters went on the rampage thursday after the son of the oil rich nation s late leader was declared winner of a bitter presidential election. the curfew went into effect on thursday from 8 pm 1900 gmt to 6 am on friday and will be repeated as long as necessary if calm does not prevail, the interior ministry said after protesters torched a french consulate in the city of 80,000 and attacked a prison. disturbances were also reported in several districts of the political capital libreville after officials said ali bongo had won the contest to succeed his father, omar bongo ondimba, with around 42 percent of the vote. crowds of young men chanted death to the whites as paris told around 10,000 french nationals not to leave their homes amid rumours the former colonial power had conspired to fix the result. the shells of burnt out cars littered highways around the capital while demonstrators had set fire to piles of tyres and erected makeshift barricades. by nightfall, libreville s streets were all but deserted except for the police and army. a number of youths suspected of being involved in violence in libreville were arrested, public television and a witness said. within hours of the announcement that ali ben bongo, a former defence minister, had won with 42 per cent of the vote, riot police fired teargas and used batons as they waded into crowds in libreville, the capital of the west african state of gabon. since the election result was announced on thursday at least two people have been shot dead in unrest in port gentil where security forces battled looters overnight friday to saturday and a police station was also attacked. a curfew is in place. the situation in port gentil appeared calm on sunday, after police used tear gas to disperse looters late saturday with protesters also setting up barricades in some areas to stop police vehicles patrolling.

sources: 18 hurt in gabon student protest agence france presse english, february 11, 2010 thursday 6:53 pm gmt, 103 words ;
notes: at least 18 people were injured in clashes thursday between gabonese police and students at libreville s omar bongo university protesting the non payment of their grants, medics said. we have treated 18 casualties. none are critical, doctor jean jacques allogo of the libreville hospital centre told afp. dozens of spent tear gas grenades as well as stones and earth clods littered the campus entrance following the protest, an afp journalist reported. a student who asked not to be named said that when they peacefully blocked the campus entrance, police attacked with tear gas. students then responded with stone throwing.

sources: gabon troops break up opposition protest agence france presse english, january 27, 2011 thursday 9:17 am gmt, 474 words ;
notes: gabon security forces fired tear gas and arrested about 30 supporters of opposition leader andre mba obame at a protest in libreville, injuring several of them, one of his aides said. mba obame, a former foreign minister and failed presidential candidate, who took refuge in un offices in the capital after having declared himself president on tuesday, denounced the intervention as irresponsible. michel ongoundou, appointed defence minister in the government that mba obame appointed, told afp that soldiers and paramilitary gendarmes had moved in on protesters at dawn outside the un premises. there was tear gas fired. there have been people injured and about 30 arrests, he said. an interior ministry spokesman told afp that it was possible that there have been arrests, but if these people are just supporters, they will not stay in prison. an afp journalist who visited the site at 6:15 am 0515 gmt was escorted away by gendarmes, but saw officers cleaning up plastic bottles and other debris from the vigil: a tent, sound system and plastic chairs set up the demonstrators on wednesday.

sources: fuel supply strike begins in gabon agence france presse english, april 1, 2011 friday 1:20 pm gmt, 528 words ;
notes: this is coded as political process as the primary demand because the protesters want a law that would affect the secondary demand? s, labor, process in the country. gabonese fuel supply sector workers went on strike friday in a protest against the employment of foreign staff at the expense of locals, but there was no rush by motorists keen to stock petrol. in port gentil, about 300 people demonstrated in the morning outside the headquarters of total gabon, where banners read, unlimited general strike against the abusive employment of foreign workers. the powerful onep union initially announced a strike to begin on march 27 at midnight, but after a week of negotiations with the government, it suspended its call while waiting for the cabinet to come out on wednesday with a decree regulating the employment of foreign workers. the strike was called when no decree was forthcoming. we hoped that the government would pass this decree, which is ready, but the government preferred to state that it was necessary to consult all the social partners, landry ivala said.

sources: new clashes between students, police in gabon agence france presse english, april 18, 2012 wednesday 1:27 pm gmt, 136 words ;
notes: since police needed to employ tear gas to disperse the protesters, it seems reasonable to say that this protest had over 50 participants. students threw stones at police and officers fired teargas to disperse them in a new bout of clashes wednesday at omar bongo university in gabon s capital libreville. the university has been the scene of violent protests by students demanding payment of scholarship funds. wednesday s clashes saw students stone police who have been stationed at the university at the rector s request since the previous disturbances. police responded by firing teargas, scattering the students into nearby streets, where they set fire to tyres and rubbish and stopped traffic. students had last week pledged to intensify their protests. we re going to empty the classrooms every day until our demands are met, student leader nicolas ondo had told afp.

protesteridentity: demonstrators led by the first lady
sources: gabon: thousands march against ritual killings the associated press, may 11, 2013 saturday 06:26 pm gmt, international news, 120 words ;
notes: since a petition was presented to the president urging him to fight the crime, it implies the protesters wanted the government to intervene, and therefore we can consider this on of our protests. thousands of gabonese people marched to protest ritual killings, in which people are murdered so their body parts can be used in amulets to bring good luck. sylvia bongo ondimba, gabon s first lady, led the event saturday along with christian and muslim religious leaders. the president of the association for the fight against ritual crimes, elvis ebang ondo, estimates that gabon has 20 mutilation killings a year. he said there are more such killings in election years, as some people seek amulets to win government positions. the marchers presented a declaration to president ali bongo ondimba, urging him to fight the crime. police dispersed a separate march by a group opposed to the participation of the first lady.

sources: 1. at least one killed in clashes at gabon opposition rally. agence france presse english. december 20, 2014 saturday 9:56 pm gmt : 409 words. 2. gabon police break up opposition rally, 1 killed. associated press international. december 21, 2014 sunday 9:04 am gmt : 138 words.;
notes: a student was killed in clashes at an opposition rally in gabon s capital, where police fired tear gas to disperse protesters demanding the resignation of president ali bongo ondimba. the opposition claimed three people had died and hundreds were injured in the violence, though there was no official confirmation of those figures. at least 20 people were arrested in scuffles between police and demonstrators, an afp journalist saw.

sources: gabon calm returns after violent demonstration cameroon tribune yaound , april 14, 2015, 343 words, emmanuel kendemeh gabon blames political lackeys for torching benin embassy agence france presse english, april 14, 2015 tuesday 11:45 am gmt, 507 words;
notes: calm and normal circulation returned to libreville, the capital of gabon, monday, april 13, 2015 following violent and destructive protests of sunday, april 12, 2015 by supporters of the opposition leader, andr mba obame whom rfi reported died in yaounde, cameroon where he was undergoing medical treatment police and other forces of law and order swiftly intervened and the protesters were disperse late at night, reports say. some demonstrators on sunday accused the regime of poisoning mba obame and in particular vented their wrath on bongo s cabinet director, maixent accrombessi, who comes from benin but has taken gabonese nationality. the opposition believes accrombessi has too much influence over the president.

sources: gabon police charge at protesters, beat afp cameraman agence france presse english, july 23, 2016 saturday 7:50 pm gmt, 342 words;
notes: security forces in gabon violently charged at demonstrators gathering saturday in libreville defying a heavy police presence, hundreds of protesters took to the streets in opposition to president ali bongo ondimba s candidacy for re election on august 26, the afp correspondent said. some 15 opposition leaders also attended the protest, forming a human chain at the front of the crowd. among them was presidential candidate guy nzouba ndama, the former parliamentary speaker. the young protesters broke into song, chanting the national anthem as the security forces began firing tear gas at the crowd. police then moved to break up the protest and several shots were heard, according to the afp journalist who saw 70 year old nzouba ndama running for cover with other demonstrators.

sources: gabon parliament set ablaze after bongo declared winner agence france presse english, august 31, 2016 wednesday 10:34 pm gmt, 827 words protesters torch gabon parliament after bongo clings to power thetimes.co.uk, september 1, 2016 thursday 12:01 am gmt, world, 537 words, jerome starkey, africa correspondent;
notes: angry protesters torched gabon s parliament wednesday after president ali bongo was declared winner of what he claimed was a peaceful and transparent election, but which the opposition said was fraudulent. it only took a few minutes for the announcement for thousands of people taking to the streets to express their fury. gunfire and explosions rocked gabon s capital libreville in a second day of violence after president ali bongo was declared the winner of abitterly disputed election. the main opposition candidate, jean ping, said government troops killed two people and wounded at least 19 others during a pre dawn raid on his headquarters.

sources: 1. police fire tear gas at protesters who prompted border closures. the associated press. october 15, 1990 , monday, am cycle : 222 words. 2. police gas protesters calling for democracy. the toronto star. october 16, 1990 , tuesday, final edition : 133 words.;

sources: 1. troops ring presidential palace to demand back pay. agence france presse english. 360 words. may 15, 1993 . 2. presidential palace siege ends peacefully, soldiers win back pay. agence france presse english. 534 words. may 15, 1993 . 3. soldiers seize radio, surround palace demanding pay. the associated press. may 15, 1993 , saturday, am cycle : 321 words.;
notes: troops of the presidential guard ringed the presidential palace and the radio station here saturday, to press their demands for payment of eight months of back pay. the central african republic s treasury is bankrupt and has not paid government workers for several months.

sources: soldiers fire shots, surround presidential palace. the associated press. may 19, 1993 , wednesday, am cycle : 164 words.;
notes: for the second time in four days, soldiers fired in the air and surrounded the presidential palace to demand back wages wednesday. civilians cleared off the streets and shopkeepers closed their stores. the demonstration was a replay of events saturday, when soldiers from the presidential guard surrounded the palace. regular army soldiers joined members of the guard in wednesday s protest.

sources: associated press international. february 15, 1996 ; thursday : 1386 words.;
notes: riot police used tear gas, rubber bullets and batons thursday to break up a protest by about 2,000 high school students supporting a teachers strike. a dozen students were arrested, but no injuries were immediately reported.

sources: associated press international. april 02, 1996 ; tuesday : 820 words.;
notes: at least 2,000 teachers marched through the capital tuesday chanting anti government slogans and demanding months of back pay.

sources: associated press international. april 18, 1996 ; thursday : 347 words.;
notes: soldiers demanding four months back pay mutinied and clashed with loyal government troops thursday, sending residents running for cover. some civilians were injuries while fleeing the violence, but there were no immediate reports of deaths. defense minister jean mete yapende went on state radio to promise the troops would be paid by friday; he urged them to return to their barracks. loyal military police began patrolling the streets.

sources: associated press international. april 20, 1996 ; saturday : 432 words. ;
notes: renegade soldiers demanding their paychecks began looting the city saturday and released hundreds of criminals into the streets after bursting into the capital s main prison. french troops expanded patrols throughout the capital, bangui, but the 3 day old mutiny showed no signs of abating and appeared to have turned into a massive looting and shooting spree. clashes were reported between mutineers, who numbered about 400, and loyal troops who surrounded the presidential palace and government buildings.

sources: 1. associated press international. may 18, 1996 ; saturday : 432 words. 2. army mutinies again in central african republic. may 18, 1996 , saturday, am cycle : 345 words. 3. sporadic firing continues in centre of capital. agence france presse english. 667 words. may 19, 1996 19:14 gmt . 4. associated press international. may 20, 1996 ; monday : 678 words. 5. associated press international. may 21, 1996 ; tuesday : 688 words. 6. french general, mutineers in first contact. agence france presse english. 840 words. may 23, 1996 23:21 gmt . 7. associated press international. may 24, 1996 ; friday : 591 words. 8. associated press international. may 28, 1996 ; tuesday : 342 words.;
notes: mutinous soldiers took the army chief and a cabinet minister hostage saturday and surrounded the presidential palace in their second uprising in two months. there were no immediate reports of casualties from the revolt, which began at about 11 a.m. 1000 gmt when scores of soldiers firing weapons into the air swept through the capital. the number of mutineers was estimated at about 200, and a group who visited a local journalist s home said they were demanding their paychecks and control of the main armory. hours later, some of the soldiers broke into the armory and fled with heavy weapons, including rocket launchers.

sources: associated press international. november 08, 1996 ; friday : 1011 words.;
notes: riot police firing tear gas and rubber bullets dispersed about 2,000 protesters who defied government orders friday and marched to the presidential palace. the protesters were civil servants who say they are owed months of back pay and have not had a raise since a salary freeze in 1986. witnesses said 13 people were arrested in friday s melee, which occurred when the crowd gathered outside the palace to press its demands. about 200 riot police moved in, swinging batons and firing gas and rubber bullets.

sources: civilians demand resolution of mutiny. the associated press. december 27, 1996 , friday, am cycle : 217 words.;
notes: civilians marched through the capital of the central african republic on friday, demanding an end to a standoff with mutinous soldiers that has paralyzed parts of the city. the 5,000 demonstrators urged both rebel soldiers and loyalist forces to remove roadblocks set up across the city since the nov. 8 mutiny.

sources: police break up student protest in bangui. agence france presse september 10, 1997 10:16 gmt .;
notes: police in the central african republic capital bangui broke up a protest wednesday by some 50 students demanding payment of bursaries from the cash strapped government. the students from the university of bangui had blocked the main road leading to the airport before being peacefully dispersed.

sources: violence despite supposed day of peace in bangui. agence france presse english ;
notes: violent incidents broke out wednesday in parts of the capital of the central african republic, where the opposition for a general shutdown in protest at the nomination of a new premier after 10 ministers resigned. in the southeast of bangui, protesters set up barricades and threw stones at passing vehicles, including a car belonging to the international committee of the red cross icrc , before security forces intervened. but new barricades sprung up in other areas as fast as the old ones were torn down and the sound of tear gas being fired was heard.

sources: 1 gunfire reported near central african republic president s home. agence france presse english; 2 guards fire outside central african republic president s home. associated press international, january 24, 2000; monday, advisory; 3 five people arrested after centrafrican militia protest: police. agence france presse english ;
notes: 1 sustained automatic weapons fire broke out near the residence of central african republic president ange felix patasse overnight, related apparently to a demonstration by youths, witnesses said monday. twice on sunday evening, live or tracer bullets were fired from kalashnikov assault rifles and volleys of teargas grenades were unleashed, triggering panic among residents of the capital bangui, sources said...the shaven headed youths who demonstrated near patasse s residence were members of a militia known as base karako, set up to protect the regime during two army rebellions in 1996 and 1997, many witnesses said... ; 2 the shots, which rang out late sunday night outside patasse s palatial home, sent the militiamen about 300 unarmed, uniformed men demonstrating to be inducted into the national army running for cover...a source at bangui s major government hospital said no injured people had been taken there overnight, though a police official said there had been about 10 arrests...sunday s demonstrators said they were protesting the delay in their being sent to join about 400 of their colleagues currently undergoing military training in the western town of bouar... ; 3 one militiaman, beaten by truncheon wielding police, was still in hospital tuesday but his life was not in danger, an official at bangui hospital told afp...

sources: militiamen protest in central african republic. agence france presse english ;
notes: several hundred militiamen recruited by president ange felix patasse during army rebellions in central african republic staged a protest march here on friday demanding integration into the armed forces. heavily armed riot police stopped the marchers close to the headquarters of the ruling centrafrican people s liberation movement mlpc as they headed for the presidential palace in bangui. the protesters dispersed without incident...

notes: 1 occurs during a two week civil servants strike nov. 2 14 ; strike called off the same day as protest; bangui, is reported tense after security forces used teargas to disperse protests by groups of young people earlier this week...the demonstrations were organised by a youth group named flambeau centrafricain central african torch . on tuesday, they attempted to block one of the capital s main arteries l avenue boganda and looted several cars. they set up barricades and burnt tyres, prompting police and presidential guard units to use teargas against them. analysts said the demonstrations were incited by the opposition which was trying to exploit the social crisis in the country ; 2 police tuesday fired tear gas and rifles to disperse more than 4,000 demonstrators at the bangui stadium, demanding that president ange felix patasse step down. the protest organised by more than a dozen opposition political parties had earlier been banned by the authorities. the clash ensued when the demonstrators including some opposition leaders rejected police orders to disperse

sources: 10,000 march in central african republic to demand late wages. agence france presse english ;
notes: more than 10,000 demonstrators, mainly striking government employees, on friday marched through the streets of bangui to demand payment of salary arrears and protest at what many called famine . the demonstration, called by the major public sector trade unions, began with a rally in defiance of a government ban by some 5,000 civil servants at the labour exchange, who then set off in procession for the city centre. the marchers, kept under control by union officials as well as police, were joined on their way by thousands of other people including students and school pupils, an afp correspondent saw...

sources: centrafrican pm calls for dialogue with civil servants. agence france presse english ;
notes: during a general strike; reports of barricardes & burning tires earlier in the week but no indication it meets size requirements for coding before this event; dozens of women meanwhile marched through the streets of bangui thursday in support of the strike. they carried banners saying: we, women of central africa, support the legitimate pay claims of workers and call for the immediate payment of workers backpay. the women also called for pensioners to be given pensions owing to them and students to be paid their grants. there were no reports of trouble and the protest ended peacefully at the beginning of the afternoon...

sources: 1 central african government bans political rallies. agence france presse english 2 police clash with demonstrators in central african republic. associated press international, december 19, 2000; tuesday, international news; 3 street protests continue in central african republic. associated press international, december 20, 2000; wednesday, international news ;
notes: 1 police tuesday used teargas to end a rally called by 15 opposition groups in the central african republic car after it was banned by the authorities. the opposition leaders, party officials and hundreds of supporters turned up at bangui s bonga bonga stadium in spite of the ban, but were met by riot police who ordered that they disperse. when they refused, police fired teargas cannisters causing a stampede during which several protestors were slightly injured. youths responded by throwing stones at police, who chased them into surrounding neighbourhoods firing shots into the air, witnesses said. the protesters were calling for president ange felix patasse to resign. his financially strapped regime is faced with the demands of striking civil servants who want to be paid at least 12 months worth of unpaid salaries... ; 2 police fired tear gas and automatic rifles at thousands of anti government protesters tuesday, injuring at least 20 people. about 5,000 people gathered at a stadium in the capital, bangui, to demand that president ange felix patasse step down. authorities had banned the meeting two days before, but organizers from 15 opposition political parties decided to press ahead. when the crowd refused to disperse, security forces opened fire with tear gas and rubber bullets. police and witnesses said some opposition members returned fire with automatic rifles before security forces began using live ammunition... ; 3 73 arrested at the stadium rally, continues for a second day

sources: police break up student protest in central african republic. agence france presse english ;
notes: riot police in the capital of the central african republic on monday used tear gas and fired shots into the air to break up a protest by students, who built barricades and set fire to tires to demand the payment of grant arrears and better conditions. the police fired warning shots with automatic rifles but no injuries were reported, according to an afp reporter at the scene. the protesters were demanding that the government pay out grant arrears of up to six three month terms and improve educational conditions

sources: central african force escorts 200 ex rebels out of bangui after unrest. agence france presse english english ;
notes: some 200 ex rebels from the central african republic car and chad have been escorted out of bangui, after they clashed with government forces, by troops of an african force providing security in car, an official said monday...on two occasions in the past ten days, they have clashed with the car army. at least seven people were killed and 15 injured, according to hospital and other sources, and residents of northern bangui, where the clashes took place, fled the area in their droves...on april 17, they ran riot in northern bangui, exchanging fire with army troops. at least seven people were killed in the fighting, and days later, residents were still fleeing the area, fearing more unrest. last week, the ex rebels struck a compromise deal with the government, the details of which have not been made public but which a source close to bozize s office has said includes a promise of 300,000 cfa frances 457 euros for any ex fighters who agree to return to civilian life.

sources: opposition supporters riot after partial central african vote result. agence france presse english, may 15, 2005 sunday 1:41 pm gmt ;
notes: opposition supporters rioted in the central african republic at the weekend when the independent vote commission said their man had lost in a narrow race, releasing more results from elections last weekend. politicians both in and out of power urged people in a volatile part of bangui to calm down sunday after the independent national electoral commission cemi said the speaker of the outgoing transitional parliament, nicolas tiangaye, had been beaten in a constituency by a very narrow margin. riot police used tear gas in a prolonged effort on saturday to disperse angry crowds who built barricades and burned tyres when the cemi said a candidate of the kwa na kwa national convergence party behind outgoing president francois bozize had beaten tiangaye by 50.49 percent of the votes to 49.51 percent. media, already warned by authorities against publishing results before official ones trickled out of the cemi, which is centralising figures from across the impoverished, landlocked nation, had said a tiangaye win was a foregone conclusion... ; opposition leaders blames electoral process irregularities

sources: car: four feared dead in bangui demonstration. bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, january 6, 2006 friday;
notes: there was a violent incident yesterday afternoon in a neighbourhood north of bangui, capital of the central african republic. disturbances were sparked after the funereal of staff sgt claude sanze phonetic who was killed on tuesday by members of the presidential guard to revenge the death of their boss. barricades were set up and shots fired. according to witnesses, the security forces opened fire on the crowd attending the funereal. four people are feared dead. here is christian panika: panika tension increased by a notch yesterday in bangui s northern neighbourhood following angry demonstrations by a crowd which had just attended staff sgt claude sanze s funereal. the soldier, who shot a fellow soldier on monday evening, was tortured then killed on tuesday by other soldiers close to the victim. on their return from the cemetery, the crowd began setting up barriers along the highway. the crowd first ran into the gendarmerie and then the republican guard. according to witnesses, the security forces opened fire on the demonstrators whom they could not contain. the crowd ransacked two refreshment rooms and a video hall belonging to a words indistinct and one of the president s sons. sources at the hospital say one woman was shot dead. other sources say that three, maybe four people are dead...

notes: 1 more than 1,000 people marched through the capital of the central african republic car to condemn unrest in the northwest of the country. they were led by the widows of two doctors from the world health organization who who were shot dead by unknown armed men in an ambush while on a mission the region last month. the marchers waved placards condemning impunity, lack of governance and rebellion... ; 2 thousands of demonstrators marched friday to protest rising violence in central african republic, calling for the government and a new rebel group to work toward peace. some 3,000 trade unionists, human rights advocates and others waved placards reading no to rebellion as they wended their way through the streets of the capital, bangui. we want peace not violence, said one organizer, noel ramadan. other protesters said the government and a new countryside insurgent group should lay down arms and work toward a cessation of hostilities...

sources: over 80 soldiers desert barracks in northeastern car. bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, august 8, 2006 tuesday ;
notes: over 80 central african soldiers have deserted their post in the northeast of the country. they returned to bangui to protest against their living conditions but were immediately arrested by their superiors. this is the third time, in less than three months, a group of soldiers has deserted their post in the northeast. recently, violent clashes between the army and unidentified armed men were reported in this region hit by high insecurity.

sources: witnesses: central african republic police shoot at irate street vendors. associated press international, january 30, 2007 tuesday 12:57 pm gmt, international news, 213 words, by joseph benamsse, associated press writer ;
notes: police fired into a crowd of rioting street vendors in the capital of central african republic on tuesday, killing at least one, according to witnesses and hospital workers. an associated press reporter saw police shoot into a crowd of about 60 people who were facing off against the officers in the streets of a commercial area of bangui. one of those involved, a vendor named jean marie guerekonzi, said the violence started after a storeowner asked police to disperse about two dozen vendors who had set up tables around his shop. guerekonzi said they refused to move and some people started throwing stones at police, who then started shooting. the vendors offer items like cloth, shoes and notebooks to passers by.

sources: police in car crush protest against their violence. agence france presse english, february 14, 2007 wednesday 1:33 pm gmt ;

sources: soldiers clash with protestors in central african republic. agence france presse english, march 6, 2009 friday 3:14 pm gmt ;
notes: soldiers clashed with demonstrators in the central african capital of bangui friday who took to the streets to protest at the killing of the city s police commissioner, an afp correspondent said. violence broke out thursday night after police commissioner daniel sama was beaten to death by members of the presidential guard earlier that day. demonstrators burned tyres and set up road blocks, leading the army to disperse the crowd by firing live rounds, witnesses said

sources: soldiers fire on central africa crowd, three wounded. agence france presse english, november 14, 2010 sunday 3:46 pm gmt ;
notes: soldiers in the central african republic opened fire sunday to disperse angry demonstrators protesting the death of a youth, wounding at least three people, witnesses said. an afp reporter counted three people with bullet wounds a young woman and two men being driven to a hospital in the capital, bangui. authorities could not immediately say how many people were hurt or what had happened. soldiers also briefly detained at a military headquarters three local radio reporters who were covering the events. they were released two hours later without explanation and with their tape recorders confiscated. a relative calm reigned by early afternoon in the capital where riot police had been deployed. witnesses said soldiers opened fire on demonstrators after police had initially tried to reason with them. the unrest began early sunday when residents of a bangui neighbourhood torched a bar and ransacked the home of a soldier they accused of having killed a young man for suspected theft, witnesses said. the group then took to the streets in protest, setting tyres on fire, putting up barricades and calling for justice to avenge the youth s death.

sources: central african doctors demand better protection against lra. agence france presse english, june 10, 2011 friday 3:50 pm gmt ;
notes: medical workers in the central african republic on friday demanded their government better protect the country against a brutal rebel army which recently killed a doctor and his driver. central african military officials said the two were killed in an ambush this week by the lord s resistance army, a rebel group with ugandan origins, while carrying polio vaccines in the southeast of the country. we decided to protest against the brutal and atrocious death of our colleague, said abdoulaye sepou, who heads a council of doctors, pharmacists and dentists, roughly 100 of whom marched in the capital bangui on friday. it is time for the highest authorities in the country to guarantee the protection of doctors who have the responsibility to care for the population, he added...

sources: briton behind bars in central africa freed during riot; david simpson, the british pilot held behind bars in bangui for over four months, was dramatically released when rioters stormed the prison. here he tells harriet alexander about running for his life to escape the rampage.. telegraph.co.uk, august 4, 2012 saturday 9:39 pm gmt, news, 1733 words, by harriet alexander ;
notes: thursday s prison break was started by a riot in the centre of the capital, bangui, which spread to the jail. local people, angry at the government for charging a fee for entering the military and then refusing their applications, took to the streets to vent their anger burning cars and attacking shops. a statue of president francois bozize was toppled from its perch, smashing into pieces, and the riots spread across the city...

notes: seleka rebels took control of the capital in march 2013 so they are the de facto government & appointed the pm; the rebels had just picked up two more citizens, caught reading fliers calling for a general strike, their friends said shortly after. beaten as they were shoved into the truck, the men were unlikely to be heard from again, the friends feared. a similar seizure had occurred nearby the day before. four people had been shot and killed and dozens wounded during a protest over another abduction less than a week before that

sources: thousands occupy car airport runway in protest over seleka violence. guardian.co.uk, august 29, 2013 thursday, david smith africa correspondent theguardian.com ;
notes: response of crowd dispersal by un peacekeepers; thousands of people fled to central african republic s car main international airport to escape marauding gunmen, blocking the runway and preventing flights from landing on thursday morning. more than 5,000 civilians, many of them women and children, occupied the tarmac for about 18 hours and protested by throwing stones at peacekeepers before they were dispersed with water canon and teargas...boeing residents said that what started as an evacuation had become a protest against the wider state of lawlessness...over the past 10 days arbitrary arrests, detention, torture, extortion, armed robberies, physical violence, restriction of movement, lootings and attacks on civilians have displaced thousands of people, according to the un s refugee agency. ten fatalities have been reported.

sources: 14 die after muslims block march. the star south africa , october 07, 2013 monday, pg. 8 ;

sources: c. african republic lawyers protest judge s murder. the new zealand herald, november 23, 2013 saturday, news; world ;
notes: bangui, central african republic ap more than 100 judges and lawyers have taken to the streets of the capital in central african republic to protest the slaying of a colleague. modeste martineau bria, the director of judiciary services at the justice ministry, was killed about a week ago by the rebels who overthrew the government earlier this year. on friday, more than 100 people took part in the demonstration in bangui, carrying a banner that read: no to genocide. lawyer emile bizon says the march was organized to protest bria s assassination and the more and more frequent killings taking place in the volatile country. rebels invaded the capital in march and have since been blamed for killing scores of civilians. international observers warn the country is now in a state of near anarchy.

sources: silent protest against violence. cape argus south africa , november 26, 2013 tuesday, pg. 16 ;
notes: a thousand women staged a silent rally against violence towards women outside parliament in the strife torn central african republic yesterday. the rally aimed to raise awareness of the spike in violence between unidentified armed groups and former rebel fighters. it is the deadliest the country has experienced since march, when rebel groups deposed president francois bozize.

sources: demonstrators in c.africa reject call for election delay agence france presse english, may 12, 2015 tuesday 6:39 pm gmt, 254 words;

sources: un force in c. africa denies peacekeepers killed three protestors agence france presse english, september 28, 2015 monday 6:01 pm gmt, 208 words three killed by un troops in tense c.african capital agence france presse english, september 28, 2015 monday 3:45 pm gmt, 541 words about 500 prisoners escape central african republic jail associated press international, september 29, 2015 tuesday 12:38 am gmt, international news, 628 words, by hippolyte marboua and krista larson, associated press;
notes: the un s peacekeeping force in central african republic denied reports its troops had opened fire on protestors in the capital bangui on monday after a hospital source said three demonstrators had been killed. minusca peacekeeping officers deny reports that they opened fire on the population, the mission said in a brief statement sent to afp journalists in libreville, capital of gabon the statement came after a hospital source told afp on condition of anonymity that three protestors died and seven were wounded when un peacekeepers opened fire on a crowd of several hundred heading for the presidency. the shooting was also seen by a witness, who spoke to afp, also on condition of not being named. the demonstrators were demanding the resignation of interim leader catherine samba panza after the deaths of at least 20 people in bangui at the weekend. the resurgence this weekend of violence in central african republic was sparked by the murder of a motorcycle taxi driver in central bangui s muslim majority pk 5 neighbourhood. violence on saturday is not codeable, because it is not clear there was an anti government demand, it appears to be sectarian violence instead.

sources: new unrest in c.africa after ex president barred from vote agence france presse english, december 8, 2015 tuesday 9:48 pm gmt, 528 words ;
notes: gunfire erupted on tuesday in the central african republic s capital bangui, where protesters erected barricades after an announcement that ex president francois bozize was barred from running for election gendarmes and police intervened with the support of senegalese troops from un peacekeeping force minusca, a minusca source said. they were able to raise the barricades and reestablish order. the unrest followed the constitutional court s rejection of the exiled bozize s bid to run for president in december 27 elections.

protesteridentity: protesters against the upcoming censure motion against national assembly president karim meckassoua
sources: cafrica rebels issue ultimatum to government officials, agence france presse english, october 27, 2018 saturday 7:30 pm gmt
notes: central african republic s ex seleka rebels on saturday gave government officials in areas under their control 48 hours to leave. the ultimatum came a day after the sacking of the national assembly president which the rebels say was illegal. the state representatives posted in the zones occupied by the armed groups of the ex seleka have 48 hours to leave those zones, abdoulaye hissene, the leader of the ex seleka and of the national defence and security council, which comprises several ex seleka armed groups, told afp. deputies in the national assembly voted out their president, karim meckassoua, in a censure motion late friday. the move against meckassoua, who represents a predominantly muslim neighbourhood in bangui as mp, was not justified by any wrongdoing and therefore illegal , hissene said. we think it happened because he s a muslim, he said. several hundred people demonstrated on tuesday to protest against the upcoming censure motion against meckassoua. one demonstrator, moussa, warned that there would be total crisis in this country if the parliamentary chief was ousted. note: the actual location of the protest was not provided in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: had: lawyer s assassination sparks off public revolt. ips inter press service. february 22, 1992 , saturday : 680 words.;
notes: the assassination this week of the vice chair of chad s human rights league has provoked a wave of mass demonstrations and strikes unprecedented in the history of this war torn sahelian nation. forty eight year old joseph behidi was shot at point blank in the early hours on feb. 17 outside his car in the moursal district of this chadian capital. his assailants then drove his car away. two days later, tens of thousands of mourners marched from the independence square here to farcha, 4 miles away, to bury behidi. demonstrations were also held on the burial day in behidi s home town of moundou, 232 miles south of here.

notes: chadian university students held a violent demonstration here tuesday, setting vehicles alight, to press demands for the payment of grants which are several months overdue, witnesses said. the security forces made several arrests on the campus and in neighbouring ndjamena districts after the students poured petrol over three vehicles, including that of a french cooperation official, and set them ablaze. even people who were not involved in the demonstration were picked up by the security forces, witnesses said. the total number of arrests made was not known. the ndjamena university students are also demanding the resignation of national education minister mahamat ahmat alhabo, whom they accuse of being unwilling to negotiate, and tuition for third year science students, who lack professors.

sources: deby wins chad s second multiparty presidential election. associated press international, may 28, 2001; monday, international news, abakar saleh;
notes: six opposition candidates and more than 80 of their supporters were briefly detained by police monday, hours after incumbent idriss deby was declared the winner of chad s presidential election. the six were meeting at the house of saleh kebzabo one of the candidates defeated in the may 20 vote when police shot in the air and used tear gas to disperse scores of opposition supporters who had gathered outside the residence in a southern part of the capital. reporters saw police beat and arrest a number of the supporters and then go into the house and take the candidates to police headquarters. the detained were later released...although voting was peaceful and international observers have said the election went off without major problems, the opposition candidates have jointly accused deby s ruling popular salvation movement of massive fraud. just hours before the results were announced, eight opposition members of the electoral commission resigned, alleging irregularities...
