notes: a chadian court on tuesday fined and handed down suspended prison sentences of 18 months on three trade union leaders who published a petition hostile to the authorities. in a tense atmosphere at the courthouse in n djamena, filled with union activists and opposition supporters, the bench also fined and gave a suspended jail term of 12 months to a journalist who published a report on the petition...large numbers of police surrounded the courtroom, while opposition activists gathered outside. when the verdict was announced, they sang the national anthem in protest and then organised a peaceful march to the labour exchange, where they dispersed peacefully.

sources: n djamena schools closed over helmet protests agence france presse english, march 10, 2015 tuesday 7:43 pm gmt, 136 words;
notes: schools and universities in the chadian capital were closed on tuesday and will remain shut until further notice , the government said after student rallies against motorcycle helmet laws left at least one person dead. the closure comes a day after students took to the streets to protest against a rise in helmet prices ever since their use became obligatory in n djamena early this month. the protesters set fire to several vehicles and blocked access to schools and universities, an afp journalist said. clashes broke out after security forces used tear gas to disperse the protesters.

sources: demo against girl s brutal rape turns violent in chad agence france presse english, february 15, 2016 monday 5:59 pm gmt, 255 words;
notes: riot police violently shut down a protest on monday by hundreds of young chadians in the capital n djamena, after photographs of a girl who had allegedly been brutally gang raped spread on social media. one protester was reported to have been shot dead as police moved to disperse the demo with tear gas, a fellow demonstrator told afp on condition of anonymity.

sources: chad student shot dead by army as gang rape protests spread agence france presse english, february 22, 2016 monday 7:00 pm gmt, 665 words;
notes: a chadian student was shot dead and five others wounded monday when soldiers broke up a protest over a girl s brutal gang rape, as demonstrations showed no sign of abating ahead of a presidential vote. the death was the second in a week of protests by students who have taken to the streets of the capital n djamena and beyond to express rage over the gang rape of a girl named zouhoura, which has been blamed on the sons of senior officials.

sources: chad rocked by growing protest movement ahead of election agence france presse english, march 11, 2016 friday 4:24 pm gmt, 331 words;
notes: police broke up a student demonstration in chad s second city friday, local residents said, as protests against the country s long serving ruler gather pace a month before elections. several hundred students had gathered to protest overdue scholarship payments in the commercial capital moundou amid a growing crackdown on dissent in the central african country, resident said. six protesters were arrested, they added.

sources: protests as prosecutors demand jail for chad activists agence france presse english, april 7, 2016 thursday 2:40 pm gmt, 279 words;
notes: prosecutors in chad on thursday demanded six month jail terms for five anti government activists, as police fired live rounds and tear gas to disperse hundreds of protesters who rallied in their support. five senior figures from several protest movements have been held in recent weeks on charges of attempting to disturb the peace for urging anti government demonstrations, ahead of sunday s presidential election.

sources: protester shot dead ahead of chad leader s swearing in agence france presse english, august 7, 2016 sunday 11:21 pm gmt, 262 words;
notes: a young protester who had torn the flag of the mps deby s ruling patriotic salvation movement was shot dead, during the protest which had been banned by the government, the police officer said on condition of anonymity. opposition leader saleh kebzabo confirmed the news, saying one person had died after being shot by live police rounds during the authorities attempts to disperse the protesters. he added that another youth had been hit in the chest by a bullet and taken to hospital. earlier security forces used tear gas to disperse the protest against the deby regime. kebzabo said many of the protesters were very angry at being prevented from marching and had returned only for their protest to be broken up again.

sources: chad opposition figures held as police disperse march agence france presse english, november 17, 2016 thursday 10:11 pm gmt, 380 words;
notes: several opposition activists and politicians were detained on thursday in the chadian capital n djamena, after the government banned a rally following a failed bid to hold a vote of no confidence. some 30 people were arrested, opposition chief saleh kebzabo told afp. among those held was mahamat bechir barh, an opposition party leader, kebzabo said. the arrests were made when the demonstrators tried to march towards a stadium after holding a public meeting at the headquarters of kebzabo s party, the undr. the stadium was cordoned off by the security forces, who stopped the protesters from entering. fifteen minutes later, the security forces attacked us with tear gas on the street. after that the crowds were dispersed, kebzabo said.

sources: police break up student demonstration in brazzaville agence france presse english, 77 words ;
notes: police wednesday fired tear gas to break up a demonstration by brazzaville university students who were demonstrating against the government s failure to pay their grants. students said a number of the demonstrators were hurt. the students had gathered outside the main tax office in congo s capital, blocking traffic and shouting anti government slogans, because of the government s failure to pay their monthly allowances for the past three months. given that the students were able to block traffic and that the police felt the need to respond with tear gas implies that this protest had at least 50 participants.

sources: congolese troops surround army hq, government rejects demands agence france presse english, 501 words ;
notes: elite troops of congo s disbanded presidential guard surrounded the headquarters of the army and a radio station wednesday, delivered demands, then withdrew without incident. they demanded the immediate sacking of a junior defense minister, cancellation of military appointments and reinstatement of sacked officers. the government wednesday night rejected the demands out of hand. during the brief occupation of the radio station, an officer read a statement on the air demanding that junior defence minister michel gangouo be sacked by day s end. given that the troops were able to surround both buildings and control the radio station for some time implies this protest had at least 50 participants.

sources: mutinous troops take over, fire on protesters; three reported killed the associated press, january 20, 1992, monday, am cycle, international news, 658 words, by armand bernard massamba, associated press writer demonstrators defy military ban on protests in congo the associated press, january 21, 1992, tuesday, am cycle, international news, 480 words, by armand bernard massamba, associated press writer ;
notes: three people were killed and several people were wounded, hospital officials said. the troops, angered by milongo s appointment of new military commanders, earlier seized state radio, television and the international airport, and demanded monday that he step down. hours later, troops fired into a crowd of hundreds of milongo s supporters, who were marching in the suburb of bacongo, where the prime minister usually lives. the soldiers ordered them to disperse and when the crowd kept marching, the soldiers opened fire. the soldiers are seeking back pay and higher wages, and object to a military shakeup milongo tried to carry out, charging the new military appointments would tear apart the fabric of the army. milongo, other government officials and military sources have said the revolt involves only about 300 soldiers from the former personal guard of president denis sassou nguesso, who was stripped of power last year. milongo was named to head an interim government to organize open elections by june.

sources: congo pm holds crisis talks after army mutiny kills five the guardian london , january 22, 1992, foreign; pg. 9, 456 words, mark huband in abidjan demonstrators defy military ban on protests in congo the associated press, january 21, 1992, tuesday, am cycle, international news, 480 words, by armand bernard massamba, associated press writer ;
notes: sources in brazzaville said soldiers refused to allow the prime minister, andre milongo, access to the radio and television station under their control since sunday, unless he agreed to their demand for his resignation. mr milongo pre recorded a statement asking people to remain calm and not to give in to provocation . he denied he had fled the capital on sunday when the mutiny began. last week, the council criticised mr milongo, considering a censure motion against him for refusing to negotiate with rebel troops who briefly occupied brazzaville airport on friday. they were demanding the reinstatement of officers fired last week, and the dismissal of the junior defence minister, col michel gangouo. mr milongo has insisted the sackings were necessary to eliminate tribalism in the army. milongo, other government officials and military sources have said the revolt involves only about 300 soldiers from the former personal guard of president denis sassou nguesso, who was stripped of power last year. milongo was named to head an interim government to organize open elections by june.

sources: world in brief protesters disrupt congolese voting the globe and mail canada , august 3, 1992 monday, 81 words, reut ;
notes: street protests in brazzaville by young militants of congo s former ruling party perturbed voting yesterday in the country s first multicandidate presidential elections. police said about one hundred supporters of the congolese labour party pct set up barricades and attacked a police station yesterday in protest over non receipt of voting cards. no injuries were reported. the formerly marxist pct was the sole legal party in congo until a pro democracy national conference last year.

sources: brazzaville police arrest 20 demonstrators agence france presse english, 205 words;
notes: police arrested some twenty demonstrators late thursday for building barricades in a protest against president pascal lissouba s decision to dissolve the national assembly, police officials said. ten of the demonstrators were taken to the city s central police station, while the others were questioned at the armed forces headquarters. most of the demonstrators, however, have close ties with the coalition formed by the former ruling congolese labour party pct and the union for democratic renewal urd . the demonstrators erected barricades in several avenues in the capital tuesday, when president lissouba announced the dissolution of the national assembly and the reappointment of stephane maurice bongho nouarra s government which the pct urd coalition had overturned in a no confidence vote on october 31. given that 20 people were arrested, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people altogether.

sources: three killed in opposition demos agence france presse english, 344 words congolese opposition says eight people died in demonstrations agence france presse english, 352 words ;
notes: three people were killed and 11 injured, 10 of them seriously, as opposition party activists demonstrated monday in the congo capital to push for the government s resignation, hospital sources said. the dead, taken to the university hospital mortuary as police could be heard firing to disperse the demonstrators, included a 28 year old taxi driver hit in the abdomen by several bullets and a schoolchild. the security forces earlier stopped the marchers from getting to the parliament building and the office of president pascal lissouba and fired into the air to try to disperse them. the demonstrators wanted lissouba to reverse his decision two weeks ago to dissolve the national assembly because it voted a no confidence motion against prime minister stephane maurice bongho nouarra. the opposition also want a new premier named from among their number, arguing that they now constitute a majority in parliament after the formation of an alliance between the labour party, formerly the country s only legal political movement, and a grouping of seven other parties. the congolese opposition said late monday that eight people have died in demonstrations organised in the capital since friday to push for the government s resignation. the first shots were heard when demonstrators threw stones at the soldiers trying to restore order. most of the soldiers fired into the air, but some fired into the crowd, witnesses told afp. given how many people were killed and injured, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: social agitation in congo before legislative election xinhua general news service, march 25, 1993, thursday, 287 words ;
notes: a series of strikes and sit ins by railroad workers and two classes of teachers demanding regular payment of their salaries and parity with other teachers is complicating the political situation before the country s legislative election in may. the teachers, who have been striking for the last three months, were dispersed by congolese police tuesday when they initiated a sit in in front of the prime minister s hall. volunteers, those who volunteered to be teachers and servicemen, those assigned to be teachers after finishing their national military service, are being paid less than half of the salaries paid to other teachers employed by the government. the total number of volunteers and servicemen, is estimated at approximately 15,000, or about 60 percent of the congo s teachers, and their organization has so far been unsuccessful in negotiating parity for them. given how many of these types of teachers make up the entire teaching sector and that the police felt the need to disperse their peaceful sit in protest, this demonstration is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: one dead in new shootout in brazzaville after polls agence france presse english, 440 words ;
notes: shooting here monday during a demonstration outside the home of trade minister gabriel bokilo left one dead and four injured, including a soldier in the presidential guard, hospital sources said. one person was killed by a bullet to the neck, a hospital source said, while the presidential guardsman and two other people were hospitalized with bullet wounds. the guardsman was riding in a jeep with three colleagues and had approached the mob outside bokilo s home, where an earlier shootout sunday night claimed at least two lives and left one person seriously injured. angry demonstrators reportedly torched the vehicle. the opposition had called for a boycott of the second round, accusing the government of president pascal lissouba of using fraud to deny it a majority in the first round. given that there was a mob in front of the house and that such violence erupted, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: protesters throw up barricades, fire shots the associated press, june 12, 1993, saturday, am cycle, international news, 216 words congo: opposition turns violent after disputed election agence france presse english, 707 words ;
notes: anti government protesters threw up barricades and fired shots in the air saturday responding to a call for unrest by congo s ousted military government. protesters burned a bakery and blocked streets with tires and junked cars. streets were otherwise empty and shops closed. no injuries were reported and police did not intervene. the opposition claims the june 6 legislative elections, which were marred by shootings and grenade attacks, were fraudulent. it won 49 seats compared to 69 for the ruling party. barricades were reported in all seven districts of the city on saturday evening as young supporters of the opposition coalition chopped down trees and piled up tyres and old cars to block main thoroughfares. since the protesters were able to barricade all areas of the city while paralyzing it, this protest is believed to have at least 50 participants.

sources: demonstrators erect barricades in congolese capital agence france presse english, 374 words shots fired as troops dismantle barricades agence france presse english, 734 words stray bullet kills girl, 3, as gunfire breaks out over barricades agence france presse english, 600 words ;
notes: demonstrators, some of them armed, barricaded brazzaville streets on wednesday to press demands for the resignation of congo s government and the dissolution of parliament. the protests came hours after president pascal lissouba issued a veiled warning to the army in congo, which emerged last year from more than two decades of formerly marxist and military rule, to stay out of politics. demonstrators used wrecked vehicles and tree trunks to close roads to all traffic in the southern bacongo district, considered a stronghold of the opposition. armed protestors fired into the air wednesday when congolese trooops attempted to dismantle barricades erected by opposition supporters in demonstrations to press demands for the resignation of the government and the dissolution of parliament. witnesses said that the troops also fired into the air in a bid to clear the roads as armoured vehicles moved into position along the avenue of the organisation of african unity, one of the main axes leading to the bacongo suburb. a three year old girl was killed and five other people were wounded as armed protestors and congolese troops fired into the air wednesday, a hospital source said. the gunfire broke out during a dispute over control of a road leading to the the regional african headquarters of the world health organisation. this protest is believed to have at least 50 people due to the damage done and how the demonstrators were able to paralyze the city.

sources: rocket fire shatters day of uneasy calm in brazzaville agence france presse english, 574 words the washington post, troops fire in congo, from news services, july 10, 1993, saturday, capital edition, first section; page a15; around the world, 111 words ;
notes: rocket fire broke out here late thursday between opposition militants and the military, a military source said. the firing in bacongo, a southern district of the capital, shattered an uneasy calm which reigned during the day after unrest wednesday in which two people died, including a three year old girl shot in the head by a stray bullet. the first shots came 30 minutes before a dusk to dawn curfew came into force at 7 p.m. 18hoo gmt for the second night running. they were fired by opposition protestors on a military camp not far from the savorgnan de brazza school. the military replied by firing a rocket towards the bacongo district, but it was not known whether there had been any victims. troops fired in the air to move people off the streets and barricaded an opposition stronghold, where militants fired a rocket overnight and hit a military camp. sporadic gunshots echoed in the city after authorities imposed a dusk to dawn curfew thursday to try to halt violence over disputed legislative elections. there were no reports of casualties in the latest fighting. given the increasing violence between the troops and the opposition supporters, this protest yet another in a series is again believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: four civilians killed in disturbances agence france presse english, 334 words ;
notes: four civilians were killed as armed militants of the opposition rampaged through congo s capital monday, hospital sources said. the deaths were revealed at the end of two days of shooting and looting by groups of armed youths whose political leaders have demanded that president pascal lissouba dismiss the government and call new elections. opposition supporters wearing paratroopers uniforms fired into the air for 30 minutes in central brazzaville monday near the state radio station, causing panic among pedestrians and office workers. informed sources said that the two day rampage in the capital s suburbs had forced more than 700 families to seek refuge in the city centre. but the opposition s official line is that the newly appointed government headed by general joachim yhombi opango must resign. the opposition contends the government is illegal. the fact that the opposition was rampaging through the city and killed four people implies a protest of at least 100 people.

sources: congo declares emergency the herald glasgow , july 17, 1993, pg. 4, 348 words, antoine mouyambala two youths killed as unrest spreads to port city agence france presse english, 760 words ;
notes: protests spread to the oil capital, pointe noire, last tuesday when demonstrators burned a police station and set up street barricades of blazing tyres. a soldier killed two unarmed youths as protests and looting spread to the country s economic capital pointe noire wednesday, with congolese pro government forces accusing the opposition of armed rebellion. in the m voumvou district of pointe noire opposition activists torched a timber lorry and ransacked shops belonging to west africans and business people close to the government. the state railway company suspended services between pointe noire on the atlantic ocean and the capital brazzaville because of the security situation. this protest is believed to have at least 50 people based on the fact that the railroad was forced to suspend services and that the protesters were able to burn a police station and cause other great amounts of damage.

sources: capital calms down after fiery reaction to emergency extension agence france presse english, 294 words ;
notes: hostility to the president s extension of the state of emergency seemed to fade sunday after a night of opposition militants firing shots and setting up checkpoints in the city centre here. militant members of the opposition, who contest the results of the may june parliamentary elections, took to the streets firing shots and mounting roadblocks in the central district of ouenze, an anti government stronghold. the opposition activists searched pedestrians and motorists at the checkpoints and demanded proof of identity, and allegedly detained lissouba supporters in the ouenze house of former president denis sassou nguesso. the opposition alleged there were irregularities in the first round poll and boycotted the second round. saturday s violence ended several days of relative quiet here.

sources: police gun down wounded militiaman in hospital agence france presse english, 347 words ;
notes: police drew their guns again on monday to fire into the air and used teargas to disperse a student demonstration here that led to looting and rioting, according to journalists on the scene. there appeared to be no arrests or injuries among the demonstrators, they said. the trouble began after about 50 students from the marien n gouabi university on monday marched through the poto poto and moungali districts to call for the payment of six months worth of more than a year in unpaid grants.

sources: students, teachers arrested in protest over unpaid grants agence france presse english, 267 words ;
notes: several students and teachers were arrested in pointe noire, the congo s second city, where police said they were planning to disrupt classes after months of unpaid school grants, government radio said monday. it said many of the protestors had come in from brazzaville, where for more than a week students some reportedly armed have disrupted classes in the capital s northern district to demand the government pay up at least six months of the education grants that have gone unpaid for 16 months. the radio said the protestors also included students from pointe noire who were now studying at university in the capital, along with members of the teachers union close to the opposition, the cstc. this protest is believed to have at least 50 people based on the various cities that the demonstrators came from, and how they have been able to disrupt classes in the cities.

sources: associated press international, march 12, 1996; tuesday, international news, 276 words unrest in congolese army worries politicians politicians agence france presse english english, joseph gouala gouala;
notes: army recruits whose mutinous three day rampage for better pay killed four people and wounded 37 others will be punished severely, the government says. about 1,200 young army recruits went on a rampage in the congolese capital on feb. 14, blocking streets and firing rifles into the air. among those killed was a 15 year old girl, shot by a stray bullet while she was sleeping. the recruits were upset because they had been promised full time soldier status which would earn them the equivalent of dlrs 230 a month, instead of the dlrs 100 they currently get. the day after the riots at brazzaville s two major camps began, a government spokesman conceded that the recruits grievances were legitimate and promised to see that they were integrated into the military as soon as possible. in february last year some 300 former members of militia loyal to president pascal lissouba took over an armoured regiment at m plia, in the eastern suburbs of brazzaville, using its tanks to block traffic. several articles pinned the number at 300 rather than 1200, and therefore, this protest is coded as 300 people.

sources: would be soldiers stage protest in congo agence france presse, february 04, 1997, international news, 152 words congo mutineers plunge cities into darkness agence france presse, february 05, 1997, international news, 209 words government soldiers put down loudima mutiny agence france presse, february 06, 1997, international news, 305 words unrest in congolese army worries politicians politicians agence france presse english english, joseph gouala gouala ;
notes: several dozen men seeking to join the congolese army have taken over their training camp and the railway station in the southern city of loudima, sources in brazzaville said tuesday. the men, who were recruited between 1994 and 1996 for military training, cut off rail traffic between brazzaville and the port of pointe noire after seizing control of their camp in loudima, 250 kilometers 150 miles west of the capital. the protesters, who are demanding entry into the army at the rank of sergeant, control the railway station in loudima, and have threatened to fire on any train that tries to enter it, a railway source said. on saturday, several dozen men seeking to join the congolese army took over their training camp and the railway station in the southern city of loudima. government soldiers put down a six day old rebellion and took back a power station occupied by mutinous soldiers, officials said here thursday. three of the mutineers were taken prisoner after the government forces seized the electricity station at loudima, 200 kilometres 125 miles west of brazzaville, which the mutineers had occupied since tuesday. they had cut off the electricity supply, plunging the south of congo, including the country s second and third largest cities pointe noire and dolisie, into darkness. a year later another 300 men, also from the president s faction, demonstrated at the training centre at loudima, in the southwest of the country. they demanded that all new recruits be promoted to the rank of sergeant, and that the centre s commanders be sacked on the grounds that they were corrupt.

sources: unrest in congolese army worries politicians politicians agence france presse english english, joseph gouala gouala ;
notes: in the latest incident last week some 100 recruits at the brazzaville naval base began a similar protest movement, seeking improved conditions and the removal of senior commanders accused of regional and tribal bias in making assignments. here again, the authorities only calmed the rebels by agreeing to suspend the head of the navy and the commander of the brazzaville base. none of the mutineers has been punished, despite a threat of sanctions issued in february by the chief of the armed forces general staff, general daniel mabika. mabika claimed that the army was the victim of political manipulation, and said investigations had been opened to determine the real cause of the earlier incidents. the date is recorded as the 16th of april; the date of the article is the 21st, and it says this protest occurred the week before, and the 16th is the wednesday the middle of the week.

sources: 1 congolese police fire on protest march: opposition. agence france presse english, july 15, 2009 wednesday 9:45 pm gmt; 2 opposition disputes congo republic results. upi, july 16, 2009 thursday 11:15 am est;
notes: 1 police in congo fired tear gas and live ammunition to break up an opposition march wednesday, injuring some demonstrators, participants said. police said the march, which came in the wake of official results that returned president denis sassou nguesso to power, had not been authorised. we just wanted to stage a peaceful demonstration with our supporters when the police started firing tear gas bombs, emmanuel ngouelondele, president of the party for democratic alternance pad , told afp. police had fired live rounds, injuring some of the demonstrators, he said, without elaborating. between 300 and 500 people took part in the attempted march, witnesses said. the march was organised in protest after authorities earlier wednesday banned a press conference by six of the candidates, who took part in the july 12 disputed presidential election... ; 2 about 2,000 opposition supporters protested the election results in brazzaville but were dispersed by riot police firing tear gas, the bbc reported

sources: students riot in congo after final exams cancelled agence france presse english, june 5, 2015 friday 1:14 pm gmt, 234 words;
notes: thousands of students rioted friday in congo s capital brazzaville, attacking schools and the education ministry after authorities cancelled the final day of end of year exams over alleged massive fraud . students in one area of the capital broke doors and windows of their school and pelted cars with rocks after the cancellation was announced via government media sources, authorities said. in another part of brazzaville, where testing had been underway since tuesday, students erected barricades and burned tyres but were chased off after security forces fired tear gas at them after the announcement that the exam was cancelled we went outside to protest peacefully, said student amour maloula in the southern city of pointe noire. to our surprise a battalion of police officers, soldiers and gendarmes suddenly appeared and threw tear gas canisters at us. some of my friends were hit with truncheons.

sources: huge demo in congo against president s bid to extend rule agence france presse english, september 27, 2015 sunday 10:24 pm gmt, 418 words world watch wall street journal abstracts, september 28, 2015 monday, a; pg. 13, 36 words, reuters;
notes: thousands of people staged a mass demonstration in congo s capital brazzaville sunday to protest at plans by veteran ruler denis sassou nguesso to try to extend his rule. the rally was the biggest since sassou nguesso returned to power in 1997, an afp journalist said, stretching for almost a kilometre along a main boulevard in the city centre the roughly two hour demonstration ended without violence, though some local businesses closed up early fearing there might be trouble.

notes: seven people were injured on tuesday in in clashes between police and demonstrators against a constitutional referendum to allow republic of congo s longtime president to run for a new term, said a hospital official...the protests in brazzaville come after six people were injured in weekend clashes in repbublic of congo s second largest city, point noire.

sources: four dead in congo as protesters defy clampdown agence france presse english, october 20, 2015 tuesday 10:29 pm gmt, 725 words clashes, arrests in congo after day of deadly protest agence france presse english, october 21, 2015 wednesday 6:15 pm gmt, 589 words;
notes: four people were killed and 10 injured tuesday in the republic of congo, according to officials, as demonstrators braved a government clampdown and took to the streets to protest the president s bid for a third term in office. the violence prompted urgent calls for calm from a visiting senior us official and amnesty international. clashes erupted after authorities banned a protest rally against next sunday s referendum on president denis sassou nguesso s bid to extend a three decade stay in office but shops remained shuttered and schools and offices were closed across most of the city as young protesters took to the streets and torched tyres in the southern makelekele district and in bacongo in the west. police opened fire several times. sources at makelekele hospital said five people were seriously wounded by gunfire, and two others were injured by shrapnel from teargas grenades. an afp correspondent saw another person being brought to hospital with a gunshot wound to the abdomen.

sources: clashes, arrests in congo after day of deadly protest agence france presse english, october 21, 2015 wednesday 6:15 pm gmt, 589 words;
notes: demonstrators and security forces clashed for a second day in congo s capital wednesday in unrest triggered by the president s bid to extend his three decade stay in office. calm returned to the city late wednesday after youths took to the streets in western brazzaville in the morning in an apparent bid to throw up barricades as security forces fired rounds of tear gas grenades to hold them back the country has been rocked by weeks of protests ahead of a planned referendum on sunday to amend the constitution that would enable veteran ruler denis sassou nguesso to remain in office.

sources: congo police fire tear gas at opposition supporters: afp agence france presse english, march 20, 2016 sunday 8:38 pm gmt, 70 words;
notes: riot police in congo on sunday used tear gas to disperse 200 opposition supporters who were trying to get into a polling station during counting in the country s presidential election, an afp journalist saw. dozens of heavily armed police fired tear gas at the supporters of opposition candidate guy brice parfait kolelas and chased them away from the polling station in the south of the capital brazzaville.

sources: republic of congo marchers want to leave international court associated press international, november 3, 2016 thursday 5:23 pm gmt, international news, 144 words, by louis okamba, associated press;
notes: about 300 people have marched in the republic of congo s capital to demand that the country leave the international criminal court. thursday s march comes shortly after three african countries, south africa, gambia and burundi, announced they would leave the tribunal that is meant to pursue some of the world s worst atrocities. some african countries say the court unfairly targets the continent, though many of its cases were requested by african states. thursday s protesters were under the direction of two parties in the ruling coalition.

sources: students demonstrate again in zaire xinhua general news service, may 29, 1990, tuesday, 109 words ;
notes: students of the kinshasa university and several other universities in zaire s capital took to the street monday in defiance of an appeal made by the transitional governement on friday. according to the zaire news agency, the student demonstrators attacked a police office and took away some weapans before entering clashes with the security forces. two policemen and two students were injured during the demonstration.

sources: witnesses say police killed 3 people in zaire riots the new york times, september 4, 1991, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 8; column 4; foreign desk, 348 words, ap ;
notes: widespread rioting broke out here in the zairian capital and in other towns on monday as the police battled thousands of anti government protesters. witnesses said at least three people were killed when the police opened fire during the unrest, which left shops looted and cars burned. witnesses in the capital said they saw the police fatally shoot two men and a woman. there were secondhand reports of deaths in other towns, but those could not be verified. zaire s ambassador to belgium, kimbulu moyanso, denied that anyone was killed, and the state press agency reported only that violent scenes had occurred. it was not clear whether the violence started after or before the police fired into crowds gathered to demonstrate for greater democracy, reporters said. the demonstrations were called by leaders of the opposition to president mobutu sese seko, a soldier who seized power 26 years ago. the opposition wants a national conference held to appoint an interim government and organize the first free elections since independence from belgium in 1960.

sources: ruling party headquarters set ablaze in zaire riots the toronto star, september 24, 1991, tuesday, final edition, news; pg. a17, 442 words, reuter ap ;
notes: brussels reuter ap demonstrators set fire to president mobutu sese seko s party headquarters today during rioting in zaire s capital kinshasa that has killed 15 people in two days, the zairean news agency azap said. the agency, monitored in brussels, said anti government demonstrators had also looted the headquarters of the ruling mouvement populaire de la revolution mpr . the report quoted a local source as saying that the dead included eight civilians killed in a gas explosion that ripped through a chemical factory they were looting.

sources: anti mobutu protests set off violence the new york times, october 11, 1991, friday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 4; foreign desk, 537 words, by kenneth b. noble, special to the new york times ;
notes: demonstrations and sporadic violence aimed at ousting the government of president mobutu sese seko erupted here today as efforts to form a new coalition government continued. soldiers used tear gas, gunfire and truncheons to break up some of the protests. later, about 100 troops briefly surrounded the headquarters of the main opposition party, the union for democracy and social progress, whose leader, etienne tshisekedi, was named prime minister two weeks ago.

sources: riots continue over ouster of mobutu foe the new york times, october 25, 1991, friday, late edition final, section a; page 8; column 1; foreign desk, 509 words, reuters ;
notes: angry crowds put up barricades and battled the police today to protest the president s refusal to reappoint a leading opposition figure as prime minister. several people were reported injured in clashes in kinshasa, the capital, where protesters threw up roadblocks and burned buses and private cars. hundreds of demonstrators sprinted for cover as a jeep carrying government troops screeched to a halt and the soldiers fired automatic rifles into the air.

sources: zaire s security fire on pro democracy demonstrators the associated press, february 16, 1992, sunday, am cycle, international news, 528 words, by armand bernard massamba, associated press writer rights group says 30 zaireans died when troops fired on march the associated press, february 17, 1992, monday, am cycle, international news, 643 words, by cindy shiner zairean troops kill 13 in crowd the globe and mail canada , february 17, 1992 monday, 416 words, reut ;
notes: security forces in zaire fired on pro democracy demonstrators sunday during a church led march that the government said was an illegal attempt by subversive priests to bring down president mobutu sese seko. zairian television quoted kinshasa gov. madiata kibabu as saying at least 13 people were killed, including one member of the elite civil guard. earlier the television reported two demonstrators were killed when they attacked soldiers. soldiers from the presidential guard killed at least 30 people and wounded more than 100 when they broke up a peaceful pro democracy march, the zaire human rights league said monday. the united states, france and belgium, which already have cut off aid to this bankrupt central african nation, strongly condemned the attack on sunday sdemonstration. france called it brutal and murderous repression. zairean troops opened fire yesterday on anti government demonstrators led by radical roman catholic priests, killing 13 people, witnesses and a government official said. witnesses said the killings took place when thousands of christians began a peaceful street protest against president mobutu sese seko s government after church services in the capital, kinshasa. the protest, called to urge the government to restart a suspended national conference, was banned on saturday by city authorities and was not supported by zaire s roman catholic primate, frederic cardinal etsou. mr. kitenge said troops opened fire when mobs of youths joined the demonstration, throwing stones and attacking security forces. several priests were arrested, he said, including two belgians who would be deported as soon as possible.

sources: police disperse demo over new banknote agence france presse english, 202 words ;
notes: zairean riot police dispersed demonstrators protesting here monday at the issue of a new five million zaire banknote the government has already demonetized. president mobutu sese seko s office broadcast a statement overruling the government and saying that anybody trying to harass the holders of the banknote would face the consequences. about 50 demonstrators were dispersed on kinshasa s main avenue, while security forces also broke up a demonstration by women on a commercial street. storekeepers and market traders had been refusing to take the note. worth just three u.s. dollars in a country of rocketing inflation, the note was issued by the central bank of zaire against the advice of the finance ministry and the interim government.

sources: three killed in kinshasa clash agence france presse english, 103 words at least 5 killed in anti government protest in zaire the associated press, december 18, 1992, friday, am cycle, international news, 362 words world in brief deaths reported the globe and mail canada , december 19, 1992 saturday, 100 words, reut ;
notes: two people were killed friday in a clash between anti government demonstrators and police in kinshasa, and another was killed by protestors, kinshasa governor mungul diaka said. eight people were wounded, he said. the demonstrators were protesting against the rule of president mobutu sese seko. protestors threw up barricades on main roads leading into the center of the city from poorer, heavily populated districts. but the situation had returned to normal by late friday. at least five people were killed, including one man who was shot in the stomach, and several others were wounded, according to zaire radio monitored by the british broadcasting corp. earlier reports said soldiers loyal to mobutu fired in the air to disperse the crowds. the circumstances surrounding the five deaths were unclear. the protest was originally urged by zaire s christian lay committee, which called for a popular uprising to end colonel mobutu s 27 year rule. reuter

sources: demonstrators die as protest against mobutu goes ahead the guardian london , december 21, 1992, the guardian foreign page; pg. 7, 158 words, reuter in kinshasa ;
notes: since this protest simply says weekend ? i have coded it to have occurred on saturday the 19, although it may have happened on the 20. this is distinct from the protest on the 18, as this protest had originally been called off by the opposition but proceeded anyways , whereas the protest on the 18 was called for by the christian lay committee. at least three people were killed in zaire at the weekend after demonstrators failed to heed a decision by opposition leaders to call off a planned day ofprotest against president mobutu sese seko s efforts to delay the introduction of multi party democracy. the governor of kinshasa, mungul diaka, said that two people were shot dead in confrontation with the security forces and a third died defending his shop from looters. however, an opposition newspaper said eight people had been killed as demonstrators blocked streets throughout the capital with burning tyres and refuse bins. the protests had been called after the presidential guard stopped the high council, the country s interim parliament, from holding its scheduled first meeting last week. but in the face of international criticism and growing anger at home, president mobutu allowed parliament to meet a day later. the opposition then called off its protest.

sources: troops go on rampage in zaire, three killed agence france presse english, 129 words ;
notes: dateline: wednesday december 23 soldiers from the kisangani garrison in northeast zaire went on a looting spree on monday to protest delays in their november paychecks.

sources: troops go on rampage in zaire, three killed agence france presse english, 129 words in brief herald sun, december 23, 1992 wednesday, 189 words ;
notes: zairean troops armed with automatic weapons ransacked the center of the eastern town of goma tuesday in a sweep that left three people dead and seven seriously wounded, state radio reported. informed sources said the town, located near the rwanda border, was 90 percent destroyed as troops went on the rampage in zaire for the second time this week. the radio said that in the incident tuesday troops from the 411th commando brigade, stationed in rumangabo 55 kilometers 30 miles from goma, had wanted to arrest the governor of north kivu province, whom they accuse of having taken a negative position on their presence in the kasindi border region. kasindi has come under several attacks from the rebel lumumba national congolese movement based in uganda, the most recent occurring last week. authorities in north kivu last october convinced the government to withdraw federal troops from the kasindi border post. but following last week s raid they were forced to return. troop mutiny kinshasa mutinous troops have gone on the rampage in the central zaire city of kisangani, looting shops and homes and arresting the regional governor.

sources: a leader of mobutu s party dies amid protesters attack the new york times, january 17, 1993, sunday, late edition final, section 1; page 10; column 2; foreign desk, 100 words, reuters ;
notes: a senior official in president mobutu sese seko s governing party died today after an attack by members of a crowd demonstrating against the central african nation s longtime ruler. members of president mobutu s popular revolutionary movement said the party s general secretary, makoba bidimo, was stabbed and kicked to death by the crowd here in kinshasa, the capital. opposition members said mr. makoba, threatened by the crowd, died of an asthma attack as he tried to flee. the zairian opposition has mounted a campaign to oust president mobutu, who has ruled the country since 1965.

sources: french troops enter zaire; 45 reported killed in riots the new york times, january 30, 1993, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 6; column 1; foreign desk, 823 words, ap 45 dead in zaire after soldiers riot over pay the ottawa citizen, january 30, 1993, saturday, final edition, news; pg. a6, 801 words, cp and reuter ;
notes: there is a dispute between the two accounts on when the rampaging began. one articles notes thursday while the other notes friday. for the purposes of coding, i have coded it as lasting one day, on thursday. kinshasa mutinous zairean soldiers rampaged through the streets of kinshasa and shot dead the french ambassador yesterday before being forced back to barracks by troops loyal to president mobutu sese seko. witnesses said the mutineers, from two different barracks, opened fire and looted shops in protest at the introduction of new banknotes which opposition leaders say are worthless. the 62 year old envoy, who had been in kinshasa only since december, died immediately, according to witnesses quoted on french radio. members of mr mobutu s presidential guard and other special forces then drove the mutinous soldiers away, killing several of them, witnesses said. most of the killed were soldiers who went on a rampage thursday to protest their low pay and what they said were worthless new banknotes given to them by president mobutu sese seko.

sources: zairean soldiers keep up siege the guardian london , february 26, 1993, the guardian foreign page; pg. 12, 366 words, kin kiey mulumba in kinshasa irate soldiers seize zaire parliament the new york times, february 26, 1993, friday, late edition final, section a; page 9; column 1; foreign desk, 662 words, by kenneth b. noble, special to the new york times ;
notes: reuter: troops held zairean legislators prisoner for a second day yesterday, demanding they approve use of controversial banknotes which have causedriots and crippled trade since being issued by president mobutu sese seko. witnesses said 400 members of the transitional parliament, the high council of the republic, were still trapped by soldiers at kinshasa s people s palace conference centre as night fell. no one was allowed in or out and it seemed likely that the council members, some of them elderly, would have to spend a second night under siege. hundreds of heavily armed soldiers have seized control of the parliament building here and are holding hostage several hundred members of zaire s parliament, demanding that the lawmakers approve new bank notes as legal currency. officials inside the building, contacted by telephone, said the soldiers have told them that they would not be allowed to leave until the parliament issues orders requiring local merchants to accept the new high denomination bank notes. the bills, with which the soldiers are being paid their monthly salary, were issued by zaire s central bank, which is under the direct control of president mobutu sese seko. the latest demands were issued when zairean troops, some accompanied by their wives and children, blocked all entrances to the people s palace conference hall, using large caliber weapons and armored cars. as news of the encirclement spread, there reportedly was panic inside the conference center, where members of the parliament were in session. but witnesses said there were no immediate signs of violence. today, hundreds of soldiers and their families were camped out inside the eight foot high fence surrounding the parliament building. in the outside perimeter, street merchants gathered to sell food mostly bread and dried fish to those inside. but diplomats said there was no running water inside, and some of

sources: goma erupts in protests against alleged military abuses associated press worldstream, august 11, 1994; thursday, international news, 608 words, brian murphy zairians pelt aid thieving soldiers the gazette montreal, quebec , august 12, 1994, friday, final edition, news; pg. b1 break, 521 words, ap; reuter ;
notes: infuriated by thieving soldiers preying on residents and refugees, more than 5,000 protesters pelted troops with rocks and blocked food convoys in an violent backlash as the town sinks into lawlessness. the nearly two hour demonstration in downtown goma was touched off by the shooting death of a well known money changer. his body was carried through the streets on a wooden stretcher covered with a dirty flowered sheet. protesters claim the man was shot by a soldier who demanded money. soldiers dispersed the crowds by firing into the air, which was hazy with ash after a brief eruption of the nearby nyiragongo volcano late wednesday. there were no reports of injuries during the protest. throw the soldiers out, chanted protesters piled on trucks following the funeral procession. goma residents claim that troops have conducted house to house extortion campaigns and robberies at gunpoint. u.n. officials also have accused zairian soldiers of looting from refugees in the camps around goma. they have been seen helping themselves to relief supplies unloaded from the 30 to 40 aid planes landing each day. nearly 400 members of elite military outfits, including the presidential guard, were ordered to goma when refugees began pouring across the border last month. thousands of soldiers are posted around goma. two soldiers were killed by outraged refugees last week. but the protests in goma were the first significant sign of the frustration boiling over in the city of 80,000. infuriated by thieving zairian soldiers preying on local residents and rwandan refugees, more than 5,000 protesters pelted the troops with rocks and blocked food aid convoys yesterday.

sources: zairean troops open fire on demonstrators, killing eight agence france presse english, 507 words at least 7 killed in anti government demonstration associated press worldstream, july 31, 1995; monday, international news, 206 words ;
notes: kinshasa, july 29 afp zairean troops opened fire on demonstrators opposed to president mobutu sese seko on saturday, killing six, after a mob attacked a sergeant and killed him with his own gun, official sources said. the sergeant with the civil guard had ordered his troops to keep the marchers away from the people s palace, where the transitional parliament meets, the sources close to security forces said. after demonstrators attacked and killed him with his own gun, troops fired on the marchers, killing eight and injuring 18, hospital sources said. nine soldiers were also injured in the melee. the march, organized by the opposition palu party, had not been announced nor had it received official authorization. it was called to protest the continuing dictatorship of marshal mobutu, who has ruled zaire since 1960, and a two year delay in the country s transition to democracy, organizers said. human rights activist put the numbers at 10 people killed and 30 injured when about 2,000 people marched to the parliament building in the capital of the central african nation on saturday.

sources: zairian students demonstrate against premier the new york times, november 6, 1996, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 9; column 1; foreign desk , 457 words, ap ;
notes: thousands of students poured into the center of kinshasa today to demonstrate against the government in defiance of a ban. they drove around the capital in stolen vehicles, angrily calling for the prime minister s resignation. moments later, hundreds of students scattered into the bushes when a truckload of soldiers sped by and fired rifles into the crowd. no one appeared to be wounded.

sources: zairian soldiers mutiny as rebels near second city the new york times, april 8, 1997, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 1; column 6; foreign desk , 1293 words, by howard w. ;
notes: elsewhere in the capital, in scenes that recalled the 1989 tiananmen square uprising in beijing, hundreds of students surrounded armored personnel carriers of mr. mobutu s presidential guard, immobilizing the vehicles as they slapped their metal sides with bare hands and harangued the soldiers to help them sweep mr. mobutu from power. many of the soldiers appeared to sympathize with the students, and merely went through the motions of trying to shoo the crowds away.

sources: zairian soldiers mutiny as rebels near second city the new york times, april 8, 1997, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 1; column 6; foreign desk , 1293 words, by howard w. french ;
notes: the paragraph that starts with elsewhere in the capital ? implies that the 1000s of students were also in the capital. while lubumbashi teetered toward rebel hands without a fight from government forces, army units still loyal to zaire s longtime dictator, mobutu sese seko, fought running street battles in kinshasa with thousands of student protesters who called for the president s ouster. near one university campus, units of the civil guard and gendarmerie in armored vehicles chased carloads of students back and forth in a vigorous cat and mouse game this morning under a blistering sun. elsewhere in the capital, in scenes that recalled the 1989 tiananmen square uprising in beijing, hundreds of students surrounded armored personnel carriers of mr. mobutu s presidential guard, immobilizing the vehicles as they slapped their metal sides with bare hands and harangued the soldiers to help them sweep mr. mobutu from power.

sources: troops in congo break up anti kabila protests the new york times, may 25, 1997, sunday, late edition final, section 1; page 8; column 1; foreign desk , 466 words, ap ;
notes: troops loyal to congo s new president broke up demonstrations by hundreds of angry supporters of an opposition leader today. the troops took away placards and detained several people. it was the second straight day of protests against laurent kabila, who led a rebellion that made him president. the protests make clear his quick transformation from hero to target in congo, the former zaire. the protesters are angry that etienne tshisekedi, a longtime leader of the nation s political opposition, was denied a role in congo s new government. kabila, assassin! they chanted,

sources: congo soldiers break up sparse protest against new president the new york times, may 29, 1997, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 13; column 1; foreign desk , 596 words, by james c. mckinley jr. the washington post, protesters in kinshasa defy kabila s ban; troops disperse demonstrators, but tensions persist between new order, old opposition, lynne duke, washington post foreign service, may 29, 1997, thursday, final edition, a section; pg. a25, 826 words ;
notes: it is worth noting that there are conflicting reports on the level of violence that the state responded with as well as the number of those involved. dateline: kinshasa, congo, may 28 soldiers broke up a peaceful demonstration today against laurent kabila, the rebel leader who took over this gigantic country just over a week ago, arresting and beating dozens of protesters and scattering others by firing guns in the air. about 150 demonstrators started the march at the city s central train station at 10:30 this morning, snaking through the streets toward mr. tshisekedi s residence. as it moved, the crowd picked up bystanders and passersby, growing to about 800. a few soldiers shot their rifles in the air, witnesses said. others jumped down and began beating demonstrators with belts and ropes. the crowd screamed and stampeded, spilling into side streets. at least 30 people were arrested. no injuries were reported during the demonstration by a few thousand participants, which kabila s troops dispersed with skyward bursts from their assault rifles.

protesteridentity: citizens, association of anti war groups
sources: the washington post, world in brief, august 3, 1999, tuesday, final edition, a section; pg. a12;
notes: protest marks 1st year of congolese civil war: kinshasa, congo more than 5,000 people marched through the streets of kinshasa to protest fighting between the government and rebels on the first anniversary of the outbreak of congo s civil war. the march was organized by an association of anti war groups to prove to the country and the world that the congolese people are tired of war, said modeste mutinga, head of the planning committee. mutinga appealed for an end to the fighting and the release of political prisoners to pave the way for an open and inclusive national dialogue.

sources: pastor who called for burning of koran arrested in dr congo. agence france presse english;
notes: a self styled kinshasa pastor who called on his flock to burn the koran was arrested at the weekend and is in detention at the central prison here, his entourage said monday. kutinho fernando, founder of the church of the army of victory, was heard saturday by a magistrate who had received numerous complaints from moslems. he was placed in custody at makala prison while his television station halted its broadcasts out of concern for appeasement, a member of his entourage said. in a live broadcast on september 12, fernando urged viewers to burn the koran, and he symbolically set fire to a notebook, unleashing a storm of protest from kinshasa s vocal minority moslem community. last friday, several thousand moslems demonstrated in the center of kinshasa to press the government to punish fernando. police dispersed the protest.

sources: congo police leave bunia after protests. morning star, june 23, 2003, pg. 2;
notes: about 150 police left the congolese town of bunia yesterday after being asked to withdraw by an international force sent to safeguard civilians from ethnic bloodletting. the government in kinshasa sent 112 armed police reinforcements to bunia on friday, a move that the international force said violated a peace deal signed in may by the government and militias fighting over the town. the arrival of the police sparked a protest by about 100 residents on saturday, who said that they considered the police as members of the congolese army, which they accuse of backing gunmen allied to the ethnic lendu tribe...

sources: 1 un troops kill two congolese protesters: fall of eastern city bukavu enrages citizenry. edmonton journal alberta , june 4, 2004 friday final edition, news; pg. a12, daniel balint kurti; 2 un troops kill two in congo riots. the guardian london final edition, june 4, 2004, guardian foreign pages, pg. 14, jeevan vasagar in nairobi and agencies in kinshasa; 3 fragile peace settles over congo: after largest protests since 1997. un peacekeepers take control of bukavu after guerrillas withdraw. the gazette montreal, quebec , june 5, 2004 saturday final edition, news; pg. a28, rodrique ngowi;
notes: nationwide protests in response to a rebel group breaking a cease fire & capturing a town; sources 1&3 s reports make protests a coded event against the state; source 2 and other sources report anti un demonstrations but not directly against the state; 1 crowds numbering in the tens of thousands turned on congolese president joseph kabila s government and the 10,800 member un peacekeeping force in the country for failing to stop the fall of bukavu, some 1,500 kilometres to the northeast. the state is dead! protesters cried in the demonstrations that broke out at daybreak, filling the city centre with thunderous chants. swinging wooden clubs and converging on un posts, they vowed: we will punish the united nations ourselves ... ; 2 in the capital, kinshasa, police fired into the air and volleyed teargas at a massive mob which surged around the un headquarters in the city centre, hurling rocks and chanting ; 3 in kinshasa, the capital about 1,500 kilometres to the southwest, kabila spoke on state television thursday and yesterday to calm the nation after two days of countrywide protests, the largest since 1997...thursday s riots against the government and the united nations revealed the weakness of kabila s government, even on its home turf. protesters blamed congo s army for the loss of bukavu and congo s 10,800 strong un force for standing by as it was seized

sources: strike grips kinshasa. morning star, january 15, 2005, pg. 3;
notes: the streets of congo s capital kinshasa were silent yesterday as a citywide strike got under way to commemorate the killing of several people during protests this week against a government decision to delay nationwide elections. thousands of people protested in kinshasa on monday, throwing rocks at police and burning tyres. police responded with bullets and tear gas, killing at least three people. more than 60 people were arrested.

sources: riots after congo elections bring fears of fresh fighting. the independent london , october 31, 2006 tuesday, world; pg. 24, steve bloomfield in kinshasa;
notes: mobs went on the rampage through a town in northeastern congo and thousands of ballot papers were burnt yesterday after a drunken congolese soldier killed two election observers, highlighting the fragility of the peace in a country which has just held its first elections in decades. violence erupted and half of the polling stations in fakati, a town in the war ravaged ituri district, were destroyed after news of the killings sparked widespread anger

protesteridentity: supporters of presidential candidate jean pierre bemba
sources: congo protesters set fire to court. the irish times, november 22, 2006 wednesday, world; pg. 10, felim mcmahon in kinshasa;
notes: a fire started by supporters of defeated presidential candidate jean pierre bemba has extensively damaged the congolese supreme court here in the capital after a protest outside the building yesterday turned violent. up to 200 supporters of mr bemba gathered outside the court as it started hearing the former rebel leader s challenge to provisional election results, announced last wednesday. those results handed victory in the presidential run off to incumbent president joseph kabila, with 58 per cent of the vote, a result rejected by mr bemba s camp, amid allegations of fraud on a massive scale and an electoral hold up . congolese riot police came under fire from armed elements in the crowd after they used tear gas to break up the protest at around 11.30am. demonstrators then fell back to mr bemba s nearby residence, followed by police, who again fired tear gas on the crowd...

sources: world briefing africa: congo: soldiers riot and loot over pay. the new york times, january 13, 2007 saturday, section a; column 5; foreign desk; pg. 4;
notes: soldiers protesting unpaid bonuses fired guns and grenades, looted shops and homes around bunia, the main city in the eastern ituri district, and raped the daughter of a world food program worker in a nightlong rampage, officials said. united nations peacekeepers and local military authorities arrested at least 24 soldiers and stopped an advance towards the city center. the rioting troops, who complained they had not been paid year end bonuses, were members of a national army being put together from former warring rebel and militia groups. diplomats and aid workers say the fledgling army is badly paid, operates in appalling conditions and is the worst rights abuser in the country.

sources: 1 world briefing africa: congo: 35 killed in election clashes. the new york times, february 2, 2007 friday, section a; column 1; foreign desk; pg. 8; 2 world in brief. the washington post, february 3, 2007 saturday, a section; a11; 3 world in brief. the washington post, april 19, 2007 thursday, foreign; pg. a24;
notes: 1 more than 35 people have been killed in clashes between security forces and opposition supporters in several towns in western bas congo province, government and hospital officials said. the violence started wednesday when supporters of jean pierre bemba, who lost the presidential election to joseph kabila last year, protested governors elections that were mostly won by pro kabila candidates. ; 2 days of clashes between security forces and demonstrators claiming electoral fraud have left nearly 100 people dead in several southwestern congo towns, humanitarian and rights groups said ; 3 congolese soldiers shot dead dozens of unarmed civilians, some while they prayed, in a violent crackdown on protests this year, a rights watchdog said wednesday. the violence occurred jan. 31 and feb. 1 after a religious group allied with the opposition demonstrated against alleged fraud in an election for governor in the western province of bas congo. supporters of the group, bundu dia kongo, beat 10 police officers to death with sticks and clubs, including one as he was being treated in a medical clinic, human rights watch said. two civilians were also killed. in response, security forces unleashed a disproportionate amount of force at several sites, according to human rights watch, which documented 116 deaths. a u.n. report shortly after the violence put the death toll at 134.

sources: 1 protesters burn polling stations in congo vote. canwest news service, november 28, 2011 monday 07:00 pm est, mike pflanz, the daily telegraph; 2 rigged vote fear amid blockades, arson and deaths. the times london , november 29, 2011 tuesday, news; pg. 24, jonathan clayton;
notes: armed protesters set fire to polling stations and at least five people were killed as reports of widespread vote fraud swept the democratic republic of congo during elections on monday. ballot boxes were found already stuffed with votes and polls opened late across the country, prompting crowds to throw stones at voting centres, burning 15 of them. people failed to find their names on voters lists or reported that others had used their names to cast ballots. in the most serious outbreak, at least five people were killed and several injured when armed civilians opened fire on queues outside polling stations in the southern mining city of lubumbashi. police also reportedly blocked opposition leader etienne tshisekedi and thousands of his supporters on a main road in the capital kinshasa as the presidential candidate went to cast his vote on monday night...

notes: with a contentious election still unresolved more than a week after the voting, an uneasy quiet held here on wednesday, punctuated by occasional blasts of tear gas, hurled rocks, gunshots and promises of more intense confrontations to come...photo: the police rounded up opposition supporters at a protest in kinshasa, congo, on wednesday.

sources: 1 congo braced for conflict as rival rejects kabila victory. canwest news service, december 9, 2011 friday 08:00 pm est, mike pflanz, the daily telegraph; 2 president of congo is declared winner. the new york times, december 10, 2011 saturday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 6, by adam nossiter; 3 two self declared leaders help keep congo on edge. the new york times, december 11, 2011 sunday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 14, by adam nossiter; 4 sandf ferried tons of ballot papers. cape times south africa , december 14, 2011 wednesday, news; pg. 6;
notes: 1 gunshots rang out in the capital kinshasa s eastern neighbourhood of limete, where mr tshisekedi has his party headquarters, and in the central neighbourhood of bandale, where protesters set tires on fire and threw stones at police. there were also reports of looting and at least one person was shot and wounded. smoke rose over parts of mostly pro opposition kinshasa, where riot police had been deployed in advance, as worries mounted that a post election dispute could renew conflict in the country... ; 2 the silence was punctuated by occasional gunshots as cruising police officers, guns pointing out from their patrol vehicles, fired in the air to disperse the crowds...crowds, fleeing the roaming police, occasionally surged unexpectedly through the streets in the hazy late afternoon light... ; 3 earlier, guns were fired in the air by the police and tear gas was sprayed on citizens who came out to protest mr. kabila s apparent victory. by saturday, burned out, looted cars lined a principal avenue in 20 mai, while the remains of burning tires were smoldering in the neighborhood s streets. but there were no large scale demonstrations, and the capital s six lane boulevards were deserted saturday... ; 4 violent protests and looting followed the announcement of the results on friday, leading to a crackdown on protests by the drc s military forces. at least four people were reported to have been killed.

protesteridentity: supporters of joseph mukungubila a fringe evangelical preacher
sources: world digest: dec. 30, 2013. the washington post, december 31, 2013 tuesday, a section; pg. a06;
notes: armed assailants attacked the state television station, airport and main military base in congo s capital, kinshasa, early monday in what many feared was a coup attempt, officials and witnesses said. lambert mende, congo s government spokesman, said about 40 people were killed in the attacks, including 16 at the military base, 16 at the airport and eight at the tv station. he also confirmed that shootings had occurred in lubumbashi, located in southeastern congo. the assailants at the tv station said they wanted to broadcast a message on behalf of joseph mukungubila, a fringe evangelical preacher in congo. the signal to the tv station was cut before they could do so. mukungubila confirmed that his followers were behind the coordinated attacks, but he said his disciples were armed only with sticks and faced the automatic weapons brandished by the country s security forces. he said his faithful were acting out of anger after two boys in his congregation were attacked by security forces in lubumbashi over the weekend...

sources: dozens are killed after protesting the herald glasgow , january 22, 2015 thursday, pg. 16, 156 words, caroline woollard;
notes: at least 42 people have been killed in three days of protests in democratic republic of congo over a proposed legal reform the opposition says would keep president joseph kabila in power for years. paul nsapu, secretary general for africa of the international federation for human rights fidh , said most of the victims had been killed by government security forces as they took part in political protests. the government, which says only 15 people have been killed, said most of the victims were shot by private security guards while looting. for the most part these people were killed while they were advancing to protest, mr nsapu said, adding that more than 100 people had been injured. we don t expect the government to act in the same way as a rebel group. in a third day of protests, police fired tear gas at demonstrators at the university campus in the capital kinshasa. clashes also took place in three other areas of the city.

sources: congolese activists on hunger strike after court refuses release; fred bauma and yves makwambala among dozens of drc youth group members in prison for demanding democratic change the guardian, march 24, 2016 thursday 2:31 pm gmt, world news, 823 words, tom wilson in kinshasa;
notes: nearly 30 members of lucha are now in prison after 18 were arrested on tuesday in goma during a peaceful protest calling for bauma and makwambala s release. last month, six were sentenced to six months in prison for incitement to revolt after police found them making banners that called for political change in a private home. during tuesday s protest lucha activists walked peacefully through goma city centre with their mouths gagged and hands tied in a powerful visual demonstration of their opposition to the government s crackdown on political freedoms.

sources: scores arrested in democratic republic of congo clashes; one protester killed in goma during opposition organised protests against president joseph kabila s plan to delay elections the guardian, may 27, 2016 friday 12:34 pm gmt, world news, 589 words, jason burke africa correspondent, and agencies;
notes: opposition parties and civil society groups had called for nationwide demonstrations to protest against a ruling earlier this month by congo s highest court that would allow president joseph kabila to remain in power if presidential and parliamentary elections due in november are not held. while a march that was authorised in kinshasa drew several thousand opposition supporters, demonstrations in other cities were banned by local authorities.

sources: clashes in kinshasa leave 50 dead, say drc opposition groups; unrest over president joseph kabila s decision to delay elections continues, with opposition party hqs torched overnight the guardian, september 20, 2016 tuesday 10:21 am gmt, world news, 767 words, jason burke africa correspondent;
notes: police and demonstrators have clashed in the democratic republic of the congo, in the latest round of violence sparked by the ongoing political crisis in the troubled central african state. opposition groups said more than 50 people died on monday in clashes in the capital, kinshasa. the government said at least 17 people had been killed but warned that the toll could rise further. witnesses said protesters had beaten at least one police officer to death. four people were also killed when the headquarters of three drc opposition parties were torched overnight and early on tuesday, agence france presse reported.

sources: drc protests grow as kabila clings to power despite his term ending; opposition leader calls on congolese to peacefully resist illegitimate leader amid clashes with security forces the guardian, december 20, 2016 tuesday 12:24 pm gmt, world news, 1021 words, jason burke in kinshasa at least 20 reported dead as congolese security forces fire on protesters the new york times , december 20, 2016 tuesday 00:00 est, world; africa, 265 words, reuters nearly 300 are arrested in congo as protests appear to wane the new york times, december 22, 2016 thursday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 14, 630 words, by reuters;
notes: hundreds of protesters have clashed with security forces in the democratic republic of the congo after the mandate of the president, joseph kabila, expired with no sign of the 45 year old former guerrilla commander leaving power. in kinshasa, the capital of the vast resource rich central african nation, police and soldiers fired live ammunition as opposition activists burned tyres, attacked an office of the ruling party and threw stones. violence was also reported in the southern city of lubumbashi.

protesteridentity: protesters against president kabila, who has refused to step down or hold fresh elections since his term as president ended in december last year
