notes: 1 a funeral on wednesday degenerated into a riot. opposition protesters pelted cars with stones and set a government building on fire. ; 2 president mwai kibaki and opposition leader raila odinga met briefly thursday 1 24 for the first time since kenya s disputed presidential election threw the country into weeks of protests, riots and ethnically charged violence. the meeting at first appeared to be a breakthrough, albeit a symbolic one, and their handshake afterward on the steps of a government building in downtown nairobi was met with camera flashes and cheering from hundreds of onlookers.

sources: 1 slain kenyan legislator was a healer amid chaos. the new york times, january 30, 2008 wednesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 8, by jeffrey gettleman; reuben kyama contributed reporting; 2 opposition legislator slain in kenya, sparking clashes. the washington post, january 30, 2008 wednesday, a section; pg. a01, stephanie mccrummen; washington post foreign service;
notes: 1 on tuesday morning, as he pulled up to the gate of his home, mr. were was dragged out of his car and shot to death...the details are still sketchy, but the shooting appears to have been a planned murder, not a robbery. word spread fast and led to violence, with opposition supporters rioting across nairobi, the capital...opposition supporters immediately called the killing a political assassination, intended to intimidate their movement, which is challenging the election in december that kenya s president, mwai kibaki, narrowly won, against the top opposition leader, raila odinga...on tuesday morning, a huge crowd of mourners streamed into his ranch house. the grief soon turned to outrage, and by midmorning the tears had dried and the roadblocks were going up. mourners set tires aflame and hauled huge stones into the road. it was the first time that riots had reached a middle class neighborhood in nairobi...the problems have laid bare the shortcomings of kenya s poorly paid security forces...on tuesday, they drove past a crowd of young men pulling down a telephone pole in front of mr. were s house and did nothing. ; 2 mourners gathered there by the hundreds until police arrived and fired tear gas. the scene turned into an angry, tire burning demonstration...and in kisumu, farther west, thousands of opposition supporters barricaded roads with bonfires, stopped buses and stoned a man to death...

sources: second lawmaker is killed as kenya s riots intensify. the new york times, february 1, 2008 friday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 6, by jeffrey gettleman; reuben kyama contributed reporting from nairobi, and abisalom omolo from kisumu;
notes: a second kenyan opposition lawmaker was shot dead on thursday, and riots immediately exploded in opposition strongholds, putting the country increasingly on edge. the lawmaker, david kimutai too, a former teacher from the volatile rift valley, was gunned down by a policeman in eldoret. kenyan government officials were quick to say the killing was a crime of passion connected to a love triangle. opposition leaders called it an assassination. how can police call this an ordinary murder before any investigations? said william ruto, an opposition leader...a shock wave of outrage and panic moved across the country as the news of mr. too s death spread. in kisumu, an opposition stronghold in western kenya, mobs of young men tore through the streets, burning tires, throwing rocks and blockading roads. some carried gasoline bombs and vowed to burn down the police station. the rioters did not appear to accept the government s explanation of the killing. it seemed that even if mr. too s death had nothing to do with the volatile political situation here, it was bound to be interpreted as being politically motivated, especially coming so soon after the killing of another opposition lawmaker...in eldoret, shopkeepers shuttered their stores and people dashed home. protesters massed at the police station, and truckloads of paramilitary officers arrived in town. hospital officials said the police shot 10 people, killing one. many people feared reprisal killings in the night.

sources: 1 riots erupt in kenya capital as opposition suspends power sharing talks. the new york times, april 9, 2008 wednesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 6, by jeffrey gettleman; kennedy abwao contributed reporting from nairobi.. kennedy abwao contributed reporting from nairobi.; 2 kenya. the washington post, april 11, 2008 friday, foreign; pg. a15; 3 around the world. the washington post, april 13, 2008 sunday, foreign; pg. a18;
notes: 1 riots erupted in kenya on tuesday as opposition leaders announced that they were suspending talks with the government over a stalled power sharing agreement. according to witnesses, dozens of young men stormed into the streets of kibera, a sprawling slum in the capital, nairobi, lighting bonfires, ripping up railroad tracks and throwing rocks at police officers... no cabinet, no peace! the protesters yelled, referring to the cabinet that has yet to be formed because of bitter divisions between the government and the opposition...riots also broke out in kisumu, in western kenya, where witnesses said hundreds of angry opposition supporters blocked the road to the airport and stoned cars... ; 2 kenya s political rivals appealed for calm thursday as a month long deadlock over a power sharing agreement sparked a third day of violent protests and police fired tear gas to disperse the crowds... ; 3 kenyan president mwai kibaki and opposition leader raila odinga reached a deal saturday on a coalition cabinet, following protracted talks on implementing a power sharing deal meant to end the political crisis over a disputed election, officials said...

notes: at one camp in molo, a large town in the rift valley where much of the fighting occurred, a mini protest broke out monday morning when hundreds of displaced people refused to leave. peter ngoge, a shopkeeper, shook a piece of notebook paper listing several demands. he spoke for many, as evidenced by the feisty crowd behind him, when he said he would not leave the camp until the government improved security and paid compensation to those displaced.

sources: 1 kenya: decision to deport cleric prompts protests. the new york times, january 16, 2010 saturday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; world briefing africa; pg. 6, by jeffrey gettleman2 police break up pro faisal demo. the nation nairobi , january 15, 2010 friday; 3 one killed in protests over sheikh. the nation nairobi , january 15, 2010 friday, sammy cheboi and kibiwott koross;
notes: 1 police officers in nairobi on friday clashed with rock throwing mobs who were angry about the government s decision to deport a radical islamist cleric. the police fired tear gas and unleashed attack dogs on hundreds of demonstrators. witnesses said at least three people were killed. ; 2 a demonstration called to protest the arrest of controversial jamaican muslim cleric sheikh abdullah al faisal has been broken up by police. one person died in the confrontation between the police and rowdy muslim youths, and three others suffered injuries...the pro faisal demo, called by the muslim human rights forum, started peacefully at the jamia mosque in nairobi s banda street. youths waving placards castigating the government s move to arrest the cleric, who is on an international terror watchlist, and his botched deportation took to the streets after their friday prayers...the demonstration soon turned ugly as a confrontation between the youths and police ensued. police fired teargas canisters to disperse the youth, who in turn pelted the officers with stones. a huge pall of smoke engulfed banda street as the two groups engaged in a cat and mouse chase... ; 3 in mombasa, angry muslim leaders led another protest over continued incarceration of the cleric, and called for resignation of immigration minister otieno kajwang ...a handful of riot police that sought to disperse them was forced to retreat when the protesters hurled back tear gas canisters thrown at them, and stones. the retreat of police ushered in a stone throwing duel between the protesters and other wananchi, who expressed anger at disruption of their businesses. a dozen cars and buildings were destroyed as the street battles raged on into the night on the busy biashara, muindi mbingu, market and kigali streets. having been overpowered by the demonstrators, riot police made up of administration police, gsu and their regular counterparts, took a break and became spectators, occasionally stepping in with tear gas canisters...in mombasa, cipk s sheikh mohammed khalifa said the immigration minister had failed his ministerial duties and claimed that he was incapable of handling such a crucial docket...although the police were to quell the demo, the unfolding confrontation between citizens was left to rage on for remainder of the day. a police helicopter circled overhead and police also used water cannon to contain the clashes.

notes: bus and matatu operators held peaceful demonstrations to push the government to repair the 22 kilometre road which was constructed 38 years ago. holding placards and tree branches, more than 50 matatu owners, drivers and conductors chanted songs as they walked from mazeras town to kaloleni district commissioner s office where they presented their grievances. anti riot police were deployed very early in the morning and were positioned in strategic areas for the whole day to ensure the demonstrators maintained order. those interviewed accused the government and area mp of neglecting the road which plays a vital role to kaloleni farmers...mr mohammed banza, one of the matatu owners said they are incurring huge losses due to persistent repair of their vehicles. matatu owners are just doing a favour to kaloleni people to ply the road since most of the money they get is spent on maintenance and they are not gaining any profit from the business, he said. mr emanuel chengo, one of the protestors, said they are planning a major strike if the government does not respond to their grievances.

notes: 1 public health minister beth mugo was on thursday forced to flee as her constituents held chaotic demonstrations to protest the killing of seven people by the police. the demonstrators in nairobi s kawangware estate were protesting the killing of seven people by police on wednesday night. the official account from the police is that the seven were part of a notorious gang killed in an ambush. but according to the demonstrators, the seven were taxi drivers. minister mugo s attempt to quell the demonstrations proved futile and was forced to flee from the charged crowd. police lobbed tear gas cannisters to disperse the demonstrations staged along the old naivasha road. ; 2 the incident sparked widespread protests from residents. mr david mbogo and mrs mary wanjiku, one of the victims parents, said their son was a hard working and law abiding citizen who was not in anyway involved in crime. for the better part of the day, hundreds of youth barricaded the busy highway with boulders and fires until reinforcements from kabete police station arrived. commissioner of police mathew iteere on thursday ordered an investigation into the shooting... ; 3 prime minister raila odinga has directed internal security minister george saitoti to expedite the investigations into the killing of seven taxi drivers in nairobi. he ordered that the suspects be arraigned in court within 48 hours. i want this to be a test case of our government s commitment to police reforms and the rule of law, mr odinga said at his office on saturday... ; 4 on thursday, residents of kawangware went on the rampage, blocking roads with boulders and fires over the killings. police who were brought in to quell the riots could be seen beating and kicking residents.

notes: more than 1,000 farmers on monday boycotted tea picking over the recently released bonus payment. the growers from mununga tea factory in kirinyaga central district dismissed the payment as peanuts and passed a vote of no confidence in their six directors. they accused the directors of not representing their interests and called for fresh elections so that they could replace them. the farmers staged demonstrations demanding better payment for their produce. at one point, they raided the home of a colleague who had failed to join them in the protest, chased away his workers and set some of his property on fire. they turned away vehicles ferrying goods to the factory. the growers then proceeded to the company offices and tried to force their way in but were repulsed by police...they claimed their money had been misused and vowed never to accept the low bonus. carrying placards, the farmers said the boycott would continue until they were paid what was rightful theirs. we shall only go back to our farms after we have been paid what we had been promised, a farmer, mr kiai murango, shouted. they accused the company of making unnecessary deductions on their payments without consulting them. as the demonstration went on the directors and other company officials were holding crisis meeting. similar demonstration went on at thumaita tea company in kirinyaga east district. farmers rioted on the kimunye kamugunda road.

sources: new medical supplies agency deal to reduce cost of aids treatment. the nation nairobi , september 28, 2010 tuesday, mike mwaniki;
notes: addressing protesters from civil society organisations, who had marched to his afya house office in nairobi, the minister said plans to commercialise kemsa had been finalised...the protesters, led by human rights activist catherine mumma, presented a petition to the minister in which they accused the government of reneging on the abuja declaration signed in 2001 by african heads of state to allocate 15 per cent of national budgets to the health sector. later, the protesters marched to the treasury offices, where they demanded to be addressed by finance minister uhuru kenyatta. after singing protest songs for more than 30 minutes, assistant planning minister peter kenneth and finance secretary mutua kilaka came out and addressed them. mr kenneth urged kenyans to ensure that their right to health, which is guaranteed in the new constitution, is not violated. after handing over a memorandum, ms mumma appealed to the government to reduce funding to the military and instead channel the money to the health sector to fight aids and other diseases...

sources: protesters hold traffic for hours on major highway. the nation nairobi , september 29, 2010 wednesday;
notes: the mob blocked the road at samburu by burning used tyres and logs for more than four hours before the police intervened. the protest started at about 5pm on tuesday after a cyclist was knocked down by a speeding vehicle a few hours after a girl was killed by another car on the same spot...mr ayubu said the residents decided to block the road after the local provincial administration and police failed to fulfil their promise to erect bumps on the road...acting coast traffic officer charles koskei said they were meeting road engineers to ensure the grievances of the residents were addressed...

protesteridentity: human rights activists, muslim for human rights muhuri
sources: lobby pushes for release of 13 in bombs case. the nation nairobi , september 30, 2010 thursday, anthony kitimo;
notes: rights activists on thursday took to the streets in mombasa, protesting at failure by the government to protect the rights of 13 kenyans being held in uganda over the kampala blasts ...the activists, among them members of the muslim for human rights muhuri , held the protests along moi and nkrumah roads. they carried placards and chanted, expressing their disappointment over failure to take any action to ensure the rights of the suspects were protected...armed administration police officers kept off the activists from mombasa district commissioner s office where they tried to forcefully enter to submit a memorandum on the issue. the group camped outside the office singing and chanting for more than 30 minutes before dc hassan abdi accepted to address them. in the memorandum, the group is demanding the sacking of internal security minister george saitoti, foreign affairs minister moses wetang ula and justice minister mutula kilonzo for what they termed as their failure to protect kenyans from being taken to uganda. the activists also called for the disbandment and restructuring of the anti terrorism police unit for alleged failure to carry out their job professionally...

sources: youths hurt in clash with police. the nation nairobi , september 30, 2010 thursday, john shilitsa;
notes: several youths were injured in a confrontation with officers at the musanda police post in mumias after they were shot at...the youths had attempted to free murder suspects who were in police custody. mr laboso said police tried to disperse the youths and restore calm...residents of south wanga had earlier accused the police of high handedness, saying the officers opened fire on them without considering their explanations. they claimed officers allowed a suspected motorcycle thief to take refuge at the police post and repulsed the mob that was baying for the suspect s blood. police have launched a search for leaders of the protests in mumias, of whom some ran into a sugarcane plantation.

sources: tour group threatens to strike over poor mara roads. the nation nairobi , october 19, 2010 tuesday;
notes: hundreds of operators last week poured into the streets of narok town to protest the poor state of roads leading to masai mara.

sources: doctors protest move to withdraw college funding. the nation nairobi , october 19, 2010 tuesday, casper waithaka;
notes: the move by government to scrap funding for students pursuing postgraduate studies in medicine is causing jitters in the medical profession. it was prompted by universities increase in fees from sh120,000 to sh214,900 which the government cannot afford. hundreds of young doctors tuesday held a peaceful demonstration at freedom corner, uhuru park to protest the move. they presented a petition to prime minister raila odinga...

sources: paper mills workers hold demo over pay. the nation nairobi , october 19, 2010 tuesday, eric ngobilo;
notes: workers at pan paper mills have petitioned the government to settle their salary arrears and come clear on the fate of the factory. the workers held demonstrations in webuye town paralysing transport at sango area on the eldoret malaba highway as they waved twigs and chanted slogans against the government. they accused government officials of misleading them to vote yes at the referendum on the promise that the factory would resume full operations.

sources: new fees spark protest at farmers market. the nation nairobi , november 1, 2010 monday, casper waithaka;
notes: business came to a standstill at the wakulima market in nairobi yesterday after traders took to the streets, protesting against new charges introduced by the city council last week. they demanded the local authority stop the new charges and instead improve the facilities at the market and get rid of the garbage, which is an eyesore...only selected lights at the market were functioning when a high profile delegation visited the market yesterday led by the acting mayor, mr george aladwa, area mp simon mbugua and other senior council officers. mr aladwa expressed shock over the situation at the market. i am in shock, this is pure sewage which must not mix with food, he said. he directed the traders not to pay the new rates until the matter was resolved and a taskforce chaired by the area councillor, mr james gakuya, formed. he further revealed that the council had released sh7 million to improve the infrastructure and clean the market.

sources: 1 residents block busy highway to protest at poor road network. the nation nairobi , november 9, 2010 tuesday; 2 police halt busy highway protest. the nation nairobi , november 10, 2010 wednesday, jonathan manyindo; 3 transport chaos on busy highway. the nation nairobi , november 10, 2010 wednesday;
notes: 1 hundreds of voi residents on tuesday took to the streets and barricaded the mombasa highway to protest against the poor state of roads in taita taveta county. transport between mombasa and nairobi was paralysed for the better part of the day as travellers were left stranded...although the strike started on monday with demonstrations by matatu operators plying voi taveta and voi wundanyi mgange routes, the public joined in as the police who had initially tried to keep the road open retreated... ; 2 police have repulsed angry demonstrators who had barricaded the nairobi mombasa highway for more than 24 hours demanding the immediate repair of the dilapidated voi taveta road. taita taveta police boss nathaniel aseneka said after dialogue failed they had to use an alternative method to open up the flow of traffic... ; 3 on tuesday nov. 9th , the government released sh20m for routine maintenance works on the stretch. roads minister franklin bett said his ministry had advertised tenders for reconstruction of the road and he expected the contractor to be on site by february 2011.

sources: sonko arrest riddle after vigilance talks. the nation nairobi , november 19, 2010 friday, peter leftie;
notes: confusion surrounded the whereabouts of makadara mp gidion mbuvi kioko following reports that he had been arrested and locked up at a nairobi police station. the mp who spoke to nation on the phone said that he was being held at the gigiri police station and that detectives were yet to tell him the reason for his arrest....earlier, two separate groups marched to the city centre in support of the makadara legislator. the groups, one consisting of women who said they were from makadara constituency and the other, mainly made up of youths, marched to the nation centre chanting slogans in praise of the mp. sonko si mwizi. acheni fitina. sonko is not a thief. stop the propaganda , the demonstrators chanted. the mp denied sponsoring the demonstrations...

sources: civic candidate s supporters protest against petition delay. the nation nairobi , november 24, 2010 wednesday;
notes: supporters of a civic candidate in the last general election held a demonstration to protest at the delay in determining a petition she had filed. the supporters left the eldoret high court immediately after it had allowed the current councillor to file an appeal after a magistrate s court had declared that he lost the election. they marched through the streets to nandi gardens where they held a noisy protest...the demonstrators chanted slogans and briefly blocked traffic as they marched in the streets before they peacefully dispersed.police officers watched the protest from a distance and did not attempt not stop the demonstration. the demonstrators complained that no directions had been given by the judge as to when the appeal would be filed. mr maisiba had found cases of inflation of votes for mr kiptum...

sources: orengo urged to take back stolen land. the nation nairobi , december 10, 2010 friday, galgalo bocha;
notes: human rights activists and leaders have called for the immediate repossession of grabbed land in coast. the thorny land issue surfaced during celebrations to mark the international human rights day, at the makadara grounds in mombasa on friday. coast non state land actors an umbrella group for activists championing land rights asked lands minister james orengo to cancel all titles deeds issued for thousands of hectares of public plots acquired fraudulently at the coast...dozens of mombasa residents joined coast non state land actors in a procession from kengeleni links through nyali bridge road, finally converging at makadara grounds. the peaceful demonstrators wore sack clothes inscribed with the theme of event: speak up stop discrimination ...

sources: youths protest businessman s drug trafficking involvement. the nation nairobi , december 30, 2010 thursday, paul ogemba;
notes: the youth & youth groups have been protesting against drug trafficking and drug traders; this is the first article directly linking demands to government policy actions; the youths also vented their anger on parliament, questioning why they debated his alleged involvement in drug trafficking in the house where the businessman could not defend himself.

sources: voi sisal plantationworkers now strike over pay cut. nairobi star nairobi , january 5, 2012 thursday, raphael mwadime;
notes: operations at the voi sisal estate were yesterday grounded for the second consecutive day following protests by workers protesting over poor working conditions. the workers further lamented that their pay has been reduced by their employer from sh270 to sh135 per day without notice. the more than 100 workers led by the taita taveta cotu secretary general richard juma vowed not to resume work until their bosses hear their cry. they further complained that the houses they are living in are deplorable. they marched to the voi district labour office to present their grievances...

sources: jomvu residents protest over blocked roads and containers. nairobi star nairobi , january 9, 2012 monday, maureen mudi;
notes: hundreds of jomvu mikanjuni residents in changamwe paralysed transport on the mombasa nairobi highway protesting the poor state of the road due to blockage by trucks. the residents chanted slogans on the road for close to seven hours, as they demanded that the government acts on two shipping companies, which have had its lorries block the road while parked...

protesteridentity: supporters of deputy chief justice nancy baraza
sources: protestors hit bungoma streets over baraza saga. nairobi star nairobi , january 18, 2012 wednesday, simbi kusimba and john nalianya;
notes: supporters of embattled deputy chief justice nancy baraza held a peaceful demonstration in bungoma town yesterday morning claiming she was a target of a witch hunt aimed at creating a vacancy for a certain personality from central kenya. the demonstrators who were on foot, bicycles, motorcycles and cars took to the streets shortly after 10am waving placards claiming baraza is innocent. they brought traffic along the busy moi avenue to a standstill...they later converged at the bungoma bus park where they were addressed by knut deputy executive secretary kellan wavomba...

sources: kimende traders protest relocation. nairobi star nairobi , january 18, 2012 wednesday, njenga gicheha;
notes: about 600 kimende traders paralysed operations along the nairobi naivasha highway over a move by the kiambu county council to relocate them. the traders held a procession to the dc s office to lounge their complain. they said demands by the council to stop operating at the open air market along the highway will affect business. the traders said they cannot afford to raise sh2,200 each to build stalls as required by the council...wainaina said if the stalls are constructed, the market will not be able to accommodate such a big number of traders. he said the council had plans to have only 76 stalls which will mean about 500 plus traders will be rendered jobless...dc bernard kinyua assured the traders that the council will hearken to their cry. he called upon njoroge and the traders leaders to visit the council offices in kiambu on tuesday next week and solve the stalemate.

protesteridentity: youth supporters of nairobi metropolitan development minister njeru githae
sources: kirinyaga mps in row over mwea, ndia boundaries. nairobi star nairobi , january 19, 2012 thursday, jane mugambi;
notes: fought with youth in protest 5; tension is high at kagio town in kirinyaga county as two rival groups allied to nairobi metropolitan development minister njeru githae and mwea mp peter gitau faced off over a constituency boundary dispute. hundreds of youths gathered at kagio shopping centre for a planned demonstration from kagio to sagana town led by the mwea mp and other leaders from mwea constituency. but youths allied to githae also gathered to support the minister. business came to a standstill at the busy kagio market as the rival groups engaged in confrontations with police before the demonstration was declared illegal and the crowd ordered to disperse. police in full riot gear were called in to prevent violence...the officers pleaded with the two camps to discuss the issues and present their views to the independent electoral and boundaries commission which will tour kirinyaga county today. addressing the charged crowd gitau said that the people of mwea will not accept to be divided, and will accept nothing short of a new constituency...githae denied the accusations and said that the people of ndia constituency were also opposed to give them a location from mwea which they did not ask for. he said kirinyaga county must be given a new constituency and proposed mwea be split into two...

protesteridentity: youth supporters of mwea mp peter gitau
sources: kirinyaga mps in row over mwea, ndia boundaries. nairobi star nairobi , january 19, 2012 thursday, jane mugambi;
notes: fought with youth in protest 6; tension is high at kagio town in kirinyaga county as two rival groups allied to nairobi metropolitan development minister njeru githae and mwea mp peter gitau faced off over a constituency boundary dispute. hundreds of youths gathered at kagio shopping centre for a planned demonstration from kagio to sagana town led by the mwea mp and other leaders from mwea constituency. but youths allied to githae also gathered to support the minister. business came to a standstill at the busy kagio market as the rival groups engaged in confrontations with police before the demonstration was declared illegal and the crowd ordered to disperse. police in full riot gear were called in to prevent violence...the officers pleaded with the two camps to discuss the issues and present their views to the independent electoral and boundaries commission which will tour kirinyaga county today. addressing the charged crowd gitau said that the people of mwea will not accept to be divided, and will accept nothing short of a new constituency...githae denied the accusations and said that the people of ndia constituency were also opposed to give them a location from mwea which they did not ask for. he said kirinyaga county must be given a new constituency and proposed mwea be split into two...

sources: youth block litein road. nairobi star nairobi , january 20, 2012 friday, sonu tanu;
notes: transport services came to halt along the litein mogogosiek road after 300 youths barricaded it to protest increasing cases of hit and run motorists who have left several children dead...they directed accusing finger to local traffic police officers who ignore cautioning matatu operators fond of over speeding and who have claimed lives of innocent children. they appealed to roads ministry to take necessary action and have permanent road blocks erected in all areas where crossing children had been hit and killed...despite earlier appeals to the ministry of roads to have bumps erected on the black spot nothing had happened...

sources: mt elgon sldf could be regrouping, say leaders. nairobi star nairobi , january 23, 2012 monday, john nalianya;
notes: mt elgon county council chairman amos tulkon yesterday led hundreds of residents in kaptama in protesting the increase of murder cases in the area. speaking to the star after the demonstration, tulkon said of the recent cases where several people have been shot dead in the area: we want to call on the government security apparatus to act first because this is how it started in 2006 and the police down played our cries until over 1,200 people lost their lives and another 10,000 displaced. ...however, mt elgon police boss robison mboloi saidthe cases are normal crime and termed those saying the sldf was grouping as alarmists ...tulkon further called for a total reshuffle of the provincial administration and police operating in the area saying most of them had overstayed and were being compromised... most of those who were arrested in connection with the activities of the militia group have been acquitted by different courts and they could be regrouping to go back to their old habits.

sources: machakos women protest poor sand price. nairobi star nairobi , january 28, 2012 saturday, wambua kavila;
notes: hundreds of women yesterday demonstrated in machakos town over poor producer prices for sand, terrazo tiles and building stones. the women from ebenezer women group in kaseve walked six kilometers from their workplace to machakos town in what they termed as exploitation by middlemen and lack of assistance from their local leaders. they said they were being offered sh150 for a 120 kilogram pack of terrazo tiles which they said fetched over four times the amount in nairobi where the demand is high. where are our leaders? we are languishing in poverty yet we are producing high quality products that are beautifying nairobi and elsewhere, they said. they marched from kaseve, six kilometers from machakos town and blocked the busy kitui road. they demanded for help from machakos leaders. machakos county is rich in natural resources but our leaders are oblivious of the exploitation that is going on which is irresponsibility on their part, the women said...

sources: pokot farmers uproot pyrethrum over pay. nairobi star nairobi , january 31, 2012 tuesday, nicholas wamalwa and maryann chai;
notes: several pyrethrum farmers in west pokot county have uprooted the crop to protest the failure by the ministry of agriculture to pay them over sh40 million. the more than 5,000 farmers blamed the pyrethrum board of kenya of not paying for the crop delivered to it. the board s regional director stephen yakan said majority of farmers in the district have destroyed the crop after delayed payments...farmers, yakan said, claim payment arrears of sh12 million for 2008 to 2009, and over sh25 million for last year... it is bad to wait for two years to be paid for the crop delivered to the government.we have decided abandon the crop because it is valueless to us, he said...

sources: isiolo locals protest killing. nairobi star nairobi , february 3, 2012 friday, hussein salesa;
notes: hundreds of isiolo town residents poured into the streets yesterday after the police shot a herdsman dead. shops in the town were closed as protesters lit bonfires and pelted the police with missiles. a senior police officer commanding the police response to the riots was injured and rushed to the isiolo district hospital for treatment. the riots started after residents learnt the police had killed a herdsman during a shootout in the outskirts of the town. a police source who did not wish to be named said police on patrol stumbled on a group of herders who started shooting at them without provocation. the police used teargas and batons to restore calm and disperse the rowdy crowd. one of the protesters was shot in the hand and was treated at the isiolo district hospital and discharged. upper eastern regional commissioner isaiah nakoru said the herders death will be inestigated. he appealed for calm and patient as the cause of the shooting is established. a group of men dumped the body of the herder at the gates of the dc s office in anger.

sources: violent protests rock mara over equity deal. nairobi star nairobi , february 4, 2012 saturday, kiplang at kirui;
notes: violent protests erupted in narok county on thursday at sekenani gate of the world famous maasai mara game reserve. protests started when a group of youth began vandalising solar panel equipment and other software gadgets equity bank installed to monitor entry into the park and and collect revenue. they residents are protesting against the ten year contract which the narok county council awarded equity bank to collect tourism revenue on its behalf. operation at the park were grounded for several hours with tourists sitting pensively in their vans as the locals blocked the gate and engaged police in running battles for more than three hours.

sources: machakos drivers protest over death of colleague. nairobi star nairobi , february 4, 2012 saturday, wambua kavila;
notes: hundreds of matatu drivers and conductors in machakos yesterday protested over the death of their colleague who they claimed was beaten up by council askaris. the drivers blocked the kitui highway in the morning before they marched to town hall and subsequently to machakos police station. they called for the arrest of two council askaris who they blamed for the killing. however, according to town clerk ahmed abdullahi, the victim, mutuku muthoka was arrested at the machakos bus park for touting and taken to machakos police station. on reaching the station,the tout bolted and ran away with both the police and council askaris giving chase. he was re arrested about 200 metres from the station. abdullahi said muthoka was booked in the station and a few moments later, he complained of severe chest pains and was rushed to machakos district hospital where he died later in the night...however,the victims colleagues said two council askaris weer seen beating up the tout after re arresting him in a trench where he had fallen into...machakos ocs,peter mwaura had a rough time yesterday trying to calm down the irate matatu men who kept vigil outside the station for the better part of the day calling for the arrest of the council askaris. the police boss told them it was meaningless for them to claim that the victim was beaten yet none of them were willing to produce witnesses to record statements over the incident... the matatu men said council askaris were brutal and usually assaulted touts at the machakos bus stage prior to frog marching them to machakos police station and wanted the council to crack the whip on the askaris whom they claimed were a law unto themselves.

sources: mtongwe residents hold demo over ferry services. nairobi star nairobi , february 4, 2012 saturday, maureen mudi;
notes: hundreds of mtongwe residents yesterday demonstrated against the kenya ferry services move to withdraw services at the mtongwe channel. they have given the management seven days to return the services or they paralyse business at the channel. the likoni police boss abaragamayo guyo and other security officers arrived at the jetty and tried to calm the crowd down. the residents, who were at the mtongwe jetty from 6am, said they have for the past two months been forced to access mombasa town using the likoni crossing, making them incur more transport costs since it is far...kfs managing director hassan musa, had announced two months ago that services at the mtongwe jetty will be suspended to repair the ramp. yesterday, musa called on the commuters to be patient, saying that they are hoping to get funding for the project soon...amidsts chants of haki yetu , our rights , the residents said they pay taxes and demanded to be served by the government...

sources: 1 protests over tout s killing in machakos. nairobi star nairobi , february 8, 2012 wednesday, wambua kavila; 2 two arrested in violent protests in machakos. nairobi star nairobi , february 9, 2012 thursday, wambua kavila;
notes: 1 machakos town was yesterday turned into a battle field as rioting youths stoned police protesting the death of a tout in custody last week. police had to fire live ammunition in the air and lobbed several tear gas canisters during the running battles at the machakos town bus park and its environs. the rampaging youths destroyed the toll station at the bus park, damaged street lights and burnt a giant water tank during the hour long fracas. shortly after midday protesting matatu operators found police in riot gear manning the bus park. the touts, joined by scores of youths, hurled missiles at the police who lobbed tear gas back at the youths. by 1pm the police had managed to disperse the protesters with hundreds scampering for safety...what started as a peaceful demonstration in the morning degenerated into a battle as hundreds of youths joined the matatu men after a meeting held outside the machakos municipal council. during the meeting, machakos town mp victor munyaka accused the council of corruption and brutality and called for action to be taken against the two council askaris who allegedly beat mutuku matheka to death last week. the protesters also called for the transfer of town clerk ahmed abdullahi and said he should take responsibility for rogue council askaris... ; 2 the youths were arrested during running battles with the police which lasted the better part of the day and police used live ammunition and tear gas to disperse protesters. machakos police chief richard kerich said the suspects will be charged with stoning police officers and malicious damage to property...

sources: 1 idps from bungoma now demand to be resettled. nairobi star nairobi , february 9, 2012 thursday, john nalianya; 2 police brutality on idps in bungoma condemned. nairobi star nairobi , february 13, 2012 monday, john nalianya;
notes: 1 thousands of idps yesterday held demonstrations in bungoma demanding that their grievances be heard. the idps pitched camp at the provincial commissioner s office and vowed not to leave until they are given audience. the displaced families from bungoma, mayanja, sirisia, malakisi, chewle, kimabole, namwela and kamukuywa accused the government of being biased in resettlements. the chairman of the group, hudson wanyonyi, accused the government of concentrating on the displaced persons from rift valley and neglecting those from bungoma...efforts by bungoma south dc sylvester mwangulo to calm down bore no fruit. mwangulo urged them to give the government time to sort out the issues raised. they however refused to go back to their camps... ; 2 the idps who had pitched camp at the upper western regional commissioner s office were forcefully dispersed by anti riot police...

sources: mwingi protests plan to scrap constituency. nairobi star nairobi , february 10, 2012 friday, musembi nzengu;
notes: mwingi residents yesterday poured into the town s streets to protest alleged attempts subvert the creation of mwingi central constituency. they claim there is a move to create mwingi east constituency instead of central. the protesters waved placards and shouted slogans to oppose the alleged move by local mps vice president kalonzo musyoka mwingi north and david musila mwingi south to have the mwingi central constituency scrapped from the ligale proposed 80 new constituencies...the residents who marched in a convoy led by boda boda operators held a peaceful protest under the aegis of the mwingi residents consultative forum. they were closely monitored by police who trailed the procession in an unmarked cid land rover pick up. the procession made a brief stop at the mwingi independent electoral and boundary commission offices where their leaders peter mutemi chairman , sammy nzoka secretary and mutua kathau treasurer presented a memorandum to an official angela munyoki...

sources: narok residents stage demo over boundary. nairobi star nairobi , february 15, 2012 wednesday, kiplang at kirui;
notes: hundreds of narok south residents yesterday held a demonstration against the boundary report by the independent electoral boundary commission. the protesters blocked the busy narok bomet road for more than three hours waving placards and twigs...appealed to the parliament to follow the ligale report saying it will address conflicts in the region...he said that the proposed boundary were not the fairest attempt at equitable delineation of electoral area. cheborge said that the kipsigis should be allowed to exercise their constitutional rights by allowing them to have a parliamentary representative...

sources: kiabonyoru residents oppose borabu shift. nairobi star nairobi , february 16, 2012 thursday, angwenyi gichana;
notes: hundreds of kiabonyoru division residents have protested the decision by the independent electoral and boundaries commission to move them to the newly created borabu constituency. the residents, who held a peaceful demonstration over the matter yesterday, said they want to remain in north mugirango constituency. they accused the iebc of ignoring their views...

sources: ngilu effigy burnt as kisasi protests boundary proposals. nairobi star nairobi , february 21, 2012 tuesday, phillip muasya;
notes: on thursday last week ngilu addressed a delegation of about 70 people who had travelled to nairobi to present a memorandum protesting the exclusion of the initially proposed mwingi central constituency

sources: ngilu effigy burnt as kisasi protests boundary proposals. nairobi star nairobi , february 21, 2012 tuesday, phillip muasya;
notes: residents of kisasi district in kitui county at the weekend held a demonstration and castigated water minister charity ngilu for allegedly interfering with boundaries review. the residents drawn from mbitini and kisasi locations accused ngilu of being behind the move to hive off the two locations from kitui central to the newly created kitui rural constituency. waving placards and twigs, the angry residents held a two kilometre procession before setting alight the minister s effigy. we have burned ngilu to demonstrate our dislike for her leadership skills. she is behind the idea to hive off kisasi and mbitini to kitui rural after realising we stopped voting for her. this is an unacceptable move, paul mutisya an opinion leader said. the residents said they felt imposed in lower yatta district whose huge sections forms the new constituency. the residents decried high political influence by the minister...

sources: nandi elders appeal for tinderet boundary review. nairobi star nairobi , february 21, 2012 tuesday, barry salil;
notes: the elders appeal comes in the wake of public demonstrations that rocked tinderet constituency at the weekend when thousands of residents held peaceful demonstrations to protest proposed boundaries as tabled by iebc before parliament a week ago. carrying twigs and placards, the residents held a procession from ol lessos to nandi hills grounds where they were addressed by church leaders and human rights officials. they want a boundary of the proposed two constituencies along the nandi escapement to separate the tea growing area to be named nandi hills constituency while the lowlands along the sugar belt bordering nyando district to be named tinderet constituency.

sources: murang a students strike over daily githeri meals . nairobi star nairobi , march 1, 2012 thursday, jesse mwangi;
notes: more than 250 students of kirogo boys secondary school in murang a county went on strike yesterday and spent the night in the streets of murang a town. the students, who were protesting over inadequate food, went on strike on tuesday night. they trekked more than 10 km to murang a town. they spent the night in the streets as they could not get transport to their homes at the time. the area district education officer mark alulu said the students were protesting poor and inadequate diet. he said they were against the increase in fees from sh12,000 to sh16,000. the students said the administration had failed to improve their diet as promised...he said efforts by the area police officers and the teachers to calm the students failed. ruitha said the school board of governors will be meeting on saturday to address the students grievances...

protesteridentity: staff at the kenya broadcasting corporation
sources: 1 kbc staff down tools over poor conditions. nairobi star nairobi , march 1, 2012 thursday, henry kibira; 2 kbc staff vow to stay put. nairobi star nairobi , march 5, 2012 monday, henry kibira;
notes: 1 hundreds of staff at the kenya broadcasting corporation staff yesterday downed their tools to protest poor working conditions...kbc managing director waithaka waihenya yesterday accused the staff of failing to follow laid down mechanisms to raise their grievances. the strike is illegal. the mechanisms of dialogue were not followed and the strike was not called by the union. the management has been dialoguing with workers yet they took the precipitate decision of attempting to paralyse operations, waihenya said... ; 2 employees of the kenya broadcasting corporation kbc vowed they will not go back to work until their demands are addressed . they want their pay increased and working conditions improved and artistes on contract hired permanently. yesterday they held a peaceful demonstration from their offices and pitched tent at prime minister raila odinga s office...the strike, which enters its sixth day today, has paralyzed operations at the station. we are aware that the management is trying to send a wrong signal to the public that we are a rowdy group, she said. management has locked out the striking staff after the expiry of the two hour ultimatum information and communication minister samuel poghisio gave them on friday to return to work, or be sacked...

sources: narok farmers demo over fertiliser. nairobi star nairobi , february 29, 2012 wednesday, kiplang at kirui;
notes: farmers in narok county held a demonstration to push the state to release the subsidised fertiliser. hundreds of commuters including tourists visiting world famous maasai mara game reserve were stranded as the farmers demonstrated. the protesters blocked the busy narok mai mahiu highway for more than three hours, waving placards and twigs...the farmers protested against the fertiliser shortage that has hit the area. they fear the input will not arrive in time yet in two weeks time, the planting season will be over...koonyo said that when the agriculture assistant minister kareke mbiuki visited the farmers last month, he assured them the fertilisers will be given to them....he gave the government a seven day ultimatum to provide the farm inputs or else they will hold a series of demonstrations....

sources: idps clash with naivasha cops. nairobi star nairobi , february 29, 2012 wednesday, george murage;
notes: scores of idps holding a peaceful demonstration over their failed resettlement were injured after clashing with police in naivasha. the idps from wanaruona baraka and kihoto camps in gilgil had camped at the naivasha district hospital on their way to nairobi when the officers moved in. the more than 200 idps were ordered into police lorries and ferried back to their camps as others escaped. earlier the idps had staged a demonstration along the nairobi nakuru highway and were headed to nairobi to seek audience with the president over their suffering. but as darkness approached, they sought refuge at the hospital only for armed police officers to arrive and order them back to their camps...

protesteridentity: nurses, health workers, union of kenya civil servants
sources: 1 public hospital workers start strike today. nairobi star nairobi , march 1, 2012 thursday, ramadhan rajab; 2 health workers strike called off. nairobi star nairobi , march 6, 2012 tuesday, ramadhan rajab; 3 striking health staff sacked, says nyong o. nairobi star nairobi , march 7, 2012 wednesday, ramadhan rajab; 4 new nyanza hospital nurses return to work. nairobi star nairobi , march 14, 2012 wednesday, justus ochieng; 5 kenya: health workers end strike. the new york times, march 16, 2012 friday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; world briefing africa; pg. 5, by reuters;
notes: 1 over 60,000 nurses and health workers will start a nationwide strike today. the strike is set to paralyse operations in public hospitals in the country. union of kenya civil servants which is leading the industrial action said the strike will be marked with street protests. processions in nairobi are planned to start at the kenyatta national hospital through the ministry of medical services headquarters at afya house and end at parliament buildings... ; 2 officials of kenya health professionals society and the union of kenya civil servants are calling on all their members to resume duty. this comes after a section of the nurses, orderlies and health professionals pressed on with their nationwide strike yesterday even after a return to work deal was reached on sunday evening between the government and their officials. the workers who staged protests at uhuru park and afya house accused their officials of reaching a deal with the government without consulting them we are not convinced by the deal reached, the negotiations had no gains for us and we feel duped. for this reason, we will continue with the strike until all our grievances are met... ; 3 the striking health workers technically remain without their jobs this morning if the government s threat to sack them yesterday is anything to go by. the workers had been given until 2pm yesterday to resume duty or have the positions declared vacant. we are dismayed that after we reached an agreement with the workers leaders and the strike called off unconditionally, the workers have defied the deal with a section pressing on with the strike. i wish to emphasise all health workers should resume duty with immediate effect and not later than 2pm today yesterday . those who will not have reported will be deemed to have to have deserted duty and will be summarily dismissed without further reference to them, medical services minister anyang nyong o said...on monday, the nurses, orderlies and other health workers trashed the deal entered between their leaders and government to end four days shunning their working stations and continued with their protest marches at uhuru park. even after the minister ultimatum, the health workers stood their ground with reports of deserted public hospitals in meru, kisumu, nakuru and a section of them staging protests in nairobi. ; 4 on friday, a record 25,000 nurses who were on strike since march 1 to protest the government s failure to effect a promised salary increase that was agreed upon last year were sacked. the strike paralysed operations in public hospitals with some of the patients who were being turned away from the facilities reported to have died. ; 5 public health workers have ended a nearly two week strike over pay after reaching a deal with the government, which withdrew a threat to fire 25,000 members of the union, officials said on thursday. the protest, which left patients without medical treatment, was the latest in a string of strikes to grip kenya as soaring consumer prices have fanned widespread discontent. a spokesman for the union said the government promised to address the workers demand for pay raises in july.

sources: 1 garissa students injured in kcse results protest. nairobi star nairobi , march 7, 2012 wednesday, stephen astariko; 2 north eastern pc bans garissa town protests. nairobi star nairobi , march 9, 2012 friday, stephen astariko;
notes: 1 several students and police officers were injured in protests in garissa town over the recent massive cancellations of kcse exam results by knec over alleged malpractices. the students from garissa high, county high, nep girls, umul salam and other local schools took to the streets chanting slogans denouncing the government s mistreatment of people from north eastern region. they chanted somali war songs and lit bonfires on main streets in the usually busy commercial town using old tyres before destroying signboards, vehicles and offices of government ministries by pelting them with stones and other crude weapons. the troubled started after the peacefully protesting students who assembled at the local dc s office seeking audience with government officials were turned back by administration police manning the premises prompting the students to go on a violent rampage that took eight hours...police fired live ammunition in the air to and lobbed tear gas to disperse the rowdy students who had the backing of the residents who were equally angry after the cancellation of their children s exam results. at one time security personnel had to take into their heels after huge number of public onlookers was touched by the senseless beating of an administration police of subdued student... ; 2 public protests have been banned in garissa, north eastern pc james serian has announced. the announcement came in the wake of violent street protests in which students and police were injured last tuesday...the 30 students who were arrested during tuesday s demonstration have been released...

sources: administration police beat up kitui boda boda protesters. nairobi star nairobi , march 7, 2012 wednesday, musembi nzengu;
notes: a demonstration by boda boda operators in kitui town was violently dispersed by police officers in full riot gear yesterday afternoon. a number of operators were beaten up by ap officers, most who were trainees based in kitui for their practical lessons...about 200 protestors blocked the kitui mutomo road disrupting transport near wikililye trading centre about two and half kilometres from kitui town. senior police officer benson shikuku from kitui police station asked the protestors to withdraw from the road but they refused. consequently, the police dispersed the operators and arrested at least three of the organisation s leaders...however the protestors regrouped and staged a counter attack from a safe distance by throwing stones and other missiles at the officers. as the protesters had used their motorbikes to block the busy road, their representatives went to the kitui dc s office to seek audience with him alleged uncalled for arrests by police recruits who had been posted to kitui from training colleges for a three months practical session. the boda boda men also claimed the wanted the road block removed because it had been turned into a toll station where policemen collected sh. 50 daily from ant motorcyclist plying the route...

sources: kitengela boda boda riders protest colleague s murder. nairobi star nairobi , march 8, 2012 thursday, kurgat marindany;
notes: transport along the namanga nairobi highway was paralysed for close to five hours yesterday morning after more than 500 motorcycle riders blocked it with stones to protest insecurity in kitengela town in kajiado county. police watched as the boda boda cyclists, who were protesting the killing of one them, burnt tyres and placed huge stones to block the highway linking kenya and tanzania...yesterday, the police restrained themselves from firing in the air or even using tear gas to disburse the protestors. later in the afternoon, kiragu and the local do kirop were expected to meet with the leaders of the riders to address the insecurity in the town. however, the meeting was delay with the riders demanding comprehensive investigations before the body was removed. they also declined to meet kiragu and kirop at the local police station for fear of being intimidated over the riots...

sources: kikuyu residents protest bad roads, blame nguyai. nairobi star nairobi , march 10, 2012 saturday, njenga gicheha;
notes: second was kigumo over the poor condition of the mathioya muguga road before they stormed the constituency offices in kikuyu town. they said the mp has not been keen on road repairs and maintenance after the constituency was split into two. police had a hard time controlling the demonstrators who had barricaded the busy highway.

sources: kikuyu residents protest bad roads, blame nguyai. nairobi star nairobi , march 10, 2012 saturday, njenga gicheha;
notes: protest started at nderi market from where the residents trekked for more than one kilometre to the nairobi naivasha highway lighting bonfires on the way as they chanted slogans against the local government assistant minister?

sources: 200 protest over grabbing of malindi land. nairobi star nairobi , march 15, 2012 thursday, alphonce gari;
notes: more than 200 residents of gede in malindi district held a demonstration yesterday protesting an alleged grabbing of a public land by leaders and sold it private developers. the residents, who marched from gede stage to the chief s office, accused william baya thoya and former malindi mayor councillor mohamed menza of grabbing the land.

sources: dc cancels njenga s nakuru peace rally. nairobi star nairobi , march 18, 2012 sunday, irene wairimu;
notes: a weekend peace rally convened by former mungiki leader maina njenga in nakuru was canceled at the last minute by the provincial administration citing security reasons. nakuru dc kangethe thuku issued orders late friday stopping the meeting which was to be held at afraha stadium on saturday from 10am. attempts by maina and his co convener pastor mike brawan of metro church to go on with the meeting were thwarted when hundreds of regular and administration police officers in riot gear were deployed to the stadium. thousands of youth who had travelled for the rally from across the country were instead diverted to brawan s church in freehold estate where they proceeded to hold the rally. they condemned the government and the provincial administration for cancelling the meeting...although the meeting had been passed off as peace prayers, politics dominated the speeches with maina calling for a generational change in the next general elections...

sources: 30,000 kinango farmers protest jumbo invasion. nairobi star nairobi , march 19, 2012 monday, philip mbaji;
notes: over 30,000 farmers in kinango district have petitioned wildlife minister dr noah wekesa to rein in a rancher in the area for breaking the tsavo east national park fence letting elephants into their farms. the farmers also blamed the rancher on the current human wildlife conflict facing the residents of the semi arid region saying he had been overstocking the kenya meat commission ranch making him desperate to look for pasture from the park...

sources: alarm over security lapse at the port. nairobi star nairobi , march 21, 2012 wednesday, wesonga ochieng;
notes: more than 300 fishermen, who were demanding compensation, on monday managed to enter the facility with ease. fishermen from likoni, mtongwe and port reitz were protesting over kpa s failure to pay them as agreed in the compensation action plan drawn in 2008 after stopping to fish in the indian ocean to pave way for the dredging of the likoni channels and port reitz...

protesteridentity: residents, muslims for human rights, taita taveta human rights watch
sources: voi residents protest attacks by herders. nairobi star nairobi , march 21, 2012 wednesday, raphael mwadime;
notes: transport along the nairobi mombasa highway was yesterday paralysed for several hours when taita residents blocked the road. they were protesting recent attacks on local residents at shelemba area by illegal herders from north eastern province...led by several civil society groups from the region including muslims for human rights and taita taveta human rights watch, the protesters closed the highway at caltex junction near voi town for more than two hours forcing voi dc raphael lemaletian to address them in the middle of the highway. the protests caused a heavy traffic jam along the busy highway as vehicles were barred from moving along the road as the protesters petitioned internal security minister george saitoti to take action. lemaletian and taita ocpd nathaniel aseneka had a difficult time calming the protesters who were demanding an explanation as to why the illegal herders have not moved...the dc promised that the government will flush out the illegal herders on monday if they will not have moved out by then...after the dc addressed the protesters, they opened the road and marched in the voi streets singing and dancing anti camel songs as they demanded the herders flushed out of the area...the peaceful demonstrations ended at the moi stadium in voi where the organizers of the protests addressed a public rally.

sources: 3,000 idps hold kisii demonstration. nairobi star nairobi , march 24, 2012 saturday, benson nyagesiba;
notes: more than 3,000 integrated idps from kisii and nyamira counties yesterday held a peaceful demonstration over the government s delay to pay them their compensation. the idps demonstration came after word went round that special programmes minister esther murugi, who was expected to visit them, cancelled her trip. the angry idps converged at the gusii stadium before matching to eastern nyanza regional commissioner lydia muriuki s office where they sought for an explanation.

sources: magarini protest over misuse of cdf kitty. nairobi star nairobi , march 24, 2012 saturday, alphonce gari;
notes: more than 300 residents of magarini yesterday demonstrated against misuse of sh65 million cdf in the past five years. the residents allege that mp amason kingi and the cdf committee were misappropriating funds meant for projects. chanting anti kingi slogans, the residents marched from mamburui junction to the magarini cdf offices to petition the committee to be transparent.

sources: police defy raila as slum in nairobi brought down. nairobi star nairobi , march 27, 2012 tuesday, mosoku geoffrey;
notes: government officers yesterday defied prime minister raila odinga and proceeded to demolish nairobi s mitumba slums...by last evening, the squatters were still waiting for the pm to address their plight as hundreds of them staged a demonstration along mombasa road.

sources: 1 mombasa riots deepen concern about religious tensions in kenya; religious divides appear to be deepening as riots continued in mombasa, kenya, in the wake of a cleric s killing. extremist group al shabab called on muslims to take matters into their own hands. . the christian science monitor, august 28, 2012 tuesday, fredrick nzwili correspondent; 2 the washington post, august 28, 2012 tuesday, a section; pg. a08; 3 muslims fear police murder squads after string of deaths; kenya. the times london , november 3, 2012 saturday, news; pg. 33, jerome starkey;
notes: 1 kenya s coastal city of mombasa has witnessed a new wave violence for the second day running, as muslim youths protested the killing of sheikh aboud rogo...on tuesday, a grenade attack on a police truck near a church left one policeman and one civilian dead and another 13 officers injured. the policemen were racing to save the church, which was being set ablaze by the youths, an eyewitness said. many protesters charge that the police had a hand in what they are calling an extrajudicial killing of the cleric, who was awaiting trial on terrorism related charges...earlier in the day, the youths, who were armed with stones, had used burning tires to barricade roads. looting of shops and homes has also been reported, with the police arresting 12 protesters. the clashes were more intense in the muslim neighborhood of majengo, where the cleric frequently preached his fiery sermons... ; 3 his death sparked three days of riots and the government launched a commission of inquiry. so far, no one has been arrested...

sources: 1 kenyan lawmakers raise taxes, take a hefty bonus; protests broke out in kenya after lawmakers voted to give themselves a 25 million bonus in a bill that raises taxes. the christian science monitor, october 9, 2012 tuesday, mike pflanz correspondent; 2 kenya: parliament bonus is vetoed. the new york times, october 10, 2012 wednesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; world briefing africa; pg. 6, by reuters;
notes: 1 demonstrators marched through nairobi s capital today to protest another attempt by kenyan lawmakers to boost their pay, after it emerged the officials had voted for a 25 million bonus for when they leave office. ; 2 president mwai kibaki vetoed huge bonuses that parliament members quietly awarded themselves last week after protests and public outcry over the action.

sources: 1 kenyan court upholds election of candidate facing charges in the hague. the new york times, march 31, 2013 sunday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 6, by jeffrey gettleman; 2 spurts of violence punctuate calm after kenyan vote is upheld. the new york times, april 1, 2013 monday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 4, by jeffrey gettleman;
notes: 1 kenya s supreme court on saturday unanimously upheld the election victory of uhuru kenyatta as the country s president, dismissing allegations that the vote had been rigged. but almost immediately, protests erupted in some opposition strongholds, with stone throwing mobs squaring off against kalashnikov toting police officers...on saturday night, after the supreme court upheld mr. kenyatta s victory, protests broke out in several slum areas of nairobi, the capital, and in kisumu, mr. odinga s ethnic stronghold. his supporters tried to barricade roads with burning tires, but police officers shot in the air and chased them away. it s such a sad moment, said christine ololo atieno, a shoe seller in kisumu. we saw evidence that the election wasn t free or fair. now we feel our rights have been sacrificed for the happiness of others. ... ; 2 in kisumu, mr. odinga s ethnic stronghold, young men battled with police officers on saturday night and at least two protesters were shot to death...

sources: 1 protests in nairobi over mps pay. daily nation kenya , may 14, 2013 tuesday, nation reporter 1; 2 protesters take battle to parliament. daily nation kenya , may 14, 2013 tuesday, peter obuya potieno ke.nationmedia.com 1; 3 world digest: may 14, 2013. the washington post, may 15, 2013 wednesday, a section; pg. a10;
notes: 1 civil society activists have held a demonstration to protest mps demand for a salary increase. the occupy parliament protestors blocked the main entrance of the national assembly waving placards condemning mps greed. they also let loose pigs outside parliament s gate. some mps made their way to parliament but refused to address the crowd. police, who had kept vigil during the demonstration, fired teargas at the protestors. the demonstration comes a day after the salaries and remuneration commission src ruled out a pay increase for mps... ; 2 police also added military water cannon to their anti riot arsenal. again, the pigs were also hit by the water cannons. the police arrested about 18 protesters for creating disturbance of the peace... ; 3 police fired tear gas and water cannons and swung their batons to disperse the approximately 250 protesters, who gathered in what was dubbed the occupy parliament protest...

sources: 1 live: fresh protest over mps pay. daily nation kenya , june 11, 2013 tuesday, aggrey mutambo 1; 2 pigs return to haunt mps in pay protest. daily nation kenya , june 11, 2013 tuesday, aggrey mutambo amutambo ke.nationmedia.com 1;
notes: 1 a group of activists is holding demonstrations in nairobi to protest mps push to increase their pay. the lobby groups have pitched tent outside parliament waving placards denouncing the legislators move to enhance their remuneration from the sh532,500 set by the salaries and remuneration commission. the mps are agitating for a pay raise that will see them earn sh851,000. the demonstrators assembled at freedom corner in uhuru park, donned in t shirts denouncing any attempts by legislators to increase their pay before marching to parliament. this is the second time the activists under the banner of the national civil society congress are protesting at what they call mps greed at the expense of the taxpayer. the protestors carried banners castigating mps for their greed and insensitivity to the plight of kenyans... ; 2 then they hurled bottles of blood mixed with dung to the parliament compound, targeting mps cars before spraying the road with it. it splashed onto activists, the pig , journalists and the police alike. it smelt like a war trench. the activists were denouncing the legislators move to increase their salary from the sh532,500 set by the salaries and remuneration commission to sh851,000. this is besides calling for the dissolution of this commission...this time, though, there was no clobbering and the police accompanied the band as it moved along the highway to parliament, without hurling tear gas. although central police boss patrick oduma had promised that there would be no tear gas, the nation later learnt there was a strategy adopted by the activists to keep tear gas at bay just in case police changed their mind...

protesteridentity: kenya union of post primary teachers kuppet
sources: 1 mps cut tourism budget to pay teachers. daily nation kenya , june 18, 2013 tuesday,nation team newsdesk ke.nationmedia.com 1; 2 kra wants inherited debts settled. daily nation kenya , june 22, 2013 saturday, yvonne kawira ymurori ke.nationmedia.com 1;
notes: 1 parliament tuesday moved to forestall a crisis in schools and universities after mps allocated sh4 billion in additional funds to the education ministry to cater for staff salaries and allowances...tuesday, the strike called by the kenya union of post primary teachers kuppet started in protest against failure to allocate funds for members allowances. the kenya national union of teachers knut has also said it was preparing its members for a strike and warned that its members would not support the laptop for public primary schools project unless they are paid the allowances agreed on in 1997 under the daniel moi regime... ; 2 nairobi is currently struggling to raise money to pay employees who went on strike last wednesday to protest the salary delay. nairobi county inherited more than sh53 billion in debt from the nairobi city council which the county says is straining the county government s finances...

sources: activists stage protest march over food taxes. daily nation kenya , june 25, 2013 tuesday, aggrey mutambo amutambo ke.nationmedia.com 1;
notes: more than 10 civil society groups tuesday marched to the treasury offices in nairobi to demand a stop by the government of plans to tax basic commodities. as part of their three day mass action against plans to introduce value added tax on maize flour, milk, bread, sanitary towels and fertiliser, the coalition for constitution implementation cci presented a 10 point petition to the treasury, demanding that the government explains how it will ensure food remains affordable...the activists later marched to harambee avenue where the treasury offices are situated. although they were largely peaceful, police refused to let in all the protesters, insisting that only four of them would be allowed in...

protesteridentity: kenya national union of teachers knut
sources: 1 learning disrupted as teachers strike begins. daily nation kenya , june 25, 2013 tuesday, nation team 1; 2 parents protest as strike bites. daily nation kenya , june 26, 2013 wednesday, nation team newsdesk ke.nationmedia.com 1; 3 state to hire 10,000 teachers as kaimenyi insists strike is illegal. daily nation kenya , june 28, 2013 friday, nation reporter 1; 4 otieno: uhuruto s first 100 days has been a mess. daily nation kenya , july 6, 2013 saturday, otieno otieno 1; 5 parents ask knut chiefs to end strike. daily nation kenya , july 11, 2013 thursday, nation team 1;
notes: 1 learning has been disrupted in schools countrywide as the teachers strike started tuesday. in nairobi, teachers stayed away from classrooms as the strike called by the kenya national union of teachers knut took effect...on monday, knut dismissed calls for dialogue by president kenyatta. in a meeting convened by its national executive council, the union declared a national strike to demand the government honours a 1997 pay agreement. ; 3 the government will employ 10,000 teachers next month to alleviate staff shortage in schools, education cabinet secretary jacob kaimenyi said on friday. in what amounted to a climb down from an earlier position, the government has also agreed to promote teachers due for upgrade. these are among the concessions the government is making in response to demands by the kenya national union of teachers knut , which called out its members on strike this week to protest over non payment of allowances amounting to sh47 billion. also, the union had demanded recruitment of teachers and promotion of those due for upgrade... ; 4 a teachers strike has paralysed learning in schools in the past two weeks... ; 5 parents in kiambu on thursday demonstrated against the kenya national union of teachers knut for refusing to call off the strike now in its 19th day...

sources: groups stage demo against unga taxes. daily nation kenya , july 2, 2013 tuesday, aggrey mutambo amutambo ke.nationmedia.com and john ngirachu jngirachu ke.nationmedia.com 1;
notes: lobby groups tuesday staged protests to oppose the value added tax bill as the government formally tabled the proposed law in the national assembly. they marched from freedom corner in uhuru park, carrying leftover ugali and maize flour while asking treasury cabinet secretary henry rotich to resign...led by the consumer federation of kenya cofek , they also presented a petition to the treasury and national assembly calling for mr rotich to quit his job for playing hide and seek over the contents of the alien bill.

protesteridentity: mps from coalition for reforms and democracy cord
sources: 1 cord mps walk out of house in bills row. daily nation kenya , july 23, 2013 tuesday, john ngirachu jngirachu ke.nationmedia.com 1 2 cord protests lack of respect in house. daily nation kenya , july 24, 2013 wednesday,nation reporter 1;
notes: mps from the cord coalition last evening staged a walk out from the national assembly to protest what they termed a tendency by the jubilee side to use their tyranny of numbers to push through whatever they want. the mps walked out en masse, frustrating a motion by the constitutional implementation oversight committee cioc to extend the deadline to implement bills on the freedom of the media. it requires two thirds of the house membership to pass the motion since it touches on the constitution, which means the 216 jubilee members alone cannot meet the constitutional threshold...

sources: 400 riot police officers deployed after chaotic protests by hawkers. daily nation kenya , september 17, 2013 tuesday, nation correspondent 1;
notes: hundreds of riot police officers were today deployed to the city centre following violent protests by hawkers. hundreds of riot police officers were yesterday deployed to the city centre following violent protests by hawkers. the heavy police presence, comprising about 400 officers, follows chaotic protests on monday in which pedestrians and traders were robbed, vehicles vandalised and a policeman attacked and his motorcycle set on fire...the hawkers were protesting a directive by the nairobi county government to evict them from the city centre. the demonstration turned rowdy and police responded by lobbing teargas. five people were arrested and mr kibui said they will be charged with robbery...

sources: nandi women protest sale of liquour to learners. daily nation kenya , september 19, 2013 thursday, tom matoke 1;
