notes: hundreds of women in nandi county thursday staged demonstrations against the sale of alcoholic drinks to school children. the women also accused some chiefs and some police officers of not taking action against some traders who sold spirits in kiosk which are near schools and violating government rules by allowing cheap brews to be sold to students. the demonstrators who carried twigs and placards walked over 15 km to seek audience with the nandi county commissioner and nandi county governor charged that relatives to some of the chiefs and their assistants and some police officers owned kiosks which sold the wines and spirits to school children. the women demanded stern action be taken against complacent police officers and chiefs adding it was illegal for school children to go bars and kiosks where wines and spirits are sold and drinking at their education s expense. the angry women who stormed the nandi county commissioner offices were addressed by deputy commissioner john mbugua and administration police commander patrick maundu. they asked interior minister to take action against officers and chiefs who allowed cheap drinks which had not been passed kenya bureau of standard to ruin students...tempers had flared earlier after the administration police officers locked gates to the county commissioner office forcing the member of kapsabet ward fred kipkemboi and ap boss mr. maundu to intervene after women threatened to strip naked and express their wrath at officers whom they accused of frustrating their peaceful demonstration...the protestors were then allowed into the county commission compound where mr maundu promised that a crackdown would be held to net all those who sold spirits and cheap drinks to under age children adding some of the traders got information from officers whenever crackdown was organized. he also denied allegations some of his officers owned kiosks in local markets which sold children alcohol.

sources: 1 riots hit mombasa after cleric shot dead. daily nation kenya , october 4, 2013 friday, galgalo bocha 1; 2 riots in kenya after killing of muslim cleric. the new york times, october 5, 2013 saturday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 9, by josh kron; nicholas kulish contributed reporting.;
notes: 1 sporadic violence that swept through parts of mombasa county friday as youths engaged police in running battles to protest against the killing of a muslim preacher on thursday night...friday, public transport was brought to a halt in parts of mombasa as the youths, who accused anti terrorism police of being behind the killing of the cleric, unleashed violence on innocent civilians...riots spread within mombasa island with one group of youths smashing windows and forcing businesses to close in the general post office area. police battled the stone throwing youths... ; 2 followers of sheik ismail said they believed that the killings were political, and that his death was the beginning of the feared retribution against muslims after the mall siege. the police are killing people while saying it is a war against terrorism; this is a war against islam, said another radical cleric, abubaker shariff ahmed, according to agence france presse.

sources: riots in mombasa after arrest of cleric. daily nation kenya , october 25, 2013 friday, kna 1;
notes: police in mombasa are holding a muslim cleric from tanzania who entered the country a few days ago under unclear circumstances. the arrest of the outspoken preacher last evening at musa mosque in majengo suburbs triggered violent confrontations between supporters of the preacher and the police. there were pitched battles between police and hundreds of the preacher s supporters shortly after friday prayers. five protesters were arrested and will be arraigned in court on monday, according to mr adoli...

protesteridentity: women, africaunite, the coalition on violence against women covaw , african women s communication and development network femnet , youth deliver and avaaz
sources: 1 radical protest for rape victim liz kicks off. daily nation kenya , october 31, 2013 thursday, digital news 1; 2 cabinet secretary joins campaigners in demanding swift justice for liz. daily nation kenya , october 31, 2013 thursday, njeri rugene 1; 3 mutunga wants busia rape suspects arrested. daily nation kenya , november 2, 2013 saturday, njeri rugene 1;
notes: 1 the protest, seeking justice for the busia rape victim is dubbed keep off our panties . a demonstration in protest of police handling of rape cases is currently underway. the nairobi protest march dubbed keep off our panties, is organised by africaunite, an umbrella body of organisations fighting to end violence against women, the coalition on violence against women covaw , african women s communication and development network femnet , youth deliver and avaaz... ; 2 chanting justiceforliz, the protesters who included women from across africa attending a conference in nairobi marched through the city s streets to the jogoo house office of inspector general of police david kimaiyo. however, mr kimaiyo did not meet them but they were addressed by mr william thwere okello, a senior assistant commission of police and the chief of staff at the inspector general s office... i want to assure the public that we are a reformed service and whoever will be found culpable officers will be dealt with. i am here on behalf of the inspector general and i am mandated to tell the public that the case and any other similar cases will be dealt with the seriousness they deserve and according to the law mr okello, told the activists outside jogoo house... ; 3 on thursday, more than 300 protestors demanding justice for the 16 year old marched through the streets of nairobi to the offices inspector general of police where they handed out the petition...

sources: kiambu youths demonstrate against bill. daily nation kenya , october 31, 2013 thursday, anne macharia 1;
notes: youth in limuru barricaded the nairobi nakuru highway thursday protesting against the draft kiambu county financial bill, 2013...the bill proposes to charge bizarre fees for county cemeteries, church crusades and slaughtering of animals among other charges proposed by the county government...the protests were largely peaceful except for a few stone throwing incidents and tear gas used to disperse the demonstrators. limuru police, led by area ocpd michael mbaluku were forced to disperse the crowd after they barricaded the main highway paralysing transport...

location: Nairobi, Mombasa, Nyeri, Nakuru, Kilifi, Mount Kenya region and Eldoret
sources: 1 journalists hold street protests over media law. daily nation kenya , december 3, 2013 tuesday, lucas barasa 1; 2 journalists protest against oppressive media law. daily nation kenya , december 3, 2013 tuesday, nation team 1;
notes: 1 journalists tuesday held protests in nairobi and other major towns over changes in the media bill that curtail press freedom. the protests were also held in mombasa, nyeri, nakuru and eldoret. in nairobi, the journalists converged outside nation centre before starting the procession on kimathi street, moi avenue and later joined harambee avenue before presenting their memorandum to the office of the president, deputy president, attorney general and to parliament. the media personnel bound their mouth and camera lenses with tapes... ; 2 hundreds of journalists from different media houses including nation media group, standard media group, radio africa, royal media, public relations firms and journalism students from different universities and colleges poured into the streets of nairobi to agitate for their rights...

protesteridentity: health workers, kenya national union of nurses knun , kenya medical practitioners, pharmacists and dentist union kmpdu , kenya health professionals union khpu
sources: 1 court stops strike by health workers. daily nation kenya , december 11, 2013 wednesday, maureen kakah 1; 2 knh recalls staff from leave as strike bites. daily nation kenya , december 12, 2013 thursday; 3 industrial court extends order stopping health workers strike. daily nation kenya , december 16, 2013 monday, maureen kakah 1; 4 court dismisses case against health devolution. daily nation kenya , december 18, 2013 wednesday, nation reporter 1;
notes: 1 the high court has stopped the ongoing health workers strike. this follows an application by health cabinet secretary james macharia on wednesday seeking to stop the strike which began at midnight on monday. the health cabinet secretary through state counsel paul ojwang argued that the ongoing strike contravenes the constitution and section 78 of the labour relations act which prohibits those involved in the delivery of essential services from participating in a strike. health workers are protesting against plans to transfer the channelling of their salaries to the county government as they prefer it to remain under the control of the national government...they allege that they are unhappy with the manner in which the transition authority and the governors council are handling devolution of health services. the government agreed on tuesday to delay the transfer of health services to counties for two months in a statement which was not signed by the health workers union officials... ; 2 the country s largest referral hospital has recalled staff on leave to mitigate the effects of the ongoing national strike by their colleagues in public health facilities. kenyatta national hospital acting chief executive simeon monda told the nation that though their staff is not on strike, they are overwhelmed by the increasing numbers of patients coming from the public hospitals that have since closed... ; 3 the industrial court on monday extended orders stopping the strike by health workers. justice james rika extended the orders to stop the strike and further directed three health workers unions and their officials to respond or give their opposing views within seven days...

sources: students riot over power blackout. daily nation kenya , december 10, 2013 tuesday, nation reporter 1;
notes: university of nairobi students on tuesday night took to the streets reportedly in protest over a power blackout. the students disrupted traffic on university way, uhuru highway and state house road as they stoned vehicles. a nation reporter who visited uhuru highway said police used tear gas in an attempt to disperse the rioting students.

sources: police seek motive in murder of court clerk and family. daily nation kenya , december 14, 2013 saturday, george munene 1;
notes: when news of the murders spread, hundreds of traders staged a protest march and attempted to storm kerugoya police station. they closed their shops and trekked to the station demanding the arrest and prosecution of the killers. tension mounted as riot police cocked their guns as the traders protested. however, they were repulsed when they attempted to force their into the station to seek audience with the county police commander. the traders also demanded transfer of all the officers accusing them of sleeping on the job. they idle around as our people continued being slaughtered by well organised gangsters and they should be moved to other areas, one of the traders said...

sources: controversial media bill signed into law. daily nation kenya , december 16, 2013 monday,nation reporter 1;
notes: the media bills were passed in a chaotic sitting chaired by temporary speaker rachel shebesh nairobi county, tna . the majority of mps in the chamber were drawn from the jubilee coalition. their cord counterparts left en masse in protest after several failed attempts to postpone debate on the matter.

sources: machakos protesting lorry drivers block mombasa road. daily nation kenya , december 18, 2013 wednesday, ponciano odongo 1;
notes: protesting sand miners and transporters tuesday blocked mombasa road at mlolongo town for close to five hours. sand miners and transporters tuesday blocked mombasa road at mlolongo town for close to five hours paralysing movement on the busy road. the sand traders and transporters were protesting over a monday night incident in which police from athi river allegedly shot at a lorry and arrested its driver. the traffic snarl up extended for more than 6 kilometres on both sides of the road causing difficulty in movement... we are being mistreated by police who are always asking for bribes. it is wrong and we ask the government to act, said joseph kioko one of the protesting traders. kioko alleged that the police had badly harmed one of them after he refused to part with the bribe demanded by the officers at the mto wa mawe road block...machakos senator johnstone muthama who was also caught up in the long traffic jam had to talk to the protestors to stop their demonstrations. mr muthama assured the protesters that he would address the matter....

sources: nairobi street boys protest over killing. daily nation kenya , december 26, 2013 thursday, otiato guguyu 1;
notes: protests hit nairobi s boxing day calm after police gunned down a street boy at globe cinema roundabout thursday. street boys took to the streets thursday after a police officer allegedly gunned down one of their colleagues at globe cinema roundabout. the street children broke the boxing day calm in nairobi as they engaged the police in running battles. they stoned police vehicles, claiming that the police were targeting them. we are helpless that is why they are killing us, claimed samuel macharia...

sources: mosque rioters charged. the times london . february 4, 2014 tuesday : 64 words.;
notes: nairobi more than a hundred people arrested during riots were charged as members of al shabaab, the somalia based insurgent group linked to al qaeda. the violence, in which three people died, broke out on sunday after a police raid on a kenyan mosque. four of those charged were not in court because they were receiving medical treatment. police fired at rioters and used teargas. afp

sources: gettleman, by jeffrey. opposition rallies ranks in kenya, peacefully. the new york times. july 8, 2014 tuesday : 438 words.;
notes: hey started streaming in at dawn on monday, thousands of people, the crowd slowly building as the sun rose. men in rubber swamp boots. men in thin suits. men in raggedy trousers and ripped t shirts, men from the slums. monday was supposed to be their day, the day of the long awaited saba saba rally called by kenya s opposition to commemorate the birth of the multiparty democracy movement 24 years ago. while many people in nairobi had been scared for weeks that this rally would set off riots, and much of the city had cleared out on monday and was crawling with riot police officers, opposition supporters were hoping to hear a new plan for the future.

sources: angered by assault, women take to nairobi streets in miniskirt protest ; in an unusually public protest, 1,000 women danced, sang, and chanted my dress my choice and shame, shame on monday after a woman was stripped naked earlier this month by men who disapproved of her clothing.. the christian science monitor. november 17, 2014 monday : 619 words.;
notes: kenyan women on monday demonstrated against increasing violence against girls and women, as the country begins to confront an attack in downtown nairobi where a woman wearing a miniskirt was stripped naked. some 1,000 women in miniskirts, tights, and trousers danced, sang, and chanted my dress my choice and shame, shame in solidarity with the victim, who is now being celebrated as the woman in red.

sources: athi river workers protest delayed pay. the star nairobi , january 07, 2015;
notes: hundreds of athi river subcounty workers yesterday protested over failure by the machakos county government to pay them. the workers, who earn between sh8,000 and sh12,000 monthly, said they had not been paid for three months a spot check showed the workers strewed garbage on roads, open air markets, shop verandas and within estates, affecting transport and business for the better part of the day. the workers faulted the county government for delaying their wages and making them operate under poor terms and conditions...

sources: goons block medics protest in murang a. the star nairobi , january 07, 2015, alice waithera;
notes: goons disrupted a peaceful demonstration by health workers in murang a county yesterday. they locked the protesting medics in ihura stadium and prohibited them from marching the town. the health workers who were employed under the economic stimulus programme have been on strike for three weeks. they are demanding to be hired on permanent basis. the medics gathered at the stadium after they were allegedly locked out of their work stations by people they said were hired goons. the healthworkers later broke out of the stadium and tried to enter into murang a town but the goons blocked the road using boda bodas. one of the men who was blocking the road was injured after he was hit in the face with a stone during the standoff with the medics. the goons left after police officers arrived at the scene and the medics went back to stadium...

sources: farmers, police clash over naivasha farm. the star nairobi , january 08, 2015, george murage;
notes: a farmers society invaded part of ndabibi farm in naivasha and battled riot police. ndibithi farmers society accused a tycoon of illegally taking the land in 1964 during president moi s administration. during the tuesday confrontation, 10 farmers were arrested and five tractors confiscated by riot police. more than 300 farmers engaged police in running battles. police used teargas to disperse the farmers working on the land, most of whom are elderly. speaking on the phone, naivasha subcounty commissioner abraham kemboi said the farmers invaded private land. he said the farmers ignored a court order...

sources: laikipia locals in demo over increased crime. the star nairobi , january 09, 2015, wanjohi gakio;
notes: mass protests yesterday continued for a second day running at ol moran, laikipia north, over rising insecurity. hundreds of residents blocked the ol moran survey road, demanding deployment of the kenya defence forces. carrying twigs and placards, they said action should be taken against illegal herders from baringo and pokot counties. the residents said the herders are contributing to increased livestock theft...laikipia women s representative jane apollos and sossian ward representative jacob edung, who joined the demonstrators, called on the government to act swiftly...

sources: kuppet to flush out teachers in class. the star nairobi , january 10, 2015, reuben olita;
notes: the kenya union of post primary education teachers issued the threats on thursday as they staged demonstrations in busia town to push the national government to succumb to their demands...the teachers marched from fitness centre offices to tsc county director beatrice lukalo s office, where they handed their memorandum. the protesting teachers denounced the government pay package of sh9.3 billion offered to them by tsc and said they will continue with their strike until a 50 to 60 per cent increase is agreed on. executive secretary paul namukuru said the teachers demanded their right of basic salary increase and not car loans and mortgages...

sources: kitui traders protest high taxes. the star nairobi , january 09, 2015, musembi nzengu;
notes: traders at kalundu market yesterday held a demonstration in kitui town, protesting against high market charges by the county government. the traders, led by rogers wambua, marched to the county headquarters and demanded to be addressed by governor julius malombe. malombe, was, however, not available and traders were addressed by county secretary musyoka nyamai. nyamai said the county government does not have any interest to exploit the traders. he said if taxes were adjusted slightly, it was only meant to improve services to them and the entire kitui population. nyamai said his office will not allow overtaxation of traders. he said action will be taken against any revenue officers who overcharge traders. wambua said the traders are unhappy that the new market charges that took effect this week have been increased more than two folds. he said it is unfair and exploitive. wambua said the county government should revert to the old rates.

sources: fishermen clash with police at disputed naivasha plot. the star nairobi , january 09, 2015, george murage;
notes: fishermen yesterday clashed with riot police at the moi south lake road in naivasha. the officers were manning a closed corridor leading to lake naivasha and karagita beach. beach officials obtained an injunction from the high court stopping the closure of the corridor. tens of officers drawn from the ap, regular police and prison s department camped at the scene...

sources: kapsowar teachers blame cs kaimenyi for failure . the star nairobi , january 13, 2015, stephen rutto;
notes: teachers held a demonstration in kapsowar town on friday demanding the resignation of education cabinet secretary jacob kaimenyi. knut branch secretary john cheberi said kaimenyi has failed to resolve the standoff between teachers and the tsc over pay increase. cheberi said kaimenyi has not embraced dialogue while dealing with the teachers. the teachers marched to marakwet west subcounty education ministry offices. they said they will not be cowed by threats to sack them if they continue with the strike.

sources: senator slams rutto lone ranger politics. the star nairobi , january 15, 2015, felix kipkemoi;
notes: on monday, bomet central mp ronald tonui and his bomet east counterpart benard bett joined residents in a protest march in the town. they accused rutto of pushing for the construction of a university on his home turf. the two mps said the university should be built in bomet town. rutto wants the university put up in sigor town...

sources: three shot as youths fight cop in laikipia. the star nairobi , january 14, 2015, wanjohi gakio;
notes: lenontari said the officer and the youth wrestled before lenasilale s friends, leshaki lekitasharan, 17 and john lenasilale, 27, and a mentally unsound woman attempted to intervene. the woman was slapped several times and chased away while the officer cocked up his gun and shot the three men in the legs, he said. residents demonstrated against the incident in rumuruti town. they demanded the arrest and prosecution of the officer. mps mathew lempurkel laikipia north and sarah lekorere urp, nominated flew in from nairobi and mobilised witnesses to record statements with police. at least 300 residents volunteered to record statements over the shootings...

sources: 500 women support fgm. the star nairobi , january 17, 2015, kiplang at kirui;
notes: more than 500 women in trans mara west subcounty on thursday demonstrated in support of female genital mutilation. the women from enoosaen criticised the maendeleo ya wanawake chairperson hellen katim for her opposition to the practice. they said their uncircumcised girls are no longer wanted as wives. area police boss alfred muthua said the women should understand fgm is illegal and those involved will be punished.

sources: parents protest over sponsors row. the star nairobi , january 19, 2015, brian otieno;
notes: two groups clashed on saturday in protests against the withdrawal of sh60 million annual sponsorship for four schools in mtwapa. hundreds of teachers, students and parents of the mtwapa educational institute in kilifi took to the streets, accusing the county government of frustrating their sponsor. another group, of about 100 youths, however attempted to stop the demonstrators, saying the county government has already committed itself to sponsoring the institute. the youths were overpowered and the protestors marched to mtwapa police station to air their grievances...

sources: 1 governors mutua, kabogo and tunai face an anxious 2015. the star nairobi , january 20, 2015, felix olick; 2 digitise revenue collection to cut losses, kiambu told. the star nairobi , january 23, 2015, william mwangi;
notes: 1 in kiambu, thika town mp alice ng ang a and her kikuyu counterpart kimani ichung wa have threatened to initiate the recall of governor william kabogo. for two days over the weekend, violent protests rocked makongeni market in thika over high levies, leaving one person dead and several others injured. we are only giving him two months, warned nga ng a during the protest. we will soon come for your signatures and send him kabogo home. residents and a faction of leaders have vehemently opposed a controversial finance bill, whose implementation would see an increase in market charges, shop license fees and burial charges in government cemetries... ; 2 the kiambu government has been in the spotlight for imposing high taxes on farmers and traders. in the latest case, market traders at madaraka market in thika town staged a three day protest over increased levies. mps intervened and on saturday thika town mp alice ng ang a said she had called president uhuru kenyatta and he had ordered the market reopened...

sources: 1 police use teargas to disperse langata pupils fighting for grabbed playground. the star nairobi , january 19, 2015, nancy agutu; 2 five pupils injured, two activists arrested in lang ata playground protest. the star nairobi , january 19, 2015, nancy agutu; 3 no way to handle a demo that includes children editorial . the star nairobi , january 20, 2015; 4 defending greed with teargas opinion . the star nairobi , january 24, 2015, oduor ong wen;
notes: 1 anti riot police on monday lobbed tear gas canisters at lang ata primary school pupils and activists protesting against the grabbing of their playground. the pupils who had attempted to bring down the gate of the walled property withdrew but stayed at the site awaiting the outcome. part of the wall separating the school from weston hotel was demolished. the protest resulted in a traffic snarl up on lang ata road which was sealed off. school headteacher peter mugo said last week that the wall was constructed in four days starting december 9. he said he was shown documents approving its construction by city hall during a confrontation between the community and youths hired by the developer. the national land commission said last week that preliminary investigations revealed that the land belongs to the school. chairman muhammad swazuri said nlc will review all land ownership documents given to individuals to verify their authenticity. he said the commission and the nairobi government will ensure children access the playground when they report back. ; 2 five pupils were injured and two activists arrested in the protest against the grabbing of the lang ata primary school playground on monday morning. two journalists and a police officer were also injured in the incident. officials said the activists had no right to lead the protest which they said was illegal. lang ata ocpd elija mwangi said the protest was not the right approach to settling the land dispute. mwangi warned protesters against involving children saying those above the age of eight can be arrested. he refuted earlier reports that the police used tear gas to disperse the activists. the pupils waved signs terming the alleged grabbing of their playground terror against children . they also carried stones and attempted to bring down the property s gate. the activists, alongside the school s management, demolished the wall separating the school from weston hotel. the protest resulted in a traffic snarl up on lang ata road which was sealed off... ; 3 the sight of riot police baton charging and teargassing schoolchildren in nairobi disgusted many kenyans and other observers yesterday. the lang ata road primary school playground land grab culminated in pupils joining activists and politicians in protesting the erection of a perimeter wall around the field by a so called private developer... ; 4 a cellphone video one of many taken by a protestor, shows a group of people, the majority of whom are schoolchildren, marching with their hands up as they are blocked by hundreds of police in riot gear. amid cries of confusion, the protesters are charged and beaten down violently by an impenetrable wall of militarised force. the police left no doubt that they had come for war as they were armed with guns, ferocious dogs and tear gas canisters. loud cracks and ear shattering explosions, followed by smoke, pierce the air and shake the frame of the camera, as the cops fire tear gas, rubber bullets and flash grenades. scores of police continue to charge and assault the protesters with batons. many demonstrators are forced to turn and flee in panic. at the end of it, several people, including six pupils and two journalists, were seriously injured. the activists, teachers and pupils say that the demonstration got violent after police assaulted the protesters. firsthand accounts at independent and social media outlets largely confirm this view, painting a picture in stark contrast to mainstream reports of the protests being violent...

sources: students protest to have deputy principal moved. the star nairobi , january 27, 2015, rita damary;
notes: students of limuko secondary school in bahati constituency have demanded the transfer of deputy principal margaret warukira. more than 200 students went on strike yesterday, accusing warukira of high handedness. the students stormed out of their classrooms shortly after the morning assembly. they accused warukira of pushing for the transfer of principal dominic njenga to gain control of the school. the students said njenga s transfer to a school in lower subukia was instigated by warukira. warukira declined to speak to the press.

sources: five moi referral nurses arrested. the star nairobi , january 27, 2015, mathews ndanyi;
notes: riot police lobbed teargas canisters yesterday to disperse striking nurses at the moi teaching and referral hospital, eldoret town, and arrested five of them. the nurses blocked roads to demand the hospital management sign a collective bargaining agreement that increases their salaries and allowances, we will not negotiate or resume work until our demands are met. we also demand that our colleagues who were arrested should be released, said kennedy orangi, chairman of the nurses union...criticised the hospital management for calling in riot police to disperse nurses yet they were not violent or rowdy...

sources: 1 governor tunai condemns narok protests, says officers acted in self defence. the star nairobi , january 26, 2015, lydia matata; 2 one person killed, area ocpd injured in narok town clashes. the star nairobi , january 26, 2015, nancy agutu; 3 world digest: jan. 26, 2015. the washington post, january 27, 2015 tuesday, a section; pg. a09;
notes: 1 narok county governor samuel tunai has said that officers who opened fire on a crowd during a protest against his leadership in narok town on monday were acting in self defence. the governor condemned the incident in which one person was killed and several people among them, narok north ocpd paul leting, was injured...the scuffle and the resultant injuries were a product of police engaging in self defence when they were attacked by the irate mob. the narok governor said...tunai added that it is unacceptable that a set of leaders have taken take sadistic pleasure in inciting some residents of narok along partisan and private interests, fashioned along clan divisions on false claims of corruption against my administration. he termed the disputes in narok county as a contest of greed and clannism against transparency and a new leadership order... the protesters had taken to the streets of narok town demanding that tunai step down over corruption allegations. they demanded that the receive the petition in person but police shot in the air to disperse the crowd. the protesters gave the tunai 21 days to respond to allegations. the protest was led by senator stephen ole ntutu and mps moitalel ole kenta narok north , patrick ntutu narok west , johana ngeno emurua dikirr and korei ole lemein narok south . the leaders later presented the petition to county secretary seki ole lenku. monday s protests went on despite a directive from interior cs joseph nkaissery warning against the demonstrations... ; 2 one person has been confirmed dead while ten others have been seriously injured after protesters took to the streets of narok town to evict governor samuel tunai over corruption allegations. narok north ocpd paul letting was among the injured victims. the ocpd was rushed to the hospital with severe head injuries. according to eye witnesses,police officers tried to disperse the protesters from the town by lobbing tear gas. the police then opened fire at the protesters injuring several of them... ; 3 one person was killed andseveral wounded monday when kenyan police clashed with masais protesting a local governor whom they accuse of misappropriating tourism funds from the masai mara game reserve, an official said. police fired live rounds and tear gas as thousands of people from the masai ethnic group, clad in traditional red cloaks, marched to the governor s office in narok town, the administrative center of the sprawling masai mara park, witnesses said...

sources: 1 st catherine school parents march to ngilu s office over grabbing of playground. the star nairobi , january 28, 2015, patrick vidija; 2 ngilu backs south b school in land ownership row with private developer. the star nairobi , january 28, 2015, eugene okumu;
notes: 1 about 200 parents from st catherine primary school in south b, nairobi have marched to ardhi house to protest against the grabbing of the school s playground. the parents walked the 5kms to lands cs charity ngilu s office on wednesday, carrying placards with anti land grabbing messages. school representatives have been allowed to meet ngilu. the parents accused nemka commercial agency, a private development company, of the land grabbing. the company sued the school s management for constructing swings on the property which it says it owns. school sponsors led by catholic nun mary killeen however said city hall allocated the school seven acres of the land... ; 2 lands cabinet secretary charity ngilu has said her ministry will ensure st catherine primary school secures its disputed playground. ngilu said the school is the rightful owner of the land. i will dispatch a team of surveyors and physical planners to re establish the boundaries and we will issue the title to the school. i will instruct my officers to enjoin the ministry in the matter to ensure that the school secures its land, she said. she was addressing a group of about 200 parents that marched to her office in protest on wednesday morning...

sources: nairobi aviation college to take nmg to court over certificates of doom , 12 protesting students arrested. the star nairobi , february 02, 2015, nancy agutu and collins kweyu;
notes: the certificates of doom expose alleged that the school cleans and issues certificates to students without pre qualifications at a minimum cost of sh3,000. hundreds of students protested against the claims outside nation centre earlier in the day. at least 12 were arrested in the demo that saw them barricade kimathi street and beat journalists covering it. they also hurled stones at the building, breaking a window, and demanded an explanation for the unfair coverage. the police used tear gas to disperse them.

sources: 1 protestors in narok block roads after arrest of senator, four mps for incitement. the star nairobi , january 28, 2015, kiplang at kirui; 2 four injured in narok as mps freed on bond. the star nairobi , january 30, 2015, alphonce mung ahu and kiplang at kirui;
notes: 1 protestors in narok county blocked on wednesday night blocked roads in the area after senator stephen ole ntutu and four legislators were earlier arrested over demonstrations that occurred on monday. the protestors who were armed with sticks and arrows blocked the road in ololunga area and another in katagala for more than two hours over the arrests. they accused the government of victimizing narok residents by arresting their leaders and vowed to continue blocking the roads until the leaders were released. police had to fire tear gas at the protestors to disperse them. the officers are currently paroling the town and are escorting motorists, some of whom had their vehicles damaged by the protestors. narok senator ole ntutu and four area mps are currently being held at the muthaiga police station after they were arrested for leading protests against the leadership of governor samuel tumai. ntutu and mps moitalel ole kenta narok north , patrick ntutu narok west , johana ngeno emurua dikirr and korei ole lemein narok south , were arrested after they recorded statements at the cid headquarters over the incident. lawyer martin kamwaro who is acting for senator ole ntutu and the mps, told journalists outside the cid headquarters that the leaders are expected in court tomorrow where they will be charged with incitement to violence... ; 2 their release followed an application by director of public prosecutions keriako tobiko, who withdrew his earlier application to have them remanded for seven days to enable police to complete investigations. the dpp urged the court to release the five lawmakers on bond after he received information chaos had erupted in narok as residents demanded the legislators release. during the protests, four people, including a woman, were injured as the demonstrators engaged police in running battles. the woman fainted after police fired teargas. the three men sustained rubber bullet wounds. the residents blocked the busy bomet narok mai mahiu highway at narok town, olululunga, ntulele and katakala. the residents also blocked the narok ewaso nyiro road, which leads to the masai mara game reserve at ewaso nyiro trading centre and the narok nakuru road at tipis trading centre. hundreds of commuters, including tourists visiting the masai mara, were stranded in narok town, which was a no go zone. business operations were halted at narok town as the residents engaged police in running battles. police fired teargas to disperse the demonstrators, but the rowdy residents regrouped moments later. the residents, most of them armed with swords, spears and rungus, battled police for the better part of the day...

sources: wajir students protest over lack of teachers. the star nairobi , january 30, 2015, stephen astariko;
notes: hundreds of parents and students in wajir county yesterday protested against absense of teachers in schools. protestors in public primary and secondary schools carried placards and tree branches as they marched to the teachers service commission. finding no one to meet them, they marched to the county commissioner s office. commissioner fredrick shiswa addressed them. student mohamed abdi said classes have not begun, a month after schools reopened. he said non local teachers have not reported to work although non local civil servants, business people and casual labourers have resumed work. why should the teachers subject us to this situation?. we idle in classes from morning to evening while our colleagues from other parts of the county are busy in classes, said abdi, a form four student at wajir high school. he appealed to president uhuru kenyatta to ensure classes resume. shiswa said the government is talking with partners in education to solve the problem. he said security has been enhanced and urged teachers to resume duty...

sources: locals storm police station, eject nine lazy officers. the star nairobi , february 02, 2015, john nalianya;
notes: residents yesterday stormed mayanja police station in kanduyi constituency and ejected nine officers, accusing them of sleeping on the job. bungoma police boss kirinya limbitu and kanduyi mp wafula wamunyinyi s efforts to cool down the residents were futile. the residents were protesting against an incident where a gang held a village hostage on saturday night, robbing the residents and injuring four people. businessman shefu nyongesa lost money. it took the intervention of officers from bungoma police station to calm down the villagers.

sources: 1 jumbo crushes granny to death. the star nairobi , february 11, 2015, john kisu; 2 six elephants invade kajiado school. the star nairobi , february 11, 2015, kurgat marindany;
notes: 1 last week five stray elephants invade imbuko village in isara division of kajiado county and killed mpaa saitoti sapuru 40 years old while on his way from a local market. local maasai community blocked emali loitokitok road for two days in protest of the killings until local leaders addressed them. the animals also destroyed bananas and water melon farms. kenya wildlife service officers led by jeremiah rungut visited kikumini area and by yesterday they were still trying to drive away the wild animals back to the park... ; 2 last week, kws officers were forced to shoot dead an elephant in mashuuru after it killed a resident. the residents barricaded the emali loitokitok road for two days, demanding that the elephant be killed

protesteridentity: teachers, kenya national union of teachers
sources: northern region teachers protest against failed meeting with house committee. the star nairobi , february 03, 2015, patrick vidija and eugene okumu;
notes: a group of teachers from the northern region protested outside parliament on tuesday over a failed education committee meeting. the teachers left knut headquarters and marched to parliament when the meeting slated for 11.30am did not take place. kenya national union of teachers secretary general wilson sossion was to air their grievances at the meeting. the teachers stationed in wajir, mandera and garissa counties have been seeking intervention for their plight over insecurity. they told the government that they will return to work after their safety is guaranteed...

sources: city park market traders protest against burning of stalls. the star nairobi , february 06, 2015, nancy agutu;
notes: unclear who is responsible for gun shots. city park market traders hurled stones at road users and blocked limuru road in a protest against the burning of their stalls on friday. the traders burned tyres on the road and engaged the police in running battles. gun shots were heard in the area as the police lobbed tear gas canisters to disperse them. nairobi governor evans kidero sought dialogue with the traders over the matter but they refused to give him audience. the stalls might have been set on fire by city county officials so we do not need him to address us, one of them said. the traders said the thursday night attack on the market was aimed at sabotaging them. they said the ownership of the land the market sits is disputed, and demanded government compensation.

sources: nyeri butchers strike over increased fees. the star nairobi , february 07, 2015, wambugu kanyi;
notes: more than 200 butchers from othaya yesterday boycotted work and protested against the increment of regular charges levied by the county government. the new charges proposes that meat inspection per animal be charged sh200 instead of the normal sh100. meat transport permit per container will be charged sh300 instead of sh100. the traders stormed nyeri south commissioner s offices, demanding to know why the county government has inflated the fees...

sources: six elephants invade kajiado school. the star nairobi , february 11, 2015, kurgat marindany;
notes: the invasion comes only a day after more than 200 maasai women walked to governor david nkedianye s office to protest the invasion by elephants in their farms

sources: kabete demo over muchai. the star nairobi , february 11, 2015, george mugo;
notes: residents of kabete constituency yesterday held a demonstration at wangige trading centre over the pace of investigations into area mp george muchai s murder. carrying placards, more than 5,000 residents gave the government seven days to complete its probe into muchai s murder...

sources: man shot dead in makindu as kws rescues elephant stuck in shallow well. the star nairobi , february 12, 2015;
notes: a man was shot dead in makindu, makueni county, as residents tried to kill an elephant that had been trapped in a shallow well. the man was shot in a confrontation between the residents and kenya wildlife service rangers who had rescued the elephant. the residents tried to kill the jumbo after it was rescued by the rangers. the jumbo had been trapped in the ditch for hours. after being pulled out by the kws officers, the residents wanted to kill it and share the meat as it was still tired. the public later barricaded the mombasa nairobi highway to protest the killing. speaking on the phone, acting makueni county commissioner henry metto urged the residents to be calm...

sources: vc akenga dismisses claims on nepotism. the star nairobi , february 14, 2015, mathews ndanyi;
notes: the university of eldoret has dismissed claims of corruption and nepotism at the institution. on thursday, police used tear gas to disperse villagers and a senator who stormed the institution demanding the removal of vice chancellor teresia akenga. prof akenga said there have been no irregular employment at the institution based on nepotism...they said akenga hires outsiders at the institution yet more than 300 local people do not have jobs. akenga said the list of employees at the institution is open for inspection...

sources: squatters in lamu protest harassment by officers. the star nairobi , february 13, 2015, cheti praxides;
notes: squatters from lake amu and kiongwe town, mpeketoni, took to the streets yesterday to protest against alleged harassment by the kenya forest service. more than 500 squatters said kfs officers beat them up and set their homes and farms on fire to drive them out of the land...the squatters marched to the kfs offices in mpeketoni where they threatened to camp until the issue is resolved...

sources: burma market traders protest against alleged land grabbing by private auctioneer. the star nairobi , february 13, 2015, nancy agutu and partrick vidija;
notes: coded because the event was precipitated by legal battles & the police accompanied the land grab. traders of burma market, nairobi used flaming tyres to block jogoo road in a demo against alleged land grabbing on friday morning. the traders hurled stones at motorists preventing access to the road and causing a traffic snarl up. they engaged police in running battles as tear gas canisters were lobbed to disperse them. the traders, known as shauri moyo furniture makers, said an auctioneer closed the market claiming he owned the land. we were surprised at 5am when a private auctioneer, accompanied by police officers, came with ten lorries and carried off all our goods worth sh50 million saying the land belonged to him, one said...the traders said the five claimed they owe shsh960,000 and that they have fighting the issue in court for years...

protesteridentity: embu governor martin wambora s supporters
sources: embu governor wambora, mp mbarire supporters clash. the star nairobi , february 16, 2015, reuben githinji;
notes: embu governor martin wambora s supporters and those of runyenjes mp cecily mbarire clashed on saturday. wambora s supporters were demonstrating against the high court s decision to remove wambora from office last thursday. the demonstrators wore t shirts with wambora s portrait and waved placards saying mbarire had a hand in wambora s woes. the demonstrators had walked for about 100 metres on the runyenjes embu road when the pro mbarire group surrounded them. the two groups engaged in running battles before riot police intervened.

sources: mau evictees close camps and move to bomet town. the star nairobi , february 18, 2015, felix kipkemoi;
notes: mau forest evictees from two camps in konoin constituency have moved to bomet town to demand resettlement. the more than 700 evictees closed their camps on sunday night and walked for more than 70km. they arrived at the town yesterday morning, they accused the government of neglecting them in the squalid camps...county commissioner bernard leparmarai received their petition.

protesteridentity: university of eldoret students, uasin gishu senator isaac melly
sources: university of eldoret closed indefinitely after riots. the star nairobi , february 19, 2015, mathews ndanyi;
notes: the university of eldoret was on thursday closed indefinitely following riots by students demanding the removal of vice chancellor professor teresia akenga. a senate meeting resolved to shut down the college and students given half an hour to leave the university which has been hit by riots for the last three days. uasin gishu governor jackson mandago has demanded that the cabinet secretary for education, jacob kaimenyi, find a solution to the problems at the college...anti riot police were deployed to the institution as two separate groups of students, one supporting akenga and another calling for her removal, threatened to carry out fresh protests. senator isaac melly, who has been leading the protests against the vc, was among several people injured during the wednesday riots...

protesteridentity: university of eldoret students, uasin gishu senator isaac melly
sources: 1 university of eldoret students on the rampage, khalwale seeks answers on ejection of besieged vc over tribalism. the star nairobi , february 18, 2015, nancy agutu and mathews ndanyi; 2 senator injured in eldoret varsity riot. the star nairobi , february 19, 2015, stanley magut and jessica nyaboke;
notes: 1 university of eldoret students stormed their vice chancellor s office to forcefully eject her on wednesday afternoon. they want vc teresia akenga removed over allegations of corruption and nepotism. the students took to the streets led by uasin gishu senator isaac melly. melly claimed that akenga has been hiring staff from her tribesmen on permanent and pensionable terms, and overlooking other communities. the students hurled stones at anti riot police officers who lobbed tear gas canisters to disperse them...a group of mps from uasin gishu, nandi and elgeyo marakwet counties held a press conference over the matter amid the protest. the 17 mps, who met at parliament buildings, nairobi, said the institution s wrangles do not warrant violent demonstrations... while we acknowledge that there are grievances at the university, they do not warrant the reaction they have attracted, said ainabkoi mp samuel chepkonga... ; 2 uasin gishu senator isaac melly was yesterday beaten up by riot police during protests at university of eldoret...

sources: voi residents demand ward rep waweru s arrest over alleged sexual abuse. the star nairobi , february 19, 2015, raphael mwadime;
notes: hundreds of voi residents took to the streets on thursday in a protest for the arrest of marungu ward rep paul waweru over alleged sexual abuse. they accused waweru of touching a woman inappropriately on february 17, saying no action has been taken by the police. led by sagalla ward rep godwin kilele, the residents stormed voi police station chanting slogans against waweru...voi subcounty commissioner hamadi shivogo told the protesters that the matter is being investigated...

protesteridentity: university of eldoret students, uasin gishu senator isaac melly
sources: university of eldoret closed indefinitely after riots. the star nairobi , february 19, 2015, mathews ndanyi;
notes: the university of eldoret was on thursday closed indefinitely following riots by students demanding the removal of vice chancellor professor teresia akenga. a senate meeting resolved to shut down the college and students given half an hour to leave the university which has been hit by riots for the last three days. uasin gishu governor jackson mandago has demanded that the cabinet secretary for education, jacob kaimenyi, find a solution to the problems at the college...anti riot police were deployed to the institution as two separate groups of students, one supporting akenga and another calling for her removal, threatened to carry out fresh protests. senator isaac melly, who has been leading the protests against the vc, was among several people injured during the wednesday riots...

sources: student raped, killed at moi university. the star nairobi , february 23, 2015, mathews ndanyi;
notes: a third year student at moi university has been raped and killed at the institution, causing riots by angry students protesting over insecurity. the student, charity maina, was strangled by her attackers, who also tore off her clothes. the body was found near a matatu terminus located next to the gate of the main campus. rioting students burned down a police land rover that had gone to collect the body, which had been detained by students. the students had refused to release the body, which they wanted to transport to the morgue using a college bus. hundreds of anti riot police were deployed on the campus amid tension as angry students threatened to carry out more protests. we have been asking the police to provide adequate security for us but nothing has been done. we have had many incidents of insecurity yet police do not act, said student leader rolex riziki...angry students then set ablaze the land rover, forcing police to use tear gas to disperse them. uasin gishu county commissioner abdi hassan said security would be beefed up at the university...

sources: demo over tax stops business in kitui. the star nairobi , february 24, 2015, musembi nzengu;
notes: there was a total business shutdown in kitui town yesterday as hundreds of traders poured into the streets to protest high taxation. all businesses, except banks and a few restaurants, remained closed throughout the day as the impact of the protest sank. the peaceful demonstration was closely monitored by riot police, led by kitui police boss kennedy onsando. the nearly two kilometre procession started at the kalundu section of the town and ended up at governor julius malombe s offices. the chairman of one of the two rival kenya national chamber of commerce and industry kitui branch factions, wilson muema, presented a memorandum to the county secretary musyoka nyamai. although the demonstration was generally peaceful, there a time when a group joined by mwingi central mp joe mutambu tried to force their way into the governor s compound. onsando, however, agreed to let in representatives...muema and the co organiser of the protests, vanilla mwendwa, gave the county government seven days to recall the finance act 2014 that stipulated the contested levies. he said the traders will have nothing less than the degazettement of the act...

sources: 1 farmers demo against kingangop power project over lack of involvement. the star nairobi , february 23, 2015, george murage; 2 farmers block highway for four hours to protest kinangop wind project. the star nairobi , february 24, 2015, george murage; 3 kinangop wind project to go on, vows government. the star nairobi , february 26, 2015, george murage;
notes: coded because farmers blame mp. 1 farmers blocked nairobi nakuru highway at flyover trading centre in a protest against the kinangop wind park project on monday. they lit a bonfire and burned a house and a car allegedly belonging to supporters of the project... ; 2 farmers yesterday blocked the nairobi naivasha highway for more than four hours protesting against the controversial kinangop 61mw wind project. the farmers said the sh13 billion project will not go on. during the protest, one house and a vehicle were burnt down as the farmers engaged police in running battles. there were unconfirmed reports that two women and a boy were rushed to a private hospital with bullet wounds. the kinangop farmers blamed their mp stephen kinyanjui and the investor for the impasse. they said hundreds of families will be displaced if the project continues. troubled began in the morning when surveyors erected wind turbines in farms. the farmers blocked the njabini magumu road before moving to the nairobi naivasha highway which was blocked for over two hours with no police in sight... ; 3 on monday and tuesday more than 1,000 farmers opposed to the project held demonstration in nyandarua. one person was killed, scores injured and property worth thousands of shillings destroyed...

sources: 1 farmer shot dead, several injured in day two of kinangop wind park protests. the star nairobi , february 24, 2015; 2 kinangop wind project to go on, vows government. the star nairobi , february 26, 2015, george murage;
notes: 2nd day of protest; related to previous entry on feb 23 in nyandarua. 1 one person died and several others were injured after farmers took to the streets for the second day on tuesday protesting the wind power project in kinangop, nyandarua county. according to eye witnesses, the deceased was hit by a bullet when police shot in the air to disperse the irate farmers. the police officers resorted to using live bullets to disperse us after they realised that the tear gas canisters were not working, he said..meanwhile, two suspects were arrested for burning a car and a house during the protests, which paralysed transport along the naivasha nairobi highway on monday evening... ; 2 on monday and tuesday more than 1,000 farmers opposed to the project held demonstration in nyandarua. one person was killed, scores injured and property worth thousands of shillings destroyed...

sources: mumias boda boda fee sparks demos. the star nairobi , february 27, 2015, shaban makokha;
notes: boda boda operators in mumias town yesterday held the second day of demonstrations against increased levies. the kakamega government increased levies on the riders from sh20 to sh30 last month. the boda boda riders protested on the kakamega bungoma road, waving twigs and chanting, oparanya must go! the charges were increased only here in mumias, boda boda self help group chairman abubakar shikunyi told the press. our colleagues in other towns are paying sh20, whereas we are forced by county officers to pay sh30 daily. the boda boda riders destroyed temporary county stalls used for collecting levies from psc vehicles and motorcycle riders on the road at ekero and mumias town. they forced the county government revenue collectors to flee for their safety, accusing some of the county askaris of harassment...riot police officers moved with the protesting boda boda riders without interrupting the demonstrations...

sources: kisii traders protest landgrab of market. the star nairobi , february 26, 2015, benson nyagesiba;
notes: more than 200 businesspeople in kisii town yesterday staged a demonstration to protest against grabbing of land where they operate. the traders protested against a decision by the county government to move them from outside the kisii municipal market. the traders, led by their chairman elijah ombongi, said they will not move from the place nor will they allow anybody to take the land...

sources: loitoktok women take babies to protest against water shortage. the star nairobi , february 26, 2015, kurgat marindany;
notes: hundreds of women blocked loitokitok road in a demo against prolonged water shortage on thursday. transport between loitokitok and ilasit towns was paralysed for about seven hours as the women defied police orders to end the protest. the officers did not use teargas to disperse them as some were carrying babies. they refused to listen to the female officers sent to talk to them and demanded audience with a senior county government official...

sources: mumias boda boda fee sparks demos. the star nairobi , february 27, 2015, shaban makokha;
notes: 2nd day of previous protest. boda boda operators in mumias town yesterday held the second day of demonstrations against increased levies. the kakamega government increased levies on the riders from sh20 to sh30 last month. the boda boda riders protested on the kakamega bungoma road, waving twigs and chanting, oparanya must go! the charges were increased only here in mumias, boda boda self help group chairman abubakar shikunyi told the press. our colleagues in other towns are paying sh20, whereas we are forced by county officers to pay sh30 daily. the boda boda riders destroyed temporary county stalls used for collecting levies from psc vehicles and motorcycle riders on the road at ekero and mumias town. they forced the county government revenue collectors to flee for their safety, accusing some of the county askaris of harassment...riot police officers moved with the protesting boda boda riders without interrupting the demonstrations...

sources: activists dump tvs, chicken outside ca in protest against switch off. the star nairobi , february 27, 2015, rhoda odhiambo and nancy agutu;
notes: activists dumped old tv sets and chicken outside ca offices on waiyaki way, nairobi in a demo against the switch off on friday. the national civil society congress claimed the signals were turned off after ca director general francis wangusi and information cs fred matiang i ate chicken . led by coordinator john wamagata, the protesters demanded matiang i and wangusi s resignations. we are calling on president uhuru kenyatta to sack wangusi for mishandling the digital migration process, one of them said. ncsc further demanded that wangusi reveal the owner of the pan african network group. the protesters said they support the digital migration but want the process to be transparent. they said the migration should not be rushed noting that there is ample time before the june 17 deadline...security officers were deployed to the area to prevent riots...

sources: ojaamong will be re elected, says speaker. the star nairobi , march 03, 2015, gilbert ochieng;
notes: more than 400 butchers in nyeri county yesterday held demonstrations against the increase in tax charged by the county government. waving twigs and placards, the traders staged a march in nyeri town and stormed the governor s office. they are against the 200 per cent tax increase by the nyeri county revenue administration act, 2014...the protesting butchers blocked all roads leading to the governor s office. they stormed town hall where deputy governor samuel wamathai told them only the county assembly can amend the law...similar protests were held in karatina town. last saturday, mweiga and othaya slaughterhouse operators downed tools protesting the same. the new charges proposes that meat inspection per animal will be charged sh200 instead of the normal sh100.

sources: students want new principal. the star nairobi , march 06, 2015, stephen rutto;
notes: students of chebara boys secondary school, marakwet west, held a demonstration on wednesday, demanding the removal of principal gideon okonyene. the 450 students walked for 25 kilometres from the school to the subcounty education office in kapsowar. they accused okonyone of mismanaging the school.

sources: residents demand repair on isinya kiserian road. the star nairobi , march 06, 2015, kurgat marindany;
notes: people living on the isinya kiserian road on wednesday clashed with police. they were demonstrating against the poor state of the road. the residents said the road has not been repaired for 10 years despite the government claiming to have allocated money each financial year. they demanded to be addressed by kajiado governor david nkedianye, senator peter mositet, mps moses ole sakuda kajiado north and peris tobiko kajiado east .

sources: 1 mumias east mp left with broken finger after farmers protest turns chaotic. the star nairobi , march 06, 2015, shaban makokha; 2 get mumias on its feet governor. the star nairobi , march 06, 2015, hilton otenyo; 3 youth leader, mca arrested. the star nairobi , march 07, 2015, shaban makokha;
notes: 1 mumias east member of parliament benjamin washiali finger was broken when a demonstration by sugar cane farmers turned chaotic. the demonstration began their protest peacefully with a march from shianda to mumias east through mumias town and stopping at the area deputy county commissioner s office to present a petition. the farmers were joined by washiali and his bumula counterpart boniface otsiula , kakamega county odm chairman david malala, county governor s political adviser justin mutobera and county odm secretary paul posho. malala, mutobera and posho addressed farmers at oketch park near the mumias sugar company main entrance. washiali and otsiula on the other hand led a second team to present their memorandum to county commissioner francis komeni. odm national youth leader rashid mohammed and mayoni ward mca libinus oduor joined the team at the komeni s office where they accused organizers of the demonstration of fronting their own selfish interests. efforts by washiali to present the memorandum to the area county commissioner were curtailed by mohammed and oduor who demanded to know the contents of the memorandum. at one stage, mohammed snatched the memorandum from washiali and threw it at the crowd to read its contents. washiali engaged the two in a fight. chaos soon followed as the protestors also began fighting. police were forced to use teargas to disperse the rowdy crow. washiali was left with a bruised left hand and a broken finger following in the melee. ; 2 kakamega governor wycliffe oparanya has said sugarcane farming has impoverished residents. oparanya said the sugar industry has been politicised and farmers are the most affected...oparanya launched distribution of subsidised fertilizer at bukura market on wednesday. he said he does not support planned demonstrations to push the national government to give money to rescue the company. ; 3 odm national youth leader rashid mohammed and mayoni mca libinus oduor were arrested on thursday afternoon, following a farmers protest to demand the arrest of mumias sugar company former managers. the demonstrations were organised by farmers and some politicians from the mumias sugarcane zone. bumula mp boniface otsiula joined his mumias east counterpart david malala kakamega odm chairman , county governor s political adviser justin mutobera and county odm secretary paul posho to lead the farmers in the demonstration. washiali and otsiula led the protests from shianda through mumias town to mayoni shopping centre, where they held a rally. before washiali presented a memorandum to deputy county commissioner francis komen, rashid demanded to know the contents of the petition, claiming it was authored by a few individuals. he said it does not represent the real issues affecting cane farmers. rashid snatched the document and threw it to the farmers. a fight erupted and police dispersed the crowd using teargas.

sources: schools demo over results. the star nairobi , march 11, 2015, sharon chepchirchir;
notes: elgeyo marakwet four secondary schools staged demonstrations to protest poor management as a cause for low academic performance. koitilial and chebara school students in marakwet west subcounty marched to the education office in kapsowar on saturday. their counterparts in lelboinet and st mary s kitany schools marched to the county headquarters in iten on monday. speaking at her office, county education director sabina aroni said: we are committed to providing quality and equitable education to all children in this county and if there were factors hindering attainment of this objective we are going to address them.

sources: police lynch nyeri man on family coffee farm. the star nairobi , march 10, 2015, wambugu kanyi;
notes: residents of mukurweini, nyeri, are calling for justice over the extrajudicial killing of a 30 year old mason. the residents on sunday held a protest march, waving twigs and chanting anti police slogans, after king ori kanyi was found dead with bullet wounds in the family s coffee plantation. residents tried to block police from retrieving the body, demanding to be addressed by area police boss beatrice kimoning. the locals stormed the mukurweini subcounty hospital mortuary and removed the body, before medics calmed them down. they then marched to the mukurweini police station demanding the arrest of three police officers...he said the officers broke into king ori s house and took him away. after a few minutes, we heard gunshots in our coffee plantation, maina said. king ori was shot in the back less than 2km from the police station. joseph macharia said one of the officers told me to my face that they will kill my son for being tough headed . he said king ori was in a bar brawl with one of the officers three weeks ago. the three officers came to my home armed and drunk, he said. this is extrajudicial killing and we want justice. kimoning said police are investigating the matter and promised to bring the three officers to book.

sources: schools demo over results. the star nairobi , march 11, 2015, sharon chepchirchir;
notes: elgeyo marakwet four secondary schools staged demonstrations to protest poor management as a cause for low academic performance. koitilial and chebara school students in marakwet west subcounty marched to the education office in kapsowar on saturday. their counterparts in lelboinet and st mary s kitany schools marched to the county headquarters in iten on monday. speaking at her office, county education director sabina aroni said: we are committed to providing quality and equitable education to all children in this county and if there were factors hindering attainment of this objective we are going to address them.

sources: kanduyi traders protest against eviction order. the star nairobi , march 13, 2015, john nalianya;
notes: traders in kanduyi market, bungoma, protested on wednesday against an eviction notice. the traders blocked the malaba eldoret road, saying they will not move. this is our only source of livelihood and evicting us without giving us another place is unfair, said mary nasike, a trader. police later dispersed the traders. trade executive laurian kholikho told the star on the phone the bungoma government will not reverse its decision...

sources: mourners storm akaranga s office with empty coffins after mortuary closure. the star nairobi , march 13, 2015, joseph jamenya;
notes: mourners carried empty coffins in a joint demo with nurses in mbale town after they were barred from collecting bodies following a strike. about 13 families realised the nurses were on strike on thursday, when they saw them carrying placards reading haki yetu ...the mourners joined the nurses in a march to vihiga governor moses akaranga s office. they forced their way into the county offices and demanded audience with akaranga. his chief officer, andrew ondego, addressed the protesters and ordered the immediate release of the bodies. the nurses however returned to the mortuary ahead of the mourners and barricaded its entrance. officer from mbale police station dispersed the crowds...

sources: mandera mca accuses nkoyo of laxity in war on terror. the star nairobi , may 06, 2015;
notes: exact date is unclear. in march, residents held peaceful demonstrations demanding nkoyo s removal, claiming he was incompetent. the residents were led by 20 mcas

sources: 1 taveta squatters on hunger strike over land injustices, arrest of activists. the star nairobi , march 18, 2015, raphael mwadime; 2 taveta squatters fight land injustice. the star nairobi , march 19, 2015, raphael mwadime;
notes: 1 hundreds of taveta squatters went on hunger strike on tuesday, in protest against alleged land injustices by the area s government officers. the hunger strike began with a demonstration from taveta sisal area to the subcounty commissioner s office where they spent the night. the squatters complained that many of them were not allocated portions of 15,000 acres of land the government bought to settle them...the squatters further demanded the immediate release of the subcounty s land rights activists arrested and charged last week... ; 2 hundreds of squatters in taita taveta are on a hunger strike to protest land injustices by government officers. the squatters want the immediate release of land rights activists from taveta who were arrested two weeks ago and charged at the voi law courts. the hunger strike began on tuesday with a protest march from taveta sisal area to the town...

sources: parents, pupils oppose privatising school. the star nairobi , march 19, 2015, maurice alal;
notes: parents and pupils of thessalia primary school on the kisumu and kericho border are opposed to privatising the school. more than 350 pupils held demonstrations on tuesday. the parents say an administrator of thessalia mission clement oguta has turned part of the primary school into a private secondary school. they urged president uhuru kenyatta and education cabinet secretary jacob kaimenyi to intervene. parents said oguta did not consult the community.

sources: wamunyu says no to sand harvesting. the star nairobi , march 24, 2015, andrew mbuva;
notes: residents of wamunyu market demonstrated on the machakos kitui road on saturday. they said about 30 lorries ferry sand from athi river every night. the protesters blocked the road with stones, causing a traffic snarl up. hundreds of youth engaged the police in running battles, forcing the officers to teargas and disperse them. youth leader shadrack mutuku said their continued complaints to the authorities and the county government always landed on deaf years. he said too much scooping may weaken the athi river bridge s foundation. some of those doing this business are well connected in the county government, mutuku said.

sources: 1 malindi county government backs down on taxes after traders demo. the star nairobi , march 26, 2015, alphonce gari; 2 haki africa accuses cops of shooting woman. the star nairobi , march 31, 2015, alphonce gari;
notes: 1 the kilifi government yesterday agreed to reduce the taxes. an elderly woman was killed on monday during a demonstration of thousands of traders demonstrated against the increased rates. police have denied killing the woman, saying they did not use live bullet to disperse the demonstrators. governor amason kingi intervened to stop the demo and promised the the traders the county finance act will be amended to reduce the levies... ; 2 a human rights organisation wants the commanders of police units who led the operation to disperse traders during demonstration in malindi last monday to be suspended. an elderly woman was killed. haki africa said the senior officials should be suspended pending investigations as they were responsible for the use of live bullets, one of which killed mbodze makupe...

sources: demo on school land grabbing. the star nairobi , march 25, 2015, rita damary;
notes: nairobi road primary school parents want the government to stop the grabbing of a section of the school s land. more than 300 parents held a peaceful demonstration at the school on monday. they urged the government to revoke the titles of nine plots already issued to individuals.

sources: release of two murder suspects in sabatia sparks violent protests. the star nairobi , march 25, 2015, joseph jamenya;
notes: residents of sabatia constituency on monday burned two shops and a house over the release on bond of two murder suspects. the hundreds of villagers from vokoli also blocked eldoret chavakali road for hours and injured one police officer. they were protesting against the release on sunday of joyce imungu and emily muhonja. the two had been arrested on friday in connection with the death of edith jadenya, 46...on monday morning, police were forced to shoot in the air to disperse the villagers, who wanted to lynch muhonja chaos erupted when police were called to rescue muhonja from the crowd...

sources: mourners dump body at station in nyeri. the star nairobi , march 27, 2015, wambugu kanyi;
notes: a man shot dead by police was buried yesterday in mukurweini township after a battle between the cops and residents. king ori kanyi, 33, had a misunderstanding with policemen at a local pub. on march 7, two officers came for him at his house and shot him dead in the family coffee farm at night. yesterday morning, 500 mourners stormed the mukurweini police station and dumped a coffin in the compound. mourners camped outside the police station, demanding that the officers who killed king ori take the body for burial 500m away. mukurweini politician dick wathika arrived at the scene after a one hour stand off...police fired in the air to disperse the crowd but the mourners pelted officers with stones. one officer was seriously injured in the melee with gunshots renting the air...police later found themselves on the receiving end when they threw teargas unto the mourners who were leaving station only for the teargas to turn against them...

sources: sexual violence is also a form of corruption, activists tell uhuru. the star nairobi , march 31, 2015, lydia matata;
notes: unclear if the previous protest on thursday should be coded, no indication of size. activists under the banner okoa dada kenya on tuesday marched from freedom corner in nairobi to parliament building calling on the government to deal with the rise in sexual violence in the country. the march follows a similar protest by activists and members of the civil society on thursday. in a statement read on behalf of the group by activist diana okello, okoa dada said rape cases have dominated recent news reports saying that mind sets need to change now to assure women and girls of their safety... president uhuru kenyatta, this is also corruption, the group added. okoa dada kenya further appealed to the judiciary to handle rape cases seriously and empathize with survivors...the group also called on women mps to take action against sexual violence...

sources: traders defy tax rise in kabete town. the star nairobi , april 02, 2015, george mugo;
notes: more than 5,000 kikuyu and kabete constituency traders have pledged not to pay increased fees. many staged a peaceful protest yesterday against the controversial kiambu finance bill, which raised licence fees. they said governor william kabogo is not within the law to change fees for different licenses by word of mouth...

sources: university students protest against garissa killings, present petition to president. the star nairobi , april 07, 2015;
notes: kenyan university students marched in the capital on tuesday to demand more security from the government after gunmen killed nearly 150 people at a campus in the eastern town of garissa last week on tuesday, hundreds of students from different universities walked through the streets in the city singing and shouting, and some headed to the office of the president where they presented a petition.

sources: workers demo over 2012 deal. the star nairobi , april 09, 2015, rita damary;
notes: more than 100 kenya medical training college workers have downed their tools to demand implementation of collective bargaining agreement signed in 2012. on tuesday, the workers staged a peaceful demonstration outside kmtc nakuru campus paralysing operations in the institution...

sources: kisii traders told not to politicise finance act. the star nairobi , april 13, 2015, benson nyagesiba;
notes: exact date is unclear. kisii governor james ongwae has warned residents against politicising the provisions in the county s finance act. last week, a group of people marched through the town streets protesting against increased license fees. ongwae asked those aggrieved to follow the right procedures to have their issue addressed.

sources: thika traders protest over hiked taxes. the star nairobi , april 17, 2015, john kamau;
