notes: three kiambu mps on wednesday led hundreds of traders in thika town to protest against increased taxes by the county government. led by kiambu mps alice ng ang a thika town , jude njomo kiambu town and kimani ichung wa kikuyu , the traders demanded the resignation of governor william kabogo. they had gone to present a memorandum of amendments in his office but kabogo was in kiambu launching an e system...

sources: 1 nandi road blocked in boda boda protest. the star nairobi , april 20, 2015, barry salil1; 2 machakos boda boda operators in demo. the star nairobi , april 20, 2015, andrew mbuva;
notes: 1 thousands of travellers were yesterday left stranded after the eldoret kisumu highway was barricaded by boda boda operators. the operators in mosoriot, nandi county, lit a bonfire to protest against a police crackdown. thirty motorcycles were seized and 20 people arrested during the crackdown. among those arrested included aic pastor dickson leting, whose motorcycle was impounded outside a hotel. he was arrested for protesting after his motorcycle was loaded onto a waiting lorry. for nine hours, the highway remained a no go zone as residents joined the protest and threatened to burn vehicles that defied their orders to stop. former mp mark too negotiated with the traffic police to release the boda boda operators and their motorcycles, which had been taken to kapsabet police headquarters. ; 2 officers lobbed teargas canisters when the operators marched to the machakos police station to demand the release of colleagues arrested during the demonstration.

sources: nyeri traders in demo over abattoir bid. the star nairobi , april 28, 2015, wambugu kanyi;
notes: a group of meat traders and slaughterhouse workers in mukurwe ini, nyeri, have accused the county government of perpetrating corruption and nepotism in the rehabilitation of the county abattoir. the more than 100 traders held a demonstration in sunday ion gakindu town over the delay in rehabilitating the slaughterhouse. they said the slaughterhouse, which was closed down by public health officers three years ago, is yet to be rehabilitated because of an unprofessional and flawed tendering process...

sources: mandera referral hospital closed after demo over salaries, six arrested. the star nairobi , may 06, 2015, star correspondent;
notes: mandera county referral hospital has been closed following a health workers strike for higher salaries. more than 459 health workers chanted haki yetu along streets and waved placards with their demands in a demonstration on monday afternoon. they want their salaries increased from sh58,000 in group h to sh65,000 in group k...six kenya national union of nurses officials were arrested for allegedly inciting the health workers to strike. they spent monday night in jail after they were denied bail following an alleged call from a county government official, but were released on tuesday morning.

protesteridentity: residents, kenya national union of teachers
sources: hundreds protest wave of crime in marigat. the star nairobi , may 05, 2015, joseph kangogo;
notes: business was brought to a standstill in marigat town on monday after hundred of residents demonstrates over insecurity in baringo county. the residents want the government to find a lasting solution to the perennial insecurity taking a toll on the county s development since 2002. they pointed an accusing finger at president uhuru kenyatta, his deputy president william ruto, and interior cabinet secretary joseph nkaissery for doing little to arrest the problem...led by the kenya national union of teachers baringo branch executive secretary charles kamuren, the residents said over 38,000 students are out of school this term due to insecurity. the demonstrators matched through the streets the town carrying placards with the writings; government we want to go back home. over 183 people have been killed in baringo county. we are being finished by cattle rustlers. president obama come and safe kenya. ...

sources: machakos tuk tuk drivers protest demand for bribes. the star nairobi , may 06, 2015;
notes: tuk tuk operators and taxi drivers yesterday protested against harassment by machakos county officers. led by their chairman, joseph mutisya, the motorists who operate in machakos town and its environs blocked sections of the town as they marched to the machakos police station, demanding fair treatment. speaking to the press, mutisya said the mistreatment has been escalating. i have been receiving complaints from the operators that the county officers are harassing them demanding money yet we pay tax just like other businesspeople, he said.

sources: nyali mp slams joho over failed meeting. the star nairobi , may 08, 2015, brian otieno;
notes: governor hassan joho showed disrespect when he sent county executives to meet nyali mp hezron awiti, the legislator said yesterday. awiti went to joho s office in kizingo on wednesday to discuss revenue collection, education and health in his constituency. however, joho sent chief of staff idris abdulrahman and county executives francis thoya lands and tendai mtana education . i couldn t table my constituents grievances for i felt it was disrespectful for the governor to delegate his duties, awiti told the star yesterday. the mp, who was accompanied by mcas mohamed ndanda and jabess oduor and hundreds of his supporters, stormed out of the meeting in protest. he led a peaceful demonstration, marching from joho s offices to furaha plaza on nkrumah road. however, thoya, tendai and abdulrahman said awiti s letter was clear that he wanted to meet the county executives...

sources: resident shot in utange evictions. the star nairobi , may 11, 2015, brian otieno;
notes: a youth is admitted at the coast general hospital after he was shot on saturday evening during a forced eviction in utange village, kisauni. ronal baya was shot in the leg after residents of utange resisted evictions. more protests were witnessed yesterday morning as hundreds of residents demanded justice. residents said baya was shot as he tried to run away from the police who he thought were thugs. the residents blocked utange road and lit bonfires as they chanted anti oppression songs. kisauni police boss richard ngatia could not be reached for comment as calls to his phone did not go through...

sources: muturi should stop thinking for us, say makueni protesting women. the star nairobi , may 14, 2015;
notes: women in makueni county on tuesday held a peaceful demonstration to oppose a bill on the implementation of the two thirds gender rule. among them were county women s representative rose museo, kibwezi east mp jessica mbalu and deputy governor adelina mwau. there was a huge traffic snarl up on the road towards the county headquarters in wote town. the more than 50 women accused national assembly speaker justin muturi of giving his views on the matter yet he is the ceo of the house . they said he should be neutral. we want muturi to stop thinking for us. we all have equal rights and you should actually respect the constitution, period, a placard read. mwau held a meeting with the group at kusyombunguo resort. those present said they support the kenya women parliamentarians. mwau said the proposal to implement the gender rule progressively should be put on hold.

sources: doyo seeks answers on three missing men. the star nairobi , may 14, 2015, hussein salesa;
notes: more than 2,000 people in garba tulla subcounty yesterday protested against the alleged kidnapping of three people by the kenya wildlife service rangers. they were backed by isiolo governor godana doyo and isiolo south mp abdulah banticha who yesterday said they have asked the government to investigate. residents said adan ismael, halake kalicha and godana guyo went missing two days ago. they had been tracked and abducted by the rangers along duse bibi kinna road residents said...

protesteridentity: gusii institute of technology students, youth
sources: 1 gusii institute students clash with police in demo over death of two classmates. the star nairobi , may 15, 2015, nancy agutu and kna; 2 politicians behind kisii riots lobby. the star nairobi , may 18, 2015, angwenyi gichana;
notes: 1 seven people were injured in a clash between the police and students of gusii institute of technology who were protesting the death of two of their classmates. the two were hit by a lorry allegedly being driven by a police officer at daraja moja area along kisii keroka highway on thursday night. it is said that the officer was driving the vehicle to a kisii police station after seizing it from a driver flouting traffic rules at kegati area. the demonstrators denied the police access to the scene where the two bodies lay under electricity poles, said kisii county police commander simeon kiragu. they burned the lorry and used some of the poles to block the road, and hurled stones at motorists paralysing transport, kiragu said. they torched eight vehicles at a nearby police station, he said, adding that police patrols have been intensified. kiragu said two police officers sustained injuries as the students engaged them in running battles. the other casualties were three students and two members of the public, he said... ; 2 two pedestrians said to be employees of the institute were hit by a lorry transporting electricity poles last thursday evening. the driver was a traffic police officer. students from the institute started rioting and were joined by youths. eight cars were set ablaze and a petrol station vandalised on friday...

sources: manda demo nipped in the bud by police. the star nairobi , may 18, 2015, cheti praxides;
notes: anti riot police in lamu on sunday morning dispersed a demonstration against governor issa timamy s move to revoke land ownership in the manda area. security has been beefed up following the demo threats

sources: one killed, 11 injured as isiolo residents clash with kws rangers. the star nairobi , may 18, 2015, hussein salesa;
notes: one person was killed and 11 others sustained bullet wounds when kenya wildlife service rangers and residents in isiolo clashed at kinna adjacent to meru national park on monday. hundreds of residents took to the street protesting against the disappearance of the three people last week, accusing the kws of kidnapping them. the residents marched to the meru national park and allegedly set a fire at the park. however locals claimed that it was kws who set the park on fire...isiolo county commissioner wanyama musiambo confirmed the incident and warned that action will be taken against those behind the shooting. isiolo governor godana doyo said he regretted that the peaceful protest turned violent. he asked the national government to investigate and arrest the officers behind the shooting...locals staged demonstrations and blocked the roads leading to meru and garba tulla demanding kws vacate the meru national park. they asked president uhuru kenyatta to intervene and relocate the park to avoid further conflict.

sources: naivasha residents protest. the star nairobi , may 28, 2015, george murage;
notes: transport on moi south lake road in naivasha was paralysed for more than three hours as residents protested the closure of a public corridor leading to lake naivasha. the more than 400 residents blocked the road using boulders and light fires to protest the closure demanded justice. they were dispersed by the anti riot police from nakuru. landing beach association chair david kilo said the closure has led to job losses for the fish traders. kilo said the land supports many families. he said a private developer claiming ownership of the land is using senior government officers to oppress them...

sources: 1 scores injured, bus torched in protests over closure of lake naivasha corridor. the star nairobi , may 28, 2015, george murage; 2 two shot in naivasha row. the star nairobi , may 29, 2015, george murage;
notes: second day of protests that began on may 27. 1 a bus belonging to a flower farm was set on fire and scores injured after protests over the closure of the corridor leading to lake naivasha entered its second day. residents of karagita estate, naivasha engaged police in running battles on thursday. hundreds of flower farm workers, international tourists and motorists were caught up in the demonstration that left scores nursing various injuries. national land commission chair mohammed swazuri, who toured the closed corridor promised that the issue would be resolved in one week...the sentiments were echoed by hellsgate mca jonathan warothe who challenged the governor to take charge and direct that the corridor be opened up. the emotional mca said that tens of people had been injured during the two day riots and hundreds of others left homeless. the clashes which started on wednesday erupted after police acting on a court orders closed down the corridor which leads to karagita landing beach. the move angered hundreds of residents in karagita estate who rely on the lake for fishing. the residents on a rampage blocking the busy moi south lake road and stoning motorists. later in the day, hired goons razed down all structures on the landing beach fueling the demonstrators anger. they reacted by damaging property belonging nearby flower farm. ; 2 a flower farm bus was torched and scores of people left nursing bullets wounds as the public corridor closure naivasha protests entered day two...

sources: laikipia north residents plant shrubs on bad road in protest. the star nairobi , june 04, 2015, kings waweru;
notes: hundreds of residents of ngenia village in laikipia north constituency yesterday demonstrated over poor state of roads in the area. they planted vegetation on the kwa makara umande road, accusing area member of parliament mathew lempurkel and the county government of neglecting them...they urged the mp to consider repairing the road by putting murram so that transport can be eased...

sources: mikindani road workers protest over pay delay. the star nairobi , june 10, 2015, ernest cornel;
notes: youth employed to repair roads at jomvu in mikindani, mombasa county, held a protest march on monday over delayed pay. each of them wants to be paid sh8,400 in arrears. the workers said they were forced to strike after their efforts to reach their mp badi twalib to listen to their complaints hit a snag...

sources: subukia shops closed for the lack of toilets. the star nairobi , june 26, 2015, rita damary;
notes: the nakuru government on wednesday closed down 50 businesses at kabatini trading centre in subukia due to lack of pit latrines. the public health office issued a notice on tuesday warning that should the business owners fail to comply with the notice, they risk being prosecuted for violating the public health act. the notice was copied to the area ocs, subcounty ap commander and the divisional public health officer. on wednesday, the business owners held a protest march in the town and accused the county government of double standards as they have already paid for single business permits. the nakuru government is to blame for failing to provide public toilets, said john munyiri who operates an electronics shop...

sources: 1 activist boniface mwangi arrested and beaten for filming a protest. the star nairobi , july 01, 2015, joseph ndunda; 2 boda bodas in demo against city askaris. the star nairobi , july 02, 2015, julius otieno;
notes: 1 human rights activist boniface mwangi has been arrested and allegedly beaten after he filmed the protest between boda boda operators in the cbd and city council officers on wednesday morning. mwangi was arrested by ap officers guarding city hall before he was handed over to the nairobi central police station for questioning. police said he was arrested for obstruction, causing chaos, mobilising boda boda riders to demonstrate in town and engaging city county askaris in running battle. he was also accused of causing a major cbd traffic snarl up. the riders stormed central police and engaged the police in running battles in their protest against alleged harassment by city council officers. police are yet to release mwangi despite pressure from city activists... ; 2 hundreds of boda boda operators yesterday held a demonstration outside city hall in nairobi, accusing city askaris of harassment. the operators were from the cbd, eastleigh, dandora, mathare, kayole, bahati and kariobangi. they accused the askaris of arresting and extorting money from them...

protesteridentity: residents, nyandarua county women s representative
sources: police, locals clash over brew at engineer. the star nairobi , july 06, 2015, bob muriuki;
notes: police and the residents of engineer trading centre in nyandarua county clashed over a haul of illicit brew stored in a police station on saturday. the residents wanted to destroy the samples the police had confiscated from a bar 50 metres away. the police blocked the residents led by nyandarua county women s representative wanjiku muhia from destroying the 1,200 cartons of liquor. the angry residents stormed the police station demanding to know why samples of the brew were being stored in the station instead of being destroyed. muhia went to seek audience with the deputy police boss peterson gitaga but she was turned away in full glare of tv cameras. police lobbed teargas at the crowd accompanying the mp when they asked to know why she was not being listened to. the residents who barricaded the miharati njabini road as police in riot gear engaged them in running battles. several people including a police officer sustained minor injuries in the five hour melee. the protesters hurled stones at the riot police who shot in the air to disperse the crowd. muhia accused the police of protecting traders in the illicit brew business.

sources: university of eldoret closed indefinitely after student protest over higher fees. the star nairobi , july 08, 2015, mathews ndanyi;
notes: the university of eldoret was shut down indefinitely on wednesday following student riots over fee increments. vice chancellor teresia akenga ordered students to leave by 2pm saying property of unknown value was destroyed during the protest. anti riot police were deployed to the university where students hurled stones at buildings and vehicles...

sources: traders fight street eviction order. the star nairobi , july 14, 2015, hilton otenyo;
notes: the kakamega administration has promised to evict traders from the cbd. head of communication sumba juma yesterday said all traders have been allocated stalls at the county main market. juma accused the traders of politicising their relocation even though they were given an eviction notice. administration police and county askaris engaged traders in running battles in kakamega town on thursday. some traders said they are yet to be given an alternative stall. three traders and mahiakalo mca cleophas malala were arrested during the riot and locked up in kakamega police station for several hours...

sources: kipipiri school shut as students strike. the star nairobi , july 23, 2015, bob muriuki;
notes: manunga girls secondary school in kipipiri, nyandarua county, has been closed indefinitely after students went on the rampage. the 300 students stormed out of the school on monday night and spent the night on the ol kalou miharati road. they were protesting against what they termed harshness by the management. the students want the principal and her deputy transferred. kipipiri police boss murkomen chebet said the students stormed out at 10pm. chebet said the students complained of being given small food rations. they also accused the school management of denying them permission to go with food to their hostels, he said.

sources: stop land grab or face the sack, shanzu rep warned. the star nairobi , july 23, 2015, brian otieno and ernest cornel;
notes: residents of shanzu ward, mombasa county, yesterday protested against the area mca for not stopping land grabbing. they braved the rain and marched to the bamburi police station, threatening to recall mca maimuna salim. we are tired of having our lands grabbed, resident athman mwajazi said...

protesteridentity: female administrative police, kenya association of women in policing
sources: female aps protest against flawed elections as kawp gets new officials. the star nairobi , august 17, 2015, kamore maina;
notes: female aps took to the streets of kakamega town on monday, in a protest against elections from which their representative was allegedly barred. the officers, under the kenya association of women in policing, claimed maureen lidava, who sought to represent the nyanza western region was wrongfully locked out. following the countrywide poll, largely boycotted in western and nairobi, they marched across the town in their uniforms, waving placards saying no maureen, no voting , no lidava, no voting . but officials of the election held earlier in the day, and tallied at police pavilion in nairobi, said lidava did not meet the deadline for submitting papers...

sources: siaya workers on strike over unpaid salaries, poor working conditions. the star nairobi , august 20, 2015, brenda okoth;
notes: siaya county workers stormed governor cornel rasanga s office demanding their rights, as part of a protest that began at midnight. the workers, including those from the health sector, earlier marched through the town chanting no pay, no work , and gathered at the siaya county referral hospital. the health sector, which has the largest number of workers, is most affected. we have not been paid last month s salaries. there are arrears and the state of our facilities is deplorable, a protester said...the protester said when they got to the governor s office, they were informed that their money had been sent to the wrong account...

sources: garissa town march to demand teachers. the star nairobi , august 21, 2015, stephen astariko;
notes: residents of garissa town yesterday took to the streets demanding a solution to deteriorating education standards in northeastern. more than 800 teachers have fled the region after terror attacks in mandera and garissa. led by 47 civil society groups, the residents waved placards and marched from garissa primary school to the regional coordinator s offices. parents, schoolchildren and other education players took part in the march. they handed northeastern regional coordinator mohamud saleh a memo for president uhuru kenya. we all know why the teachers and health personnel left this region, saleh told them. as residents we should denounce terrorism. the coordinator blamed insecurity on internal conflicts and urged the residents to re examine themselves ...

protesteridentity: residents, lobbyists, kisumu city residents voice, kisumu youth caucus, mcas
sources: kisumu police urged to tackle high crime. the star nairobi , august 22, 2015, justus ochieng;
notes: about 1,000 residents and lobbyists in kisumu town yesterday held a demonstration in protest against worsening insecurity...carrying twigs, placards and banners, the protesters marched from taifa park on oginga odinga street to kenyatta avenue. they chanted anti police slogans and songs outside central police station. armed officers formed a cordon at the entrance to keep them off. the protestors were led by ogada, kisumu youth caucus officials erick okello and dennis menya and mcas edwine anayo and paul achayo. ogada read a petition citing measures they want taken to stop crime...the residents demanded a county policing authority be formed.

sources: gatundu south farmers reject dam project, fear displacement. the star nairobi , august 28, 2015, ng ang a thairu;
notes: some 600 farmers from karangi village in kiganjo ward, gatundu south, have opposed a mega dam. the national irrigation board plans to build the dam to irrigate 37 sublocations on the farmers 27 acres. during a demonstration on monday, spokesman joseph njoroge said they were not consulted by the government or the irrigation board. njoroge said the dam should be constructed in the kinale forest, instead of displacing the 600 inhabitants. farmers committee member gabriel kamau accused nib officials and the provincial administration of intimidation...

sources: drama as striking nyeri nurses block cash couriers. the star nairobi , august 26, 2015, wambugu kanyi;
notes: more than 300 striking nurses in nyeri town blocked four cash couriers during a protest that saw them sleep on a road on tuesday. they had camped outside governor nderitu gacagua s office seeking to talk to him, when the vehicles approached with their sirens on. the protesters were forced out of the way after about five minutes, during which six ap officers stepped out of the vehicles and cocked their guns...waving twigs and placards, the health workers, most of whom were female nurses, shouted at them after they passed. gacagua did not turn up to address the group that police tried in vain to control. the health workers earlier protested within the town before heading to the office of county health executive charles githinji, where they were turned away by police. githinji has insisted that the strike, which began last monday, is illegal saying the kenya national union of nurses has received a court order stopping it. but nyeri knun chairperson ann nyawira has maintained that the strike, which has led to the crowding to private hospitals, will continue...

sources: kiambu destroys illegal buildings. the star nairobi , september 02, 2015, stanley njenga;
notes: only unapproved buildings are being targeted in the ongoing demolitions in kiambu, a county official has said. ten buildings were demolished in juja estate on saturday. residents on saturday were woken up by earth movers pulling down the houses. police provided security to prevent any chaos. officers lobbed tear gas canisters at residents protesting against the demolition. several people were injured and rushed to hospital...

sources: nyeri walkout nurses torch bosses effigies. the star nairobi , september 02, 2015, wambugu kanyi;
notes: despite earlier threats from the county government to sack them, the striking workers demonstration was joined by residents and nyeri town mp esther murugi on monday. they camped outside the health executive charles githinji s office for hours, demanding to speak to governor nderitu gachagua. he did not speak to them. the protesters also burnt effigies of githinji and his chief officer peter munyua...

sources: kishushe fights for title deeds. the star nairobi , september 03, 2015, raphael mwadime;
notes: hundreds of residents from kishushe and paranga locations on tuesday held peaceful demonstrations to protest against land problems. they marched to taita taveta governor john mruttu s office and handed their petition to deputy governor mary ndigha

protesteridentity: residents, youth, jap nyeri branch, the citizen initiative
sources: nyeri protesters back striking nurses, want state to take over health. the star nairobi , september 03, 2015, wambugu kanyi;
notes: more than 500 nyeri county residents held an operation rudisha health services to national government on thursday. waving twigs and placards in a march around town on thursday, they criticised the county for failing to end the nurse s strike that is in its third week. they lit bonfires and camped outside governor nderitu gachagua s office demanding to present him a petition. the protesters, who prevented entry into the office, were joined by jap nyeri branch chairman wambugu nyamu, coordinator samson kagiri and officials of the citizen initiative. a group of youths forced its way into the offices before nyeri ocs raphael gaa arrived with a contingent of police officers. the youths banged the gate, lay on the road and chanted slogans against the governor, amid pleas by the officers for them to calm down...

sources: bungoma youths storm slaughterhouse to see special wheelbarrows. the star nairobi , september 08, 2015, john nalianya;
notes: hundreds of youths stormed a slaughterhouse in bungoma county for a look at 10 wheelbarrows bought at sh109,000 each by the agriculture ministry. waving pacards and twigs, the youths, majority of whom were juakali craftsmen, demonstrated against the purchase, which has raised concerns of fraud by county executives. we as juakali artsians have looked at those wheelbarrows; they can t cost more than sh3,000, said their chairman moses wekesa. the demonstrators, who disrupted business with marches on bungoma town s main streets, said the protests will only end once action is taken. the marched to governor kenneth lusaka s office demanding to speak with him. it took the intervention county assembly majority leader majimbo okumu for them to calm down...

sources: county medics down tools over poor pay. the star nairobi , september 08, 2015, julius otieno;
notes: county health workers in nairobi downed their tools yesterday citing discrimination, late salaries and poor working conditions. they issued the strike notice on august 20. the worst affected hospitals are mama lucy kibaki and mbagathi, whose staff camped in protest at uhuru park...

protesteridentity: kenya national union of teachers knut
sources: sossion leads teachers in fresh demos as tsc sack threat ignored. the star nairobi , september 07, 2015, collins kweyu;
notes: teachers in several counties demonstrated on monday over their salary increase stalemate, ignoring a tsc sack threat over their strike. the strike over a 50 to 60 per cent pay hike, upheld by the supreme court, has entered its second week...knut secretary general wilson sossion addressed the teachers outside the union s headquarters during the nairobi demo that kuppet officials also joined...in kisumu, the teachers stormed the county headquarters after holding a peaceful demonstration in town, and demanded to speak with governor jack ranguma. they waved placards criticising kaimenyi and src chairperson sarah serem, and demanded that the court ruling be honoured. the tsc had asked teachers to report to work today, saying those on strike would be deemed to have absconded duty and removed from the payroll with immediate effect. ...

sources: teachers hold demo over pay. the star nairobi , september 10, 2015, mathews ndanyi;
notes: most public schools in eldoret town remained shut yesterday as teachers protested in the streets. they urged president uhuru and deputy president william ruto to resolve the standoff. the teachers said the president should speak about the pay dispute. but teachers in private schools were at work.

protesteridentity: kenya national union of teachers knut
sources: kenya national union of teachers murang a south branch members yesterday took to the streets asking for their court ordered pay increase from the teachers service commission. the teachers led by their branch secretary amos murigi, chairman john njata, murang a woman representative mary kimani and other executives protested around kenol market. the teachers said they will not report to work, even if they are served with sacking letters. they said tsc chairpaerson lydia nzomo and executive secretary nancy macharia should be charged with contempt of court... ;
notes: kenya national union of teachers murang a south branch members yesterday took to the streets asking for their court ordered pay increase from the teachers service commission. the teachers led by their branch secretary amos murigi, chairman john njata, murang a woman representative mary kimani and other executives protested around kenol market. the teachers said they will not report to work, even if they are served with sacking letters. they said tsc chairpaerson lydia nzomo and executive secretary nancy macharia should be charged with contempt of court...

sources: mugo wa wairimu rape probe must be thorough gender activists. the star nairobi , september 15, 2015;
notes: gender activists accused the police and the judiciary of handling rape cases slowly during a demonstration against sexual violence in the nairobi cbd on monday. the marched on streets, further accusing the government of taking very little action , and demanding justice against a gynaecologist accused of rape...the demonstrators further marched to the offices of the cj, the ig and the dpp to deliver their petitions...

sources: nys youth protest delayed pay, sacking by waiguru. the star nairobi , september 14, 2015, enos teche;
notes: nys employees took to the streets on monday protesting over delayed payments by the devolution ministry. they marched from south b to cs anne waiguru s office at harambee house carrying placards written we are being eaten by vultures, waiguru must go and show them we can make it without them . we have not been paid for eight weeks by the ministry, we cannot be working for them and they do not appreciate our efforts. this is tiring, said one of the protesters. the youth from mukuru kayaba said more than 2,000 were sacked without warning, claiming some were misled into taking leave, but did not get their jobs back upon return...

sources: wambora denies jobless embu youth are ignored. the star nairobi , september 15, 2015, reuben githinji;
notes: embu governor martin wambora has told unemployed youth his government will address their plight...the youth wielded placards before gathering at the county government headquarters in embu...he said plans are underway to open more factories to provide more jobs. wambora said his government has sponsored youth who travelled to dubai and qatar for employment. the youth said the government only makes empty promises, which are never implemented. the group blew whistles and vuvuzelas and chanted wambora sio bora wambora is not the best . they were joined by boda boda riders. the youth demonstrators said they are yet to get contracts and funds from the county government. they said only well connected youth get government benefits. the youth lit a bonfire at the county headquarters using waste papers, demanding to be allowed in. they said the county government has not set aside enough funds to empower them through their talents.

sources: lobbies protest against gmos. the star nairobi , september 17, 2015, patrick vidija;
notes: a group of civil societies in nairobi yesterday protested against lifting the ban on genetically modified foods, saying they are unsafe for consumption. the protesters marched from freedom corner to deputy president william ruto s office in the cbd, where they presented a petition for the ban not to be lifted. this comes after ruto last month said the government is planning to lift the ban on gmos in two months...

sources: tetu residents hold anti raila demos over waiguru attacks. the star nairobi , september 17, 2015, wambugu kanyi;
notes: more than 200 residents of tetu, nyeri county, protested against cord leader raila odinga s regular attacks on devolution cs ann waiguru on thursday. the protesters said raila should not taint waiguru s name over the sh791 million nys scandal, and asked him to respect women instead of fighting them...the protesters lay on giakanja gathuthi highway blocking it, before marching to wamagana trading centre waving twigs and placards. area police boss stephen obara stopped the demonstration for an address by deputy county commissioner herman shambi. shambi assured the youths that the programme, which had been put off, would resume and their arrears paid this week.

sources: 1 scores injured as police disperse kisumu demo. the star nairobi , september 23, 2015, faith matete; 2 university students held in city riot. the star nairobi , september 23, 2015, elizabeth were;
notes: scores of demonstrators were yesterday injured and others arrested as police dispersed a demonstration in kisumu town. the demonstrators were marching towards the kisumu government offices to protest against rising crime. residents want governor jack ranguma to form the county policing authority...they said people are being killed daily but the governor does not want to listen to their grievances. the demonstrators said the county government is not doing its part to fight crime. police officers confiscated boda boda motorcycles left behind by fleeing demonstrators...the students started the march from their hostels to the helb offices at the anniversary towers, then to the national treasury through uhuru highway and harambee avenue. they went back to campus through tom mboya street and university way where they clashed with police...

sources: 10 students arrested in demo over helb loans. the star nairobi , september 22, 2015;
notes: 1 at least 10 students were arrested and taken to central police station amid running battles with police in a demonstration over delayed helb loans on tuesday. police used tear gas to disperse the students, who stepped on kidero grass and harassed motorists in a march uhuru highway in the nairobi cbd. we want our money! comrades power, they chanted as they marched to treasury offices, causing traffic and forcing motorists to use alternative routes... ; 2 twenty university of nairobi students were arrested yesterday during a protest in the city centre to demand quick approval of helb loans. they engaged the police in street battles which lasted for hours. at least 20 students were arrested and taken to the central police station. police lobbed teargas canisters to disperse the students who were throwing stones. sonu chairman babu owino, who led the demonstration, accused the finance ministry of frustrating students by delaying the money...

sources: st catherine school parents march to ngilu s office over grabbing of playground. the star nairobi , october 08, 2015, patrick vidija;
notes: about 200 parents from st catherine primary school in south b, nairobi have marched to ardhi house to protest against the grabbing of the school s playground. the parents walked the 5kms to lands cs charity ngilu s office on wednesday, carrying placards with anti land grabbing messages...

sources: students torch maseno offices. the star nairobi , october 09, 2015, maurice alal;
notes: 1 maseno university s administration block was burnt on wednesday night by student arsonists and rioters angry they were barred from contesting elections...a senior police officer told the star rioting students lit bonfires before attacking security guards at the main entrance, forcing them to flee...sources in the university said the fire is linked to elections of student organisation of maseno university...the sources said some of the candidates barred from contesting might have started the fire. the candidates were blocked after they failed to meet the election requirements...

sources: 1 kabete residents hold demo over poor roads. the star nairobi , october 13, 2015, george mugo; 2 give mp waititu time to fix poor roads in kabete, says his aide. the star nairobi , october 14, 2015, george mugo;
notes: 1 residents of kabete constituency yesterday held demonstrations over poor roads and accused mp ferdinand waititu of not fixing them. they blocked the wangige rwaka road at gikuni using stones, logs and lit bonfires using old tyres. this resulted in a traffic snarl up for hours. they said waititu promised to tarmac the wangige gikuni road during his campaigns, but it has gotten worse...officers from waititu s office, led by simon ngugi, arrived tried without success to stop the demonstrations...the demonstrators were later dispersed by officers from kikuyu police station, led by ocs joshua arende... ; 2 the residents on monday closed the wangige rwaka road at gikuni, causing a traffic snarl up for most of the day. they accused waititu of lying to them during the campaigns that the ruku ngecha, mukui nyathuna and gikuni wangige roads would be tarmacked once he was elected. the protesters, led by a group calling itself the cuba elites, said waititu is never seen in kabete, but only heard in the press criticizing governor william kabogo or playing politics...

sources: nakuru sex workers write to uhuru after four killed, ask for protection. the star nairobi , october 12, 2015, william mwangi;
notes: in the town on monday, more than 200 commercial sex workers protested against poor security saying many of their colleagues are killed by men pausing as clinets. spokesperson daisy achieng said they should be protected as they make significant contributions to the economy.

sources: 1 mombasa technical university closed after student protest over higher fees. the star nairobi , october 19, 2015, calvin onsarigo and william mwangi; 2 mombasa varsity on strike over fee hike. the star nairobi , october 20, 2015, ernest cornel;
notes: 1 the technical university of mombasa was closed indefinitely on monday after students took to the streets in protest against fee increment..they blocked roads around the institution in tudor area, krcs said via twitter, and set two county lorries on fire, preventing access on bakhstan road. police lobbed teargas canisters and fired in the air as the students engaged them in running battles. the students accused the university of increasing the school fees by sh3,000 without official communication . this fee also varies from one department to the other. in some classes it has been increased from sh6,000 to sh8,000, one said... ; 2 students rioted yesterday over increased fees at the technical university of mombasa. the university was closed indefinitely after students became violent and torched county lorries. more than 60 students were detained and 50 injured. the students criticised a fees increase of more than sh7,000, which they say was imposed without consent...police and the inspectorate department denied the accusations. there is no arrest that has been reported, mombasa police boss martin asin said...

sources: mate jumps over wall as suppliers storm office. the star nairobi , october 22, 2015, reuben githinji;
notes: hundreds of suppliers, contractors and residents demanding their dues yesterday ejected embu speaker justus mate from his office. mate has blocked the sh800 million supplementary budget so there is no money to pay the debts. carrying crude weapons and placards written mate must go , the demonstrators forced their way into the assembly despite the presence of armed police officers. they headed straight to mate s office. he jumped over a wall and escaped...the suppliers tried in vain to break the burglar prove door to his office in the 10.30am incident. the demonstrators nailed timber bars on the door to keep mate away. others broke a window pane and threw undergarments and placards into the office as riot police watched helplessly...the mcas accused mate of deliberately blocking the supplementary budget to allocate funds not spent in the last financial year...

sources: lamu drug dens listed as locals pull kiosks down. the star nairobi , october 26, 2015, cheti praxides;
notes: meanwhile, more than 500 residents from mokowe and local administrators on friday staged a demonstration to protest against drug peddling. they accused police of laxity and colluding with drug barons. the demonstrators demolished kiosks believed to be owned by drug peddlers in majengo village. we are doomed if this drug business continues. we have lost and are still losing our children. our sons are now slowly being turned into zombies, who can t think of nothing else but drugs, resident asman omari said. he said if the police can t do their work, we are glad to be of help . lamu senior chief abdalla shahasi urged addicts to surrender themselves to the county government for rehabilitation...

sources: protest over potholed roads. the star nairobi , october 27, 2015, cheti praxides;
notes: transport was halted for two hours on saturday as residents barricaded roads with tyres. more than 500 residents carried placards complaining the 15km mpeketoni road, which links the town to lamu, is highly potholed . they urged the county government to repair it...

sources: kilifi residents want cashew plant reopened. the star nairobi , october 27, 2015, alphonce gari;
notes: kilifi residents yesterday held protests demanding the revival of the cashew nut industry. they demanded the revocation of a 999 year lease of 350 hectares to an investor who is manufacturing tar instead of processing cashew nuts. the dormant kenya cashew nuts ltd factory is on the land in kilifi town. the investor goes by the name millennium management ltd. residents marched to the factory to issue a 14 day ultimatum to the investor to leave. they asked him to hand over the factory to them or they will forcibly take it. they told the investor to seek compensation from the national government and leave...led by the kibaoni ward progressive association founder hamisi bwalema, the residents accused the investor of frustrating residents. the residents urged president uhuru kenyatta to allocate funds to revive the industry the same way he did for mumias sugar company...

sources: nyeri residents want ballast plant closed. the star nairobi , october 28, 2015, wambugu kanyi;
notes: hundreds of mweiga residents in nyeri county on tuesday held demonstrations demanding closure of a mega ballast plant over health hazards. they demanded relocation of the plant. the residents of kwa mburu village in kieni west say it causes too much noise, dust and degrades the soil. they urged the national environment management authority to close the site...

protesteridentity: voi girl s high school students
sources: 600 voi girls protest over sgr dust. the star nairobi , october 30, 2015, raphael mwadime;
notes: classes at voi girl s high school were on thursday disrupted after students walked away in protest against dust from construction of the standard gauge railway. the school is to be relocated but leaders are yet to agree on the site. on wednesday, more than 600 girls took to the streets to demand relocation away from the dusty and noisy construction site. they complained of pollution, saying it caused them frequent asthma attacks and other respiratory problems. we can t concentrate in class because of the noise and dust from the construction, said one student, who spoke to the star outside voi subcounty commissioner s offices. the girls demonstrated around voi town before proceeding to the district education offices and later to the subcounty commissioner s offices...

sources: 1,500 eldoret idps protest payout delay. the star nairobi , november 06, 2015, mathews ndanyi;
notes: more than 1,500 idps, including forest evictees in uasin gishu county, are yet to be resettled. the idps held a protest march at burnt forest on wednesday, demanding compensation from the government. paul tanui and jane kirwa, who spoke on behalf of the group, said the government has been biased in the resettlement process...

sources: coffee farmers say police hired to intimidate them. the star nairobi , november 18, 2015, reuben githinji;
notes: hundreds of farmers who pulled out of coffee cooperatives protested police harassment on monday. the farmers, drawn from tharaka nithi, embu, kirinyaga and meru counties, convened at manyatta shopping centre in embu north subcounty to protest. they say the police make illegal arrests on the orders of cooperative officials and politicians...protestors marched to the embu north subcounty headquarters to present a petition to the government demanding an end to illegal arrests...at the subcounty headquarters, they were addressed by assistant deputy county commissioner evans otieno who told them their grievances will be addressed. he said a meeting will be arranged with government officials to resolve the problem. otieno urged farmers to be patient.

sources: masinde muliro students demo over schoolmate s death at kakamega hospital. the star nairobi , november 19, 2015, hilton otenyo;
notes: police fired in the air to disperse university students demonstrating in kakamega over the death of a schoolmate at the level 5 hospital last sunday. officers also lobbed tear gas canisters at the masinde muliro university students during the protest on thursday over the death of their second year schoolmate. abigael ng asia, who had delivered a baby at kakamega level 5 hospital, reportedly died days later after a 12 hour wait. patient elizabeth akala died three weeks ago after allegedly waiting 14 hours. the hundreds of students, who waved twigs, stormed the county headquarters at about 9.30am demanding to submit their memorandum to governor wycliffe oparanya. security officers kept them off as the governor was driven from the premises, but they marched to the hospital to which regular and ap officers denied them access. outside the hospital s gate, superintendent augustine ajevi told the students investigations into ng asia s death were launched, but they responded by hurling stones into the compound. leader felix koech said they were displeased that students who sought treatment at the hospital were allegedly neglected. we have raised this issue with the governor more than once but nothing has happened. we are demanding that he sacks all those behind the deaths or we shall physically eject them from office, he said. police kept guard around kakamega town to keep the students from regrouping...

sources: ruiru traders riot over demolition of kiosks. the star nairobi , november 20, 2015, john kamau;
notes: hundreds of traders took to the streets on friday morning protesting the demolition of kiosks in ruiru, kiambu county. the traders lit bonfires on the major roads disrupting traffic on the highway and engaged police, who tried to disperse them using tear gas, in running battles. the traders claimed the county government did not give any notice of the friday morning demolitions...

sources: traders and employees protest closure of fish factory in kisumu. the star nairobi , november 25, 2015, maurice alal;
notes: hundreds of fish traders and employees of a fish processing factory in kisumu town yesterday held a peaceful demonstration to protest the factory s closure. the traders and the employees marched from the victoria delight fish factory in industrial area to the town centre through obote and oginga odinga streets. they marched to governor jack ranguma s office to seek his audience, but did not find him. they said the factory was closed abruptly on october 31 without employees being informed...kisumu east subcounty ap boss karanja muiru and kisumu town chief willis anyona helped to calm down the protesters who blocked the entrance to the governor s office.

sources: 200 protest land grab in malindi town. the star nairobi , november 25, 2015, alphonce gari;
notes: residents of nayeni, kilifi county, yesterday held a peaceful demo in malindi town, protesting against the grabbing of 230 acres. the 200 said 1,800 residents have been rendered squatters. they accused the national land commission of failing to take action against the alleged grabbers...

sources: gatundu youths protest moses kuria s detention over panga remarks. the star nairobi , november 26, 2015;
notes: boda boda operators lit bonfires on roads in gatundu south in a protest over mp moses kuria s detention on wednesday. they disrupted business at a taxi bay and marched to the local police station before moving to the thika juja junction but did not damage any property. the youths questioned why kuria, who is accused of inciting area youths to violence during a past function, was detained yet othersfacing similar charges are free. kuria was remanded to kilimani police station on wednesday after denying incitement charges over the panga remarks he allegedly issued in july...

sources: parents reject sex education for kids. the star nairobi , november 26, 2015, joseph ndunda and clayton onyango;
notes: parents held a protest march in nairobi city centre yesterday to oppose the sex education bill. the bill was proposed by nominated senator judith sijeny. the parents marched from uhuru park to jogoo house chanting sijeny must go . they filed a petition with the education ministry calling for the shelving of the bill...

sources: elgeyo mcas reject water tower plan. the star nairobi , november 30, 2015, mathews ndanyi;
notes: mcas and residents of elgeyo marakwet on friday held demonstrations to protest against a government plan to declare kaptagat forest a water tower. they gave governor alex tolgos two weeks to rescind his plan or they will carry out more protests. the forest lies in two counties including uasin gishu, whose governor jackson mandago also wants it declared a key water source. leading more than 3,000 residents in the protests, kaptarakwa mca thomas kigen and chepkorio s tecla cherotich said the plan is political...

sources: 26 youth held in anti graft march to state house. the star nairobi , december 02, 2015, patrick vidija;
notes: twenty six protesters were yesterday arrested by riot police on state house crescent road. the group led by political activist boniface mwangi were among hundreds of protesters who marched on the streets in nairobi to condemn corruption in government...the group started the peaceful march at freedom corner in uhuru park and proceeded to supreme court where they handed a petition to chief justice willy mutunga. they then headed to parliament buildings. dressed in red, black and white t shirts and waving placards reading knockout corruption the group left parliament headed for state house. their attempts to march on to state house were, however, thwarted by riot police. the group demanded that president uhuru kenyatta forms a corruption control council to fight graft in government...

sources: gachie residents protest over rise in crime. the star nairobi , december 04, 2015, stanley njenga;
notes: hundreds of gachie residents from kiambaa constituency yesterday protested against rise in crime, accusing police of laxity they said crime increased after the area, which was being manned by gigiri police station in nairobi, was referred to karuri police station in kiambu county, they said. the karuri police station is 4km away and officers take too long to respond to distress calls, residents said. they marched to gigiri police station...ocpd vitalis andege calmed the protesters and said he will work with kiambu police to improve security.

sources: kang ata leads drive to slash water prices. the star nairobi , december 07, 2015, alice waithera;
notes: kiharu mp irungu kang ata has accused murang a water and sanitation company of bribing a resident to drop a suit against a water tariff increase. the mp was leading a protest march in murang a town on friday to condemn the water bills increase

sources: athi river residents demand sgr payout. the star nairobi , december 09, 2015, george owiti;
notes: more than 500 residents of kwa mang eli village in athi river subcounty want compensation for property destroyed for the standard gauge railway project. they held a march in athi river town on monday. the residents demanded compensation for land, crops, trees, vegetables and fruits destroyed during demolitions to pave way for the project...speaking on behalf of the residents after the two hour march, he said it has taken too long for the government to fulfil its promise... we are calling for the national government s intervention so krc pays us what rightfully belongs to us, he said. the demonstrators blocked the road linking athi river town to mombasa road at stage 39 bridge, where construction is underway...they gave a police officer manning the site a hard time before he pushed them back...

protesteridentity: widows, disabled, parents & guardians of orphans, vulnerable children
sources: widows protest in nakuru over funds. the star nairobi , december 12, 2015, amos kerich;
notes: business yesterday came to a standstill in keringet town, nakuru county, as hundreds of demonstrators protested against neglect by the county and national governments. the widows, disabled, parents and guardians of orphans and vulnerable children marched to the deputy county commissioner s office to be addressed. they accused the two governments of not providing money from the cash transfer funds meant for them. the protesters said kuresoi, keringet ward, is not benefitting from the national and county governments funds. they urged the government to set aside funds for the poor widows and widowers, regardless of their age, saying most of them are weak, poor and unable to take care of their children...assistant deputy county commissioner yasmin musembi told the protesters the government has factors to consider to make when disbursing the money. she said no cash is set aside for widows.

sources: kisumu protest raila s eurobond summons. the star nairobi , december 14, 2015, justus ochieng;
notes: hundreds of kisumu residents and odm supporters on monday took to the streets protesting eacc s move to summon cord leader raila odinga. wielding twigs, the protesters chanted pro raila and odm slogans as they marched from kondele to kisumu central business district...

sources: police beat nairobi poll protesters the times london , may 18, 2016 wednesday, business; pg. 35, 224 words, kenya jerome;
notes: police fired tear gas and beat demonstrators with truncheons to stop them storming offices of the electoral commission in nairobi on monday. a video shows a man in a green sweatshirt running from police and falling to the ground. three officers take turns striking him with batons and kicking his motionless body as it lies slumped on the kerb. the protest was legitimate, it was a sign of kenya s hunger for free and fair elections but the response from police was shocking, said meluleki mthembu from the african democratic institute, based in johannesburg. not even claims of looting by protesters justifies such brutality.

sources: kenyan police in fresh clashes with political activists; opposition supporters in running battles with officers in nairobi and mombasa, as protests over electoral authorities continue the guardian, may 24, 2016 tuesday 8:37 am gmt, world news, 558 words, jason burke africa correspondent, and agencies;
notes: the worst of monday s confrontations occurred in nairobi, the capital, when protesters tried to march on the offices of the independent electoral and boundaries commission. police had banned the planned demonstration and scores of officers in riot gear guarded the building. a water cannon truck later forced the convoy of vehicles carrying opposition leaders and supporters accompanying it on foot out of the city centre, witnesses said. earlier, police said they had arrested seven people in mombasa where other protests took place.

sources: two killed in protests against election bias the times london , june 7, 2016 tuesday, news; pg. 36, 58 words, reuters kenya bans unlawful demonstrations the new york times, june 8, 2016 wednesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 9, 416 words, by jeffrey gettleman. follow jeffrey gettleman on twitter gettleman;
notes: the protesters demanded that commission members quit before elections next year and set tyres alight, blocking roads. monday deadly protests rocked several areas of kenya, government security officials issued a decree on tuesday banning all unlawful demonstrations. in kisumu, in western kenya, the police battled mobs, shooting several people. the government said on tuesday that 50 people had been injured and two killed, and it blamed the protesters for the violence. witnesses in kisumu said police officers had opened fire on a crowd, hitting a 5 year old boy in the back.

sources: 4 kenyan policemen charged in deaths of lawyer, client and driver the new york times, july 19, 2016 tuesday, section ; column 0; foreign desk; pg. , 297 words, by reuters;
notes: about 300 people marched through nairobi on july 4 to protest the men s disappearances, and demanded that the interior minister, joseph nkaissery, resign.

sources: this has pushed a button : killings in kenya ignite national outcry the new york times , july 8, 2016 friday 00:00 est, world; africa, 1274 words, jeffrey gettleman;
notes: four officers have been arrested and the case has exploded like few others in kenya, provoking marches, protests, the involvement of the f.b.i. and outrage that has turned into violence. hordes of young men stormed a police station this week and burned the metal container where the victims had been secretly held. lawyers vowed to boycott the courts for a week, out of solidarity for their fallen colleague, and their absence has paralyzed kenya s justice system.

location: Mathari National Teaching and Referral Hospital
sources: dozens of psychiatric patients flee hospital the times london , december 6, 2016 tuesday, news; pg. 38, 66 words;
notes: a national strike among medical workers led to at least 87 patients fleeing kenya s only psychiatric hospital after being left unattended. seventeen were brought back to mathari national teaching and referral hospital yesterday. police fired tear gas to disperse doctors protesting about salaries. union leaders say new doctors with six years training get less than police recruits.

sources: kenya raises threat of jail in doctors strike the times london , january 28, 2017 saturday, news; pg. 42, 168 words, aislinn laing;
notes: the doctors, who have brought city centres to a standstill with regular protest marches, say the dispute is not about salaries alone: they are also demanding that hospitals be better equipped, and patients given better treatment.

protesteridentity: doreen musungu, head teacher of kenyatta golf course academy, and her pupils
sources: kenyan pupils evicted, the times london , may 16, 2017 tuesday, news; pg. 32, 65 words;
notes: nairobi kenyan pupils used their desks to block a busy nairobi road in protest against the demolition of their primary school at the weekend after a land dispute. doreen musungu, head teacher of kenyatta golf course academy on the edge of the kibera slum, said that they had been allocated the land by a local government official in 2010 and were given no notice that they were being evicted. note: the number of protesters was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: opposition who claim that the electoral commission s servers had been hacked to award the incumbent, uhuru kenyatta, a significant lead.
sources: kenya election hacked, opposition leader says, the new york times, august 10, 2017 thursday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 5, 884 words, by kimiko de freytas tamura; violence erupts in kenyan cities over rigged election, the times london , august 10, 2017 thursday, news; pg. 31, 614 words, julia steers;
notes: the kenyan opposition leader, raila odinga, threw early results of the country s presidential election into doubt on wednesday, claiming that the electoral commission s servers had been hacked to award the incumbent, uhuru kenyatta, a significant lead. protests followed shortly afterward in parts of kisumu, one of kenya s biggest cities and an opposition stronghold. demonstrators also burned tires, set up roadblocks and clashed with the police in parts of nairobi, the capital, the associated press reported. earlier, at least one protester was killed by police gunfire in kisii county, the a.p. said, citing a regional police commander, leonard katana. the mood was tense in kisumu, where residents said they were furious about what they called a hacked election. large parts of the city were calm, but in the kondele neighborhood, crowds were being dispersed by police officers using tear gas. part of a nearby road was blocked, and tires had been set on fire. some residents were seen running away. as violence spread across the country, the authorities took extra precautions in addition to keeping more than 150,000 troops and police on the streets. note: the actual number of protesters was not provided in the sources, and is based on prior coding decisions

location: National: Kisumu; Nairobi; Kisii County; western Nyanza province
protesteridentity: opposition who criticize the presidential election as a charade
sources: rival calls president s election win in kenya a charade, the new york times, august 12, 2017 saturday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 5, 818 words, by kimiko de freytas tamura; election protests rage on in kenya, the new york times, august 13, 2017 sunday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 4, 1235 words, by kimiko de freytas tamura; after president s reelection, at least 24 reportedly killed in kenya violence, the washington post, august 13, 2017 sunday, a section; pg. a12, 613 words, rael ombuor;kevin sieff; in historic ruling, kenyan court nullifies president s re election, the new york times, september 2, 2017 saturday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 1, 1473 words, by kimiko de freytas tamura;
notes: president uhuru kenyatta on friday was officially declared the winner of a bitterly disputed election in kenya, but his opponent, raila odinga, refused to concede defeat, criticizing the vote as a charade and edging the country closer to violence. on friday, mr. odinga s party, the national super alliance, refused to take part in the announcement of the election results, accusing the commission of releasing the outcome before addressing its concerns. top opposition party officials also indicated that they were unwilling to resolve their claims about election fraud in court, in comments that could be interpreted by supporters as a call to protest. protests in several opposition strongholds erupted shortly after mr. kenyatta s victory was declared. police officers equipped with riot gear moved into some areas of nairobi, the capital, and kisumu, kenya s third largest city and mr. odinga s birthplace, where tear gas was used and live bullets were fired at protesters, according to witnesses. the sun had barely risen, but protesters were already bracing for another wave of confrontations with the police in the city of kisumu on saturday after an election disputed by supporters of kenya s opposition party. as the smell of tear gas and smoke from burning debris clung to the morning mist, residents began assessing the damage from the previous night s protests after the re election of president uhuru kenyatta, a vote that many in this part of western kenya believe was stolen, even though international observers concluded that it was fair and transparent. hundreds of residents of kisumu, an opposition stronghold, clashed overnight with the police, who, they said, cut off electricity to create confusion, sprayed live bullets into crowds, fired tear gas and blasted them with water cannons. the police, witnesses said, conducted house to house raids in parts of the city, and residents accused some officers of beating them with clubs and stealing money from them. the police in kisumu declined to comment on the allegations. at least 24 people, including a 6 year old child, have been killed since the election results were announced friday night, according to the kenyan national commission on human rights. in kibera, nairobi s largest slum, residents said that at least six people were killed late friday and early saturday in clashes with police. young men in the slum had promised for days to hold demonstrations if kenyatta defeated their candidate, raila odinga, who has not yet accepted the results or conceded, raising concerns of further violence. there were also protests in western nyanza province. in a historic ruling and a first in africa, kenya s supreme court nullified on friday september 1st the re election of a sitting president, ordering a new vote to be held within 60 days after finding that the outcome last month had been tainted by irregularities. note: the number of protesters was not included in the sources, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: supporters of raila odinga, leader of kenya s opposition alliance
sources: kenya protesters met with tear gas, the times london , october 10, 2017 tuesday, news; pg. 36, 53 words; opposition leader drops out of kenyan presidential race, the washington post, october 11, 2017 wednesday, a section; pg. a14, 795 words, rael ombuor;paul schemm;
notes: nairobi police fired tear gas at supporters of raila odinga, leader of kenya s opposition alliance, as they protested before a presidential poll rerun on october 26. the protests have been heating up, with police opening fire on a demonstration in nairobi on monday, injuring one man. note: the number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: supporters of opposition leader raila odinga that defied a government ban on demonstrations
sources: protesters killed as police move to quell kenyan poll unrest, the times london , october 14, 2017 saturday, news; pg. 45, 194 words, aislinn laing; official fears kenyan vote will lack credibility, the new york times, october 19, 2017 thursday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 6, 790 words, by jina moore;
notes: kenyan police shot dead at least two people as supporters of raila odinga, the opposition leader, defied a government ban on demonstrations aislinn laing writes . the shootings happened after a group stormed a police station in bondo, mr odinga s home town in the west of the country, police said. witnesses said police shot one man in the head and a second in the chest. n mombasa and the capital nairobi, officers fired tear gas at politicians from mr odinga s national super alliance who tried to lead rallies, left, and had running battles with protesters in kisumu, another odinga stronghold. the protest began after mr odinga, 72, announced that he would withdraw from a re run of the election won by president kenyatta, 55, on august 8 but overturned by the supreme court, citing irregularities with vote tallying. the re run is due on october 26 but mr odinga is demanding reforms and called for daily protests. on thursday the interior minister banned demonstrations in main cities, saying opposition supporters had looted businesses and attacked police stations. human rights watch said that up to 67 people may have been killed and many more seriously hurt. on tuesday october 17, mr. odinga called off protests in nairobi s city center, alleging that his supporters were the targets of police violence. note: the number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: opposition to the presidential election that is being re run
sources: police break up demo, the times london , october 25, 2017 wednesday, news; pg. 32, 70 words;
notes: nairobi police used bullets and tear gas to disperse a small protest in nairobi before the presidential election is re run tomorrow. raila odinga, the opposition leader, who is not standing, had called for protestsagainst kenya s election board but now says that his supporters should not vote. the supreme court will hear a petition today by human rights activists who say that kenya is not ready for the vote. note: the number of supporters is not stated in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: kenyan opposition vows campaign of unrest; kenya, the times london , october 26, 2017 thursday, news; pg. 32,33, 598 words, aslinn laing;
notes: barricades were put up in some neighbourhoods loyal to kenya s opposition leader last night as raila odinga promised a campaign of defiance against the incumbent dictatorship after a lastditch legal attempt to delay today s election rerun was scuppered by a shooting. in nairobi s kibera slum, another area dominated by supporters of mr odinga, there were pockets of violent protests and roadblocks were erected. there were also reports that unidentified people were circling the area in flatbed trucks fitted with loudspeakers, warning those who went to vote that there would be consequences . the centre of the capital was calm but patrolled by heavily armed police backed by armoured vehicles with water cannon. note: the number of supporters is not stated in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

location: Kisumu; Mathare, a slum on the outskirts of Nairobi
protesteridentity: opposition to the rerun of its presidential election
sources: clashes, low turnout in kenya s divisive election rerun, the washington post, october 27, 2017 friday, a section; pg. a12, 1039 words, kevin sieff; kenyan president reelected after tumultuous rerun vote boycotted by many, the washington post, october 31, 2017 tuesday, a section; pg. a13, 670 words, kevin sieff;
notes: kenya held a rerun of its botched presidential election thursday, but the opposition boycotted, and clashes broke out between police and protesters, threatening further political turmoil in one of sub saharan africa s key economies. the incumbent, uhuru kenyatta, was viewed as almost certain to win because of a boycott by the leading opposition candidate, raila odinga. odinga had claimed that it was impossible to hold a credible election and told his followers that they now were part of a resistance movement against what he described as kenyatta s dictatorship. violence thursday was concentrated in opposition strongholds, particularly the western city of kisumu, where three people were killed and 29 injured, according to the county governor. in mathare, a slum on the outskirts of nairobi, witnesses said police charged into a crowd of protesters and started shooting live rounds. one man, paul oketch, 27, was shot in the head and killed. note: the number of protesters was not provided in the source, and was based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: supporters of the opposition politician raila odinga
sources: kenya s opposition leader returns to nairobi amid deadly clashes, the new york times, november 18, 2017 saturday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 6, 638 words, by jina moore.; five die in kenya unrest, the times london , november 18, 2017 saturday, news; pg. 46, 69 words;
notes: at least five people were killed on friday in clashes between the kenyan police and supporters of the opposition politician raila odinga after a disputed contest in which president uhuru kenyatta was re elected, despite reports of voting irregularities. the police fired water cannons and tear gas as mr. odinga s convoy made its way to upper hill in central nairobi where he addressed supporters. the unrest was broadcast on live television. the police denied that they had fired their weapons or killed anyone, despite several reports by witnesses and journalists to the contrary. the associated press reported that one person had been killed in the clashes, and agence france presse said that one of its reporters saw the bodies of three men who had been shot to death on a road in muthurwa, a suburb where riot police officers armed with tear gas, water cannons and rifles clashed with stone throwing protesters. note: the number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: kenya s president begins 2nd term after divisive vote, the washington post, november 29, 2017 wednesday, a section; pg. a10, 664 words, rael ombuor;
notes: kenyan president uhuru kenyatta was sworn in for a second term tuesday amid the thunderous applause of supporters even as pro government forces fired on protesters angered by the contentious election process that kept him in power. as kenyatta was sworn in, police across town opened fire on opposition demonstrators, with reports of at least one dead. an impromptu rally later by opposition leader raila odinga was hit by tear gas, forcing his abrupt retreat to his vehicle. note: the number of protesters was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: thousands denouncing kenya s electoral autocracy and election stealing.
sources: kenyan authorities cut off telecasts of opposition s symbolic inauguration , the new york times, january 31, 2018 wednesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 8, 1283 words, by jina moore.; massive crowds turn out for kenya s mock president, the times london , january 31, 2018 wednesday, news; pg. 24,25, 570 words, kenya aislinn;
notes: the kenyan government cut transmissions of three private television stations and moved to criminalize a political opposition group on tuesday, as supporters of the opposition leader raila odinga gathered in the capital to name him the people s president. mr. odinga lost his bid for the presidency last year to the incumbent, uhuru kenyatta, but he says the voting was plagued by fraud. his supporters have been planning an alternative inauguration for months, and government and police officials have threatened to crack down on any such event, as they have in the past. the event proceeded peacefully and without police interference. but early tuesday evening, fred matiang i, the interior ministry secretary, declared the national resistance movement, which is part of mr. odinga s opposition coalition, an organized criminal group. by 3 p.m. tuesday, mr. odinga had taken an oath as the people s president and had given a short speech in front of a crowd of thousands denouncing kenya s electoral autocracy and election stealing. the park emptied immediately after he spoke. the leader of the kenyan opposition has been threatened with arrest after he staged an unofficial swearing in ceremony as an alternative president. the security forces did not try to halt the ceremony, but police fired tear gas to disperse the crowds afterwards.

sources: hundreds of kenyans in the capital march against corruption, associated press international, may 31, 2018 thursday 12:42 pm gmt, international news, 275 words, associated press, nairobi, kenya
notes: carrying signs saying kenya is bleeding and stop these thieves, hundreds of people marched thursday in nairobi to protest against widespread corruption and deliver a petition to the office of president uhuru kenyatta. kenyatta is under increasing pressure as outrage grows over a number of corruption scandals revealed in recent weeks around the ministries of health, energy, agriculture, public service and youth. this week 24 officials were charged with corruption related offenses in a probe linked to the alleged diversion of nearly 80 million. we are tired of the theft that is going on in this country. we have waited for so long for action to be taken but nothing is happening, activist and marcher ndungi githuku told the associated press. kenyatta, long criticized for not acting against corrupt officials, said wednesday there will be no mercy for the thieves.

protesteridentity: activists protesting plans for a joint venture between the kenyan and chinese governments to mine coal and open a coal fired power plant
sources: kenyan activists protest plans for coal fired power plant, associated press international, june 5, 2018 tuesday 3:19 pm gmt, international news, 242 words, by tom odula, associated press
