notes: kenyan activists on tuesday protested the plans for a joint venture between the kenyan and chinese governments to mine coal and open a coal fired power plant near the indian ocean coast, saying it will have devastating effect on the environment and health of the local population. kenya is set to build the 981.5 megawatt coal fired plant to generate electricity in the manda bay area of lamu county. the site is not far from the lamu old town settlement, a unesco world heritage site. government officials have said the east african nation, a regional commercial and transport hub, needs to increase its capacity to generate electricity to keep up with demand. critics say the project goes against kenya s commitments under the 2015 paris climate accord. hussein khalid, activist and executive director of community organization haki africa, said coal energy is being abandoned elsewhere in the world because of the harm it causes. why are they not doing this project in china? khalid asked as the marchers took to the streets of the capital, nairobi. why are they coming here to spoil our environment? so we are telling the government that kenyans come first. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: residents demanding security improvements in the county and borders
sources: kenya strikes deal with protesters to allow transportation of crude oil, xinhua general news service, july 6, 2018 friday 9:31 pm gmt, international news, 379 words, robert manyara
notes: transportation of crude oil from kenya s turkana county in northeast region to the coastal city of mombasa will resume next week after protesting residents agreed to end the blockade, officials and leaders said on friday. residents and their leaders made the decision to end protest against the truck ferrying the oil from ngamia 8 after the government pledged to improve security in the county and borders. rift valley regional coordinator mongo chimwaga and petroleum cabinet secretary john munyes brokered the deal after a lengthy deliberation with lawmakers and elders. chimwanga announced that the concerns raised by the community will be addressed with immediate effect to ensure tullow oil operations resume. we had healthy discussions with the stakeholders and the state has assured residents of security and issues raised will be worked on. trucks transporting crude oil to mombasa will resume next wednesday, the government official told xinhua. he said that combined teams of security personnel will now be deployed in the troubled areas to combat cases of banditry and cattle rustling. oil transportation from the area has been disrupted for one week after residents blocked trucks carrying the commodity to mombasa demanding that the government provide them security and stop external intrusions. note: the actual start date of the protest was not provided in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

location: Jomo Kenyatta International Airport  JKIA , Nairobi
protesteridentity: ground workers at jkia who were protesting the planned partial takeover of the airport, operated by state run kenya airports authority, by national carrier kenya airways
sources: police fire tear gas as strike strands travellers at nairobi airport, agence france presse english, march 6, 2019 wednesday 4:52 pm gmt, 701 words, nairobi, march 6 2019
notes: hundreds of travellers were stranded for hours at nairobi airport wednesday, and some were treated for tear gas exposure, as striking workers and police faced off at east africa s busiest air traffic hub. while departing planes were grounded from midnight onwards, some incoming flights to jomo kenyatta international airport jkia were rerouted to runways elsewhere in kenya, even tanzania, in a protest the government described as illegal, even sabotage . there were tense moments in the morning when baton wielding police in riot helmets squared up to striking ground workers at jkia and fired tear gas even as hundreds of anxious and frustrated travellers amassed in the terminals waiting for information about their flights. several strikers and would be travellers were treated on site for exposure to the blinding, choking spray, and others for minor injuries sustained in the chaos that ensued as they tried to escape the fumes. a water cannon was seen arriving at the airport, but was not put to use. by late morning, officials advised would be passengers not to come to jkia east africa s busiest airport. according to the kenya airports authority kaa . airport workers aligned to the kenya aviation workers union kawu , are angry about the planned partial takeover of the airport, operated by state run kaa, by national carrier kenya airways. transport minister james macharia told journalists that workers need not worry about the possible change of ownership. what they were fearing is that the proposed merger between kq the acronym for kenya airways and kaa will result in job losses but we gave assurances that that will not happen, he said. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions. note: the kq majority owner is the kenyan government

protesteridentity: protesters against a project to build a coal power station near the lamu archipelago
sources: kenyans protest bid to build east africa s first coal plant, agence france presse english, june 12, 2019 wednesday 1:30 pm gmt, 522 words, nairobi, june 12 2019
notes: scores of kenyans on wednesday protested against a project to build a coal power station near the lamu archipelago, a popular tourist spot that includes a unesco world heritage site and boasts vibrant marine life. the power station, which has been in the planning stages for about six years, has faced fierce resistance from activists and local communities, and the national environmental tribunal is to rule on june 24 on the fate of the project. a group of about 200 protesters carrying black coffins emblazoned with white skulls, as well as a miniature chimney spewing smoke, marched through downtown nairobi on wednesday chanting coal is poisonous! there is no need to build centralised dirty sources of energy such as coal to answer kenya s energy demands, especially when the country is taking the lead in africa with an 85 percent renewable energy base, said decoalonize campaign coordinator, omar elmawi. with access to wind, solar, geo thermal and tidal energy sources, kenya s renewable energy potential is cost efficient and causes no harm to the people and environment.

protesteridentity: protesters hoping to persuade leaders to act against climate change and environmental disaster
sources: schoolchildren throng streets in vast global climate strike, agence france presse english, september 20, 2019 friday 7:44 pm gmt, 785 words, new york, sept 20 2019; protesting climate change, young people take to streets in a global strike, the new york times, september 20, 2019 friday 11:26 est, climate, 1665 words
notes: huge numbers of children skipped school friday to join a global strike against climate change that teen activist greta thunberg hopes will mark a turning point in persuading leaders to act against environmental disaster. chanting slogans and waving placards, youngsters and adults filled the streets of cities across the world in what was expected to be the biggest ever protest against the threat posed to the planet by warming temperatures. hundreds also took to the streets in kenya and uganda. banners in kenya s capital, nairobi, ranged from serious to humorous. one read, climate emergency now. another said, this planet is getting hotter than my imaginary boyfriend. note: each of the actual protest locations were not included in the source; the protest location is based on prior coding decisions

notes: dar es salaam aana thousands of muslim fundamentalists in the tanzanian capital, dar es salaam, brought parts of the city around mwembe chai mosque to a stand still on may 29 after they rioted and set government vehicles on fire. the muslims were angered by the recall of a permit granted to muslim women to meet at a public hall in town. the women s agenda included what they said was mistreatment by police last february after the police arrested women demonstrators during a street protest.

notes: fifteen civilians and 14 policemen were injured in a riot in zanzibar on wednesday when 18 opposition civil united front cuf members were brought to court to answer treason charges, local media reported on thursday. zanzibar assistant commissioner of police juma mtumwa was quoted as saying that 40 people had been arrested and would soon appear in court.

sources: zanzibar riots after election fraud the daily telegraph london , october 31, 2000, tuesday, 285 words, by tim butcher in zanzibar ;
notes: police clashed with demonstrators in zanzibar yesterday as anger boiled over at government fraud in sunday s presidential elections. police in full riot gear fired live rounds in the air and used tear gas to disperse a crowd of about 300 mainly young people who had started to throw stones at a police car on the outskirts of stone town. a small group of demonstrators took refuge in nearby buildings but were forced out by police who beat them with batons. several were arrested and driven away by police.

sources: voting dispute turns violent in zanzibar the new york times, january 28, 2001 sunday, section 1; column 5; foreign desk; pg. 6, 165 words, reuters 17 die as poll demo erupts the observer, january 28, 2001, observer news pages, pg. 21, 259 words, burhan wazir 13 feared dead as police and poll protesters fight running battles the sunday herald, january 28, 2001, pg. 18, 250 words world; in brief the washington post, january 28, 2001 sunday, a section; pg. a23, 724 words zanzibar clashes spread to mainland the guardian london , january 29, 2001, guardian foreign pages, pg. 14, 242 words, james astill 32 die in zanzibar as police and protesters clash the new york times, january 29, 2001 monday, section a; column 1; foreign desk; pg. 3, 311 words, agence france presse ;
notes: protesters seeking new elections fought running battles with the police today as violence spread across tanzania and left as many as 17 people dead. opposition officials and doctors said 16 protesters had been killed on zanzibar s main islands of unguja and pemba as demonstrations across the archipelago calling for a rerun of disputed elections turned violent. one member of the security forces was decapitated, a police official said.

sources: world in brief: poll protesters on the march the observer, april 8, 2001, observer news pages, pg. 19, 80 words, jane astill ;
notes: more than 50,000 protesters marched through the tanzanian capital, dar es salaan, as one of africa s most united countries moved further towards possible disintegration, writes jane astill. the marchers wanted a rerun of elections last year in the semi autonomous zanzibar islands. opposition groups say the voting was rigged by the ruling chama cha mapinduzi party.

notes: at least 50,000 people marched yesterday in the first joint opposition demonstration on zanzibar since the controversial october elections that international observers described as fundamentally flawed. demonstrators from six opposition parties marched to maisara grounds, where they held a rally demanding new elections for the semiautonomous archipelago in tanzania.

notes: tanzanian police on saturday dispersed dozens of opposition supporters who had attempted to protest the government s decision to buy a controversial air traffic control system from britain, witnesses said. they said about 100 supporters of the opposition tanzania labour party tlp had gathered at tlp offices in dar es salaam around midday, but were dispersed by anti riot police.

sources: tanzanian utility workers resist takeover by s. african firm agence france presse english, april 11, 2002 thursday, international news, 158 words ;
notes: hundreds of workers of tanzania s electric supply company tanesco staged a demonstration at the firm s head office here thursday to protest its takeover by a south african firm, officials and witnesses said. the government appointed net group solution on april 2 to run tanesco before it is privatised, but workers at the state firm are demanding payment of their benefits before the new management takes over thursday.

sources: tanzanian power workers demonstrate against south african managers agence france presse english, may 1, 2002 wednesday, international news, 240 words ;
notes: hundreds of workers of tanzania s state owned power utility, electric supply company tanesco , wednesday marked may day by staging a demonstration against south african managers. instead of going to the dar es salaam national stadium to march with other workers in the official a may day parade, the singing, dancing and placard waving demonstrators, gathered at tanesco head office to protest against the takeover of tanesco by south african managers.

sources: 50 tanzanian students arrested over campus demonstration xinhua general news service, april 21, 2004, wednesday, world news; political, 211 words ;
notes: tanzania s anti riot police have dispersed a demonstration staged by students of the university of dar es salaam and made some 50 arrests, local newspaper daily news reported wednesday. the students gathered tuesday on the campus in a protest of the higher education students loan bill which was passed by the national assembly on monday.

sources: voter registration turns violent in zanzibar ahead of 2005 elections associated press international, december 1, 2004 wednesday, international news, 534 words, ali sultan; associated press writer ;
notes: police opened fire on protesters at a voter registration center in an opposition stronghold of zanzibar on wednesday, killing three people and wounding dozens of others, police said. regional police commander faraji kayuga said officers opened fire when confronted by protesters at a center in ngombeni on the northern zanzibari island of pemba. opposition members tried to prevent the armed riot police from entering the center, kayuga said.

sources: zanzibar poll turns violent amid claims of fraud the australian, november 1, 2005 tuesday all round country edition, world; pg. 10, 444 words zanzibar s president sworn in after marred election, opposition calls for investigation into polls ap worldstream, november 2, 2005 wednesday, international news, 533 words, ali sultan; associated press writer ;
notes: soldiers have fired shots and teargas to disperse opposition protesters at a zanzibar polling station as sporadic violence and charges of fraud marred elections on the volatile tanzanian archipelago. the violence erupted as the main opposition party on zanzibar denounced what it said was widespread fraud in sunday s election and alleged the ruling party was trying to cook the results .

notes: riot police in zanzibar fired tear gas to disperse residents of tumbatu island in north unguja who stormed a voter registration centre yesterday demanding to be registered without the zanzibar residence ids.

sources: residents stage protest over road the citizen dar es salaam , january 13, 2010 wednesday, 550 words, george sembony ;
notes: the construction of the 65km tanga horohoro highway took a new turn at the weekend after a group of villagers closed a section of it demanding that the new road should pass through their village. vehicles, including buses plying between tanga and mombasa in kenya, were held for almost five hours at mabokweni village as villagers camped at the middle of the road pressing their demand.

sources: opposition party says graft body not acting enough the citizen dar es salaam , october 7, 2010 thursday, 454 words, adam ihucha ;
notes: the prevention and combating of corruption bureau pccb has warned pressure groups against attempts to use it for their own interests. the anti corruption watchdog was reacting to chadema supporters allegations that it has been lenient in acting on corruption tip offs in political campaigns. said the arusha regional pccb commander, mr ayoub akida, recently: we don t want to be used by a faction of people who may have malicious interests.

location: Mwanza, Dar Es Salaam, Kahama, Arusha, Busanda, Tarime and in Zanzibar
sources: chaos reigns as electoral commission delays releasing results the citizen dar es salaam , november 1, 2010 monday, 936 words ;
notes: chaos reigned in mwanza city and other lake zone districts yesterday as impatient youths protested the delay in announcing election results by the national electoral commission nec officials. two vehicles, a nissan patrol and a saloon car said to belong to ilemela deputy returning officer paulo masangu, were torched using a petrol bomb while as many as 10 other cars had their windows smashed with stones as thousands of opposition supporters in ilemela and nyamagana constituencies demanded the immediate release of poll results.

sources: city standstillas opposition reigns arusha times arusha , november 2010, 441 words ;
notes: thousands of arusha residents thronged the city hall throughout monday demanding prompt release of the results causing the police to deploy teams of anti riot squads equipped with all necessary weapons including, tear gas canisters and the menacing, armored dong feng winnebago truck that sprays stingy liquid.

sources: chaos as cuf members call for new constitution the citizen dar es salaam , december 28, 2010 tuesday, 843 words ;
notes: police fired in the air to disperse hundreds of opposition supporters who were yesterday planning to demonstrate in dar es salaam in support of calls for a new constitution. a dozen members of the civic united front cuf were arrested when they engaged the police in a cat and mouse chase along the busy city streets for most of the morning hours as they attempted to march to the ministry of justice and constitutional affairs.

sources: blood, tears as police stop chadema march the citizen dar es salaam , january 5, 2011 wednesday, 885 words, zephania ubwani two killed in chadema banned demo the citizen dar es salaam , january 6, 2011 thursday, 108 words ;
notes: the leader of the official opposition in parliament, mr freeman mbowe, was among four chadema mps detained by police after a demonstration called by the opposition party was violently broken up yesterday. other mps who were being held at central police station in arusha were mr godbless lema arusha , mr joseph selasini rombo and mr philemon ndesamburo moshi urban . a section of the busy arusha moshi highway turned into a battlefield as heavily armed riot police moved in to break up the demonstration led by senior chadema officials. several of the party s leaders were arrested, and dozens of people, including journalists, beaten up and injured by baton wielding police officers. police also fired in the air, sending people scurrying for cover.

sources: udsm students protest, clash with police in dar es salaam the citizen dar es salaam , february 4, 2011 friday, 413 words, beatus kagashe ;
notes: the police force yesterday used tear gas, water cannons and pepper spray to disperse hundreds of university of dar es salaam udsm students who were matching to the state house to present their demands for increased meals allowance. the students engaged the law enforcers in a running battle at survey area, where the field force unit ffu confronted the students. the students have boycotted classes since thursday to press for increases of meals allowance from the current sh5,000 to sh10,000 per day, citing increase in cost of living.

sources: chadema sounds alarm on potential for protests the citizen dar es salaam , february 24, 2011 thursday, 901 words, ray naluyaga can chadema demonstrations oust the ccm government? the citizen dar es salaam , march 1, 2011 tuesday, 1134 words, mlagiri kopoka ;
notes: activities in most of mwanza came to a standstill yesterday afternoon as people took part in a peaceful demonstration organised by chadema.the demonstration was led by mr mbowe, who is also leader of official opposition in the parliament. he was flanked by dr slaa and almost all chadema mps. there were only few uniformed policemen and chadema s red brigade took charge of security during the demonstrations and at the rally. the demonstration started at around 1pm at buzuruga primary school and went through musoma, pamba, kenyata and makongoro roads before it climaxed at furahisha grounds at around 3.45pm.addressing the rally earlier, the kawe mp, ms halima mdee, urged tanzanians to shun fear and confront the government when it does not deliver. it took a young man who set himself on fire to overthrow corrupt governments in tunisia and egypt. time to fear is long gone, she said.

sources: demolition of traders stalls sparks violence the citizen dar es salaam , march 3, 2011 thursday, 390 words, victor karega ;
notes: several people were reportedly injured when the police used live ammunition and tear gas canisters to disperse petty traders who were protesting the demolition of the manzese second hand clothes market. the fracas erupted after the traders blocked a section of morogoro road in protest of the demolition. after arriving at around 11am yesterday to find about 100 stalls on the ground, the traders protested the move by blocking the road with logs and other debris. the police moved in and fired several warning shots in the air and tear gas canisters to the traders to disperse them

sources: chadema leads thousands to protest high cost of living the citizen dar es salaam , may 6, 2011 friday, 365 words, boniface meena ;
notes: thousands of mbeya residents yesterday thronged city streets in peaceful demonstrations organised by the opposition chama cha demokrasia na maendeleo chadema to protest the increasing cost of living.the demonstrations, which started at mafiati and climaxed at ccm grounds, were led by chadema national chairman freeman mbowe who is also the leader of official opposition in parliament. other leaders who participated in the demonstrations were chadema secretary general willibrod slaa, outspoken arusha urban mp godbless lema and his mbeya urban counterpart joseph mbilinyi.

sources: bus operators strike renders city chaotic the citizen dar es salaam , july 25, 2011 monday, 621 words, zephania ubwani ;
notes: police here were forced to use teargas to disperse rioters during the early morning hours of yesterday following a strike by commuter bus operators over alleged harassment by the law keepers. until late in the afternoon, however, there were no reports of injuries, but several government vehicles had their windscreens smashed by mobs of rioters. also smashed were the glass windows of a motor vehicle showroom along the dodoma road.

sources: villagers fight over scarse waterthe citizen dar es salaam , november 8, 2011 tuesday, 565 words, joseph lyimo ;
notes: police in arumeru district, arusha region were at the weekend forced to fire tear gas and live bullets into the air to disperse angry people fighting over water at kikwe and nambala villages. the confrontation came about when the law enforcers blocked the villagers from using the water from the nearby rivers, which is increasingly dwindling due to drought, to irrigate their farms.

sources: 46 varsity students arrested over demo the citizen dar es salaam , november 11, 2011 friday, 378 words, mkinga mkinga ;
notes: about 46 university of dar es salaam students were arrested yesterday after staging a demonstration to pile pressure on the government to disburse loans to all deserving students.the early morning protest was in solidarity with nearly 4,000 of their colleagues countrywide who have reportedly been denied state funding for their higher education requirements this financial year.

protesteridentity: legal and human rights centre lhrc , tanzania gender networking programme tgnp and tanzania media women association tamwa
sources: strike public anger over indecision the citizen dar es salaam , february 8, 2012 wednesday, 756 words, the citizen reporters ;
notes: the ongoing doctors strike took a dramatic twist yesterday when activists in dar es salaam took to the streets to protest what they termed government s failure to address the crisis decisively and avert deaths and suffering. this comes in the aftermath of a cabinet meeting that took place in dodoma on tuesday evening chaired by prime minister, mr mizengo pinda, who then flew to dar es salaam the next morning. his office did not, however, give details on the purpose of the impromptu journey. in dar es salaam the activists blocked a section of ali hassan mwinyi road at the busy selander bridge intersection for about an hour before police persuaded them to disperse. the marchers carried placards that criticised the government, accusing it of indecisiveness in the face of the ongoing doctors strike as innocent tanzanians continued to die at muhimbili national hospital. however, before they dispersed, the activists from 14 civil society organisations gave the government 24 hours to resolve the crisis. should the government fail to do to so, they vowed, marchers would return to the streets. their placards carried several messages including those calling on president jakaya kikwete to fire top official in the ministry of health and social welfare, including minister hadji mponda, his deputy dr lucy nkya, permanent secretary blandina nyoni and the chief government medical officer dr deo mutasiwa.

sources: protestors gunned down in songea the citizen dar es salaam , february 22, 2012 wednesday, 663 words, joyce joliga ;
notes: police in songea allegedly shot dead four civilians yesterday, during a fracas associated with a public demonstration against a reported string of murders over the past four months, that the law enforcement organ is accused of neither curbing nor resolving.in a quick rejoinder, however, ruvuma regional police commander michael kamuhanda put the figure of those who had died at two. several other people were injured when police officers used tear gas and live ammunition to quell angry demonstrators, some of whom had stormed the town s main police station.the ruvuma regional hospital chief medical officer, dr benedicto ngaiza, confirmed that the hospital had received four bodies and about 20 injured persons.

sources: 30 protesters held after cleric s arrest independent.co.uk, november 2, 2012 friday 4:49 pm gmt, africa, 237 words, fumbuka ng wanakilala ;
notes: muslim protesters clashed with police in the commercial capital, dar es salaam, today during a protest over the arrest of an islamic cleric. police fired tear gas and at least 30 people were arrested. similar demonstrations have erupted sporadically in recent weeks, raising religious tensions in the relatively stable and secular east african country. sheikh ponda issa ponda was arrested last month and charged with theft and trespass.

sources: island of ghosts; from the archive 8 december 2008: killing spree leaves albinos living in fear, the independent daily edition, december 6, 2017 wednesday, features; pg. 52, 1585 words, daniel howden;
notes: it is a sanctuary on the vast waters of lake victoria, a safe haven amid a gathering storm of killings. white skinned albinos, known here as ghosts , are being hunted down by their own people, harvested for body parts by those who believe they will add potency to black magic rituals. i had been brought to ukerewe by the tanzanian albino society, an organisation set up to fight discrimination which is entirely funded by the uk based charity action on disability and development, one of the three charities being supported by this year s the independent christmas appeal. beyond the shores of ukerewe, an even worse fate awaits. the one time zeru are hearing a different nickname called to them now, money : they are seen as walking bank notes. jospehat torner is attempting to document the horrific killing spree that has left albinos feeling terrified and hunted . mr torner is a leading campaigner with the tanzanian albino society, an organisation set up to fight discrimination that has found itself fighting for life itself. he says last week s murder of the 13 year old girl was typical. she had been tempted to leave the safety of her home to see a film about jesus being shown on a projector near to her village. all the local children went. on the way back, those he calls the greedy people got her. they chopped off her legs and her arms, he adds. the question, he says, is, who is the consumer of these body parts? when you go to the healers they say it s the fishermen; when you go to the fishermen they say it s the miners. and they blame the traditional healers. tas believes its mission to reach out to the multitude of albinos in tanzania and educate them, bring them into the open and teach them their rights is the only way to fight back in what has become a battle for survival. the non profit group does not have the resources to face the mounting crisis and has been utterly reliant on the british charity add action on disability and development . support for tas is vital if albinos are to secure the of basic human rights of safety, security and freedom, said add s acting chief executive, jabulani ncube. the president, jakaya kikwete, was guest of honour at the 19 october demonstration and has recently sponsored the country s first albino mp. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: island of ghosts; from the archive 8 december 2008: killing spree leaves albinos living in fear, the independent daily edition, december 6, 2017 wednesday, features; pg. 52, 1585 words, daniel howden;

when you go to the healers they say it s the fishermen; when you go to the fishermen they say it s the miners. and they blame the traditional healers. tas believes its mission to reach out to the multitude of albinos in tanzania and educate them, bring them into the open and teach them their rights is the only way to fight back in what has become a battle for survival. the non profit group does not have the resources to face the mounting crisis and has been utterly reliant on the british charity add action on disability and development . support for tas is vital if albinos are to secure the of basic human rights of safety, security and freedom, said add s acting chief executive, jabulani ncube. last month, when the death toll stood at 30, tas drew thousands of people to a protest march to highlight the killings. note: the actual date of the event was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: students demonstrate against election results. agence france presse english. 267 words. june 4, 1993 .;
notes: a thousand burundi university students held a silent protest friday after the election that gave the central african country its first president from the hutu majority, melchior ndadaye. students from different ethnic groups took part in the demonstration, where the watchword was that only the banners should speak, according to witnesses. banners dismissed the vote as an ethnic census of burundi.

sources: 5,000 protest ndadaye s ethnic based election victory. agence france presse english. 387 words. june 5, 1993 . ;
notes: up to 5,000 people, some ripping up their voter s card, demonstrated here saturday to protest the ethnic based election of melchior ndadaye as burundi s first president from the hutu ethnic majority. the protestors from the minority tutsi ethnic group carried banners attacking the ethnic character of the election, which gave ndadaye a 64.79 percent victory in tuesday s poll, according the latest official results published saturday.

sources: new president to amnesty 500 political and other prisoners. agence france presse english. 334 words. june 8, 1993 .;
notes: some 2,000 tutsi college and school students demonstrated in the capital earlier tuesday against ndadaye s election. on monday, police broke up a similar demonstration with tear gas.

sources: numerous protestors killed in bujumbura: bishop. agence france presse english. 174 words. october 22, 1993 .;
notes: a number of protestors were killed in the burundi capital bujumbura during a demonstration against the overthrow of president melchior ndadaye, bishop alfred ndoricimpa said here friday.

sources: anti junta protest in bujumbura as parties call general strike. agence france presse english. 880 words. october 24, 1993 .;
notes: nearly 1,000 youths marched through burundi s capital sunday in a demonstration against the coup in which president melchior ndadaye was reported killed, as four political parties called for a general strike.

sources: thousands demonstrate in burundi. agence france presse english. 480 words. october 26, 1993 . ;
notes: around 10,000 people staged a silent demonstration here tuesday against the military coup that has sparked a new wave of ethnic violence in burundi. demonstrators walked through the streets of the burundian capital that were otherwise quiet with public transport at a halt.

sources: demonstrators call on government to retake reins. agence france presse english. 854 words. october 28, 1993 . ;
notes: more than 10,000 burundis calmly took to the streets here thursday to urge government ministers to come out of hiding after last week s coup attempt, as the army chief assured the elected authorities of his support.

sources: thousands protest deployment of oau troops in burundi. agence france presse english. 414 words. december 27, 1993 .;
notes: thousands of anti government demonstrators took to the streets here to protest plans to deploy organisation of african unity oau troops in burundi in a bid to restore confidence in the wake of widespread ethnic carnage. answering an appeal by seven anti government parties, the demonstrators protested sunday the planned arrival of a 200 stong oau protection force, including 180 soldiers, shouting slogans claiming the deployment would turn burundi into a second somalia.

sources: 1. opposition protesters seal off burundi capital. agence france presse english. 1174 words. january 06, 1994 burundi demo lead 2 last . 2. thousands demonstrate in bujumbura. united press international. january 7, 1994 , friday, bc cycle : 145 words. 3. upi spotlight opposition leaders sought. united press international. january 8, 1994 , saturday, bc cycle : 215 words. ;
notes: thousands of opposition supporters erected barricades in burundi s capital bujumbura on thursday to protest the planned arrival of united nations forces, relief officials said. shops, schools and offices were closed, and young protesters manning barricades on the three main roads into bujumbura prevented traffic from leaving or entering the capital, said the officials, contacted by telephone in bujumbura.

sources: burundi opposition demonstrates for constitutional legality . agence france presse english. 280 words. january 12, 1994 15:13 eastern time .;
notes: around 2,000 opponents of assassinated burundi president melchior ndadaye held a demonstration here wednesday demanding what they called the immediate restoration of constitutional legality.

sources: 1. burundian opposition leader placed under house arrest: sources. agence france presse english. 2067 words. august 08, 1994 10:24 eastern time . 2. tensions high in burundi capital but no new violence. agence france presse english. 627 words. august 10, 1994 14:35 eastern time . 3. violence paralyzes the capital of burundi. the new york times. august 10, 1994 , wednesday, late edition final : 214 words.;
notes: the detention order against mathias hitimana, who heads the people s reconciliation party prp , was served sunday hours after around 500 youths held a demonstration in central bujumbura to protest the arrest of seven students, the source said. police dispersed sunday s demonstration with tear gas after the protestors erected street barricades in outlying districts of the city.

sources: striking students keep burundi on powderkeg. agence france presse english. 654 words. august 12, 1994 08:29 eastern time .;
notes: burundian students pursued a protest strike against the government on friday, raising the tension in a country fearful of an ethnic bloodbath after a murderous grenade attack in the capital. the students, mainly tutsi supporters of opposition parties, demanded the release of politician mathias hitimana, arrested on sunday after he organised a student demonstration which left 17 people dead.

protesteridentity: supporters of tutsi dominated main opposition party
sources: burundi: opposition calls demo to oust hutu speaker. agence france presse english. 360 words. december 05, 1994 04:27 eastern time .;
notes: supporters of burundi s tutsi dominated main opposition party rallied monday for a protest march to demand the resignation of the country s parliamentary speaker whom they accuse of inciting ethnic bloodshed.
burundian president sylvestre ntibantunganya renewed support for his prime minister on saturday as several hundred opposition members converged on central bujumbura to demand the premier s dismissal.

sources: 1. hutus and tutsis clash, tutsi students demonstrate. agence france presse english. 854 words. march 23, 1995 11:51 eastern time . 2. tutsi students hold threatening demonstration. agence france presse english. 840 words. march 23, 1995 07:22 eastern time .;
notes: with the tiny central african nation on the brink of a bloodbath, the 2,000 to 3,000 students accused the envoy, ahmedou ould abdallah of mauritania, of siding with armed hutu extremists. the students also demanded the resignation of president sylvestre ntibantunganya, a hutu, unless he provided details of the provenance of the arms being used by hutu gangs in clashes with tutsi militias which are sharpening fears that burundi may plunge into full scale civil war comparable to the one which tore neighbouring rwanda apart last year.

protesteridentity: tutsi university and secondary school students
sources: students demand justice in protest march. associated press worldstream. may 2, 1995 ; tuesday : 186 words.;
notes: some 3,000 university and secondary school students marched through burundi s capital tuesday, demanding justice for killers involved in mass slayings two years ago.

protesteridentity: youth solidarity for the defence of minorities sojedem
sources: 1. burundi tutsi extremists bring capital to a standstill. africa news. january, 1996 : 534 words. 2. tutsi extremists bring burundi capital to a halt. agence france presse english. 760 words. january 16, 1996 16:17 gmt .;
notes: the standstill was brought about without violence by a tutsi movement, youth solidarity for the defence of minorities sojedem , led by deo niyonzima and tutsi extremist organisations, which accuse ntibantunganya, a hutu in charge of a shaky coalition, of conniving with hutu extremist gangs fighting a guerrilla war against the tutsiwith its turnout early last week the army clearly distanced itself dominated army.

sources: burundians battle in north, protest in capital. january 18, 1996 , thursday, pm cycle : 653 words. ;
notes: in the capital bujumbura, soldiers marched through the streets today to disperse demonstrators bent on ousting president sylvestre ntibantunganya. about 200 tutsi youths gathered in the main square late in the morning, and offices and shops quickly closed their doors. within minutes, about 200 soldiers arrived, walking eight and 10 abreast through the streets with their automatic weapons raised. one soldier kicked a man who didn t get off the street fast enough.

protesteridentity: supporters of former president jean baptiste bagaza and people
sources: bujumbura protests against foreign military aid. agence france presse english. 400 words. june 29, 1996 29:19 gmt .;
notes: hundreds of demonstrators marched through bujumbura on saturday to protest against foreign military intervention to quell ethnic violence in burundi. the protestors, rallied by former president jean baptiste bagaza, converged on bujumbura football stadium where thousands of other supporters of the former leader were already assembled. bagaza, a tutsi, who exerts powerful influence in the tutsi dominated army and among young tutsis, has denounced the burundian government for calling for military assistance during a regional summit in arusha, northern tanzania, last tuesday.

sources: students protest foreign intervention in burundi conflict. agence france presse. july 04, 1996 : 182 words.;
notes: several hundred tutsi students from the university of bujumbura protested here thursday against the possibility of a foreign military peacekeeping force being deployed in their strife torn country. the students called for the immediate departure of genocidal president sylvestre ntibantunganya, a hutu, and expressed strong support for the tutsi dominated armed forces.

sources: tutsis march in protest in burundi capital. agence france presse. july 05, 1996 : 402 words. ;
notes: tutsi opponents of burundi s hutu president sylvestre ntibantunganya took to the streets of bujumbura on friday to protest against all foreign intervention in their violence wracked nation. some 2,000 to 3,000 were seen taking part in the demonstration, although organizers mainly tutsi political parties claimed that the turnout was in excess of 10,000.

sources: burundi workers protest against killings in burundi. africa news. july, 1996 : 307 words.;
notes: activities ground to a halt in bujumbura friday, as workers in strifethe work stoppage was organized workers union to protest the death of about 100 workers killed last week in the central town of teza, in an attack on a tea packaging factory. the unions have urged government officials to abandon their ambivalent attitude to the crisis in the country and put an end to the continuing massacres.

sources: 1. burundi; burundi youths oppose security assistance. africa news. july 16, 1996 : 387 words. 2. burundi youth stage new march against foreign intervention plan. agence france presse. july 16, 1996 : 297 words. ;
notes: some 2,500 burundian students, pupils and jobless people demonstrated in bujumbura monday in opposition to proposals for a regional military force that is to try and restore order in the country.

sources: 10,000 demonstrate against foreign troops in burundi. july 19, 1996 , friday, am cycle : 456 words. by stefan lovgren, associated press writer ;
notes: vowing to resist foreign military intervention, some 10,000 protesters marched friday through the streets and called for the overthrow of the coalition government. it was the largest demonstration since hutu president silvestre ntibantunganya and tutsi prime minister antoine nduwayo appealed june 25 for outside assistance which they later acknowledged would be military aid to end ethnic violence in the tiny central african nation. the united nations also has called for international help.

sources: ap photo buj101 103 associated press international, february 26, 2000; saturday, international news, 524 words, hrvoje hranjski ;
notes: anti riot police and soldiers on saturday dispersed a thousand, mainly tutsi, demonstrators who crowded into a downtown quarter of the capital in defiance of the government to air their opposition to peace talks with hutu rebels. before the gun and baton wielding security forces broke up the rally near bujumbura s central market, the protesters waved placards condemning negotiations with hutu political and rebel leaders, whom they called the perpetrators of genocide against minority tutsis. as policemen pummeled protesters after cornering them in the street, about a dozen of protesters were whisked away in police cars. shop owners closed their doors and onlookers fled to their houses.

sources: burundi trade unions launch strike over government failure agence france presse english, 184 words calls for strike ignored by capital s workers associated press international, august 18, 2000; friday, international news, 1480 words, jocelyne sambira ;
notes: hundreds of people marched through the streets of the burundian capital friday after trade unions in the war torn country launched an open ended strike to protest at the failure of the current government. the government is violating union rights... the economy has broken down, citizens can no longer meet their basic needs, said a statement from the country s main trade union grouping, the confederation of burundi trade unions, cosybu. police were out around the protesters.

sources: protests against burundi peace deal, president raises doubts over signing agence france presse english, 393 words burundi s tutsis protest peace talks with hutu rebels associated press international, august 19, 2000; saturday, international news, 616 words, hrvoje hranjski ;
notes: several hundred people marched through the city centre here saturday to protest against the government and the peace talks aimed at ending burundi s seven year civil war. over a two hour period, police dispersed demonstrators who tried to reach two main squares. there were few clashes as the protestors melted away into the crowd at a market when police intervened. police used tear gas once against a group of people trying to reach the market square while shouting anti arusha slogans.

sources: tutsi demonstrators arrested in burundi agence france presse english, 406 words ;
notes: up to 40 members of a radical tutsi party were arrested here saturday for trying to demonstrate against the dissolution of the country s army, which they say is the only shield against the genocide of their people. a heavy riot police detail was deployed on independence square, where members of parena party for national recovery had tried to mount their protest. party secretary general remy nkengurutse said about a dozen party activists had been arrested, some in pre dawn raids on their homes.

sources: ten arrested at demo by radical tutsis in burundi agence france presse english, 226 words ;
notes: ten radical tutsi militants and a correspondent for the associated press news agency were arrested by gendarmes in burundi at a demonstration against the arusha peace accord, witnesses said thursday. ap correspondent aloys niyoyita, who was released six hours later, told afp he had been beaten and abused by the gendarmes. some 100 protesters took part in the demonstration, organised by power of self defence amasekanya, which groups young tutsis opposed to the arusha peace accord signed in august 2000.

sources: youth injured as police open fire on burundi demo agence france presse english, april 28, 2002 sunday, international news, 264 words ;
notes: burundian police on sunday opened fire on a group of some 5,000 high school students who were staging a protest to demand payment for cleaning up the capital, bujumbura, one of the protesters told afp. but interior minister salvator ntihabose said a 13 year old youth who was injured when the demonstration was violently dispersed was not fired on by the police.

sources: three police injured in clashes with burundi school children agence france presse english, may 21, 2002 tuesday, international news, 197 words police, schoolchildren clash in burundi agence france presse english, may 22, 2002 wednesday, international news, 178 words three school children injured in clashes with police in burundi agence france presse english, may 23, 2002 thursday, international news, 267 words ;
notes: police in burundi fired in the air wednesday to disperse 1,000 secondary school pupils demonstrating for a solution to end a strike by their teachers, government officials told afp. it was the second day of clashes between the pupils and security forces. wednesday s unrest took place in the central town of gigega, where the children were trying to gather in the town s centre, according to a local administrator.

sources: burundi police disperse hundreds of protesting moped taxi drivers agence france presse english, november 20, 2002 wednesday, international news, 238 words ;
notes: police in burundi s capital used baton charges wednesday to disperse hundreds of moped taxi drivers who were protesting against a ban on their trade, an afp journalist reported. several policemen were hurt by stones. the drivers were demonstrating for a second day in front of the interior ministry when about 30 police officers charged and struck out with their batons. the protesters, who numbered about 500 according to police, responded by throwing stones.

sources: burundi police shoot in air to break up cycle taxi drivers demo agence france presse english, november 13, 2003 thursday, international news, 294 words ;
notes: police in burundi s capital fired into the air thursday to disperse hundreds of bicycle taxi operators protesting against a ban imposed to prevent rebel incursions. in several parts of the city, police clashed with the taxi operators, some of whom had vented their anger on other cyclists delivering goods rather than passengers and who were not subject to the ban. they slashed tyres, spilled milk churns and in some cases beat up the riders.

sources: burundi peasants protest to demand restitution of seized land agence france presse english, february 19, 2004 thursday, international news, 247 words burundi peasants end nine day sit in over seized land agence france presse english, february 25, 2004 wednesday, international news, 168 words ;
notes: about 100 peasants from southwest burundi thursday entered the fourth day of a sit in in front of the agriculture ministry in bujumbura to demand the government restore land they say was seized from them. we are owners of land in gatakwa since 1982, we have developed these marshes and today eager officials have dispossessed us and divided up this land, said one of the demonstrators, egide ntabandi, 45. the peasants, including women with babies on their backs, arrived from gatakwa, about 100 kilometers 60 miles south of the capital, to begin the sit in on monday morning. they spend the night under the stars, wash their laundry and spread it out atop the hedges, and say they are determined that justice will be done, said ntabandi. the government on wednesday established a mediation committee to solve the gatakwa problem once and for all, said the committee s chairman, anicet niyongabo, governor of bururi, which includes gatakwa.

sources: burundi releases prison mutineers in amnesty spat agence france presse english english, 366 words five thousand prisoners demand release in burundi agence france presse english english, 352 words prison protests spread in burundi agence france presse english english, 465 words, esdras ndikumana burundi minister appeals in vain to prisoners to end protests agence france presse english english, 577 words police storm jail in burundi agence france presse english english, 301 words ;
notes: about five thousand prisoners held in burundi s largest jails and accused of offences related to the central african country s civil war have demanded their freedom, a rights group said. the detainees, most of whom have not yet been brought to trial, consider themselves to be political prisoners and object to getting different treatment from politicians granted immunity under a peace pact signed in 2000.

sources: ex burundi fighters occupy building to protest at delayed demobilization payments bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, february 22, 2007 thursday, 180 words ;
notes: on prince louis rwagasore road at the inss building, everything was fine except after the clash between police and several hundred demobilized former fighters. the building which is occupied by us ngo padco expansions untraced and is located on the road mentioned was besieged by several hundred angry demobilized former fighters starting this morning. in the building s corridors, the inner court and the parking was full of former fighters who refused workers entry. police who intervened a little late were almost unable to eject them from the building and opted to negotiate with them to secure the people who had been taken hostage.

sources: burundian police break up protest over arrest of ex party head agence france presse english, may 9, 2007 wednesday 3:43 pm gmt, 303 words ;
notes: burundian police used clubs and belts to break up a protest wednesday in support of the former head of the president s political party, who was arrested last month. dozens of police officers charged the crowd of hundreds in the capital, resulting in several injuries, including a woman who fainted for several minutes, an afp journalist saw. it s unacceptable. the police do not have the right to charge people who are demonstrating peacefully, said pierre claver mbonimpa, head of the association for the defense of detained persons and human rights.

sources: 18 high school students hurt in burundi demo agence france presse english, november 1, 2007 thursday 3:54 pm gmt, 188 words ;
notes: eighteen students were injured on thursday in a clash with police when they marched on burundi s education ministry to protest at poor food in their technical college, students and officials said. the high school students came from bubanza, 35 kilometres about 20 miles north of bujumbura, where they wanted to march on the ministry of education, bubanza provincial governor pascal nyabenda told afp. i couldn t allow that, so i asked the police to stop them, he said, while protesting students said the police did so by opening fire and clubbing some of them with batons at mpanda, 12 kilometres outside the capital.

sources: prisoners in protest demo in burundi jail: official agence france presse english, april 22, 2008 tuesday 6:08 pm gmt, 282 words ;
notes: about 2,500 burundian prisoners rioted in the country s largest jail, leading police to intervene with tear gas, a prison official said tuesday. many of the inmates of mpimba jail in the capital bujumbura barricaded themselves off late monday against warders trying to restore order and tried to break doors. police had to be called in during the night, said anaclet gasanirwa, director of correctional facilities.

sources: police fire at burundi student demo: witnesses agence france presse english, may 14, 2008 wednesday 4:18 pm gmt, 161 words burundi: three injured as university students demo turns violent bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, may 14, 2008 wednesday, 79 words ;
notes: demonstrations held in burundi today degenerated resulting in three people, including a police officer, being injured. the demonstrations were held by students in the capital, bujumbura, to demand an increase in their university allowances. policemen intervened and dispersed them using truncheons and tear gas.

sources: burundi opposition chief charged with contempt for president: lawyer agence france presse english, november 11, 2008 tuesday 2:49 pm gmt, 320 words ;
notes: a burundi opposition leader was on tuesday charged with contempt for the president, his lawyer said, following his november 3 arrest alongside 37 party members for holding an illegal meeting. dozens of policemen were deployed near the court where around 150 supporters gathered to protest against alexis sinduhije s arrest.

sources: hundreds protest burundi opposition leader trial agence france presse english, november 28, 2008 friday 4:49 pm gmt, 295 words ;
notes: hundreds of burundians gathered in a show of support for opposition party leader and former journalist alexis sinduhije, whose trial on charges of contempt for the president opened here friday. more than 100 burundian police forces, some of them in anti riot gear, had gathered since the early morning to bar demonstrators from approaching the high court in the capital bujumbura. what the police is doing here is a violation of the law... all this further proves that it is a political trial, francois nyamoya, a close friend of sinduhije s, told afp.

sources: thousands of burundians turn out for anti gay demo agence france presse english, march 6, 2009 friday 6:56 pm gmt, 389 words burundians demonstrate to outlaw homosexuality the vancouver sun british columbia , march 7, 2009 saturday, canada & world; in brief; pg. b11, 57 words, vancouver sun ;
notes: thousands of burundians demonstrated friday in the capital to demand the outlawing of homosexuality after senators rejected a draft law last month that would criminalize the act. up to 20,000 people turned out for the government planned protest against homosexuality, which organizers described as a foreign practice that is tarnishing morals.

sources: burundi child soldiers mutiny over camp conditions agence france presse english, may 5, 2009 tuesday 4:32 pm gmt, 275 words ;
notes: hundreds of former child soldiers for burundi rebels staged a mutiny at a demobilisation camp to demand better conditions, an official said tuesday. some 340 child soldiers from the national liberation forces fnl , burundi s last active rebel group, have been in gitega, 100 kilometers 60 miles east of bujumbura, since early april awaiting demobilisation. the 340 child soldiers gathered at gitega demobilisation centre mutinied yesterday evening, head of the centre romain ndagabwa, told afp in a telephone interview.

sources: arrests after burundi demo turns violent agence france presse english, april 20, 2010 tuesday 12:40 pm gmt, 319 words ;
notes: former burundi rebels clashed with riot police when a protest in the capital bujumbura turned violent and eight people were arrested, police said tuesday. police spokesman pierre chanel ntarabaganyi said that about 300 members of the former national liberation forces fnl were involved in the violence during monday s protest and that police intervened to restore calm and arrested eight ring leaders. demonstrators threw stones at police and passing cars, said ntarabaganyi, adding that in any case, the protest was illegal . the police charged while we were calmly asking for our money, they beat us, threw tear gas and pursued us to the market place, said david, a 25 year old former fighter who declined to give his full name. hundreds of the former fighters had demonstrated outside the offices of the service responsible for demobilising fighters from the small central african country s 13 years of civil war.

sources: post vote clashes erupt in burundi agence france presse english, may 29, 2010 saturday 10:13 pm gmt, 352 words ;
notes: clashes erupted in burundi s capital saturday in the first violence linked to last week s disputed local polls, with several people wounded and arrested, an opposition party and officials said. the election commission has announced the ruling party won more than 60 percent of monday s vote but eight opposition groups allege there was massive fraud and have demanded a re run. the opposition national liberation forces fnl said people began demonstrating in bujumbura s kinama quarter when they found several ballot boxes filled with balloting papers, some of them not counted.

sources: burundi police block demo agence france presse english, april 8, 2011 friday 3:09 pm gmt, 304 words ;
notes: burundi s police on friday blocked a demonstration organised to demand justice for an assassinated anti corruption activist and briefly detained two activists. the demonstration had been organised to commemorate the second anniversary of the murder of ernest manirumva, a former deputy of the central african country s olucome corruption watchdog who was stabbed to death in 2009. we don t understand why the regime is preventing us from marching to demand justice for the third time in a year. it is a right enshrined in the constitution, pacifique nininahazwe, who heads a civil society platform of some 150 associations and non governmental organisations, told afp. we want justice to be done, because two years after his death, the trial hasn t produced anything, he said in bujumbura, where a small group of demonstrators were barred from holding their march.

sources: burundi journalists demonstrate for freedom agence france presse english, may 3, 2011 tuesday 1:18 pm gmt, 307 words ;
notes: about 100 journalists marched here tuesday to press for the release of a jailed colleague, the decriminalisation of press offences and to mark world press freedom day. we re demonstrating, on the international day for press freedom, to demand first and foremost the release of our colleague, jean claude kavumbagu, who has been jailed for months and risks a life sentence, alexandre niyungeko, the president of the burundian union of journalists, told afp. the state prosecutor in mid april called for life imprisonment for kavumbagu, who has been in detention since july 2010, accused of treason for having doubted the ability of burundi s security forces to prevent an attack by somali insurgents on burundian soil.

sources: inmates riot at burundi s ruyigi prison over deteriorating living conditions xinhua general news service, may 17, 2011 tuesday 11:40 am est, world news, 197 words ;
notes: at least 900 inmates detained at ruyigi prison with a capacity of 300 on tuesday morning rioted to protest against deteriorating living conditions, local media reported. media quoted prisoners as saying that they have spent a whole week without receiving beans rations, the staple food in the prison of ruyigi. the inmates rioted in an attempt to get out of the prison and the deteriorating living conditions.

sources: burundi lawyers strike over arrest of colleague agence france presse english, july 25, 2011 monday 6:10 pm gmt, 165 words ;
notes: lawyers in burundi announced a week long strike on monday in protest at the arrest of one of their colleagues for complicity in espionnage . around 100 lawyers gathered outside the courthouse in the capital bujumbura in support of suzanne bukuru, who was arrested and imprisoned on july 15 for helping french journalists get an interview with victims she is representing in a rape trial involving a french man, according to legal sources.

sources: prosecutor insists on life sentence for burundian journalist agence france presse english, november 9, 2012 friday 4:59 pm gmt, 413 words ;
notes: a prosecutor friday asked an appeal cout to uphold the life sentence handed to burundian journalist hassan ruvakuki over terrorism charges. hassan ruvakuki is a terrorist, said prosecutor emmanuel nyandwi on the last day of an appeal hearing in gitega, central burundi. he does not have the right to hide behind his journalism profession to kill. that is why i ask the court to uphold the life sentence which was given to him the first time, added nyandwi amid protests by crowds gathered in and out of the courtroom.

sources: burundi, a nation divided over land agence france presse english, june 7, 2013 friday 2:52 am gmt, 790 words ;
notes: both have a case to make, but some see the government s national commission for land and property cntb as favouring one side over the other, said pacifique ninahazwe, a prominent civil society figure. the cntb is increasingly deciding in favour of returnees and ethnic hutu more generally, rather than recognising that both returnees and residents face problems, ninahazwe told afp. if this continues it will lead to other potentially devastating conflicts. in one recent case in burundi s capital bujumbura, riots broke out as police tried to evict a tutsi family from their house in order to give it back to a hutu family, former residents 40 years ago. we are here to oppose injustice, to oppose the cntb, which is undermining reconciliation in burundi society, shouted a member of the thousand or so youths who gathered at the protest. in that case, the standoff lasted six hours, left more than a dozen people hurt and resulted in the arrest of 20 youths.

sources: two dead, 16 wounded in burundi prison riots: police agence france presse english, august 9, 2013 friday 8:47 am gmt, 243 words 2 killed in burundi s prison clashes xinhua general news service, august 9, 2013 friday 7:42 pm est, world news; political, 216 words ;
notes: rioting broke out in two overcrowded prisons in burundi, leaving one civilian and one inmate dead and at least 16 others wounded, a police spokesman said friday. at mpimba prison, the country s largest, in the capital bujumbura, police stepped in to put down the rioting on thursday, and two people were killed by the rioters, the spokesman, pierre nkurikiye told afp. it happened as some 100 muslims were visiting the prison to pray with inmates at the end of the islamic holy month of ramadan. two people were killed one of the muslims who was visiting and one detainee, killed by rioters, nkurikiye said.

sources: burundian party holds anti government demo in bujumbura. bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring. march 5, 2014 wednesday : 359 words.;
notes: uprona union for national progress , the main tutsi party in burundi, held a demonstration yesterday to demand an end to government interference in political parties. it has been a month since the party leader was removed from office by the authorities and president pierre nkurunziza s party wants to impose a former member of the party who is reputed to be in close ties with the government to occupy the vacated post.

sources: several injured in burundian capital following police, opposition group clashes. bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring. march 9, 2014 sunday : 355 words.;
notes: everything began at dawn when thousands of youths of the msd opposition party tried to converge in the heart of the city of bujumbura clashed with hundreds of policemen who were deployed to the strategic areas of the burundian capital who dispersed them with teargas. initially, the movement for solidarity and democracy activists wanted to demonstrate to condemn the constant violations of civil and collective liberties in bangui as received , namely the right to hold meetings and to stage demonstrations.

sources: burundi mob tries to stone female police officer to death. the times london , may 13, 2015 wednesday, news; pg. 39, jessica hatcher;
notes: protesters in burundi s capital overran a police line firing live rounds yesterday and tried to stone to death a female officer who they caught and accused of shooting a demonstrator. as the police cordon broke under a hail of missiles, the woman and two male officers ran for their lives, pursued by screaming youths for 500 metres, before she was caught and her colleagues, who had initially tried to protect her, fled. after weeks of protests against the president s plans to run for a third term, in which police have killed about 20 people and thousands have fled the country, the mob in bujumbura wanted revenge...young women and children began gathering stones as the mob punched the woman, who was later identified as commander medikintos inabeza, 34. then a middle aged man emerged from the crowd, shielded the officer and managed to talk round the baying crowd. the protesters then carried her writhing body back towards nearby police and dumped her. she later limped away. the protesters oppose the president s bid to run for a third term...after two weeks of continuous unrest, the government has given the police and military a 48 hour deadline to clear the capital of barricades. as dawn broke yesterday, the main road in buterere, one of two neighbourhoods that have been turned into police no go zones, was blocked by blackened tree trunks, lines of rocks and a blue shipping container that previously housed a bakery. the 100 strong police deployment that arrived to remove the barriers was soon confronted by a large and ferocious crowd determined to keep them out. thousands of protesters surged towards the police, hurling stones, and the officers responded by shooting live rounds into the air. after almost an hour of clashes, the police retreated, overwhelmed. at least two protesters died of bullet wounds. the police said that they had shown restraint as they had been shot at with a hunting rifle and had not fired directly at demonstrators...

sources: 1 president has been removed from power, general says. the new york times, may 14, 2015 thursday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 7, by isma il kushkush; sadi niyungeko contributed reporting from bujumbura, burundi; 2 opposition activists in burundi fear crackdown after president s return. the new york times, may 16, 2015 saturday, section ; column 0; foreign desk; open source; by robert mackey;
notes: 1 it was not immediately clear whether the general had the backing of the army, or whether a coup had been carried out successfully. but soon after the announcement, police officers who had been clashing with protesters in downtown bujumbura began withdrawing, while demonstrators honked car horns, took photographs and cheered. a popular radio station that had been shut down by the government went back on the air...hundreds have been demonstrating in the capital for more than two weeks against the president s bid for a third term... ; 2 gathered again on wednesday, just before the attempted coup was announced, the demonstrators were attacked by the police with tear gas and water cannons...

sources: hundreds take to streets in burundian capital, defying officials. the new york times, may 19, 2015 tuesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 8, by isma il kushkush;
notes: hundreds of protesters took to the streets across the capital on monday, despite officials warnings against demonstrations after a failed coup last week. our politics are different, protesters chanted in the local kirundi language, as some stomped in unison, clapped, blew whistles, raised hands and carried branches. our politics are different because we are against corruption, said arakata bonfils, 32. the president has become a king. ...on monday morning, many shops here in the capital, bujumbura, remained closed, public buses were scarce and army patrols roamed through town. in areas where protests were expected, soldiers were heavily armed. in the working class neighborhood musaga, demonstrators started to gather in the midmorning, carrying banners that read, no to a third term and no war in french. a soldier fired warning shots that dispersed the crowd, at least for a few moments...protesters slowly trickled back, burning tires, setting up a roadblock of stones, branches and trash, chanting and singing choir songs and the national anthem. as one group of soldiers tried to manage the protest, another unit without numbers on their uniforms walked up from behind, cocking their guns and igniting a quarrel. that led the first group to plead with them to back off...
