notes: paving stones and a tire fire at an antigovernment protest friday in bujumbura. parliamentary elections are set for monday

sources: schoolchildren arrested in burundi for defacing pictures of president pierre nkurunziza telegraph.co.uk, june 3, 2016 friday 9:24 pm gmt, 425 words, by agence france presse;
notes: eleven high school students in a city in central burundi were detained and charged on friday with defacing a photo of president pierre nkurunziza, a police official said, as three people were shot and injured in a protest at the arrests. hundreds of students at muramvya municipal high school immediately rallied to demand the release of the 11, witnesses said. policemen in the burundi secret service opened fire to disperse the protest, said one source.

protesteridentity: republican democratic movement, liberal party, social democrat party
sources: opposition holds first mass demonstration in rwanda agence france presse english, 226 words ;
notes: some 25,000 people staged an impressive march for democracy in rwanda here sunday at the call of three opposition parties. the march called by the republican democratic movement, the liberal party and the social democrat party was the first ever opposition demonstration in rwanda. the newly registered rwandan socialist party also joined in the demonstration. demonstrators bore placards hostile to the ruling and formerly sole party, the rwandan movement for national development, and called for the holding of a national conference. the main purpose of the march was to protest against monopolisation of the broadcast media by the party, against use of state vehicles for ruling party rallies and against intimidation of opposition sympathisers.

sources: opposition, security forces, clash for second day the associated press, may 29, 1992, friday, pm cycle, international news, 284 words ;
notes: police wielding tear gas canisters and batons today clashed with thousands of anti government demonstrators, one day after riots left at least five dead and dozens wounded, state radio rwanda reported. troops fired in the air to disperse about 2,000 protesters who stoned vehicles and set up roadblocks, witnesses said. several shops and vehicles were looted and businesses remained closed for a second day.

protesteridentity: coalition for the defense of the republic
sources: clashes kill 3 in rwanda the associated press, august 4, 1992, tuesday, am cycle, international news, 182 words ;
notes: since the protesters had weapons but it doesn t say what the police action was, the protesting is deemed violent while state response is deemed crowd dispersal. protesters wielding sticks, knives and clubs clashed with police in rwanda s capital tuesday, leaving three people dead and at least six injured, radio rwanda reported. the state owned station said the dead were a policeman and two members of the coalition for the defense of the republic, considered an extremist group. the broadcast said about 500 young party members armed with sticks, knives and clubs gathered in front of the ministry of justice in kigali and blocked the road with stones and logs. they were demanding the release of party members jailed on charges of participating in violent protests. the party is dominated by rwanda s majority ethnic group, the hutus, and is allied to the national republican movement for democracy and development party of president juvenal habyarimana.

protesteridentity: the mdr, the liberal party pl , the social democrat party psd , and the christian democrat party pdc
sources: 10,000 demonstrate after seven die in kigali agence france presse english, 201 words ;
notes: anti riot police being deployed sends the message they had the intent to disperse the crowd if needed nearly 10,000 people thronged into the streets of kigali thursday to demonstrate against insecurity in rwanda, where seven people have died in political clashes since monday, informed sources said. rioters barricaded all the roads leading to the area. the demonstrators in kigali responded to a call from the opposition parties, which all participate in the transition government: the mdr, the liberal party pl , the social democrat party psd , and the christian democrat party pdc . they carried banners reading elections after national reconciliation , we protest against terrorism , the people must be protected . some of the demonstrators were armed with sticks, clubs and stones while anti riot forces were deployed in all areas of the capital.

sources: demonstration blocks lifeline trade route in rwanda xinhua general news service, january 12, 1993, tuesday, 222 words ;
notes: since they were able to block the trade route, i have determined this as 50 there is no way to tell where exactly on the kibungo rusumo road in rwanda the youths are protesting, so i have left the location as simply the road and the region the road runs through young supporters of the rwandan president juvenial habyarimana blocked the country s lifeline trade route to tanzania on monday to protest against what they described as his minority rule in an interim government, according to a report reaching here today. the young people belonging to the ruling national movement for democracy and development mrnd went on the rampage on the main kibungo rusumo road which links rwanda with tanzania, said the report. the youths beat up people and looted property and cars, forcing the closure of the vital route for the tiny central african state s tea and coffee exports and most imports. the protest followed the signing of a power sharing protocol last weekend by the rwandan government and the rebel rwanda patriotic front rpf . the rpf, made up mainly of exiled tutsi tribesmen, invaded rwanda from neighboring uganda in october 1990 in an attempt to topple the government of president habyarimana.

protesteridentity: youths of national republican movement for democracy and development mrnd
sources: demonstrators paralyze rwanda s capital the associated press, january 20, 1993, wednesday, am cycle, international news, 294 words, by manasses mugabo, associated press writer protests against deal with rebels leave two dead agence france presse english, 93 words ;
notes: since all of the roads were blocked, i have coded this as 50 president juvenal habyarimana s supporters paralyzed the capital wednesday in a third day of demonstrations against an agreement to end more than two years of rebellion. at least three people were killed, witnesses said. armed with sticks, machetes, spears and wooden clubs, the demonstrators blocked all roads from kigali to this tiny central africa nation s 10 provinces. witnesses said at least three people were killed in clashes among supporters of different political parties. the demonstrators say the rebel rwandese patriotic front got too many seats in an interim government proposed in a peace pact jan. 12. the demonstrations were organised in eight districts of the small highland nation by the youth wing of president juvenal habyarimana s national republican movement for democracy and development mrnd .

sources: 50,000 protest political, ethnic violence the associated press, january 31, 1993, sunday, am cycle, international news, 230 words rwanda says 300 killed in clashes, 4,400 displaced the associated press, february 7, 1993, sunday, am cycle, international news, 266 words, by manasses mugabo, associated press writer ;
notes: an estimated 50,000 people marched in kigali on sunday to protest ethnic and political violence that has claimed dozens, if not hundreds of lives in the past 10 days. most of the demonstrators in the rwandan capital were supporters of four opposition parties, three of them partners in president juvenal habyarimana s coalition government. the protesters marched for five miles holding placards blaming habyarimana for the killings and urging support for peace talks between the government and the rebel rwandese patriotic front. the government also ordered the interior minister to suspend local officials who were implicated in the killings or failed to maintain order.

protesteridentity: fawe, the rwanda association of university women, national youth council, care, new dawn associates, plan rwanda and she
sources: activists call for tax waiver on sanitary pads. the new times kigali , march 26, 2010 friday, irene v. nambi;
notes: based on stunning survey results which revealed that half the number of girls in school miss classes due to lack of sanitary pads, hundreds of activists from various organizations yesterday took to the streets to advocate for lower or no taxes on the towels. as they held their placards high with messages like remove taxation on sanitary pads to keep the girl child in school and improve women s health , the group emphasized the need to also break silence on menstruation...according to officials, all prices of sanitary pads include an 18 percent value added tax vat which makes it expensive for thousands of girls and women countrywide. organized by fawe, the rwanda association of university women, national youth council, care, new dawn associates, plan rwanda and she, the march began at the kigali business centre and proceeded to petit stade amahoro.

protesteridentity: association of students survivors of the genocide aerg , association of former students survivors of genocide gaerg , kigali youth forum, and forum for rwanda university students assembly fager ?
sources: youth demand govt withdraws bbc licence the new times kigali , october 23, 2014, 924 words, edwin musoni genocide rura bans bbc kinyarwanda the new times kigali , october 25, 2014, 955 words, edwin musoni ;
notes: thousands of youth yesterday staged a protest to demonstrate their disapproval of a british broadcasting corporation bbc documentary they say is an attempt to revise the 1994 genocide against the tutsi, demanding that government cancels the public broadcaster s operation licence in the country. the demonstration was organised by association of students survivors of the genocide aerg , association of former students survivors of genocide gaerg , kigali youth forum, and forum for rwanda university students assembly fager . rwanda utilities regulatory authority rura yesterday suspended bbc kinyarwanda service over a series of programmes by the british broadcaster which genocide survivors and activists say minimise the 1994 genocide against the tutsi. on the basis of that documentary, we have seen massive protests from women, youth and mps expressing outrage against the bbc documentary. we had to take a decision in the interest of protecting our citizens and the principles of unity and reconciliation, he said. bbc broadcasts in rwanda on the basis of bilateral agreement signed in 1997. part of article 01 of the agreement reads that: the bbc shall, in respect of broadcast of its programmes, respect the people s right to information and to balanced and objective reporting. not to broadcast any material which is likely to incite hatred, violence and division .

sources: genocide rura bans bbc kinyarwanda the new times kigali , october 25, 2014, 955 words, edwin musoni ;
notes: the decision was announced hours after members of avega agahozo, the umbrella association of genocide widows, and other women added their voice to calls for stern action against bbc, during a protest in kigali. in a related development, over 2000 women yesterday mounted a protest against the same documentary and petitioned the parliament to push for a ban on bbc and seek an official apology. their petition was received by the senate president bernard makuza who promised to look into it.

sources: somali capital calming down xinhua general news service, july 15, 1990, sunday, 203 words ;
notes: the somali capital city of mogadishu is calming down after the government announced the release of signitories of a manifesto. but scattered gun shots can still be heard in some areas. a mass riot took place in many areas of mogadishu this morning and thousands of people took to the streets around 10:00 hours to demostrate against the government. the demonstrators chanted anti government slogans and threw stones at security police and cars. some cars were overturned and burned. the riot took place when the somali security court started the trial of the signitories who signed and distributed a hardworded manifesto. the manifesto called for the change of the present government of president mohamed siad barre. radio mogadishu said this afternoon that the security police shot into the air to restore peace and no one was killed in the crackdown. but some eyewitnesses said some policemen fired at the demonstrators and a number of people were killed and wounded.

sources: fuel price increases lead to riots in mogadishu xinhua general news service, august 8, 1990, wednesday, 148 words ;
notes: since riot police were necessary to quell the riots, this has been determined to include 50 protesters. riots broke out today in the somali capital of mogadishu following the fuel price increases by the government tuesday. owners of public transport vehicles staged a strike early this monring, demanding the government to increase the fare to compensate the fuel price hikes. thousands of people were stranded at bus stops and some of them threw stones at moving cars. police in full battle uniform were soon deployed at road junctions and opened fire to quell the riots.but no casualties have been reported so far. gunshots can still be heard in the evening in some areas of the capital. the government announced yesterday that the price for one litre of petrol increased from about 300 somali shillings to 510 and diesel from about 250 shillings to 386. it said that the hikes were caused by the recent increase of world oil price and the devaluation of the somali currency.

sources: anti government riot breaks out in mogadishu xinhua general news service, october 23, 1990, tuesday, 209 words somalia releases 1,000 prisoners xinhua general news service, november 7, 1990, wednesday, 63 words ;
notes: since this is the largest anti government riot since 1969, this has been deemed large enough to code, although it is possibly probably more than 50 . at least one policeman was killed and three others injured in a crack down on an antigovernment demonstration which turned violent in the somali capital mogadishu today. several government cars were burnt and some buildings damaged, but no reliable figures of the casualities of the demonstrators were immediately known. witnesses said the demonstration, announced several days ago by leaflets issued by unidentified anti government organizations, started here this morning. a clash broke out when policemen tried to stop the demonstrators from marching to the center of the city. the demonstrators threw stones at policemen, who in return opened fire, mostly to the sky. gun shots were heard in many parts of the city in the morning and all shops closed. anti government leaflets said that the demonstration was staged to demand the release of all political prisoners in somalia and give support to those political prisoners who are holding a hunger strike in mogadishu for their early release. local journalists described the anti government riot as the biggest in somalia since president siad barre came to power in 1969. the situation in mogadishu calmed down in the afternoon but gun shots could still be heard in many areas of the city. the somali government announced tuesday that 1,122 prisoners will be released to mark the country s 21st anniversary of revolution. somali attorney general ahmed hassan sheikh said in a statement tuesday that among the first prisoners to be released will be nine political detainees who went on hunger strike last month in protest against their detention without trial.

sources: shells explode on somali peace demonstrators, two injured agence france presse english, 334 words ;
notes: this protest is coded as anti government because the warlord aidid is the self proclaimed ruler. at least two women were injured when shells exploded near a group of women taking part in an anti war demonstration in south mogadishu on monday, witnesses said. the estimated 100 women were demonstrating against bloody clashes between militias loyal to warlord mohamed farah aidid and those of his former financier and fellow habr gedir clansman, osman hassan ali atto.

sources: hundreds demonstrate against price rise of khat in somali capital agence france presse, november 11, 1996, international news, 327 words ;
notes: hundreds of angry traders, most of them businesswomen, took to the streets of the somali capital on sunday and monday to demonstrate against a steep rise in the price of khat, a stimulant plant chewed in somalia and the gulf region. similar demonstrations against the price rise were also held in two days ago in hargeisa, the capital of the breakaway self declared republic of somaliland, which has yet to receive international recognition. there were conflicting reports on the reason for the price rise, with others attributing it to an increase in taxes levied by the kenyan government, while others blamed the government of hussein mohamed aidid.

sources: hundreds demonstrate against price rise of khat in somali capital agence france presse, november 11, 1996, international news, 327 words ;
notes: hundreds of angry traders, most of them businesswomen, took to the streets of the somali capital on sunday and monday to demonstrate against a steep rise in the price of khat, a stimulant plant chewed in somalia and the gulf region. during their two hour march on monday, the protesters were joined by hundreds of other khat users angry at the rise in price during the past two days from two us dollars to five dollars a bundle. there were conflicting reports on the reason for the price rise, with others attributing it to an increase in taxes levied by the kenyan government, while others blamed the government of hussein mohamed aidid.

sources: police, students clash in somaliland capital agence france presse english ;
notes: on saturday, 5,000 people took to the streets of hargeisa to protest against tuur s presence in burao, chanting anti somalia slogans and waving banners criticising those who want to dismantle somaliland s unrecognised independence. we are an independent state that cannot accept federalism with the warring factions of somalia, somaliland s interior secretary mohamed abdi gabose told the protesters. tuur declared the republic of somaliland in may 1991, but after finishing his two year term as the new state s first president, abandoned the unilateral status of somaliland in 1994 after it failed to get international recognition. tuur then allied himself to the late somali warlord general mohamed farah aidid s united somali congress somali national alliance usc sna faction that rules south mogadishu and accepted the post of vice president aidid s unrecognised government, now headed by his son hussein mohamed.

sources: somali jihadist turned politician arrested before regional vote, agence france presse english, december 13, 2018 thursday 5:41 pm gmt, 421 words, mogadishu, dec 13 2018; somalia tells un not to interfere after expelling envoy, agence france presse english, january 3, 2019 thursday 6:59 pm gmt, 532 words, united nations, united states, jan 3 2019
notes: a former senior somali militant islamist leader was arrested on thursday, the government said, less than a week before he was scheduled to run for a regional presidency. the government accused muktar robow, who defected from the jihadist al shabaab movement last year, of organising a militia in baidoa, the capital of the southwestern bay region, and seeking to undermine stability . these actions indicate that he never relinquished his extremist ideologies and is ready to harm the somali people again, the government said in a statement. authorities had been attempting to prevent robow from standing in the december 19 election because he remains subject to us sanctions for his time as deputy leader of shebaab. baidoa residents told afp that hundreds of supporters took to the streets in protest of the detention of robow, who enjoys the support of several clans and is regarded as a serious candidate for the region s leader. sporadic gunfire was heard in the city, the residents said. this is a violation of democracy, robow was standing in his region and his people wanted him. the government has no right to arrest him, this will lead to violence, said mohamed sheik ali, a baidoa resident told afp. the people are burning tyres and the police are firing gunshots to disperse them. there is gunfire and there are casualties as well, said osman adan, another witness. armed militia and supporters of robow have reportedly clashed with the police and the situation in town is tense as we speak, he added. the somali government ordered haysom, a south african lawyer and experienced diplomat, to leave late tuesday after he wrote a letter requesting information on the legal basis for the arrest of muktar robow who was running for the post of regional president of south west state. robow, who defected from al shabaab in 2017, was arrested last month and flown to the capital mogadishu. the arrest sparked protests in the southwestern town of baidoa on december 13 15 that were violently suppressed by somalia s security forces, leaving at least 15 dead.

sources: one dead in clashes in djibouti agence france presse english, april 18, 2002 thursday, international news, 156 words;
notes: about 100 demobilised security officers clashed with police during a protest in djibouti on thursday, leaving one dead and about a dozen injured, radio djibouti reported, quoting the interior ministry. the demobilised police and soldiers were protesting delays in the payment of their pensions and the lack of measures to help them reintegrate civilian life. clashes broke out when the protesters tried to make their way to the presidential palace and a former security officer was killed. two police were among the injured. police used tear gas and fired warning shots to try to get the protesters to turn back but they charged on a police roadblock, witnesses said. thousands of men recruited into the security forces during the government s four year war against rebels were later let go. the interior ministry said an investigation had been opened to determine who was responsible, according to the radio report.

notes: major towns and cities across ethiopia s oromia region are experiencing unrest and protests by people demanding wider freedoms. some businesses have been targeted on suspicion of links to the government. protests continued sunday, and many roads into and out of addis ababa are blocked. protesters burned and looted tourist lodges on the popular lake langano in oromia this past week.

notes: following the approval of the first ever national monitoring and evaluation policy, the government is to implement a rigorous regulation on 10 government institutions to ensure the efficient design, development and implementation of policies. aspiring to ensure accountability and transparency, the adminstration of prime minister hailemariam desalegn endorsed the policy about a month ago. the approval comes as the country is engulfed in political unrests and uncertainty, which has even resulted in the shutdown of social media networks last week, after anti government protests broke out in public universities and other towns, mainly in the oromia regional state. note: the actual event start date was not provided in the source, and is based on the description provided in the story. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: amid turmoil, ethiopia s premier resigns, the new york times, february 16, 2018 friday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 9, 855 words, by jina moore; ethiopian prime minister resigns amid unrest, political prisoners release, the washington post, february 16, 2018 friday, a section; pg. a14, 832 words, paul schemm;
notes: the prime minister of ethiopia, hailemariam desalegn, resigned on thursday, state media reported, after deadly unrest pushed the government to release several high profile political prisoners. the announcement followed the release this week of eskinder nega and woubshet taye, two prominent journalists who spent seven years in prison, and of bekele gerba, one of the country s most important opposition figures, who was jailed in 2015. the state broadcaster reported that mr. hailemariam submitted his resignation to parliament on thursday, and that he expected it to be accepted. an interim leader is likely to be appointed until the ruling coalition names a new leader. hallelujah lulie, a political analyst in addis ababa, the capital, said mr. hailemariam s resignation was just a matter of time. in a move many believed was designed to release some of that tension, mr. hailemariam announced in january that the country would free some prisoners, including opposition politicians. several hundred were freed, but the government continued to hold some of the most high profile prisoners, including the journalists and mr. bekele. observers have said that the government s reluctance to free prominent prisoners illustrated divisions within the ruling party over the release program specifically and of the march toward reform generally. there are elements within the ruling party who don t want to do that, who want to resist it at every turn, said hassan hussein, an ethiopian analyst and professor at st. mary s university in minneapolis. he said the government and members of the opposition, especially the political party of the oromia people, had disagreed about the conditions for releasing prisoners. to accelerate the process, oromia opposition members inside and outside ethiopia called for a boycott on monday. shops and banks in the province of oromia were closed, and those who did not join the street protests largely stayed home, residents said. activists said as many as 20 people were killed. young men blocked roads leading out of the capital with rocks and burning tires, disrupting public transportation. the boycott was officially canceled after mr. bekele was released on tuesday, but mr. hallelujah said the protests had continued in many places. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters supporting a senior opposition leader being held in jail
sources: opposition leader freed, the times london , february 14, 2018 wednesday, news; pg. 30, 68 words;
notes: ethiopia released a senior opposition leader from jail and dropped all charges against him a day after protest rallies were held in several towns. bekele gerba, of the oromo federalist congress, was arrested in december, 2015, after protests in the oromiya region over claims that farmers were forced to sell land with scant compensation. he had been held on incitement to violence charges.

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to prime minister abiy ahmed s move to hand over the town to eritrea
sources: residents protest peace deal on ethiopia eritrea border, agence france presse english, june 11, 2018 monday 4:11 pm gmt, 272 words, addis ababa, june 11 2018; in disputed badme, ethiopians reject peace with eritrea, agence france presse english, june 15, 2018 friday 3:42 pm gmt, 703 words, on the ethiopia eritrea border, june 15 2018
notes: residents of the flashpoint town of badme on ethiopia s northern border protested on monday prime minister abiy ahmed s move to hand over the town to eritrea, a government spokesman said. abiy announced last week that he was reversing years of policy and would accept a 2002 united nations backed demarcation of ethiopia s border that would see badme made part of eritrea. reda e halefom, a spokesman for the regional state tigray on ethiopia s border with eritrea, told afp around 25,000 ethiopian residents of badme and surrounding areas marched through the town s streets in protest over abiy s announcement. it was very peaceful, and they simply wanted to convey their messages that they are ethiopians and they don t want to see the algiers agreement implemented as it is without discussion, reda e said. the tigrayan people s liberation front tplf , an influential political party that administers badme, has called for an emergency meeting of ethiopia s ruling coalition to discuss the issue. note: badme was still a part of ethiopia at the time of the protest

protesteridentity: supporters of abdi mohammed omer, former president of ethiopia s eastern somali regional state
sources: ethiopia charges former regional state president with plotting civil conflict, xinhua general news service, january 30, 2019 wednesday 10:47 pm gmt, international news, 200 words, ,elias
notes: the ethiopia federal attorney general on wednesday filed criminal charges against abdi mohammed omer, former president of ethiopia s eastern somali regional state, with plotting to incite civil conflict. omer is accused of organizing a youth vigilante group called heego and ordering them to carry out deadly attacks on non native ethnicities living in somali regional state, during several days of unrest in august. the federal attorney general also filed criminal charges against 46 other individuals, accused of overseeing deadly attacks on non native ethnicities in august in several cities of somali regional state. several days of deadly unrest in jijiga, capital of somali regional state and other smaller cities in the region in august of last year left around 58 people dead and 266 others injured. cities across somali regional state were engulfed in violence between aug. 4 6, 2018, as supporters of omer rioted in the streets to protest an army intervention to oust him. the army intervention came amid reports of tension between the ethiopian federal government and the former regional president over alleged human rights abuses in somali regional state.

protesteridentity: protesters against the killing of civilians and property damage in various areas on the outskirts of addis ababa
sources: roundup: thousands in ethiopia s capital protest againt attack on civilians; call for gov t protection, xinhua general news service, september 17, 2018 monday 11:51 pm gmt, international news, 566 words, ,habtamu, africa; mobile internet restored in ethiopian capital after 48 hours blackout, xinhua general news service, september 19, 2018 wednesday 10:08 pm gmt, international news, 298 words, ,elias; ethiopian police detains gov t officials as death toll from deadly attack reaches 26, xinhua general news service, september 21, 2018 friday 1:20 am gmt, international news, 307 words, ,habtamu; thousands are arrested in ethiopia after ethnic violence, the new york times , september 24, 2018 monday 06:45 est, world; africa, 896 words, hadra ahmed and joseph goldstein
notes: thousands of people on monday protested against the killing of civilians and property damage in various areas on the outskirts of ethiopia s capital addis ababa. some 23 people have so far been confirmed dead while some 886 others have left their homes as the attack drove residents to flee and seek refuge in schools and other public facilities, ethiopian state news agency ena reported. protesters flocking to ethiopia s national palace and national broadcaster early monday in addis ababa voiced for protection and security from the government. they also urged the government to take action and bring the perpetrator to justice. they further called for the provision of swift support from the government to the displaced people. during the protest, however, five people were shot dead as confrontations rose between security forces and angry demonstrators. ethiopia s oromia regional state on thursday announced the arrest of regional security officers and government officials for failing to discharge their responsibilities during the recent conflicts on the outskirts of ethiopia s capital addis ababa. police in ethiopia s oromia regional state said on tuesday that 269 individuals were under investigation in connection with the attack on civilians and damage to property. the ethiopian government has arrested thousands of people around the capital, addis ababa, over the last week and sent many of them to military camps for rehabilitation, the authorities said on monday, as the government sought to respond to mounting criticism from ethiopians who say it has done little as ethnic violence has flared.

protesteridentity: protesters supporting jawar mohammed, a prominent critic of the prime minister, who had accused the police of plotting an attack on him
sources: 67 killed in ethiopia unrest, but nobel winning prime minister is quiet, the new york times, october 25, 2019 friday 10:14 est, world; africa, 794 words, simon marks
notes: weeks after receiving the nobel peace prize, prime minister abiy ahmed is coming under harsh criticism over his silence in the face of protests this week that police said had resulted in the deaths of 67 people. mr. abiy remained at a summit meeting of african leaders in the black sea resort town of sochi, russia when thousands of people took to the streets of the ethiopian capital and several regional towns on wednesday. the protests were spurred by a prominent critic of the prime minister who had accused the police of plotting an attack on him. the critic, jawar mohammed, is the founder of an independent media network, and claimed that there was a plan to arrest or possibly kill him at his house in the capital, addis ababa. the accusations stoked longstanding tensions in ethiopia, the second most populous nation in africa, and drove hundreds of mr. jawar s ethnic oromo supporters to gather outside his home. thirteen of those who died in the protests were killed by security forces and the remainder died in sporadic fighting that broke out between rival groups, said kefyalew tefera, the regional police commissioner for the oromia region. note: the exact locations of the protests outside of adidas ababa were not provided in the source.

protesteridentity: muslims calling for the perpetrators of the burning of four mosques to be brought to justice
sources: ethiopian muslims protest after several mosques burned, associated press international, december 24, 2019 tuesday 1:24 pm gmt, international news, 200 words, addis ababa, ethiopia
notes: several thousand muslims across ethiopia in recent days have protested the burning of four mosques in the amhara region. the dec. 20 attacks in motta town also targeted muslim owned businesses. muslims have called for the perpetrators to be brought to justice. prime minister abiy ahmed has called the attacks attempts by extremists to break down our rich history of religious tolerance and coexistence. recent ethnic based unrest in some parts of the country has at times taken religious form. prominent muslim scholar kamil shemsu on tuesday told the associated press there are political actors who want to pit one religious group against another and blamed the negative role of activists and videos circulated online. amhara regional officials said they have arrested 15 suspects in connection with the attacks. police commander jemal mekonnen told state media the attacks appeared to be triggered by news of a fire that broke out in an orthodox church a few days earlier. regional officials were criticized for their slow response and their inability to stop similar attacks. many communities across ethiopia have seen demonstrations including the capital, addis ababa. note: the actual start and end date of the protest event was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: ethiopians protesting their government s failure to find at least a dozen university students and five other people who were believed to have been kidnapped from a bus by masked men in december
sources: abduction of ethiopian students fuels anger at the government, the new york times, january 30, 2020 thursday 22:20 est, world; africa, 1113 words, simon marks and abdi latif dahir
notes: ethiopians are taking to the streets and to social media to protest their government s failure to find at least a dozen university students and five other people who were believed to have been kidnapped from a bus by masked men in december in the latest in a chain of ethnically driven conflicts. the students, most of whom are women who belong to the amhara ethnic group, were studying at dembi dolo university in oromia, a region populated by ethnic oromos, officials said. the two ethnic groups, which have clashed in the past, account for about 60 percent of the population of about 100 million in this nation in the horn of africa. the disappearance has stoked anger, resentment and frustration at the government, with thousands of protesters joining demonstrations in recent days to demand answers. relatives and supporters began a campaign using the hashtags bringbackourgirls and bringbackourstudents, reminiscent of the efforts to rescue schoolgirls abducted by boko haram in the northern nigerian village of chibok in 2014. the families are crying they are begging for help, said dessalegn chanie, the chairman of the national movement of amhara, an opposition party. these are poor farmers who have invested a lot in their kids to send them to school. the case poses a danger to the governing party of prime minister abiy ahmed, who has introduced sweeping political reforms that have won him global praise and the 2019 nobel peace prize. amid the growing criticism, mr. abiy met on thursday with eight parents of the kidnapped students, his office said. officials said on wednesday that they had organized a group to investigate the kidnappings, and that federal and regional security forces were collaborating in the search. note: the actual start and end date of the protest event was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: executions spark campus protest against mengistu the independent london , may 26, 1990, saturday, foreign news page; page 14 , 546 words, from richard dowden in addis ababa ;
notes: the execution of 12 generals involved in a failed coup in ethiopia last year has led to an unprecedented demonstration of opposition to the rule of president mengistu haile mariam. some 300 students have been arrested at the university where classes were boycotted and pictures of the president torn down earlier this week. on tuesday, university students started a strike which achieved nearly 100 per cent support in the social science and medicine departments ironically the very departments where, in 1974, the revolution started which ended the rule of emperor haile selassie and brought president mengistu to power. the students destroyed party files kept on the campus. they also tore down pictures of the president and, according to university sources, put up pictures of the executed generals instead.

sources: 2 ethiopian protesters are killed as rebels fire on anti u.s. rally the new york times, may 31, 1991, friday, late edition final, section a; page 10; column 5; foreign desk, 520 words, ap ;
notes: the rebel government of ethiopia put down more protests today by firing on demonstrators, killing two of them. at the same time a number of former ranking officials gave themselves up for possible trial. the demonstrators were opposing the new government and american involvement in ethiopia. today s demonstrations began in the morning, when crowds of several hundred people chanting anti american slogans gathered near the defense ministry, on mexico square and revolutionary square.

sources: pro monarchy demonstration held in addis ababa xinhua general news service, may 10, 1992, sunday, 238 words ;
notes: thousands of ethiopians staged a demonstration here today to demand the return from abroad of atse amha sellasie, a pretender to the throne. atse amha sellasie, son of late emperor haile selassie, is reportedly residing in the united states. haile selassie was deposed by the armed forces in september 1974. he died 11 months later. the demonstrators, members or supporters of the moa anbessa ethiopians for constitutional monarchy established shortly before the downfall of the former regime, marched from center of the city to the prime minister s office to press for their demand for the return of atse amhasellasie to restore the ethiopian crown. they argued that constitutional monarchy on the british and japanese models was necessary for the preservation of the country s unity, history and prosperity. they also chanted slogans like one ethiopia with a single flag . daniel mengistu, vice president of the moa anbessa , said during the demonstration that the return of atse amha sellasie to ethiopia would be conducive to the country s unity. the demonstrators also demanded an end to armed interethnic clashes and rivalries among various political organizations. since the overthrow of the regime of former president mengistu haile mariam, in may last year, armed clashes between various political organizations and ethnic groups have ravaged eastern ethiopia, causing losses of lives and property.

sources: large demo for islamic law in constitution agence france presse english, 587 words muslims demand greater role for islamic courts in ethiopia associated press worldstream, november 28, 1994; monday, international news, 296 words, abebe andualem office of ethiopian prime minister responds to demands of moslems xinhua news agency, november 28, 1994, monday, 123 words ;
notes: almost 150,000 people demonstrated here monday to press for islamic sharia law to be enshrined for their community in the country s new constitution, witnesses said. demonstrators also demanded civil courts be barred by law from reviewing decisions of islamic courts on religious issues. other demands included state subsidies for the muslim supreme council as is the case with ethiopian orthodox church, wearing of muslim cloths by school girls and designated places for muslim prayers in public institutions. the office of the prime minister of ethiopia today issued a statement saying that it has reached a general understanding with moslems on their issues.

protesteridentity: alternative council of the forces of peace and democray acfpd
sources: more than 200,000 protest against ethiopian leader agence france presse english, 400 words ;
notes: up to 250,000 people turned out sunday in addis ababa to protest ethiopian president meles zenawi s decision to allow ethnic groups to secede from ethiopia. the three hour demonstration was called by the alternative council of the forces of peace and democracy acfpd , an umbrella organisation of opposition groups. it was called following the recent adoption by the constituent assembly of two articles, one allowing provinces to secede and the other proclaiming that all land belongs to the government.

sources: addis ababa businessmen demonstrate against house rent regulation xinhua news agency, september 3, 1996, tuesday, 208 words continuing anger in addis ababa against rise in commercial rents agence france presse, october 03, 1996, international news, 188 words ;
notes: thousands of businessmen held a demonstration here today demanding lifting of the recent regulation on price fixing for rents of houses, stalls and verandahs used for commercial purposes issued by the addis ababa regional council. the demonstrators were quoted by the official ethiopian news agency as saying that the regulation is a failure to consider the paying capacity of traders and businessmen , unstudied and spontaneous . they demanded the addis ababa regional council to immediately lift the regulation. however, the council said the regulation was thoroughly researched and meticulously studied before it was formulated into a law. it said the regulation would remain in place as it was justifiable. on september 3 more than 100,000 people demonstrated against the rent hike, which the ethiopian human rights council says have been increased 3,000 percent on average.

sources: continuing anger in addis ababa against rise in commercial rents agence france presse, october 03, 1996, international news, 188 words ;
notes: this protest is related to the first one coded one month prior protest 1 this year. anger over a government decision to raise commercial rents in addis ababa provoked a demonstration by around 5,000 shopowners thursday, according to observers. it was the second time in four weeks that traders had protested. on september 3 more than 100,000 people demonstrated against the rent hike, which the ethiopian human rights council says have been increased 3,000 percent on average. ethiopian prime minister meles zenawi said last week that the economy would be governed by free market principles and those who found the rent too high in the capital could go somewhere else, where it is more affordable.

sources: university students detained for staging illegal demonstration xinhua news agency, march 21, 1997, friday, 104 words ;
notes: the addis ababa region police commission today announced that close to 200 university students were detained today in the capital for taking part in an illegaldemonstration. a spokesman of the police commission was quoted by the official ethiopian news agency as saying that the students took to the streets of the capital city in a move against the land reform implemented in the amhara region. the spokesman said, it is surprising to see students go against the interest of farmers as opposed to the tradition of the student movement which staunchly fought raising high the motto land to the tiller .

sources: riot police injure more than 50 protesting students associated press international, april 11, 2001; wednesday, international news, 278 words, abebe andualem ;
notes: riot police wielding batons injured 50 students wednesday who were boycotting classes in an attempt to get university administrators to agree to a number of their demands, witnesses said.

sources: police clash with schoolchildren in addis ababa agence france presse english, 207 words school children run amok for second day in ethiopian capital agence france presse english, 268 words at least 38 dead in ethiopia clashes agence france presse english, 509 words;
notes: security forces in the ethiopian capital clashed tuesday afternoon with schoolchildren demonstrating in soldidarity with striking university students, an afp journalist reported from the scene of the violence

protesteridentity: democratic association of women of addis abiba
sources: ethiopians protest in support of tougher laws against rapists agence france presse english, 141 words;
notes: hundreds of ethiopians demonstrated in addis abiba s central square tuesday to call for tougher laws against rapists.

sources: two students killed, five injured in student protests in western ethiopia associated press international, march 29, 2002 friday, international news, 323 words, abebe andualem; associated press writer;
notes: security forces battled student protesters demanding aid for farmers, leaving two dead and five injured in four ethiopian cities, a regional official said friday.

sources: more than 10,000 protest horn border ruling in ethiopian agence france presse english, may 19, 2002 sunday, international news, 187 words;
notes: more than 10,000 people demonstrated in addis ababa on sunday against the findings of a neutral international body on the path of the border between ethiopia and eritrea, an afp journalist at the scene reported.

protesteridentity: south ethiopian people s democratic coalition
sources: 16 dead in clashes in southern ethiopia: official agence france presse english, may 25, 2002 saturday, international news, 317 words thirty killed as soldiers open fire on group of 3,000 demonstrators the independent london , may 25, 2002, saturday, foreign news; pg. 13, 109 words;
notes: at least 16 people were killed and an unknown number injured in clashes between ethiopian security forces and demonstrators in the southern town of awassa, an official source said saturday.

sources: at least 6,000 demonstrate against bad governance in ethiopia agence france presse english english, 391 words;
notes: at least 6,000 opposition supporters took to the streets of the ethiopian capital on sunday to demand better governance, a change of electoral laws and the restoration of stability in the troubled southern region.

sources: students beaten over poll protest the independent london , june 8, 2005, wednesday, first edition; foreign news; pg. 24, 257 words, by tsegaye tadesse in addis ababa ethiopia in chaos as police kill 22 during protests the independent london , june 9, 2005, thursday, first edition; foreign news; pg. 29, 876 words, by meera selva africa correspondent government forces in ethiopia kill 22; police, troops fire on crowds contesting results of parliamentary vote the washington post, june 9, 2005 thursday, a section; a12, 656 words, katie nguyen, reuters ;
notes: ethiopian security forces beat stone throwing students protesting against the results of elections which they say were rigged, in a second day of violence that has left one person dead. correction form of the first protest of 2005

sources: protests over ethiopia vote leave eight dead in capital the washington post, november 2, 2005 wednesday, a section; a17, 282 words, reuters more than 20 killed as riots continue in ethiopian capital the independent london , november 3, 2005, thursday, first edition; foreign news; pg. 31, 128 words ;
notes: eight people were killed and 36 wounded in clashes between riot police and opposition supporters in the ethiopian capital tuesday, a sign of persistent political tension in the horn of africa nation.

sources: world briefing africa: ethiopia: police and protesters clash in capital the new york times, january 21, 2006 saturday, section a; column 5; foreign desk; pg. 7, 165 words, by marc lacey nyt world in brief the washington post, january 21, 2006 saturday, a section; a15, 724 words;
notes: a religious festival in the capital, addis ababa, turned violent as the police clashed with celebrators who were shouting antigovernment slogans. at least one person died, and several dozen others, including at least seven policemen, were injured. the police blamed the crowd for the violence, saying a hand grenade was thrown at officers, but witnesses told news agencies that the procession was fired on after some in the crowd threw stones at the authorities. the festival, timkat, the orthodox epiphany, is second in importance only to christmas for members of ethiopia s orthodox church, who typically gather on the streets in the tens of thousands. but this is a delicate time in ethiopia, which has been on edge since parliamentary elections in may that the opposition accuses the government of rigging. twice last year, government troops opened fire on opposition activists, who prime minister meles zenawi says are trying to overturn the legal results by mass action. marc lacey nyt

sources: muslims accuse ethiopian government of meddling in mosques; ethiopia s muslims have been protesting state interference in their affairs for the past six months. could government accusations of muslim extremism risk greater tension? the christian science monitor, may 31, 2012 thursday, 1477 words, william davison correspondent;
notes: the most serious incident occurred on april 27 in the southeast town of asasa in the oromia region, when four people died in clashes after police arrested a muslim preacher. the government said the preacher had been trying to instigate jihad. earlier in april, prime minister meles zenawi told parliament that an al qaeda cell containing a few salafist extremists operated in the area, while at the beginning of may the government announced it deported two arabs of unspecified nationalities for trying to incite violence outside addis ababa s largest mosque.

sources: will ethiopian crackdown stir islamist backlash?; peaceful protests continue in addis ababa this week among muslims angry over what they see as ethiopian government interference. the government sees foreign extremist threat. the christian science monitor, july 27, 2012 friday, 1427 words, william davison correspondent;
notes: with arms raised and wrists crossed, silent muslim worshippers surrounding the largest mosque in addis ababa, ethiopia s capital, again today peacefully protested what they call a violent government response to legitimate demands.

sources: alleged alamata squatters resist police, military addis fortune, january 13, 2013, 737 words, ashenafe endale;
notes: a two day protest by residents of alamata town, 600km north of addis abeba, in the tigray regional state, led to the arrest of close to 40 people, who are all currently under custody, in a maichew town prison, 60km farther north.

sources: 11 killed, 70 injured in deadly clashes mmegi the reporter gaborone , may 03, 2014, 353 words ;
notes: since this article only says this week i have coded it as the beginning of the week of may 3, which was april 27. give then number injured, i have coded the protests as 50 . although some of the injured were innocent bystanders, for such a number to be injured, more than 50 protesters had to be in a given place. eleven people were killed and 70 injured this week, a result of violent clashes in ambo, haromaya and medda welabu universities, the government communications affairs office gcao announced in a statement late thursday. the government blamed anti peace forces for the incident. according to a statement sent to the reporter, mass demonstrations caused loss of lives and property in the ambo and tokekutayo towns in the oromia regional state. the government said that students were deliberately misled by rumors, which was the catalyst for the mayhem. the demonstrations erupted last week against plans by the ethiopian government to develop a common masterplan for addis ababa and neighboring towns of the oromia regional state. however, the plan was perceived by students to mean that the towns would be incorporated into addis ababa, the statement read. according to the statement, an attempt to loot the ambo branch of the construction and business bank resulted in the death of seven residents of the ambo and tokekutayo towns. apart from the two towns, three students were killed at medda welabu university and a hand grenade killed one student and injured 70 in haromaya university, 19 km north of harrar town. the incident happened while students were watching a football match on television. pictures released on social media including facebook and twitter, reveal that there were protests and high security presence in dire dawa university. similarly, students of addis ababa university also protested on thursday. that same day the reporter observed that a considerable amount of federal police officers and members of the addis ababa police force were seen at the gates of the university.

sources: police clash with muslim protesters mmegi the reporter gaborone , july 19, 2014, 264 words ;
notes: the federal and addis ababa police officers clashed with muslim protesters yesterday around mercato following friday prayers at the great anwar mosque. hundreds of muslim protesters demonstrated in mercato around anwar mosque echoing their frequent demands of the release of 17 members of the muslim community jailed under terrorism charges about two years ago. police immediately dispersed protesters and arrested an unstated number of protesters. however, witnesses told the reporter that the police have been randomly beating some protesters.

sources: the washington post, december 24, 2015 thursday, a section; pg. a08, 788 words ethnic group in ethiopia challenges urban plan the new york times, december 17, 2015 thursday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 10, 669 words, by jacey fortin;
notes: since late november, dozens of violent confrontations have erupted in towns across ethiopia s central oromia region, home to the country s largest ethnic group, the oromo. merera gudina, chairman of the oromo federalist congress opposition party, estimates that at least 50 people have been killed in clashes with security personnel over the past few weeks, affecting dozens of towns across oromia protesters and opposition party members say they are fighting against an urban plan commonly referred to as the master plan that would link infrastructure development in addis ababa with that of surrounding towns in oromia, including burayu. critics say the plan threatens the sovereignty of oromo communities. government forces in ethiopia have killed more than 80 people in the past four weeks during protests in the oromia region, an opposition party charged wednesday the opposition bloc s allegation comes after a report last week by human rights watch that said government forces killed at least 75 people protesting a government plan to incorporate some rural areas into the capital, addis ababa. dates are unclear, this is coded as four protests over four weeks though there are more.

sources: eritrean government denies university students held in camp agence france presse english, 566 words;
notes: the students had refused to participate in the program after their student union leader, semere kesete, was arrested on july 31, days after he had given a graduation speech in which he expressed student grievances about university conditions and government interference in university affairs. the students demanded that semere either be released or charged before a court of law. the students cannot interfere in court matters. and they have a social obligation to do the summer work program, in return for the free tuition and boarding facilities the government provides, yemane said. the government had to take deterrent and preventive measures. after boycotting the program, hundreds of them were gathering at the courthouse and trying to assemble at the university after it had already closed for the summer. we got the impression that they were intending to riot. so the police intervened, he said, explaining the reasons for the student arrests on august 10.

sources: eritrea opposition claim political purge after mutiny agence france presse english, january 25, 2013 friday 9:59 am gmt, 464 words eritrea calls soldiers political protest stupid , not coup agence france presse english, january 26, 2013 saturday 1:09 pm gmt, 442 words eritrea since independence agence france presse english, may 22, 2013 wednesday 2:03 am gmt, 494 words ;
notes: eritrea dismissed reports saturday that a protest by mutinous soldiers seeking political reform, a rare challenge to the authoritarian regime of the horn of africa nation, was a coup attempt

sources: 28 die in eritrea school protest; world bulletin, the daily telegraph london , november 2, 2017 thursday, news; pg. 15, 45 words; protests leave 28 dead in eritrean capital, the herald glasgow , november 2, 2017 thursday, pg. 14, 259 words, by elias meseret;

sources: angolans protest high unemployment, agence france presse english, august 24, 2019 saturday 7:11 pm gmt, 227 words, luanda, aug 24 2019
notes: hundreds of angolans took to the streets on saturday to protest against high unemployment, two years after president joao lourenco was elected promising to overhaul the southern african country s economy. lourenco vowed an economic miracle when he campaigned in 2017 to take over from jose eduardo dos santos, who had ruled the nation for 38 years. but, despite its vast oil wealth, angola is struggling with foreign currency shortages, unemployment and poverty. one of lourenco s campaign promises was to create half a million jobs, raising the hopes of millions of unemployed young people. we are only asking that joao lourenco delivers on his 2017 promise of 500,000 jobs and nothing more, said geraldo gala, one of the organisers of saturday s protest in the capital luanda. similar protests took place in other parts of the country.
