sources: protester dies in clash as malawi awaits vote results agence france presse english, may 30, 2014 friday 3:57 pm gmt, 423 words malawi post election violence police shoot dead protester the new times kigali , may 31, 2014, 281 words, agencies ;
notes: one person was killed friday when police clashed with protesters demanding a recount of malawi s disputed presidential elections, as the country nervously awaited a court decision on last week s vote. in the southeastern town of mangochi, police fired teargas and rubber bullets at more than a hundred demonstrators who claimed that the election was rigged, witnesses said. a teenager was killed by a teargas cannister, which exploded in his hands as he was trying to throw it back at us, mangochi police officer elijah kachikuwo told afp. many of the protesters in mangochi were members of the people s party of president joyce banda, who was trailing in third place in early results from the election. others were from the malawi congress party mcp , whose candidate lazarus chakwera was in second place and has asked the court to order a recount. demonstrators in the mangochi district, in the southern part of malawi, smashed shop windows and burned tyres along the road, prompting police to fire tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse them. in the ensuing fracas one person has been shot dead as police tried to defend themselves after being overpowered by angry protesters, police officer elijah kachikuwo told reuters.

sources: malawi: children protest over teachers strike the associated press, november 19, 2014 wednesday 5:03 pm gmt, international news, 242 words, raphael tenthani, associated press ;
notes: blantyre, malawi ap about 500 schoolchildren broke classroom windows and damaged cars to protest a strike by their teachers in malawi s commercial capital, blantyre, on wednesday. the students, aged between six and 12, smashed at least 40 cars, according to police. we re not learning, the pupils chanted in the local chichewa language as they blocked one of the city s main roads with rocks and tree branches. we want the president to know we are angry, said thoko, a 12 year old student, who would not give her last name for fear of retribution. he must pay our teachers so that we can go back to class. dressed in their school uniforms, the students marched toward president peter mutharika s official home in the city. mutharika was away, attending a graduation ceremony at the university of malawi. police fired tear gas to disperse the children but none of them were injured according to police.

sources: malawi police block protest march by hundreds of albinos, agence france presse english, march 6, 2019 wednesday 7:34 pm gmt, 299 words, lilongwe, malawi, march 6 2019
notes: malawi police on wednesday blocked a protest by around 200 albinos who marched to the presidential palace to protest the killing and abduction of people living with albinism. the group, joined by 500 sympathisers, was stopped outside the parliament building, about a kilometre from kamuzu palace, where police formed a cordon to stop them. malawi, one of the world s poorest countries, has experienced a spike in violent attacks on people with albinism over the past four years. in many cases those with albinism are targeted for their body parts to be used in witchcraft. the association of people with albinism in malawi said they are frustrated by government inertia. the vigil was aimed at forcing president peter mutharika into action.

protesteridentity: malawian opposition supporters protesting against alleged fraud in elections
sources: malawi opposition rally against election robbery , agence france presse english, june 4, 2019 tuesday 5:30 pm gmt, 393 words, lilongwe, malawi, june 4 2019
notes: malawian opposition supporters marched through the capital lilonge and burst into government offices tuesday to protest against alleged fraud in elections last month that returned peter mutharika as president. backers of the opposition malawi congress party mcp allege their leader lazarus chakwera was robbed of victory in the may 21 election, which an official count showed he lost by just 159,000 votes. protestors swarmed into ministerial and civil servant offices after about 3,000, according to an afp estimate, marched from mcp headquarters to capital hill, the seat of the malawi government, chanting anti mutharika slogans. we wanted to show the current regime that it is not supposed to carry out its duties unless a proper count of the votes is done, said mcp official george zulu. what we are doing are peaceful demonstrations. these marches will go on until this government steps down.

protesteridentity: supporters of the opposition malawi congress party mcp
sources: us ambassador flees teargas at malawi election protest, agence france presse english, june 6, 2019 thursday 1:14 pm gmt, 378 words, lilongwe, malawi, june 6 2019; malawi police unknowingly tear gas u.s. ambassador amid clash with protesters, xinhua general news service, june 7, 2019 friday 3:31 am gmt, international news, 375 words, kondwani magombo
notes: the us ambassador to malawi was on thursday forced to hurriedly leave the main opposition party s headquarters as police fired teargas at protests outside over alleged election fraud. supporters of the opposition malawi congress party mcp had gathered in the capital lilongwe in ongoing street protests after the may 21 presidential election, which their leader lazarus chakwera narrowly lost. just as we finished the meeting, apparently rocks were thrown and the police responded with teargas. there was teargas flying around but my security people came and we proceeded out without incident. mcp activists allege that chakwera was robbed of victory in the election, which he lost by just 159,000 votes to incumbent peter mutharika. chakwera has rejected the outcome as daylight robbery and launched a court battle to have the result annulled on the grounds of fraud. malawian police thursday afternoon unknowingly tear gassed u.s. ambassador, virginia palmer, in their efforts to disperse supporters of opposition the malawi congress party mcp who were protesting against may 21 presidential election results. malawi police spokesperson, james kadadzera, confirmed the mishap to the local media saying the police were not aware of the u.s. ambassador s presence at the mcp headquarters when they fired the teargas. local media reports indicated that the u.s. ambassador was meeting the mcp leader, lazarus chakwera, at the party s headquarters in the capital when the police fired teargas at the premises to disperse the party s supporters who had gathered there. we were dealing with a volatile situation where people believed to be mcp supporters were rioting and in trying to calm the situation, we fired teargas to disperse them from the party s headquarters, the police spokesperson told the local radio, zodiak. three people were reported to have been shot during the thursday fracas and, according to zodiak, they are receiving treatment at the country s central referral hospital in the capital, lilongwe. but the police spokesperson denied having received any reports on the shooting. he, however, confirmed the arrest of mcp designate legislator and 17 supporters of the party for inciting violence. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the sources, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters demanding the resignation of malawi electoral commission chairwoman jane ansah
sources: police fire tear gas as thousands in malawi protest election, associated press international, june 20, 2019 thursday 3:51 pm gmt, international news, 333 words, by gregory gondwe, associated press, blantyre, malawi
notes: police in malawi fired tear gas at some protesters on thursday as thousands demonstrated in major cities over last month s disputed election. the confrontation in blantyre occurred as some protesters tore down and burned billboards showing president peter mutharika, who narrowly won a second term. the protesters in this southern african nation have demanded the resignation of malawi electoral commission chairwoman jane ansah. a human rights defenders coalition statement alleged that the commission did not properly deal with more than 140 election related complaints, and it accused ansah of a scandalous approach and stubborn attitude in managing voters concerns. opposition leaders lazarus chakwera and saulos chilima, who finished second and third in the election, respectively, joined the protesters in the capital, lilongwe. both are challenging the election results in court, alleging irregularities. also present was former chief justice richard banda, the husband of former president joyce banda. the protesters in lilongwe delivered a petition listing grievances to the president s office. a police statement later noted sporadic incidences of violence but did not mention arrests. on wednesday, protesters in lilongwe scuffled with police as they blocked the road the 78 year old mutharika was meant to travel to speak to parliament, forcing his motorcade to use a different route. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters demanding the resignation of malawi electoral commission chairwoman jane ansah
sources: police fire tear gas as thousands in malawi protest election, associated press international, june 20, 2019 thursday 3:51 pm gmt, international news, 333 words, by gregory gondwe, associated press, blantyre, malawi
notes: police in malawi fired tear gas at some protesters on thursday as thousands demonstrated in major cities over last month s disputed election. the confrontation in blantyre occurred as some protesters tore down and burned billboards showing president peter mutharika, who narrowly won a second term. the protesters in this southern african nation have demanded the resignation of malawi electoral commission chairwoman jane ansah. a human rights defenders coalition statement alleged that the commission did not properly deal with more than 140 election related complaints, and it accused ansah of a scandalous approach and stubborn attitude in managing voters concerns. opposition leaders lazarus chakwera and saulos chilima, who finished second and third in the election, respectively, joined the protesters in the capital, lilongwe. both are challenging the election results in court, alleging irregularities. also present was former chief justice richard banda, the husband of former president joyce banda. the protesters in lilongwe delivered a petition listing grievances to the president s office. a police statement later noted sporadic incidences of violence but did not mention arrests.

protesteridentity: supporters of the malawi congress party mcp
sources: malawi court allows case on election fraud claims, agence france presse english, june 21, 2019 friday 8:12 pm gmt, 405 words, lilongwe, malawi, june 21 2019
notes: malawi s constitutional court ruled friday in favour of opposition parties pursuing a case over disputed election results, an opposition leader said, as further protests erupted over alleged vote fraud. president peter mutharika, who narrowly won the election last month, had applied to have the court application by two opposition parties thrown out. but the court in lilongwe, which did not allow press access, said the case could continue and set june 26 as the date for a full hearing. we are very happy with the ruling and we will be proceeding with the case, lazarus chakwera, leader of the malawi congress party mcp main opposition party, said outside the court as scores of supporters celebrated. they have been given leave to appeal, but that will not stop the process, he added. police used tear gas earlier friday to disperse opposition supporters gathered at the scene, in the latest of a series of clashes since the may 21 election. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters against the re election of president peter mutharika, which they claim was fraudulent
sources: fresh protests over disputed elections in malawi, agence france presse english, july 4, 2019 thursday 4:17 pm gmt, 276 words, lilongwe, malawi, july 4 2019
notes: several thousand people protested in malawi s capital lilongwe thursday against the re election of president peter mutharika, which they claim was fraudulent. police and soldiers were on duty as marchers headed towards parliament for a two day vigil against the result of the may 21 presidential vote. this is the resolute commitment of every malawian who wants to see justice roll in the offices, in the streets, in the corridors of power, lazarus chakwera, defeated presidential candidate for the opposition mcp, told the crowd. i join the same malawians because i am one of the aggrieved.

protesteridentity: protesters denouncing the disputed results of may elections in which president peter mutharika won a second term
sources: second day of malawi protests alleging election fraud , agence france presse english, july 5, 2019 friday 5:14 pm gmt, 194 words, blantyre, malawi, july 5 2019
notes: several thousand malawians took to the streets for a second consecutive day friday to denounce the disputed results of may elections in which president peter mutharika won a second term. in the capital lilongwe, businesses in the city centre remained closed as nearly 3,000 marchers gathered in the streets. in blantyre, the financial capital, similar numbers turned out as army vehicles patrolled.

sources: malawi protesters, police clash in new wave of post vote demos, agence france presse english, august 6, 2019 tuesday 4:27 pm gmt, 317 words, blantyre, malawi, aug 6 2019
notes: police and demonstrators battled in malawi s capital lilongwe on tuesday before troops intervened to restore calm, in the latest protests against the outcome of presidential elections, witnesses said. demonstrations have been regularly staged since the may 21 elections, aimed at forcing out electoral commission chairwoman jane ansah over her handling of the poll. the protest organisers, the human rights defenders coalition, had dubbed tuesday s rally the one million march, in a quest to draw a million marchers to the cities of lilongwe, blantyre and mzuzu. a lilongwe based journalist, golden matonga, estimated the turnout in the capital in the hundreds of thousands. in commercial centre of blantyre, more than 20,000 took part. participation was slightly lower in mzuzu, the landlocked southern african country s third largest city, sources said. while the protests in blantyre and mzuzu were generally peaceful, the lilongwe event was marred by violence, including the burning of a police armoured vehicle. calm return after the military was deployed, witnesses said. residents said they had seen cars being torched and shops looted. apart from the police vehicle, i saw at least two other government vehicles being burnt and shops literally being ransacked along the path of demonstrations, local resident patrick banda told afp. the unrest began after police had fired teargas to try to disperse the crowd, and people retaliated by setting fire to the police vehicle. note: the variation in state responses captures the different state responses across the multiple protest locations

sources: malawi protester dies in custody after army arrest: lawyer, agence france presse english, september 26, 2019 thursday 3:07 pm gmt, 362 words, blantyre, malawi, sept 26 2019
notes: a malawian anti government protester has died in prison after being brutally detained by military officials during a protest last week, a family lawyer said thursday. justin phiri was arrested while taking part in demonstrations against presidential election results in the northern town of karonga. protests have flared since the elections in may, which saw president peter mutharika secure a second five term with 38.57 of the vote. phiri was among 15 protesters arrested by the military last week. he was transferred to the town of mzuzu, where he was due to appear in court. he died in custody on tuesday, aged 29. his lawyer, family and protest organisers claim he was beaten by army officials. around 30 people were injured at the protest during which phiri was arrested last week. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions. note: the actual start and end date of the protest event was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: protesters calling for the sacking of the head of the electoral commission
sources: malawi activists resume protests over presidential vote result, agence france presse english, september 18, 2019 wednesday 4:15 pm gmt, 205 words, lilongwe, malawi, sept 18 2019
notes: thousands of people gathered in three cities in malawi wednesday to call for the sacking of the head of the electoral commission, as protests continue over may s presidential election result. the demonstrations came two days after the expiry of a 14 day ban on protests ordered by the supreme court in a bid to allow mediation between the government and protest leaders. protesters demonstrated in the capital in the capital lilongwe, in the commercial centre blantyre and in the third city of mzuzu. they want the head of the malawi electoral commission jane ansah to step down over her handling of the disputed may presidential elections. according to the official results, president peter mutharika secured a slim margin of victory over opposition chief lazarus chakwera. wednesday s protests passed off peacefully, gift trapence, vice chairman of the human rights defenders coalition hrdc told afp, adding that they had presented a petition to parliament.

protesteridentity: protesters demanding the resignation of malawi s electoral commission chairwoman
sources: malawi govt sympathisers clash with opposition supporters, agence france presse english, september 25, 2019 wednesday 3:16 pm gmt, 315 words, blantyre, malawi, sept 25 2019
notes: malawi government supporters on wednesday clashed violently with opposition groups protesting the result of presidential elections in may. the skirmish erupted in the commercial capital blantyre, where hundreds of people were marching to demand the resignation of malawi s electoral commission chairwoman. macdonald sembereka, who heads the coalition that organised the protest, told afp that president peter mutharika s sympathisers confronted marchers along the way. we were ambushed and stoned by ruling democratic progressive party dpp supporters... alongside the route of the march, said sembereka, adding that several people were injured. an afp reporter at the scene said dpp supporters hurled stones at anti government protesters. they attempted to fight back until police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.

protesteridentity: demonstrators demanding the resignation of the electoral commission chairwoman jane ansah
sources: malawi police fire tear gas at marchers protesting vote result, agence france presse english, october 1, 2019 tuesday 4:58 pm gmt, 389 words, blantyre, malawi, oct 1 2019
notes: malawi police fired tear gas at thousands of demonstrators who took to the streets of the capital lilongwe on tuesday, in the latest wave of protests over the disputed may presidential election. for five months the southeastern african country has been shaken by demonstrations demanding the resignation of the electoral commission chairwoman jane ansah, who they accuse of rigging the vote in favour of president peter mutharika. the police were unprovoked when they fired tear gas at protesters gathering for the march, protest leader and reverend macdonald sembereka said. people were just assembling, dancing and singing when the police came and started firing tear gas at the marchers, he told afp. one person was hospitalised with a suspected bullet injury, but hospital administrator jonathan ngoma refused to confirm if it was a bullet wound until after surgery.

sources: malawi anti bribery protest draws thousands, agence france presse english, january 16, 2020 thursday 4:46 pm gmt, 438 words, lilongwe, malawi, jan 16 2020
notes: tens of thousands of malawians took part in protests on thursday at alleged attempts to bribe judges overseeing a legal challenge to the re election last year of president peter mutharika. people took to the streets after the country s chief justice charged that the five judges presiding over the case had been offered kickbacks. the complaint, which was filed to the anti corruption bureau acb on monday, prompted a call for demonstrations in malawi s three main cities. around 50,000 people gathered in the capital lilongwe, with smaller rallies in blantyre and mzuzu. they braved the rain and stood vigil outside parliament. many wore white t shirts printed with acb name and arrest the bribers now . opposition leaders say the may 21 poll, which saw mutharika narrowly beat runner up candidate lazarus chakwera, was marred by fraud. in august, they petitioned malawi s top court to annul the results the first time presidential election results have been legally challenged since the country gained independence from britain in 1964. gift trapence, head of a watchdog group called the human rights defenders coalition hrdc , said his organisation was pressuring acb head reyneck matemba to seek justice . we met mr matemba yesterday and we told him that the taxpayers want the culprits exposed and arrested, trapence told the rally in lilongwe. we told him that if they sue the acb, we, the taxpayers, will pay. the hrdc, who organised the protests, has called on the acb to release the names of the suspects and arrest them.

sources: soweto students protest failing grades the washington post, january 8, 1990, monday, final edition, first section; page a18; around the world, 78 words, from news services and staff reports ;
notes: black students and their parents demanded nullification of high school exams that 58 percent of them failed, and they urged the failing youths to re enroll in defiance of government rules. the steps were endorsed at a meeting of more than 1,000 people, called to focus on a crisis in black education. nationally, only 42 percent of more than 190,000 black high school seniors passed standardized exams last year, compared to more than 95 percent of white students.

sources: cape town march the washington post, january 11, 1990, thursday, final edition, first section; page a27; around the world, 89 words, ns ;
notes: about 1,200 black rail workers marched through central cape town protesting the killing of at least six railwaymen tuesday, when strikers and non strikers clashed on a station platform in germiston, near johannesburg. some trade unionists said police did not try to stop tuesday s clash at germiston.

sources: gatting rumours spark protests; cricket the times london , january 17 1990, wednesday, issue 63605., 477 words, from richard streeton, johannesburg ;
notes: rumours that mike gatting s english cricketers had arrived in south africa secretly overnight led to an immediate demonstration yesterday outside a leading hotel in the city centre here. after an hour the protesters dispersed peacefully when they learned that the englishmen were not in the country. the incident was a forerunner of what gatting s players can expect when they arrive here nearer the weekend. it involved about 100 protesters representing the pan africanist movement, a black political group, which is affiliated to the banned pan africanist congress. most of the demonstrators carried banners which demanded land rights as well as objecting to the cricket tour.

sources: violent demonstration puts tour in doubt the times, january 20, 1990, saturday, sport, 597 words, from richard streeton, johannesburg ;
notes: two hours before mike gatting s team of english cricketers had even arrived yesterday, the south african police used alsatian dogs and tear gas to disperse about 150 anti apartheid demonstrators outside the main building at jan smuts airport outside johannesburg. this early violence of the sort that the south african cricket authorities had dreaded and the protesters had hoped to avoid must surely have put the future of the tour in immediate jeopardy. mrs winnie mandela, the wife of the jailed african national congress leader, was among the protesters who arrived in buses at the airport. the protesters were given one minute to disperse, but almost immediately, eye witnesses said, the tear gas sprays were fired at them and they were harassed by the dogs and hit by batons.

sources: bush aide optimistic on south african shift the new york times, january 25, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 14, column 1; foreign desk, 257 words, special to the new york times pretoria gets u.s. promise on sanctions; end of measures linked to reforms the washington post, january 25, 1990, thursday, final edition, first section; page a29, 591 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
notes: mr. cohen summarized his impressions in a statement saying he thought both the government and the anti apartheid movement were making commitments to negotiations. hours before he spoke, the police opened fire on a crowd in a black township, killing two people and wounding two others after a crowd of about 5,000 gathered outside the mining town of carletonville, 50 miles southwest of johannesburg, to protest the death of a 17 year old black youth. according to a police report, police fired tear gas and birdshot at demonstrators, who were throwing stones at them and their cars after attending a rally to protest the death in police custody last week of a 16 year old black. two men were killed and at least three others wounded, the report said.

sources: clashes in black areas dim south african joy the new york times, february 6, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 6, column 1; foreign desk, 919 words, by john f. burns, special to the new york times ;
notes: angry clashes broke out today between police and demonstrators in a black township near here, and anti apartheid violence continued in black residential areas elsewhere, underscoring the uncertainty that has overtaken south africa in the wake of measures announced on friday by president f.w. de klerk. the day s events marked an apparent shift in the national mood. the euphoria that swept the country after mr. de klerk told parliament that the government had lifted bans on the african national congress and other leading anti apartheid groups gave way to concern on the part of many blacks and whites that the government s program might prove too limited to draw its black opponents into the negotiations over the country s future. as maneuvering continued over terms set by the congress and its leaders for entering political talks, an anti apartheid protest erupted into violence in tembisa, one of the biggest black townships that ring johannesburg. all day, and into the night, heavily armed police officers fired tear gas canisters into crowds of young blacks protesting, among other things, mr. de klerk s failure to include some tembisa residents in the amnesty he declared for banned and restricted persons in his speech to parliament. the violence in tembisa came as gangs of black youths threw stones, set fire to tires and mounted an arson attack on the home of tembisa s mayor. doctors at a local hospital said that at least 18 blacks were injured, including an 8 month old infant. given how long the clashes between protesters and police occurred, as well as the police s response, this protest is believed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: black conflict threatens to ignite south african tinderbox the times, february 15, 1990, thursday, overseas news, 1239 words, r.w.johnson, durban ;
notes: tens of thousands of blacks joined protest marches in south africa yesterday as police reported the deaths of 13 more people in violence following the release of mr nelson mandela. the state run south african broadcasting corporation estimated that 100 blacks have died since mr mandela was released on sunday. four of yesterday s deaths occurred in two black townships in natal province, while nine died in kwanobuhle, near uitenhage in the cape province. this rising violence, in natal especially, is casting a dark and growing shadow over the land. about 3,000 blacks have already died in the savage fighting, and well over 100,000 have been made homeless. feelings run high, and the story you get depends on who you listen to.

sources: de klerk policy condemned at white rally in pretoria the new york times, february 16, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 2, column 1; foreign desk, 914 words, by john f. burns, special to the new york times right wing afrikaners pledge to fight reforms the times, february 16, 1990, friday, overseas news, 500 words, from gavin bell, pretoria ;
notes: about 15,000 people, one of the largest crowds to attend any white political gathering in south africa in years, turned out today for a right wing rally in protest against the government s actions in freeing nelson mandela and legalizing the african national congress. the rally was called by the opposition conservative party, which has vowed to arouse white anger against president f. w. de klerk and to unseat him at the next election, or at least to defeat any plan he may bring forward in a referendum to transfer a share of power to blacks. although the rally was peaceful, with only a few police officers on hand at the edges of the crowd, the mood was one of bitterness and determination, as mr. treurnicht expressed it, to see that the wagon wheel of afrikaner history rolls forward and crushes any attempt to deprive whites of their right to rule themselves. thousands of afrikaners brought traffic in pretoria to a standstill yesterday with a huge demonstration denouncing president de klerk, and vowing to begin their own freedom struggle . official permission had been granted for the demonstration, and police lining the street and observing the proceedings from side streets did not intervene.

sources: cape town prisoners begin hunger strike the new york times, february 27, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 10, column 4; foreign desk south african political prisoners fasting the new york times, march 5, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 6, column 1; foreign desk, 768 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: about 340 prisoners at robben island prison off cape town began a hunger strike yesterday. outside parliament in cape town, about 30 relatives of prisoners demonstrated in conjunction with the strike. the prisoners say they should be released because the groups to which they belong are now legal. the south african government said it will not free prisoners convicted of violent crimes. several hundred south african political prisoners have begun a hunger strike to force president f. w. de klerk to release them under a general amnesty that could strengthen the negotiating position of the african national congress. the hunger strike was started a week ago by 343 prisoners at robben island, the country s highest security prison, and has spread since to include some convicts elsewhere, including several whites jailed in pretoria. in a rare display of political unity, the strikers include members of the african national congress, the rival pan africanist congress and the black consciousness movement. in a statement said to have been smuggled from robben island, the hunger strikers defined as political prisoners all incarcerated people who have engaged themselves in various ways in the struggle against the system of apartheid, its various structures and forces of reaction whose role is to maintain and sustain the apartheid system.

sources: homelands system facing collapse as violence spreads the times, march 8, 1990, thursday, overseas news, 505 words, from gavin bell, pretoria ;
notes: the unrest is spreading to black townships within south africa, notably katlehong on the east rand and khutsong in the western transvaal. at least 28 people were injured in katlehong yesterday when riot police fired shotguns to disperse thousands of residents demanding lower rents and electricity tariffs.

sources: homelands system facing collapse as violence spreads the times, march 8, 1990, thursday, overseas news, 505 words, from gavin bell, pretoria african congress faulted on unrest the new york times, march 9, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 757 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times south african violence nears level in black uprising of 80s; leaders of both races cannot restore calm the washington post, march 10, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a1, 955 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
notes: rioting spread yesterday from ciskei to bophuthatswana, where seven people were reported killed and hundreds wounded in clashes with territorial security forces firing live ammunition and tear gas from armoured vehicles. president de klerk said on state television last night that troops would be sent to bophuthatswana if necessary, in consultation with its government. he was determined to pursue his liberal reforms, but they required stability, and steps would be taken to prevent the country from sliding into anarchy and chaos. as in ciskei, where an army officer who staged a coup last weekend is calling for reintegration in south africa, the demonstrators in bophuthatswana were demanding an end to their illusory independence. the violence flared after an estimated 50,000 people converged on a magistrate s court in garankuwa township, near pretoria, to demand the immediate resignation of mr mangope. within minutes of bophuthatswana security forces arriving on the scene, pitched battles broke out and spread throughout the township. the latest outburst of violence occurred yesterday here in garankuwa, a crowd of as many as 120,000 demonstrators complaining about living conditions tried to deliver their grievances to a magistrate and clashed with homeland police. at least seven people were killed. the garankuwa hospital reported today that it had treated 350 injured people, most of them for gunshot wounds. many protests are against electricity and water rates, house rents and education issues that have sent hundreds of thousands of blacks into the streets to march on local town halls or government offices in scores of townships. but some marches have degenerated into violence as youthful bands heading home begin throwing rocks at the police.

sources: 8 die as south african police fire on protesters in black township the new york times, march 27, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 451 words, reuters deaths threaten pretoria talks the times, march 27, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, 325 words, from gavin bell, johannesburg eight die as south africa police fire on black marchers the times, march 27, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, 615 words, from gavin bell, johannesburg mandela s group calls off talks the new york times, april 1, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 15, column 1; foreign desk, 864 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: the south african police opened fire today on black anti apartheid and hospital workers reported that eight people were killed and hundreds wounded. the police said they could not confirm any deaths in the clash in the black township of sebokeng, south of johannesburg, where thousands of residents had taken to the streets to protest high rents and racially segregated housing. witnesses said the police opened fire with rubber bullets and shotguns after the protest march was declared illegal under south africa s three year old state of emergency. bloodstained protesters were guarding roadblocks, they said, as men in civilian clothes drove through the township in unmarked cars shooting at random. most of the casualties were in sebokeng, south of the johannesburg, which resembled a battlefield after police opened fire with shotguns on tens of thousands of people protesting against high rents and racially segregated town councils. the order to fire was given by senior officers at the scene when the crowd ignored a judicial ban on the demonstration. witnesses said the crowd fled in panic when the police opened fire, and shortly afterwards the local police station was pelted with stones and the town council offices were set on fire. a hospital employee identified one of the dead as a girl, aged 14, and said hundreds had been wounded by shotgun fire. many, the employee said, had been shot in the back. on monday, the police in sebokeng, a black township 50 miles south of johannesburg, fired tear gas, shotgun and rubber bullets to disperse a crowd of thousands who had gathered to deliver a petition complaining about living conditions in their township and demanding the resignation of municipal council. a local magistrate had previously denied permission for the march.

sources: mandela and buthelezi to meet on black violence the washington post, march 30, 1990, friday, final edition, first section; page a19, 627 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
notes: today, thousands of postal, rail and municipal employees, including 200 suspended workers from the johannesburg prison, marched here and in pretoria to protest government plans to turn many state run services over to the private sector. the socialist oriented black unions oppose the plan on ideological grounds and also fear it will mean loss of jobs. in pretoria, police broke up the march in the city center using dogs and tear gas and arrested 39 union members. the march here took place without incident.

sources: fugitive extremist in coup threat against pretoria the times, april 20, 1990, friday, overseas news, 519 words, from gavin bell, johannesburg south african police kill 4 demonstrators the new york times, april 20, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 2, column 3; foreign desk, 217 words, reuters evolution in europe; riots hit pretoria township where police killed 5 the new york times, april 21, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 5, column 1; foreign desk, 669 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: in the orange free state yesterday, police shot dead four boys, said by activists to be aged under 16, and wounded at least one person in a black township near viljoenskroon. a police spokesman said the police had used shotguns and rubber bullets after a crowd ignored warnings to disperse and threw stones at a police patrol. black anti apartheid campaigners in rammulotsi township in the orange free state said the police opened fire on a peaceful demonstrtion, killing four youths and wounding 19. local black anti apartheid campaigners, reached by telephone in nearby kroonstad, said that about 400 youths, mainly of high school age, were marching peacefully, singing and chanting, when police officers in a van pulled across their path, got out and opened fire without warning. four victims died at the scene after the police opened fire on a crowd that had gathered to demand the resignation of the township s council. a fifth person died at a nearby hospital.

sources: evolution in europe; riots hit pretoria township where police killed 5 the new york times, april 21, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 5, column 1; foreign desk, 669 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times anc condemns killing of teenagers by police; 5 shot as they emerged from school the washington post, april 21, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a15, 560 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
notes: riots shook the black township of rammulotsi in the orange free state today after five youths were shot to death by the police on thursday. in response, youths today set fire to at least two houses and a funeral home owned by two of the township councilors. the police guarded the property of five other councilors. the police rode through the shabby township in an armored car, chasing rioters and firing tear gas. the youths emerged from behind rows of small houses to pelt the armored car ineffectually with rocks and stones. police and hundreds of youth clashed throughout the day today in this orange free state township outside of viljoenskroon, 125 miles southwest of johannesburg. youth threw stones at two police armored cars that patroled the streets. occasionally, white and black policemen emerged from the hippos, as they are known, to shoot tear gas canisters and rubber bullets to disperse the crowds. but today no shotguns were used by police, local residents said.

sources: three blacks killed as police fire on crowd in s. africa the washington post, may 21, 1990, monday, final edition, first section; page a15, 300 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service pretoria looks at township changes the new york times, may 22, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 4; foreign desk, 548 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times troops surround riot township the times, may 22, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, 563 words, from gavin bell, johannesburg ;
notes: three blacks were killed today and scores of others were injured in a confrontation with police in thabong township near the racially tense mining town of welkom, according to police, hospital and other sources there. police fired on a crowd emerging from a public meeting where a decision had been made to end a nearly two week old black boycott of white businesses in welkom, according to the first sketchy reports of the incident. it was not immediately clear why police had fired on the crowd, but the south african press association sapa reported that stones had been thrown and property set on fire in the township. welkom hospital officials said 12 other blacks had been admitted with birdshot or rubber bullet wounds. the government announcement came a day after an eruption of violence between blacks and police officers in thabong, a township near the mining town of welkom in the orange free state. the toll in that incident, in which the police fired on a crowd of black protesters, reached 7 dead and 40 wounded today. the violence erupted in thabong on sunday, shortly after a community meeting decided to suspend a black boycott of white businesses in the adjacent gold mining town of welkom. as the rally dispersed, about 1,000 miners and 500 youths formed a procession, apparently intending to march to the town. police allowed the workers to catch transport to mine hostels, but ordered the youths back into the township. angered by the decision to lift the boycott and by police action, the youths began attacking police vehicles with stones and petrol bombs. a police spokesman said tear gas, rubber bullets and birdshot were fired at mobs which set fire to buildings and built roadblocks of burning tyres.

sources: 60,000 afrikaners protest de klerk s dialogue with anc the washington post, may 27, 1990, sunday, final edition, first section; page a29, 1033 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
notes: south african proponents of apartheid held the largest gathering of whites in nearly three decades today and heard conservative party leader andries treurnicht call for the ouster of president frederik w. de klerk and the establishment of an all white state. treurnicht warned de klerk that south african conservatives are not about to accept black majority rule without bitter struggle and demanded recognition for our right to our own territory and the right to rule ourselves. the rally, held beneath the imposing afrikaner voortrekker monument on a knoll outside pretoria, drew an estimated 60,000 right wing and conservative whites strongly opposed to de klerk s policies of legalizing the african national congress and other anti apartheid groups and opening negotiations with them for an end to the apartheid policies of racial segregation and white domination. massed below the voortrekker monument, which marks the boer trek northward from the british ruled cape colony in the 1830s, the demonstrators were asked by one speaker whether they wanted de klerk to negotiate on their behalf. no, no, no, no, they shouted back. the gathering, attended by many extended white families, from grandparents to small babies in carriages, was a measure of the considerable white resistance de klerk is certain to face as he presses forward with his announced plans to phase out apartheid legislation and pursue talks with black leaders.

sources: pretoria arrests 9 right wingers the new york times, july 9, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 642 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: tonight, the police also reported that tear gas and rubber bullets were used to disperse 1,000 blacks in the township of mamelodi east of pretoria. the police said the crowd had been burning vehicles, setting fire to trash and throwing firebombs and stones. a police spokesman said he had no information about any injuries. however, moses chikane, an official of the united democratic front, said that more than 100 people were injured in the confrontation with police, who he said surrounded a soccer stadium where a public meeting was held to discuss a rent boycott. mr. chikane charged that the police had blocked the main entrance to the stadium and then fired tear gas into the crowd. he said the united democratic front would formally protest the incident to mr. vlok. the south african press association quoted a spokeswoman for two local hospitals as confirming that more than 100 people had been admitted for treatment.

sources: at least 30 killed in clashes with riot police in south africa the new york times, august 10, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk township riots toll rises to 33 the times, august 10, 1990, friday, overseas news, 419 words, from ray kennedy in johannesburg pretoria sends troops to aid in fighting unrest in south the new york times, august 11, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 3, column 5; foreign desk, 493 words, by alan cowell, special to the new york times riots spread in s. africa; week s death toll put at 42 the washington post, august 11, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a17; around the world, 110 words, from news services;
notes: riot police attempting to arrest two protesters yesterday during clashes that took at least 30 lives in port elizabeth, in a neighborhood set aside by apartheid legislation for persons of mixed racial descent. at least 33 people have been killed and more than 100 injured in riots sweeping through coloured areas of port elizabeth in south africa for the past three days, according to police figures yesterday. one of the dead was a baby shot in its mother s lap. rampaging mobs, fuelled on looted drink, have set fire to entire blocks of indian and chinese owned shops in the city s northern areas. the disturbances have caused millions of pounds of damage to shops, factories and schools, the government said. the rioters have proclaimed one district, the chatty area, an anc liberated zone , but the anc strongly denied that it was involved. the violence has been triggered by rent increases and a critical housing shortage in an area of high unemployment. in port elizabeth, police said 32 shops, six houses, two factories, a church, three schools and 41 police vehicles had been destroyed by fire as hundreds of protesters and rioters set up blazing barricades, stoned police and drew police and army fire. witnesses contacted by telephone said many of the properties damaged or destroyed had been linked to mr. hendrickse s labor party, accused by its critics of collaborating with apartheid by participating in the segregated three chamber parliament. rioting spread from port elizabeth to neighboring uitenhage yesterday, and south african police said 42 people had been killed since monday. maj. bill dennis said police and soldiers worked through the night to bring rioting under control in mixed race, or colored, areas of port elizabeth, a coastal city in eastern cape province. but he said the violence spread to the neighboring car making town of uitenhage, about 20 miles away, where black and colored crowds burned and looted shops.

sources: blacks march in an afrikaner suburb the new york times, august 19, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 723 words, by alan cowell, special to the new york times ;
notes: andre erasmus peered down the broad, straight road outside his tin roofed home in a whites only suburb here and gazed with a baleful eye on the advance of 15,000 black protest marchers, chanting through the dust clouds raised by many stamping feet. the unprecedented march by blacks through white suburbs in this conservative town south of johannesburg, he said, shows that the a.n.c. is winning in its campaign to end apartheid. it was the first time white officials had permitted blacks to enter vereeniging to make a legal protest, he said, and that in itself was a victory. although they did not meet in today s march, called to protest killings in sebokeng township near here, both men seemed to say that whatever else has happened since the freeing of the congress leader nelson mandela from prison in february, old certainties are gone beyond recall. and bolder political demonstrations by blacks, like today s march in vereeniging, seem to strengthen uncertainty and hatred of blacks among relatively low income whites like mr. erasmus who stand to lose most from black advance and who question mr. de klerk s avowed commitment to a new political order.

sources: township violence the washington post, august 30, 1990, thursday, final edition, first section; page a39; around the nation, 57 words, from news services and staff reports ;
notes: police used birdshot, batons and tear gas to disperse student marches against violence in black townships. three blacks died in new fighting, raising the toll to 518 in less than three weeks. given the police response and the widespread violence these students were marching against, this protest is believed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: zulus held after township deaths the times, september 24, 1990, monday, overseas news, 300 words, from ray kennedy in johannesburg ;
notes: meanwhile, the fragile calm in the townships since the police and army launched its operation iron fist last week is being threatened by the 9pm to 4am curfew that comes into operation tomorrow. about 3,000 people marched in soweto on saturday, and handed a protest note to the mayor warning that they would defy the curfew. but if the townships are beginning gradually to return to normality, it means the delicate negotiation process has survived its sternest test so far.

sources: protesters on opposite sides still defying pretoria the new york times, november 4, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1; page 20; column 1; foreign desk, 521 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: in pretoria, the conservative party, which opposes the dismantling of apartheid, gathered several thousand white supporters for a march to the union buildings, where mr. de klerk s offices are situated, to deliver a petition contending that he had no mandate to dismantle white minority rule. they demanded that he call a new election for white voters. the conservative party contends that mr. de klerk has betrayed whites, and particularly afrikaners, by meeting with the african national congress, which was banned for 30 years. if apartheid cannot be maintained, the conservatives want the country partitioned into separate homelands for whites and blacks.

sources: protesters on opposite sides still defying pretoria the new york times, november 4, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1; page 20; column 1; foreign desk, 521 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: in soweto, nearly 50 miles to the south, several thousand black supporters of the pan africanist congress, which regards whites as settlers who must return the land to its original inhabitants, gathered in a soccer stadium for the funeral of their leader, zephania mothopeng. he died of cancer oct. 23 at the age of 77. the pan africanist congress has accused the african national congress of selling out the country s black majority by agreeing to talk to the government. it says white minority rule can be toppled only by armed struggle, which the african national congress suspended three months ago.

sources: police battle blacks in johannesburg; anc intensifies nationwide campaign to end township councils the washington post, november 18, 1990, sunday, final edition, first section; page a33, 718 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
notes: south african police clashed with anti apartheid activists for three hours here today as a campaign to force the collapse of all black township councils accelerated with marches and rallies around the country. riot police and army reinforcements, seeking to disperse groups of demonstrators, opened fire on them repeatedly with birdshot, tear gas and rubber bullets, and also used dogs. protesters pelted police with bottles, stones and chunks of cement from buildings in a four block downtown area. police said 15 people were injured, six of them seriously from gunshot wounds, in the worst outbreak of violence in the city since feb. 2, the day president frederik w. de klerk announced the legalization of all anti apartheid groups. one person thought to have been caught up in the confrontation died in the hospital, police said. the street violence here was touched off by a local magistrate s last minute rejection of a march request after the organizers had reportedly obtained permission from the johannesburg town council and traffic police. given policy response and the amount of damage that the protesters were able to cause, this protest is believed to have at least 100 people.

sources: farmers invade pretoria the times, january 30, 1991, wednesday, overseas news, 190 words, from ray kennedy in johannesburg farmers leave the times, january 31, 1991, thursday, overseas news, 80 words, ray kennedy ;
notes: a judge granted an urgent application by the pretoria town council yesterday to end an occupation of the south african capital by an estimated 10,000 white farmers. the judge was ferried from his home by motorcycle because the farmers had barricaded the city centre. the farmers, however, vowed to continue their protest. police said they had arrested 120 farmers but most of them were warned and released. the farmers had invaded pretoria with their tractors, trailers and pick up trucks to protest about the government s perceived lack of interest in their plight. farmers debt in south africa totals more than 15 billion rands pounds 3 billion . the farmers maintain their distress is made worse by high interest rates, a poor return on production, high input costs and, most important, disquiet over the government s proposed revision of the land act, which will enable blacks to buy farms in hitherto white areas. the 10,000 farmers who brought chaos to pretoria for 24 hours by blocking streets with tractors and lorries in a protest at what they see as government indifference to their economic situation trekked back to their farms yesterday in heavy rain. the end came after the city council was awarded a supreme court injunction declaring their presence in the city illegal, after the judge was taken to court on the back of a motorcycle because of the traffic jams.

sources: south africa moves to scrap apartheid the new york times, february 2, 1991, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 1; column 1; foreign desk, 1797 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: the speech by mr. de klerk today lent further momentum to a process that the president began at the opening of parliament last year, when the african national congress and other anti apartheid organizations were legalized and mr. de klerk announced his government s intention to release the congress s leader, nelson mandela. mr. mandela walked out of a prison farm nine days later. in the short span of a single year, mr. de klerk said today, substantial progress was made. the government is determined to build on the foundations laid purposefully, efficiently and with due speed. as he spoke, the african national congress, conducted mass marches in cape town, johannesburg, pretoria and some other cities to put pressure on the government in advance of looming but as yet undefined constitutinal talks. the anti apartheid group also sought to underscore the reality that blacks remain excluded from parliament and from institutional political life. in cape town, walter sisulu, a senior leader of the congress, addressed a crowd of perhaps 15,000 people who had gathered outside city hall.

sources: right wing afrikaners fight police outside jail the times, february 28, 1991, thursday, overseas news, 418 words, from gavin bell in johannesburg ;
notes: right wing extremists, angered by the detention of fellow activists, have clashed with police in the biggest confrontation of its kind since the south african government began dismantling apartheid a year ago. several hundred khaki clad demonstrators broke through police cordons round pretoria s central prison on tuesday night, before being forced back by tear gas. at least one shot was fired, but no serious injuries were reported and there were no arrests. eugene terre blanche, the leader of the afrikaner resistance movement awb , said all hell would break loose if 40 right wing activists, detained for acts of political violence, were not released. he made the threat after his supporters had been prevented from delivering a television set to the prisoners. police said permission had been granted for a protest rally, but they had stopped an illegal march on the prison.

sources: some in prison as deadline for pretoria passes the new york times, may 1, 1991, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 6; column 1; foreign desk, 655 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: miss marcus said in a telephone interview that the congress would probably reserve decision on whether to break off talks until a second deadline of may 9, by when it has called on the government to stop the current factional violence. the congress has again threatened to stop talking to the government about the country s future unless mr. de klerk meets a number of its demands. these include dismissing two cabinet ministers who supervise the security forces, which the congress accuses of abetting the violence. the congress has also demanded an end to all politically related trials, but miss marcus said more than 200 political trials were still under way, affecting 1,200 or more defendants. you re not actually emptying the prisons, she asserted. you re putting more in. the expiration of today s deadline ushered in a new wave of nationwide protests by members of the african national congress and its allies that is expected to be conspicuous in may day rallies on wednesday. more than 150 protesters were reported arrested by this evening; some were protesting the continuing incarceration of political prisoners. this protest is recorded as in the 100s because of how many people nationwide who were arrested. not enough information was given to record it as more than that.

sources: the washington post, south african hunger strike, ns, may 18, 1991, saturday, final edition, first section; page a16; around the world, 79 words hunger strike raises fears the times, may 31, 1991, friday, overseas news, 89 words, gavin bell hunger strike the times, may 25, 1991, saturday, overseas news, 112 words, stephen taylor ;
notes: nearly 200 jailed south africans have gone on a hunger strike to press their case that they are political prisoners who should have been released under an agreement between the african national congress and the government. several human rights groups have accused prison authorities of mistreating the hunger strikers. they said the government on wednesday removed the last 28 political prisoners from robben island and took them to pollsmoor prison on the mainland. lawyers say that more than 100 prisoners, convicted of what they regard as politically related offences, are refusing food. the mass hunger strike began on may 1 and the health of some of the strikers is said to be precarious. the detainees are demanding freedom under an agreement between pretoria and the african national congress. president de klerk said he was satisfied that all prisoners who clearly qualified for political status had been released, but officials were still sifting through petitions. although technically a strike, this was included as a protest due to the coordinated effort and the clear political message to the government. seven prisoners were freed yesterday on the orders of mr de kl erk as the government moved to neutralise a hunger strike campaign by dozens of inmates claiming their freedom as political prisoners. however, the rapid deterioration in the hunger strikers health was clearly a factor. nelson mandela, the anc deputy president, and archbishop desmond tutu said that the government had accepted that if a hunger striker died it would seriously jeopardise the chances of political negotiations.

protesteridentity: anc women s and youth leagues
sources: gains seen in de klerk mandela talks the new york times, may 9, 1991, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 4; foreign desk, 681 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: outdoor gatherings would be prohibited for two weeks, mr. vlok s statement said, with exceptions for church and sports events and funerals. recent political rallies held by the inkatha freedom party have become catalysts for bloodshed. mr. vlok s statement said nothing about banning weapons, including traditional spears, clubs and other arms brandished by inkatha supporters. the issue of eliminating such weapons figured prominently in talks that president de klerk held yesterday with the inkatha leader, chief mangosuthu gatsha buthelezi. the government mounted a similar crackdown last september after violence became intense, but the effort only temporarily stopped the killing. today, hundreds of members of the women s and youth leagues of the congress mounted demonstrations and sit ins to call attention to the issue. at least 155 people were reported arrested. in its april 5 ultimatum, the african national congress set these conditions: that mr. vlok and defense minister magnus malan be dismissed; that weapons be banned at public rallies and marches; that counterinsurgency units be dismantled; that police officers involved in two fatal confrontations be suspended; that police officers assigned to crowd control not be issued live ammunition; that single sex migrant workers hostels, which have been flashpoints for violence, be phased out; and that an independent commission of inquiry be established to investigate complaints of misconduct by the security forces.

sources: winnie mandela given sentence of 6 years in kidnapping case the new york times, may 15, 1991, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 1; column 1; foreign desk, 1248 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: winnie mandela, the wife of the african national congress leader nelson mandela, was sentenced today to six years in prison in the kidnapping and beating of four young men in soweto in late 1988. the sentences stunned spectators in the courtroom, some of whom expected mrs. mandela to get a suspended sentence. but her lawyer immediately filed an appeal, postponing for months the prospect that mrs. mandela will actually go to prison. and there has been speculation that president f. w. de klerk may yet step in and pardon her in order not to jeopardize proposed negotiations on the nation s future with mr. mandela and the african national congress. released on a modest bail equivalent to 72, mrs. mandela looked defiant as she walked out of the courthouse to cheers from several hundred waiting supporters, some of whom held placards declaring stop harassing our mother winnie mandela and no justice under an unjust government.

sources: winnie mandela arrested twice in clashes with police the times, may 23, 1991, thursday, overseas news, 542 words, from ray kennedy in johannesburg the washington post, winnie mandela arrested, ns, may 23, 1991, thursday, final edition, first section; page a40; around the world, 72 words ;
notes: mrs mandela was arrested for obstruction after an all night vigil in central johannesburg over the fate of political prisoners on hunger strike for 22 days. the demonstration was staged by the anc women s league. a minibus secured by a heavy chain was used to block off one of the city s main thoroughfares. fifteen other protesters were also arrested, and taken to police headquarters at john vorster square. they were released after appearing before a magistrate, who set a hearing for june 21. meanwhile, about 200 members of the women s league, led by albertina sisulu, the organisation s national vice president, had been arrested outside police headquarters after staging a protest against mrs mandela s arrest. mr mandela telephoned president de klerk, but was told that he was still asleep. adriaan vlok, the minister of law and order whom the anc is demanding should be sacked from the cabinet, said that he would investigate what had happened. when the two groups were released from police headquarters, mrs mandela led another march of about 100 supporters back to the scene of her arrest. this time police went into action swiftly and for the first time in a so called unrest situation used stun grenades and tear gas to disperse the crowd. winnie mandela was arrested twice after scuffles with police during demonstrations demanding the release of hunger striking political prisoners. mandela was released after appearing in court on charges of resisting arrest and obstructing traffic. she was sentenced to six years in prison last week after being convicted in connection with the 1988 abduction and beating of four young men. she is appealing the conviction.

sources: 5 are killed in south africa in protest and black clashes the new york times, june 2, 1991, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1; page 20; column 1; foreign desk, 115 words, reuters ;
notes: five people were killed overnight in 30 incidents of black factional fighting and anti apartheid protests in south african townships, the police said today. policemen and soldiers patrolling the johannesburg township of katlehong shot and killed a man armed with an ak 47 automatic rifle. three other blacks were killed in the natal township of tongaat and in soweto. rioting groups shot dead a policeman in the eastern cape province township of komga. three people were arrested. other incidents of unrest reported across south africa included police dispersing of anti government protesters, stoning of government buildings, and fighting between rival black political groups. given that this protest is national with 30 incidents and involved the deaths of 5 people, this protest is assumed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: blacks protest highlights schools injustice the times, june 27, 1991, thursday, overseas news, 418 words, from gavin bell in alexandra township the washington post, cheating south africa s young, july 1, 1991, monday, final edition, opinion editorial; page a18, 444 words ;
notes: mid term exams at east bank high school in the south african township of alexandra were disrupted yesterday by political activists, television crews and 200 riot police supported by armoured vehicles and a helicopter. the incident was designed to focus attention on the enduring injustice of the education system, with white schools being closed for lack of pupils while black institutions are overcrowded and ill equipped. the national education co ordinating committee, a black community organisation, had intended to transport 300 pupils from the township to occupy a vacant primary school in a white johannesburg suburb five miles away. the government, while sympathising with black aspirations, ordered the security forces to prevent what it termed illegal seizure of private property. recently anti apartheid activists began to force the disparity issue by seeking to occupy an empty white school with 300 black schoolchildren who attend overcrowded and dilapidated schools. the police turned them back.

sources: 2 killed as apartheid supporters battle police at de klerk speech the new york times, august 10, 1991, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 1; column 4; foreign desk, 480 words, by the associated press five die as neo nazis attack de klerk supporters at rally the times, august 10, 1991, saturday, overseas news, 606 words, from gavin bell in johannesburg ;
notes: hundreds of policemen and white protesters battled with guns and tear gas today when pro apartheid militants tried to stop president f. w. de klerk from speaking. at least 2 people were killed and 54 wounded. pitched battles raged through the main street of this conservative town as members of the afrikaner resistance movement tried to fight their way into the hall where president de klerk was giving a speech. it was the worst outbreak of violence between white right wingers and security forces. a minivan carrying blacks along the highway that cuts through the center of town careened out of control into the fighting crowd and flipped on its back. the police said one white militant had been killed by the van. enraged whites then surrounded it and opened fire, wounding four black passengers. the other person killed was a white protester shot to death by the police, col. johan mostert said, adding that there were unconfirmed reports of at least three other deaths. six policemen were wounded, three critically, colonel mostert said, adding that at least 12 blacks, 9 white protesters and 27 white bystanders were injured. ventersdorp is the headquarters of an extreme right wing group known as the afrikaner resistance movement, which opposes mr. de klerk s policy of racial liberalization. hundreds of khaki clad members waving flags with the group s swastika like symbol marched toward the hall in theevening as mr. de klerk began to speak. right wingers then besieged the police station while their leader, eugene terre blanche, negotiated with senior officers. with tension at fever pitch, awb members spray painted police vehicles with slogans and deflated their tyres to prevent the police from leaving. the situation was defused when six awb men who had been arrested were released, pending a court appearance on monday.

sources: two black groups and pretoria sign peace agreement the new york times, september 15, 1991, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1; page 1; column 6; foreign desk, 1042 words, by kenneth b. noble, special to the new york times ;
notes: since the agreement is meant to prevent provocative public displays or actions, and specifically imposes a voluntary ban on the carrying of weapons to meetings, the demonstration today by inkatha supporters, outside the luxury downtown hotel where the accord was signed, immediately called into question inkatha s commitment to it. thousands of supporters of the zulu dominated movement and its leader, chief mangosuthu gatsha buthelezi, chanted, sang and staged mock battles, to the obvious displeasure of heavily armed government soldiers in armored cars. the zulus disregarded police requests to surrender their weapons. the people outside the hotel, while they apparently enjoyed themselves, according to all the reports i received, at no stage posed a threat to anyone, mr. de klerk said.

sources: the washington post, millions strike in s. africa; blacks protest tax, lack of labor role, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service, november 5, 1991, tuesday, final edition, first section; page a15, 695 words;
notes: millions of black south africans stayed home from work today in protest over a new general tax and the government s attempts to carry out economic and other reforms without the agreement of black labor and political groups. it was the largest nationwide strike in the nation s history. the strike s start was marred by a battle sunday night between pro and anti strike workers at a mine outside welkom, 160 miles south of here, where 15 miners died and 43 were injured. elsewhere, the strike proceeded relatively peacefully today, although police said they arrested 108 people during 16 protest marches and demonstrations held without permission.

sources: de klerk vows black vote on reform the new york times, january 25, 1992, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 5; column 1; foreign desk, 946 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: president f. w. de klerk promised today to include south africa s disfranchised black majority in any referendum on political change, but at the same time he reiterated that the white minority would have an opportunity to veto the terms of transition to a new nonracist constitution. mr. de klerk s nationally televised speech, which lasted nearly an hour, was criticized by the african national congress, whose executive committee in johannesburg accused him of an insensitivity, uncaring attitude and complacency towards the plight of millions of people whose lives have been ruined by the system of apartheid. as mr. de klerk finished speaking, at least 20,000 black demonstrators surged through downtown cape town in what the congress, which organized the protest, billed as a people s parliament. it endorsed the congress s demand that the government be replaced by an interim government within six months and that a constituent assembly be elected by the end of 1992 to draw up a new constitution.

sources: the washington post, south african protest dispersed, from news services and staff reports, january 28, 1992, tuesday, final edition, first section; page a16; around the world, 152 words;
notes: police arrested a leader of south africa s radical pan africanist congress and fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse a crowd of demonstrators who were protesting high rents and electricity fees in the black township of ennerdale. pac spokesmen said more than 1,000 people attended the protest rally and that several were wounded by police gunfire. police estimated the number of protesters at 500 and said they had no reports of casualties. a police spokesman said the officers opened fire after the crowd ignored orders to disperse and began throwing stones. pac is campaigning against constitutional talks that the larger african national congress and other black groups are holding with president frederik w. de klerk s minority white government.

sources: the washington post, white militants challenge s. african reforms, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service, february 3, 1992, monday, final edition, first section; page a13, 1116 words;
notes: they marched by the hundreds in black and khaki uniforms with swastika like armbands, singing: this land is for the boers. shoot the kaffirs. shoot. they belong to the afrikaner resistance movement, a neo nazi movement in style, language and garb, if not objective. all day saturday, the group put on a multi act performance of the skills of its growing private army for local and international media in the streets of this rural village, about 90 miles west of johannesburg. saturday s parade, however, numbered no more than 500. they are up in arms over constitutional negotiations that are moving toward the end of white minority rule here, and so they are preparing a last stand in the name of a separate white nation. the rise of the afrikaner resistance, unopposed by the government despite the group s declaration of readiness to do battle against the state, appears to be another sign of such a trend.

sources: the washington post, township violence called threat to democracy; jurists say elections involving blacks would not be possible now in south africa, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service, march 29, 1992, sunday, final edition, first section; page a28, 829 words 5 dead in rising south african strife the new york times, april 2, 1992, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk, 691 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
notes: the most violent confrontation between police and township residents in more than a year in south africa took place in alexandra township thursday. about 100 residents were treated at the black township s clinic for birdshot and rubber bullet wounds, but probably because nobody was killed, it went largely unnoticed and unreported abroad. yet the running street battles between rock throwing youths and heavily armed special riot police said a lot about the simmering grass roots tensions and unresolved conflicts that continue to weigh heavily on south africa s fragile peace process. alexandra, one of several satellite black townships around johannesburg, teetered today on the brink of chaos as residents battled each other in politically tinged violence and angry mobs surged into the streets. the violence, which first erupted in alexandra last month, has involved migrants living in workers hostels and residents of the surrounding township, which in its organization is similar to but smaller than the better known soweto township. it quickly took on political overtones because the migrants are mostly zulus loyal to the tribally based inkatha freedom party, while the long term residents of the township largely support the african national congress. in alexandra today, young people erected barricades of burning tires, large rocks and the scorched carcass of an overturned car. the stench of tear gas and scorched rubber hung in the air at some intersections, which glittered with shards of glass. many alexandra residents want two men s hostels closed down and converted into more stable family housing. the rage in alexandra s streets was redirected today from the hostel dwellers to the south african police, whose armored cars attracted volleys of stones as they patrolled the township. since the shootings and killings appear to not be done by police, but rather by the hostel dwellers, the response for this protest is only coded as crowd dispersal. also, even though this protest involved fighting between two groups of citizens, the alexandra residents have a political demand in that they want the hostels closed and converted into proper housing.

sources: mob forces de klerk to abandon rally after foreign triumph the times, april 13, 1992, monday, overseas news, 534 words, from ray kennedy in johannesburg ;
