notes: fresh from his triumphant visit to nigeria, president de klerk returned abruptly to the confused and volatile situation in his backyard at the weekend when he was pelted with gravel and forced to abandon the national party s first rally outside white areas. although he was cheered by thousands of coloureds at mitchell s plain outside cape town, a township created in the 1970s as a result of apartheid s forced removal policies, he was booed and jeered equally as loudly by supporters of the african national congress and the new unity movement. his address in a marquee erected in the centre of the township was almost inaudible. as the protesters hurled handfuls of gravel at the platform, police advised the president to cut short the proceedings in case somebody was hurt. he cancelled a walkabout in a shopping centre and a luncheon and was driven back to his official residence. the anc, which also opposed mr de klerk s visit to nigeria, said the rally had been an extravagant flop after the national party np had spent 250,000 rand pounds 49,700 on its organisation. the number of protesters is assumed to be in the 1000s, because the number of supporters of the president was listed to be this much, and then it was said that the opposition the protesters had an equally loud voice, thus implying that it had similar numbers.

sources: the washington post, at soweto funeral, upheaval seems near; anc comrades in black township set themselves for revenge against inkatha rivals, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service, june 15, 1992, monday, final edition, first section; page a12, 720 words;
notes: the anc has denounced the call up, saying it amounts to declaring war against the people and that it marks a return to the old ways of coercion and repression. the anc asked in a statement saturday why the government never ordered such a call up when inkatha had marched through the streets carrying traditional weapons that formally are banned at political rallies. the alleged police bias in favor of inkatha seemed in evidence in soweto today. down the main road in front of the township s baragwanath hospital, hundreds of inkatha youths marched armed with the banned iron spears, sharpened wooden sticks and poles. the marchers took over half of the road, but police in an empty patrol wagon and riot police in an armored personnel carrier made no attempt to disarm the marchers or get them off the road. later, however, police said they arrested 20 people, apparently inkatha members, and confiscated thousands of weapons at soweto s new canada railroad station.

sources: mandela s group begins mass protests the new york times, june 17, 1992, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 4; foreign desk, 689 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times gunmen mar anc festive day of action the times, june 17, 1992, wednesday, overseas news, 318 words, from michael hamlyn in johannesburg ;
notes: the african national congress began an open ended campaign of public protest today with a day of rallies, work stoppages and threats of a crippling general strike by the summer s end if the white minority government does not move more quickly to give blacks full voting rights. in what black leaders conceded was a high risk return to the unpredictable theater of the street, nelson mandela, the president of the congress, said the mass action campaign would continue until the government agreed to terms for creation of an interim government and an elected assembly to write a new south african constitution. addressing 30,000 supporters packed into a soccer stadium in this sprawling metropolis of black slums south of johannesburg, mr. mandela implored his followers to ignore growing calls by impatient blacks to mount a guerrilla war against the white suburbs. do not be provoked into violence, mr mandela told a 40,000 strong crowd in the orlando football stadium in soweto. by killing and revenge you do not help the community. carrying violence to the white areas would be a disaster of the first magnitude.

sources: de klerk s visit to massacre site brings new eruption of violence the new york times, june 21, 1992, sunday, late edition final, section 1; page 1; column 3; foreign desk, 1076 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times ;
notes: president f. w. de klerk ventured into this bitter black township today in a show of concern for victims of a massacre on wednesday, but was chased away by angry residents, leaving behind an ugly mood that soon exploded into more violence. about 90 minutes after mr. de klerk s motorcade fled before residents blaming him for the wednesday violence, police officers fired assault rifles into a hostile crowd in a skirmish over the body of a man shot by the police a short time earlier. the number of casualties was not immediately known. to hell with de klerk go away, go away! chanted a throng of several hundred people, kept back from mr. de klerk s caravan by guards on foot carrying machine guns. hundreds of furious residents forced president frederik w. de klerk out of this tense black township today, chasing his car through the dusty streets and shouting, go away and shoot, shoot. shortly after his hasty departure, police opened fire without warning and at close range on a crowd that had gathered in a field inside the township. at least three people were killed and 20 seriously wounded, according to a journalist who witnessed the incident. armed residents living in nearby homes then responded with sniper fire, leading to a shootout that lasted more than 15 minutes, the witness said.

sources: the washington post, anc halts 2 party talks with s. africa; mandela protests massacre, shootings, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service, june 22, 1992, monday, final edition, first section; page a1, 756 words;
notes: mandela today issued a stern warning to de klerk not to declare a state of emergency, saying, let me warn him that the introduction of anti democratic measures today will result in a defiance campaign with me leading it . mandela led an earlier defiance campaign by blacks against apartheid laws during the early 1950s. the anc leader, addressing a militant crowd of 20,000 followers in evaton, said the boipatong massacre had changed the face of south african politics and that the gulf between the oppressed and the oppressor has become unbreachable. many anc supporters have accused the government of complicity in the boipatong massacre. although a rally for the anc, there is a clear protest message among the crowd, and thus this was coded as a protest rather than excluded as just a political rally.

sources: 37 south africa victims evoke angry eulogies the new york times, june 30, 1992, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk, 951 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times ;
notes: in the dusty amateur soccer stadium of this previously uncelebrated black township, the leadership of black south africa and a crowd of 25,000 today eulogized victims of the reform era s worst massacre and roared their bitterness at the white government. the funeral service for 37 of the people killed on june 17 in a night rampage through boipatong united black leaders from moderate to militant in calling for the ouster of president f. w. de klerk. they disagreed over whether he should be driven from office by force or allowed to negotiate his own surrender. remember, mr. de klerk, we are not your kitchen maids, we are not your garden boys, jeered jay naidoo, the president of the congress of south african trade unions, who led a thunderous chant of de klerk must go!

sources: black official rejects de klerk s overture on talks the new york times, july 4, 1992, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 2; column 2; foreign desk, 465 words, ap ;
notes: thousands of angry blacks marched meanwhile today through the black township of boipatong, south of johannesburg, to protest the killings last month of more than 40 people and demand action against the attackers. a line of heavily armed police officers watched as 5,000 chanting, singing demonstrators stopped at the township s edge, separated by black protest marshals who formed a human chain. the crowd gestured toward a zulu hostel that is believed to have been the staging area for the attack june 17. leaders told the hostel s owners that the building must be demolished and the attackers brought to justice.

sources: the washington post, vance to open talks today to break s. africa impasse; anc protests seen failing to rock de klerk, david ottaway, washington post foreign service, july 22, 1992, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a26, 565 words;
notes: vance arrived on the second day of the latest phase of the anc s mass action campaign designed to pressure the government into making more concessions through strikes, marches and the occupation of government buildings. hundreds of protesters have been arrested the past two days for occupying police stations, hospitals, courts and government offices. police said they arrested 273 people for trespassing or participating in illegal demonstrations on monday. police estimated that 16,000 people joined in 27 protests that police called isolated mass actions.

sources: the washington post, anc demonstrations, july 26, 1992, sunday, final edition, first section; page a30; around the world, 99 words;
notes: thousands of african national congress supporters singing freedom songs marched on government and police buildings across south africa in a run up to mass protests planned to topple the government. the demonstrations in four main cities came as president frederik w. de klerk said that south africa urgently needs to elect a transitional government but that the stalled talks on multi racial rule will have to be resumed first. the protest marches drew less than 10,000 demonstrators short of the huge crowds the anc had predicted it would mobilize to call for majority rule and peace.

sources: how diplomat kept the guns of the veld silent the times, august 5, 1992, wednesday, overseas news, 520 words, from michael hamlyn in bisho, ciskei lone negotiator keeps ciskei protest bloodless the times, august 5, 1992, wednesday, overseas news, 185 words, from michael hamlyn in bisho, ciskei ;
notes: a five hour confrontation on the veld with 30,000 cheering demonstrators facing a line of guns and armoured cars ended miraculously without bloodshed at sunset last night. the demonstrators, supporters of the african national congress, danced and sang their way into the territory of the so called independent black homeland of ciskei as darkness fell. the 30,000 marched out of king williams town in the eastern cape at midday, determined to confront the military ruler of ciskei, brigadier oupa gqozo, who had vowed that no anc demonstrator would set foot in his realm. he was accompanied throughout the day by jose campino, one of ten united nations observers invited to monitor this week s intensification of mass action which is aimed at forcing the south african government to yield to the anc s demands for constitutional reform. the leaders insisted they were going to enter ciskei to deliver a memo to the ciskei ministers. the troops insisted, equally vehemently, that they would not. stalemate. then the negotiations of dr geldenhuys began. the stadium then became the goal of the negotiators. dr geldenhuys and senhor campino went back to the ministers and suddenly the ministers agreed. all at once it was over. the crowd surged towards the stadium. their leaders addressed them. the memorandum was delivered. it called for the immediate installation of an intermediate administration in ciskei to supervise its peaceful reintegration into south africa. the protesters had marched out of king williams town in the eastern cape at midday to deliver a demand that an intermediate administration be set up in bisho immediately to supervise ciskei s peaceful reintegration into south africa.

sources: mandela takes his message to apartheid s citadel the new york times, august 6, 1992, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 1; column 3; foreign desk, 840 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times ;
notes: nelson mandela led a huge and orderly throng of black protesters to the capital of apartheid today to raise the flag of the african national congress on the front porch of the white government and demand that president f. w. de klerk make way for majority rule. mr. mandela, president of the congress, told supporters who marched to a park beneath the union buildings, the seat of the south african executive branch, that he hoped to resume negotiations on the country s future but that south african blacks would make peace standing on our feet, not kneeling on our knees. there, under the sculptured glare of gen. j. b. m. hertzog, one of the spiritual fathers of afrikaner nationalism, the professorial liberation leader lectured on democracy before 50,000 still disenfranchised blacks. mr. de klerk spent the day sequestered in a windowless cabinet room, an aide said, and saw nothing of the events below. later he de klerk emerged to tell reporters that certain discussions have been taking place between the government and the congress, and that he expected formal talks to resume shortly. since the president addressed the crowd saying that discussions are and will take place, the response to this protest is recorded as accommodation. the most noticeable effect was in pretoria, where a vast crowd estimated at up to 70,000 watched by armed troops and police, marched behind nelson mandela, the anc president, to the union buildings on the hill overlooking the town.

sources: anc will claim strike forced concessions the times, august 7, 1992, friday, overseas news, 827 words, michael hamlyn ;
notes: as the march 17 referendum among the white community showed that president de klerk had their overwhelming support, so this week has shown that mr mandela has the support of blacks. while it is true that the success of a general strike can be ensured by intimidation and those wanting to work can be kept at home by the absence of transport, it is more difficult to intimidate people into turning out for mass marches. the vast numbers who poured into city centres on wednesday were testimony to the strength of feeling, as well as to the organising ability of the anc cadres, who transported thousands of protesters from rural and small urban districts into the big towns. estimates varied between 200,000 and 400,000. there were two other impressive things about the mass mobilisation. first, the crowds were well disciplined by marshals. there were few incidents of violence, or destruction. true, in pietermaritzburg four cars had their tyres slashed, and after thedemonstrations a couple of petrol bombs were thrown unsuccessfully in cape townships. but during the cape town demonstration, marshals handed over to the police a young man caught breaking shop windows. the same marshals insisted on protesters putting down sticks or anything that might be construed as a weapon. second, and equally impressive, was the restraint shown by the security forces. though in many cases police and soldiers were armed with shotguns and rifles, with tear gas pistols and batons, though they were dressed in bullet proof vests, steel helmets and gas masks, they stood and watched and joshed the crowd just like policemen in other less socially divided countries. it was possible yesterday to attribute only one death to wednesday s demonstrations, and that was of a man who fell from a train going home from the cape town events.

sources: south african homeland s troops fire on protest march, killing 24 the new york times, september 8, 1992, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 1; column 3; foreign desk, 1216 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times troops kill 28 at anc protest rally the times, september 8, 1992, tuesday, home news, 1043 words, from michael hamlyn in bisho, ciskei ;
notes: soldiers of the black south african homeland called ciskei rained machine gun fire today into a fleeing throng of african national congress supporters who marched on the enclave vowing to topple its military ruler. the three minute volley left at least 24 black marchers dead and scores more wounded or trampled in the panic. it also dashed any hope of a rapid reconciliation between blacks and whites on south africa s political future, because while south africa insists ciskei is an independent country beyond its control, almost everyone else here and abroad regards it as a province, if not a puppet, of south africa. we are blaming de klerk for this, and we do it without hesitation, said cyril ramaphosa, secretary general of the african national congress, one of several black leaders who dived to the ground alongside journalists and mediators to avoid the intense gunfire. the march, which set off with more than 50,000 strong from king william s town, on the south african side of the ostensible border, marked an intensification of the a.n.c. s battle to end white minority rule. the first fusillade continued for nearly two minutes. after a series of percussions, apparently a belated round of tear gas grenades, the gunfire again raked the retreating crowd for a minute. at least 28 people died and nearly 200 were injured when ciskei armed forces opened fire yesterday on a march of 70,000 anc led demonstrators seeking to occupy bisho, the capital of the nominally independent homeland. a tense standoff continued tonight as thousands of protesters out of a demonstration that initially numbered between 50,000 and 80,000 camped in an all night vigil near the scene of the shooting.

sources: the washington post, mandela calls de klerk deceitful; anc, government, clerics trade accusations over killings, paul taylor, washington post foreign service, september 9, 1992, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a23, 1119 words;
notes: on a day of mourning and recrimination, african national congress leader nelson mandela today bitterly accused president frederik w. de klerk of deceiving him during an exchange of letters prior to a march here monday in which 24 demonstrators were killed. while he was soliciting me to give my cooperation, he was preparing for war against the people, mandela told a rally of 15,000 anc supporters who gathered near the site of the massacre. it was some of the harshest language he has ever leveled at the man who has been his on again, off again negotiating partner for 2 1 2 years. although the dead were killed by defense forces of brig. oupo gqozo, military leader of the nominally independent south african homeland of ciskei, mandela made it clear he held de klerk s white minority government partly responsible. although technically a rally for anc supporters, there is a clear protest message against the government at this demonstration.

sources: the washington post, armed marchers defy s. africa s weapons ban, paul taylor, washington post foreign service, october 18, 1992, sunday, final edition, first section; page a36, 458 words;
notes: about 15,000 spear carrying, stick wielding zulus affiliated with the inkatha freedom party marched through downtown johannesburg today in open defiance of a ban, negotiated by the government and the african national congress, on the carrying of dangerous weapons. the demonstration was peaceful, and police, who monitored it with videocameras, made no arrests on the scene. a police spokesman said authorities would decide later whether to bring charges against march leaders for flouting the ban. the demonstration reflected a bitter rift that has developed between the government and inkatha onetime allies in the wake of the sept. 26 meeting between de klerk and nelson mandela, president of the anc, the nation s biggest predominantly black political party and a bitter foe of inkatha. political violence, much of it between the anc and inkatha, has claimed about 6,000 lives in the past two years.

sources: south african police clash with taxi protesters the new york times, february 2, 1993, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk police and taxi drivers clash for second day in south africa the new york times, february 3, 1993, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk protesters in soweto set buses ablaze the times, february 4, 1993, thursday, overseas news, 552 words, from michael hamlyn in johannesburg ;
notes: riot police officers fired tear gas and rubber bullets yesterday to disperse rock throwing taxi drivers who blockaded central johannesburg. the drivers demanded subsidies and complained of discrimination by traffic officers. at least 13 people, including 9 police officers, were injured. cab drivers, complaining that the traffic police harass them, blocked intersections in johannesburg for a second day. a civilian pleaded with advancing troops not to use their guns and tear gas to quell the demonstrators. in the clash, one person was left dead and three hurt. law and order minister hernus kriel declared johannesburg an emergency area, giving police special search and arrest powers after the deaths of two men in violent demonstrations by black taxi drivers. police killed one man and wounded at least three others when they opened fire on a mob attacking a white motorist in central johannesburg, police said. witnesses said a second man died when police opened fire to clear a blockade erected by the protesting taxi drivers. kriel told parliament that police had been fired on as they towed away minibus taxis parked across major intersections by some of the 800 striking black drivers. the killings climaxed two days of violence around the strike by taxi drivers alleging harassment. they virtually paralyzed traffic in south africa s commercial capital monday and said they repeated the protest yesterday to demand the release of seven arrested colleagues. violence swept the soweto township for the third day in succession yesterday, with two buses set on fire, but a heavy police presence kept rioters off the streets in johannesburg. after a tense and angry meeting at which a list of demands was drawn up, the city council reported that no progress had been made in settling the dispute.

sources: angry blacks seek armed uprising the times, april 13, 1993, tuesday, overseas news, 696 words, from michael hamlyn in johannesburg ;
notes: tens of thousands of black protesters took to south african streets yesterday as black anger at the assassination of chris hani boiled over into calls for arms to be taken up against whites. shots were fired by black radicals, police were stoned and vehicles set ablaze. but younger leaders of the anc rejected the peace calls at one mass rally, in the pretoria township of mamelodi. they demanded to know how they could be expected to act responsibly in the face of the assassination on saturday of hani, general secretary of the south african communist party, which was blamed on the government by several speakers. the rally began in a high state of anger after a police car had been stoned, injuring one of the occupants. police reacted by firing tear gas at the gathering crowds, and broke them into smaller processions. the rally ended peacefully with the crowd marching back to the township, shouting and singing freedom songs. a thousand blacks, many carrying spears and axes, marched on hani s home in a suburb of boksburg, near johannesburg, where the alleged assassin, janusz walus, 40, appears in court today. anc youth leaders told the crowd: we want power. we want it now. there was chaos in three east rand townships, katlehong, thokoza and tsikane, as protesters began to set vehicles alight. security reinforcements were rushed to the townships as angry youths tried to burn police trucks, vans and cars. in katlehong a number of black and white reporters and television crews were fired on as they tried to film a blazing truck. juda ngwenya, a photographer for reuters news agency, said he was nearly killed , but that no one was injured. police fired rubber bullets to disperse a crowd that had burnt down a house belonging to a police sergeant in katlehong. the crowd of about 200 people was returning from hani s boksburg house when it began stoning the police station, breaking the windows of buildings and vehicles. the terrified inhabitants of boksburg were visited by more than 5,000 marchers anxious to pay their respects to the dead leader. in cape province, where the worst of the violence broke out at the weekend, the townships were mainly quiet. after a black man had been killed during an exchange of shots between police and demonstrators in the chicken farm squatter camp in soweto on sunday, two white men were burned to death at lwandle township 25 miles from cape town. a third white man, who was also set alight and had his tongue cut during the same attack, died yesterday.

sources: south africa riots lead to 7 deaths; tensions run high the new york times, april 15, 1993, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 1; column 4; foreign desk, 956 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times seven die in south african violence the times, april 15, 1993, thursday, overseas news, 277 words, from michael hamlyn ;
notes: a nationwide day of mourning for the slain black leader chris hani burst out of control today, as angry young blacks rioted through several cities in defiance of pleas for order. in the worst single incident, panicky police officers here fired without warning into a throng milling outside the main police station, killing three and critically wounding five, and replenishing the rage that black leaders hoped would be spent by this day of protest. across the country, crowd control marshals deployed by the african national congress struggled to hold angry youths in check, and often failed. in cape town, durban, port elizabeth, pietermaritzburg and other cities, rallies turned into rampages of looting, burning and clashes with the police. organizers of the day s events said the casualty toll at least seven people were reported killed and hundreds hurt could have been much worse, given the hundreds of thousands who took part and the pitch of emotion after the killing saturday of mr. hani, the communist party leader and a popular figure in the african national congress. journalists and other witnesses at the police station said the crowd was preparing to disperse when an armored police vehicle roared back and forth through the crowd, followed by a police wagon. when a few young men showered stones on the vehicles, the witnesses said, a line of about 30 police, most of them white, opened fire with tear gas, shotguns and pistols. in soweto three demonstrators were killed yesterday as police opened fire on a huge crowd outside soweto s protea park police station. two others were shot and killed in cape town, and two deaths were reported in townships east of johannesburg, bringing the total toll for the day to seven.

sources: the washington post, s. africans bury black hero; tension, sporadic violence, biting orations mark funeral, paul taylor, washington post foreign service, april 20, 1993, tuesday, final edition, first section; page a15, 1067 words;
notes: as stone throwing youths and riot police faced off in running battles outside a soccer stadium here today, african national congress president nelson mandela urged 80,000 mourners inside to honor hani s memory by forming peace brigades. overhead, black smoke wafted past from nearby houses that had been torched by demonstrators. we, the victims of violence, have been blamed for the very acts that take our lives, he said. black lives are cheap and will remain so as long as apartheid continues to exist. and let there be no mistake about it: there have been many changes, and negotiations have started, but for the ordinary black person of this country, apartheid is alive and well. who killed chris hani? slovo asked. it was not just the brute who pulled the trigger. he was killed by a system that turns people into animals, a system that has made our own people foreigners in our own land. . . . let us warn the right wing that however many they kill, they represent a dying cause. they are the cave men of south africa . . . and they must not test the patience of our people.

sources: more right wing whites held over hani plot the times, april 22, 1993, thursday, overseas news, 872 words, from michael hamlyn in johannesburg ;
notes: at ceres, 60 miles northeast of cape town, police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at school children marching to the town hall to protest against a visit by president de klerk s wife, marike. in the ensuing violence two youths were arrested, a policeman s home was attacked by stone throwing youths, police vehicles were attacked and a shop window was smashed, but mrs de klerk s address to a local women s church organisation went ahead as planned. given the response from police and the destruction caused, this protest is assumed to have at least 50 participants.

sources: de klerk warns white extremists the new york times, may 9, 1993, sunday, late edition final, section 1; page 14; column 5; foreign desk, 433 words, reuters ;
notes: about 20 extremist groups met near pretoria friday to form an afrikaner people s front and called for the immediate suspension of multiparty talks on a transition from white rule to democracy. the extremist right wing pressure groups are playing with fire and violations of the law by their side will be dealt with just as strictly as violations by left wing extremists, mr. de klerk said in response to their mobilization. the government will not bow to pressure from the right. those who imagine that negotiations and a new, just dispensation can be stopped are naive. with 20 groups meeting, this protest is assumed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: de klerk warns white extremists the new york times, may 9, 1993, sunday, late edition final, section 1; page 14; column 5; foreign desk, 433 words, reuters ;
notes: in johannesburg, about 6,000 members of the inkatha freedom party, most of whose members are zulus, marched with spears, axes and shields to the offices of the state run television and radio service to protest a perceived anti inkatha bias. vitus mvelase, a member of inkatha s central committee, called for an urgent meeting between mr. mandela and inkatha president mangosuthu buthelezi to halt violence that has killed about 8,000 people in four years.

sources: white separatists storm south african negotiations the new york times, june 26, 1993, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 3; column 1; foreign desk, 1050 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times ;
notes: hundreds of armed white separatists stormed south africa s constitutional negotiations this morning, smashing through the plate glass front of the world trade center in an armored truck and holding many of the country s senior politicians under siege to dramatize their bitterness at the approach of black majority rule. after two hours of swaggering through the convention center just outside johannesburg, spraying graffiti and throwing punches, the khaki clad mob dispersed without causing any serious casualties. about 1,500 followers of the white separatist front, many armed with shotguns and pistols, massed outside the trade center complex this morning to complain that negotiators had rejected their demand for an independent afrikaner homeland. the demonstration was timed to coincide with the negotiators vote confirming the date of the first election for voters of all races next april, which separatists see as the date of their ethnic demise. but the ratification of the election date was put off until next week before the protest occurred. riot policemen put up no resistance as the crowd poured through the building, occupying the main conference room, waving guns and roughing up black journalists and an indian negotiator.

sources: in african township, 30 die in a political rivalry the new york times, august 2, 1993, monday, late edition final, section a; page 2; column 1; foreign desk, 928 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times ;
notes: if the slaughter a week ago was pure terrorism, in which the very senselessness seemed intended to announce that anyone is vulnerable, the attack saturday night was old fashioned vendetta, with deep roots in the local muck of ethnic and political hates. but to mr. dwera and his neighbors, and to many other south africans, both attacks were connected to the prospect of the country s first universal elections, which has given desperate new purpose to those, black and white, who feel endangered by the new order. the two groups have been at odds in tembisa for more than a decade. the hostility began as inevitable friction between settled township residents, whose political tone is set by young militants loyal to the african national congress, and the migrants, mainly rural zulus whose only stake was their jobs in the local factories. as night fell, according to the police and witnesses, a crowd of about 200 zulus descended from the hostel onto the four lane highway, shooting and torching taxis and attacking pedestrians, leaving the asphalt littered with bodies. the highway is used by travelers of all political leanings, but the attackers seemed not to care. at the ngabayena house, the family left supper bubbling on the stove and fled. mxolisi ngabayena took his wife, nokwanda, and their five month old son, bathando, to a bedroom and locked the door. but someone staved in the window above their heads. mother and son were shot dead where they lay. mr. ngabayena was dragged outside and killed. skirmishes continued through the night.

sources: police quell witwatersrand student protests the times, august 21, 1993, saturday, overseas news, 487 words, michael hamlyn ;
notes: witwatersrand university, a former bastion of white liberalism which for years defied the architects of apartheid, has for the first time called in the south african police to restrain students. a hundred and thirty four people were arrested after demonstrations by mobs of mainly black undergraduates disrupted lectures, scattered rubbish around the campus, barricaded entrances and flooded lecture halls with fire hoses. windows were broken and an attempt was made to seize control of the administration offices. senior staff were manhandled. the protests started three days ago, and yesterday lectures were disrupted while a crowd of demonstrators, which at one point was a few hundred strong, paraded through the corridors of the senate building, singing liberation songs. the south african students congress sasco , which is leading the student protests, yesterday called for the resignation of the university council and the senate, and for its replacement by a transitional forum. it should be representative of students, academics, workers and the community, said makhukhu mampuru, sasco s chairman. the council is overflowing with representatives of the apartheid regime.

sources: south africa: rival camps rattle swords the new york times, december 17, 1993, friday, late edition final correction appended, section a; page 13; column 1; foreign desk, 769 words, by kenneth b. noble, special to the new york times ;
notes: if mandela wants war, he ll get it, said eugene terreblanche, leader of the neo nazi afrikaner resistance movement, referring to the african national congress president, nelson mandela. he spoke before about 3,000 cheering supporters, many dressed in khaki uniforms, wearing pistols tucked into their belts or carrying riot sticks. today, the crowd of afrikaners swelled to about 10,000 as speaker after speaker deplored the desecration of their homeland by blacks and jews. ferdi hartzenberg, another right wing leader, told fellow afrikaners: all we ask is our own land, our own country, our own government, our own constitution, our own civil service, our own budget. we will not give up this freedom. we will never, never, never surrender.

sources: zulu might unleashed as king sees de klerk the times, january 18, 1994, tuesday, overseas news, 782 words, michael hamlyn in pretoria ;
notes: tens of thousands of zulus, many dressed in traditional leopard skins and almost all carrying weapons, axes, spears, assegais and knobkerries, massed on the lawns below the union buildings here yesterday, while their king, goodwill zwelethini, met president de klerk inside. a five minute volley of shots in the air came from the crowd during the talks. afterwards two people were reported hurt and another bitten by a dog. the king told president de klerk: neither i nor the amakhosi chiefs who serve the people under me could possibly advise the zulu people to participate in the proposed april 27 election while the present constitution remains what it is. after three hours of talks, the king seemed mollified, and an agreed statement promised establishment of a joint committee to examine kwazulu s status in the new south africa. members of chief buthelezi s party who back participation in the elections were upbeat. this has been very good for us, said one delegate. it gives us a way out. a thunderstorm scattered the crowd, estimated by police at 45,000, before the leaders meeting ended. one man was killed, stabbed with an assegai in pretoria s city centre. the incident was blamed on over indulgence in sorghum beer. an off duty policeman had his jaw broken by a knobkerrie blow, and a bystander suffered an axe wound.

sources: riot police fire on black marchers the times, february 17, 1994, thursday, overseas news, 199 words, michael hamlyn in standerton ;
notes: as many as 68 black demonstrators were hurt, and seven taken to hospital, when riot police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at a crowd of 2,000 trying to march from the sakhile township to this agricultural town in transvaal. they were lying in wait for the marchers on the other side of the railway which divides standerton, 100 miles southeast of johannesburg, from its indian and black townships. however, the uniformed and armed awb storm troopers avoided the attention of the police by staying under cover at the town s cattle market and claiming to be holding a farmers bazaar. tensions have been rising for the past fortnight as the sacking of two supermarket employees for theft led to a strike at the store, and then to a general boycott of the town s shops by the black community. farmers staged a mass protest, driving their tractors through the streets and claiming that standerton was part of an afrikaner volkstaat.

sources: the washington post, bophuthatswanans protest exclusion from election; strikers are tear gassed as s. african homeland chief, refusing to allow vote, reportedly negotiates, paul taylor, washington post foreign service, march 9, 1994, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a15, 433 words creature of apartheid struggles to stave off doom the new york times, march 10, 1994, thursday, late edition final correction appended, section a; page 8; column 3; foreign desk , 888 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times south african police fire on students and township strikers the times, march 10, 1994, thursday, overseas news, 469 words, from michael hamlyn in mafeking and inigo gilmore in messina, northern mangope flees his capital in helicopter the times, march 11, 1994, friday, overseas news, 787 words, from sam kiley in mmabatho, bophuthatswana defiant leader of homeland accedes to a nonracial vote the new york times, march 12, 1994, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 1; column 3; foreign desk , 975 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times ;
notes: police in the black homeland of bophuthatswana used tear gas today to disperse striking civil servants and other demonstrators protesting the refusal of their government to take part in south africa s first multiracial election. the tensions were expected to come to a head over the next few days, as south african authorities threatened coercive measures possibly including cutoff of funds to compel the homeland government to allow free political activity for the april 26 28 election. the homeland government has refused to take part in the election, contending that south africa s new constitution does not allow sufficient power for regions. here in the streets of bophuthatswana s showcase capital, protesters confronted skittish police in skirmishes that left more than 30 injured today. they taunted police officers with showers of rocks and built barricades in the streets. some said they planned raiding parties tonight to set fire to the homes of members of mr. mangope s police force a tactic employed in many south african townships. armed police fired round after round of tear gas, rubber bullets and birdshot in an effort to control crowds of striking workers and students rioting in mmabatho, the bophuthatswana capital, which swiftly spread to outlying townships.the rioters replied with stones and petrol bombs, and blockaded streets with burning tyres, stones and traffic signs. eventually the police resorted to firing live rounds and a number of people were taken to hospital badly hurt. thousands of rioters stormed through the capital of the south african homeland of bophuthatswana yesterday, declaring victory over president mangope, who was seen leaving the city in a helicopter for an unknown destination. mr mangope s refusal on wednesday to allow his subjects to take part in the south african elections in april sparked widespread rioting in which two people, one a policeman, were killed and at least 60 injured. the government of the tribal homeland of bophuthatswana appeared near collapse at daybreak today as thousands of demonstrators demanding the right to take part in south africa s first democratic election marched and looted their way through the area s capital, mmabatho, while police and soldiers made virtually no effort to restrain them. the leader of the apartheid homeland of bophuthatswana today bowed to a popular uprising and agreed to let his ostensibly independent domain take part in the first nonracial elections in south africa.

sources: pretoria jail protest kills 21 in blaze the times, march 22, 1994, tuesday, overseas news, 302 words, by michael hamlyn in johannesburg south africa prison riots gain inmates the vote the times, march 23, 1994, wednesday, overseas news, 438 words, inigo gilmore ;
notes: prisoners rioting for the right to vote in next month s multi racial election set fire to a cell in pretoria last night, starting a blaze that killed 21 people, while 2,400 inmates rampaged through another prison. the deaths came after a weekend of protests in at least 15 prisons by inmates demanding the right to vote. two prisoners died in a fire in paarl, near cape town, on saturday. at pietermaritzburg, in natal, 2,400 prisoners rampaged through the city s prison, destroying cells. with the stench of the burnt out cells still hanging in the air, heavily armed reinforcements were called in to assist prison officers in pietermaritzburg last night after jail riots led to a decision by the transitional executive council to give the vote in next month s elections to every inmate in the country.

sources: at least 31 killed in gun battles in johannesburg the new york times, march 29, 1994, tuesday, late edition final correction appended, section a; page 1; column 3; foreign desk , 1282 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times the washington post, johannesburg battles kill 18, jolt politicians; anc inkatha fight prompts conciliation talks, paul taylor, washington post foreign service, march 29, 1994, tuesday, final edition, first section; page a1, 1187 words ;
notes: gun battles rattled incongruously through the high rise canyons of downtown johannesburg today as a protest by zulu nationalists opposed to elections degenerated into the deadliest melee the city could remember. armed marchers, police officers and snipers hidden in the surrounding buildings blazed away at each other along several blocks of banks and offices, leaving at least 31 people dead and scores wounded. in the worst single battle of the day, eight zulus were killed by rifle wielding african national congress security guards who fired into a crowd of protesters they said was trying to storm the congress s headquarters. merchants shuttered their stores and office workers fled for home when zulus by the thousands converged to demand that kwazulu, the homeland created under apartheid for the zulu people, be excluded from the elections, set for april 26 through 28. the zulu nationalists want their homeland declared a sovereign monarchy. today s clashes began after about 10,000 heavily armed zulus marched in protest against the election. the zulus supporters of inkatha fought backers of the anc, which is expected to gain a landslide victory in the vote.

sources: 60 injured in violent homeland protest the times, march 30, 1994, wednesday, overseas news, 124 words, from inigo gilmore in phuthadijhada, qwaqwa ;
notes: south african defence force troops and homeland police officers patrolled the streets of phuthadijhada, the qwaqwa capital, in armoured vehicles yesterday with the city on a knife edge following clashes and looting after an african national congress march 24 hours earlier. more than 200 people were arrested and troops deployed in the tiny homeland, wedged between the orange free state and natal, when a group of youths broke away from a march by thousands of civil servants to the homeland parliament and ran amok through a shopping centre. up to 60 people were injured. members of the anc aligned national education, health and allied workers union are refusing to return to work unless the homeland government is dissolved.

sources: arms ban is defied at rally by zulu party the new york times, april 6, 1994, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 13; column 1; foreign desk , 837 words, by donatella lorch, special to the new york times the washington post, homeland said unsafe for vote; s. african panel cites bloodshed, resistance in kwazulu, paul taylor, washington post foreign service, april 6, 1994, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a1, 1009 words ;
notes: more than 20,000 zulus armed with traditional weapons such as clubs, spears and machetes marched today in support of their king s demand for a sovereign state and in defiance of the emergency decree that prohibits the carrying of weapons. the march was meant as a show of force not only to protest the government s proclamation of a state of emergency in natal province but also the shooting deaths last week of zulu marchers in johannesburg. heavily armed police officers and troops initially tried to search the marchers as they arrived in this small town in natal, 90 miles north of durban, but they pulled back as thousands of zulus continued to pour in on overloaded buses, many bare chested, chanting and doing war dances. police and the army deployed about 1,000 men to monitor the march. it was the first major political rally held under the new regulations and had been billed in advance as a major test of political will.

sources: buthelezi calls on carrington to mediate postponement of election the times, april 14, 1994, thursday, overseas news, 462 words, sam kiley in ulundi and michael hamlyn in pretoria ;
notes: thousands of zulus gathered at a stadium in vryheid, northern natal, yesterday before marching through the town in protest against the election. many were armed with spears and axes in defiance of emergency regulations, but no attempt was made to disarm them. the transitional executive council tec overseeing the move towards the elections announced yesterday that it was considering extending the voting period in natalkwazulu and broadening emergency legislation to allow it to commandeer kwazulu government property for use as polling stations. that was greeted with dismay by members of the independent electoral commission.

sources: faced with unrest, mandela reduces sentences for prisoners the new york times, june 11, 1994, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 6; column 1; foreign desk , 474 words, ap south africa convicts riot the new york times, june 12, 1994, sunday, late edition final, section 1; page 9; column 1; foreign desk , 97 words, reuters south african prison riot the new york times, june 13, 1994, monday, late edition final, section a; page 6; column 1; foreign desk , 101 words, special to the new york times ;
notes: president nelson mandela s government cut six months off virtually all prison sentences today to halt rioting in several prisons. two people were killed and scores were hurt in the violence. the concession fell short of demands by a prisoners rights group for the release of all prisoners who present no threat to the community. but the group called off mass protests it had advocated earlier this week, and unrest in at least six prisons appeared to have ended. rioting began thursday at the 4,000 inmate prison at modderbee. one prisoner was killed on thursday and another was shot to death by guards today during an attempted escape. about 600 south african prisoners rioted today and held the head of their jail hostage, one day after the government said it would cut jail terms for common criminals in reaction to earlier riots. a correctional services spokesman, brig. chris olckers, said the hostage was the head of the medium security prison at st. albans jail, outside the eastern cape city of port elizabeth. one inmate was killed and 25 were injured today at victor verster prison near cape town in the fourth day of disturbances in south africa s prisons. a spokesman for the department of correctional services said that 270 prison guards regained control of the prison around noon from 665 inmates, some of whom were heavily armed with homemade weapons. the term regaining control implies beatings on part of the guards, and so is included as a response.

sources: strike violence strains anc s relations with trade unions the times, july 18, 1994, monday, overseas news, 408 words, from ray kennedy in johannesburg ;
notes: less than three months after south africa s first democratic election, cracks are beginning to appear in the african national congress s alliance with the congress of south african trade unions cosatu as a wave of strikes over wage demands and union militancy sweeps the country. the talks followed a week in which hundreds of members of the south african catering, commercial and allied workers union, a cosatu affiliate, were arrested during violent demonstrations at supermarkets owned by pick n pay, one of the country s biggest retail chains. they were involved in clashes with police little different from those seen under the national party government. more than 70 strikers were injured by rubber bullets and dog bites. mr shilowa said cosatu expected anc ministers to remove repressive labour legislation. we are being asked by our members if democracy will ever mean anything more than the right to vote every five years. although this protest was against a private company, it was coded due to the demand that the union members have for the government to repeal certain legislation.

sources: mandela defied in unions march the times, july 26, 1994, tuesday, overseas news, 153 words, from ray kennedy in johannesburg ;
notes: several thousand trade unionists marched through the centre of johannesburg yesterday as south africa s winter of discontent continued to gather momentum. cosatu repeated a threat to call a national one day strike on august 8 unless employers met all union demands by the end of this month. langa zita, cosatu s regional secretary, said the march was the first campaign of workers in the new society with the object of putting workers demands at the top of the new agenda .

sources: south african wildcat truck strike worries business leaders the new york times, august 25, 1994, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 11; column 1; foreign desk , 633 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times ;
notes: a wildcat trucking strike that turned many miles of africa s most modern highway system into a fuming gridlock ended tonight, but not before creating new fears of anarchy to bedevil president nelson mandela in his courtship of foreign investors. the protest began on monday when hundreds of truckers demanding better pay parked across a tollgate on the country s busiest freight highway, near the indian ocean port of durban. it spread quickly to three other major routes, as the truckers rallied one another to choke points on citizens band radios. mr. mandela s minister of labor, tito mboweni, mediated a deal in which the truckers agreed to open the roadblocks in exchange for a promise that the employers would meet them in a nationwide bargaining council and that wages would be changed radically. the drivers said their campaign, which began without warning or union approval, was a spontaneous explosion of frustration sparked by a feeling that they deserved some reward for helping elect mr. mandela. truck drivers are mostly black and less than half belong to unions. julius matroose, a spokesman for the union, said many workers were disappointed that the election of mr. mandela s african national congress had not produced quick dividends for workers, and that mr. mandela was counseling patience. mr. matroose said full time truckers now get a minimum wage of about 400 a month, plus large amounts of overtime, but they work exhausting hours in trucks that are often badly maintained.

sources: students riot on campuses in south africa the times, august 27, 1994, saturday, overseas news, 340 words, michael hamlyn in johannesburg ;
notes: student unrest has spread like a veld fire in south africa as black undergraduates fight the mainly white, often liberal, administrations of higher education institutions. police used teargas and dogs to clear rioting black students from the university of south africa campus in pretoria. six staff members were injured, and the authorities have banned students from the university s premises there and in johannesburg. at vanderbijl park, south of here, majority white students and their black colleagues fought with baseball bats and knobkerries at the vaal triangle technikon, a college of advanced technology. the clash was provoked by rightwingers declaring a hall of residence to be a boerestaat white homeland , and expelling blacks. in bloemfontein, black students occupied the administration block of the university of the orange free state, protesting at the unsatisfactory results of elections to the student representative council. perhaps saddest of all, however, is the havoc wrought at the university of the witwatersrand in johannesburg, where rampaging black students threw stones, broke windows, turned on fire hoses and threw rubbish everywhere. black student demands differ from college to college but they essentially concern the inability of many of the students to pay fees or to meet rigorous culturally based examination requirements. they are demanding black student control of college administrations and, at wits, the sacking of professor robert charlton, the vice chancellor. this protest is believed to have at least 1000 people due to how widespread it is and that it is taking place in large universities across the nation.

sources: mixed race south africans riot over favoritism for blacks the new york times, september 16, 1994, friday, late edition final, section a; page 9; column 1; foreign desk , 577 words, by bill keller, special to the new york times ;
notes: the riotous scenes were reminiscent of soweto in the days of anti apartheid fervor: barricades of burning tires, rocks flying, buildings in flames, white police firing stun grenades and rubber bullets, and a smoldering racial resentment. but the target of the uprising today, in this and several other customarily sleepy townships just west of johannesburg, was nelson mandela s government, and the protesters were the country s often invisible mixed race minority, who call themselves coloreds. asserting that after decades of short shrift from white rulers they are now victims of favoritism for blacks in housing, services and jobs, the mixed race townships organized a one day general strike and began a boycott of rent and utility payments. the day ended without deaths and with few serious injuries a young woman shot in the face with a police rubber bullet, and several residents hit by birdshot when police officers fired on a crowd. although the protest technically took place in townships just outside of johannesburg, their names were not given, and johannesburg is very close, so that was the city chosen to represent the location of this protest. given the violence and the reaction to the protest, as well as how it spanned across multiple townships, it is believed there were at least 100 participants.

sources: world news briefs; south africa dismisses 2,200 awol soldiers the new york times, november 8, 1994, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 10; column 2; foreign desk , 112 words, reuters ;
notes: defense minister joe modise said today that more than 2,200 former guerrillas had been dismissed from the army for failing to meet a midnight deadline to report for duty after they left their base during a protest. mr. modise said there would be no last minute reprieve for the men and women who left the walmansthal base near pretoria last week to protest conditions, wages and the pace of their integration into the south african national defense force. he also warned against any effort by those who left to set up an underground movement. he said that 4,000 of the former guerrillas who had left the base had responded to his warnings and had returned.

sources: mandela appoints new chief in police shake up the times, january 30, 1995, monday, overseas news, 415 words, from inigo gilmore in pretoria south africa strikes jolt foreign investors the times, january 31, 1995, tuesday, overseas news, 462 words, michael hamlyn in johannesburg ;
notes: more immediately, they must deal with the issue of racism which has been made more pressing after a black policeman was shot dead by white riot police in soweto on friday during an attempt to end a strike. the latest racial clash within the force led several polic stations in soweto to shut down or go slow at the weekend in protest against the killing and to demand the removal of white officers. after a strike by black policemen in the orlando area of soweto, about 400 residents gathered outside the station yesterday to call for the suspension of brigadier chris earle, the district commissioner. the protesters believed that he had given the order for an internal stability unit to open fire on striking policemen at the station on friday; one striking officer was killed. the demonstrators wanted sidney mufamadi, the safety and security minister, to accept their petition personally.

sources: the washington post, s. african whites protest integration, february 16, 1995, thursday, final edition, a section; pg. a37, 217 words;
notes: right wing whites with sticks and dogs shouted racist insults and attacked black schoolchildren near cape town in an attempt to disrupt post apartheid south africa s tentative steps toward school integration. a white man was arrested after beating a youth with a whip as blacks and whites faced off across a street in ruyterwacht, a low income white suburb. about 100 police protected about 3,000 black children bused into the area from the khayelitsha township nine miles away in a campaign organized by the national education coordination committee to occupy abandoned white schools. a spokesman for the committee, a nongovernmental lobbying group, said a black youth had been fatally stabbed on the school grounds, probably by a fellow student. about 150 whites, some armed with chains or sticks and several holding snarling dogs, tried to prevent the children from entering the school, but police kept them at bay. police stood by throughout the day and escorted the children to their buses shortly after noon.

protesteridentity: objectors to new labour relations bill
sources: workers march against law the times, june 7, 1995, wednesday, overseas news, 440 words, michael hamlyn ;
notes: more than 100,000 people marched through the centre of johannesburg yesterday in a peaceful demonstration organised by the african national congress aligned confederation of south african trade unions cosatu . they were marching in support of cosatu objections to a new labour relations bill. the demands included a ban on management lockouts, the right to strike, and central bargaining. the real motivation was the feeling that not enough has been done to fulfil the aspirations of the black majority after the elections last year. at least one marcher bore a placard reading: let s get south africa working. jobs. jobs. jobs. recognising the strength of numbers on the streets of the commercial and industrial capital, president mandela surprised everybody by arriving at the head of the procession to address the crowd from the back of a lorry. he offered the demonstrators his support, and blessed their efforts, and while reminding them that the anc had always used the right to strike and demonstrate in its freedom struggle, he asked them to be disciplined.

sources: 3 die in south africa the new york times, june 6, 1995, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 11; column 1; foreign desk , 70 words, reuters ;
notes: at least three people were killed today when some 2,000 african national congress supporters marched to protest violence in south africa s zulu heartland, the police said. the latest deaths, in umlazi township outside the port city of durban, brought to at least 35 the number of people killed in the province since friday. the a.n.c. supporters marched to the magistrate s courts to protest the violence. the demand for this protest is coded as political process, since the protesters are angry about violence and therefore the government s inability to curb it.

sources: strikers take on mandela over pay the times, september 21, 1995, thursday, overseas news, 244 words, michael hamlyn in johannesburg ;
notes: nurses representatives have given the health minister ten days to meet a demand for a 33 per cent pay increase, postal workers have downed mailbags in pretoria, and train drivers have gone on strike on the cape town commuter network, stranding 200,000 workers. the municipal workers are seeking a minimum wage of 1,500 rands a month pounds 265 . the nurses, who brought the giant baragwanath hospital in soweto to a standstill two weeks ago, were told flatly that the government has no money for increases this year. police fired rubber bullets at demonstrations in the east rand outside johannesburg yesterday. the only casualties reported were two police hit by stones thrown by strikers. in pretoria, 2,000 strikers danced in protest outside the municipal offices, waving clubs and knobkerries, despite a court order forbidding demonstrations within 100 yards of the building.

sources: in a tense johannesburg, zulus hold peaceful rally the new york times, march 29, 1996, friday, late edition final, section a; page 12; column 1; foreign desk , 766 words, by suzanne daley ;
notes: thousands of police officers and soldiers patrolled the streets, the railroad stations and migrant workers hostels. sections of downtown were cordoned off with razor wire, and many businesses closed, their employees too frightened to be downtown when the zulus marched. the fear was that the rally, planned to commemorate the 1994 killings of eight zulus by guards at the african national congress s headquarters, would turn into the big showdown between the zulu based inkatha freedom party and what is now the a.n.c. led government. the immediate issue leading up to today s rally was the zulus rights to carry spears, clubs and other weapons at political rallies. but that was just the latest fight in the continuing feud between the congress and its most powerful black rival. but by evening, to nearly everyone s surprise, thousands of zulus had marched peacefully through downtown and both sides were claiming moral victory. each side, it seems, had given a little. the marchers were virtually all armed, and the police took away only a handful of weapons. the catch was that the weaponry had been toned down compared with earlier zulu rallies. virtually no marchers had rifles, axes or big panga knives. less than 10 percent had spears and many of those had their points wrapped in plastic or corked with corncobs. most carried knobby headed clubs, stout or sharpened sticks and small oxhide shields. a few carried only umbrellas or even mock weapons, like cardboard shields and cardboard tubes. due to the presence of 1000s of police officers, this protest is assumed to also have 1000s of participants.

protesteridentity: confederation of south african trade unions
sources: general strike fails in south africa the new york times, may 1, 1996, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 2; foreign desk , 178 words, by the new york times ;
notes: a general strike, called to fight a constitutional provision, seemed to fizzle today. with a deadline looming for constitutional negotiators to complete their work, the strike had been called to prevent the insertion in the new charter of language giving employers the right to lock out workers. for the confederation of south african trade unions, it was its first nationwide strike under black majority rule. the confederation, a powerful backer of the african national congress government, may lose some of its credibility as a result of today s lukewarm showing. it said there was 100 percent participation in some areas and 40 to 70 percent in others and said 350,000 workers took to the streets in different cities. but journalists estimated no more than 10,000 in johannesburg, 8,000 in cape town and pretoria and fewer in smaller cities. though technically a strike, article pointed to the fact that workers took to the streets; hence, this gathering makes this a codeable protest.

sources: battles put natal elections at risk the times, may 6, 1996; monday, overseas news, 319 words, inigo gilmore in johannesburg ;
notes: emergency talks were held at the weekend by president mandela after a gun battle between policemen and zulu marchers in durban threatened to disrupt plans for local government elections in the province of kwazulu natal this month. three policemen and 20 other people were injured on saturday when the police fought running gun battles with marchers among 7,000 zulus who descended on the city to protest against the ban on carrying traditional weapons in public. soon after a memorandum was handed in at the city hall, gunfire broke out from the crowd, sending people running for cover. police officers chased demonstrators carrying automatic weapons and searched for a sniper in an arcade. the south african leader summoned senior security officials to talks on saturday evening, hours after armoured troop carriers rolled into a barricaded durban city centre. the fact that a gun battle happened shows that one of the responses to this protest was shootings as well as crowd dispersal.

sources: township battle after 15 die in crush at station the times, august 1, 1996, thursday, overseas news, 708 words, inigo gilmore protesters set fire to train in township the times, august 2, 1996, friday, overseas news, 201 words, inigo gilmore in johannesburg the washington post, s. african stampede death toll reaches 16, lynne duke, washington post foreign service, august 02, 1996, friday, final edition, a section; pg. a17, 459 words ;
notes: an electric baton attack by security guards on railway fare dodgers led to a riot and a narrow escape from a violent crowd for inigo gilmore. youths fought running battles with police yesterday in tembisa township, 20 miles northeast of johannesburg, as they vented their anger after a rush hour railway station stampede left 15 people dead and more than 50 injured. in rare scenes of township violence since the end of apartheid, hundreds of youths rampaged through the dusty streets around the station vowing to kill the security guards. they also set upon journalists at the scene. riot police, firing rubber bullets and teargas, chased the mob across waste ground where i was standing. as they took up positions, a white policeman beckoned aggressively to his tormentors as they hurled rocks at him. more than 50 people were reportedly admitted to a hospital in the township with injuries caused by electric shocks. residents have pledged to conduct an arson campaign to protest at transport conditions in the township and the heavy handed use of force by security guards at the main commuter station. the guards have been accused of provoking a stampede by firing shots and using electric batons on commuters. metro rail yesterday withdrew its security personnel for fear of aggravating the situation. the bizarre incident occurred during morning rush hour as thousands of workers and students in this black township 15 miles north of johannesburg tried to board the trains, but were greeted by ticket checking security guards on a mission to stop fare evasion. tembisa station, which handles 17,000 commuters a day from this sprawling township of several hundred thousand, draws an especially heavy crowd of non payers, mateya said. metrorail tried to crack down this week by adding 14 extra security guards to the usual contingent of eight. faced with a rush of commuters wednesday, the guards used their electric prods to try to stop ticketless passengers from assembling on the station platforms. since the rail is a state owned enterprise and this riot was triggered by a change in policy number of security guards and checking tickets , this was considered a codeable protest.

sources: muslims in drug protest riot in cape town the new york times, august 12, 1996, monday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk , 272 words, reuters the washington post, vigilante justice in s. africa; fed up with crime, muslim groups take law into own hands, lynne duke, washington post foreign service, august 17, 1996, saturday, final edition, a section; pg. a18, 1249 words ;
notes: rioting erupted here cape town today when south african police and troops moved in on a march by armed muslim protesters who have vowed to eradicate drug dealing by local criminal gangs. the police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at the vanguard of some 5,000 marchers, mostly young men wearing headscarves and chanting god is great! who tried to break through a police roadblock. soldiers with rifles and gas masks poured in to support the police. a police spokesman said nine people had been wounded in the rioting, most of them by a hand grenade that was thrown at the police but that landed in the crowd instead. the clashes died down when demonstrators later headed to gatesville, the largest mosque in the area, for evening prayers, some chanting, one gangster, one bullet! the marchers vowed to become vigilantes because the local police has been inadequate in doing so. thus, the demand for this protest was considered to be political process. in recent months, masked muslim vigilantes allegedly have shot up the homes of drug dealers. they besieged the home of the nation s justice minister, also a muslim, to protest law enforcement inaction. then last week, with police and cameramen watching, vigilantes shrouded in masks and traditional kaffiyeh scarves shot and burned to death an infamous drug merchant. although many muslims supported the anti apartheid struggle waged by president nelson mandela s african national congress, they are growing concerned about the new government s liberalism, including its abolition of the death penalty and its support for abortion rights, a muslim leader said. some muslims, who under apartheid were classified as mixed race coloreds, feel alienated from the black majority, with whom they share neither language nor culture. in a nation whose crime rate is said to be the highest in the world, the neighborhoods of the flats have been ravaged by gangsters and drug dealers. scores of gangs have been operating here for two decades, and they have become more entrenched during this transition to full democracy and the influx of the international drug trade. they also have been strengthened by police collusion first for political aims under apartheid, when some gangsters were recruited as informants, and now for monetary gain as well as protection from their past malfeasance, according to criminologist wilfried scharf of the university of cape town.

sources: clashes at zulu protest the times, december 6, 1996, friday, overseas news, 190 words, inigo gilmore ;
notes: a protester makes a peace sign after south african police fired teargas and stun grenades yesterday at hundreds of zulus, some armed with handguns and traditional weapons, demonstrating on the east rand over eviction from a township. about 800 residents associated with the inkatha freedom party in the township of thokoza had started marching towards council offices in the nearby town of alberton after chasing away officials who tried to serve eviction notices inigo gilmore writes . the residents fired shots before police cordoned off roads and fired stun grenades to disperse the crowd. the trouble had its roots in violence during the run up to the 1994 election, in which thokoza was a focal point. supporters of president mandela s african national congress fled their homes when inkatha supporters occupied them. since then the township has been divided, with anc supporters living in one half and inkatha supporters in the other.

protesteridentity: people against gangsterism and drugs pagad
sources: cape vigilantes clash with police at airport the times, december 17, 1996, tuesday, overseas news, 246 words, inigo gilmore in johannesburg ;
notes: muslim vigilantes fought running battles with police for more than an hour at cape town s international airport yesterday over their demands that drug detection equipment be installed at customs posts. the illegal protest by people against gangsterism and drugs pagad and the subsequent riot caused disruption as hundreds of british tourists began arriving in south africa for a christmas break. the group s gambit of demonstrating at the airport and other choice tourist venues has brought it into direct conflict with the government. five people were injured in the riot, including two journalists, after 200 pagad members pelted police with stones. police retaliated with rubber bullets and teargas. the violence erupted near the airport entrance when pagad refused to disperse. witnesses said the marchers, chanting mandela is a dictator , were given ten minutes to leave. as the march leader tried to turn them back, a woman hurled an object at police, triggering the riot. the government has banned pagad from carrying weapons and wearing masks during its protests. last week president mandela warned it that the government would not tolerate protests at airports and other tourist venues.

sources: seeing bias in their utiity rates, mixed race south africans riot the new york times, february 7, 1997, friday, late edition final, section a; page 15; column 1; foreign desk , 742 words, by suzanne daley four feared dead in south africa riots the times, february 7, 1997, friday, overseas news, 400 words, ray kennedy in johannesburg ;
notes: residents of mainly mixed race neighborhoods around johannesburg took to the streets today, blocking roads with debris and burning tires, throwing rocks and in some cases looting stores to protest what they say is discrimination by south africa s new government. early in the day the police used tear gas and rubber bullets to quell the protests, but later they turned to buckshot and live rounds of ammunition. there were unconfirmed reports that four people, including one young boy, had been killed and hospitals in the area reported treating more than 30 people for various injuries. under apartheid, mixed race people had more privileges than blacks and are generally richer and better educated. but the community group that organized the protest is questioning why the mixed race community is paying fees based on meter readings when vast areas of soweto are being asked to pay a small fixed fee. but in addition to objecting to the fees, many of the protesters expressed a far broader anger at a sense that they were being left out of the new south africa. in westbury, hundreds of people clustered at intersections along the main road building barricades and taunting police officers. whenever the officers tried to take the barriers away, demonstrators would restore them within minutes. at one point, a taxi driver who tried to get through was hauled from his car and slapped by the demonstrators. the police eventually scattered the crowd with tear gas and rubber bullets. the most dramatic incidents were in the eldorado park neighborhood where the protesters and the police clashed repeatedly during the day. at one point, a mob smashed the windows of a service station and convenience store and began making off with cartons of sodas and bags of rolls. a police helicopter began circling and firing from the air and riot police officers arrived with tear gas. but half an hour later, the police had moved off and the crowd continued its work until every shelf was stripped bare. troops moved into coloured suburbs of johannesburg last night after a day of running gun battles between police and residents in which at least four people one a boy, aged seven were reported killed and 200 injured. police, who tackled rampaging mobs with buckshot, rubber bullets and teargas, said they had been forced to open fire in the rundown mixed race eldorado park and westbury districts, where a one day work stoppage was called to protest against evictions and the cutting of electricity supplies over non payment of rent.

sources: zulus protest 1994 deaths in johannesburg the new york times, march 13, 1997, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 7; column 1; foreign desk , 368 words, ap six killed as zulu marchers protest over massacre the times, march 13, 1997, thursday, overseas news, 702 words, inigo gilmore in johannesburg ;
