notes: thousands of zulus marched angrily through downtown johannesburg today in a show of strength that ended in gunfire, reminding south africa of its simmering political rivalries. the protest marked the unpunished killings of eight people in a similar demonstration in 1994, shortly before the country s first all race election that ended apartheid. the police reported at least two deaths and nine injuries eight from gunshots during the day, which began with violence in black townships as zulu nationalists traveled to johannesburg for a rally at the central library. zulu leaders dressed in tribal costumes led regiments of their followers armed with everything from traditional wooden clubs to rusty mop handles. speakers at the rally called for justice for the killings three years ago, when security guards at african national congress headquarters opened fire on approaching zulu marchers. when the rally ended, shooting began in the downtown streets, causing marchers, police and bystanders to dive for cover. the sound of pistols and automatic weapons echoed off the tall buildings for several minutes. the police said eight people were arrested. the angry marching and the fact that the zulus were armed pointed towards the fact that the protesters were violent. at a rally in the library gardens in central johannesburg a man in the massed ranks of zulu marchers, allegedly aligned to the inkatha freedom party, began firing into the air. as shots rang out, demonstrators among the estimated 18,000 crowd fled along nearby streets as policemen took up positions behind parked cars.

sources: news summary the new york times, march 20, 1998, friday, late edition final, section a; page 2; column 3; metropolitan desk, 1452 words the washington post, races clash in south africa; violent confrontations over schooling revive old conflicts, lynne duke, washington post foreign service, march 25, 1998, wednesday, final edition, a section; pg. a23, 981 words ;
notes: hundreds of black demonstrators in south africa marched in support of black students at a high school beset by racial violence. the marchers demanded that the school, in a white area that has resisted racial integration, be closed and its principal and governing body be removed. the center of it all, the formerly all white vryburg high, now is shut down and ringed by a wall of razor wire the latest unsettling symbol of just how fragile south africa s new democracy is in the nation s remote reaches.

protesteridentity: the people against gangsterism and drugs
sources: the queen in london the times, march 9, 1998, monday, features, 528 words ;
notes: south african police officers fired tear gas at hundreds of muslims to break up an illegal march against widespread gangsterism. the people against gangsterism and drugs had permission to march against drug lords in the cape flats township, which houses most of cape town s poor. but the crowd took an unauthorized route after police said every protester had to submit to a body search.

sources: general strike as rand plummets the times london , may 11, 2000, thursday, overseas news, 58 words ;
notes: johannesburg: tens of thousands of trade unionists staged a one day general strike across south africa in protest against the government s economic policies and rising unemployment. the stoppage cost the economy millions of pounds. at the same time the currency touched a new low of 10.86 rands to the pound and 7.16 rands to the dollar.

sources: aids forum in south africa opens knotted in disputes the new york times, july 10, 2000, monday, late edition final correction appended, section a; page 6; column 3; foreign desk , 1398 words, by rachel l. swarns and lawrence k. altman ;
notes: thousands of people held a protest rally at city hall before the meeting opened, with winnie madikizela mandela and others in the crowd berating the government for failing to speak frankly about the link between h.i.v. and aids and lagging in its efforts to fight the epidemic. aids exists, said mrs. madikizela mandela, the ex wife of former president nelson mandela and a political leader in her own right. h.i.v. causes aids. we cannot proclaim this century the african century and then ignore the aids pandemic as some political leaders are.

sources: afrikaners accuse mbeki of land grab the times london , march 17, 2001, saturday, overseas news, 418 words, michael dynes in lydenburg ;
notes: hundreds of white farmers gathered at the dutch reformed church here to protest against the return of the first white owned property to its original black owners yesterday, and accused the south african government of thabo mbeki of carrying out a mugabe style land grab. about 300 white farmers and their supporters from the lydenburg area, once a heartland of the extreme right wing awb movement, started a legal campaign against what they called a monstrous assault on white property rights. the accusation comes after pretoria s decision to press ahead with the expropriation of a 3,000 acre property belonging to willem pretorius, a white farmer from lydenburg in mpumalanga province, to return the land to its original black owners. kwape mmela, of the commission on the restitution of land rights, dismissed mr pretorius s accusations of a zimbabwe style land grab. you cannot use state money to develop a farm and expect the government to give more state money to buy it back.

sources: pretoria thwarts land grab the times london , july 6, 2001, friday, home news, 157 words, michael dynes in bredell, the east rand ;
notes: hundreds of policemen swooped on a squatter camp outside johannesburg yesterday after the pretoria government announced that it would move swiftly to prevent any zimbabwe style land grabs in south africa. armoured vehicles were sent at dawn to a field at bredell, near the city s international airport, where thousands of landless black people had been queuing for days to buy a plot of land for 25 rand pounds 2 . the pan african congress pac , a small radical party, began selling plots of land owned by the local council in protest at the slow pace of the government s land reform programme. more than 70 people, including two members of the pac, were arrested for trespassing after police armed with shotguns blocked access to the field and began patrolling the camp to prevent the squatters bringing in building materials to erect makeshift homes. about 20,000 people were estimated to have been at the site.

sources: s. africa flattens squatter homes; peasants say move invokes memory of apartheid the washington post, july 13, 2001 friday, a section; pg. a01, 1009 words, jon jeter, washington post foreign service ;
notes: in riot gear and armored cars, the police arrived at noon, escorting construction workers who tore through the warren of tin shacks with crowbars, leaving one home after another in a heap of scrap metal and ripped tarpaulin. with nowhere to go, hundreds of squatters who settled on the sprawling, dusty patch of land known as elandsfontein farm 12 watched as their homes were flattened. men shook their fists defiantly at the police, while women chanted anti government slogans and danced in protest, baring their breasts to taunt the demolition crews. authorities arrested 110 of the squatters last week, and most of the others packed up and left, leaving a few hundred still on the land.

sources: world briefing africa: south africa: new squatter protest the new york times, july 26, 2001 thursday, section a; column 2; foreign desk; pg. 6, 64 words, agence france presse ;
notes: about 200 angry squatters occupied land in khayelitsha township in cape town, emulating a larger land invasion outside johannesburg earlier this month. the squatters moved onto the private land during the afternoon, the police said, and demanded that the government build them houses. the squatters measured out plots, marked them with wire and started digging trenches around them.

sources: south africa sees turmoil dividing ruling party the new york times, november 20, 2001 tuesday, section a; column 3; foreign desk; pg. 11, 767 words, by rachel l. swarns ;
notes: south africa has lost thousands of jobs even as mr. mbeki s government has been praised by the international monetary fund for reducing the deficit and inflation and improving tax collection. ordinary people say they have suffered from economic restructuring. in august, thousands of workers marched to protest plans to privatize state enterprises. today, the union said it was a planning a similar march for early next year. this is not what we expected from the government we voted for, said mbulelo bara, 30, an assembly worker who attended the meeting. huge numbers of jobs are being lost. the dissatisfaction of workers must be dealt with. since this article discussed a past protest, wires were then searched to see if any specific information could be found: tens of thousands of trade unionists demonstrated in cities across south africa on thursday to demand that the government abandon plans to privatise state owned enterprises.

sources: world briefing africa: south africa: arrests in land protests the new york times, august 22, 2002 thursday, section a; column 4; foreign desk; pg. 6, 109 words, agence france presse ;
notes: fifty two protesters were arrested after about 2,000 landless south africans marched in johannesburg to demand an end to forced removals from squatter camps. those arrested refused to move away from a government office they had put under siege, a police spokeswoman said. under siege implies protester violence.

sources: in south africa, leaders face blacks ire the new york times, october 2, 2002 wednesday, section a; column 1; foreign desk; pg. 10, 937 words, by rachel l. swarns ;
notes: the black protesters marched by the thousands today through the gritty heart of this mining city. they shouted angry slogans, waved fiery banners and, for a moment, it felt like the old days when blacks took to the streets to oppose the white apartheid government. the demonstrators accused the government of losing touch with the poor, who are struggling to cope with deep unemployment and surging food prices. they demanded an end to the nation s privatization of state assets, which they say has resulted in job losses. create decent jobs! the marchers cried. privatization is born again apartheid!

sources: world briefing africa: south africa: protest for aids drugs the new york times, march 26, 2003 wednesday, section a; column 5; foreign desk; pg. 6, 57 words, reuters ;
notes: stepping up a civil disobedience campaign aimed at forcing the government to provide drugs for aids patients, about 50 activists shouted down the country s health minister, manto tshabalala msimang, as she made a speech in cape town, and called for her resignation. the government contends that the antiretroviral drugs are too expensive.

sources: aids summit opens with accusations; south africa s delay in introducing anti retroviral drugs fuels outrage the washington post, august 4, 2003 monday, a section; pg. a11, 428 words, reuters ;
notes: activists jeered south africa s health minister today at the opening of a national aids conference, reflecting mounting anger at the government s tepid response to the disease, which activists say kills 600 south africans a day. protesters holding up signs reading save our youth, save our future, treat aids now heckled the health minister, manto tshabalala msimang, as she opened the conference attended by 2,500 delegates in the port city of durban. critics say that south africa has moved too slowly in addressing hiv aids and that the government s refusal to permit public sector hospitals to use anti retroviral drugs, the only medicines that have proved effective against aids, has stoked anger. president thabo mbeki s government has questioned the drugs as expensive, potentially dangerous and difficult to take, arguing that south africa s priority must be on fighting the widespread black poverty that remains nine years after the end of white rule. the number of protesters is coded as 100 because although there were 2500 people attending the conference, it is not known whether all 2500 of these attendees were protesters.

protesteridentity: victims of crimes and their allies
sources: races unite in protest against crime the times london , december 1, 2003, monday, overseas news; 15, 487 words, michael dynes in johannesburg ;
notes: the centre of johannesburg was brought to a standstill yesterday as thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in an unprecedented protest against murder, hijackings, violent robbery and rape. in scenes reminiscent of the mass marches against apartheid, people of every race and creed walked side by side demanding urgent government action to end the high crime rates that are blighting their lives. impoverished shack dwellers from black townships and squatter camps linked arms with the well heeled residents of the affluent white suburbs, chanting enough is enough . many of the protesters in south africa s first multiracial march against violent crime had lost relatives in robberies, car hijackings and assaults, or had been the victims of crime during the ten years since black majority rule. representatives of every political party took part in the march, except the anc, which reneged on a promise to join the protesters and accept a memorandum from the organisers demanding a nationwide anti crime campaign. mrs vince jillings, who founded the alive campaign to encourage the government to take more effective action against crime, has given the anc three months to respond to alive s demand to publish the crime statistics, increase police numbers in urban areas and allocate far more resources to prosecute the perpetrators of violent offences.

sources: world briefing africa: south africa: wage protests ripple across country the new york times, september 3, 2004 friday, section a; column 3; foreign desk; pg. 6, 106 words, reuters ;
notes: thousands of public workers staged some of the biggest protests since the end of apartheid, pressuring the government for wage increases for teachers, nurses and other workers. the police estimated that more than 12,000 people jammed the streets of johannesburg while another 2,000 protesters gathered in front of parliament in cape town. union officials reported large turnouts in other cities. the protests follow a string of other demonstrations demanding better housing and more jobs. the sustained public pressure is intended to make the governing african national congress deliver on promises that helped it win the elections in april.

sources: olmert flies to south africa the jerusalem post, october 21, 2004 thursday, news; pg. 6, 284 words, ap ;
notes: his visit provoked protests by hundreds of muslim south africans who staged marches in three cities over the weekend demanding that their country cut economic ties with israel. a handful of picketers gathered wednesday outside the sandton convention center, where the investment agreement was due to be signed, chanting free palestine and holding placards reading boycott apartheid israel. police moved the demonstrators across the street, and they dispersed before olmert arrived. since this protest included calls for the south african government to cut ties with israel, this was considered as being against the government.

sources: world briefing africa: south africa: students riot over tuition increase the new york times, february 18, 2005 friday, section a; column 5; foreign desk; pg. 6, 103 words, by michael wines nyt ;
notes: police officers used rubber bullets and water cannons against 1,000 students at tshwane university of technology protesting tuition increases and housing shortages at their campus in soshanguve, north of pretoria. the riot was spawned by the students contention that the university had doubled tuition instead of raising it by a promised 6 percent. the university says that fees had been sharply raised for some individual courses but that the basic tuition rate was not greatly increased. the students set fire to a police vehicle and stoned motorists and police officers before being dispersed. michael wines nyt

sources: shantytown dwellers in south africa protest the sluggish pace of change the new york times, december 25, 2005 sunday, section 1; column 1; foreign desk; pg. 10, 1813 words, by michael wines ;
notes: sending what some call an ominous signal to this nation s leaders, south africa s sprawling shantytowns have begun to erupt, sometimes violently, in protest over the government s inability to deliver the better life that the end of apartheid seemed to herald a dozen years ago. at a hillside shantytown in durban called foreman road, riot police officers fired rubber bullets in mid november to disperse 2,000 residents marching to the municipal mayor s office downtown. two protesters were injured; 45 were arrested. the rest burned an effigy of the city s mayor, obed mlaba. lacking cars, taxi fare or even bicycles to commute to work, the residents marched in protest on nov. 14, defying the city s refusal to issue a permit. the demonstration quickly turned violent. this article also refers to other protests but unfortunately there is not enough information available to confidently code them.

sources: cape town rally demands sanctions the jerusalem post, august 6, 2006, sunday, news; pg. 5, 233 words, ap; jerusalem post staff contributed to this report. ;
notes: thousands of south africans marched through cape town to parliament on saturday to demand sanctions against israel for its strikes against lebanon and the palestinian territories. they urged the south african government to recall its ambassador from israel and sever diplomatic ties impose trade sanctions and prosecute south africans who serve in the israeli defense force. since the protesters are demanding action from their government and are not just protesting the actions of a foreign nation, this demonstration was coded.

sources: thousands support strike dividing the unions and anc the times london , june 14, 2007, thursday, overseas news; pg. 41, 450 words, jonathan clayton in johannesburg ;
notes: thousands of south african workers marched in sympathy with striking civil servants yesterday in the biggest show of force against the government since the end of apartheid. bringing city centres across the country to a halt, demonstrators demanded higher salaries for teachers nurses and policemen, highlighting the divide between the ruling african national congress anc and its trade union allies. the powerful confederation of south african trade unions cosatu , one of the main allies of the anc led liberation movement, called the demonstrations to support a 12 day strike by public sector unions, in which about 600 nurses have been sacked amid intimidation of non strikers. patrick craven, a cosatu spokesman, estimated that the march in johannesburg s central business district attracted about 15,000 people. we just hope this show of force will convince the government to enter serious negotiations, he said.

sources: south africa: angry soweto clashes the new york times, september 4, 2007 tuesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; world briefing africa; pg. 6, 109 words, by michael wines ;
notes: police officers fired water cannons and rubber bullets at about 500 protesters in soweto after crowds gathered in two neighborhoods, protea and kliptown, to complain about municipal services. the kliptown protest was calm, but the protea crowd blocked a highway and threw stones at the police and journalists, sending one photographer to a hospital. one protester was killed when a bakery van accidentally backed over him; several others were arrested. protests over poor services have become common in the country s poorest neighborhoods as the government struggles to provide water, power and other basic utilities to shantytowns and low income areas.

sources: miners strike over profits dripping in blood the times london , december 5, 2007, wednesday, overseas news; pg. 40, 569 words, jonathan clayton in johannesburg south african miners strike for better safety conditions the new york times, december 5, 2007 wednesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 3, 528 words, by sharon lafraniere ;
notes: almost a quarter of a million mineworkers downed tools yesterday in south africa, the world s top gold and platinum producer, in the country s first strike over safety conditions in some of the world s deepest mines. many attended rallies, such as the one in central johannesburg, organised by the num still by far the most powerful member of the confederation of south african trade unions, which is backing mr mbeki s rival jacob zuma for the leadership of the party and the country. the protesters handed in a petition outlining their grievances to the chamber of mines, the organisation that regulates the industry. although the strike was national, the actual gathering appears to have taken place mainly in johannesburg, and so, the location of the protest is coded as that. all the miners were rescued, but state officials subsequently ordered a safety inspection of all 2,800 mines. the audit is to begin later this month.

sources: miniskirt marchers in taxi rank protest after barmaid is punished for her dress the times london , march 5, 2008, wednesday, overseas news; pg. 39, 514 words, jonathan clayton in johannesburg ;
notes: hundreds of south african women took to the streets yesterday calling for an end to sexual harassment after a young woman was assaulted by taxi drivers for wearing a miniskirt. the demonstrators marched to the johannesburg taxi rank where the attack took place, demanding action from the government and for taxi associations to punish those responsible for such acts. minibus taxis are notorious for packing in as many passengers as possible and for their poor safety record. women passengers are often exposed to taunts, jeers and drunken sexual advances from drivers and male travellers. women activists blame senior african national congress leaders for not helping to change the way women are treated. they point to the rape trial of jacob zuma, president of the anc, who was acquitted in may 2006, but said in court he knew from the way a woman sat if she wanted sex.

sources: rising prices, rising anger the washington post, april 23, 2008 wednesday, foreign; pg. a13, 215 words safrican unions protest mounting food prices agence france presse english, april 17, 2008 thursday 5:33 pm gmt, 214 words ;
notes: thousands of members of the national labor federation marched through johannesburg earlier this month to protest higher food and electricity prices. since there was a lack of specific information, wires were looked into as well. hundreds of trade unionists marched in south africa s largest city on thursday in a protest over rising food prices and the country s electricity crisis. around 1,500 demonstrators marched on a branch of retail chain pick n pay in johannesburg city centre to demand a hold on food prices and an end to price fixing.

sources: colombia the washington post, may 25, 2008 sunday, foreign; pg. a19, 584 words around the world the washington post, may 26, 2008 monday, foreign; pg. a13, 421 words ;
notes: thousands of people marched through johannesburg on saturday, calling for an end to the violence that has killed at least 50 african migrants and forced tens of thousands to flee their homes. demonstrators carrying placards saying xenophobia hurts like apartheid and we stand against xenophobia brought traffic to a standstill in the city center. police said that townships around johannesburg were quiet but that shops were looted and burned outside cape town late friday. the south african government has been criticized for its slow reaction to the violence, the worst since apartheid ended 14 years ago, and for not addressing the poverty that many blame for the bloodshed. south africa has been disgraced by a wave of violence against foreigners that has left at least 50 dead, president thabo mbeki said. in a nationally televised address, mbeki said south africans heads were bowed and called the violence an absolute disgrace.? ? the shameful actions of a few have blemished the name of south africa, he said. mbeki said south africans should remember that their economy was built with the help of migrants and that its neighbors had helped fight apartheid and some had died for their efforts.

sources: commodities: risks and rewards the jerusalem post, july 17th, 2008 thursday, economics; pg. 18, 444 words union protest brings safrican city to standstill agence france presse english, july 9, 2008 wednesday 2:58 pm gmt, 210 words ;

sources: trade union group, a.n.c. ally, holds strikes in south africa the new york times, march 8, 2012 thursday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 8, 533 words, by lydia polgreen ;
notes: tens of thousands of south africans marched in the streets of the nation s major cities on wednesday in a national strike called by cosatu, the powerful group of trade unions, a crucial ally of the governing african national congress that is growing increasingly critical of its policies. the stated reason for the strike was to protest new highway tolls and the practice of contracting out jobs through temporary employment firms, at lower pay and with fewer benefits than permanent workers get, a practice known here as labor broking. but the strike tapped a deep undercurrent of dissatisfaction with the a.n.c., which has governed south africa since white minority rule ended in 1994. zwelinzima vavi, the secretary general of cosatu, said in a fiery speech that racial apartheid was increasingly being replaced by economic apartheid. he said there would be civil disobedience if the government went ahead with its plans to charge tolls on highways that were built with tax money. south africa is often roiled by protest. demonstrations, sometimes violent, happen almost daily in the townships where the poor struggle to live without basic services like electricity, water and toilets. but the outpouring on wednesday came from working people, not the destitute, and their protests took place not in distant townships but in the heart of south africa s cities. the toll issue was a flashpoint for their anger. we already paid once, why should we pay again? said busi harishe, 34, a shop clerk who joined the protest. petrol prices are already high. working people are suffering too much.

people dead and 78 wounded, a sharply higher toll than initially reported.the commissioner, riah phiyega, described a desperate struggle by the police to contain the machete wielding crowd of thousands of angry miners who broke through two lines of defense, leaving officers with no choice but to open fire with live ammunition. the police retrieved six guns from the protesters, including one that had been taken from a police officer who was hacked to death by the workers earlier in the week, ms. phiyega said, as well as many machetes, cudgels and spears. the splinter group claims that the older union, which is closely allied to the african national congress, is too cozy with big business and the political elite. police declined to offer casualty figures after the shooting at the lonmin platinum mine near marikana, 40 miles northwest of johannesburg. but police ministry spokesman zweli mnisi acknowledged late thursday that some of the miners had been killed. the police opened up with a water cannon first, then used stun grenades and tear gas on the crowd, montsho said. the strike has pitted the country s largest mine workers union, which is closely allied with the governing a.n.c., against a radical upstart union demanding sharp increases in pay and faster action to improve the grim living and working standards for miners. just before 4 p.m. on thursday, after repeated warnings to the crowd of about 3,000 miners to disarm and disperse, the police began firing tear gas and water cannons to try to get them to leave, witnesses said. in video captured by government, wage dispute is not included as a protest demand.

notes: about 500 people gathered in johannesburg on saturday to join the international fight to save dwindling rhino and elephant populations. they marched through south africa s largest city as part of global gatherings for rhinos and elephants that were planned in 136 cities to mark world animal day, according to organizers. the demonstrations aimed to raise awareness of the international ivory trade and to press governments to use stricter legal measures to prevent poaching. we want the south african government also to make changes in legislation, said dex kotze, one of the organizers. south african authorities have made more than 100 arrests related to poaching this year and have introduced longer prison sentences, but that has done little to deter poachers. more than 550 rhinos have been killed in south africa during that time. another emphasis of the march was to conserve wildlife populations for future generations, and many marchers brought along children.

notes: an opposition mp was so badly beaten during a brawl in the south african parliament that she was taken to hospital with a broken jaw, it has been claimed. reneilwe mashabela, of the economic freedom fighters party, was held down and hit in the face with a shoe, according to julius malema, the leader of the eff. it looks like she must have an operation, he added. the party s mps had disrupted an address on thursday night by president zuma, who is embroiled in a scandal over refurbishments to nklanda, his country estate. they repeatedly asked when he would pay back the money for upgrades which included a swimming pool and an amphitheatre. plainclothes police, some with guns, were called into the chamber to throw out the objectors. fist fights ensued, with the officers finally bundling all 25 eff mps out of the door. the main opposition party, the democratic alliance, then walked out in protest against the presence of police in parliament, which it said violated the constitution. an apparently unperturbed mr zuma delivered the rest of his speech to a half empty house. the president, who has repeatedly avoided answering questions about nklanda, is facing growing calls to resign amid accusations that the use of force in the chamber had turned the country into a police state .

sources: 1 in rallies against president, s. africans reveal deep grievances over corruption; a majority of south africans believe corruption is on the rise, despite reports that say otherwise a reason many are now calling for president zuma s resignation. the christian science monitor, december 16, 2015 wednesday, world, ryan lenora brown correspondent; 2 thousands march in south africa to call for president s resignation. the new york times, december 17, 2015 thursday, section ; column 0; foreign desk; by norimitsu onishi; kimon de greef contributed reporting from cape town; 3 step down or be ousted, south africans tell zuma. the times london , december 17, 2015 thursday, news; pg. 39, ruth maclean;
notes: 1 as thousands of south africans across the country marched wednesday morning in protest of the administration of president jacob zuma, their banners targeted, in a hundred different ways, a single grievance. we need leaders, not looters, read one sign. corruption must fall, zuma must fall, read another... ; 2 thousands of people marched in major cities across south africa on wednesday to demand the resignation of president jacob zuma after an important government appointment last week that raised concerns about his handling of the nation s economy. protesters in cape town, johannesburg, pretoria and elsewhere have called on the governing african national congress to recall mr. zuma, whose tenure as president has been marred by a series of scandals and accusations of pervasive corruption, but the party has stood by him so far... ; 3 thousands of south africans took to the streets in major cities across the country yesterday to demand that their president resign or be sacked. the demonstrations were organised in the wake of a political fiasco which saw three men holding the position of finance minister within a week...

sources: violence flares in cape town amid calls to oust zuma the times london , february 12, 2016 friday, news; pg. 38, 570 words, ruth maclean zuma sniggers as politicians accuse him of corruption the times london , february 17, 2016 wednesday, news; pg. 34, 232 words, ruth maclean;
notes: rival political factions battled in the streets of cape town last night as president zuma gave his state of the nation address to the south african parliament. riot police fired tear gas and beat protesters gathered outside the building, amid growing tensions over a plummeting currency, corruption, unemployment and a failed harvest. all have increased pressure on mr zuma who, according to his critics, abused his office by lavishing state funds on his country estate. anc supporters attacked anti zuma protesters with planks of wood while riot police fired tear gas in retaliation for rocks thrown at them and arrested those who had armed themselves with broken up benches. after a march dominated by middleclass whites carrying banners that declared zuma must fall , members of the economic freedom fighters, the red beret wearing radical party of the firebrand julius malema, took to the streets. 1000s of protestors from other source

notes: south africa s main opposition democratic alliance party staged a protest outside the nation s constitutional court on friday to demand that president jacob zuma resign or be fired following the court s ruling that he violated the constitution.

sources: topless students protest over campus rapes the times london , april 21, 2016 thursday, news; pg. 36, 397 words, stuart graham;
notes: female students went topless at a south african university in protest at what they say is a failure by campus authorities and police to tackle the problem of rape. the protest, at rhodes university in grahamstown, came after a list of male students and workers at the university accused of raping women students was released on social media. campus support groups say that there have been at least 22 attacks this year. the women who faced off against riot police yesterday have threaten ed to shut down the university until their grievances are addressed. officers fired pepper spray at the crowds and made several arrests. earlier this week police were called into restrain students who had chased some of the men named on the list.

notes: the city of johannesburg sponsored the erection of a six meter bronze statue of nelson mandela which was unveiled in newly named mandela square in ramallah on tuesday. a delegation led by the mayor of johannesburg, parks tau, attended the unveiling ceremony. people living in the poorer districts of ramallah might well wonder why money could not have been diverted to them as during the previous few days there have been protest marches there demanding service deliveries which are constantly lacking.

sources: south africa isn t junk yet but fury at zuma burns bright the times london , june 4, 2016 saturday, business; pg. 51, 470 words;
notes: last week a mob marched up a potholed road in a town north of pretoria to have it out with a local councillor after their tin shacks were demolished. hours earlier members of their community killed two young men who had been paid 150 rand 6.80 each by an eviction company employed by the authority to break down their illegal homes in hammanskraal. the mob, chanting for president zuma to fall, said the loss of their homes was the final straw. they give us nothing and now they have taken my house, beauty nkuna told the times. we have no water, no schools, no electricity nothing, another woman said.

sources: looters on the rampage in south africa s capital; south africa stuart the times london , june 22, 2016 wednesday, news; pg. 30,31, 381 words, stuart graham south africa suffers worst rioting since end of apartheid the times london , june 23, 2016 thursday, news; pg. 24,25, 945 words, graham pretoria five die in south african riots the times london , june 24, 2016 friday, news; pg. 36, 186 words;
notes: violent mobs burnt at least 20 buses, looted foreign owned shops and threw stones at ambulances as riots spread around pretoria in the worst fighting for decades. demonstrators are angry about a mayoral candidate picked by the african national congress anc because they say she is from the wrong tribe. witnesses said that they ran for their lives as looters stopped buses, ordered people off and set fire to the vehicles. police fired rubber bullets at mobs in mabopane, northwest of the city, as people poured into shops, ripping out whatever they could carry away. at least five people have been killed, scores injured, and 200 arrested since rioting began on sunday. lasted 4 days

sources: drivers mugged as tribal riots spread to cape town the times london , july 1, 2016 friday, news; pg. 34, 552 words, stuart graham;
notes: on saturday night anc members stoned cars, barricaded a gate and burnt tyres in protest against the party s choice of a ward candidate. these people do not like the candidate and are even less impressed with the cape town mayoral candidate, xolani sotashe, a senior party member told the local daily voice newspaper. our members believe the anc is not taking them seriously. we were kept hostage for about an hour and my car was badly damaged. they threw petrol bombs and sang, vowing to vote for anyone but the anc. party officials insisted that the party list was final and would not be changed.

sources: drivers mugged as tribal riots spread to cape town the times london , july 1, 2016 friday, news; pg. 34, 552 words, stuart graham;
notes: violent political riots in south africa have spread to the city of cape town. members of the ruling anc burnt buses, stoned cars and blocked highways with flaming tyres and rubble in protest at the party s list of candidates in a municipal election. two buses were set alight on the n2 highway near the city s airport on wednesday night, causing traffic gridlock in both directions. some motorists stuck in the traffic were mugged in their cars during the chaos. police fired rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse about 200 protesters from the barcelona shanty town, which runs alongside the n2.

sources: protests over black girls hair rekindle debate about racism in south africa the washington post, september 4, 2016 sunday, a section; pg. a16, 1084 words, krista mahr;
notes: protests were staged on the leafy, gated campus over the hair fracas and other incidents reported at the school, including allegations that teachers were discouraging students from speaking african languages. some see the students allegations as a depressing sign that the promises of the rainbow nation a term coined by archbishop desmond tutu that came to encapsulate the hopes of a post apartheid south africa are going unfulfilled for its youngest citizens. it s not about just schools, said yvette raphael, a human rights advocate for young women and girls who attended one of the protests. the rainbow nation is not a true thing. it s not reality. ... behind closed doors, some of the things of pre 1994 are still happening. government forces school to change its policy.

sources: students riot over rise in college fees the times london , september 22, 2016 thursday, news; pg. 28, 186 words, stuart graham johannesburg fees must fall : anatomy of the student protests in south africa the new york times, september 23, 2016 friday, section ; column 0; foreign desk; pg. , 746 words, by christine hauser what did newton know? rioting students determined to defy gravity the times london , october 17, 2016 monday, news; pg. 39, 564 words, stuart graham my university is on fire the new york times, october 31, 2016 monday, section ; column 0; oped; on campus; pg. , 1083 words, by nicky falkof. nicky falkof is the head of the media studies department at the university of the witwatersrand.;
notes: the infighting in the anc comes amid a wave of violent protests by students demanding that university fees be abolished and the syllabus decolonised . south african students fought with security forces yesterday, throwing bricks and concrete, blocking roads and smashing windows in growing protests against the african national congress led government s plan to increase tuition fees. according to the police, 567 people have been arrested in connection with student protests this year. police fired tear gas, rubber bullets and stun grenades at students

sources: the new york times, february 25, 2017 saturday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 6, 272 words, by norimitsu onishi. follow norimitsu onishi on twitter onishinyt;
notes: anti immigrant protesters led a violent march into south africa s administrative capital, pretoria, on friday, and the police responded with rubber bullets, tear gas and water cannons. legal and illegal african immigrants to south africa, which has the continent s most advanced economy, have been the focus of criticism and resentment and sometimes of violent attacks in recent years. south africans accuse migrants of stealing jobs or exploiting locals by running small businesses in poor, black townships. others blame foreigners for the country s high crime rates. the accusations, which are not backed up by official statistics, resonate in a country with a jobless rate of 27 percent and yawning income inequalities.

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to the sacking of pravin gordhan, the finance minister
sources: south africa turns on zuma after his night of long knives, the times london , april 1, 2017 saturday, news; pg. 38, 784 words, aislinn laing;
notes: president zuma was last night battling for his political survival as opposition parties demanded a vote of no confidence and he was accused of launching an assault on south africa s poor and dismantling the mandela legacy. calls for the south african leader to quit came after he sacked his highly respected finance minister and replaced him with an inexperienced politician accused of being a crony. at the same time, he moved 20 ministers and their deputies and sacked six, in a cabinet reshuffle that was dubbed south africa s night of the long knives . the sacking of pravin gordhan, the finance minister, led to panic in the markets as the value of the rand fell 5 per cent to a new low against the us dollar and bond prices sank. investors fear a financial crisis without the restraint of mr gordhan, who they say kept spending under control and was an obstacle to the growing political influence of mr zuma s rich friends. hundreds took to the streets in cape town and pretoria to protest over the sacking, as thabo mbeki, the former president, called on mr zuma to be honest about his reason for sacking mr gordhan or risk major and very serious social instability .

protesteridentity: protesters opposed to president zuma for purging his cabinet of critics
sources: mandela s widow and anc chiefs turn screw on zuma to quit early, the times london , april 3, 2017 monday, news; pg. 31, 512 words, aislinn laing;
notes: leaders in south africa s ruling anc party criticised president zuma for purging his cabinet of critics as nelson mandela s family took part in rallies demanding that he resign. three of the anc s most senior figures, including zweli mkhize, the party s treasurer, expressed anger that mr zuma had unilaterally fired eight cabinet ministers on thursday night, including pravin gordhan, the finance minister. opposition parties are now clamouring for parliament to be recalled for an urgent vote of no confidence in mr zuma in the hope that 70 of the anc s 249 mps might help it to succeed by going against him. mr gordhan joined mandela s widow, gra a machel, and eldest granddaughter, ndileka mandela; the leaders of the anc in gauteng, the province of johannesburg and pretoria; several of the recently ousted ministers and some serving ministers at a rally on saturday calling for the public to rise up against mr zuma. the event, which was officially a memorial service for the late antiapartheid activist ahmed kathrada, attracted huge crowds to johannesburg and there was a heavy police presence. mr gordhan told a packed hall that a streak of authoritarianism was creeping into south africa s political system. we are a vibrant society that has a long history of mass mobilisation and mass organisation. i m unashamedly encouraging mass mobilisation, he said. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters demanding the resignation of president jacob zuma
sources: after a firing, south africans push for zuma to step down, the new york times, april 8, 2017 saturday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 4, 667 words, by norimitsu onishi; kimon de greef contributed reporting from cape town..;
notes: in the largest protest in years, tens of thousands of people demonstrated in south africa s major cities on friday to demand the resignation of president jacob zuma after his dismissal of a well respected finance minister intensified concerns about government corruption. marches in cape town, durban, johannesburg and pretoria brought together a mix of political opponents, civil society leaders and ordinary south africans, united in their message that mr. zuma had lost the moral authority to lead the nation. supporters of mr. zuma and his governing african national congress held smaller counterprotests in durban and johannesburg. the protests were prompted by mr. zuma s abrupt dismissal of the finance minister, pravin gordhan, in a midnight cabinet reshuffle last week. mr. gordhan, known for his fiscal prudence and oversight of state enterprises, was regarded as a bulwark against the a.n.c. s perceived culture of corruption and patronage that mr. zuma has come to symbolize.

protesteridentity: south africans from rival political parties that joined forces to demand that president zuma step down
sources: opponents join forces in mass march against zuma, the times london , april 13, 2017 thursday, news; pg. 28, 218 words, aislinn laing;
notes: president zuma was subjected to an uncomfortable 75th birthday yesterday as up to 100,000 south africans from rival political parties joined forces to demand that he step down aislinn laing writes . the protesters marched for two miles through pretoria before gathering at union buildings, the seat of government. there, in the shadow of a 9m high statue of nelson mandela, speaker after speaker lambasted mr zuma over the many corruption scandals that have dogged his presidency, culminating in a disastrous cabinet reshuffle last week that led to the rand plummeting and the country s bonds being downgraded to junk status. julius malema, a former zuma cheerleader and now his fiercest critic, told the crowd that the anc would have to change its mind about its leader. this is not a futile exercise. you came out in your numbers and you have sent a strong message, he said.

protesteridentity: protesters organized by a coalition of more than 20 civil society organizations
sources: south african leader faces sixth no confidence vote, the new york times, august 8, 2017 tuesday, section a; column 0; foreign desk; pg. 4, 956 words, by kimon de greef;
notes: over his eight increasingly embattled years in power, president jacob zuma of south africa has fended off five parliamentary no confidence motions that would have forced him from office. on tuesday, he is to face another, with a difference: lawmakers will vote anonymously. the speaker of parliament, baleka mbete, announced late on monday afternoon that a vote of no confidence would take place by secret ballot, following a request from a coalition of opposition parties. protesters gathered in cape town on monday afternoon, led by a coalition of civil society and religious leaders called unitebehind. a brief but spirited counterprotest by members of the a.n.c. s umkhonto we sizwe military veterans association, numbering some 50 people, was disbanded by police. the marchers were addressed outside parliament by mcebisi jonas, a former deputy finance minister axed by mr. zuma in a contentious cabinet reshuffle in march. the protest, organized by a coalition of more than 20 civil society organizations, was a call for accountability from a.n.c. members, said its organizer mandisa dyantyi, deputy secretary general of the social justice coalition, which helped organize the protest. they re in parliament to represent the people who elected them, not their party, she said. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

location: Cities including Cape Town; Polokwane; Port Elizabeth; Durban; Johannesburg
protesteridentity: protesters and cabinet ministers calling for an end to president zuma s presidency
sources: cabinet ministers join protests against zuma, the times london , september 28, 2017 thursday, news; pg. 42, 295 words, aislinn laing;;
notes: ministers within south africa s ruling alliance joined strikes and protests across the country yesterday calling for an end to president zuma s presidency aislinn laing writes . while smaller than some demonstrations organised by the opposition, it is significant because cabinet ministers were present. people took to the streets in cities including cape town, polokwane, port elizabeth and durban. the johannesburg branch of the anc took part as protest leaders from the congress of south african trade unions cosatu and the south african communist party sacp traditionally anc allies warned that spiralling sleaze under mr zuma was costing jobs. the chamber of mines and major business associations backed the marches, arguing that corruption and cronyism risks causing irreparable damage to the economy. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters alleging corruption and poor services, and demanding the removal of the premier of north west province, supra mahumapelo
sources: ramaphosa seeks to calm city paralysed by corruption protest, the times london , april 21, 2018 saturday, edition 2, national edition, news; pg. 43, 483 words, jane flanagan
notes: president ramaphosa of south africa is facing the biggest test of his leadership as he tries to restore calm to a city that has been crippled by three days of violent protests over alleged corruption and poor services. after abandoning his visit to the commonwealth heads of government meeting in london, he went to mahikeng to mediate in a standoff between protesters and the premier of north west province, who is accused of corruption. strikers are refusing to restore order until supra mahumapelo is replaced. last night, after several hours of talks with the unpopular premier, his team and senior officials from the african national congress, mr ramaphosa asked protesters to be patient while he heard from all parties about the service crisis in the city before making a decision. we want to base our decision on proper analysis, on proper evaluation, he said. there may be concern out there that we are going to take forever, i want to assure everyone that we are going to act speedily on this matter. ignoring the president s appeal for calm and a return to order, hundreds of angry protesters lit fires and damaged cars as they surged towards mahikeng s main shopping centre. riot police used stun grenades, rubber bullets and tear gas. the border between the province and botswana has been closed. the services crisis in the city came to a head this week because of strikers unmet demands for the dismissal of mr mahumapelo and the scrapping of a 180 million rand 11 million contract that he had awarded to a medical technology company linked to the gupta brothers, who are accused of buying influence in mr zuma s circle. violence began on wednesday when the streets were barricaded with rocks, cars were set alight and shops were looted. many of the businesses targeted belonged to immigrants from other african countries. police responded with tear gas and rubber bullets. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: protesters angry at poor public services
sources: ramaphosa admits to corruption failure in polling day plea; south africa, the times london , may 9, 2019 thursday, edition 1, national edition, news; pg. 30,31, 608 words, jane flanagan
notes: president ramaphosa of south africa made a last desperate effort to persuade voters that a victory for his tainted party in the general election would mark an end to corruption. the tightest campaign since apartheid closed yesterday with pockets of protest across the country amid anger at rife unemployment, poverty and a decade of state sponsored looting. as mr ramaphosa, 66, cast his vote at a primary school in soweto he conceded that the african national congress anc had let millions down by failing to deliver the jobs and homes promised at the end of white rule. corruption got into the way, patronage got into the way and not focusing on the needs of our people got in the way. now we are owning up to that. we are saying we are going to correct the bad ways of the past, he said. there were reports of burning tyres and stones thrown in parts of the country as frustrated people used polling day, a public holiday, to vent their anger at poor public services. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: am i next protests: south africans push to renew fight against rape; uyinene mrwetyana s rape and murder have reawakened outrage about violence against women in south africa. but will it lead to change, protesters ask?, the christian science monitor, september 19, 2019 thursday, world, 1017 words, ryan lenora brown staff writer
notes: before she was a hashtag, before she was a rallying cry, before she was the reason for candlelight vigils and presidential promises and protesters facing down tear gas, the most striking thing about uyinene mrwetyana was just how ordinary she seemed. in the days after the brutal rape and murder of the 19 year old university of cape town student inside a suburban post office in late august, photos and videos of ms. mrwetyana circulated widely on social media. they captured an effervescent teenager, flashing a wide brimmed smile as she posed at the beach, on mountaintops, and behind her smartphone in the glint of her bedroom mirror. in south africa, where a woman is murdered every three hours, violence against women is often too ordinary to make headlines. even when it does, the stories are so many that they often wash together, quickly forgotten. but ms. mrwetyana s struck a chord. after her confessed killer, a post office employee, was arrested in late august, her name became a hashtag. and then that hashtag became a question, aminext? women flooded their facebooks and twitters and whatsapp groups with their own memories of violence they had faced at the hands of men. and then they flooded the streets. demonstrators marched in front of parliament. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions. note: the actual start and end date of the protest event was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

protesteridentity: mostly female students highlighting south africa s epidemic of violence against women
sources: violence against women an epidemic , the times london , september 5, 2019 thursday, edition 1, national edition, news; pg. 39, 535 words, jane flanagan
notes: a crowd of mostly female students who tried to storm an international conference to highlight south africa s epidemic of violence against women were pushed back by riot police with stun grenades and water cannon. the scenes at the world economic forum in cape town heaped further embarrassment on president ramaphosa as he showcased his country to investors after days of violence against foreign owned businesses in other cities. he had barely welcomed guests, including some african heads of state, when chanting protesters tried to surge into the conference centre. a recent spate of murders of women prompted a day of action in schools and campuses across the country. a woman is murdered every three hours in south africa, more than five times the global average, according to data from the world health organisation. more than 500 demonstrators, mostly dressed in mourning black, carried banners asking, am i next? , shouted, bring the death sentence back and demanded that mr ramaphosa appear.

protesteridentity: protesters goading world leaders into addressing what they call the climate crisis
sources: meet 8 youth protest leaders, the new york times, september 20, 2019 friday 15:18 est, climate, 1596 words, somini sengupta
notes: from melbourne to la paz, london to cape town, young people took part in an historic day of protests on friday to goad world leaders into addressing what they call the climate crisis. rallies were held in an estimated 150 countries and across the united states. ruby sampson and ayakha melithafa wanted to be interviewed together as members of the african climate alliance. they do not skip school every friday. it s not ethical, ayakha said, to call on kids to skip school when their parents sacrifice so much to pay school fees. this friday is an exception. it s not just for the privileged kids whose mummies can drive them back and forth, ruby said. buses have been rented, with the help of environmental groups, to ferry children to and from the strike. ruby and ayakha see the impact of climate change in the successive droughts that have struck southern africa, and particularly in the water crisis that struck their city last year. the tap water was contaminated in ayakha s neighborhood and when her brother drank it, unknowingly, he suffered from diarrhea for a week. ruby s family, like all cape town families, had to strictly ration water. i couldn t take showers, i was drinking less water, clothing had to be worn over and over again, ruby said. we are living the way people are afraid to live when climate crisis hits in privileged communities, ayakha said. they want an immediate moratorium on the extraction of coal, oil and gas in south africa. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: losing his spark; cyril ramaphosa has yet to show that he can halt south africa s decline, the times london , february 14, 2020 friday, edition 2, national edition, features; pg. 31, 544 words; de klerk tries to defuse row over apartheid, the times london , february 18, 2020 tuesday, edition 1, national edition, news; pg. 35, 603 words, erin conway smith
notes: it is now 30 years since nelson mandela was released from jail and the lights are still on in south africa. although not always. the country has been hit by periodic rolling power failures since 2007. last december the state run energy company eskom, which provides roughly 95 per cent of the country s power, introduced rolling blackouts to deal with demand. manufacturing immediately plunged to its lowest level in five years. yesterday the south african parliament was temporarily suspended amid chaotic scenes as cyril ramaphosa, the president, was prevented from delivering his fourth state of the nation address on time. ostensibly the protest, led by the red shirted, far left economic freedom fighters, was over the presence of mandela s own predecessor and south africa s last white president, fw de klerk, who had been invited as a formality. the presence of the former president in parliament for the annual state of the nation address last week drew a furious protest from the radical economic freedom fighters party, which unsuccessfully demanded that he be removed from the chamber. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: australia s hawke ready for fourth term the toronto star, march 28, 1990, wednesday, final edition, news; pg. a20, 492 words, reuter ;
notes: president sam nujoma of namibia announced a wide ranging amnesty for prisoners yesterday. he said he would pardon or grant remission to all first time offenders except those sentenced for murder, rape, robbery, stock theft and commercial offences carrying sentences of longer than two years. on independence night march 21 more than 1,000 inmates of windhoek prison rioted, in a rampage sparked off by expectations of an amnesty.

sources: namibia: ex combatants challenge government for better deal ips inter press service, july 30, 1991, tuesday, 643 words, by kate burling ;
notes: the challenge came from the heart of the south west africa people s organization swapo own movement, when former swapo fighters staged a series of violent protests against what they termed humiliating treatment by the government. a week of simmering tension followed last week s violence, which culminated in a three hour bank siege and running battles with police and widespread damage. the former plan fighters, who returned to namibia last year after many years in the bush, believed they were being cheated out of money promised by the namibian and south african governments. in windhoek, unemployed ex combatants who had walked for kilometers and lined up for hours were turned away, while better informed comrades, often with jobs and houses, were able to collect their money. the first mass protest last week was in the swapo stronghold of ondangwa, in northern ovambo, an area which suffered heavily during the 23 year war of liberation. thousands of residents gathered for the region s biggest post independence meeting to condemn the government s bungling. an estimated 70 percent of real combatants had been cut out of the payments through no fault of their own, she said. given clashes with police, the response is coded as crowd dispersal. also, the date chosen was the previous wednesday, with last week ? being the only indicator for the date of the protest.

sources: police fire rubber bullets at crowd agence france presse english, 133 words namibian president intervenes to defuse a violence xinhua general news service, november 21, 1991, thursday, 171 words ;
notes: namibian police wednesday fired rubber bullets at a 300 strong crowd attempting to release prisoners from a jail in otjiwarongo, north of here, police said. the crowd marched on the police station in otjiwarongo, 200 kilometres 125 miles north of here, and demanded the release of a man charged with housebreaking and theft, police spokesman commissioner siggi eimbeck said. when the police refused to release the man, the crowd threw stones damaging a large number of windows and police vehicles, he added. when the mob tried to break open the cells and free the prisoners, police fired at least 40 rubber bullets to disperse them, eimbeck added. namibian president sam nujoma last night ordered the release of a house breaking suspect to defuse violence in otjiwarongo.

protesteridentity: former people s liberation army of namibia plan guerrillas
sources: updates 5th item on namibia with government saying no one was killed in prot associated press worldstream, october 11, 1995; wednesday, international news, 1365 words, the associated press ;
notes: former guerrilla fighters who held a government official hostage this week will be absorbed into the military and police, the government said wednesday. police opened fire monday on hundreds of the former people s liberation army of namibia plan guerrillas who took a deputy cabinet minister hostage during a meeting to discuss demands for money and other compensation. twelve people were injured. the government had earlier said one person was killed, but later said there had been no deaths, explaining it had received incorrect information from the protesters. deputy defense minister erikki nghimtima announced wednesday the namibian defense force would take on 1,000 of the guerrillas and another 900 would join the police.

sources: namibia; hai om case dropped africa news, june 19, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 627 words, christof maletsky, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: charges have been dropped against 62 hai om san people who protested outside the entrance to etosha national game park to highlight their plea for the return of ancestral land. the hai om case dates back to mid january, when 73 members of the tribe, under aib, staged a peaceful demonstration at the ombika and anderson gates leading to etosha. they piled tree trunks and rocks at the entrances and physically prevented visitors from entering the park by standing with bows and arrows drawn in front of the gates. however, the protest was brought to an abrupt end when the police moved in and arrested the 11 people demonstrating at the anderson gate and the 62 at ombika gate. the demonstration was part of the hai om s efforts, ongoing since 1993, to convince government to return their ancestral land in the vicinity of ombika, outjo, otavi, otjiwarongo, grootfontein, tsumeb and oshivelo. given the date of the protest just being the middle of january, i chosen january 15th as the probable protest date.

sources: namibia; the power of silence speaks africa news, june 20, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 454 words, jean sutherland, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: jolted into action by the the horror rape of a two year old toddler, which left the child severely injured, namibians countrywide took to the streets or wore black yesterday to protest violence against women and children. in the largest anti violence demonstration of its kind yet, more than 500 people gathered at the kudu in central windhoek at lunch time to observe an hour s silence. the crowd came from all walks of life with women, men and children turning out in droves as namibians rallied to show their abhorrence and concern over sexual attacks on the nation s most vulnerable citizens. the courts have a duty to protect citizens by stiff sentences , words are meaningless. action! , castrate child molesters , when i say no, i mean no , and rape is bad, rape is sad were among the most common slogans.

sources: namibia; accused child rapist faces community anger africa news, june 20, 1997, news, documents & commentary, oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: tsumeb accused child rapist nangombe kalukambe faced the wrath of hundreds of women and men when he appeared in court at tsumeb yesterday charged with the brutal rape of a two year old toddler. angry demonstrators rushed to grab kalukambe as he was bundled out of the court and into a police car after the hearing in which he was remanded in custody until july 24. as police officers pushed him inside the vehicle the protesters stormed the car which was taking kalukambe back to the cells at oshivelo the crowd blocked the vehicle while some banged on it with hands and fists. the police car eventually managed to move off with livid protesters still demanding that kalukambe be presented to them. a large crowd of people, mainly clad in black, had earlier gathered outside the magistrate s court building to protest against crimes against women and children. the protesters placards demanded that kalukambe should not be given bail and that rapists should face severe punishments from the courts.

sources: namibia; fighters won t budge until they see nujoma africa news, june 24, 1997, 800 words, news, documents & commentary, oscar johnson, the namibian windhoek namibia; deadlock over ex fighter demo africa news, june 26, 1997, 960 words, news, documents & commentary, oscar johnson, the namibian windhoek namibia; fighters suspicious of job offers africa news, june 30, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 787 words, helge schutz, the namibian windhoek namibia; former plan fighters beat strategic retreat africa news, july 7, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 587 words, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: a disgruntled crowd of around 300 unemployed ex plan soldiers descended on parliament yesterday insisting they were prepared to camp out until they gained an audience with the president. former members of the people s liberation army of namibia, frustrated at being out of work since independence, rallied in the courtyard of the national assembly yesterday afternoon after a march from swapo headquarters and a protest outside state house. our purpose for gathering here today has to do with our fate. we fought for this country but since independence seven years ago we have never gained any thing or enjoyed any fruits of independence, said kondja shili nghilpangelwa, spokesperson for the group. former plan combatants were locked in a meeting with government officials late yesterday over their prolonged state of unemployment since independence. the ex combatants, who were relocated from the grounds of the national assembly on tuesday night, began talks with defence minister philemon malima, after spending their second night of protest in the main hall of the windhoek showgrounds. earlier yesterday government held an emergency cabinet meeting to discuss the plight of the former freedom fighters. however, nothing concrete has been forthcoming yet. more than 300 demonstrators swarmed the parliamentary building on monday vowing not to leave until they were able to address their grievances to president sam nujoma in person. the ex combatants, whose protest action enters its seventh day today, are resolute in their determination to wait for president sam nujoma to return to windhoek so that they can address their problems directly to him. according to a spokesperson for the ex plan fighters, who preferred to remain anonymous, their numbers had now swelled to more than 2 000, with new members joining their ranks daily. after spending a night in the shadows of parliament, the group was relocated to the windhoek showgrounds on tuesday, where they have been ever since. even after president sam nujoma met with the ex combatants last monday and promised 4 128 permanent jobs, they refused to budge. after staging an 11 day demonstration in windhoek against prolonged unemployment, more than 2 000 ex plan combatants returned to their homes over the weekend to await employment.

sources: namibia; ex plan fighters in north on march africa news, july 8, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 867 words, oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek namibia; hostage drama rocks oshakati africa news, july 9, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 1107 words, oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek namibia; fighters furious over use of field force africa news, july 10, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 880 words, oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: between 400 and 600 ex plan fighters have laid siege to the swapo head office at oshakati and are refusing to budge until they have been given the jobs promised to all ex combatants by president sam nujoma last week. like their counterparts in windhoek, ex combatants in the north are protesting to press home their demands for jobs in the post independence namibia we fought to bring to birth . the group descended on the ruling party s headquarters on friday and have remained camped out there ever since, many braving the cold night air without even a blanket. we were called in to come to oshakati in order to get jobs or to be told where we are going to work, but when we came here, travelled long distances, many of us were not taken in for the jobs as promised, why? the ex combatants asked. they vowed that they would not return to their villages until they had received firm offers of jobs. from the governor s office, the demonstrating fighters marched the three kilometres back to the swapo headquarters on friday, where they have been camped out ever since. they are sleeping outside in the open air with their children. in a tense standoff at oshakati, ex combatants protesting for jobs held four regional councillors hostage for nearly five hours at the swapo head office yesterday afternoon. initially it appeared as if the officials would be held overnight, with the large group of ex plan fighters warning that they would not release them until their demands for work had been met. although the situation was resolved peacefully and the officials are free, the situation remained tense last night, with more than 600 fighters still entrenched at the swapo hq. since then the group, including many women with young babies, has set up camp outside the building, sleeping in the open air. their numbers are growing by the day as disgruntled ex fighters from the regions join the protest. the majority of protesting ex combatants at oshakati yesterday vowed not to budge from the premises of the swapo headquarters until they had jobs in hand , and lashed out at the decision to deploy the special field force and police against them on tuesday. the ex combatants were up in arms over the use of the paramilitary forces. they came in casspirs with sjamboks and guns as if they were coming to the enemies, outraged protesters told the namibian. when regional councillor and swapo regional co ordinator klemens kashuupulwa, one of the four councillors held hostage, and ashipala arrived, they told the ex combatants that each and every one of them should go back to their constituency as the registration and allocation of jobs would be done there, according to cabinet policy.

sources: namibia; anti abuse activists undeterred by ban africa news, july 14, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 507 words, helge schutz, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: president sam nujoma s controversial announcement last week that public demonstrations or processions required written permission from the police is unlikely to stop a series of peaceful protests on violence against women and children. protesters approached for comment at last thursday s weekly gathering in central windhoek, the fourth of its kind, were unanimous in saying that they would continue to hold peaceful demonstrations and that the barring of demonstrations was undemocratic. another demonstrator, helle jensen, said that citizens of a democratic country should have the right to call demonstrations on issues of public concern and that the prohibition of peaceful demonstrations only happened in military states. what has happened to the struggle, she asked, saying that she and many other activists from the pre independence era regularly used to demonstrate in front of the south african embassy in london when swapo members were detained. last thursday s anti violence demonstration was attended by around 60 people, including many school children. the weekly protests against the rape and abuse of women and children were sparked by the brutal rape of a two year old toddler which left the young child severely injured. although articles said that these protests took place every thursday, the number of protesters was only given for this one, and so was the only one which was coded.

sources: namibia; nurses demand overtime from govt africa news, august 13, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 592 words, christof maletsky, the namibian windhoek namibia; government tells nurses strike or not, we have no money africa news, september 3, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 383 words, christof maletsky, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: hospital nurses in windhoek have given the ministry of health until the end of the month to pay outstanding overtime payments of around n 20 million, or face further action. the demand was made by nurses at windhoek and katutura hospitals yesterday following a protest march from katutura hospital to their ministry s headquarters, where a petition outlining grievances was presented to officials. in a letter signed by akwenye, management told the nurses that their complaints were being attended to, but a committee representing the nurses insisted that this be told by akwenye person to a meeting of approximately 1 200 nurses affected by the overtime payments. the ministry of health and social services has apparently told aggrieved nurses pushing for long outstanding overtime claims that there is no money in the state coffers to pay the n 20 million. minister dr libertina amathila was this week quoted as saying, there is no money whether you strike or not. a well placed source said the minister told a meeting last week that nurses at state hospitals would have to wait until the next financial year as there was no money in the budget this year.

sources: namibia; mixed response to anti abortion bill march africa news, october 6, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 614 words, chrispin inambao & oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: there was a mixed reaction to the council of churches ccn call for countrywide demonstrations against the abortion and sterilisation bill yesterday, which appeared to go largely unheeded. in windhoek around 200 christians marched on the swapo headquarters in katutura to voice their opposition to the bill, while members of one congregation at ongwediwa spent half an hour on their knees praying that the bill might not become law. close to 200 christians held prayers and a march outside the swapo head office in katutura, protesting against the proposed bill. the group, led by nakamhela, petitioned health and social services minister dr libertina amathila not to bring the proposed bill on abortion and sterilisation before parliament, saying that abortion should not be given on demand .

sources: namibia; fighters in yet another war of words ... africa news, october 24, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 678 words, chrispin inambao, the namibian windhoek namibia; nujoma plans national tv address on ex fighter issue africa news, november 13, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 372 words, helge schutz, the namibian windhoek namibia; ex fighter demos drag on africa news, november 10, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 320 words, absalom shigwedha, the namibian windhoek ;
