notes: a crowd of around 250 jobless ex fighters and other former exiles have camped out in the parliament gardens in windhoek after failing to meet with both president sam nujoma and prime minister hage geingob yesterday. the group marched from swapo headquarters in katutura to state house in windhoek in a bid to have an audience with president sam nujoma. but the deputy secretary to the president kondja kambala informed the protesters that nujoma had jetted out of the country to attend the commonwealth heads of government meeting chogm in scotland. we ex combatants we need jobs because we have been here for eight years without having jobs, one of the placards read. in their petition, the protesters demanded that they be given jobs before the end of the year. they also voiced dissatisfaction at that fact that a number of ministries had not recruited former combatants this year. several hundred former fighters have been camped out in the gardens for just over two weeks. they are demanding jobs from government, and have vowed not to leave the gardens until president sam nujoma addresses them on their grievances. josef said they would stick to their decision not to leave the gardens. we will not leave this place until the president comes. let hunger kill us. he must come or send someone to talk to us, josef told the namibian. president sam nujoma is to deliver a statement on national television in the near future about the issue of demonstrations by ex combatants. this was announced by minister of information and broadcasting ben amathila during cabinet s weekly press briefing yesterday. at present around 200 former fighters are camped out in the parliament gardens in windhoek demanding jobs. they marched on state house on october 23 demanding an audience with the president, who had just left the country to attend a series of international engagements. he returned on friday.

sources: namibia; ex fighters gather at president s home town africa news, november 6, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 365 words, absalom shigwedha and oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek namibia; ex fighter demos drag on africa news, november 10, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 320 words, absalom shigwedha, the namibian windhoek namibia; nujoma plans national tv address on ex fighter issue africa news, november 13, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 372 words, helge schutz, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: about 200 former fighters have gathered at president sam nujoma s home town of okahao in the northern omusati region to demand that government give them jobs. like other similar protests going on around the country, the demonstrators have vowed not to disperse until nujoma has addressed them and listened to their grievances. and a group of about 200 ex fighters are also camping at okahao, nujoma s home town. these two groups have also vowed not to abandon their protest until the president has addressed them. another 400 plus ex fighters have gathered at the president s home village of okahao and have vowed not to budge until nujoma has addressed them and listened to their grievances.

sources: namibia; scathing attack on men as swakop marches over child rape africa news, december 8, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 511 words, kate burling, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: namibian men who can be respected as role models and family leaders are fast becoming an endangered species , minister of lands, resettlement and rehabilitation, pendukeni iiluva ithana, told a demonstration against rape and sexual abuse staged by swakopmund parents this weekend. speaking to an audience of about 100 people who had gathered in town after a peaceful march through mondesa and tamariskia, ithana asked, where are the men today? do they not consider this occasion to be worthy of support or notice? the demonstrators, including a number of small children, wore placards asking the same questions put by other grieving women in other stricken towns over the past two years as reports of child rape escalate and legal reform lumbers on in low gear. where are the new laws? , why are sentences so light? , why are we not protected? , what say our menfolk?

sources: namibia; angry pensioners mount bills protest africa news, january 14, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 379 words, hugh ellis, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: pensioners from the katutura and khomasdal areas of windhoek participated in an angry demonstration against high priced municipal services in front of the municipal buildings in the capital s independence avenue tuesday. the demonstration was organised by ada gui, which means let s unite , an organisation representing senior citizens of the city. johannes hendricks, an ada gui representative, said pensioners could not afford to pay high electricity and water bills with their meagre state pensions. he added that several pensioners houses had been repossessed by the municipality following non payment of accounts. he said it was also unfair to expect pensioners to pay these amounts in full before they could purchase houses under the city s alienation scheme. hoabeb and ueitele expressed sympathy with the pensioners, but said they should see municipal officials on a personal basis, rather than en masse as they had done. speaking in afrikaans, hoabeb said he wanted to see people come to the municipality to discuss their financial problems on a person to person basis. the officials said they did not want to condemn anyone, but that they had to consider each case on its own merits. the pensioners meeting en masse implies that pensioners met as a large group, so the number of protesters is recorded as 50 .

sources: namibia; government given ultimatum africa news, february 26, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 623 words, tabby moyo, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: teachers countrywide yesterday gave government two weeks to act on their grievances or face action, as thousands of educationalists countrywide took to the streets. the teachers did not spell out what action they planned to take, but presented government with a comprehensive list of matters they want dealt with. in windhoek a petition outlining the grievances and demands was handed to basic education minister john mutorwa by namibia national teachers union nantu president elias manga following a demonstration by an estimated 1 000 teachers through the streets of the capital. similar demos were held in other regions where the same petition was handed to senior regional basic education ministry officials. the namibian s oswald shivute reported that between 4 000 to 5 000 teachers marched at ondangwa, with teachers streaming from outlying schools some up to 200 kilometres away to join the demonstration. from the coast, the namibian s kate burling reported that there had been a good turn out at both swakopmund and walvis bay, with around 250 teachers, drawn from a wide spectrum of the teaching profession, staging a spirited protest at both the coastal towns. they demanded: that the ministry of basic education immediately stop the illegal implementation of the staffing norms that their pay structure be revised and improved within two weeks and that all civil servants receive salary increments with the exception of the management cadre which consists of deputy directors etc.

sources: namibia; down with self enrichment down! africa news, february 27, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 365 words, kate burling, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: loud cheers of approval greeted each demand of the namibia national teachers union nantu petition as it was read out at swakopmund on wednesday before being handed to regional director for education, linus garoeb. a particularly resounding cheer was reserved for the final point condemning current tendencies of self enrichment of political office bearers at the expense of the namibian population , as the crowd of about 250 teachers, learners and parents made their feelings known. speaking just before the start of the march, jantjies said that while swakop teachers grievances were generally in line with the national demonstration, they were particularly concerned about low staffing levels and poor maintenance of buildings. receiving the petition on behalf of the regional education director, de castro said he would forward a copy to both garoeb and the minister of basic education with his own comments attached.

sources: namibia; magistrate must go africa news, june 26, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 526 words, zoe titus, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: women at rehoboth feel that the town s magistrate must go and deem him incompetent to deal with matters relating to violence against women and children. the group of approximately 60 women went to hand over a petition to express concern over violence against women and children at rehoboth. they were reportedly told to f. . .k off by nangula when they congregated in front of his office. the group of women have forwarded a statement to the offices of the multi media campaign on violence against women and children in windhoek who have requested the ministry of justice to investigate the matter.

sources: namibia; swakopmund sorrow leads to united action africa news, june 22, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 705 words, kate burling at swakopmund, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: only one man joined a march by hundreds of women who took time off work and from household chores on friday to draw the attention of swakopmund and the entire namibian nation to the ongoing tragedy of violence against women and children. as expected the peaceful protest, with mourners dressed in black and carrying flickering white candles as they sang age old anthems of hope, was extremely well attended. by the time it arrived at the magistrates court, where thomas florin was due to appear charged with the murder of his wife, monika, more than 800 people had gathered. beverley figaji explained to magistrate elton hoff that the petition contained more than 7 000 signatures and asked that bail be denied to anyone accused of a serious crime against women and children. courts do not exist in isolation. they live among the community. they are not there to please themselves but to serve us, she said, underlining the no bail demand and calling for stricter sentences for people convicted of serious crimes against women and children.

sources: namibia; ex fighter demonstration swells africa news, july 22, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 428 words, oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek namibia; abandoned fighters take demo to outapi africa news, august 4, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 318 words, oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek ; namibia; fighters stand ground africa news, august 10, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 724 words, oswald shivute at ondangwa, jean sutherland in windhoek, the namibian windhoek namibia; jobs offered to 100 ex fighters africa news, august 11, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 417 words, oswald shivute at oshakati, the namibian windhoek namibia; ex fighters to stay put, want explanation on jobs africa news, december 23, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 581 words, oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek namibia; we won t be forgotten africa news, september 25, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 577 words, oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: the number of protesting former swapo combatants at okahao grew to over 200 yesterday with some of the ex fighters saying they were prepared to maintain their vigil until death if they were not given jobs. demonstrators ilya nakambale and ndategapo shipulwa said yesterday that no regional leaders from either the government or swapo had come to speak to them since they started their protest six days ago. they said they would stay at okahao until president sam nujoma came to address them. the kids are feeling cold, we do not have proper blankets, we do not have enough food, but we are going to stay here at okahao until our demands have been met by the government, nakambale said. the ex fighters started their demonstration last thursday. around 330 former plan fighters protesting their plight at okahao town in the omusati region have shifted their battle front to outapi, and have vowed to march on oshakati and even windhoek if their pleas continue to be ignored. the ex combatants, now in their third week of demonstrations, have directed a desperate plea to the authorities and president sam nujoma in particular to help find them employment. so far their call for help has fallen on deaf ears. former plan fighters protesting for jobs in northern namibia say they will stay put at ondangwa airport until government helps them find employment despite an appeal by president sam nujoma on friday that they return home. the now more than 480 ex fighters in the north, including pregnant women and mothers with their small children, marched on foot from outapi to oshakati on thursday and initially planned to take their march for jobs to windhoek. however, swapo s chief for the oshana region, klemence kashuupulwa, stopped them as they marched towards ondangwa on friday and told them the president would speak to them. however, when the leaders briefed the group, which had swelled to 650 by friday evening, they responded by saying that when they had gone home in the past nothing had happened. three weeks of protests by former plan fighters in the north has resulted in jobs being lined up for at least 100 of the ex combatants. the namibia protection service company nps has offered employment to about 100 of the 650 ex fighters who have now converged on ondangwa airport calling on government to help them find work. a source told the namibian yesterday that president sam nujoma had met with the head of nps, alfonso ngeama at ondangwa airport yesterday afternoon and had discussed the employment of 100 ex fighters in the security company. hundreds of former fighters have vowed to remain camped at ondangwa airport despite a call from the cabinet technical committee on ex combatants that they should return to their homes and await news on jobs they have been promised. some 580 ex fighters are currently at the airport, where they have lived since august as part of a long running protest demanding jobs. yesterday the former combatants said they would remain at the airport until they had received clarification about the process through which they are supposed to obtain jobs in the government. the next phase of the socio economic integration programme would not cover ondangwa airport but regional capitals. the government last week said it would employ or give pensions to some 9 500 unemployed ex fighters. in august there were 3000 people there, but the government said last week that only 1392 of this group qualify for jobs under the new scheme. only former plan fighters and those who are currently without means of subsistence who were in exile, but too young to fight in plan can be registered for jobs.

sources: ; namibia; fighters stand ground africa news, august 10, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 724 words, oswald shivute at ondangwa, jean sutherland in windhoek, the namibian windhoek namibia; city demonstration swells africa news, august 11, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 376 words, chrispin inambao, the namibian windhoek namibia; address us or we march on state house africa news, august 14, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 434 words, chrispin inambao, the namibian windhoek namibia; demonstrations will end if govt keeps promises africa news, august 17, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 644 words, chrispin inambao, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: and in windhoek a growing number of ex combatants, now well over 100, have also vowed to stand their ground until they are given solid offers of work. they are camped out in zoo park in the heart of the capital and close to state house. on friday night the windhoek group slept on one side of peter muller street, opposite luderitz street, braving windy and sometimes wet conditions as odd showers fell during the night. the number of mainly ex fighters and former namibian exiles currently camping out in the heart of the capital demanding that government help them find jobs has now increased to 780, one of the leaders of the group told the namibian yesterday. after marching from katutura last thursday, the group, which at that time numbered around 100, has set up home in zoo park. more than 1 000 ex plan fighters and war orphans currently camped at zoo park in downtown windhoek say they will march on state house today if the president or any other senior government official does not address them. the ex fighters and orphans are calling on government to help them find jobs. by yesterday afternoon the number of protesters in the zoo park had increased to 1 026, with more and more streaming in from different parts of the country. a spokesperson for the windhoek demonstrators said yesterday that she and her colleagues were happy that their recent protests had jolted the government into seeking a technical rather than a political solution to their plight. the demonstrators had previously complained that no senior government official had addressed them since they started their protest 11 days ago. more than 1 500 former war disadvantaged have been camped out in windhoek since early this month, first at zoo park in the centre of the capital s central business district and subsequently at the showgrounds. since the registration exercise ended on friday, the group which earlier last week numbered over 1 500 has gradually dwindled to about 300 people who have been sleeping outside the windhoek showgrounds.

sources: namibia; council to decide on pay hikes later africa news, october 1, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 479 words, chrispin inambao, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: a decision on proposed massive salary hikes for top municipal officials were put on ice for now at last night s windhoek city council meeting, which also attracted a public demonstration. the proposals, which were were originally due to be discussed at last night s meeting, included upping the pay of the municipality s chief executive officer to n 637 000 a year and increases of between 39 and 44 per cent for other highly paid officials. shortly before the meeting around 100 placard waving windhoek residents opposed to the gravy train hikes converged on town hall to make their views on the huge salaries clear. stop the blood suckers , stop the increases, shame on you council and municipality fat cats were some of the messages articulated on the posters. the protesters also attended the meeting. however, the meeting, which was chaired by matthew shikongo and attended by all councillors, decided that the issue should be discussed further at a management council meeting to be called soon. the delay is recorded as accommodation in that the protesters were able to temporarily get what they desired.

sources: namibia; women protest at armed captors africa news, november 9, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 456 words, oswald shivute, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: residents from a number of villages close to namibia s border with angola in the west of ohangwena region on friday staged a march to back earlier appeals to government to protect them from armed gangs in military uniforms that are terrorising them. they believe that the best solution would be for government to set up a military base in the area. gang members are accused by residents of abducting women across the border into angola where they are raped and then sent back into namibia. the namibian spoke to some of the alleged victims at ohangwena last friday. placard brandishing villagers, most of them women and children, held a peaceful march on friday, starting from their villages in the west of ohangwena and oshikango towns and proceeding to ohangwena police station, where they handed their petition to the commander of the ohangwena police, inspector i hainghumbi. hainghumbi also told them that he had deployed police and special field force officers in the affected areas to protect the villagers and arrest criminals found there. the villagers said this was inadequate and felt a military base in the area would be the best solution. although the villagers are protesting against the violence from angolan citizens, they are also critiquing the lack of adequate protection from their own government; hence this protest was included. it is coded as 50 due to the number of villages which took place in the protest.

sources: namibia; poly students demonstrate africa news, april 14, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 310 words, christof maletsky, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: students at the polytechnic of namibia boycotted classes yesterday to demand the removal of a white lecturer in nature conservation whom they allege is racist. around 150 students demonstrated in front of the main office building at the polytechnic for about two hours demanding that willem adank be sacked. they alleged that adank gave higher marks to white students and made racist remarks during classes. dean of students, frieda shimbuli, promised to investigate the allegations. at times the demonstration threatened to get out of hand as the student leaders battled to control the emotional protesters. the students also vowed to approach the office of the ombudsman about adank and his alleged racism.

sources: namibia; transnamib staff protest job losses africa news, june 10, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 352 words, tabby moyo, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: about 100 namrail employees at keetmanshoop took to the streets to protest the moved on tuesday, demanding that the management of transnamib be dismissed instead. the group, which marched from the train station in the town to transnamib s regional office, maintained that the poor performance of the parastatal was not caused by over staffing but rather by an incompetent management cadre inherited from the colonial era. they also lashed out at transnamib for failing to implement affirmative action in its top management structure after nine years of independence. the demonstrators accused a senior namrail manager in the south of abusing his powers by using company property, employees and time for work on his farm. natau has urged government to get to the root of the real problems causing the companies falling under the parastatal to incur huge losses. it maintained that the losses being incurred were mainly due to mismanagement and to the management cadre offering itself abnormal salaries, perks, benefits and expenditures .

sources: namibia; horrific evidence on how man torched his girlfriend africa news, june 15, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 607 words, werner menges, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: members of the okahandja community, where the late regina kastoor grew up, packed the public gallery in the court room where judge mavis gibson presided over the trial of kastoor s former boyfriend, 28 year old efraim rachimo haradoeb. an estimated 200 to 300 people staged a demonstration at okahandja earlier yesterday, which culminated with the presentation of a petition to the town s magistrate, eileen gous. in the petition the protesters demanded still tougher treatment for men charged with violence directed at women.

sources: namibia; assault on politician stirs strong emotions africa news, july 27, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 540 words, chrispin inambao, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: 100 strong, placard waving crowd consisting mainly of farmworkers protested on sunday against an alleged assault on a swapo politician at a farm in the omaheke region. during a highly charged meeting at the remote okanjetu farm, swapo regional co ordinator kauku hengari claimed the beating of blacks on farms by whites has progressively continued and can t be allowed to continue unabated. we are saying enough is enough. citing alleged threats to use guns by some farmers as an indication that they are ready for war and they want war, hengari charged, therefore we have no other alternative, we have to retaliate against the white farm owners in steinhausen constituency in a manner befitting them, with all means at our disposal . in the petition swapo demanded that dippenaar apologise publicly for the incident. other demands were that the ministry of labour must ensure that labour inspectors have full access to private property in that area, while government officials must be exempted from making appointments before they can visit farmworkers.

sources: namibia; jobs for ex fighters spark gobabis demo africa news, august 2, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 198 words, christof maletsky, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: gobabis residents on friday protested against the employment of ex combatants in regions other than where they hail from. about 150 people, organised by dta leaders in the town, also complained about a lack of medicine at state run clinics and hospitals in omaheke region. after marching from epako township to the town centre under the watchful eyes of the police, they handed a petition to governor of the region, paulo thataone. residents also demanded improved medical services in their region. disclosed recently that the 65 000 inhabitants of omaheke face the possibility of being turned away from the gobabis district hospital or clinics in the region because of a shortage of essential medicines.

sources: namibia; stop ignoring us plead farmers africa news, september 8, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 639 words, christof maletsky, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: more than 700 communal farmers from across the country, who say they are fed up with being ignored by government, marched on parliament yesterday. the farmers, some holding traditional weapons such as bows and arrows, handed a petition to the speaker of parliament, dr mose tjitendero, wholeft a cabinet meeting to receive it. namibia national farmers union president gabes shihepo said the placard waving farmers decided to march after their proposals on resettlement and communal land administration were ignored and sidelined by the ministry of lands, resettlement and rehabilitation. we are one. i receive your petition very humbly on behalf of parliament. the only reason that you stand here is because you have elected us to be here. we don t have a different agenda, he said. state house and the office of the speaker have yet to respond to concerns raised by some 800 communal farmers from across namibia who last month took to the streets of the capital to press home their dissatisfaction with the slow pace of land reform.

sources: namibia; aussenkehr workers protest mining rights africa news, september 13, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 682 words, christof maletsky, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: some 1,000 people staged a march at aussenkehr near the south african border on friday, demanding that the ministry of mines withdraw its decision to grant prospecting rights to the land on which the community is housed. davis mushitu, spokesperson for the community, told the namibian they were protesting against the mineral rights commission for granting exclusive diamond prospecting rights to northbank diamonds to mine the land on which some 1,000 aussenkehr workers and their 6,500 relatives live. the workers, together with the management of the aussenkehr grape farm, have already appealed against the decision and a high court hearing is scheduled for october 25. the ministry of mines and energy, in a statement, claimed that the workers were mobilised and instigated by the farm management and said the employers were greedy, incorrigible and bent on frustrating and chasing away investors from a potentially lucrative venture .

sources: namibia; protesters oppose bail for caprivi suspects africa news, september 23, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 173 words, chrispin inambao and werner menges, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: a group of some 300 protesters marched on the grootfontein magistrate s court yesterday to hand over a petition opposing bail for the caprivi accused. grootfontein mayor engelhardt gariseb handed over an 11 point petition to magistrate christie liebenberg, who is hearing the bail applications. we the community of grootfontein are hereby strongly condemning the bail application for the secessionists, stated the petitioners, who added, they secregion as well as the rest of namibia. the petition threatened that if bail is granted to the rebels remember that you will bear the consequences. and remember that rebels will go and reorganise themselves for another possible attack .

sources: namibia; katima demo slams bail for secession suspects africa news, september 23, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 606 words, chrispin inambao, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: caprivi residents, including government employees and school pupils, yesterday protested at katima mulilo against the recent granting of bail to four alleged secessionists. on september 13 divisional magistrate cassie carstens granted bail of n 1 000 each to dino dias, ndf soldier kashuka eugene kamashungu 19 , beaven kabwana namitala and hoster shimwe kulisesa 22 . regional police commander in the caprivi, chief inspector hieronymus goraseb, said the crowd which he estimated at between 1 500 and 2 000 people, handed a petition to the governor bernard sibalatani at around 10h00. goraseb has been implicated in the torture of suspects in evidence heard at the bail hearings currently proceeding at grootfontein. the petition read: the first four rebels released by magistrate carstens must go back to jail where they belong. these people are criminals of the highest order who are bent towards causing trouble and insecurity in the region. however, justice permanent secretary, dr albert kawana, confirmed that the ministry had received petitions from both grootfontein and katima mulilo.

sources: namibia; protesters threaten rough justice africa news, october 18, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 775 words, werner menges at grootfontein, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: eleven caprivi high treason suspects, including former mp geoffrey mwilima, on friday became the fourth group of alleged secessionists to be refused bail by the grootfontein magistrate s court. the refusal of bail by magistrate clemens hausiko came after some 200 people staged a vocal demonstration opposing bail outside the court. in a repeat of open threats made against magistrate christie liebenberg at the previous bail hearings in the northern town in september, the protesters also handed a petition to magistrate hausiko warning against the granting of bail. it included a statement that the magistrate would be held responsible if any of the suspects absconded after being granted bail. in addition, the petition read: the justice system should protect the citizens country by all means and if fails we will protect ourselves and we are capable of doing so! we can do it!

sources: namibia; viva the girl child africa news, march 17, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 290 words, zoe titus, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: loud cheers of approval and acknowledging drum beats reverberated through zoo park yesterday in the first celebration of what is intended to become an annual celebration of girl child day. normal business activities came to a halt at lunch time when about 400 young women streamed down independence avenue to protest violence against women, discrimination against young women and other women s rights issues as part of the sister namibia organised gender awareness month.

sources: namibia; peeved workers protest at rehoboth africa news, may 24, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 358 words, chrispin inambao, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: more than 100 disgruntled workers from the ministry of regional, local government and housing on secondment to the rehoboth municipality, yesterday staged a peaceful demonstration listing a litany of grievances. the 120 strong group, mostly staff of the rehoboth town council, are chiefly dissatisfied that their period of secondment has elapsed with nothing transpiring from the interim arrangement. the aggrieved workers handed a petition to rehoboth s town clerk neville smith, which stated: there is a general feeling of unhappiness and dissatisfaction as we don t have any job security, and we don t know who our employer is as the contract stipulating the employment conditions has yet to be implemented. the workers demands include the reinstatement of the 13th cheque, a salary review, a bonus for every five years of service, access to housing loans and they have called on the council to stop further recruitments until their status at the authority is clarified.

sources: namibia; ex combatants to march on state house africa news, july 7, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 286 words, panafrican news agency namibia; former swapo war veterans from the north are on the march again africa news, july 10, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 864 words, the namibian windhoek namibia; nujoma loath to meet ex fighters africa news, july 12, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 688 words, the namibian windhoek namibia; we owe war vets nothing, says government africa news, july 13, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 648 words, the namibian windhoek namibia; police use dogs to block war veterans march africa news, august 3, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 234 words, panafrican news agency ;
notes: over 100 swapo liberation war veterans, including disabled former combatants, friday embarked on a long march to see president sam nujoma in windhoek, to remind him to fulfil his promise to pay 75,000 namibian dollars per person as compensation for their role in bringing about independence. the group s spokesperson, petrus julius, told the national news agency friday that the former bush war fighters were staging a peaceful march to protest against the hunger and poverty they have experienced for the past 10 years after independence. so far, there has been no response to their demand yet, julius said, adding that they were prepared to even spend their christmas in front of the state house, if nujoma does not come up with a satisfactory answer. around 108 ex combatants maimed during the liberation struggle are demanding the n 75 000 each they say they were promised by government, swapo and president sam nujoma in 1997, a promise they say has vanished . quietly determined, they left oshakati for windhoek on friday morning on foot, on crutches and in wheelchairs. since this protest marched for several days through several cities, this protest is considered national. president sam nujoma is reported to have told ministers that he will not meet with demonstrating ex fighters camped outside the osona army base. government yesterday denied that either it or the ruling swapo party had ever promised to compensate people for their part in the struggle for the country s independence. over 100 war victims and veterans are currently camped at osona demanding payments of n 75 000. kalomoh said that when people joined the struggle for liberation they were never promised that they would later receive a reward. the namibian police thursday used police dogs to block over 100 former swapo liberation fighters and war victims from marching to state house to see president sam nujoma.

sources: namibia; namibian students demonstrate against unita banditry africa news, august 13, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 738 words, panafrican news agency namibia; kavango stand off as heavy security greets protest africa news, august 14, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 713 words, chrispin inambao, the namibian windhoek ;
notes: about 400 students hailing from namibia s kavango region staged a peaceful demonstration in windhoek sunday morning against what they called ongoing banditry activities alleged committed in that region by suspected unita rebels. although the demonstration was under police escort and supervision there was no official from state house available to receive a petition the protesters wanted to deliver to president sam nujoma. some of the placards the students carried read: we are tired of sleeping in the bush. kavango is not a war zone. we need peace and tranquility in the kavango region now. others read: unita is not aids, why don t you president nujoma stop them killing our family and relatives , and what did we do wrong in kavango? . in a scene reminiscent of the colonial era, more than 30 armed law enforcement agents, from the police riot unit and the special field force, prevented the group from marching to state house by erecting a barricade at the junction of robert mugabe avenue and daniel munamava street. some members of the police were armed with batons and tear gas canisters, while there were gas masks in one of the vehicles that rushed officers to the demonstration.

sources: namibia; civil servants protest against ? poor? ? pay africa news, october 21, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 481 words, panafrican news agency ;
notes: some 1,000 namibian civil servants took to the streets of the capital saturday in protest against what they called meagre wage increases for civil servants in the country. p olice barred the marchers from proceeding to the state house where they had intended to hand over a petition to president sam nujoma, who is currently in northern namibia. in the petition read by tun president gert jansen, the unions expressed dismay at the disgusting 83.5 dollar per month salary paid a civil servant from the last increment in april.

sources: namibia; marchers seek equity for namibian women africa news, november 13, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 506 words, panafrican news agency ;
notes: some 200 namibians monday took to the streets to express their dissatisfaction with the imbalance in the representation between women and men in elected positions at all levels of government in the country. with shouts of we want 50 50 in government now and we want more women as ministers now , the demonstrators marched from kudu park through independence avenue to the parliament to hand a petition to the speaker of the national assembly, mose tjitendero.

sources: namibia; protest pressure africa news, february 9, 2001, news, documents & commentary, 818 words, the namibian ;
notes: the khomas regional branch of the swapo party staged an outspoken demonstration at the high court yesterday, calling for home affairs minister jerry ekandjo to be acquitted of contempt of court in a judgement set to be delivered today. their ruling will be announced in the shadow of a demonstration that made it clear that the khomas regional branch of the ruling party wanted to see ekandjo let off the hook, while they further called for sikunda s release not to be ordered and for him to be deported from namibia instead. some 400 demonstrators refused to heed police instructions not to proceed to the steps of the high court with their demonstration around lunch hour yesterday. the flag and placard waving crowd surged past police officers trying to stop them three times on their way to the court. the petition further says that the khomas swapo branch encourages all patriotic judges in our country to continue to serve the interests of the namibian people first and foremost , and that they should not give in to the intimidation by the unpatriotic and unprincipled hostile print media operators who have chosen to fight in the interests of the imperialists, the bandits and disgruntled elements in our society .

sources: namibia; oppressed karibb residents protest africa news, february 14, 2001, news, documents & commentary, 606 words, the namibian ;
notes: residents of karibib yesterday took up president sam nujoma s call for a clampdown on official waste. about 300 people demonstrated at the municipal offices and handed over a petition to the mayor listing their grievances, including allegations that municipal vehicles are being abused by councillors and municipal employees. they also requested that auditors look at the council s books. we are very unhappy with the way in which the town is managed, said sara brunzel, a member of the community development committee which organised the demonstration. hoeseb said they had tried to explain this to residents many times. he said he suspected that the demonstration was politically motivated, charging that some individuals want to be seen and heard . he said the petition would be discussed today and the council would then decide on how to respond.

sources: namibia; two lose legs to landmines africa news, february 22, 2001, news, documents & commentary, 422 words, the namibian ;
notes: last saturday, more than 200 tjeye residents, 20km east of rundu, held a peaceful demonstration and accused the faa and unita of being responsible for several attacks at the village.

sources: namibia; whose bank is it anyway? africa news, march 8, 2001, news, documents & commentary, 389 words, the namibian ;
notes: chanting whose bank is it? and we feed the nation, take us seriously , members of the namibia national farmers union nnfu yesterday demonstrated at all six agricultural bank of namibia branches countrywide. demonstrations took place simultaneously at the bank s branches at mariental, windhoek, otjiwarongo, oshakati, rundu and katima mulilo. the union, which describes itself as the sole and authentic voice of communal farmers , organised the protest action after accusing agribank of brushing aside their arguments.

sources: namibia; protest claims graft at walvis africa news, april 10, 2001, news, documents & commentary, 230 words, the namibian ;
notes: demonstrators from kuisebmond yesterday demanded the resignation of the mayor of walvis bay and the suspension of the municipality s chief executive officer and other councillors. it requests swapo headquarters and the ministry of local government and housing to investigate alleged corruption in the municipality. we therefore request the suspension of all our local councillors who are involved in this issue including liboly haufiku, the ceo of walvis bay municipality, augustinus katiti, and king mandume muatunga. the mayor of walvis bay, theresia samaria must resign or alternatively she must not stand for the coming election. further demands by the protesters, which have been mentioned in two previous petitions over the past month by the same group, are their rejection of the tutaleni low cost housing project, a request for an electricity card system and that serviced land be made available to residents at a reasonable price. we want to make it categorically clear that we the community of walvis bay will never support or defend any people who are making corruption in namibia, the petition, signed by unionist benhard petrus on behalf of the roughly 700 protesters, says.

sources: namibia; marching ex fighter struck by a vehicle africa news, september 18, 2001 tuesday, 525 words, the namibian ;
notes: more than 100 ex combatants, who say they were in the people s liberation army of namibia in exile, have started gathering at swapo headquarters in windhoek in the latest of a series of protests that have taken place since the mid 1990s. over 120 people were gathered at the swapo hq yesterday morning. at the moment we have no proper homes to live with our children. we live in a shanty house on the outskirts of okahandja, she said. speaking on behalf of the ex plan fighters, fiina tuyeni, a youth who was born in exile, said the younger ones in the demonstrating group had been told by the swapo leadership that they were too young to be considered in the same category as ex combatants. niilo taapopi, head of the technical committee dealing with the plight of ex combatants and permanent secretary in the ministry of home affairs, told the namibian the committee s mandate has been extended by cabinet to deal with the demonstrating ex combatants. we are working very hard to find a solution to this problem, he said.

sources: namibia; teen rape shocks walvis into action africa news, january 31, 2002 thursday, 667 words, the namibian ;
notes: close to 4 000 pupils from walvis bay took to the streets yesterday to express shock and outrage at the gang rape of a 14 year old girl at the town last week. claire campbell, the junior mayor, read out the petition to magistrate pietie husselmann. it reads: if the very persons we entrust to ensure that our children and women travel to and from home perpetrate barbaric crimes, it is time to step in and say enough . what is happening to our society when the fabric of decency is torn apart senselessly? families are suffering. the town is suffering. the country is suffering. in the petition they ask that the perpetrators drivers licences be revoked, that harsher sentences be imposed on rapists and that no parole be granted to convicted perpetrators of crimes of this nature.

sources: namibia; university workers stage demo africa news, may 23, 2002 thursday, 189 words, the namibian ;
notes: over 100 workers at the university of namibia unam yesterday protested over management s alleged failure to act on wage and other problems. the demonstrators were members of the namibia national teachers union nantu and the namibia public workers union napwu . the demonstrators were members of the namibia national teachers union nantu and the namibia public workers union napwu . the workers accuse their employer of reneging on an earlier commitment that it would implement an across the board wage increase of 8,5 per cent for the next three years, and a separate 16,5 per cent increase. unam spokesman, edwin tjiramba said the negotiations were ongoing on the issues raised by the workers and had already been presented to management.

sources: panafrica; africa in brief africa news, september 13, 2002 friday, 540 words, mail & guardian ;
notes: about 300 namibians demonstrated peacefully this week in protest against the recent killing of a german tourist at ameib, about 25km from usakos. renate engeborg gruber 48 died a week ago after the vehicle she was travelling in with her husband came under fire. hermut gruber 58 was wounded in the legs. the mainly youthful demonstrators carried placards and marched to usakos police station where they handed a petition to the station commander. some of the placards read: we the community of usakos will make sure that the criminals are brought to justice , viva tourists and usako s youth against crime know how to deal with these kind of criminals . aksel muafangeyo, chairperson of usakos youth against crime, said the people of usakos wanted to show the world that attacks on innocent people could not be tolerated any longer as there were many tourist attractions in the erongo region.

sources: namibia; rehobothers cause stink in water meter protest africa news, september 19, 2002 thursday, 437 words, the namibian ;
notes: the rehoboth town council is to hold an emergency meeting on monday to decide whether to sign a contract for the installation of pre paid water meters at the town. the meeting follows a demonstration last friday by residents who demanded that the council sign a contract with the company, nossob river system, for the installation of 1 315 pre paid water meters. the pre paid water meters were donated by the ministry of regional, local government and housing to help alleviate the water problems at the town. around 300 demonstrators marched on the council offices last friday and ended up emptying the slop buckets in the offices in the presence of the police.

sources: namibia; farm stand off ends africa news, october 28, 2002 monday, 937 words, the namibian ;
notes: police on friday prevented a second attempt by swapo party youth league led demonstrators to occupy a farm near gobabis, following the eviction of 30 people who had lived on the land for decades. over 100 angry demonstrators, organised by the spyl, entered the farm on thursday for several hours in response to the eviction. they slashed the tyres of vehicles on the farm and broke at least one window in the farmhouse. special field force members, armed with teargas and automatic weapons, were on guard at kalkpan from thursday until friday.

sources: namibia; outrage at omaruru africa news, february 11, 2003 tuesday, 389 words, the namibian ;
notes: omaruru residents yesterday expressed outrage over the continuous murderous attacks on women and children in namibia. about 50 people marched to the town s magistrate s court to hand over a petition before the appearance of a 45 year old man charged with murdering his girlfriend. the residents carried posters protesting violence against women and children and calling for the speedy implementation of the domestic violence bill.

sources: namibia; cops point guns at protesters africa news, february 12, 2003 wednesday, 483 words, the namibian ;
notes: policemen yesterday cocked their guns to prevent angry women and children from lobbying legislators to pass the domestic violence bill. the police officers threatened to fire at the demonstrators, who were determined to seek president sam nujoma s support for the enactment the domestic violence bill. the women chanted stop violence against women and children as police officers cocked and pointed their ak 47 rifles at the demonstrators. there is no threat coming from women and children for the police to threaten us with guns. given the protest the day before in another city over the same issue, as well as the response received, this protest is believed to have had at least 50 people.

sources: namibia; ? we must be a nation of life, not death? africa news, february 20, 2003 thursday, 407 words, the namibian ;
notes: government must make the world a place to live in and not a place to die in, pleaded anthony plaatjies, who is hiv positive, at a candlelight vigil at walvis bay on tuesday night. three vigils, organised by the treatment action forum, were held in windhoek and at walvis bay and opuwo. the aim was to remember all those who have died from hiv aids and to protest the continuing lack of affordable medication for those still living with the disease. a tearful herlyn uiras 18 told the more than 100 people at the vigil that their group had lost six people over the past couple of months. hafeni ndemula, a national councillor, accepted petitions from three speakers saying government has heard your message .

sources: namibia; hundreds in drought food demo at rundu africa news, april 15, 2003 tuesday, 216 words, the namibian ;
notes: residents of the rundu rural constituency yesterday staged a demonstration demanding the immediate resumption of drought food relief distribution which was stopped at the beginning of the year. moses nyundu handed over a petition to the governor of the region on behalf of the demonstrators, the majority of whom were women. nyundu said they were protesting the move to stop drought food relief as no clear explanation was provided by the regional emergency management unit remu . karupu assured the demonstrators that remu would discuss their petition with the emergency management unit emu in the office of the prime minister to seek an amicable solution to the problem.

sources: namibia; immigration officials cry foul africa news, july 25, 2003 friday, 305 words, the namibian namibia; ekandjo blocks march africa news, july 25, 2003 friday, 784 words, the namibian namibia; union, home affairs agree to start talking again africa news, october 23, 2003 thursday, 593 words, the namibian ;
notes: immigration officers whose main functions are to be handed over to the police have petitioned home affairs minister jerry ekandjo demanding that he stop dismantling their division. the petition was to be handed over to ekandjo yesterday, but he refused to receive it and told police to block a demonstration by the immigration officials. police threatened to use teargas to disperse the marchers whom they pushed and shoved. they were armed with rifles, handguns, teargas and batons. in july there was an outcry among the country s estimated 400 immigration officials who protested against the ministry s move, accusing minister jerry ekandjo of unilaterally changing their conditions of service.

sources: namibia; karasburg mulls action on bills africa news, september 22, 2003 monday, 199 words, the namibian ;

sources: namibia; 2 charged over farm corpse africa news, november 4, 2003 tuesday, 317 words, the namibian ;
notes: the bail application attracted a crowd of around 60 gobabis residents who staged a peaceful demonstration outside the court building to oppose the granting of bail to the two. in a petition handed over to magistrate wouter maske, the demonstrators called for an independent and unbiased hearing and a life sentence for those found guilty. maske postponed the bail application hearing until today.

sources: namibia; secessionist case triggers demo africa news, march 5, 2004 friday, 454 words, new era ;
notes: hundreds of placard carrying demonstrators yesterday marched on government offices at katima mulilo, where they protested against 13 secessionist suspects. we the people of caprivi region condemn the idea of seceding the region from the rest of namibia. we therefore call upon the masses in the region to remain united, as divided we fall, read the 16 point petition. we demand the government to follow up all the secessionist sympathisers and their supporters as they are the people engineering political instability in the caprivi region, the petition stated. the petitioners further demanded that the 13 suspects should remain in custody for the rest of their lives as they are apparently a threat to peace and development. and more radically the demonstrators called upon the government to revise the judicial system as it is seen as a threat to the national security of the country . the petitioners further appealed to the government to introduce a screening system of judges as they are seen and viewed as representing their legal interests and not the people s interests.

sources: namibia; hundreds mark women s day africa news, march 12, 2004 friday, 824 words, new era ;

sources: namibia; uis residents demand answers from council africa news, march 31, 2004 wednesday, 392 words, the namibian namibia; uis residents still waiting for answers africa news, april 15, 2004 thursday, 288 words, the namibian ;

sources: namibia; women march against lawlessness africa news, july 16, 2004 friday, 436 words, new era ;
notes: members of the hardap women s voice staged a demonstration in rehoboth yesterday condemning the continued occurrence of rape and other social evils at the southern town. led by the group s chairperson in the region rachel cloete, a large number of women accompanied by youths marched to the town s magistrate s court, where they delivered a petition to rehoboth magistrate, gaynor poulton. in the petition, the women detailed their grievances, which include rape, alcohol and drug abuse, mushrooming of shebeens and non payment of child maintenance by especially run away fathers. handing over the petition, cloete said women in the town of rehoboth were not living a safe life anymore, because they have become victims of their husbands, brothers and relatives as a result of rampant alcohol and drug abuse. cloete, who was disappointed by the low turnout for the march, said the march was to highlight the mistreatment of women in society. the petition was signed by 1 057 people. although there was a low turnout, the article mentions a large crowd of protesters, and the high number of signatories to the petition implies a protest of at least 50 people. magistrate poulton promised to forward the petition to the line ministry who should ensure that police would do their part, adding that all problems raised were more relevant to the police.

sources: namibia; traders object to council regulations africa news, august 11, 2004 wednesday, 453 words, new era ;
notes: informal traders consisting of members of the oshakati open market informal traders and street hawkers staged a peaceful demonstration yesterday against informal trading regulations in the oshakati town council suburb. the group handed a petition to oshana regional governor clemens kashuupulwa who called an emergency meeting with the group and the management members of oshakati and ongwediva town councils to harness the differences between the traders and the town council. the traders told new era over the weekend that they were unhappy with the new regulations saying that it was not proper and that these restrictions interfere with their business activities and operations. new era learnt that since monday, more than 200 informal traders were instructed and moved to new sites, while more than 200 rejected the council s order to move to newly allocated areas. more than 500 informal traders are expected to hand the petition to the office of the mayor tomorrow morning. given how many people ignored the order as well as how many traders are expected in the next day? s march, this demonstration is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: namibia; swakop marches in silence africa news, august 17, 2004 tuesday, 454 words, the namibian ;
notes: the murder of a swakopmund resident on the beach on friday morning united the coastal community yesterday morning, when about 500 people took part in a silent march to the magistrate s court. residents marched side by side in memory of alexandra mooren 44 and other victims of crime at the coast. quietly singing hymns and carrying candles, flowers and placards the procession down sam nujoma avenue brought the early morning traffic to a standstill, with many onlookers observing a moment of silence in respect. making a statement a section of the crowd of about 500 people who took part in a march at swakopmund yesterday to protest against violent crime.

sources: namibia; rising crime angers swakop residents africa news, september 17, 2004 friday, 283 words, the namibian ;
notes: residents of swakopmund who took part in an anti crime demonstration yesterday stormed a police van carrying three suspects in the mooren beach murder case. more than 300 people took part in the protest in front of the magistrate s court to speak out against crime and demand more police officers for the town. she said the crowd shouted: they are in there, they are in there and ran after the van. they shook the van and shouted angrily at the suspects.

sources: namibia; karibib residents up in arms africa news, october 19, 2004 tuesday, 577 words, the namibian ;
notes: the police at karibib had to calm a group of about 80 residents who took part in a peaceful demonstration to hand over a petition to the mayor yesterday. the group, known as the karibib community delegation, which is chaired by sara brunzel, demanded answers from the town council on a host of issues. the main concerns raised by residents are access to and service at the new health centre, pre payment electricity meters, refuse removal and outstanding money to namwater and nampower. they have also raised a number of issues to be investigated by auditors concerning the alleged abuse of council vehicles by municipal staff, allocation of projects on tender to municipal employees, insurance of vehicles and homes of former councillors, housing allowances to employees in municipal houses, loans to staff members and councillors and overtime. the mayor said he would not be able to give much feedback to the community tonight, as the auditors had not yet completed their task.

sources: namibia; workers want government intervention africa news, october 25, 2004 monday, 433 words, new era ;
notes: workers at coimbra ok foods, saddened by police inaction to arrest two portuguese bosses who allegedly assaulted a black worker, now want the ministry of home affairs to probe the incident that smacks of racism. the workers at coimbra ok foods want the ministry of home affairs to investigate their complaints jointly with the ministry of labour. they argue that had the portuguese been on the receiving end, the black perpetrator would have been arrested in record time. the ugly incident that left crispin lucas bloodied was allegedly committed by one male supervisor and his daughter and it triggered a noisy demonstration involving over 100 workers. the workers, who have since resumed duty at coim bra ok foods after the incident, are further unhappy that their representatives at nafau have dismally failed to address a list of their grievances. following the incident, three workers were fired on the spot while others were apparently forced to sign final warning letters from their seemingly unsympathetic bosses. workers and other residents at katima mulilo are unhappy that the police seem to be dragging their feet as they have not yet arrested the alleged perpetrators of the incident.

sources: namibia; shack dwellers demand power africa news, december 15, 2004 wednesday, 376 words, the namibian ;
notes: women from the drc informal settlement at swakopmund yesterday carried burning candles in a peaceful protest march to the municipality in memory of the mother and two toddlers who died on saturday when their shack burnt down. we are forced to use candles and paraffin lamps because there is no electricity, the spokesperson for the group of 50 residents, louis barnard haslund, read from a petition. the provision of electricity has been an ongoing issue raised in several protest marches to the council. how long do we still have to suffer without electricity? and have we been forgotten? were some of the statements, while one woman carried a piece of cardboard above her head simply stating power . mayor rosina hoabes said she could not give them an answer immediately. she said the procedure was that the petition had to be tabled at the next council meeting, after which the management committee would discuss it and make recommendations.

sources: namibia; is this the blood that waters our freedom? africa news, february 7, 2005 monday, 637 words, the namibian ;
notes: more than 1 000 children and adults on friday marched to the swakopmund magistrate s court in silent protest at the brutal rape and murder of a six year old girl four days earlier. along the way mothers and fathers expressed feelings of anger and frustration with the crime situation in the country and sentences meted out to those found guilty. has the life of a cow more value than that of a child s, asked sophia motinga, udf town councillor and member of the atlantic school board, referring to the severe mandatory sentences for stock thieves approved in parliament last year. the deputy mayor and magistrate gibson imbili both condemned the crime. the community of swakopmund appeals to the president to implement a special law for those raping and killing innocent children, who are the leaders of tomorrow, said uahimisa kaapehi, a father and nudo politician.

sources: namibia; windhoek residents protest against increases in crimes against children africa news, february 15, 2005 tuesday, 435 words, the namibian ;
notes: hundreds of windhoek residents, young and old, mainly wearing black and singing solidarity songs, marched from katutura to the city centre yesterday as namibians mourned the deaths of two young rape and murder victims. the march, led by spiritual leaders of churches affiliated to the council of churches in namibia, demonstrated people s anger at recent attacks in which two minors, aged three and six, were raped and killed in windhoek and at swakopmund. about 500 people, mainly women and children, walked close to 10 kilometres to the parliamentary gardens from the scene of the latest crime the rape and murder of three year old manuela sofia hoesemas in the katutura old cinema hall. we can t tolerate it any longer. they must just hang them, said one woman in her late 50s as people marched down independence avenue.

sources: namibia; tsumeb marches against rape africa news, february 22, 2005 tuesday, 404 words, new era ;
notes: the mayor of tsumeb, veueza kasiringua, over the weekend led a two thousand strong crowd of aggrieved community members through the town in a demonstration against the abuse and rape of innocent young women and children in the country. hundreds of men and women, clad in black attire and others weeping, marched through the streets of nomtsoub carrying posters calling for stiffer sentences for rapists. it is time for us to stand up against the criminals, no matter whether they are our children, fathers, mothers, family or friends, they do not deserve to be treated with kindness. given that the mayor herself participated in this demonstration, the response has been recorded as accommodation.

sources: namibia; arandis folk march against crime africa news, february 28, 2005 monday, 600 words, new era ;
notes: residents of arandis have given the police at the town until friday this week to remove the suspect in the rape and killing of six year old rachel hamutundu recently, from the town s holding cells. this ultimatum was given last week at the end of a peaceful demonstration that attracted more or less 1 000 people. since no specific date is given, the start and end date for this protest is recorded as happening one week earlier than this article. the march was against the recent rapes and killings of children hamutundu in swakopmund and manuela sofia heosemas in windhoek. the community said in a petition they were shocked by recent brutal and horrific incidences of rape and murder of innocent young children. we demand that this murderer be taken back to the place where he committed these satanic deeds with immediate effect. if not, we may take the law into own hands, said the petition.

sources: namibia; mariental community horrified by killings africa news, march 10, 2005 thursday, 235 words, the namibian ;
notes: residents of mariental yesterday turned out in droves to protest against the ruthless killing of eight people on a farm near kalkrand in the mariental district at the weekend. more than a thousand people, most of them wearing black, took part. she said the community was opposed to the two suspects being granted bail and demanded lifelong imprisonment, coupled with hard labour, for all those convicted of rape and murder.

sources: namibia; unam students protest violence africa news, march 14, 2005 monday, 367 words, new era ;
notes: traffic was brought to a halt as hundreds of students from the university of namibia unam in windhoek took to the streets to protest against a recent string of murderous acts that have shocked the nation. over three hundred students from unam vigorously marched from unam under the escort of the traffic police to the national assembly where they handed over a strongly worded petition to speaker dr mose tjitendero. reading the petition, wise said unam students are not calling for the re introduction of capital punishment, but that they find the sentences being meted out to perpetrators too lenient and not enough of a deterrent. the student community further appealed to the national assembly and to cabinet to urgently devise strategies aimed at identifying the root causes of this aberrant phenomena and speedily find and prescribe solutions.

sources: namibia; tun wants better salaries africa news, march 16, 2005 wednesday, 584 words, new era ;
notes: about 200 teachers affiliated to the teachers union of namibia tun yesterday took to the streets of windhoek to demonstrate against what they called the unsatisfactory way in which their conditions of service are being managed by the ministry of basis education, sport and culture, and their worsening financial position since 1995. but the tun march proceeded to the offices of the ministry of basic education, sport and culture, where marchers handed a petition to minister john mutorwa, demanding clear written indications from the two ministries of education that salaries of all teachers and school secretaries would be translated according to the circular that came into effect in january last year. the union thus, among others, demanded that all teachers be treated equally, and that the difference in salaries between ordinary teachers and school management be addressed. the teachers further demanded that the date of implementation should be no later than the end of april this year. the teachers asked that a fair procedure, as applicable in all ministries, be applied when over deductions are made. we are encountering serious difficulties when we just observe on our salary advances that deductions are made in such amounts that we cannot afford and which causes us serious financial problems, they explained.

notes: the wave of discontent of ratepayers with their councils that has been spreading across the country in recent weeks, reached henties bay last week when more than 200 residents demonstrated on thursday and friday with posters at the council offices. as the demonstration heated up, residents started demanding that the town council should be dissolved. the henties bay town council needed a marathon meeting on monday to answer the accusations made by a concerned community group during a two day demonstration last week. kapere, who promised to check some decisions with the permanent secretary of the ministry of regional and local government and housing, decided to call another meeting on june 11.

sources: namibia; teachers stage salary demo africa news, april 14, 2005 thursday, 211 words, the namibian ;
notes: close to 200 teachers in the karas region took to the streets of keetmanshoop on tuesday, under the banner of the teachers union of namibia tun , to protest against their conditions of employment. led by local school principals, the teachers from various communities marched to the karas regional education office to hand over a petition demanding a more equitable salary structure. the teachers demanded equitable salaries for primary and secondary school teachers, claiming that secondary school teachers and newly appointed teachers were earning more than their counterparts in primary schools. the petition called for the timely payment of leave and pension gratuities and other termination benefits as provided for by the treasury instructions, state finance act and the labour act.

notes: about 250 angry okahandja residents marched to their town council offices yesterday to hand over a petition calling for the immediate removal of the mayor, christophine citto paulus, and her co councillors. they are also demanding that all allegations of corruption be immediately investigated. paulus and her swapo party colleagues, namely her deputy constantia kahengombo, hilaria shilimetindi and johannes nande, were nowhere to be seen, as was the case with sofia noabes of the udf, aj strauss of the cod and agatha handura of nudo. individuals approached the namibian to complain of collapsing services, payments for pre paid electricity meters allegedly not being paid into their accounts, abuse of municipal vehicles by councillors and a general disregard for anyone s interests except their own.

sources: namibia; ? get money from gipf, ssc, odc? africa news, september 14, 2005 wednesday, 555 words, the namibian ;
notes: thousands of angry teachers marched countrywide yesterday to demonstrate against a cabinet decision to nullify an earlier undertaking to increase salaries and benefits for long serving teachers. the teachers defied a government order to refrain from demonstrating, as they are hoping to push the state into bowing to pressure and promised that the next action would be a potentially crippling national strike. organised by the namibia national teachers union nantu and supported by the rival teachers union of namibia tun , the teachers demanded that the state get money from the government institutions pension fund gipf , social security commission ssc and the overseas development company odc to increase their salaries and benefits.

sources: namibia; keetmanshoop on edge africa news, october 6, 2005 thursday, 648 words, the namibian ;
notes: angry keetmanshoop municipal workers and residents staged two separate protests over huge rent increases of more than 1 000 per cent yesterday. about 200 municipal workers downed tools and marched from the namibia public workers union napwu offices to the local authority building. the petition protested the delay in payment of salaries, the suspension of long service bonuses and free services, and the exorbitant increases in rent. the governor instructed the group not to pay any municipal bills rent, water and basic charges until next week. he said he would negotiate with the local council and give the group feedback next tuesday. mayor tiboth, when interviewed by the namibian, said he agreed the rent increases were too high.

notes: waving placards and chanting slogans protesting violence against women, polytechnic students and school children from five windhoek high schools drew maximum attention to their campaign by taking it to the launch of this year s state of the world population report. accompanied by family members of juanita mabula, the 21 year old woman whose body was found naked and decapitated in windhoek almost three weeks ago, the students, wearing giant cardboard cut outs of white ribbons, waited for prime minister nahas angula to hand over a petition calling for more stringent action against perpetrators of violence. the polytechnic students called on government to strengthen policing for the protection of communities and a more efficient judicial system to deal with criminals. part of the crowd that protested on wednesday included mabula s minor daughter and some relatives who were symbolically dressed in black. leading the pack of close to 250 demonstrators, rector of the polytechnic of namibia dr tjama tjivikua assisted by the dean of students frieda shimbuli, marched to the nampower convention centre, where angula was officiating the launch of the 2005 state of the world population report. the students demanded swift action and for the protection of women and children from violent men. one of the placards brandished appealed to the police to swiftly find the killer s, saying the masses were tired of crying.

sources: namibia; old timers march for pension increase africa news, october 28, 2005 friday, 643 words, new era ;
notes: the anger and frustrations of hundreds of distressed pensioners, sparked by an apparent misleading parliamentary statement on their plight, yesterday culminated in a protest march and demands for an increase in pensions in khomasdal. busloads of pensioners from the marginalised communities yesterday morning gathered from 09h00 near the khomasdal soccer stadium in preparation for a spontaneous protest march on the offices of the ministry of labour and social welfare. she went on to say that the present monthly pension of n 300 is totally inadequate for her to maintain a decent, dignified and secure standard of living.

sources: namibia; farmers give ultimatum to government africa news, november 24, 2005 thursday, 588 words, the namibian ;
notes: oshiwambo speaking farmers who have been ordered to remove their cattle from west kavango say they will not budge unless government and the ondonga and oukwanyama traditional authorities give them a place in former owambo to settle with their animals. if there is no other way to find a place for us to settle, then we are not moving out of kavango, whatever the cost, or else we are going to add to the skeletons of our brothers at the eenhana military base, the farmers said in a petition yesterday. following a demonstration at omuthiyagwiipundi yesterday, the farmers handed their petition to the chief executive officer of omuthiya constituency, samuel mbango, who received it on behalf of the omuthiya constituency councillor penda ndakolo, who is also the governor of oshikoto region. an estimated 400 farmers took part in the protest, giving vent to their frustrations by dancing, brandishing placards and chanting.

sources: namibia; community calls for chief? s removal africa news, december 6, 2005 tuesday, 481 words, new era ;
notes: over 500 disgruntled members of the hoachanas community held a peaceful demonstration at the town last week expressing their discontent over the 17 year corrupt administration of chief petrus simon moses kooper. in a petition handed over to kooper last friday, the demonstrators called for the immediate removal of the traditional chief, while at the same time calling for government s intervention into the matter. on friday, the leader of the demonstration david topnaar handed over the petition to kooper at the town s community hall. speaking to new era, topnaar said that many incidents have shown that a lot has gone wrong in the way his chieftainship has administered hoachanas.

sources: namibia; child bill sparks protest africa news, march 17, 2006 friday, 896 words, new era ;
notes: over 25 civil society organisations csos on tuesday made a last hour attempt to make lawmakers accommodate their amendments to the child status bill. they said parts of the content of the bill are not in the best interests of the child, as per the convention of the rights of the child. scores of school children from different schools and representatives of the csos holding placards and shouting slogans made their presence felt at the steps of the national assembly yesterday to ask parliament not to pass the bill in its current form. given how many organizations were involved, this protest is believed to have at least 1000 people.
