sources: namibia; walvis shebeen owners take to the streets africa news, may 19, 2006 friday, 315 words, the namibian ;
notes: shebeen owners in walvis bay on wednesday demanded that the backyard bars closed by the police last weekend be reopened and that confiscated alcohol be returned to the proprietors. some 50 shebeen owners and their clients, mostly young women, rocked up at the kuisebmond stadium in walvis bay yesterday to protest the closure of illegal shebeens in the town. many of them said they had applied for liquor licenses unsuccessfully, and did not know why their applications were rejected.

sources: namibia; pro shebeen protests move to windhoek africa news, may 26, 2006 friday, 563 words, the namibian namibia; cops stick to their guns africa news, may 29, 2006 monday, 431 words, new era ;
notes: meanwhile, some 200 protesters dug in their heels at the walvis bay municipality on wednesday some even standing firm through a bitterly cold tuesday night to convey their dissatisfaction with the closure of their businesses. we ve had meetings with the mayor, police commander, municipal ceo, town council and the regional governor. it amounted to nothing. police officers were sent to the scene to disperse the crowd and, according to petrus, they were ordered by regional commander andrew iyambo to use force if necessary. the communications officer of the municipality of walvis bay, nolita marques said more than 200 people gathered outside the municipality on wednesday and thursday and about 50 spent two nights there. though this was regarded as a sign of protest, the communications officer indicated that the municipality at the town maintained its stand, adding that this was an action by the police and the municipality had nothing to do with it. protestors were adamant that they wanted sheebens to be re opened and all the confiscated liquor be returned to the rightful owners.

sources: namibia; shebeen owners march to state house africa news, may 29, 2006 monday, 623 words, new era ;
notes: hundreds of shebeen owners angered by the recent decision to close down all unlicensed informal pubs last saturday braved the cold weather and marched to state house to express their grievances. the protesters footed from katutura to state house, where they handed over a petition listing their grievances to a senior minister who received it on behalf of president hifikepunye pohamba. the march that started from the namibia shebeen association nasa offices in katutura saw hundreds of irate men and women brandishing placards with messages demanding the re opening of their sheebens. as kandenge delivered the news that the president still needed time to study the petition before he could attend to their grievances, emotions ran high and the demonstrators threatened they would not leave until they were given an immediate answer to their concerns. kandenge told new era that circumstances forced people to operate illegally given the delays in approving licences. it takes two to three years for a licence to be approved, he said.

sources: namibia; shebeen war spreads africa news, may 31, 2006 wednesday, 656 words, new era ;
notes: scores of villagers at onyaanya in the oshikoto region yesterday staged a peaceful demonstration to condemn the disempowerment of traditional authorities from granting trading licenses as was the practice before and after independence. they handed a petition to onyaanya constituency councillor henock kankoshi after police at okatope reportedly threatened to dispose of all liquor and other alcoholic substances should the liquor act continue to be violated by the deadline of wednesday today . scores of villagers implies at least a crowd of 100 at the protest.

sources: namibia; shebeen closures to continue minister africa news, june 7, 2006 wednesday, 599 words, the namibian ;
notes: safety and security minister peter tsheehama yesterday vowed that the police would close down all unlicensed liquor outlets in namibia despite opposition from cuca shop owners. at the weekend, the police fired rubber bullets and teargas when they clashed with angry shebeen owners at omuthiya in the north. tsheehama said two members of the public and three police officers were slightly injured by stones during the fracas. the police further found a large group of people shouting slogans, defying that they will not close their bars and that blood will be shed, he said. given the police response and the large crowd and the past protests, this demonstration is believed to have at least 100 people.

sources: namibia; shebeen uproar continues africa news, june 9, 2006 friday, 559 words, new era ;

sources: namibia; pro shebeen demo marches on parliament africa news, june 16, 2006 friday, 795 words, new era namibia; we re not home and dry yet, say local bar demonstrators africa news, june 22, 2006 thursday, 386 words, the namibian namibia; shebeeners moved by the spirit africa news, june 23, 2006 friday, 374 words, the namibian namibia; protesting local bar owners agree to go home africa news, june 26, 2006 monday, 434 words, the namibian ;
notes: embittered shebeen owners marched on parliament in the grip of a pervasive mood of anger demanding a moratorium on the liquor act. yesterday thousands of disgruntled shebeen owners marched to the national assembly where they handed over a petition to speaker of the national assembly theo ben gurirab and chairman of the national council asser kapere. in the petition, demonstrators adamantly voiced a need for the government to place a moratorium on the implementation of the liquor act and the liquor regulations until factors that impede effective and efficient compliance are sorted out. escorted to the national assembly under heavy police guard, about 3000 demonstrators from all corners of the country expressed their anger towards the government adding that the current no shebeens operation campaigns that have seen the closure of more than 2000 unlicensed shebeens countrywide is subjecting them to hunger. we are hungry, this is the second petition to the government and no response is forthcoming. yesterday a group of about 60 protesters remained on the parliamentary premises, promising that more people were on the way to swell their ranks. despite sober assurances by government that it is hard at work to ensure the smooth implementation of the liquor act, a core group of shebeen protesters yesterday remained camped outside parliament in windhoek. although the numbers dwindled greatly, there were still 50 people in the area for multiple days. demonstrators, who want government to give them the go ahead to re open their unlicensed shebeens, started the trek home to their respective regions on saturday.

sources: namibia; tsumeb residents tired of promises africa news, august 31, 2006 thursday, 389 words, new era ;
notes: about 400 tsumeb residents yesterday took to the streets to voice their dissatisfaction over a range of issues they want resolved by the tsumeb town council. the angry crowd, who were shouting and singing slogans, demanded that their water be turned on and that written proof be submitted to that effect as they claim to be tired of empty promises . receiving the petition, mayor of tsumeb, engel nawatiseb, said the community has the responsibility to contribute to the town s development through the payment of rates, taxes and other consumer service fees as much as the council is expected to render such services to the community. he further said that the town council is not being indifferent to the needs of the people as there can be no greater needs than those of the people. he promised the residents that the town council would have to find some kind of solution to satisfy residents.

sources: namibia; war vets call off protest africa news, september 5, 2006 tuesday, 496 words, the namibian ;
notes: after a committee representing the group threatened to march in thousands , only a small number of former former veterans turned up for the event. about 80 people singing freedom songs gathered outside the greenwell matongo community hall in katutura from 08h00 before later dispersing. despite the low turnout, the demonstrators were ready to march across the city to hand over a petition to government, but they were stopped in their tracks by their organisers.

sources: namibia; villagers protest land grab africa news, september 25, 2006 monday, 186 words, the namibian ;
notes: residents from oshikango, omafo, engela, ohangwena and onuno villages that fall within the boundaries of the new town of helao nafidi in the ohangwena region on friday took to the streets to protest the actions of the helao nafidi town council. they want the minister of regional and local government, john pandeni, to intervene, saying that the council was taking land for new developments without properly compensating villagers. residents also say they are being charged municipal tariffs although they live in traditional homesteads and not in a town with modern services. given that residents from five villages participated in this protest, it is assumed to have had at least 50 people.

sources: namibia; nurses issue ultimatum africa news, december 7, 2006 thursday, 829 words, new era namibia; kamwi optimistic after meeting nurses africa news, december 21, 2006 thursday, 597 words, new era ;
notes: close to 300 nurses who held a peaceful demonstration in windhoek yesterday have given the ministry of health and social service an ultimatum of 30 working days to address their demands or face a national nurses strike. in oshakati, also about 300 nurses, porters and cleaners from oshakati state hospital handed a petition to the director of health, dr naftali hamata. issues raised in the petitions included the overtime rate for work done on sundays and public holidays, the proposed salary structure and an election to be held between nanu and napwu to determine who should be the sole bargaining agent for nurses and security orderlies. i heard of a nasty experience where one of the clerks was not receiving his salary for four months, and some nurses have not received their claims from as far back as april may this year, he said, adding that his meeting would help in nurturing transparency amongst all stakeholders in the health sector. the envisaged meeting is expected to be attended by regional health managers, district coordinating committees, directors, general personnel, regional directors and nursing managers.

sources: 1 unruly kids throw in the towel. the namibian windhoek , june 24, 2010 thursday, absalom shigwedha; 2 struggle kids call for police help. the namibian windhoek , july 22, 2010 thursday, absalom shigwedha;
notes: no exact dates given, we infer june 1. 1 after two protest marches to windhoek and one to ondangwa in recent weeks, the so called struggle children have received the cold shoulder from government officials, who said they were nothing special and should wait patiently for jobs like all other unemployed youth... ; 2 the group of 125 struggle children who had to return to berg aukas after futile marches to ondangwa and windhoek recently, have called in the help of the police at grootfontein to defuse a fight between them and the camp commander, colonel nestor shalauda...

sources: 1 unruly kids throw in the towel. the namibian windhoek , june 24, 2010 thursday, absalom shigwedha; 2 nearly 9,000 struggle kids registered minister. the namibian windhoek , april 7, 2010 wednesday, brigitte weidlich;

sources: 1 tertiary students fight change. the namibian windhoek , july 14, 2010 wednesday, annely inghepa and oswald shivute; 2 students at valombola college hold nta officials hostage. the namibian windhoek , august 5, 2010 thursday, oswald shivute;
notes: 1 angry windhoek college of education students marched to government offices yesterday, protesting against the change of their studies from four to five years. the students are enrolled for a basic education teachers diploma betd course but following the merger of the university of namibia with education colleges, the ministry of education introduced a requirement that upgrades their course to a bachelor of education b.ed degree...the students said they were not consulted and that the agreement signed between them and the government had no stipulation about the upgrading to b.ed. students at the valombola vocational training centre vtc at ongwediva are on strike in protest against the newly introduced namibia training authority nta curriculum. they say the new curriculum was forced on them although the nta was not ready to implement it properly. the students complain that the nta cannot offer them quality education and that their training manuals contain many errors. on monday, the students held a demonstration at the school where they threw their manuals into the rubbish bin. they handed over a petition listing their grievances over the nta curriculum... ; 2 students at the valombola vocational training centre vvtc at ongwediva in the oshana region, who have been on strike in protest against the newly introduced namibia training authority nta curriculum, held nta officials hostage for several hours on monday evening. the nta is an independent body that was created to take over vocational training from the directorate of vocational education and training in the ministry of education...nta officials led by its chief executive officer, lidia nangolo rukoro, arrived at valombola on monday to discuss the students problems with the vvtc management and the students. the discussions ended in a deadlock on monday afternoon. the angry students then locked the entrance gate and said they would keep the officials there until they solved the curriculum problem to the students satisfaction. by the evening, the police were called, opened a side gate and let the nta officials escape...oshana police commissioner ndahangwapo kashihakumwa warned the students to behave themselves and not to do things that would force the police to intervene again. the nta officials then left for rundu and katima mulilo to hold similar meetings there. students of the rundu vocational training centre are also demanding the reintroduction of the old nttc system.

sources: boois corruption case postponed to august. the namibian windhoek , july 19, 2010 monday, luqman cloete;
notes: boois s supporters staged a demonstration in front of the courthouse and rolled out a red carpet for him, but the police ordered that it be removed. the governor s supporters also shielded him from being photographed by a reporter for the republikein newspaper. the police had their hands full with a huge crowd who tried to storm into the courtroom. only some of the people were allowed in due to limited space, while the others had to stand outside. shortly after the case was adjourned, boois s supporters gathered at the town s central park, where a statement was read by tses swapo branch co ordinator petrus witbooi, who doubles as tses village council chairman. witbooi claimed that the corruption charges against boois were part of a political campaign to tarnish this political credibility on the eve of this year s regional and local authority elections...

protesteridentity: residents in the damara, herero, owambo, malanami, soweto and luiperdheuwel locations
sources: grootfontein residents cry foul. the namibian windhoek , august 10, 2010 tuesday, jana mari smith;
notes: according to the petition, residents in the damara, herero, owambo, malanami, soweto and luiperdheuwel locations had their water supply disconnected, which resulted in another peaceful demonstration to display our dissatisfaction... . according to the petition, residents feel that the higher rates will financially crush many of them, mainly pensioners and the unemployed. at the request of the residents, councillors met with the complainants on july 29. residents asked that the tariff increase be reconsidered...on thursday last week, a follow up meeting scheduled by the council and residents began...according to reports by those present at the meeting, the mayor indicated that he would only be willing to talk about the water issue and refused to acknowledge or discuss the other issues addressed in the petition.

protesteridentity: students from the university of namibia unam , polytechnic of namibia students, primary and secondary schoolchildren and members of the community
sources: 1 outrage over murder. the namibian windhoek , july 30, 2010 friday, werner menges and jana mari smith; 2 grootfontein murder accused in court. the namibian windhoek , august 4, 2010 wednesday, denver kisting;
notes: 1 outside was an enraged crowd of protesters; fed up with violent crime in namibia, thirsty for revenge, and grieving over a young life cut short through a brutal act of violence. police officers kept the protesters outside the court premises, but the din of their calls for justice to be meted out to the man accused of murdering and raping stoffels could still be heard inside the courtroom...the multitude of people who crowded the streets outside the court consisted of marching students from the university of namibia unam , polytechnic of namibia students, primary and secondary schoolchildren and members of the community. the crowd verged on the edge of unruliness, as protesters were overwhelmed with emotion and anger at various stages...adults and children in unison demanded justice and a general sentiment that was shouted out loud was that the suspect should be hanged . the issue of the death penalty was also brought up by a fifth year unam law student, stephanie de klerk. the laws are not deterring anyone. we are also calling on the churches, who have access to the community, to start advocating for the death penalty, she said...the students urged the ministry to increase teamwork with other, relevant ministries and the police to ensure that lawmakers and security personnel are up to date on current laws and be more vigilant . the minister has been petitioned to establish an office on violence against women which would be responsible for implementing acts and policies related to rape and violence against women. this will mean that more strength and co ordination will be had in the existing police women and child protection units. the students also said the judicial response to violence must improve, claiming it has remained relatively stagnant, hence some offenders have gotten off the hook or have received minimal penalties . the subject of unemployment is addressed in the petition, with the students saying most violent criminals who direct their wrath at women and girls fall into that population group which is classified as unemployed or unemployable . practically, the students suggested the ministry of education should make good on their statements earlier this year, that schoolchildren will be supplied with transport to and from schools. ; 2 followed shortly on the heels of the murder and rape of windhoek schoolgirl magdalena stoffels, which has galvanised the nation to protest against gender violence...

sources: 1 thousands march for magdalena. the namibian windhoek , august 2, 2010 monday, jana mari smith; 2 grootfontein murder accused in court. the namibian windhoek , august 4, 2010 wednesday, denver kisting;
notes: related to previous protest; 1 thousands of schoolchildren marched in solidarity on friday to protest the brutal rape and murder of magdalena stoffels. led by dawid bezuidenhout pupils, at least nine more schools joined the march from stoffels s former school to the magistrate s court in katutura, bringing the total people present at the march to at least 3 000...voices of the children chanted no justice, no school , the pupils held up countless banners demanding justice and the death penalty...a collective petition was handed to the deputy prosecutor general johnny truter at the magistrate s court. the petition, drafted by dawid bezuidenhout, was supported by all the schools present, as well as the khomasdal community forum. the petition stated that it is disturbing to note that a country with a low population of just over two million recorded at least 200 cases in 2009 in which children were murdered, raped or assaulted in namibia. the petition furthermore pointed out that only one out of every five people accused of rape or attempted rape is convicted of either of these crimes...cheers went up also at the suggestion of school buses to ferry children to and from school and the installation of cctv cameras at traffic lights...reports also came in of marches elsewhere in the country, though numbers could not be established. ; 2 followed shortly on the heels of the murder and rape of windhoek schoolgirl magdalena stoffels, which has galvanised the nation to protest against gender violence...

sources: karasburg pensioners protest municipal tariffs. the namibian windhoek , august 5, 2010 thursday, luqman cloete;
notes: about 50 pensioners took to the streets at karasburg in the south on tuesday to protest against skyrocketing municipal tariffs, demanding a reduction in water rates and other municipal tariffs...they also demanded that the municipality write off accumulated municipal debts added to their bills after they inherited municipal houses from deceased relatives. we appeal to government to show its last respect to us as pensioners by giving priority attention to our socio economic problems because we fought for this land and want recognition to that effect, a petition handed over to mayor mathew mumbala reads. in addition, the pensioners called for subsidies on their municipal bills. the pensioners also expressed concern over the drought relief aid that has been suspended at the town. apparently drought relief aid to pensioners at the town was suspended because of allegations that some had exchanged the drought relief items for alcohol...

sources: grootfontein residents cry foul. the namibian windhoek , august 10, 2010 tuesday, jana mari smith;
notes: grumblings about unfair treatment of a section of grootfontein s residents by grootfontein council members, including the mayor, have escalated and culminated in protest marches and urgent meetings with the grootfontein municipality. last month, the grootfontein municipality temporarily cut the electricity supply to people living in the single quarters, citing long outstanding debts. mayor rapama kamehozu said recently that the total outstanding debts of people living in the single quarters stood between n 200 000 and n 300 000. in response, it is understood that the residents protested the move and the municipality quickly switched on the lights again. since then, several accusations have been levelled against the municipality by members of the community, who allege that the council is fuelling tribalism and doing special favours for residents in the single quarters, who are treated differently from others living in poor conditions. towards the end of july, these residents drafted a petition and handed it to the municipality, saying that the attempt by the municipality to collect outstanding debts from the single quarters residents had backfired for political reasons. the petition alleged that the electricity was reconnected swiftly due to the apparent political connections of single quarters residents as they are perceived as loyal swapo party supporters. the petition claimed that the single quarters received special treatment, such as receiving bulk water and electricity supply ... to operate business . another complaint lodged against the mayor and several of his councillors, in particular mandume kawana, chairperson of the management committee, was that they acted unfairly towards the majority omulunga residents, who said they feel unsatisfied and above all feel that the grootfontein town council is discriminatory towards us in comparison to those residing in the single quarters. one example is the recent announcement of a 10 per cent increase in municipal rates. according to the petition, residents in the damara, herero, owambo, malanami, soweto and luiperdheuwel locations had their water supply disconnected, which resulted in another peaceful demonstration to display our dissatisfaction... ...

location: Keetmanshoop, Katutura  township in Windhoek , Omuthiya, Ondobe, Eenhana and Oshakati
protesteridentity: rally for progress and democracy rdp and republican party rp supporters
sources: 1 police break up rdp demo. the namibian windhoek , august 16, 2010 monday, luqman cloete; 2 small group of rdp marches to supreme court. the namibian windhoek , august 16, 2010 monday, brigitte weidlich;
notes: seperate marches or attempted marches in locations throughout the country by supporters of two opposition parties; 1 police at keetmanshoop on saturday cancelled a march by rally for progress and democracy rdp supporters amid strong opposition. at first the local rdp leadership vowed to continue with the protest, and resisted police officers who tried to block their path to march to the local magistrate fs court. expressing their disgust about the march being blocked, the rdp sympathisers and members chanted: arrest us all. is namibia only for swapo party? the namibian government is bad than the past colonial regime. namibia is not nujoma s farm. at one stage the local police station commander, chief inspector james nderua, tried to grab the petition from rdp regional secretary willem stephanus...the protestors later gave in to the police order to discontinue their march following talks between the karas police regional commander, commissioner josephat abel, and the local rdp leadership. abel told the rdp local leadership that he was only carrying out orders to halt the march as ordered by nampol inspector general sebastian ndeitunga. as leader, i am appealing to you to call off the march for own your safety, abel said... ; 2 about 60 members and supporters of the rally for democracy and progress rdp and the republican party rp defied a police ban on saturday which prohibited all demonstrations until this week friday and marched from katutura to the supreme court, demanding the delivery of supreme court judgement on the 2009 election challenge appeal. one police vehicle escorted the peaceful march while more police were observing the scene at the supreme court. opposition and civil society groups were allegedly prevented from marching by police in northern namibia. police erected roadblocks and severely disrupted peaceful demonstrator at omuthiya, ondobe, eenhana and oshakati in northern namibia, according to the national society for human rights nshr . prospective demonstrators in the omusati and erongo regions were told that no demonstrations or gatherings would be held there, but a group held a peaceful protest at keetmanshoop...

sources: blackout at okahandja. the namibian windhoek , september 8, 2010 wednesday, tileni mongudhi;
notes: thousands of okahandja residents were left without electricity for most of yesterday after namibia s power utility company, nampower, pulled the plug due to the municipality s non payment of debts...at one stage the police were called in to maintain order, after angry residents stormed the town council building to express their dismay at the lack of electricity. some of the council workers had to flee their offices as the angry mob from the community descended on them. by then, the town s chief executive officer regina alugodhi was reportedly on her way to nampower s head office in windhoek to negotiate for down payment of the debt...okahandja residents have in the past accused the municipal management as well as the council of poor financial management. the council and its management have always rejected such allegations and described themselves as well functioning . the municipality is well known for its infighting among councillors.

sources: 1 otjiwarongo marches in protest. the namibian windhoek , september 16, 2010 thursday, jana mari smith; 2 otjiwarongo ceo sets record straight. the namibian windhoek , september 17, 2010 friday, jana mari smith;
notes: three consecutive days with marches related to this demand issue. 1 otjiwarongo community members on tuesday marched across town to demonstrate their anger at a long list of problems which they claim the municipality continues to ignore. the demonstration, attended by at least 200 people, ended at the municipal buildings where a petition and a list of grievances were handed over to the officials. in the petition, addressed directly to chief executive officer manfred uxamb, residents lashed out at the town councillors, and uxamb in particular, whom they accused of refusing to listen to their grievances...some of the issues listed by the community include costs they pay for the repairing of broken pre paid water metres, lack of water connections, for the past two years, at some points, basic rates which residents cannot afford, debt which residents struggle to pay off due to interest rates and the high cost of burial sites...the list of issues focused primarily on pre paid water meter issues and the cost of services...other issues include the fact that residents feel it has become impossible for us to pay monthly accounts, as the cost of basic services have soared. a community leader told the namibian that the demonstrators are prepared to meet with uxamb. a meeting would have taken place at 14h00 on tuesday to discuss their grievances. he said that should uxamb fail to show up, another demonstration will start. we expect that you answer in person the grievances of the community during this same week, the petition warned. uxamb, who was not in the region on tuesday afternoon, was not available for comment on this issue. a source at the municipality said that community leaders held discussions with uxamb and other managers last week on a number of grievances forwarded to the municipality. ; 2 the municipality of otjiwarongo yesterday called a press conference to set the record straight in regard to accusations levelled at them by protesters this week. the municipality proved that the community s demands for meetings to discuss several issues had been met more than a week ago. manfred uxamb, chief executive officer of the municipality, made it clear yesterday that the municipality has met with the protesters, and listened to, the grievances banded about by them at several marches this week. he said that the press conference yesterday was necessary to put the record straight on the events which led to the demonstrations this week...after the initial meeting held last week wednesday, a second, last minute meeting was requested with uxamb for saturday. he could not attend this meeting due to prior engagements, he explained, and asked that the next meeting be scheduled for this week wednesday...demonstrators marched again on wednesday and congregated at the municipality yesterday morning...

sources: 1 sex attack angers okahandja residents. the namibian windhoek , october 1, 2010 friday, werner menges; 2 okahandja rape case postponed to january. the namibian windhoek , october 8, 2010 friday, werner menges;
notes: 1 a crowd of hundreds repeated at okahandja yesterday, when they marched to the okahandja magistrate s court to stage an angry demonstration over the alleged violent rape of a girl on wednesday...some of them were displaying placards calling for the death penalty to be reintroduced in namibia a demand that is a non starter, unless namibia s entire constitutional order is overthrown... ; 2 the incident sparked an angry demonstration by hundreds of okahandja residents mostly schoolchildren at the time of goagoseb s first court appearance last week. another demonstration was staged at the court with his second appearance this week.

sources: squatters appeal to regional councillor. the namibian windhoek , october 18, 2010 monday, absalom shigwedha;
notes: about 70 illegal squatters from the 8ste laan informal settlement in otjomuise marched to the offices of their regional councillor, margaret mensah williams, on thursday to hand over a petition. when the group got close to the office, security guards locked the gate to deny them access. they then picketed the gate, singing songs and showing placards, with some police officers keeping an eye on them..the city has been issuing eviction notices to 8ste laan squatters, ordering them to remove their shacks because they occupied the land illegally.

sources: mass protest over toddler s murder. the namibian windhoek , november 1, 2010 monday, luqman cloete;
notes: earlier on friday, a mass protest was staged at the local magistrate s court, where a petition was handed over to regional magistrate sunsley zisengwe. they demanded a more proactive approach by the police, the municipality and political leaders with regard to the rape and murder of women and children. slamming the mushrooming of shebeens and tombo homebrew houses, the people claimed that these drinking spots fuel alcohol abuse and violent crime. they demanded that these bars be removed immediately. at a meeting on thursday afternoon where the mass protest was planned, people blamed the police for the child s murder. they claimed police officers on duty on wednesday had told the family to search for the toddler themselves when they reported her missing...

sources: man hacked to death. the namibian windhoek , november 9, 2010 tuesday, absalom shigwedha;
notes: ...the demonstrators condemned the police for being very slow in taking the victim to hospital after he was attacked. he said there was a general belief that adolf haipinge s life could have been saved had the police acted more promptly?

protesteridentity: rally for democracy and progress rdp and four other opposition parties & supporters
sources: rdp protests verdict delay. the namibian windhoek , november 22, 2010 monday, tileni mongudhi;
notes: the rally for democracy and progress rdp is keeping up pressure on the high court to deliver judgement in the 2009 election challenge by nine opposition parties. on saturday the party was joined by four other parties to hand over a petition to the high court, but no one was there to receive the petition. a lively crowd, mostly dominated by rdp members, marched along windhoek s john meinert street to the high court, demanding that judge president petrus damaseb and judge collins parker speed up the process and deliver the judgement...the crowd asked the judges to do everything they could to ensure that the court verdict is reached and made public as soon as possible to make way for elections later this week...he also said the march was not against the judiciary, but to protect it from certain politicians who have little or no respect for the country s constitution and laws. parallel marches were held at ongwediva and oshakati over the weekend.

location: north central regions, Oshakati and Ongwediva
sources: northern taxi drivers ask for lighter traffic fines. the namibian windhoek , january 18, 2011 tuesday, oswald shivute and lucia kamati;
notes: thousands of taxi drivers from the four north central regions went on strike yesterday and protested at local authorities and police stations in oshakati and ongwediva against stiff new fines for traffic offences. they gathered near the okandjengedi combined school early yesterday morning, from where they marched under police escort to the ongwediva town council to hand over a petition asking for taxi ranks. they then marched back to the oshakati town council s offices, where they also handed over a petition asking for the taxi ranks in oshakati. from there they marched to the oshakati police station where the regional nabta chairman, pendapala nakathingo, read a petition addressed to the police chief, lieutenant general sebastian ndeitunga...police deputy commissioner sydney philander said he would forward the petition to lieutenant general sebastian ndeitunga. both the ceo of ongwediva, damian egumbo, and the acting ceo of oshakati, ores shilunga, promised to address the lack of taxi ranks in their towns...

sources: 1 nabta angry over illegal taxi strike. the namibian windhoek , january 25, 2011 tuesday, jana mari smith and absalom shigwedha; 2 taxi rebellion turns violent. the namibian windhoek , january 26, 2011 wednesday, absalom shigwedha; 3 govt backs police action. the namibian windhoek , january 26, 2011 wednesday, jana mari smith;
notes: 1 a surprise protest in windhoek yesterday by hundreds of taxi drivers is threatening to bring the city of windhoek to a partial standstill in days to come...the strike, which took place at two sites in katutura, was monitored by the city police and nampol officers. strikers were adamant that a strike could help them solve the issue of high fines, and nangombe was criticised for his perceived lack of action. the nabta boss was described as useless and his plea that the strike be called off was ignored...part of the group meeting at donkerhoek in katutura yesterday. taxi drivers say the high fines are unreasonable and will ruin their business...city police chief abraham kanime personally visited both sites of the protest, and attempted to discuss the issues. kanime stressed that the fines are not a fee. you have an option. if you don t contravene the law, everything will be good. kanime warned that the traffic fines are based on law, which cannot be changed on short notice... ; 2 two taxi drivers were injured after the police clashed with a group of striking windhoek taxi drivers in katutura yesterday morning. the confrontation between the taxi drivers and a contingent of law enforcement agents consisting of uniformed and plainclothes police officers as well as the police special reserve force started when the drivers decided to march to the city centre in defiance of police orders. the police had to fire warning shots in the air to stop the approaching mass of taxi drivers. the unruly taxi drivers retaliated by throwing stones at the police. the police were forced to fire rubber bullets at the group. the two taxi drivers who were injured are mateus leonard 45 , who was hit by rubber bullets in the head and arm, and simon shangula 29 , who was beaten on the head with the butt of a gun.; 3 government yesterday condemned the violent behaviour of protesting taxi drivers, which led to the arrest of 90 taxi drivers and injuries to at least six police officers and two taxi drivers...violent scenes played out in katutura yesterday, as hundreds of taxi drivers scattered in all directions in the lafrenz area after the police fired tear gas into the crowd. the police said several rocks had been thrown at police officers and their vehicles and several taxi drivers were shooting with live ammunition while the rocks were being thrown. the police later arrested several men and confiscate their firearms. a number of taxi drivers, who refused to take part in the strike, were beaten up by striking colleagues. the situation was still tense last night, as police and taxi drivers were again in a standoff as the drivers tried to reach their parked cars in katutura s donkerhoek neighbourhood...

sources: pohamba shrugs off gipf petition. the namibian windhoek , february 16, 2011 wednesday, jo mar duddy;
notes: president hifikepunye pohamba yesterday snubbed hundreds of disgruntled civil servants wanting to voice their dismay about the lost millions of the government institutions pension fund gipf when he refused to receive their petition at the opening of parliament. the police turned back at least 700 peaceful protesters, blocking them at the zoo park in independence avenue and marching them to gipf house where a press officer from state house was sent to pick up the petition...

sources: government nurses take to the streets. the namibian windhoek , july 19, 2011 tuesday, nico smit;
notes: on april 6, the nurses submitted proposed salary structures and re grading to the ministry of health and requested a meeting with kahuure on may 17, but have not had any response?

sources: 1 youth march stopped by police. the namibian windhoek , may 10, 2011 tuesday, jana mari smith; 2 youth demonstrators must forget payout shipoh. the namibian windhoek , may 11, 2011 wednesday, nico smit; 3 three youth protesters arrested. the namibian windhoek , may 12, 2011 thursday, nico smit;
notes: turned violent on the third day; 1 a youth organisation march to the ministry of youth yesterday was stopped in its tracks by police in wanaheda after the group threatened to camp on the ministry s premises until their demands are met. deputy commissioner andreas nelumbo confirmed that the wisdom youth organisation wiyo protesters were ordered to stop the march because of their intention to camp on the ministry grounds...several members of wiyo decided to camp at the corner of the wanaheda police station, surrounded by a number of police officers ordered to keep the group calm...wiyo members and organisers agreed that their main goal is to find employment and stop the rising levels of youth unemployment in the country... ; 2 the permanent secretary in the ministry of youth and sport, dr peingeondjabi shipoh, has dismissed demands by a group of young people camping outside the wanaheda police station in katutura...shipoh said he met the group two to three weeks ago already... ; 3 the police stopped a march by a youth group to the ministry of youth, national youth service, sport and culture and arrested three of the protesters. after spending two days camped outside the wanaheda police station in katutura, the group calling themselves wisdom youth organisation wiyo claimed that they were told by the station commander, chief inspector joshua shikongo, that they could march to the ministry...the youth organiser said that deputy commissioner andreas nelumbu had set up a blockade to prevent them from marching further...the police prevented the protesters from marching further and kept them there for most of the day, until late in the afternoon...at around 15h45, the police had left the scene where they had set up the blockade and the protesters continued their march...however, 300 metres down the road they were stopped and prevented from moving further...the incident turned violent when the police began pushing the crowd of largely women and children protesters back in the direction from which they had come. three of the protestors, all of them male, were arrested by the police in the scuffle. the police continued to herd the protesters in the direction of the wanaheda police station, constantly pushing the women and children without encountering any real resistance.

protesteridentity: plastic packaging employees, metal and allied namibian workers union manwu
sources: plastic packaging workers on strike. the namibian windhoek , june 7, 2011 tuesday, nico smit;
notes: plastic packaging employees took to the streets in protest yesterday morning following a breakdown in wage negotiations...207 workers took part in the strike at all three plants and would not return to work until the issue had been resolved...plastic packaging management held a meeting with manwu representatives yesterday afternoon, but the dispute remained unresolved.

sources: government nurses take to the streets. the namibian windhoek , july 19, 2011 tuesday, nico smit;
notes: on june 13, nurses in the khomas region staged another peaceful demonstration to hand over their petition and express their dissatisfaction at the manner in which they were being treated by government?

sources: airport employees still in the dark. the namibian windhoek , august 12, 2011 friday, nico smit;
notes: in early july, approximately 200 employees staged a lunch time demonstration at the country s main airport over demands for a housing allowance from their employer. napwu shop steward and nac employee faye kandjoo said in july that management had called the airport s company s employees to the negotiating table approximately one week after the first peaceful protest. roughly a month after the negotiations began, a senior official inside napwu yesterday said that the two parties were still in the negotiating process and that progress was being made.

sources: government nurses take to the streets. the namibian windhoek , july 19, 2011 tuesday, nico smit;
notes: between 500 and 700 nurses gathered outside the high court in windhoek yesterday, from where they marched down independence avenue, and up fidel castro street to deliver a petition to prime minister nahas angula. yesterday s peaceful demonstration and handing over of the petition was the third public demonstration by nurses in windhoek this year. nurses at the oshakati state hospital also demonstrated yesterday...

sources: 1 police and residents clash at herero mall. the namibian windhoek , august 8, 2011 monday, nico smit; 2 swanu probes herero mall unrest. the namibian windhoek , august 10, 2011 wednesday, nico smit;
notes: 1 chaos erupted at herero mall in katutura, windhoek on friday evening when the police clashed with an unruly crowd who refused to let the police close down shebeens which were operating without licences. herero mall has recently been at the centre of attention following a bust up between khomas regional councillor ambrosius kandjii and a shebeen owner, and a police clampdown on illegal alcohol sales...when about three or four police officers arrived at herero mall on friday evening to close down operations for the evening, they were met by disgruntled and unruly shebeen owners and patrons who demanded that the police show them the documents authorising the closure of the shebeens. the police officers then left the scene only to return about 20 minutes later with about 30 police and special reserve members. the situation quickly spiralled out of control as patrons and shebeen owners refused to allow the police to close the shops. while the police fired teargas and bullets into the air to disperse the agitated crowd, the police themselves faced a barrage of rocks and empty bottles from the crowd...one man at herero mall asked why only that place was being targeted by the police and why shebeens in eveline street were allowed to operate until late into the night. ; 2 two men arrested on friday evening at herero mall appeared in the windhoek magistrate s court in katutura on a number of charges. samson ngombe, a shebeen owner at herero mall, and ngumenitize katjimune were arrested on friday evening when a riot broke out as police attempted to enforce new operating hours for shebeens and close them down for the evening...

sources: 1 bethanie residents lock out council workers. the namibian windhoek , september 22, 2011 thursday, luqman cloete; 2 bethanie faces power blackout. the namibian windhoek , september 23, 2011 friday, luqman cloete; 3 bethanie protest drags on. the namibian windhoek , october 5, 2011 wednesday, luqman cloete; 4 bethanie seeks interdict against protestors. the namibian windhoek , october 10, 2011 monday, luqman cloete; 5 bethanie has no confidence in council chairperson. the namibian windhoek , november 17, 2011 thursday, luqman cloete; 6 bethanie residents dismantle camp. the namibian windhoek , july 18, 2012, luqman cloete;
notes: 1 disgruntled residents of bethanie village in the south yesterday padlocked the council s gates in protest against the recent work contract renewal of the council s chief executive officer, willy humphries. the residents let in council workers only after police intervention... ; 2 the council yesterday reconnected water and electricity supply to residents houses after they protested. claiming the council had failed to inform them in advance about the cancellation, the protesting residents demanded that the council restore the services and negotiate with affected residents on how to repay their debts. the council suspended water and electricity supply because of residents outstanding debts. during the protest the residents also called for the termination of humphries s employment contract, which the council had recently renewed for another five year term. the disgruntled residents claimed the council s administration was in shambles because humphries allegedly runs the office from his cellphone . ; 3 angry residents of bethanie village in the south are still protesting in front of the village council, objecting to the renewal of the work contract of the council s ceo, willly humphries. the protest is now a week old? ; 4 the bethanie town council is turning to the courts to remove angry residents protesting in front of the council offices. council s decision to renew an employment contract of its ceo, willy humphries, for another five year term led to the protest now edging towards its second week. the residents want the council to terminate humphries contract with immediate effect, claiming that it was renewed in a dubious manner at the beginning of september...picketing protestors, who have illegally set up tents at a council plot, about 30 meters from the council office... ; 5 meanwhile, a group of residents have vowed to continue their two month old protest in front of the council office to object to the renewal of humphries s contract. the group now also demands that knouwds be removed as a council member. ; 6 a group of bethanie residents camping in front of the local council offices on monday voluntarily dismantled their protest camp. the residents calling themselves the bethanie concerned community had set up the protest camp on september 21 2011 in protest against the contract renewal of the council s top administrator willy humphries in august last year and council s alleged failure to respond to the group s petition containing maladministration allegations...the group s spokesperson hendrik jansen yesterday told the namibian that they ended the protest after they were served with summons to explain in the high court why they refused to vacate the premises that they occupied illegally...

protesteridentity: nampower employees, mineworkers union of namibia mun
sources: nampower workers petition management. the namibian windhoek , september 28, 2011 wednesday, nico smit;
notes: approximately 260 nampower employees staged a protest outside the power utility s main offices in windhoek yesterday. they handed over a petition to nampower managing director md paulinus shilamba. the workers are not happy with the deadlock in wage negotiations between nampower and the mineworkers union of namibia mun and overspending by the company...accepting the petition, shilamba said the fact that he personally received the petition was a sign that nampower was committed to the wellbeing of its employees, whom it regards as the organisation s most important assets. shilamba told the workers that nampower had always been a good employer and ensured them that their concerns would receive thorough consideration.

sources: democracy and progress branch fails to recall bethanie councillor. the namibian windhoek , october 13, 2011 thursday, luqman cloete;
notes: on monday local police used teargas to disperse a mob of local rdp members after they had allegedly stormed the council office and insisted on handing over the recall letter personally to knouwds. protestors calling for the termination of humphries s contract have voiced their disapproval of the harsh treatment the rdp members had received at the hands of the police...

protesteridentity: polytechnic employees, namibia public workers union napwu
sources: polytechnic staff threaten with strike. the namibian windhoek , october 13, 2011 thursday, nico smit;
notes: a group of between 60 and 70 polytechnic employees held a demonstration outside the main gate of the polytechnic s windhoek campus yesterday to voice their concern over what they claim to be a general disregard of their concerns by the institution s management. namibia public workers union napwu senior organiser cleophas katuuo read out a petition setting out the polytechnic employees grievances, saying that the unfair labour treatment of polytechnic of namibia employees by dr tjama tjivikua cannot be tolerated in an independent namibia anymore ...

location: Iipandayamiti, Oshoogolo, Ombalala, Omafo and Oheke villages
protesteridentity: residents of iipandayamiti, oshoogolo, ombalala, omafo and oheke villages
sources: etayi s villagers demand electricity. the namibian windhoek , november 1, 2011 tuesday, oswald shivute at etayi;
notes: residents of iipandayamiti, oshoogolo, ombalala, omafo and oheke villages in the omusati region held a demonstration last week, demanding that pre paid electricity metres be installed at their churches, settlements and businesses...the villagers also said that they do not have roads in the constituency and it seems that earlier promises of roads have died a natural death. the residents than called upon their councillor and omusati governor sophia shaningwa to consider their petition as an urgent matter.

sources: tsumeb residents march against toxic concentrates. the namibian windhoek , november 28, 2011 monday, oswald shivute at tsumeb;
notes: residents of tsumeb on friday demonstrated, demanding the immediate halt of copper concentrate imports for refining at the namibia custom smelters ncs . they also called on the government to ban the import of copper, especially from bulgaria. the demonstration was led by swapo regional coordinator for the oshikoto region armas amukwiyu and joined by some oshikoto regional councillors and the senior headman of oshivelo traditional district, nation nashikaku...accepting the petition, councillor tobias said he is also concerned about this issue, and promised that he will forward the petition to the office of the oshikoto governor penda yandakolo for his immediate attention.

sources: khorixas residents rally against corruption. the namibian windhoek , february 17, 2012 friday;
notes: about 500 khorixas residents yesterday demonstrated against corruption at the local council, calling for the removal of the chief executive officer. the demonstrators in no uncertain terms called for the current ceo nicodemus gaeseb to be replaced with a new chief executive...closely monitored by armed police. some protesters threw stones at the council offices before the police intervened. after much argument between the ceo and the demonstrators and with the intervention of the police the petition was later handed to the ceo, who promised to forward it to the minister of regional, local government and housing, jerry ekandjo, to whom it is addressed...

protesteridentity: municipal bus drivers, namibia public workers union napwu
sources: 1 windhoek bus drivers protest. the namibian windhoek , february 24, 2012 friday, nico smit; 2 bus drivers still waiting. the namibian windhoek , february 29, 2012 wednesday, nico smit; 3 windhoek bus drivers run out of patience. the namibian windhoek , march 16, 2012 friday, nico smit;
notes: daily protests began on february 23rd, but after approximately two weeks of no response, the bus drivers marches on the mayor s office on march 15th; 1 municipal bus drivers took to the streets of windhoek yesterday to voice their dissatisfaction with their employer s refusal to pay them overtime backdated to 2007. the group of about 60 drivers also expressed unhappiness over the manner in which the municipality s public transport division is being run...alleged that nepotism and favouritism are rife in the division, adding that rupingena does not follow any of the municipality s policies and procedures... ; 2 municipal bus drivers in windhoek have still not received any response from the windhoek municipality following daily demonstrations which started last thursday over a dispute relating to overtime payments... ; 3 municipal bus drivers in windhoek yesterday marched to the mayor s office to hand over a petition demanding overdue overtime payments as well as the axing of their department head. roughly two weeks ago municipal bus divers in windhoek engaged in a daily peaceful protests outside the city s public transport division to voice their disappointment over a number of issues...the group also expressed their unhappiness over the manner in which the municipality s public transport division is run by its manager, clarence rupingena. however, over the last two weeks the drivers protest action has fallen on deaf ears, prompting the drivers to engage in a march and hand over the petition...deputy mayor gerson kamatuka received the petition on behalf of mayor elaine trepper, who is out of town. kamatuka said he would discuss the issues contained in the petition with trepper and raise them at the city council s management committee meeting on monday.

sources: parties differ on keetmans community s vote. the namibian windhoek , february 27, 2012 monday, luqman cloete;
notes: close to 70 residents led by community activist ernst jash on friday staged a protest march and presented a petition containing the so called no confidence vote against the council and its ceo to karas governor bernadus swartbooi s special advisor, lucia basson...

sources: rundu vendors give swapo cold shoulder. the namibian windhoek , march 7, 2012 wednesday;
notes: street vendors, who were evicted by the rundu town council and ordered not to sell their goods in the central business district cbd , indicated after the meeting that they will go back on the streets to conduct their businesses in the usual manner. the town council last week abandoned an eviction order, after they apparently received instructions from kavango regional governor maurus nekaro that the namibian police should allow the vendors to continue selling on the streets. last week s eviction was the second time in two years that street vendors were ordered away from the cbd. the latest eviction was met with fierce resistance from more than 600 street vendors who flocked to the municipal offices, demanding to see rundu mayor hilka levi...after failing to see the mayor, the street vendors then resorted to an unsanctioned demonstration through the town s main street, despite several reminders from police officers that what they were doing was illegal. the street vendors claimed that the open markets are too small and cannot accommodate all of them, and that is why they opted to sell in the streets. they also indicated that they cannot afford to pay rental fees at the open market, as they do not generate significant profits from their businesses.

sources: residents have no confidence in maltah ?he council. the namibian windhoek , march 29, 2012 thursday, luqman cloete;
notes: angry residents of maltah ?he yesterday staged a protest march against the village council. the protest march, spearheaded by a pressure group calling itself the maltah ?he community advocacy committee, called for the removal of the entire council...the residents also took issue with alleged interference by the local government ministry in appointing senior council staff...

sources: maltah ?he residents march again. the namibian windhoek , april 27, 2012 friday, luqman cloete;
notes: although the source says this is the third demonstration in recent months, only two are reported in our sources; maltah ?he residents yesterday staged a third peaceful demonstration in less than two months against alleged corruption, poor service delivery and incompetence in their village council. recently the disgruntled residents adopted a no confidence vote against the entire council, accusing them of not knowing what their responsibilities as elected office bearers are. because of their alleged ignorance, the councillors are being manipulated by council s top administrative staff, the residents claimed. handing over a petition to the council following a protest march spearheaded by the community advocacy committee cac ...the council s chief executive officer, eliphas shipanga, received the petition and promised to forward it to the council...

sources: walvis bay municipal workers list grievances. the namibian windhoek , june 13, 2012 wednesday, adam hartman;
notes: workers from almost every department of the walvis bay municipality stopped working yesterday to stage a protest march and hand over a petition containing labour grievances. they wanted to give it to either the mayor, derek klazen, or chief executive officer muronga haingura but it was received by the general manager of communications, kevin adams, in the presence of councillor romeo goseb...brand said the workers want the municipality to honour the recognition agreement signed in 1999. according to the workers, the council has been ignoring the agreement by issuing directives that allegedly have had an adverse effect on employees working environment, benefits and work relationships...

sources: football clubs feud with outapi town council over land. the namibian windhoek , july 16, 2012, oswald shivute;
notes: six football clubs in the omusati region staged a demonstration against the outapi town council on wednesday after their grounds were taken away from them. the protesters accuse the council of having demolished their four sport fields at onakayale village without their consent. they claim to have been allocated the piece of land by the late village headman blasius nangolo, who died earlier this year...led by a police escort, the demonstrators marched to the office of governor sophia shaningwa who told their leader, jona dlamini ndinoshiho, that she cannot receive their petition as the right person to receive it is the mayor of outapi. the town council is said to have earmarked the area situated less than 50 metres from the nangolo homestead for unspecified development...

protesteridentity: rally for democracy and progress rdp supporters, other opposition party supporters
sources: 1 police dampen rdp sit in. the namibian windhoek , july 17, 2012, catherine sasman; 2 rdp blames political interference for removals. the namibian windhoek , july 19, 2012, catherine sasman;
notes: 1 the rally for democracy and progress yesterday accused the police of using a colonial law which prohibits a demonstration in or near a court building to remove their supporters from the supreme court. the party had staged a sit in since sunday to demand the verdict of the 2009 national assembly election court challenge, but the police gave them until 16h00 yesterday to pack up and go or face the law...since sunday noon, more than 200 demonstrators have arrived at the supreme court from most regions of the country... the election verdict is three years outstanding; we want this matter to be finally dealt with so that we know which way we are going. ... ; 2 rally for democracy and progress rdp demonstrators who moved their tents from the supreme court to the parliament gardens on monday have been ordered to move again. the party s secretary for information and publicity, jeremiah nambinga, yesterday said the police were not against the demonstration and sit in at the start, blaming political interference for the police s decision to have them removed from the area in front of the supreme court...the party has decided to withdraw from the parliament gardens in order to avoid a confrontation with the police...the demonstrators will be moved to the shalom centre in the goreangab dam area where they will sleep, and return to the supreme court during the day where they will continue with their demonstration...

sources: 1 jobs for struggle kids at swapo farm on cards . the namibian windhoek , september 12, 2012, catherine sasman; 2 khomas constituency office rejects job reservation order. the namibian windhoek , october 01, 2012, catherine sasman;
notes: 1 the 195 struggle kids still camping out at brakwater may soon get entry level jobs in the public service....the brakwater area outside windhoek yesterday, where 195 struggle kids have been staying since july 17, they were in high spirits, performing dances and songs for a filming crew of namrights that is doing a documentary on the struggle kids who have staged protests at various locations since september 2008...the news of possible jobs for the youths came as a very welcome reprief and proof that when pressured, government can come up with the goods, commented the executive director of namrights, phil ya nangoloh. ; 2 ...a group of about 200 struggle kids have camped at a swapo plot at brakwater north of windhoek since july 17 after their protests in the city were stopped by the authorities.

sources: teachers march to nantu office. the namibian windhoek , october 18, 2012, selma shipanga;
notes: close to 300 teachers who staged a demonstration at the office of the namibian national teachers union nantu yesterday afternoon to hand over a petition calling on general secretary basilius haingura to report on the status of salary negotiations...

protesteridentity: residents of swakopmund drc informal settlement
sources: police pepper spray drc residents. the namibian windhoek , october 26, 2012, adam hartman;
notes: police at swakopmund used pepper spray yesterday to disperse hundreds of people who demonstrated outside the town s municipal building for better service in the drc informal settlement. the demonstration turned violent when the protesters became frustrated with police officers who were summoned to disperse the crowds after they refused to leave the premises and opted to stay on until last night s ordinary council meeting at 19h00. the protest was in response to the town council s alleged procrastination when it came to the formalisation of the shantytown on the north eastern fringe of swakopmund. residents of all ages marched about five kilometres from the drc to the municipality to air their frustration and to hand over another petition to swakopmund ceo eckart demasius. demasius assured them that the matter would be addressed at last night s council meeting, but the protestors refused to accept this as an official acknowledgment of their petition. instead they opted to occupy the municipal grounds until the meeting where they expected an official response. the police were called in while the town s managers applied for a court order to stop the protest. the protestors however stood their ground...at lunchtime, residents started arguing with officers who were ordering them to leave the premises and scuffles broke out. one man involved in a tussle with an officer was handcuffed and dragged to a police van. protestors then stormed the police, demanding that they let the man go. some ran toward the van, shouting their dissatisfaction and making threats, and the police used pepper spray to disperse the crowd...

location: Khomas region and Otjiwarongo, Oshana Region, Oshakati, Ompundja and Onamutai, Omaheke, Karas, Erongo, Ohangwena and Otjozondjupa regions and Windhoek
protesteridentity: teachers, teachers union of namibia tun
sources: 1 teacher strike snowballs. the namibian windhoek , october 30, 2012, selma shipanga; 2 teachers arrested. the namibian windhoek , november 01, 2012, oswald shivute and selma shipanga; 3 teachers strike heads to court. the namibian windhoek , november 02, 2012, werner menges and selma shipanga; 4 teachers urge civil servants to join strike. the namibian windhoek , november 07, 2012, selma shipanga; 5 teachers reject pay deal. the namibian windhoek , november 09, 2012, selma shipanga and denver kisting; 6 lessons of the teachers strike. the namibian windhoek , september 27, 2013;
notes: related to october 17th event. when khomas & otjozondjupa protest on oct. 29th there is no response source 1 . when teachers in additional locations protest on nov. 1 police try to disperse the crowd and arrest some teachers source 2 . 1 more than 400 teachers from the khomas region who took part in a strike yesterday stated that until their demands for a salary increase are met, they will not return to school and will continue to demonstrate at the ministry of education office premises. added to that figure are over 200 secondary and primary school teachers from the otjozondjupa region who also demonstrated at otjiwarongo yesterday. ; 2 some teachers in the oshana region were arrested yesterday for picketing without permission from the police. the teachers from the oshakati, ompundja and onamutai circuits went on strike yesterday, joining their counterparts in the khomas, omaheke, karas, erongo, ohangwena and otjozondjupa regions. the strike has been declared illegal by the ministry of education and the office of the prime minister. the oshana teachers first met at the oshakati independence stadium but the police chased them away. they then set up camp in othingo village on the oshakati okahao main road, where some were arrested and the rest were ordered to leave...meanwhile, in windhoek, more than 500 teachers picketing at the offices of the ministry of education were informed by the police of the correct procedures to follow before picketing... ; 3 the more than 500 khomas region teachers who have been striking in front of the head office of the ministry of education since monday said they would be marching to the high court today as from 12h00. attempts by the teachers to march to the offices of the prime minister on tuesday were blocked by the police because of the illegality of the strike... ; 6 the namibian teachers nation wide strike, that lasted almost two weeks from the 29th of october until the 8th of november 2012...

sources: teachers reject pay deal. the namibian windhoek , november 09, 2012, selma shipanga and denver kisting;
notes: hundreds of nurses and other health workers, including hospital cleaning staff, gathered at the katutura state hospital s nurses home yesterday where they decided to go on strike on tuesday...

sources: teachers reject pay deal. the namibian windhoek , november 09, 2012, selma shipanga and denver kisting;
notes: the namibia national students organisation nanso yesterday led a march by close to 1 000 pupils from schools in khomasdal and katutura, which started at the dawid bezuidenhout secondary school and ended at the immanuel shifidi secondary school. nanso and the pupils are asking the government to meet the demands of their teachers so that the teachers could return to school for the examinations that started this week...

sources: zemba, himba demonstrate over exclusion. the namibian windhoek , november 28, 2012;
notes: himba and zemba people from the omuhonga and epupa areas on saturday marched from their villages to okanguati, 120 kilometres from opuwo, to protest against human rights violations against them? in these declarations, they denounced the planned hydro electric dam in the baynes mountains, which they said would threaten their way of life and the natural environment that sustains it, and lead to a potential loss of land...

sources: himba, zemba protest widens. the namibian windhoek , december 12, 2012, catherine sasman;
notes: himba and zemba communities have again taken to the streets to amplify their demand for more control over their traditional lands. the groups first demonstrated at okanguati, 120 kilometres from opuwo, in late november, and on december 5 took a petition straight to the government offices at opuwo, capital of the kunene region, to repeat their dismay at a planned hydro electric dam in the baynes mountains...

sources: khorixas residents demonstrate over corruption. the namibian windhoek , december 19, 2012, clemans miyanicwe;
notes: about 100 placard waving khorixas residents on monday demanded the suspension of town council officials who have been charged with corruption...the demonstration gathered at eddie bowe soccer field in front of the khorixas town council offices and chanted slogans calling for the removal of the three officials. they also demanded the reconnection of water supply that was disconnected over unpaid bills and that a new debtors system be implemented within 60 days...

sources: you have no right to occupy party premises . the namibian windhoek , january 24, 2013, timotheus andreas;
notes: swapo party secretary general nangolo mbumba says he has neither the power nor the capacity to provide the children of the liberation struggle with jobs. mbumba told nampa yesterday that as part of his duties as sg he can meet them, and nothing else. he was responding to demands by a group of about 80 struggle kids as they are often referred to on january 11 to meet him specifically...

sources: struggle kids camp again. the namibian windhoek , january 21, 2013, oswald shivute;
notes: a group of children of the liberation struggle have been camping outside the swapo regional office at outapi in the omusati region since late last week, demanding employment by the government...they accuse the ministry of youth, national service, sport and culture of failing to deliver on its promises of public service jobs made when it registered them in 2008 and 2009... we will camp here until our demands for employment are met, said amutenya. they want to meet with prime minister hage geingob, defence minister nahas angula and youth minister jerry ekandjo to discuss their situation. the protesters are from 12 constituencies of omusati, namely outapi, anamulenge, ruacana, onesi, tsandi, okahao, otamanzi, elim, oshikuku, etayi, ogongo and okalongo...

sources: ohangwena struggle kids camping at eenhana swapo office. the namibian windhoek , february 04, 2013, oswald shivute at eenhana;
notes: about 800 children of the liberation struggle from the ohangwena region are camping at the regional swapo office at eenhana, demanding government jobs. one of the spokespersons of the group, asteria patrick, confirmed to the namibian over the weekend that more than 800 of them from all over the ohangwena region have been camping at the swapo office since january 28 and will remain there until their demand is met. she said they have handed a petition to the ohangwena governor, usko nghaamwa, who promised to forward it to the relevant authorities. they said they were registered by the ministry of youth in 2009 and were promised jobs in the public service, but this never materialised...

sources: homeowners petition stopped in tracks. the namibian windhoek , february 11, 2013, catherine sasman;
notes: the police stopped a group of demonstrators under the home owners association hoa from continuing with their march on friday. the march was intended to petition the high court against alienating houses from poor households?

sources: protesters defend the mini. the namibian windhoek , february 25, 2013, selma kaulinge;
notes: what started with a controversial statement by the inspector general of the namibian police ended with a protest by a large crowd of women, and even some men, dressed in miniskirts. in last week tuesday s edition of the namibian, lieutenant general sebastian ndeitunga was quoted as saying that women must stop wearing skimpy miniskirts and hot pants or face arrest. ndeitunga was said although the police do not want to interfere in citizens constitutional freedom, skirts that are too short and revealing are not acceptable in african culture and amount to public indecency. those who are behaving outside the normal tradition of an african will be dealt with, he said...others called it an abuse of women s rights and called for peaceful protests which led to hundreds of protesters coming together at the zoo park in windhoek on friday. at around lunchtime, a crowd of female protesters, and even some men, showed up in miniskirts and skimpy shorts in defiance of the police s view that wearing short skirts and shorts amounts to public indecency...there are already a number of cases of women being threatened with arrest because of wearing miniskirts. the miniskirt came under the spotlight over the festive season when more than 40 girls wearing hot pants were arrested at rundu. kavango deputy commissioner willie bampton told nampa earlier this year that the police would continue arresting those who are not properly dressed...

protesteridentity: struggle children, namibian exile kids association neka
sources: 1 police stop illegal march. the namibian windhoek , march 06, 2013, clemans miyanicwe; 2 neka gives government seven days. the namibian windhoek , march 18, 2013, selma shipanga; 3 struggle kids granted n 500 bail. the namibian windhoek , april 29, 2013;
notes: started as a 700km march from the north to windhoek & setting up of a tent camp source 2 then turned into a march & police confrontation source 1 . source 3 indicates the camp lasted from march 1 april 22. 1 the police yesterday blocked an illegal march in windhoek s robert mugabe avenue by a group of children of the liberation struggle who wanted to petition the office of the prime minister. a scuffle erupted between the police and the marchers after one male member of the group hit a police officer. some members of the group were lying in the street to block it and were removed to the pavement. we wanted to go to the office of the prime minister but the police blocked the road and shot at us with rubber bullets, conrad claimed later. one police officer was hit in the face with a stone while another was hit on the leg. stones were raining, these people are a nuisance, one police officer said when the namibian arrived at the scene. the police used teargas to disperse the protesters and about 40 of them were arrested. inspector ismael basson said the march was illegal and was therefore stopped by the police. two of the officers were injured seriously and we rounded up 40 of them protesters , basson said. officers and some injured struggle kids were taken to hospital for treatment. later in the day, some of the struggle kids again had a scuffle with the police at the gates of the swapo headquarters where they sang liberation songs and chanted give us work . our mothers and fathers died, we are alone, some shouted. later about 50 police officers arrived in riot gear and an estimated 100 tents were removed from opposite the swapo headquarters. ; 2 talk of a national protest by neka comes after a group of more than 50 so called struggle kids arrived in windhoek last month after allegedly covering more than 700 kilometres on foot from outapi in northern namibia. since arriving in windhoek, the group have been camping near the swapo headquarters in katutura where they ve since been evicted following several run ins with the police. some of them were arrested and spent a day or two in police holding cells. earlier this month, the group of protesting struggle kids tried marching to geingob s office but were stopped in their tracks by the police... ; 3 the 224 children of the liberation struggle arrested for illegally camping near the swapo party headquarters in the capital have been granted bail of n 500 each...the two charges of loitering emanated from their alleged illegal camping at an open area near the swapo party headquarters at the corner of hans dietrich genscher and leonard auala streets in katutura from 1 march to 22 april 2013...

sources: 1 himba, zemba reiterate no to baynes dam. the namibian windhoek , march 26, 2013, catherine sasman; 2 muharukua angered by himba demo. the namibian windhoek , march 27, 2013, catherine sasman;
