notes: 1 indigenous himba and zemba communities from villages in the kunene region held a demonstration at opuwo yesterday to express their frustration over unrecognised chiefs, illegal fencing of parts of their land, and the implementation of the communal land reform act of 2002. another pressing issue they want to drive home to the powers that be is the planned construction of a hydro electric project in the baynes mountains, which they say would further push them off their land...yesterday s march was also to call for drought relief from the government. the communities want the government to subsidise fodder for their livestock, and to look into improving the distribution of drought relief food. the himba and zemba communities are especially hard hit by the current drought because of their remoteness and the inaccessible terrain in which they live. the communities fear that their cattle might start dying because of the extremely dry and hot weather conditions during this rainy season. with little or no rain this year yet, the communities have also not been able to plant gardens, so they do not have any maize to sustain them... ; 2 the demonstration on monday was reportedly met with resistance from the authorities. earth peoples said namibian police tried to stop the marching crowds outside opuwo, but that the himba and zemba simply passed the police and calmly and peacefully continued. it said once in the centre of opuwo, the streets were flooded by hundreds and hundreds of singing and dancing people who walked to where they were to meet governor ho beb...

sources: hr s up ante against regrading. the namibian windhoek , july 11, 2013, theresia tjihenuna;
notes: more than 200 human resource hr practitioners working for government gathered at the government office park on monday to express their dissatisfaction with the recent regrading. the practitioners from the different government ministries say their hopes were dashed after they felt their profession was graded extremely low when compared to other job categories like the accountants. the group agreed to draft an appeal to the office of the prime minister opm to protest what they feel is government s failure to recognise their profession...in a document released by the opm as part of the april regrading, government announced the new entry level requirement for hr administrators is a minimum of grade 12. the requirement is considered a drop from the current requirement which was a minimum of two years experience...

sources: taxi strike turns nasty in windhoek. the namibian windhoek , july 24, 2013, clemans miyanicwe;
notes: the strike by taxi drivers which was called by the namibian transport and taxi union nttu was characterised by chaos yesterday as some drivers harassed and threatened passengers who had boarded taxis of the few drivers who did not to join the industrial action. several commuters were pulled out of cars and others verbally abused as they tried to get transport to different destinations in windhoek...januarie told the city police that nttu will only take responsibility of taxi drivers who are at an open field in katutura s donkerhoek. he said the taxi drivers will remain at the open field until their demands are met. the drivers are demonstrating against high traffic fines issued for breaking traffic regulations as well as other issues affecting them. nttu put the figure of the striking drivers at 900 although the figure appears to be less than that.

protesteridentity: teachers, students, namibia national teachers union nantu
sources: teachers, pupils demonstrate after teacher killing. the namibian windhoek , september 27, 2013,oswald shivute;
notes: a large group of teachers and pupils from all over the omusati region held a peaceful demonstration at outapi on wednesday to denounce the killing of vistorina nandjamba amunyela 30 , a teacher who was allegedly shot dead by her boyfriend petrus kashimba 33 , who also killed himself at outapi last week thursday...the teachers are demanding that the lawmakers amend the current laws that deal with such offenses, and are calling for stiffer punitive measures to be applied to such actions. they are of the opinion that national political leaders, churches, and civil society organisations and community members should join forces in combating such cruel actions by educating the society on human rights...nantu also urged the ministry of gender and child welfare to spearhead research programmes to find main reasons for gender based and domestic violence in namibia and indicated that namibia must use its resources to create effective awareness to highlight equality in intimate relationships...

sources: court orders drc protestors off council premises. the namibian windhoek , october 24, 2013, adam hartman;
notes: number of participants is inferred based on a later article that says 7700 drc residents returned their voter id cards to protest the govts process regarding the drc residences. drc protestors who have been occupying the swakopmund municipality premises since last week were ordered to end their unlawful occupation by acting judge petrus unengu in the high court yesterday...by yesterday morning, all the protestors had gone home..

sources: guards threaten christmas strike. the namibian windhoek , november 18, 2013, theresia tjihenuna;
notes: the security guards work for a variety of private employers but the demand is about minimum wage which is state policy. security guards have planned for a national strike over the festive season should their grievances not be addressed before 15 december, the namibia security guard and watchmen s union nsgwu has announced. secretary general of nsgwu david frans said this during a demonstration that took place on saturday in windhoek where more than 100 security guards gathered at katutura s old compounds...he said the minimum wage of security guards in namibia is a joke compared to that of other neighbouring countries like angola. some security guards who turned up at saturday s demonstration told the namibian that the monthly deductions on their salaries leave them completely cash stripped...

sources: police assault demonstrating youths at airport. the namibian windhoek , december 09, 2013, theresia tjihenuna;
notes: more than 60 youths, including six opposition parties youth wing leaders who demonstrated against the ecuador trip on thursday clashed with the police at the hosea kutako international airport. sources say chaos erupted at the international airport between 18h00 and 19h00, when police descended on the demonstrators with pepper sprays. the short lived protest came after more than 250 youth leaders from various bodies, including the swapo party youth league, the national youth council, officials from the ministry of youth and the minister of youth, national service, sport and culture, jerry ekandjo, were boarding a plane to attend the 18th world festival of youth students in ecuador. the trip has drawn a lot of criticism, particularly from opposition parties youth leaders as well as some government officials because of the staggering n 10 million budget, while the country is facing a drought and a collapsing health sector. the opposition party youth leaders and demonstrators have described the trip as discriminatory, unrepresentative and a waste of taxpayers money. approximately within six minutes after holding up our posters at the check in, the police emerged and started kicking, pushing, beating and using pepper sprays to disperse the peaceful gathering, said the rdp youth league secretary general monica nambelela...

sources: youth protest proposed new parliament building the namibian windhoek , january 14, 2014, 312 words, fikameni mathias ;
notes: just under a hundred, mostly young people, took to the streets of windhoek yesterday to express their disapproval of government s plan to construct a new parliament building. last week the namibian revealed that government would have to fork out n 700 million for the new building. affiliated to no specific political party, the youth decided to break their silence on topical issues, taking to the streets and marching to parliament to hand over their petition, signed by about 900 people. this is the first stand that we take against our government. our money cannot be squandered like this. we have the right to a say, said victor mabuku, a youth activist. we, as the youth, feel it is not the right time to spend such an amount of money when the country is faced with bigger problems such as youth unemployment and patients sleeping on hospital floors. we, therefore, urge our leaders to prioritise the nation s needs, said michael mulunga, another activist.

sources: angry mob attacks police new era windhoek , february 21, 2014, 321 words, john muyamba ;
notes: windhoek city police officers assigned to go and demolish a new shack in goreangab yesterday were attacked with bottles and rocks by a mob. the riotious mob of over a hundred were angered by the fact that the police were demolishing a shack shebeen. in return the police, who initially ran for cover from the hail of flying bottles and rocks, fired tear gas into the air to disperse the unruly mob. but the mob remained defiant and continued to throwing every conceivable missile they could lay their hands on at the police even after tear gas was fired by the police. police vehicles were also damaged during the riot as car windows were smashed with stones and both the police and journalists had to shield themselves behind their vehicles to dodge the fussilade of missiles. three of the protesters were arrested. residents complained they needed land, but the government is not responding to their plight, but instead offers land to foreigners. they gave land to the chinese to do business in the area, they even have a farm here where they keep pigs and they have gardens there, but why can t they give us land?

sources: men in stilettos march against gbv new era windhoek , march 10, 2014, 601 words, alvine kapitako ;
notes: in order to demonstrate their support against gender based violence gbv hundreds of men, the majority of whom wore high heels while a few featured in feminine attire such as mini skirts and long dresses, on saturday protested against the violence that has skyrocketed in recent months. the walk a mile in her shoes campaign that coincided with international women s day saw men bravely sporting heels and skirts to demonstrate in independence avenue, with the protest march starting from the offices of the ministry of gender equality and child welfare and ending at zoo park in the city centre. dressing up in heels and dresses was meant to demonstrate to men how it feels to be a woman, at least to a certain degree. though many thought it would be easy walking in high heels, they admitted that it was no walk in the park but if that sent a message against gender based violence it was worth it, they felt. and indeed, the men made sure that the walk was not a lousy one as they chanted slogans denouncing gender based violence.

sources: omaruru officials ignore petitioning residents the namibian windhoek , march 19, 2014, 446 words ;
notes: a group of concerned omaruru residents staged a peaceful demonstration against the operations of the town s municipality on monday. about 50 people marched from the ozondje residential area to the omaruru town council s building. they had prepared a petition for the attention of the minister of regional and local government, housing and rural development, charles namoloh, but the petition was never handed over as their demonstration was ignored by senior officials of the municipality. in the petition, the group expressed concerns about the manner in which a number of local authority councillors were suspended during december 2013. the group said the suspended councillors were democratically elected, and complained that they have not been legally charged since their suspension on 16 december.

sources: reho council blocks ears to community demands the namibian windhoek , april 29, 2014, 636 words, theresia tjihenuna ;
notes: rehoboth residents marched to the town council offices on friday in a second demonstration in less than a month. the residents said they were demonstrating against alleged corruption revealed in several audit reports by pricewaterhousecoopers, among them the damning adonis it solutions report that exposed abuse of funds at the council. the community also criticised council s decision to take legal action against baster kaptein john mcnab, who is accused of illegally parcelling out land using the rukoro report as justification. the residents had given council until last week to respond but said they did not get a satisfactory response. about 100 people, most of them pensioners, joined the march that was conducted under heavy police presence. police stopped the impatient demonstrators just short of the council s gates, preventing them from advancing further. speaking from a white bakkie parked in front of the council gates, leader of the demonstration lukas de klerk accused the town s ceo, theo jankowski, of snatching bread from our children s mouths and vowed that they will not loosen their grip on the council this time.

sources: namibians protest against rhino poaching the namibian windhoek , may 22, 2014, 510 words ;
notes: zoo park was fittingly the venue for namibia s first anti rhino poaching protest, bringing together more than 60 demonstrators fighting the cause of the threatened species yesterday. now that it looks as if the eyes of the poachers are turning towards namibia, we want to send them a strong message that we have zero tolerance for poachers, and that they will be caught and sent to jail, high school pupil nita pallett said during the protest. at yesterday s protest, weeks told the namibian that it was vital that the public took a stand during the bail hearing of the chinese to ensure that a zero tolerance policy would be enforced before the situation ends up like in south africa , where rhino poaching has reached unprecedented and uncontrollable levels. weeks also said that the protest was aimed at creating awareness not only among the public but also among lawmakers, who should amend legislation to ensure that current laws to protect wildlife, which are too lenient , are tightened.

sources: residents protest over debts new era windhoek , may 28, 2014, 611 words, john travolter matali ;
notes: residents at the copper mining town of tsumeb in the oshikoto region took to the streets last week friday to protest against what they say are high water bills that are unrealistic . a crowd of more than 50 pensioners and other residents marched to the tsumeb municipal offices to hand over a petition demanding that their high water debts be cancelled and that the water meters be removed from their homes as they can no longer afford to pay skyrocketing water bills. some pensioners have lived in the municipal houses for over 30 years. the angry pensioners said they could not understand why water was so pricey while the town has plenty of ground water. in tsumeb tap water costs more than mineral water sold in shops, this is unacceptable, these are our own resources. remove the prepaid meters if you cannot reduce the price of water, said 89 year old justus thomas.

sources: fisheries workers demand land the namibian windhoek , october 02, 2014, 499 words ;
notes: about 50 workers of fishing companies at walvis bay yesterday held a peaceful demonstration to demand affordable land, with the trade union congress of namibia tucna saying that if their demand is not met, the workers would take the land by force. we need land in our country, the workers shouted, waving posters, as they marched from kuisebmond to the walvis bay municipality offices in town where they presented a petition. although only about 50 workers, who are members of the namibia seamen and allied workers union nasawu , took part in the demonstration, tucna president paulus hango said about 10 000 workers would have joined the march had they not been prevented by their employers. he accused municipalities of holding onto the land in order to get better profits, pushing the prices up and making land too expensive for low to middle income earners as well as small businesses. we are not asking for free land and houses. we are prepared to pay for houses, water and electricity as long as we are paying a reasonable price, the petition concluded.

sources: walvis shack dwellers march for land new era windhoek , october 03, 2014, 536 words ;
notes: the need for affordable housing was once again highlighted when about a 150 residents of walvis bay peacefully marched to the walvis bay municipality offices and handed over a petition in which they ambitiously demand at least 8 000 plots for the homeless and backyard squatters. the demonstration follows just a day after reports indicated that namibia had the second highest house price increase in the world after dubai, that shows owning a house could remain a distant dream for many namibians. the residents who stay in shacks protested against the lack of affordable land, and rising housing and electricity costs at walvis bay that have confines them to fire prone shacks. walvis is still experiencing an influx of people. those days you could rent a room for at least n 300 and still live comfortable. however, these day with the growing influx to the town, property prices skyrocket and makes it impossible for ordinary residents to rent a decent place, hango explained.

sources: youths protest over houses, cheaper land new era windhoek , november 18, 2014, 558 words, sabina elago ;
notes: over 100 young people yesterday demonstrated in front of the windhoek mayor s office where they demanded residential land, saying it is their birth right . the youths who demonstrated during lunchtime were led by the bring down the house group that also wants the prices of houses in namibia to come down. their protests follow the demonstration over land by suspended swapo party youth league spyl spokesman job amupanda who called for affirmative repositioning of land and demonstrated by sitting in on empty land in the upper class windhoek suburb of kleine kuppe. house prices in namibia are so high that the country is second only to dubai when it comes to property costs. reading the petition in the absence of windhoek city council officials and on behalf of the youthful protesters, xungi kathindi said the price of land is too high and unaffordable for most namibians. there is a high demand for land but a limited supply. this is caused by servicing and framework issues, she said. further, the group demanded transparency and accountability on the part of the windhoek city council in terms of using funds and land allocation. individuals, collectives and financial institutions should be allowed to service land at regulated prices. the city of windhoek must review the first time buyer definition, and limit the definition to first home ownership throughout namibia until the crisis is solved, said kathindi on behalf of the group.

sources: landless youth submit 14 000 applications new era windhoek , november 24, 2014, 626 words, alvine kapitako amupanda sets land grab ultimatum the namibian windhoek , december 21, 2014, 319 words ;
notes: the windhoek municipality on friday received 14 059 applications for residential land from mostly young professionals who showed an extraordinary sense of solidarity by staging a mass demonstration organised by the affirmative repositioning movement. on friday morning, young namibians thronged the front space of the windhoek municipality s head offices armed with their applications for residential land. as opposed to the typical style of namibian demonstrations, affirmative repositioning leaders made sure that theirs was a mass movement of substance by ensuring the municipality acknowledged receipt of all 14 059 applications. the demonstration was fuelled primarily by media reports of windhoek s high land prices, the cumbersome process ordinary namibians have to endure when applying for land, as well as mayor agnes kafula s questionable allocation of land to the country s elite and those with good political connections. amupanda expressed his appreciation towards taapopi and municipal spokesperson joshua amukugo, whom he said were handling the matter well. amupanda also led a massive demonstration when thousands of youth and the landless marched to the windhoek municipality to hand in applications for land. so far, 14 059 of those demonstrators have receive letters of acknowledgement from the city of windhoek.

sources: tsumeb residents march against violence new era windhoek , january 15, 2015, 430 words, rochelle neidel;
notes: residents of tsumeb took to the streets yesterday to demonstrate against gender based violence as well as other violent crime that is on the increase in the town. the group consisted of community activists, concerned residents and church leaders who together handed a petition to the tsumeb municipality, the tsumeb constituency councillor tangeni tobias, and the acting regional commander of the oshikoto region, willem peter enough is enough of all these rapes, killings and unnecessary violence in tsumeb. we would like to show our anger towards these barbaric acts, while we search for better coordination with all relevant authorities to fight perpetrators, said the spokesperson of the group, moses awiseb.

sources: emotional land protests rock okahandja... riot police disperse angry crowds new era windhoek , february 10, 2015, 686 words;
notes: riot police had to be called in yesterday to disperse angry crowds of okahandja residents, who demanded the removal of all local municipal councillors, including the mayor valerie aron. a near violent confrontation erupted in front of the okahandja municipal offices as residents demanded affordable access to land, while also calling for accountability from the town s authorities residents allege that rich people have been flocking to the garden town where land is apparently sold to them cheaply, while the poor are struggling to gain similar access. down mayor down! down councillors down! chanted hundreds of protesters, who gathered in front of the municipal premises since 07h00, demanding that the mayor come out of her office and accept their petition. by noon, things got so heated that about ten riot police officers tried to use minimal force to disperse the restive crowd and block their entrance to the premises, but the residents were unmoved.

protesteridentity: employees of langer heinrich uranium mine
sources: langer heinrich workers bemoan unsafe working conditions new era windhoek , february 20, 2015, 491 words;
notes: about 60 permanent employees participated in the peaceful demonstration to hand over the petition. workers also said the mine never implemented recommendations made after the 2013 accident that claimed the life of a miner. further, the workers allege that the mine does not have the safety of workers at heart. our members are exposed to safety hazards. the company does not properly investigate incidents at the mine, reads the petition foreigners do whatever they want here. they did not come here with uranium so they can go back where they came from. government must intervene as the mine is operating in chaos, said mun s regional organiser for erongo, kleophas ngwena. the workers also demand yearly bonuses, study assistance for every one and a company contribution of 80 percent towards their medical aid. the ministry of labour and social welfare was called upon to investigate the situation and find a solution.

sources: okahandja protestors forcefully moved new era windhoek , february 23, 2015, 541 words;
notes: the minister of regional and local government, housing and rural development, major general charles namoloh, has said aggrieved okahandja residents demonstrating against the local authority council must go home and wait for answers to their petition instead of settling on the premises of the municipality. a confrontation in front of the local municipality between the police and residents of okahandja last monday almost turned chaotic, as defiant protesters called for the removal of certain municipal councillors and staff members. by friday, police had to forcefully remove protesters from the municipality s grounds, after it became apparent that they obstinately refused to leave the premises since monday governor nuuyoma, meanwhile, maintains that accusations made against the okahandja municipality were unfounded and there was no proof on black and white to substantiate the allegations.

sources: ovitoto protest over farm new era windhoek , april 17, 2015, 302 words;
notes: close to a 100 villagers of ovitoto in otjozondjupa region on wednesday staged a peaceful protest urging the government to incorporate the recently procured resettlement farm otjisazu no. 53, unit b into the ovitoto communal area. the protest follows government s recent announcement of the resettlement of 37 people from hochfeld area at farm otjisazu no. 53, unit b. according to the villagers, the former minister of lands and resettlement now renamed land reform alpheus !naruseb assured ovitoto villagers that if any farm were to be bought in the area it would be incorporated into the ovitoto communal area where the prosters are living the continuing drought and lack of grazing land in the area are well known, stressed the group spokesperson, we want to make it categorically clear that we are not against the 37 beneficiaries of the resettled farm but we are against the manner in which everything was done, stressed kasinee.

sources: land indaba ends in stalemate new era windhoek , june 02, 2015, 1029 words;
notes: hundreds of defiant youth that occupied land at macaravan east last thursday held a highly charged meeting with the zambezi regional governor, lawrence sampofu, but no immediate solution was found for their grievances. up to 1 000 youths have in recent weeks cleared and grabbed portions of macaravan east on the outskirts of katima mulilo, alleging the town council is self serving and has failed to allocate them single use residential erven. last thursday s marathon meeting with sampofu was preceded by a march in which the youth sang and recited chants that taunted the ceo. some of the placards read, no plot, no vote, we re tired of empty promises, and don t sell our land to foreigners. there was a heavy police presence at the meeting over a week ago over a 1 000 youths grabbed land in the area of macaravan east in katima mulilo, claiming they had resorted to such action because the council failed to respond satisfactorily to their applications for land. the youths who filled up the community hall though cemented claims that their number has ballooned since the last land grab, as over 2 000 youths had come to vent their frustration over land this is the protest before the meeting. subsequent events might be codeable but it is unclear whether the land grab was a coordinated effort or not.

sources: disgruntled novanam workers hold demonstration new era windhoek , june 04, 2015, 680 words;
notes: over 300 novanam workers in l deritz under the namibia seaman and allied workers union nasawu on tuesday protested against the recruitment of foreigners by the fishing giant. workers who at lunchtime on tuesday demonstrated peacefully only went back to work after they handed over a petition listing their grievances to novanam s industrial relations officer persca mafale they further want the ministry of home affairs and immigration to stop the recruitment of foreigners and to stop issuing work permits to foreigners, because this only serves to condemn namibians to being given menial jobs with starvation wages workers also want an explanation from the employment equity commissioner and the ministry of home affairs and immigration.

sources: presidential intervention needed at katima new era windhoek , june 17, 2015, 597 words cabinet and parliament tackle land issue new era windhoek , june 19, 2015, 683 words katima gives 1 000 plots to landless youths new era windhoek , july 07, 2015, 416 words;
notes: urban and rural development minister sophia shaningwa said the land unrest in katima mulilo which degenerated into physical violence on monday this week is too serious and warrants intervention by state house. shaningwa was responding to questions from new era on what the government s stance is on youths making threats of violence as well as employing unruly tactics in their quest for land in the far eastern town. on monday, hundreds of youths in katima mulilo illegally occupied land at macaravan east and eventually took the law into their own hands by throwing stones at town council ceo charles nawa whom they accused of failing to address their plight for residential land monday s anarchy saw close to 200 aggrieved people comprising mainly the youth storming the katima mulilo town council and stoning nawa, whom they said failed to address their plight for residential land although there was a heavy police presence, the protestors were not shaken and allegedly also started to throw stones at the police, who in return used teargas to disperse the unruly crowd.

sources: karas spends over n 7 million to replace bucket toilets new era windhoek , august 19, 2015, 411 words;
notes: the karas regional council has availed more than n 7 million to aus settlement to get rid of the apartheid bucket toilet system by building more toilets, among other developmental activities, the nami nus constituency councillor, jan scholtz, has confirmed .about 200 angry aus residents on monday staged a peaceful demonstration to the settlement office to denounce the usage of the bucket toilet system at the settlement, and they even said aus benefitted more from the colonial apartheid era regime. the residents, who bemoaned the lack of development at the settlement that is home to about 1 500 people, made it clear during the demonstration, by kicking a bucket, that they have had enough of the bucket toilet system and that the time for action is now.

sources: choi residents stage demo over water new era windhoek , october 05, 2015, 647 words;
notes: choi residents agitated over a water crisis in the area they claim has persisted since independence recently took to the streets to express their dissatisfaction. they are unhappy with the government s inaction on their plight that has persisted for 25 years. during their protest at choi, residents were unable to hand their petition to kongola constituency councillor david muluti who was caught unawares by the demonstration contacted for comment muluti the kongola councillor said he had not been informed about the peaceful march therefore he could not receive the petition. he castigated those that planned the demonstration, for side stepping him. coded as 50 since the councillor responds to this particular protest suggesting it is sizable.

sources: we want fair salaries, not pennies govt workers new era windhoek , october 15, 2015, 326 words;
notes: about 700 civil servants from the four northern regions organised what was dubbed as an illegal demonstration yesterday, demanding full implementation of the government job evaluation and regrading exercise, with effect from april 2013. the group protested in front of the gipf building here to bring attention to their demands. the protesting workers included mainly clerks, handymen and labourers from ohangwena, omusati, oshana and oshikoto regions. the protesters also demanded that government consider a 12 percent increment, as opposed to the 6 percent which was announced recently. the group is further demanding that bush allowances be paid as agreed in november 2012. we want an increment on housing and transport allowance and it must be paid from april not september, the workers said.

sources: struggle kids sabotage swapo campaign launch new era windhoek , october 19, 2015, 306 words;
notes: in an unprecedented move the group of close to 100 struggle kids which is camping near the swapo head office staged a brief demonstration to demand jobs before president hage geingob could even take his seat after he officially launched the swapo election campaign in windhoek on saturday. in what seemed to be a calculated move to steal the limelight from the head of state, the group embarked on a brief but peaceful demonstration marching from the stadium to the gate before they returned to their seats to continue listening to the leaders the president, who watched the group silently and his along with his entourage, after the completion of the programme took the opportunity to address them, but was not pleased by their actions.

sources: nunw calls for calm at the coast new era windhoek , october 30, 2015, 401 words;
notes: nampa on monday reported that close to 900 fishermen from various fishing companies in walvis bay downed tools, demanding better salaries and medical care at sea, amongst other demands. according to the news agency, the workers held a peaceful demonstration led by the namibia national labour organisation nanlo on the same day and marched to the offices of different stakeholders, including the labour ministry and union offices they demand regular working hours and that overtime work be paid according to the labour law. the ministry and the unions were expected to respond within 48 hours or the fishermen would not go back to work, they threatened.

location: Namibia University of Science and Technology
sources: registration fee reprieve only temporary the namibian windhoek , january 21, 2016, 330 words nust fees fall analysis the namibian windhoek , january 22, 2016, 844 words, ndanki kahiurika;
notes: protesting at the namibia university of science and technology nust has cooled down after vice chancellor tjama tjivikua agreed to sit down with the student leadership and agreed a list of measures so students and staff could be allowed back on campus after today s demonstration. so far the university has agreed with the demonstrators that students will not pay any registration fees indefinitely and that currents debts owed to the school by students will be written off. hundreds of students from the university of namibia, international university of management and the college of the arts joined their namibia university of science and technology counterparts yesterday morning to demand that the fees should be reduced.

sources: kavangos least prepared to take charge diescho the namibian windhoek , february 29, 2016, 410 words;
notes: the lecture comes a week after residents of the two kavango regions staged a peaceful demonstration demanding that government devises strategies to alleviate poverty and reverse the wrongs done to people from the kavango east and kavango west regions. they accused government of having committed a monumental injustice through its unwritten policy of excluding and marginalising the people of the two regions.

sources: ecn wants transparency on political party funds the namibian windhoek , march 02, 2016, 419 words, chamwe kaira;
notes: referring to a demonstration last week by three political parties who petitioned that parties outside parliament should also receive funding, katjavivi said the law was clear that only parties in parliament get funded.

sources: prisoners riot over tobacco ban the namibian windhoek , april 01, 2016, 347 words, tuyeimo haidula;
notes: angry inmates at the windhoek central correctional facility rioted over the banning of tobacco at the facility on tuesday. although deputy commissioner for correctional services eveline january confirmed the riot yesterday, she said it was a minor incident. commissioner ismael kamati, who is responsible for security at correctional services, yesterday said the inmates were unhappy with the ban on smoking in public places, which was implemented according to the tobacco products control act. a source told the namibian yesterday that prison warders assaulted several inmates accused of having started the riot with batons and plastic pipes.

sources: conservancies not happy with trophy hunting ban the namibian windhoek , april 19, 2016, 335 words;
notes: the krcca held a peaceful demonstration at opuwo on friday, during which they handed a petition over to opuwo urban constituency councillor weich mupya. the petition is to be channelled through the relevant offices of members of the european parliament, and calls for a reconsideration of the possible ban of trophy hunting products to europe.

sources: rehoboth land demonstration turns violent the namibian windhoek , may 02, 2016, 307 words;
notes: chaos erupted between community members and the namibian police force nampol during what started off as a peaceful demonstration for land at rehoboth s kuvuki land residential area on earlier today. according to some community members, they had gathered at an open area to wait for the town council s response on their land allocation needs when members of nampol arrived. five people were arrested. they started firing rubber bullets at us for no reason as we did not intend to use violence. people were injured, they claimed.

sources: windhoek to erect speed humps for matshitshi street the namibian windhoek , may 09, 2016, 216 words, ndanki kahiurika;
notes: a windhoek councillor has promised to erect speed humps in goreangab dam s matshitshi street after an elderly woman was hit and killed by a car on thursday night. paulus immanuel, who visited the area on friday following a demonstration, told the community about the plans to erect speed humps. the demonstrators burned tyres and blocked the road with stones, bricks and sticks. these objects were later removed by the city of windhoek s workers. some community members said there have been three deaths due to accidents along the same street. sometimes, they also said, people race along the street.

sources: opuwo residents demand answers the namibian windhoek , june 14, 2016, 440 words, shinovene immanuel;
notes: not only are they unhappy that the town is very dirty. residents are not impressed with the fact that eight key positions at the town council are still vacant. we, therefore, would like to peacefully ask council not to renew the contract of the chief executive officer, the group said. the namibia press agency reported that over 500 protesters turned up at the demonstration, and quoted the town s mayor albert tjiuma as saying he will provide feedback to the protesters after the council meets.

sources: pupils demonstrate against release of murder suspect the namibian windhoek , june 21, 2016, 439 words, marx itamalo;
notes: the community of oshiyashemanya in the oshikoto region, including pupils and teachers at the okakondo primary school last week held a peaceful demonstration against the granting of bail to a suspect who allegedly raped and killed a girl at the village last year.

sources: youth have spoken the namibian windhoek , june 17, 2016, 602 words, tileni mongudhi;
notes: national assembly speaker peter katjavivi yesterday reluctantly obliged after earlier trying to renege on government s promise that he will accept a petition against the construction of a new n 2 billion parliament building. people from all walks of life formed part of the march: from unemployed youth to the lawyer in a business suit to pupils in school uniforms, engineers in their safety boots and business people who took the day off to protest. some, especially those employed by government and public enterprises, sacrificed their lunch hour to pitch up in solidarity with fellow youth. many of those carrying placards made their message clear: they want the n 2,4 billion earmarked for the construction of parliament to be pumped into education, healthcare, the provision of water, electricity and fighting poverty. although the turn up did not reach the 10 000 mark the organisers had hoped for, ar s nauyoma said the petition had over 3 500 signatures.

sources: struggle kids disrupt traffic the namibian windhoek , june 20, 2016, 430 words, theresia tjihenuna;
notes: traffic on the western bypass ground to a halt on friday after about 600 struggle kids blocked the road to the katutura intermediate hospital while attempting to march on parliament to see prime minister saara kuugongelwa amadhila. pm agreed to meet with representatives of the group. in protest of alleged unfair treatment they have been receiving from the swapo leadership in windhoek and to seek answers on their demands for employment.

sources: tribalism dominates agenda 2017 the namibian windhoek , june 20, 2016, 1680 words, tileni mongudhi;
notes: omaheke governor festus ueitele was the subject of a protest march on thursday at gobabis. the protestors wanted ueitele removed as governor because of a recording of him that went viral on social media. the governor was recorded claiming that president hage geingob alerted him of a herero conspiracy in the omaheke region to unseat the head of state and prevent him from taking over as swapo s substantive president at next year s elective congress. geingob was allegedly informed by the secret service about the conspiracy.

sources: police fire at struggle kids the namibian windhoek , august 17, 2016, 297 words, garwin beukes;
notes: police yesterday fired rubber bullets at violent struggle kids who were attacking them with stones and other missiles at the swapo headquarters in windhoek. this latest incident was triggered by an eviction order served on the struggle kids by swapo s legal representatives conradie and damaseb which said they should leave the farm by today. earlier this year, the struggle kids who are staying at the farm near the mix informal settlement were given an opportunity to relocate to berg aukas or du plessis farm, where they would be taught skills.

sources: residents threaten to dump human waste in council offices the namibian windhoek , september 07, 2016, 483 words;
notes: about 100 rehoboth residents took to the streets yesterday morning to protest alleged poor service delivery and corruption by the rehoboth town council rtc . the protest was organised by the dta of namibia under the leadership of lukas de klerk from the party s rehoboth branch. speaking during the handing over of the petition to rehoboth mayor christina blaauw, de klerk said basic services such as water is a human right.

sources: suspended kalkrand ceo hits back the namibian windhoek , september 22, 2016, 419 words, luqman cloete;
notes: suspended kalkrand village council chief executive officer seth boois claims that evidence of alleged misconduct levelled against him was planted. according to him, this unholy alliance conspired to sent a letter to the office of the minister through village council chairperson hendrik nu ganab, accusing him boois of having committed fraud and corruption without giving him the right to present his case. shortly after the accusations surfaced, boois added, local community activist james hansen organised a protest march and accused him of fraud and corruption.

sources: just pay up, minister tells students the namibian windhoek , october 19, 2016, 530 words, ndanki kahiurika and ndapewoshali shapwanale;
notes: university of namibia students must pay their fees if they want quality, higher education minister itah kandjii murangi said yesterday. it has become a habit for students not to pay. they wait until the last two weeks, and hope that we will allow them to write the exams. but the institution can only render quality education if they pay, kandjii murangi told the namibian, while confirming that she had been talking to the unam management about the debts. the unam management, on its part, has been talking to the student leadership. this led to a demonstration since monday, and the postponement of exams for two days.

sources: keetmans residents protest against selco the namibian windhoek , november 14, 2016, 277 words, luqman cloete;
notes: keetmanshoop residents on friday took to the streets to protest against the intended extension of an electricity management contract between the local council and southern electricity company selco . in a petition handed over to mayor gaudentia kr hne, residents carrying placards stating selcomustfall ordered the chairperson of the council s management committee gabriel freyer not to ink any agreement with selco over increasing electricity tariffs. the protestors demanded that the council sought the intervention of the electricity control board ecb as well as the urban and rural development, and the mines and energy ministries.

sources: discriminatory remarks backfire on governor the namibian windhoek , november 14, 2016, 481 words, luqman cloete;
notes: the aroab community yesterday took to the streets to protest over what they called discriminatory remarks by basson, calling for her immediate removal as karas governor, and that she be replaced by former governor bernadus swartbooi, who is now a deputy minister. the community reasoned that they are being disqualified from applying for resettlement on the basis of basson s discriminatory remarks which imply that they are not namibians. they accused her of violating article 10 of the constitution and their human rights by referring to them as south africans.

sources: omaruru residents demonstrate again the namibian windhoek , november 28, 2016, 301 words;
notes: residents of omaruru staged another demonstration on thursday to pressurise the municipality into responding to a petition they handed over last month. some of the issues they are unhappy about include the sale of 75 erven to windhoek developers ndakalimwe investments; an alleged lack of transparency around the shortage of water; and unfair allocations of land for low income housing. the omaruru municipality in april this year introduced water restrictions as a precautionary measure in response to the drought being experienced countrywide. the around 200 residents who demonstrated on thursday said they have not yet received a response from the council after handing over a petition to deputy mayor julia kahuure on 23 october.

sources: president was not bold enough, swartbooi says the namibian windhoek , december 16, 2016, 402 words, ndapewoshali shapwanale;
notes: former lands deputy minister bernadus swartbooi yesterday said the president should have been bold enough to remove him from office using his constitutional powers, instead of basing his decision on fiction and falsehood . one such group held a demonstration at keetmans hoop yesterday where they demanded his reinstatement by 17 january 2017. another group was expected to hold a march in windhoek this morning.

sources: ar gives oshakati 45 days to apologise the namibian windhoek , december 16, 2016, 473 words, marx itamalo;
notes: yesterday morning...before handing over the petition, they gathered at the oshakati community library from where they marched to the offices of the oshana regional council...as they stood outside kashuupulwa s office chanting down governor down ..after heated deliberations between mwinga and the land activists, the petition was handed over to mwinga. the protest by the ar youth was sparked by a leaked document with minutes of meetings of the oshakati town council. the minutes indicated how the town councillors, senior employees, their relatives and governor kashuupulwa were allegedly allocated plots at the expense of those who desperately need land.

sources: land bill submissions deadline extended the namibian windhoek , january 18, 2017, 457 words, luqman cloete;
notes: the land reform ministry has extended the deadline for submissions on the land bill until 16 february. the initial deadline for written submissions was 16 january. the extension for submissions followed calls that land reform activities, including the passing of the proposed land bill, be suspended until after a second national land conference. keetmanshoop residents also staged a protest on friday against the passing of the bill until after the completion of this second conference.

protesteridentity: community members; landless people s movement
sources: grootfontein residents threaten to close down municipality the namibian windhoek , march 01, 2017, 320 words, theresia tjihenuna;
notes: about 200 grootfontein want the council to step down or they will force it to close within 20 days. the residents, who demonstrated on monday, were led by land activists caroline engelbrecht and moritz gaingob of the landless people s movement. in another petition handed to police on the same day, the group demanded the removal of the station commander, esther mainga because she allegedly ordered the use of tear gas on the crowd that attempted to grab land.

protesteridentity: a group of people that are living with disabilities and were spearheaded by the mainstream foundation
sources: murder angers people living with disability, the namibian windhoek , may 23, 2017, 437 words, lugeretzia kooper;
notes: a group of people living with disabilities gathered for a peaceful demonstration with live chickens outside the katima mulilo magistrate s court on friday to protest during the bail hearing of two men who allegedly murdered a disabled man. the two accused, john musole 45 and immanuel mukubesa 22 , allegedly ran over francis masholo with a vehicle and then brutally murdered him, following the accident on 21 march 2017 at impalila. the demonstration was spearheaded by the mainstream foundation, which handed over a petition to public prosecutor george matali. many of the disabled demonstrators carried live chickens to symbolise that they cannot be slaughtered willy nilly like chickens. note: the actual number of protesters was not provided in the source, and is based on prior doding decisions

protesteridentity: residents of ondangwa dissatisfied over plans to build the planned new referral hospital at ongwediva instead of ondangwa
sources: change in location of hospital triggers demo, new era windhoek , may 26, 2017, 468 words, loide jason;
notes: residents of ondangwa took to the streets on wednesday to express their dissatisfaction over plans to build the planned new referral hospital at ongwediva instead of ondangwa. disgruntled residents marched from ondangwa to hand over their petition to oshana governor clemens kashuupulwa at oshakati, but his special advisor michael mwinga received the petition on behalf of the governor. in their petition, residents say the want president hage geingob to intervene as they feel the change in location of the referral hospital will leave ondangwa even further behind in terms of development. residents said that they are extremely unhappy with the decision not to build the hospital in ondangwa. media reports say the government will now construct the hospital at ongwediva, but ondangwa residents consider this unacceptable. note: the actual number of protesters is not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: residents of the lwanyanda compound in the zambezi region
sources: land grabber arrests upset zambezi residents, the namibian windhoek , august 08, 2017, 496 words, lugeretzia kooper;
notes: residents of the lwanyanda compound in the zambezi region, a settlement established by illegal land occupiers, say the arrest of seven of their members on sunday was senseless because they had done nothing wrong. the group, of about 5 000 members, said they were tired of waiting for the katima mulilo town council to provide them with plots, and resorted to occupying a piece of open land between the mafuta and choto compounds. irate members of the group gathered in front of the katima mulilo police station yesterday in protest against the arrest of the other land grabbers. zambezi regional police spokesperson, warrant officer kisco satali, confirmed the arrests of the seven lwanyanda group members after the town council opened a case regarding the illegal land grabbers. given mwiya 28 , one of the group members, said they were demanding that their group members be released without paying fines. this is the second time our members have been arrested, and it is senseless as we did nothing wrong. namibia is supposed to be a free country, now we are being arrested for wanting land, he stressed, adding that 27 years after independence, they still do not own land. note: the actual number of protesters was not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

location: Helao Nafidi town at Oshikango in the Ohangwena region
sources: helao nafidi vendors demonstrate against new open market, the namibian windhoek , september 14, 2017, 588 words, marx itamalo;
notes: hundreds of disgruntled vendors yesterday demonstrated peacefully at the helao nafidi town at oshikango in the ohangwena region. they were demanding that the town council should speed up the completion of the new open market. they also handed over a petition addressed to the town s chief executive officer, inga iipinge, who was not around yesterday. local economic development officer selma kapembe received the petition on iipinge s behalf. the vendors were demanding that council allows them to continue operating from the old okatwitwi open market while council completes the new market. they marched from the new open market at oshikango to the town council s offices at omafo.

protesteridentity: local land rights campaign group buchters united against corrupt land deals
sources: l deritz residents picket for land rights, new era windhoek , october 17, 2017, 498 words, tuulikki abraham;
notes: more than 100 residents under the banner of local land rights campaign group, buchters united against corrupt land deals, took to the streets of l deritz last week to demand affordable residential land on terms as favourable as the town council had offered to private developers. the protesters last wednesday gave l deritz town council seven working days to respond to their petition. peaceful picketing started in front of the main entrance to the harbour at around lunchtime before the group walked up bismarck street to the municipal offices, where they handed over more than 250 application letters from residents who want to purchase erven at the prices offered to the private developers. the protesters questioned why the council should enter into private treaty with four property developers, who would then service the land and sell it on to the residents. in their petition, the locals were adamant that the erven serviced or not should be sold to the residents of l deritz at the same price as offered to the four companies. in their petition, the residents argue that l deritz town council has a legal obligation in terms of the local authority act to service residential erven, or to put out a call for expressions of interest for the servicing of such erven.

protesteridentity: university of namibia unam khomasdal campus student teachers
sources: student teachers march for jobs, new era windhoek , october 18, 2017, 531 words, albertina nakale;
notes: more than 150 university of namibia unam khomasdal campus student teachers protest marched in windhoek yesterday to demand that the ministry of education, arts and culture releases the bulletin of teacher vacancies for 2018. delaying such announcement would send them on the streets, they argued, which would boost namibia s unemployment figure of 34 percent. the aggrieved students marched in protest despite education minister katrina hanse himarwa saying last week that the regions have submitted their staff vacancies, and that the ministry would release the bulletin not later than the end of the month. the students, led by teachers union of namibia tun secretary general mahongora kavihuha, said they have taken notice of the commitment by hanse himarwa that the bulletin would be released by the end of october. however, they threatened to take unspecified action if their demands are not met by november 17.the vacancy bulletin is normally released around july every year to allow sufficient time for a seamless recruitment process.

location: Office of the Zambezi Regional Governor Lawrence Sampofu
protesteridentity: land grabbers whose houses were demolished by the katima mulilo town council
sources: landless residents petition government in katima, new era windhoek , october 30, 2017, 543 words, katima mulilo;
notes: land grabbers whose houses were demolished by the katima mulilo town council at the beginning of this month, precipitating a firestorm of criticism, on friday marched to the office of the zambezi regional governor lawrence sampofu where they handed over a petition with their grievances. the group was led by the leader of the official opposition party dta, mchenry venaani, and former ceo of katima mulilo town council charles nawa, who read out the petition. in the petition the group demanded the resignation of the current katima mulilo ceo raphael liswaniso and the entire council management for demolishing their homes without a court order . they also demanded the resignation of the police regional commander commissioner karel theron for helping the town council demolish their homes without a court order. this is a free namibia and we know our rights, meaning the namibian police took the law into their own hands. we don t know why they were shooting on us. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

protesteridentity: a group representing open market vendors, long distance bus operators and used car dealers
sources: oshakati vendors and bus operators protest again, the namibian windhoek , november 29, 2017, 452 words, placido hilukilwa; oshakati dismisses open market demonstrators claims, new era windhoek , december 01, 2017, 338 words, nuusita ashipala;
notes: a group representing open market vendors, long distance bus operators and used car dealers held a peaceful demonstration at oshakati yesterday and handed over a petition containing a litany of complaints and demands to the town council. the council was given until 8 december to give a favourable feedback or face yet another noisy, and possibly bigger, demonstration. in their petition, read on their behalf by martha lukolo, the demonstrators demanded the construction of a road linking the new open market to the main street at the old open market. they are also demanding sign boards along the road indicating where the new open market is as well as the slashing of rent charges. they said open market tenants currently pay between n 65 and n 1 200 per month depending on the category of business and the size of the stall. long distance bus operators are demanding to know the purpose of the departure fees paid by every bus which leaves the terminal at the open market. what is the money used for? they asked. because of a feud in the transport industry, some bus operators are not allowed to use the bus terminal at the open market. they are now demanding that the town council gives them a separate terminal. n their part, used car dealers are demanding to be allowed to trade along the main road just like established vehicle dealerships. street vendors want the town council to allow them to conduct business on the streets as they have always done instead of continuously harassing people who are merely trying to make ends meet . the demonstrators said they are willing to cooperate with the council on condition council officials hold open meetings with vendors instead of cornering them one by one or threatening them. oshakati town council has refuted claims levelled against it by angry demonstrators from the oshakati open market, who protested this week against high rentals, dismissing the claims as devoid of any truth. about 30 vendors from the open market on tuesday staged a peaceful demonstration demanding reduced rent. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions as well as the number of vendors involved in the demonstration

sources: gibeon youth protest against jobs for struggle kids , the namibian windhoek , february 02, 2018, 333 words, luqman cloete;
notes: frustrated youth of gibeon in the karas region yesterday staged a peaceful demonstration over what they claimed was the unfair employment of struggle kids at a time when there is high unemployment at the village. the youth delivered a petition to gibeon constituency councillor jeremia van neel, in which they claim they were overlooked for appointment to menial jobs. this is the second time the youth have taken to the streets to express anger over appointments at the village. the demonstrators argued that the practice of employing struggle kids ahead of locals will not be and cannot be understood and accepted without referring to it as a tribal and discriminatory move against the unemployed locals . note: the actual number of protesters what not provided in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: lesotho politics: peace rally appeals to the army to end mutiny ips inter press service, january 26, 1994, wednesday, 481 words, by philip neko ;
notes: thousands of demonstrators today appealed to the two warring factions of the lesotho army to lay down their arms and resolve their dispute through negotiations. the demonstrators, led by lesotho non governmental organizations, presented a petition to prime minister ntsu mokhehle, urging him to resolve the conflict immediately. copies of the petition were also sent to the ministries of justice and human rights, home affairs, the commander of the armed forces, as well as to the principal secretary of the ministry of information and broadcasting in maseru.

sources: lesotho troops kill four after king leads coup the times, august 18, 1994, thursday, overseas news, 505 words, by michael hamlyn ;
notes: the king s coup comes two days after a 10,000 strong demonstration by supporters of the opposition basuto national party which demanded that king letsie hand back power to his father. he met the crowd and agreed.

sources: lesotho troops fire on protesters against king the new york times, august 18, 1994, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 13; column 1; foreign desk , 414 words, ap lesotho plunges into crisis after royal coup rejected agence france presse english, 1520 words ;
notes: a power struggle pitting the king of lesotho against the elected government turned deadly today when troops fired on thousands of protesters marching on the royal palace. four people were reported killed and at least 10 wounded in the clash in maseru, capital of the mountain kingdom surrounded by south africa. the crowd was protesting the monarchy s move to abolish lesotho s first democratically elected government in 23 years, and some people began throwing stones, the south africa press association said. the police and soldiers answered with gunfire, and the crowd fled, leaving shoes and clothes strewn over the main thoroughfare. angry protestors apparently stoned the security forces, who then retaliated by firing teargas and live rounds.

sources: situation in lesotho remains tense xinhua news agency, august 19, 1994, friday, 143 words troops on alert after anti monarchy protests agence france presse english, 747 words, bryan pearson ;
notes: a man was killed and another seriously injured in lesotho today when police opened fire on supporters of the basotholand congress party bcp , according to the south african press association. a lesotho police spokesman said that the police tried to disperse a crowd of about 500 people who have illegally gathered at the pitso ground, 200 kilometers south of the mountain kingdom s capital maseru. the crowd decided to burn down businesses belonging to newly appointed lesotho foreign affairs minister evaristus sekhonyana, the police said, adding that stones were thrown at the policemen. when a shot was fired from the crowd, the police returned fire and arrested three protesters, the spokesman said. the meeting was held to protest against an announcement by lesotho king letsie iii to disolve the bcp government and parliament earlier this week. one person was killed late friday when police opened fire on anti monarchy protestors in the southern town of quthing, adding to the four killed in the capital when demonstrators massed outside the royal palace.

sources: lesotho police open fire at protesting taxi owners xinhua news agency, november 7, 1994, monday, 194 words ;
notes: lesotho police today opened fire on a large crowd of protesting taxi owners in the southern lesotho town of mafeteng, the south african press association quoted lesotho radio as saying. the taxi owners, who serve the country s 3,000 districts, were protesting against the presence of the south african police in an anti car theft drive being undertaken with the lesotho police. the lesotho taxi owners stopped their services today to demonstrate against the undermining of the integrity of lesotho police by south african traffic police. the lesotho radio report said a combined force of police and army units threw teargas at the crowd and as the people fled they opened fire without any sign of provocation or warning. the taxi owners earlier blocked all roads leading into mafeteng and police towed their vehicles away. saying that the taxi owners serve 3000 districts and the crowd was considered large ? implies a crowd of at least 100 people.

sources: lesotho public servants demonstrate agence france presse english, 187 words ;
notes: around 5,000 demonstrators took to the streets of this lesotho capital thursday to protest laws aimed at preventing public servants from becoming trade union members, the south african news agency sapa said. the protestors marched on prime minister ntsu mokhehle s offices and handed him a petition, the report said. they also presented petitions against the public service bill to the president of the senate and the speaker of the national assembly, urging the two houses of the lesotho parliament not to enact the bill. the petition said the bill contravened a section of lesotho s constitution on freedom of association, freedom from discrimination, equality and justice, and the protection of workers rights.

protesteridentity: basotho national party and tribal chiefs
sources: lesotho pm dismisses claims that govt toppled agence france presse english, 587 words lesotho politics: three held after coup attempt ips inter press service, february 29, 1996, thursday, 583 words, by violet maraisane ;
notes: the radio broadcast followed a rally at a stadium here in the morning by the opposition basotho national party bnp and tribal chiefs, after which a large crowd of opposition supporters marched on parliament. motete could not say if the false broadcast was linked to the protest. large crowd implies at least 50 people, especially considering the bnp as a main opposition party. the incident occurred as members of the opposition basotho national party bnp were holding an anti government demonstration, although both the bnp and the gunmen denied that the two events were related. in fact, the bnp criticized the coup, stating that it was against any attempt to seize power and that it believed in elections.

sources: associated press international, september 24, 1996; tuesday, international news, 973 words, the associated press;
notes: more than 1,000 students of the national university of lesotho danced in maseru s streets tuesday to protest the killings of five workers of the lesotho highlands water project last week. a delegation led by student union president pitso pitso handed a petition against the killings to the offices of the prime minister, the speaker of the national assembly and the ministers of home affairs and natural resources. according to the south african press association, the petition urged the government to prosecute those responsible for the deaths and compensate families of the victims. in the clash last week in lesotho s northern mountains, police reportedly opened fire on the workers, who had been fired but refused to leave the project.

sources: lesotho; down ntsu mokhehle, down united parties africa news, june 17, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 1014 words, khutliso sekoati, mopheme the survivor maseru roundup: lesotho government faces confidence crisis xinhua news agency, june 16, 1997, monday, 556 words, by zhao yi ;
notes: the city of maseru was virtually brought to a halt when a banging chant that furiously sought to unseat prime minister mokhehle from the united parties supporters engulfed them in a mass action to the palace yesterday. led by the disappointed bcp, marematlou freedom party, the basotho national party, lesotho labour party and the lesotho education party, the mass demonstration unanimously chanted in demand for the 78 year old prime minister to step down it was remniscent of a burial ceremony when mokhehle s huge black, green and red portrait was dragged on muddy ground, mocked and then hurled with stones by the bcp supporters donning party colour garments. the two paged document handed to the king said: because of his failure to fulfil the manadte that he was given by the people as contained in the manifesto, dr ntsu mokhehle is duty bound to resign from the basutoland congress party and in view of the powers masked in your majesty as the executive authority of lesotho in terms of the electoral order, we implore your majesty to call upon dr ntsu mokhehle to resign as prime minister. several thousand supporters of lesotho political parties, waving the multiple colors of party flags, today participated in a demonstration against the mokhehle government, informed sources reaching here said.

sources: youth leaders of lesotho protest new government government agence france presse english english ;
notes: youthful lesotho opposition political leaders on thursday held a street protest calling for the resignation of prime minister ntsu mokhehle, who shocked observers by forming a new governing party last week. opposition youth leaders in this tiny southern african country marched through the streets of the capital, and petitioned king letsie iii to order the resignation of mokhehle, the sapa news agency reported. the group called on the king to return the reins of government led by mokhehle s newly formed lesotho congress for democracy lcd to the rightful people, sapa said. given how many people were involved in the protests two days before, i m assuming this protest to have had at least 50 participants.

sources: lesotho oppositions launch protest march in capital xinhua news agency, july 2, 1997, wednesday, 240 words ;
notes: the leaders of five lesotho opposition parties today defied a government ban on protest marches to the royal palace in maseru, capital of the kingdom, when they led hundreds of supporters to the office of king letsie iii, reported the south african press association. the protest, organised by the basotho national party and supported by other leading opposition groups, was the latest in a series of demonstrations against the government of prime minister ntsu mokhehle, said the report. the protesters presented a petition to the king s private secretary mabote lerothodi, who promised to pass it on to the head of state. the petition said mokhehle s establishment of the lesotho congress for democracy lcd and his installation of the lcd as the new governing party were unconstitutional. in the petition, the oppositions once again called on the king to dissolve mokhehle s administration and appoint an interim government to ensure the democratic rule in the small land locked kingdom surrounded by south africa.

sources: lesotho; mfp calls for return of bcp rule africa news, july 30, 1997, news, documents & commentary, 574 words, grace kobeli, mopheme the survivor maseru ;
notes: the marematlou freedom party mfp under the leadership of vincent malebo stageda march protest that petitioned king letsie iii as part of the campaign to lure the monarch to restore the government by the basutolnd congres party bcp . pheko khoeli of the mfp said prime minister ntsu mokhehle has captured bcp government. the peaceful march petitioned the king to urge mokhehle to step down and bring back the bcp government. one placard read: mokhehle bring back our government, we don t need you any more . some say they need mokhehle to be charged with treason. it futher said they had appeared before the king on the 16th, 19th june and 2nd july now they appear for the thorth time with the same appeal. it says they have taken this congnisance of the fact that up to now, they have not been fortunate enough to receive an answer from the council of the state. given that this is a continuation of very popular protests throughout the previous months, i assume this one to have at least 50 people.

sources: lesotho; lesotho news roundup africa news, march 19, 1998, news, documents & commentary, 2483 words, i afrika news network copenhagen ;
notes: during a demonstration in maseru on 7 march, to celebrate the day, women waved placards calling for tough sentences for rapists and child abusers. some of the boldly written placards called for the castration of the culprits. most placards said there should be no bail for rapists. ms matseliso mapetla, a lecturer at the national university of lesotho, said rape has reached unprecedented proportions in lesotho and most cases lapse in the hands of the police with dockets disappearing and the cases never making it as far as the courts. she blamed the police for asking embarrassing questions of rape and sexual abuse victims to the extent of wrecking the cases as women prefer to abandon the matter rather than be subjected to embarrassing questions. more than 500 women took part in the celebration of the day.

notes: thousands of opposition supporters streamed through this capital to protest election results that gave 52 of the 80 parliamentary races with final vote counts to the ruling party. the incidence which almost caused a confusion in maseru was however brought under control by the police who were already armed. the police kept a close eye at the protesters while appealing to them with a loud speaker saying their march was not permitted and the blocking of traffic was illegal. the two parties supporters took to the streets saying the election outcome was not true, and was rigged.

notes: prime minister mosisili will make a statement in parliament at 2:30p.m. today in maseru. the statement, according to his office is made following the protest that lasted the whole night since yesterday. protesting opposition parties supporters who spent a night blocking the palace gate have threatened to take serious steps if the king does not respond by the end of today. members of the army and police were called in to put the situation under control but could not manage to push the protestors away from the parliament gates. now about a dozen of armed soldiers and police with riot gear and water tanks are on guard at the place. yesterday morning about 1 000 lcd supporters engaged the protesters in several skirmishes that resulted in the death of one person and injuries to others. the fracas started when workers were on their way to work despite a call for a stayaway by the opposition parties. government supporters moved in to dissuade the protesters from stopping workers from going to work. they were met by opposition supporters with guns, wielding sticks and throwing stones. one man was beaten to death by the angry mob of opposition supporters. the tiny southern african state of lesotho remained tense last night as an international team of experts arrived to examine demands from protesters that the country s king, letsie iii, should order a new general election because the previous one was rigged. after a 10 day protest vigil by thousands of people at the royal palace ended with a shoot out on thursday in which nine people were injured, the streets of the capital, maseru, were calm yesterday, though shops remained closed and food was reportedly scarce. hundreds of demonstrators have held a round the clock protest at the king s palace for the last six weeks to demand that the government step down and that new elections be held. at least five people have been killed in the protests. a police officer was shot and killed in a gun battle between soldiers guarding the palace and policemen who had fired on demonstrators. south africa s first military adventure beyond its borders since nelson mandela came to power led to blood being spilt on the streets of maseru, lesotho s capital, yesterday as several south african soldiers were killed during a mission to restore order . smoke engulfed the city centre as opposition supporters set fire to government buildings in protest at the arrival of the south african troops. at week s end, a measure of calm had been returned to lesotho s capital, maseru, and the fighting in the nearby hills appeared over. only on thursday, with help from 200 botswanan troops, was some order restored in maseru. by then little was left standing.
