sources: lesotho: unions demonstrate to save agoa premium official news, december 1, 2016 thursday, 556 words;
notes: industriall global union affiliate the independent democratic union of lesotho idul joined civil society organizations in a demonstration in the capital, maseru, on sunday 27 november 2016 to demand a return to the rule of law. about 20,000 people from idul, the lesotho council of ngos, and the lentsoe la sechaba social movement took part. the demonstrators called on the government of the small southern african nation to restore democracy and the rule of law after a coup in 2014. the political instability threatens lesotho s duty free access to markets in the united states through the african growth and opportunity act agoa , which is vital for jobs.

protesteridentity: farmers protesting against regulations forcing them to sell their wool and mohair to a chinese broker
sources: lesotho farmers protest against chinese wool deal, agence france presse english, june 28, 2019 friday 11:54 am gmt, 288 words, maseru, lesotho, june 28 2019
notes: several thousand farmers in the mountain kingdom of lesotho marched to parliament on friday to protest against regulations forcing them to sell their wool and mohair to a chinese broker. wool and mohair are key exports for farmers in lesotho, but the government of the small southern africa nation signed a monopoly deal last year with a chinese broker who is accused of failing to pay for goods. the protest won the support of some members of prime minister thomas thabane s all basotho convention party, most opposition parties and prince seeiso bereng seeiso, the king s brother. about 30,000 farmers in lesotho, which is entirely surrounded by south africa, rely on wool and mohair exports. we will not sell our wool and mohair to the chinese, we would rather burn it, mokoenihi thinyane, chairman of the national wool and mohair growers association, told protesters in the capital maseru. the day before the march, the government suspended the monopoly deal for three months to allow farmers to sell globally. spokesman for the opposition parties selibe mochoboroane said we will fight this war by legal means and if we don t win, we will resort to other means.

sources: workers demonstration for higher wages in botswana xinhua general news service, march 22, 1991, friday, 149 words ;
notes: about 55,000 industrial workers across botswana embarked on peaceful demonstrations this week for higher wages. according to the guardian newspaper of botswana today, the national manual workers union, which organized the protest, said it resorted todemonstrations after its hopes of negotiated salary increment faded away when its talks with the minister for presidential affairs and public administration mompati merafhe came to a stalmate on march 12 this year.

sources: botswana students protest against mass sacking of 18,000 workers agence france presse english, 122 words ;
notes: botswana university students stopped cars here friday to protest against the mass firing of at least 18,000 striking manual workers by the government. students boycotted classes friday and decided on the lunchtime action to press demands that the workers be reinstated in government departments and parastatals. the government has not budged on the demands and reports indicated certain workers would be re hired if they accepted the low wage. given how massive the firing was and how the students were able to stop traffic in the capital, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: students riot in capital over teen ager s ritual murder associated press worldstream, february 16, 1995; thursday, international news, 481 words botswanan capital remains tense after student riots agence france presse english, 414 words editors: associated press worldstream, february 18, 1995; saturday, international news, 673 words botswanan president calls for stability in capital xinhua news agency, february 19, 1995, sunday, 281 words ;
notes: rampaging students outraged over the suspected ritual murder of a teen age girl clashed with riot police thursday in gabarone. at least two people were injured. police fired rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse the students as they tried to enter the national assembly to protest what they see as inefficiency in investigating the girl s murder. the students, estimated by journalists to number about 1,000 from the capital s university and high schools, retaliated by stoning government vehicles parked on the assembly grounds. club wielding riot police chased them through the downtown, beating students and bystanders. the students smashed bank and shop windows. most merchants closed to prevent looting. the rioting continued in the capital friday when stone throwing crowds blocked motorists from gaborone s central business district. police fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse protesters. police spokesman edwin batshu said 300 people were arrested overnight thursday in an attempt to prevent further violence in the capital, the south african press association reported. botswanan president ketumile masire today called for calm in the capital gaborone after three days of riots left at least one youth dead and two policemen seriously wounded. according to the south african press association tonight, a 24 year old teacher was also in a critical condition in hospital after she was stabbed during the riots. more than 60 people have been arrested and the university of botswana has been closed indefinitely following student demonstrations.

sources: botswana deploys military police in violence wracked village agence france presse english, 254 words students riot in capital over teen ager s ritual murder associated press worldstream, february 16, 1995; thursday, international news, 481 words ;
notes: at least three people were injured after botswana deployed paramilitary police in a village near here wednesday to quell riots sparked by the ritual killing of a teenage girl, south africa s sapa news agency said. the police special support group ssg was sent to mochudi village, 40 kilometres 24 miles from the capital gaborone, after schoolchildren attacked a restaurant belonging to a man they believe mutilated and killed their classmate, segametsi mogomotsi, on november 6 last year. last month mogomotsi s friends went on the rampage to avenge her death and to protest perceived police inefficiency in apprehending the killer. it was unclear if any demonstrators in gaborone were hurt, but at least one student was hospitalized in a similar protest in nearby mochudi after reportedly being struck by 14 rubber bullets. given the destruction that the students caused, as well as the presence of the paramilitary police, this protest is believed to have at least 50 participants.

sources: botswana: journalists protest proposed media bill ips inter press service, july 16, 1997, wednesday, 705 words, by lekopanye mooketsi ;
notes: press freedom is under attack in botswana and a bill scheduled to be introduced in the current session of parliament has unleashed a wave of protest by journalists. so strong have been the protests that the minister of presidential affairs and public administration, ponatshego kedikilwe, has agreed to delay the controversial mass media communications bill and hold more discussions. the bill comes at a time when private radio and television stations are waiting for licenses to operate. observers say that the bill will stifle the operations of the private stations. the country s only radio station and only daily newspaper are both owned by the government. there is no television channel. given the strength of the protest being enough to force accommodation , this protest is assumed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: botswana; students urge president against increasing mps pay africa news, april 15, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 284 words, wene owino, panafrican news agency ;
notes: demonstrating university of botswana students friday gave president festus mogae 14 days to reject a controversial parliamentary motion urging the government to increase salaries of lawmakers, cabinet ministers, councillors and traditional leaders. the students, who marched from the university through the capital gaborone, said they would mobilise the nation to mass action if mogae did not heed their demands. given that the students believed they could mobilize mass national action, this protest is believed to have at least 50 participants. the students braved a chilly morning to stage a peaceful protest to present their petition to parliament and the president s office. they demanded, among other things, that mogae should not endorse the motion and should recall parliament as a matter of national urgency to reverse the issue. chanting slogans and waving green twigs and posters, the students condemned the mps and called them names, with ngwaketse west legislator michael tshipinare, who moved the motion, bitterly villified. the students further called on a cabinet minister, margaret nasha, whose constituency covers the university, to dissociate herself from the motion.

sources: botswana; police surround university as students riot africa news, october 20, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 210 words, panafrican news agency botswana; students sue police over demo africa news, october 27, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 434 words, lorato maleke staff writer, mmegi the reporter gaborone ;
notes: police threw a security cordon around the university of botswana friday as students rioted to protest against the management style of its vice chancellor, prof. sharon siverts. the students also called for better learning conditions and demanded an increase in their study allowances and the improvement of their diet. the students have made an impassioned plea to university council chairman justice elijah legwaila to intervene and bring what they call siverts uncontrolled spending to a stop. the university of botswana s student representative council src has decided to sue the police for refusing to issue it with a permit to hold a demonstration and subsequently, for injuring 17 of its members. according to the src president, james mathokgwane, the students feel that the police, who fired teargas and rubber bullets last friday to disperse them, have violated their rights. the student leader said that what the police did on friday is unconstitutional because it limits the people s rights. when asked why there were a lot of police officers to quell the demonstration, mbulawa said they had to leave their duties and control the students who were behaving violently. given how the police responded and the amount of people who were injured, this protest is believed to have at least 100 people.

sources: botswana; strike deals blow to botswana s stable image africa news, december 4, 2002 wednesday, 855 words, business day ;
notes: in one of the largest demonstrations ever seen in the capital, thousands of workers poured onto the streets of gaborone on november 21 to back bulgsa. the march also served as a vehicle for trade unionists to vent pent up frustrations over labour laws. while the strike had been suspended, signs were that trade unions were not content to put up with the status quo. it is time that trade unions in this country should take a stand and be fully involved in the salary negotiations, said manual workers union organising secretary johnson motshwarakgole .

sources: botswana; fsss petition khama over stalled project africa news, september 12, 2003 friday, 427 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: parents, teachers and students took to the streets on monday to protest the stalled construction and refurbishment of francistown senior secondary school fsss buildings. the placard wielding demonstrators petitioned vice president, ian khama, to look into the matter. the petition was received by francistown district commissioner sylvia muzila on behalf of the v p. the petitioners are worried that three years following the abandonment of the fsss project, there is still no sign that construction and refurbishment will resume. the demonstrators felt that khama s intervention is required since the officials have failed to make sure the project is re started. the shortage of facilities at fsss is said to have severely affected learning at the institution. some classes are reportedly being held at the library and the dining hall because of the shortage, which was meant to be solved by the stalled construction and refurbishment. the dining hall was built 25 years ago to cater for only 400 students. the current student population at fss is well over 1000. after receiving the petition, muzila said she will forward it to the office of the vp. given the population of the school and the fact that teachers, parents and students all came together to protest, this demonstration is believed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: botswana; tonota college students riot over allowances africa news, january 15, 2004 thursday, 429 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: second year students at tonota college of education tce caused a disturbance at the institution yesterday over delayed allowances. deputy principal, gabasotlwe gobotswang told mmegi that the students wanted to be paid immediately with third years who were going for practicals in the field. according to gobotswang, the students started assembling at the main hall and demanded to meet the college principal. the principal promised to meet them but was held up with other matters. on tuesday matters came to a head as students marched to the college library where the principal was locked in a meeting. they demanded to meet with the principal whom they embarrassed in front of her juniors. gobotswang indicated that by yesterday afternoon they were yet to assess damage caused to the college property. well, as we speak now, we are not yet certain if any property has been damaged or not, he said. the president of the student representative council src , bofitlhile lewanika, told mmegi yesterday that the college authorities have themselves to blame for not taking heed of the students demands. the current crop of second year students were promised last year that some of their unpaid allowances will be paid accordingly this year. but the college was seemingly ignoring this factor, hence the demonstrations, he asserted. because the administration kept saying it would meet the students, the response is believed to be accommodation, despite being unable to meet them due to other circumstances. also, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: botswana; street vendors demonstrate over harassment africa news, february 13, 2004 friday, 575 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: thousands of street hawkers and vendors poured into the streets of gaborone yesterday jamming traffic for close to an hour as they demonstrated against what they called a tide of terrorism at the hands of the council . they also dismissed the monday national budget as a rich man s budget. about 2000 demonstrators shutdown their operation in gaborone yesterday morning to participate in the first ever march in the history of the country by the informal sector. in a petition, which was read out to the local government minister, michael tshipinare, the angry demonstrators accused the gaborone city council and the police of harassment and confiscation of their goods, hence denying them a source of living. the association furiously attacked the government policies of neglecting their sector and urged for formulation of policies that will bring equality to the nation.

notes: stop corruption. stop stealing land. crooks should be fired. state media should belong to the people. these were some of the messages on placards carried by the botswana national front bnf supporters, marching to protest the way the ruling botswana democratic party bdp runs the affairs of the country. the protest march started at old naledi on saturday morning and ended in front of the botswana national library services bnls . the party leaders and supporters marched to the office of the president to deliver the petition before assembling in front of bnls where the petition was read out to the public. the party relayed their messages through placards and party songs, alleging acts of corruption and misuse of state media by the ruling bdp. some placards carried messages, which implied that the minister of communication, science and technology, boyce sebetela should be removed from office, together with other ministers implicated in corruption. sebetela should resign, read a placard carried by one of the bnf supporters. the hyped supporters, while awaiting the formal delivery of the petition message, talked about their displeasures with the ruling party. some of them alleged that the ruling party refused to accept their petition because it is a party of cowards. given that this party is the main opposition to the ruling party, this protest is assumed to have had at least 100 people.

sources: botswana; ub students boycott classes over delayed allowances africa news, august 31, 2004 tuesday, 390 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: university of botswana ub students boycotted classes and held a demonstration yesterday to protest the delay in paying allowances for first year students. the students were annoyed that the ub administration failed to keep its promise to remit the allowances by monday this week. by 10 o clock in the morning, crowds of angry students started banging doors, chanting and generally creating havoc at the campus. the ability of the students to create havoc and that there are multiple crowds banging on doors, etc., gives the impression of this protest having at least 100 people. ub s public affairs director, samuel moribame, released a statement expressing regret that students had chosen demonstrations over other avenues of conflict resolution. we take all concerns of the students seriously and will continue to do so. we, however, believe that most, if not all the concerns can be better tackled by engaging management in fruitful discussions in a spirit of give and take rather than boycotting classes...or forcing students out of classes, or damaging property such as happened today , the statement said. there was no explicit statement of trying to resolve this issue, and therefore this is coded as an ? ignore? response. also, ? damaging property? implies a certain level of violence on the side of the protesters.

notes: university of botswana ub students took to the streets yesterday to protest against what they term meagre off campus allowances. the students waved placards, some of which read: kgoroba mosola wa gago ke eng? kgoroba george education minister what is your usefulness? taxi drivers or students, kgoroba who is important? . they submitted a petition to the ministry of education and the ub administration. in their petition to the ministry, they want an undertaking that an adjustment of students allowances would be made by september 20. the ministry has been given seven days to make this undertaking. the students demanded that the adjustment should be done in accordance with the students representative council s src proposal which was submitted to the department of student placement and welfare last month. the director of student placement and welfare, florence stoneham who received the petition, said they would respond in due course. ub vice chancellor, bojosi otlhogile assured the students that the management would respond to their concerns accordingly. given the demonstrations two days prior and the population of the total student body, this protest is believed to have at least 100 people.

sources: 20 arrested as bushmen protest the independent london , september 27, 2005, tuesday, first edition; foreign news; pg. 27, 51 words angry bushmen face court western daily press, september 29, 2005, news; other; others; pg. 10, 118 words ;
notes: more than 20 people have been arrested in botswana s central kalahari game reserve after violence over the government s policy of relocating san bushmen. president festus mogae s office said people had tried to enter the reserve, which government officials closed, citing a disease outbreak. given that 20 people were arrested, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people. the government says the reserve is closed because of animal disease, but the bushmen believe it is a ploy to destroy their nomadic way of life. the demonstrators broke into a riot and attacked the police with an assortment of weapons, a statement from the president s office said yesterday.

sources: botswana; opposition demonstrates against school fees africa news, november 1, 2005 tuesday, 542 words, mmegi the reporter ;

sources: botswana; ub shut down africa news, march 30, 2006 thursday, 602 words, mmegi the reporter botswana; ub students beat up lecturers africa news, march 31, 2006 friday, 486 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: after eight days of class boycotts and demonstrations by students following a hike in food prices, the university of botswana ub was closed yesterday. the ub council indefinitely closed the institution at 3pm and gave the students one hour to leave. by 4.30pm, there were no students inside the main campus as ub security guards and police patrolled around. the closure came as a surprise to some students who thought peace would prevail. two lecturers at the university of botswana ub were beaten up by a mob of rioting students hours before the institution was shut down on wednesday. ub s chief security officer, robert kalasi told mmegi yesterday that the students also injured two foreigners using the university library. one student was caught with a scanner and has been taken to court. kalasi said there were violent incidents the night before ub was closed as students turned against one another. this protest, given how destructive it was and the fact that it closed the school down, is believed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: botswana; bnf youth league president slams mochudi dc africa news, june 20, 2006 tuesday, 626 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: the president of the botswana national front youth league bnfyl and gaborone mayor, nelson ramaotwana did not mince words on saturday when the planned handing of their petition to mochudi district commissioner dc failed. bnfyl marched from phaphane complex to segale primary school in commemoration of june 16 day of the african child. ramaotwana said that not only did they have to wait until friday to receive the permit for their demonstration but the dc, who is paid by taxpayers, refused to take the petition and stated that they hand it in during the week. ramaotwana said that the dc could have delegated someone else to take the petition. the petition read by ramaotwana, called on the botswana democratic party bdp government to release the segametsi mogomotsi death report to the public because millions of taxpayers money was used to hire scotland yard investigators and that batswana deserved to know the truth. he said the youth of botswana have a task to advocate for the elimination of socials ill such as ritual murders, passion killings, child labour, child sexual abuse, child trafficking, poverty, disease and cultural unity in diversity.

sources: botswana; nganunu should resign unionists africa news, october 24, 2006 tuesday, 784 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: trade unions have told the chief justice julian nganunu to quit for delivering judgements that are not favourable to workers. through bulgasa official pelotshweu baeng, the trade unionists said at a massive demonstration in selebi phikwe that nganunu has delayed the hearing of workers cases brought before the him for too long. he called on the government to take all the ownership of the mines in botswana because the current situation is what causes general managers to be insensitive to workers and behave the way they want. batswana must have a hand in the running of the mines so that management of the mines can improve, he stressed. we accordingly demand that government should act swiftly to amend labour laws and give maximum protection to workers from indiscriminate expulsion from work by some employers, the petition said. members of bulgasa, bosetu, bhttwu attended the handing over of the petition to show solidarity with bmwu. ? massive? ? demonstration has been taken to imply a presence of at least 1000 people. the district officer promised to hand over the petition to the relevant ministry.

sources: botswana; police free detained kumakwane residents africa news, december 1, 2006 friday, 385 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: police on wednesday released 45 kumakwane residents who were arrested in connection with the damage of motor vehicles on sunday evening. the residents went on rampage when a man died on the spot after he was hit by a motor vehicle. the residents blocked the kanye gaborone highway of death in protest against government s refusal to erect speed humps along the road. at least six vehicles were damaged and police had to fire shots in the air to disperse the stone throwing mob. superintendent andrew bosilong told mmegi yesterday that 18 youths, aged between 13 and 18, received two strokes and were freed while 21 others, aged between 20 and 25, refused to be punished and demanded to be charged and tried as required by the law. they will be tried on december 6 when six of them will face six counts of malicious damage to property. bosilong said police were waiting for quotations from car owners. given how many people were arrested, this protest is believed to have had at least 50 participants.

sources: botswana; govt arrogant on basarwa bnf africa news, december 4, 2006 monday, 444 words, mmegi the reporter botswana; ckgr bnf should tread carefully africa news, december 4, 2006 monday, 386 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: speaking at the beginning of the demonstration at the urban freedom square in white city, motswakgakala gaoberekwe, a mosarwa rights activist, castigated the government for its violent treatment of the relocation victims. he pointed a finger at analysts and political pundits who, he says, are always quick to blame foreign influences whenever basarwa call for their rights, stating that, basarwa are human beings who are intelligent enough to wage their own struggle. people should stop blaming foreigners for our protests. it is very patronising for people to assume that we are incapable of waging our own struggle without the input of so called foreign elements, stated gaoberekwe. the demonstration involving hundreds of people and a motorcade started at white city and travelled through the city streets to the office of president. after allegations that the botswana national front bnf is courting the notorious survival international si for funds, the party staged a demonstration on saturday that could be likened to those usually organised by the british ngo to taint the image of botswana. the bnf organised the demonstration to show support for basarwa in their fight against relocation from the central kalahari game reserve ckgr by the government.

sources: botswana; anti riot police stop ub students demo africa news, february 2, 2009 monday, 706 words, mmegi the reporter ;
notes: the students, who decided to march to the moe head offices without a police permit, were stopped in their tracks by the police at the gaborone secondary school gss grounds and driven back to the university campus. in their excitement all the students approached the amateur photographer with sticks demanding that he delete the pictures forthwith. in those few seconds the man was shoved and pushed while others tried to beat him as he sprinted into the administration block as the src president tried to intervene to no avail. when reached for comment, src president thutlwe explained that they were angered by the ministry s decision to ignore changes that the students made this year. he said since semensterisation was introduced in 2004 they have had the option of changing their meal plans and to choose whether they move off campus with each new semester.

notes: an assembly of six junior secondary schools from around molepolole turned into a battlefield after police allegedly fired rubber bullets and teargas at protesting students on friday. the students had gathered at the entrance to kgari sechele senior secondary school where the previous day they had threatened violence over the fact that they had not been taught because their teachers have joined other public service employees in the ongoing strike that is now in its third week. then all hell broke loose. gathered in a place awash with stones, the irate students picked up the only weapons available to them and retaliated. the police found the missiles too much to bear. their perspex shields offered little protection from the thousands of pellets from over 3,000 children. it sounds as though the students are angered over the government? s lack of action over the public workers? strike, and thus, it is counted.

notes: police clashed with students at swaziland university, injuring 80 of them in a melee that caused 40,000 in damage, authorities said friday. four of the students were reported in critical condition, university officials told the independent south african press association. the riot wednesday night involved student grievances over campus life, including the quality of food. fighting erupted when a group of about 400 refused to leave the kwaluseni campus peacefully, erected barricades and smashed furniture and windows, the government run south african broadcasting corp. reported.

sources: strike shuts down business across swaziland associated press worldstream, march 13, 1995; monday, international news, 342 words swazi trade unions go on national strike xinhua news agency, march 13, 1995, monday, 127 words swazi workers, students continue strike xinhua news agency, march 14, 1995, tuesday, 215 words ;
notes: the swaziland federation of trade unions called the strike to press for workers rights legislation, adding its plea for reform to demands for more political openness in this usually quiet monarchy. police fired tear gas at a crowd of protesters in mbabane, the south african press association reported. the news agency said it was the biggest stay away since nationwide strikes in 1977. hundreds of striking workers and students today went to the main street of swaziland s capital mbabane to go on the kingdom s largest ever national strike. striking workers and students in swaziland s capital of mbabane continued their protest last night and at least three workers were shot and serious wounded, a local newspaper the citizen reported today.

notes: scores of people were injured during a clash between more than 500 street vendors and police during a protest in the town centre here wednesday, witnesses said. it quoted witnesses as saying baton wielding police fired teargas and rubber bullets to disperse the manzini vendors, who were protesting against enforcement of a clampdown on unlicensed street trading. the crowd retaliated by throwing stones before police waded in with batons, beating several protestors to the ground before arresting them, sapa said.

sources: scores hurt in swaziland protests agence france presse english, 267 words ;
notes: vendors also staged protests in the capital mbabane but no injuries were immediately reported, the south african news agency sapa said. in the mbabane protest, several hundred people, mainly women who sell fruit and vegetables, marched on the council controlled market where they overturned and looted stalls of licensed vendors, sapa said. protestors complained of corruption and favouritism in the granting of vending licences by the council.

sources: pro democracy orgs. protest in swaziland united press international, january 22, 1996, monday, bc cycle, international, 185 words swaziland braces for anti royalist demonstrations agence france presse english, 520 words swazi strikers clash with police, army agence france presse english, 1080 word ;
notes: labor unions and student organizations launched peaceful demonstrations monday in swaziland, demanding the restoration of multi party democracy in the small southern african kingdom. the south african press association reported the protests appeared to enjoy widespread support, with most factories and shops in the capital mbabane closed. police and troops maintained a heavy presence in public areas and sealed roads leading into mbabane and the city of manzini to minimize disruptions. no incidents of violence were reported by early evening. the demonstrators called for indefinite action to press for an end to the absolute monarchy established in that country of 800,000 people in 1972, when all political parties were banned. protestors gathered in several parts of the capital mbabane and shopkeepers kept their blinds down for fear of trouble, swaziland police said, according to the south african news agency sapa. the violence erupted after three leaders of the swaziland federation of trade unions were arrested here monday night, the south african press association sapa reported. given the presence of the police and the fact that both the labour unions and student organizations were involved, this protest is believed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: swazi strikers clash with police, army agence france presse english, 1080 words associated press international, january 23, 1996; tuesday, international news, 479 words, tom cohen associated press international, january 23, 1996; tuesday, international news, 419 words ;
notes: striking students and workers tuesday clashed with police and troops who retaliated with rubber bullets and tear gas in manzini, 42 kilometers 26 miles east of here, opposition spokesmen said. the violence erupted after three leaders of the swaziland federation of trade unions were arrested here monday night, the south african press association sapa reported. benedict tsabedze, president of the swaziland youth congress, told sapa that six people were hospitalized, while people s united democratic movement leader kislon shongwe said the exact number of wounded could not be determined because many protesters had gone into hiding. they are seeking an end to the non party political system established with the 1972 banning of political parties in the landlocked kingdom wedged between south africa and mozambique. state run television later reported that a 16 year old girl was killed by police gunfire in unclear circumstances in manzini, the country s industrial center, when the strike began monday. soldiers and police patrolled throughout mbabane, the capital, and the industrial center of manzini, 30 miles 50 kilometers to the south, on tuesday in a show of force, according to residents reached by telephone from johannesburg. on tuesday, police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse marching strikers in mbabane and manzini, according to residents and labor leaders.

sources: associated press international, january 25, 1996; thursday, international news, 529 words, tom cohen associated press international, january 26, 1996; friday, international news, 752 words, tom cohen ;
notes: the leaders of a pro democracy strike, freed from prison and embraced by cheering supporters thursday, vowed to continue their campaign against swaziland s monarchy. the men were carried on the shoulders of the chanting, singing crowd such displays normally draw a brutal police response. they were then driven to mbabane, where several hundred more supporters danced in the streets. riot police in helmets and armed with rifles stood in the streets and fired two rounds of tear gas as a crowd of demonstrators ran toward a central mbabane square, sending people fleeing with shirts pulled over their faces. there were no injuries. later thursday, police later fired two rounds of tear gas to break up crowds that ran to a central square in mbabane after the freed labor leaders rode into town with car horns blaring.

sources: swazi police fire on striking workers agence france presse, february 11, 1997, international news, 241 words ;
notes: six people were injured when police opened fire on striking sugar workers at big bend, in swaziland s central lubombo region, the sapa news agency said tuesday. the incident, which occurred on monday, is the first reported violent confrontation between strikers and the security forces of the tiny southern african kingdom since a national strike was launched by the swaziland federation of trade unions sftu on february 3. the report said the shootings occurred when striking workers wanted to enter the premises of ubombo ranches sugar company and force out workers who were maintaining essential services and machinery under an agreement between the union and the company. about 50 policemen, some in riot gear, fired teargas and warning shots in the air, prompting the workers to begin stoning them. police then opened fire on the workers, wounding six of them. the sftu, backed by outlawed political groups, is demanding that king mswati iii lift a 1973 decree that bans all political parties, and reinstate constitutional rule. even though the immediate desire of the demonstrators was to take people away from working so they could strike, this is a direct consequence of the strike s demand for democracy. given the presence of 50 police and the popularity of the strike, this demonstration is believed to have at least 100 people.

notes: in one of the biggest demonstrations seen in swaziland in years, hiv positive people marched on the offices of the prime minister and the national aids council this week to protest an insulting new media campaign. the project by the national emergency response council on hiv aids nercha seems to suggest that hiv is caused by sexual infidelity. it was launched last month without consulting people living with the virus. the campaign further stigmatises the hiv infected. it is an insult, we are angry. it is time we are involved in matters pertaining to us, said protest leader vusi matsebula, chairperson of the swaziland national network of people living with hiv aids swannepha . around 1,000 people participated in the demonstration. nercha did not return irin s phone calls on friday, but in previous press statements the organisation, which falls under the authority of the prime minister s office, has argued that makhwapheni was a dramatic attempt to change people s behaviour. however, swannepha has accused nercha of arrogance, and its staff of making a living off the aids crisis, which nercha has denied. the protestors also claimed nercha was concentrating its media efforts on uninfected swazis while ignoring people in the advanced stages of opportunistic diseases brought on by aids. von wissell refused to meet the throng, but a few days later, he gave in to the complaints and suspended the campaign.

sources: swaziland; failure to grant scholarships points to education crisis africa news, september 12, 2006 tuesday, 904 words, un integrated regional information networks ;
notes: recent clashes between swazi university students and riot police have brought a burgeoning education crisis into sharp relief, but went unreported by the state radio and television networks. street battles erupted after students marched on prime minister themba dlamini s offices demanding that the government honour its university scholarship commitments. musa hlope, a member of government s semi autonomous national curriculum centre, said reasonable people should have seen this crisis in education coming. in a report released last week, the centre said a lack of government policy on school fees, curriculum development, assessment and evaluation, and availability of schoolbooks was responsible. an analysis of various policy documents shows fragmentation and inconsistency within the ministry of education, the study commented. of immediate concern to the university students was the imminent expulsion of students who had expected government scholarships. the education ministry at first said 182 students had been affected by scholarship reduction, but the announcement that 521 students were to be deprived of scholarships provoked the protests and subsequent student unrest. based on how many students would be deprived of scholarships, this protest is coded as having at least 100 people. demand is coded as both price increases due to lack of scholarships causing an increase in fees for most students and political behaviour process due to the expulsions and policies.

sources: swaziland; worst labour strife in a decade africa news, march 6, 2008 thursday, 820 words, un integrated regional information networks ;
notes: in the strike action, which began on 3 march, workers participating in peaceful marches to demand better salaries have been teargassed and beaten by police, and at least a dozen have reportedly been injured. more than 16,000 workers, most of them women, have been affected by the strike action. local media reported that the swaziland police carried out unprovoked attacks on peaceful marchers on the first day of the strike. several injuries were reported after riot police shot teargas into a line of marchers in the matsapha industrial estate outside the central commercial town of manzini. on 5 march, several marchers were beaten and teargassed after vandals sealed the lock on the gate of a textile factory with glue. uncertain of the culprits identities, the police randomly struck at marchers, some of whom had to be hospitalised. one policewoman was injured by a thrown stone. the ministry of enterprise and employment, which brought the textile industry to swaziland, called workers and management to a resolution conference in manzini for the evening of 6 march. on the table will be the wage dispute, but another less tangible issue will likely remain unresolved when workers return to their jobs: the workers complaint about lack of respect.

sources: swaziland; enough is enough, say nurses africa news, march 11, 2008 tuesday, 491 words, un integrated regional information networks ;
notes: tired of being taken for granted, swaziland s nurses have opted for industrial action after the government ignored a deadline to improve conditions of service. after marching to the ministry of health and social welfare in the capital, mbabane, on friday to deliver their ultimatum, swaziland s nurses registered their anger with an overtime ban beginning on monday to protest delayed pay, unsafe working conditions, and crumbling facilities. the 2,016 nurses registered by the sna, who have stayed in swaziland rather than going abroad to work, have watched the deterioration of hospitals and clinics with dismay. earlier this year, the health inspector of mbabane declared the city s hospital, the largest in the country, unfit for human habitation. given the amount of nurses registered with the sna and the widespread nationwide problems this particular group of workers has faced, this protest is coded as having at least 100 people.

notes: police in swaziland beat up demonstrators with batons and used teargas against them as protests spread across the kingdom. yesterday 11 april 2012 , on the first day of what some activists are calling an indefinite protest action , large numbers of police and soldiers were present in all major towns and cities. although the 11th is considered the ? start? of the protest, marching did not occur until the next day ? april 12th. activists are protesting against the undemocratic regime of king mswati iii, sub saharan africa s last absolute monarch. all political parties and opposition groups are banned in the kingdom. more arrests of protest leaders are reported from swaziland this morning 12 april 2012 . trade union leaders were detained by police and roads blocked to stop protesters gathering. barnabas dlamini, the swaziland prime minister, had ordered a ban on all protests. police said the protests were against national security. the crackdown was so effective that by midday yesterday 12 april 2012 workers leaders called off the protest, which had been planned to last up to four days. this protest is coded as only 100 because it was largely stopped before it could gain the momentum that leaders had promised and desired.

notes: hospitals are not protecting their workers from tuberculosis tb infection, say nurses in swaziland, who recently staged a rare public demonstration to draw attention to how vulnerable they are to this highly infectious disease. nurses attached to the national tb hospital in swaziland s commercial hub, manzini, are blaming inadequate infection measures at the hospital for the risk they face. tb is one of the primary killers and the main opportunistic disease in people living with hiv and aids. given the involvement of nurses, who have gone on strike before in large numbers, this protest is coded as having at least 50 people.

sources: swaziland; defiant teachers deliver petition africa news, june 13, 2012 wednesday, 164 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: teachers in swaziland managed to deliver their petition to the government this afternoon 13 june 2102 , despite being blocked by riot police. police stopped about 3,000 members of the swaziland national association of teachers snat marching across mbabane city centre this morning. they had wanted to deliver a petition for a 4.5 percent salary increase, but were stopped from doing so. the centre for human rights, swaziland, reports, the march was characterised by threats of violence from security agents. two workers were unlawfully detained by riot police, and this seemed to anger workers who retaliated by throwing stones at the police vehicles into which the two were taken. they were promptly released and the march continued.

sources: swaziland; police attack striking civil servants africa news, july 12, 2012 thursday, 225 words, swazi media commentary gaborone swaziland wage protest the advertiser australia , july 13, 2012 friday, foreign; pg. 67, 60 words ;
notes: scores of people were injured, some seriously, by police in swaziland who fired rubber bullets and tear gas and used batons to attack striking public servants. more than 200 police officers attacked strikers in coronation park, mbabane, the swazi capital, as they prepared to march in support of a 4.5 percent wage increase. police imprisoned the strikers in the park for most of the morning yesterday 11 july 2012 and refused to allow them to leave for a march through the city. at about 2pm some strikers tried to leave the park to get lunch. it was then that police commanders ordered officers to fire rubber bullets and teargas at the strikers. police have fired rubber bullets and tear gas to stop a protest by thousands of government workers demanding higher wages.

sources: swaziland; police seal parliament from protest africa news, july 19, 2012 thursday, 506 words, swazi media commentary gaborone swaziland; police shoot innocent bystander africa news, july 18, 2012 wednesday, 208 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: in a two day protest action that ended yesterday by public transport operators in the city of manzini, police shot an innocent bystander, bonginkosi mkhonto, in the stomach for watching protesting transport operators. other incidents of police brutality were reported during this protest action. the public operators protest action came after a public bus driver was fined r4800 by a court, when police refused to let him pay a r60 on the spot fine. swaziland police shot an innocent bystander in the stomach with a rubber bullet as they attacked a protest of transport workers. the centre for human rights, swaziland, reported that several other people were injured by police who were seen ransacking the manzini bus rank in an attempt to arrest protesting transport operators. the centre said, several protesters and pedestrians have been arrested by the police who are going for any person they suspect to be taking part in the on going protest action. the police fired teargas all over the town as a result harming vendors and other people in the town. scenes of violent police have been observed all over the town as police beat up protesters using batons and fists. given the response by police and the fact that this protest is taking place alongside a much larger strike, this is coded as having at least 100 people.

sources: swaziland; police seal parliament from protest africa news, july 19, 2012 thursday, 506 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: about 1,000 parents and teachers were stopped 500m from parliament yesterday 18 july 2012 and told they could go no further. they were calling on the swazi government to find a solution to the indefinite teachers strike over pay that has been going on for a month. they also want parliament to pass a vote of no confidence in the government; scrap the recently introduced 14 percent value added tax; and scrap circular no. 1 , an order that allows government ministers and parliamentarians inflated financial benefits.

sources: swaziland; teachers march on ministry africa news, august 3, 2012 friday, 138 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: teachers in swaziland are marching in the streets of the capital mbabane today 3 august 2012 following their successful court action to stop the government sacking striking teachers. the centre for human rights, swaziland, reports that close to 200 teachers are singing and chanting struggle songs as they march from the industrial court to the ministry of education. they want to deliver a petition calling on the swazi government to stop further sackings and to hold talks with the teachers.

sources: swaziland; armed police block students protest africa news, august 16, 2012 thursday, 239 words, swazi media commentary gaborone swaziland; police shoot two students in head africa news, august 17, 2012 friday, 299 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: heavily armed state forces stopped students in swaziland from marching on government to protest about the non payment of tuition fees and scholarships. more than 100 students today 16 august 2012 gathered at the university of swaziland campus in the kingdom s capital mbabane, but they were blocked from leaving for about four hours by police and prison wardens. the students hoped to march on the labour and social security to deliver a petition concerning a continuing scholarship crisis. three university students in swaziland were shot by police two in the head while security forces stopped a protest march against scholarship cuts. reports from the centre for human rights and development, swaziland, say several other students were injured by police batons and kicks. he said police assaulted dlamini with batons and kicks. the students retaliated by pelting stones at the police officers in an attempt to save their colleague.

sources: swaziland; students lead second day of protest africa news, september 4, 2012 tuesday, 161 words, swazi media commentary gaborone swaziland; police fire teargas to stop students africa news, september 4, 2012 tuesday, 214 words, swazi media commentary gaborone swaziland; police bid to arrest student leader africa news, september 4, 2012 tuesday, 204 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: students led by the swaziland union of students snus will be marching to the ministry of education in mbabane this morning 4 september 2012 .the march is part of a global week of action for swaziland. the students are marching to demand education for all in swaziland. the centre for human rights and development, swaziland, reports more than 100 students are now gathered in manzini in preparation to proceed to mbabane where they will be meeting other students to proceed to the ministry. students fought with police in mbabane, the swazi capital, this lunchtime 4 september 2012 as they tried to arrest swaziland national union of students leader, maxwell dlamini. reports from the scene at the mbabane bus rank say that police and security forces vastly outnumber the students. state security forces fired teargas, beat up students and activists and drove them away from the bus rank towards the university of swaziland, mbabane campus, the people s united democratic movement pudemo reported. police have fired teargas and made indiscriminate arrests as they blocked a prodemocracy protest led by students in swaziland today 4 september 2012 . the sdc reports that a student from william pitcher college who fled with the snus banner during the police attack has been arrested.

sources: women and gender; women find strength in numbers africa news, january 3, 2013 thursday, 965 words, un integrated regional information networks nairobi women and gender; women in mini skirts face arrest africa news, december 23, 2012 sunday, 294 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: last month saw the establishment of a new group the swaziland young women s network which announced its launch with a march through the streets of the capital, mbabane, to protest the prevalence of sexual harassment. the police blocked the march on the grounds that some of the women were wearing miniskirts. the government s first response to women seeking our rights was to block us and threaten us with arrest, and to control us by telling us what to wear. that is their instinct, and it is going to be hard to overcome, but we are determined not only for our own sake but for the sake of the country, said simelane. police recently halted a protest march by women who wore mini skirts to draw attention to the harassment they face. this protest is coded as having at least 50 people given the history of women? s marches and the rampant prevalence of rape in the nation.

sources: swaziland; swazi police now a private militia africa news, april 13, 2013 saturday, 419 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: this follows police action that yesterday 12 april 2013 broke up a public meeting to discuss the lack of democracy in the kingdom. about 80 armed police stopped the meeting taking place at a restaurant in manzini, the main business city in swaziland. police, who did not have a court order for the action, said the meeting presented a threat to national security . given how many police showed up to break up the gathering, this protest is coded as having at least 50 people.

sources: swaziland; police break up election meeting africa news, april 20, 2013 saturday, 609 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: the swaziland youth congress swayoco tried to hold a rally in msunduza township, mbabane, on friday 19 april 2013 at the same time that king mswati iii was holding an e10 million us 1.1 million party in another part of the kingdom to celebrate his 45th birthday. the swazi police commissioner isaac magagula had warned swayoco in advance that his officers would stop any attempt at meeting. swayoco supporters went ahead with their attempt to meet with residents to discuss with them why they should boycott the national election due later this year. political parties are not allowed to contest the so called tinkhundla election and the parliament that is selected is not independent, but serves the wishes of king mswati, who is sub saharan africa s last absolute monarch. police said two people were arrested at the rally. given the importance of the group involved in this particular rally and the police desperation to stymie it, this protest is coded as having at least 50 people.

sources: swazi police stop women s demonstration against attacks bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, may 30, 2013 thursday, 351 words swaziland; police ban march against violence africa news, may 29, 2013 wednesday, 174 words, swazi media commentary gaborone ;
notes: members of the royal swaziland police service yesterday quashed a march intended by over 100 women against the recent spate of attacks against women. the event was organized by the swaziland rural women s association srwa . about 100 women ended up loitering around siphofaneni under the watchful eye of the police. the police staged roadblocks between siphofaneni and phuzumoya, where they monitored passengers aboard public transport vehicles. they also searched cars they suspected to have been transporting people who intended to join the march. srwa decided to defy the ban and continue with the march.

sources: swaziland; pro reform protestors arrested in swaziland africa news, september 6, 2013 friday, 802 words, thinkafricapress london ;
notes: swaziland police are out in force in manzini, the country s second largest city and centre of recent protests against the absolute monarchy. the police have set up a blockade on the west side of the town and almost every street corner has some form of police presence, uniformed and plain clothes. throughout yesterday, activists and advocates were followed and recorded by plain clothes police. then, vincent ncongwane, general secretary of the trade union congress of swaziland tucoswa , was arrested in his office by ten police as he prepared to lead his members in protest. no warrant was produced. given the swift and harsh put down of this protest, and given the history of protests during this particular week, this demonstration is assumed to have at least 100 people.

sources: swaziland; police point gun at journalist africa news, september 30, 2013 monday, 326 words, swazi media commentary gaborone press and media; policeman points gun at journalist in swaziland africa news, september 30, 2013 monday, 902 words, misa swaziland mbabane ;
notes: walter dlamini, of the times sunday, had taken photos at gege where police had broken up a peaceful protest march by youth in the area. they were protesting against alleged irregularities at the recent election. the casual work a day savagery of these police officers and their sense of entitlement to brutalising swazi citizens with impunity goes a long way to explaining why they would attack with teargas and batons what was a peaceful protest march before their intervention; once again proving the police are responsible for much of the violence that erupts during protests. the bashing of protestors who are unhappy with what they believe to be unfair and unfree elections and intimidation of journalists last saturday, adds to the growing reality of police repression and muzzling of civil and media freedoms in the southern african kingdom. given the harsh and brutal suppression of the protest and the history of youth protests in the nation, this is coded as having at least 50 demonstrators.

protesteridentity: protesters organized by trade union congress of swaziland tucoswa against worsening living conditions and the cost of celebrations
sources: clashes as swaziland marks 50 years of independence, agence france presse english, april 13, 2018 friday 4:14 pm gmt, 307 words, mbabane, swaziland, april 13 2018
notes: police fired rubber bullets at protesters in swaziland friday while they marched against worsening living conditions and the cost of celebrations to mark the 50th anniversary of the absolute monarchy. more than 2,000 people took to the streets to take part in a rare demonstration organised by trade union congress of swaziland tucoswa in the administrative capital mbabane. one protester was injured in the thigh when police fired rubber bullets at the crowd angered by celebrations marking independence from britain in 1968 that coincide with the birthday of king mswati iii. police tussled with protesters, some of whom burnt tyres and blocked roads, as they made their way to the prime minister s office to deliver a petition. some marchers attempted to tear down the gates at the pm s office and force their way inside but were blocked by police. regional media have claimed that swaziland s government had purchased a fleet of luxury bmws for the occasion, something that officials have denied. the times of swaziland daily reported that chief justice bheki maphalala had instructed judges to contribute at least 165 each to the festivities. our hospitals have run out of medicine. of course, ordinary citizens can t afford to go to asia or europe to get proper medical care, said tucoswa official muzi mhlanga. tucoswa said that civil servants would receive no pay hike to meet the increasing cost of living while senior ministers received increases of almost one third.

protesteridentity: workers organised by the trade union congress of swaziland protesting alleged government corruption
sources: four injured as police break up swazi workers protest, agence france presse english, june 29, 2018 friday 2:06 pm gmt, 209 words, mbabane, eswatini, june 29 2018
notes: four protesters were injured friday in eswatini, formerly known as swaziland, as police used rubber bullets to break up a workers protest over alleged government corruption, trade union officials said. the demonstration organised by the trade union congress of swaziland was over accusations that millions of dollars have been removed from the national pension fund by the government of king mswati iii, one of the world s few absolute monarchs. parliament instituted the probe into the alleged scandal, but it was later halted. police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at about 500 protesters, as well as using water canon and wielding batons, as demonstrators threw stones at officers, an afp correspondent reported. we were marching peacefully until this unfortunate incident by police, trade union leader bheki mamba told the protesters. the injured comrades have been rushed to hospital. we assured the police that we are not confrontational. note: the exact protest location was not provided in the story

protesteridentity: trade union protesters calling for public sector wage increases
sources: new name, same flaws in eswatini election, say critics, agence france presse english, september 19, 2018 wednesday 2:06 pm gmt, 806 words, mbabane, eswatini, sept 19 2018; king s absolute rule towers over eswatini election, agence france presse english, september 21, 2018 friday 5:29 pm gmt, 742 words, mbabane, eswatini, sept 21 2018; eswatini votes but the king holds absolute power, agence france presse english, september 21, 2018 friday 10:33 am gmt, 717 words, mbabane, eswatini, sept 21 2018
notes: political parties cannot be involved, there are no campaign rallies and the king wields absolute power, choosing the prime minister and cabinet: a parliamentary election in eswatini is a vote like no other. opposition activists in the tiny southern african country formerly known as swaziland say friday s election is a mockery of democracy and reveals how its 1.3 million citizens have long lived under a repressive regime. in addition to curbs on opposition parties, anti government protests are also effectively banned. undercurrents of dissent have surfaced this week with trade union protests over low wages by being broken up by riot police. at least 11 people were hurt on tuesday, a trade union official told afp. we have been told to stop the protests but we will continue. we have had thousands of people, mduduzi gina, secretary general of the trade union congress of swaziland, told afp. underlying tensions surfaced ahead of polling day as thousands of protesters joined two days of trade union marches calling for public sector wage increases. the demonstrations, which centred on the second city manzini, were broken up by riot police using tear gas and water cannons, leaving several people injured. note: the exact locations of protests other than manzini were not provided in the stories

protesteridentity: demonstrators demanding political reforms, organized by the swaziland united democratic front sudf
sources: thousands in rare pro democracy protests in eswatini, agence france presse english, may 4, 2019 saturday 9:53 am gmt, 270 words, manzini, swaziland, may 4 2019
notes: in a rare show of defiance thousands of people have demonstrated to demand political reforms in the tiny kingdom of eswatini where political parties have been banned since 1973. around 3,000 protesters, many sporting red t shirts, took to the streets of manzini, the second largest city, marching amid a heavy police presence on friday. political parties and pro democracy groups have been outlawed for nearly five decades in the kingdom previously known as swaziland. the landlocked country is ruled by king mswati iii who has supreme control over the 1.3 million population. government traditionally stifles political dissent and demonstrations. one of the protest organisers, wandile dludlu, of the swaziland united democratic front sudf , said the strong turnout showed that the political situation in the country had reached a crisis point. the march was a huge success. it was very encouraging to see youth and women defying the measures the state put in place to stifle freedom, said dludlu.

protesteridentity: civil servants protesting against low pay and rising living costs
sources: chaos in eswatini as anti monarchy protests turn violent, agence france presse english, september 25, 2019 wednesday 5:14 pm gmt, 498 words, mbabane, eswatini, sept 25 2019
notes: violent clashes erupted in eswatini on wednesday after police cracked down on civil servants protesting against low pay and rising living costs in africa s last absolute monarchy. teachers and workers went on strike last week in the four main towns of eswatini a tiny southern african kingdom until recently known as swaziland, surrounded by south africa and mozambique. they accuse king mswati iii of draining public coffers at the expense of his subjects, and flocked to the capital mbabane from friday to discuss action with opposition pro democracy groups. police fired tear gas, stun grenades and water canons on wednesday to disperse the crowd, who responded by pelting rocks at police cars and government buildings. our problem is that we have a selfish king, said sibongile mazibuko, who heads the ngwane national liberatory congress pro democracy group. he loots national coffers to satisfy his personal greed. frustrations have boiled over into a series of protests around the country this week. more than 3,500 people marched in mbabane and the neighbouring city of manzini on monday, and around 3,000 protesters showed up in the capital again on wednesday.

protesteridentity: civil servants protesting against low pay and rising living costs

protesteridentity: teachers and government workers rallying to demand better pay and lower living costs
sources: eswatini workers clash with police in salary protests, agence france presse english, october 2, 2019 wednesday 3:35 pm gmt, 314 words, manzini, swaziland, oct 2 2019
notes: angry teachers and government workers clashed with police in the tiny kingdom of eswatini on wednesday as they rallied to demand better pay and lower living costs in africa s last absolute monarchy. civil servants took to the streets in manzini, the kingdom s second largest town, singing protest songs and blowing horns. we want cost of living adjustment not bullets, read a banner wielded by one protester. the crowd threw stones at the police, who responded with water canons, rubber bullets and tear gas. civil servants launched a series of strikes across the kingdom of eswatini formerly known as swaziland last month. they accuse king mswati iii of spending public money on expensive trips abroad and royal ceremonies at the expense of their salaries. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: madagascar troops round up rebels after coup attempt fails the independent london , may 14, 1990, monday, foreign news page; page 10 , 536 words ;
notes: three people were killed and 20 injured in a failed coup attempt in madagascar early yesterday, hospital sources said, after armed rebels seized the national radio station to announce the overthrow of the president, admiral didier ratsiraka. residents said that 4,000 to 5,000 policemen loyal to mr ratsiraka ringed the radio station after the coup announcement, while about 300 protesters responded to the rebel appeal, chanting anti government slogans and stoning police who responded with tear gas. although a coup was going on, the protest is coded as only the 300 people protesting against the government and not the actual coup itself. therefore, the killings that took part against the coup members are not counted as a response to the protest.

sources: protesters demand democratic reforms in magadascar the globe and mail canada , june 19, 1991 wednesday, 100 words, reut demands for national conferences mount africa news, june 24, 1991, democracy: africa, 1498 words ;
notes: more than 100,000 protesters took to the streets of madagascar s capital yesterday on the eighth day of demonstrations for democratic reforms. diplomats say the protests pose the greatest challenge yet to president didier ratsiraka s 16 year old rule. the protests have been orchestrated by the opposition platform that includes marxists and right wingers which wants a new transitional government to supervise the introduction of a new constitution. protests that brought out 100,000 people in madagascar on june 11 were the beginning of a series of demonstrations against the regime of president didier ratsiraka that have continued to mount. the protesters in antananarivo, capital of the indian ocean island nation, have been calling for an end to ratsiraka s 16 year rule and for a national conference to draft a new constitution.

sources: thousands rally for reforms in madagascar the guardian london , june 27, 1991, 248 words, by mark huband ;
notes: on monday, the prime minister, victor ramahatra, threatened the opposition with legal action if it persisted in claiming that it had appointed a new government. thousands took to the streets in response.

sources: thousands rally for reforms in madagascar the guardian london , june 27, 1991, 248 words, by mark huband ;
notes: opposition parties in madagascar led up to 100,000 protestors through the streets of the apital to mark yesterday s independene anniversary by demanding democratic reforms. some estimates put the size of the demonstration at 200,000, or one third of antananarivo s population. the 16 party opposition coalition had agreed with the city authorities to keep the march peaceful and no violence was reported. an official military parade to mark the country s 31 years of independence attracted around 10,000 people. the opposition has accused president didier ratsiraka of rigging a 1989 election which gave him a third term in office. president ratsiraka, a former naval officer who seized power in 1975, has attempted to introduce a degree of democracy and economic liberalisation.

sources: briefly: 300,000 protest the independent london , july 7, 1991, sunday, foreign news page; page 13 , 52 words ;
notes: up to 300,000 people poured into the streets of the madagascan capital yesterday, demonstrating in support of opposition calls for a new constitution and a national conference. a general strike to try to force president didier ratsiraka to step down has been called for tomorrow.

sources: city paralysed the independent london , july 9, 1991, tuesday, foreign news page; page 8 , 52 words strike continues the independent london , july 10, 1991, wednesday, foreign news page; page 10 , 39 words ratsiraka bows to protests the independent london , july 11, 1991, thursday, foreign news page; page 16 , 84 words ;
notes: the opposition paralysed the capital of madagascar with a strike, and an estimated 400,000 people took to the streets demanding the resignation of president didier ratsiraka. protest organisers have also demanded democratic elections and the replacement of the socialist constitution. tens of thousands of people took to the streets, partially paralysing madagascar s capital for the second day in response to an opposition general strike call to bring down the government. madagascar s government alliance has agreed to talks with the island s coalition of opposition parties on a new constitution, following a month of huge demonstrations calling on president ratsiraka to step down. a large part of the capital was still strikebound yesterday and thousands of demonstrators thronged the city centre as the opposition maintained its call for an open ended general strike. almost half a million people took to the streets on monday and tuesday.

sources: malagasy opposition steps up the pressure on ratsiraka the independent london , july 17, 1991, wednesday, foreign news page; page 12 , 414 words, from chris mcgreal in antananarivo, madagascar madagascar leader resists a living force for change; the opposition is using prayer and pragmatism to oust president ratsiraka, writes chris mcgreal from antananarivo the independent london , july 20, 1991, saturday, foreign news page; page 11 , 610 words, from chris mcgreal in antananarivo ;
notes: madagascar s opposition yesterday partially called off an effective week old general strike held to precipitate the resignation of president didier ratsiraka. party leaders insisted it was a small concession that would achieve their aim. but opposition supporters were angered at their leaders climbdown and thousands filled the streets of the capital, antananarivo, in the mood to take a more confrontational tack than the peaceful protests of recent weeks. riot police were in evidence for the first time. however, opposition supporters, who have blocked the heart of the capital with almost daily demonstrations, were not content. about 60,000 largely middle class protesters filed with remarkable order into independence avenue yesterday morning. president ratsiraka abandoned his marxist experiment 11 years ago after dragging madagascar from relative prosperity to its present position as the world s 12th poorest nation. but the opposition is not convinced by his conversion to privatisation, with the considerable incentive of world bank loans. today the president is seen as more opportunist than marxist. the opposition resents his claims of credit for a substantial increase in foreign aid, mainly from the french, especially when much of it is diverted from the causes for which it was intended.

sources: the washington post, protests in madagascar, from news services, july 24, 1991, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a25; around the world, 118 words ratsiraka protest the independent london , july 23, 1991, tuesday, foreign news page; page 8 , 54 words official seized in madagascar the new york times, july 26, 1991, friday, late edition final, section a; page 8; column 1; foreign desk, 57 words, ap premier of madagascar resigns the new york times, july 29, 1991, monday, late edition final, section a; page 2; column 3; foreign desk, 383 words, ap ;
notes: demonstrators breached security cordons around two madagascar government ministries to try to install opposition ministers of finance and post and telecommunications in office. their action followed a rally of several hundred thousand people seeking to end president didier ratsiraka s rule. anti government protesters and soldiers clashed outside madagascar s state radio station as president didier ratsiraka ordered a security crackdown after weeks of peaceful demonstrations. witnesses said one soldier and several demonstrators were injured before opposition leaders told their supporters to withdraw. police commandos seized another minister in the opposition s self declared government today, while protests continued against president didier ratsiraka. the seizure of rahantavololona andrianmanjato at the public works ministry was the government s boldest move since ratsiraka declared a state of emergency tuesday to stop the takeover. prime minister victor ramahatra announced his resignation and the dissolution of his cabinet today. he acted hours after president didier ratsiraka made his first concession to seven weeks of huge pro democracy demonstrations and offered to open talks with opponents seeking his ouster.

sources: madagascar opposition rejects president s tardy olive branch the guardian london , july 30, 1991, 209 words ;
notes: madagascar s opposition has rejected political concessions made by president didier ratsiraka and in a meeting of tens of thousands of demonstrators yesterday vowed to continue its seven week campaign of strikes and protests until he steps down. what we demand is your ratsiraka s resignation, opposition leader jean rakotoharison told protesters in the capital, antananarivo. the president of madagascar, mr didier ratsiraka, bowing to a seven week campaign of strikes and protests, says he will sack his government and bring in a new constitution by the end of the year. but his concessions may not satisfy tens of thousands of anti government protesters in the capital antananarivo who have thrown the indian ocean island into turmoil and insist that he must resign.
