protesteridentity: families denouncing hardships on the un s global anti poverty day
sources: presidential poll embitters poor madagascans, agence france presse english, october 30, 2018 tuesday 3:41 am gmt, 593 words, antananarivo, oct 30 2018
notes: if i was to vote, i would definitely vote for the rubbish bins because at least they feed us, scoffed claudine rajaonarison. she had been scouring the streets of antananarivo since 4:00 am for plastic to sell. rajaonarison, a 35 year old mother of three, said she will not be voting for madagascar s next president in the november 7 poll. not one of the 36 candidates has impressed her. musician zafimahaleo rasolofondrasolo who is better known by his stage name dama, blamed madagascar s poverty crisis on a governing system concentrated in the hands of the elite. in antananarivo s may 13 square, home to an anti government protest movement from april to june, 100 families gathered on october 17 to denounce hardships on the un s global anti poverty day. please save our home, save our livelihood, we don t know where we ll go once our home is demolished, justine hanitrarivo told the crowd that day. her house lies in the path of a new motorway and is slated for destruction. we don t have qualifications to get proper jobs. it s the rubbish that has sustained us for 16 years, the 43 year old mother said. if the state orders us out, will they relocate us to another dump?

protesteridentity: opposition supporters demanding a recount of the vote in the presidential election
sources: opposition protests over madagascar vote result, agence france presse english, december 29, 2018 saturday 3:59 pm gmt, 443 words, antananarivo, dec 29 2018
notes: thousands of opposition supporters took to the streets in the capital of madagascar on saturday to protest against the victory of ex president andry rajoelina in last week s elections. around 2,000 supporters of defeated candidate marc ravalomanana gathered in the may 13 square in the heart of antananarivo, demanding a recount of the vote in the indian ocean island state. the protest, the first in a series of planned demonstrations, came as the country s top court reviews a petition filed by ravalomanana challenging rajoelina s win because of fraud allegations. opposition lawmaker hanitra razafimanantsoa, told the crowd gathered in the square that if there s a vote recount you will find that our candidate marc ravalomanana won this election .

location: The centre of the capital Antananarivo
protesteridentity: supporters of losing presidential candidate marc ravalomanana, who claims he was denied victory in last month s election because of fraud
sources: madagascar police fire tear gas to break up opposition protest, agence france presse english, january 2, 2019 wednesday 1:29 pm gmt, 215 words, antananarivo, jan 2 2019
notes: madagascan security forces on wednesday fired tear gas to break up a protest by supporters of losing presidential candidate marc ravalomanana, who claims he was denied victory in last month s election because of fraud. in the run off vote on december 19, ravalomanana won 44 percent against the winner andry rajoelina on 55 percent, according to official results. thousands of ravalomanana s supporters gathered in the centre of the capital antananarivo but were quickly dispersed by police using tear gas, according to an afp reporter at the scene. we came to erect a giant screen projecting anomalies in the second round election but we were fired at with tear gas, hanitra razafimanantsoa, a lawmaker from ravalomanana s party, told the media. respect our choice, we don t reserve a fraudulent election, read protest banners held by ravalomanana s supporters, who have vowed to hold daily protests.

protesteridentity: supporters of the losing presidential candidate protesting the election result ahead of a court verdict reviewing the vote
sources: madagascar opposition protest ahead of court s vote verdict, agence france presse english, january 3, 2019 thursday 5:43 pm gmt, 187 words, antananarivo, jan 3 2019
notes: hundreds of supporters of the losing madagascar presidential candidate staged a protest in the capital antananarivo on thursday, rejecting the election result ahead of a court verdict reviewing the vote. former president marc ravalomanana was defeated on december 19 by another former leader of the indian ocean island, andry rajoelina, who won nearly 56 percent of a run off vote. the country s constitutional court is reviewing a petition filed by ravalomanana, who claims the election was tarnished by massive fraud. the court is due to hand down its ruling on january 8. the message to the court : we will not stop until the truth is restored, vowed hanitra razafimanantsoa, a lawmaker from ravalomanana s tim party. the protesters have vowed to stage daily vigils until the results are announced next week.

location: The square outside Antananarivo City Hall
protesteridentity: supporters of the losing candidate in last month s presidential election
sources: simmering anger sparks days of protest after madagascar vote, agence france presse english, january 5, 2019 saturday 3:08 pm gmt, 333 words, antananarivo, jan 5 2019
notes: madagascar police fired teargas saturday to disperse some 500 supporters of the losing candidate in last month s presidential election, in the fifth such protest this week, afp correspondents witnessed. defying a ban on demonstrations, hundreds of supporters of marc ravalomanana took to the streets of the capital antananarivo to rally on the square outside city hall, with police firing tear gas to disperse them. several demonstrators hurled molotov cocktails at officers, who arrested four people, the correspondents said. after a brief game of cat and mouse with police chasing demonstrators, the heavens opened and a torrential downpour quickly clearing the area. police had also used tear gas at a similar demonstration on wednesday. angry protests erupted on december 29, just two days after former president andry rajoelina was declared the winner of a runoff vote which took place 10 days earlier. defeated, ravalomanana also a former president cried foul, claiming fraud and demanding a recount of votes in the indian ocean island state, which has a long and bitter history of instability.

protesteridentity: demonstrators opposed to a controversial urban expansion project
sources: violent protests against madagascar s new city , agence france presse english, october 18, 2019 friday 1:24 pm gmt, 336 words, antananarivo, oct 18 2019
notes: clashes broke out between police and protesters in madagascar overnight after stone throwing demonstrators stormed the construction site of a controversial urban expansion project, police said friday. madagascar s government has launched the construction of a shiny new urban complex meant to unclog the capital antananarivo a city wedged between the hills of the island nation s central highlands. president andry rajoelina promised to ease antananarivo s overcrowding and chronic traffic jams while campaigning in last year s elections. the tana masoandra project, dubbed the new sun the new city , is expected to house government buildings, businesses and 100,000 inhabitants. connected to antananarivo via bridge, the 1,000 hectare project will encroach on rice fields and brickyards surrounding the capital. there have been scattered protests against the project and the latest turned violent on thursday evening, when a group of people attacked a construction site. police intervened after the construction company called to report stone throwing, police spokesman richard ravalomanana told afp. some people immediately threw rocks at the officers, who responded with tear gas, he added. ravalomanana said one civilian and four officers were injured before police fired warning shots to disperse the crowd. four people were arrested at the scene. construction equipment was also ransacked in the process, according to the land ministry. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the source, and is based on prior coding decisions.

sources: comoros delays presidential election xinhua general news service, january 10, 1990, wednesday, 188 words ;
notes: the islamic republic of comoro islands will hold its presidential election on february 18, instead of january 14 as was originally planned. this is a reaction to a demonstration held on monday by 500 people in the capital, moroni, in support of opposition parties which oppose the election plan. the opposition accused the government of making the decision without consulting them.

sources: freedom riots hit comoros herald, january 10, 1990 wednesday, 189 words ;
notes: rioting broke out in the capital of the comoro islands today after police fired over the heads of demonstrators calling for a return to democracy. police also used teargas to break up the demonstrators, who had gathered outside moroni s main mosque in a protest organised by opposition parties. the demonstrators broke into small groups, pillaging government buildings and setting fire to about 10 vehicles. previously banned opposition parties are angry at being excluded from government. the opposition went ahead with today s rally despite a ban and a government announcement that elections would be held on february 18. given the damage done in the city, the response needed to break up the protest, and the connection to the 500 person protest two days earlier, this demonstration is believed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: comoro police tear gas demonstrators seeking back salaries agence france presse, january 28, 1997, international news, 147 words ;
notes: police in the comoro islands fired tear gas tuesday to break up demonstrations by government employees demanding 10 months of back salaries. the police used tear gas on the demonstrators as they marched through the capital chanting a prayer and with their arms raised to signal they did not seek violence. thirty people were injured, seven of them seriously, in clashes in the comoro islands between police and government employees demonstrating for 10 months of back salaries, sources said wednesday. police arrested 20 people in connection with tuesday s rally which touched off the third such clash in a week in this indian ocean archipelago. the seven seriously injured were all civilians and were all in hospital overnight suffering from bullet wounds, an afp reporter noted. some 20 other demonstrators were also slightly injured, most of them by truncheon blows. police used tear gas on the demonstrators, but unrest quickly spread from the north of the city. the clashes lasted three hours, and stopped only when demonstrators dispersed because of a heavy storm that lashed the city. despite the peace that the demonstrators originally showed, the word clashes implies violence on the part of the protesters erupted. given how many people were arrested and injured, this protest is assumed to have at least 100 participants.

sources: violent riot on comoran island agence france presse english ;
notes: several people were injured in clashes between students, trade unionists and security forces in the main town on one of the comoro islands in the indian ocean on tuesday, witnesses said. one trade unionist was so badly hurt that his life was in danger, while 11 demonstrators, including five school students, were arrested, sources said. the violence in matsamudu on anjouan island was continuing around midday. comorans are up in arms about the non payment of salaries and shortages of electricity and water. pupils have not yet gone back to school, though the holy fasting month of ramadan ended more than a week ago in the mainly moslem republic. given how many people were hurt, this demonstration is assumed to have at least 50 people. beatings was chosen as a response due to injuries that protesters sustained.

sources: violent clashes on comoran island: witnesses witnesses agence france presse english english government tries to quell three day riot on comoros island, march 14, 1997, friday, am cycle, international news, 438 words, by kamal eddine saindou world news briefs; comoro island troops arrest hundreds the new york times, march 17, 1997, monday, late edition final, section a; page 4; column 4; foreign desk , 180 words, reuters calm returns after deadly riots; negotiations to start associated press international, march 17, 1997; monday, international news, 374 words ;
notes: more than 3,000 demonstrators clashed with army troops on the island of anjouan in the comoros archipelago friday, witnesses said. the island has been wracked by rioting for three days over civil servants demands for payment of back wages. earlier friday, police opened fire on the rioters in mutsamudu, the island s biggest city, killing one person and wounding several others, said witnesses contacted by phone from the comoros capital, moroni. residents said today that more than 200 people, including a former member of parliament, were arrested after clashes between stone throwing villagers and armed troops on anjouan, about 80 miles southeast of the main island of grande comore. the federation of red cross and red crescent societies said security forces had moved today to the town of sima, 15 miles west of the anjouan capital, mutsamudu. they said they received many complaints that soldiers were assaulting and torturing people, some of whom were stripped and forced to crawl as soldiers beat them with guns. four people were killed and at least 20 wounded in anjouan on saturday in fighting between government troops and secessionists on the island, which holds few employment opportunities for its 190,000 population. the government on monday lifted a 4 day old curfew imposed to quell unrest in this indian ocean nation that left as many as three people dead and 19 injured. it also announced the opening of negotiations with teachers, whose three month strike triggered the conflict.

sources: urgent police kill two demonstrators on comoran island: radio agence france presse english ;
notes: gendarmes shot dead two demonstrators on the comoran island of anjouan monday as a crowd in matsamudu, its principal town, called for secession, a radio comores official told afp in nairobi by telephone. some gendarmes were injured, he said, and reinforcements were being sent there from grande comore, the main island in the indian ocean archipelago between madagascar and mainland africa. he said the demonstrations on monday france s national day had lasted all day, with anjouanians raising french flags and the flag of sultan mawana, who ruled last century. this protest is believed to have at least 100 people due to the killing of two individuals and the need for reinforcements to deal with the protesters.

sources: police hurt in comoros island protest agence france presse english army crackdown on comoros island: calm belies discontent agence france presse english, aboubacar m changama ;
notes: two police officers were seriously hurt tuesday in clashes with protestors on the comorian island of anjouan over monday s arrest of a separatist leader, sources said here. the worst clashes came in the town of domoni where the residence of new governor sheikh allaoui was set alight by protestors. there was also unrest in mutsamudu, anjouan s main town. backers of the organization for the independence of anjouan, who want the island reattached to the former colonial power france, renounced the authority of moroni at the weekend and called for their own leaders to be installed in anjouan. the soldiers moved in after violent clashes between security forces and separatist militants on the island, one of three in the comoros archipelago between madagascar and the east coast of africa. soldiers have closed off some of the main roads leading into anjouan s main town mutsamudu and mounted patrols throughout the town, said residents reached by telephone from the comorian capital moroni. reinforcements were also sent to domoni among some 120 police and soldiers who have been sent recently to anjouan to bolster an existing force of between 200 and 250 troops. given how many police and soldiers were needed to quell the rioting, this demonstration is assumed to have at least 100 people.

sources: pro unity with france protests intensify in comoros associated press international, august 03, 1997; sunday, international news, 302 words comoran island move the irish times, august 4, 1997, city edition, world news; pg. 8, 92 words ;
notes: secessionists on the comoros island of anjouan who want france to take them back into the colonial fold have intensified their protests, french media reported sunday. protests have been staging protests on anjouan and moheli over the past several weeks. islanders claim the current government of president abdallah taki abdoulkarim is corrupt and they would be better off under french rule. the crowd of some 7,000 who rallied in the central square of mutsamudu, anjouan s main town, marched to the governor s palace abandoned on saturday and hoisted the flags of france and the sultans who ruled anjouan in pre colonial days, tearing up the comoran flag that had been flying there. meanwhile comoran troops went on red alert monday, prepared at a moment s notice to deploy in mutsamudu, anjouan s main town. the total armed forces of the comoro islands amounts to some 1,200 men about 600 soldiers and 500 to 600 gendarmes. the 200 to 250 gendarmes and soldiers normally stationed on anjouan have been reinforced by 100 to 125 men since the clashes began. reliable sources in mutsamudu say they are almost out of tear gas, but still have stocks of live ammunition.

sources: france sees danger of fundamentalism in comoros revolt the times, august 7, 1997, thursday, overseas news, 355 words, ben macintyre in paris ;
notes: with the secessionist revolt spreading from anjouan to moheli, two of the four islands that make up the comoran archipelago, what began as an odd, even flattering anachronism is fast turning into an embarrassing crisis for france. riot police yesterday clashed with demonstrators on the smaller island of moheli, after they raised the french tricolour over government buildings. the separatists in fomboni, the main town on moheli, were reported to have hoisted the yellow and black flag of queen fatima djoumbe, the last ruler of moheli before colonisation. given the popularity of the separatist movement, and that major clashes occurred between protesters and police, this demonstration is assumed to have at least 50 people.

sources: separatists erect barricades, complain gov t trying to break them associated press international, august 08, 1997; friday, international news, 488 words, kamal eddine saindou the washington post, for islanders of former french colony, freedom isn t all it s cracked up to be, charles trueheart, washington post foreign service, august 08, 1997, friday, final edition, a section; pg. a26, 1016 words ;
notes: but on thursday, separatists captured a police station and arrested an emissary of president mohamed taki abdoulkarim, french newspapers reported. a government delegation, sent to anjouan from grand comoros where the government is based, has sparked unease among the secessionists. on anjouan, rebels have erected barricades across the island, preventing traffic from circulating. new barricades appeared this week in the town of mutsamudu, which has not fully supported the move for reunification with france. the demonstrations, described in news reports as reflecting the desires of a vast majority of anjouan s 200,000 largely impoverished people, culminated in a declaration of independence by rebel leaders on the island and the establishment of a new provisional government headed by a 71 year old koranic scholar, abdallah ibrahim. given the popularity of secession among the islanders, this protest is believed to have at least 100 people.

sources: comoran islanders torn between hope and despair agence france presse english, annie thomas ;
notes: in the comoran capital moroni, meanwhile, most residents, who were initially sympathetic to the separatists, have grown resentful over being made to shoulder the blame for their economic deprivation. but moroni residents do share a desire for president mohamed taki abdoulkarim s ouster. at a rally late tuesday, while backing comoran unity, some 300 residents called for his resignation.

sources: crowd rampages on separatist comoros island agence france presse english ;
notes: three hundred people on the separatist comoros island of moheli went on a rampage thursday, storming the main town s administrative offices and setting fire to one of the governor s houses. the crowd became infuriated after a demonstration demanding the resignation of the governor was set upon by tear gas firing police, a reliable witness at the scene in fomboni town said. two of the protesters were slightly hurt. the demonstrators, some of whom carried grenades, wrecked the prefecture building, setting fire to documents and furniture which they had heaped up in the street and set up road blocks. moheli, like the neighbouring island of anjouan, has declared independence from the comoros archipelago government in the capital moroni. anjouan has demanded to be reattached to the former colonial power france.

sources: last troop reinforcements leave anjouan as comoros talks set agence france presse english ;
notes: meanwhile some 500 comoran oppositionists rallied in moroni on tuesday, demanding to be included in the oau sponsored talks. the oau sponsored negotiations are to bring together government officials and separatists from anjouan and moheli.

sources: urgent troops fire on separatists in comoros agence france presse english ;
notes: troops opened fire thursday on a group of separatist activists on the island of moheli in the comoros, where at least two people were wounded, local sources told afp. the army used automatic weapons and tear gas grenades against the protesters in fomboni, capital of the smallest island in the indian ocean republic, several sources said. separatist movements have emerged recently on moheli and the island of anjouan in protest at perceived domination by grand comore, the main island in the archipelago. one resident reached by telephone said that two or three people were injured. however, separate sources gave different reasons for the clashes, which lasted several hours. however, another source said trouble broke out after separatists persuaded the governor to resign and then went to the gendarmerie paramilitary police post to demand the keys to official buildings. the gendarmes turned them down and incidents broke out, the source said, adding that several homes were razed and the gates of the governor s residence were smashed. given the popularity of the separatist movement and the clashes between the protesters and police, this demonstration is assumed to have at least 50 participants.

sources: police clash with opposition protesting military intervention associated press international, september 06, 1997; saturday, international news, 525 words, kamal eddine saindou urgent opposition demonstrators, security forces clash in moroni agence france presse english ;
notes: police clashed with opposition demonstrators saturday who were protesting the government s military intervention on the separatist island of anjouan. at least one person was injured as police used tear gas and batons to break up the march of some 500 people representing a coalition of parties opposed to president mohamed taki s attempt to put down the secession on anjouan by force. clashes broke out saturday in the comoros capital moroni between security forces and opposition demonstrators protesting against government intervention to quell a separatist uprising, witnesses said here.

sources: comoros youths protest police clampdown on independent radio agence france presse english ;
notes: several hundred youths protested tuesday in the centre of the comoran capital moroni in protest at the police seizure of an independent radio station. the protesters erected barriers in the south of the city but there were no reported incidents involving the security forces who maintained a discreet presence.

sources: government employees on strike for salary arrears in comoros agence france presse english comoros strike turns into mounting anti government protest agence france presse english comoros strike goes into second day, curfew imposed agence france presse english, aboubabacar m changama asia: riot hit grande comore braced for more unrest aap newsfeed, may 13, 1998, wednesday, nationwide general news; overseas news, 553 words, by kamardine mohamed army reasserts control over protest bound comoros capital agence france presse english ;
notes: the comoro islands capital moroni ground to a halt monday when government workers went on strike and held street protests to press demands for payment of 15 months of salary arrears. strikers blocked about 20 city streets with tree trunks, cars and rocks, with each roadblock guarded by dozens of young people. many set fire to tyres to dramatize the strike, which forced offices, markets and schools to close across the capital. state employees have not been paid since january. previously, the government owed them 12 months worth of pay arrears, and workers have said back payments must be settled before they would return to work. a few minor incidents occurred early monday, pitting security forces against stone throwing youths who broke windows at the police headquarters and the foreign and education ministries. a strike by comoros civil servants developed on tuesday into a strong protest against the government as witnesses reported arrests and increasing numbers of troops deployed in the capital moroni. sources said that about a score of youths were arrested in the old part of the main town in the indian ocean republic, while soldiers fired shots into the air and turned out with heavy machinery to shift street barricades. meanwhile the comoros authorities charged that the barricades were set up by groups of young people to protest the closing of the private radio station tropic fm last week. striking civil servants brought the comoros capital moroni to a standstill on tuesday after a tense night under curfew, when troops patrolled central streets and fired live rounds into the air. protests started on monday when thousands of civil servants went on strike and protested against not being paid for up to 15 months. they were joined by hundreds of young unemployed and students voicing their displeasure at last week s closure of a local radio station by the authorities. however, during the protests, several demonstrators clearly said they wanted to get rid of taki. the organisation of african unity oau , which has already sought in vain to mediate an end to the secession crisis, proposed to help in the trouble on grande comore itself.

sources: gendarmes tear gas demonstrating schoolchildren agence france presse english, 141 words ;
notes: gendarmes in the comoros used tear gas thursday to disperse demonstrating school pupils, a radio comores journalist told afp by telephone from moroni. the pupils, aged between 10 and 15, were protesting against a government refusal to delay examinations despite a scholastic year marked by strikes and perturbations. the gendarmes broke up demonstrations in moroni, on the main island of grande comore, and in the nearby village of vuvuni, the radio reporter said, adding that a number of people, including a cameraman, suffered minor injuries. the examinations were held thursday as planned in other towns on grande comore, but were cancelled in the capital. given the protests taking place between two cities and the apparent need for teargas to disperse the protesters, this demonstration is assumed to have at least 50 participants.

sources: anti anjouan protests in comoros capital agence france presse english, 201 words new strongman vows peace, security agence france presse english, 356 words comoros; military seize power in the comoros africa news, april 30, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 527 words, ali mondjie, panafrican news agency army seizes power in comoro islands the toronto star, may 1, 1999, saturday, edition 1, 148 words ;
notes: some 150 protesters in the comoran capital reacted angrily tuesday after representatives from the separatist island of anjouan declined to sign a deal to end the archipelago s political crisis. staging a second day of demonstrations, mostly young protestors called on anjouanese families to leave their civil servants accommodation. they also called for the resignation of comoran interim president tadjidine ben said massounde, himself from anjouan, whose plans for a government of national unity have been rebuffed by anjouanese leaders. that led to violent protests earlier this week in moroni, on the main island of grande comore, and hundreds of anjouanese fled the capital to return to anjouan. soldiers stood by without acting as hordes of youths, mostly the unemployed, attacked people from anjoua islands, after delegates from the separatist island refused to sign the meeting s final document. col. azaly assoumani said he ousted the government of president tadjiddine ben said massonde to restore order after three days of violent protests against the autonomy deal reached last weekend.

sources: demo broken up in comoran capital agence france presse english, 217 words ;
notes: security forces used teargas saturday to break up a small demonstration in moroni called to protest a sovereignty deal struck by the comoran junta chief and the separatist leader on the island of anjouan. some 200 people took part in the demonstration, which was broken up less than a minute after it began.

sources: police clash with protesting youths in comoran capital agence france presse english, 394 words comoros; violent protest in moroni over price hikes africa news, october 13, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 394 words, panafrican news agency ;
notes: several demonstrators took to the streets of moroni friday to protest against the rise of the price of fuel and other basic goods. traffic was totally blocked by barricades that were erected very early in the morning from 3 am by rather dissatisfied youths. riot police threw tear gas to disperse the protesters. there was hardly any traffic in moroni by late morning, and most business concerns and schools remained closed during the day. about 30 people were arrested and some of them were later released, according to witnesses. the worst violence took place in irougoudjani, a working class district near the port. police here were repeatedly forced to beat a retreat under a hail of stones. the protests were sparked by the government s decision to raise the price of fuel from 390 francs to 450 francs and that of kerosene from 100 francs to 150 francs per litre. given the response and the traffic problems which occurred due to the protesters, this protest is assumed to have at least 100 people.

sources: comoran police, army, break up demo, make arrests inside mosque agence france presse english, 280 words ;
notes: police in the comoran capital on saturday used tear gas to break up an anti junta demonstration, raided houses and made arrests inside a mosque during prayers. events appeared to have been sparked by a protest staged by women in the mtsangani district against the repression of the military regime, which came to power in april 1999. about 20 people were arrested. given how many people were arrested and the lengths the police went to stop the demonstrations, this protest is taken to have at least 50 people.

sources: comoros; opponents of fomboni declaration stage protest africa news, november 23, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 494 words, ali moindjie,, pana correspondent, panafrican news agency ;
notes: some 150 demonstrators staged a peaceful protest thursday in moroni, the comorian capital, to oppose the implementtion of the fomboni accord. the protest march organised by a reunion based comorian lawyer, larifou sai, who heads the national public salvation committee opposed to the authorities in moroni as well the separatists in mutsamudu anjouan , went off without any violence. the protestors waved banners with words hostile to the military government and the fomboni accord.

sources: police, demonstrators clash on comoran separatist island agence france presse english, 122 words comoros: further arrests after protests in anjouan agence france presse english, 389 words ;
notes: police clashed with protesters overnight on the road leading to the main airport on the comoran separatist island of anjouan, residents told afp by telephone tuesday. security forces heavy handedly dealt with the protests, according to the same sources. a rrests were made after protesters clashed with security forces on monday night and blocked the airport road. security forces intervened overnight monday after protesters said to oppose reconciliation with the comoro islands central government on moroni blocked the airport road and poured sand on the runway. those taken into custody were andili massoundi and ridjali abdou, who had been members of a parliament dissolved by anjouan leader lieutenant colonel said abeid abderemane in october, and halifa said and takidine salim, according to an opia spokesman reached by telephone. given the ability of the protesters to block the airport road and pour sand on the runway, as well as the involvement of two prominent former pms, this protest is assumed to have had at least 50 people involved.

sources: calm returns to anjouan following soldiers mutiny agence france presse english, 218 words anjouan airport, port, closed as soldiers protest, shots fired agence france presse english, 119 words ;
notes: sporadic gunfire rang out wednesday in the breakaway comoran island of anjouan, where a protest by soldiers led to the closure of the airport and port, residents contacted by phone told afp. the soldiers, from the island s main town, mutsamudu, occupied the port to protest perceived discrimination and to demand promotions. the soldiers, from the island s main town, mutsamudu, occupied the two facilities to protest perceived discrimination and to demand promotions. the residents, who had reported sporadic gunfire wednesday morning, said the soldiers in the afternoon left the port and airport, which had since reopened. they said, however, that at one stage the situation had become critical , with confrontation between loyal troops and mutineers who had occupied the port narrowly being averted. they gave no further details. given how the mutineers occupied two facilities, created a critical situation, and were able to prevent two aircrafts from landing, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: gunfire and barricades in comoran capital agence france presse english, 287 words ;
notes: residents of the capital of the comoro islands woke to gunfire monday, when several streets were barricaded in the wake of protests against police corruption and unpaid salaries, witnesses said. the gunfire echoed for about an hour in the north of moroni, where a series of strikes and demonstrations have been held in recent days, an afp journalist reported. there were no reports of casualties resulting from the gunfire, which residents put down to police attempts to disperse protestors trying to erect new barricades. armed police in the capital of the indian ocean island nation patrolled several streets monday morning, looking for rioters . about 10 taxi drivers were arrested over the weekend and were still being held monday morning. since october 5, drivers protests have resulted in the frequent closure of many roads leading out of the capital, virtually cutting off the south of the island of grande comore. given the response and the need for barricades, this protest is assumed to have at least 100 people.

sources: 100 arrested after protesters attack police station agence france presse english, 165 words ;
notes: about 400 people in 26 towns and villages in the north protested earlier in the day at the headquarters in moroni of the comoran company for electricity and water cee about electricity cuts that have been going on for months. clashes between the police and protesters left several injured, one seriously, said the hospital in moroni. this prompted the protesters to attack a police station before returning to their villages to block the roads. the police retaliated by erecting a roadblock about 30 kilometres 20 miles outside moroni. the roadblock was still in place on wednesday evening. some 100 people have been arrested in the north of the comoran island of grande comore after a police station was attacked by people protesting about utility services, local inhabitants said. although this protest started out against a private company and therefore would not have been counted , the protesters turned on police after witnessing the harsh treatment they were receiving. thus, this protest has been coded as against police brutality; the demands of the protesters for the company are left out.

sources: protests in comoros after ex coup leader claims poll victory agence france presse english, april 15, 2002 monday, international news, 355 words ;
notes: angry youths set up barricades in the capital of the indian ocean archipelago of comoros on monday to protest at former military leader colonel azali assoumani s declaration that he had won presidential elections. roadblocks were put up in the centre of the capital, moroni, shops remained closed the old market was practically deserted in protest of azali s announcement of victory. a number of the demonstrators were seen marching towards the volo volo district in the north of moroni, where the capital s largest market is located. given that roadblocks were set up and the old market was deserted, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: youth injured as comoro army clashes with protesters agence france presse english, august 28, 2002 wednesday, international news, 317 words ;
notes: a 12 year old boy was shot in the chest wednesday as troops armed with rifles and tear gas clashed with anti government protesters in moroni, capital of the comoro islands, a witness told afp. an afp journalist saw sporadic skirmishes in moroni, where youths had set up barricades overnight as a protest against colonel azali assoumani, president of the union of the comoros, in the indian ocean between madagascar and the african mainland. on wednesday, about 50 soldiers were patrolling the streets, taking down the roadblocks made of stones, burning tyres and wrecked cars. in some areas, as soon as the troops moved on, the protesters, many with their faces covered in scarves as protection against the tear gas, reappeared to rebuild the barricades, occasionally throwing stones at their adversaries.

sources: demonstrators clash with comoro army for second day agence france presse english, august 30, 2002 friday, international news, 447 words ;
notes: comoro army troops firing tear gas clashed with masked anti government protestors on friday in a second day of unrest in the capital of the indian ocean archipelago, witnesses said. the rioting followed similar clashes on wednesday when three people were wounded. they said soldiers used tear gas as gangs of youths, most of them wearing scarves around their faces, used trees, rocks and vehicles to throw up barricades in moroni and blocked two major routes into the city. they included a boy of 12 who was wounded after allegedly being shot in the chest. the barricades were set up in protest at a perceived imbalance in power sharing between colonel azali assoumani, president of the union of the comoros, and president abdou soule elbak of the main island of grande comore where the capital is situated.

sources: six wounded in student protest in comoro islands agence france presse english, march 25, 2003 tuesday, international news, 218 words chaotic situation in moroni the indian ocean newsletter, march 29, 2003, politics & power; comoros islands; n. 1036, 329 words ;
notes: six people five civilians and a police officer were wounded here monday when police clashed with students protesting to demand better conditions for pursuing studies in the comores, the comoran red crescent said. a peaceful march by hundreds of moroni high school students took place monday morning, and in the afternoon several dozen students built barricades in several parts of the capital. police, backed by army soldiers, responded to the student protestors with tear gas and fired automatic weapons into the air, afp witnessed. for their part, middle and high school students fearing the idea of an invalid year took to the streets of moroni on march 24 to shout their anger. for 48 hours, the capital s activities were disturbed by the youth protests, which were marked by walls of tires on fire on the city s main arteries. confrontations with the army didn t end until the early evening on march 25, after many people were wounded, including five seriously by shots who had to be hospitalized and undergo operations. the gendarmerie made more than fifty arrests among the students.

sources: comoros; ongoing political confusion impacts economy africa news, april 10, 2003 thursday, 480 words, un integrated regional information networks ;
notes: the ongoing row over political power in the comoros now threatens to weaken the country s already fragile economy, analysts said on thursday, as traders on grande comore took to the streets in protest against double taxation. the strike was a way of showing authorities that businesses on the island are tired of this confusion. commercial traders are unsure who they should obey, because on the one hand the island authorities are demanding that they pay their taxes, while the union administration is also asking to be paid, former politician abdorahim said bacar told irin. given the amount of commercial traders who participated in the strike on the previous tuesday, and the fact that this protest took place across the entire island of grand comore, this protest is believed to have at least 100 people.

sources: opposition leader, french citizens detained in comoros agence france presse english, september 22, 2003 monday, international news, 175 words comoro govt has compromising evidence against detained frenchmen agence france presse english, september 25, 2003 thursday, international news, 340 words said larifou wins a bet the indian ocean newsletter, september 27, 2003, politics & power; comoros islands; n. 1057, 361 words suspected mercenaries on comoros moheli island: president agence france presse english, october 3, 2003 friday, international news, 665 words ;
notes: on september 15, 1,500 people attended a peaceful ridja rally against azali. larifou heads the opposition ridja party, which earlier this month held demonstrations against union president colonel azali assoumani. the peaceful protests against the rise in prices, organized throughout grande comoros from september 15 to 22 by franco comorian lawyer said larifou s ridja party ion 1055 , was a real success, especially among youth, making union of comoros authorities lose their cool. prior to larifou s arrest, his ridja party had on september 15 organised a peaceful protest in fomboni against assoumani. some 1,500 backers of the opposition party attended the demonstration.

sources: said larifou wins a bet the indian ocean newsletter, september 27, 2003, politics & power; comoros islands; n. 1057, 361 words ;
notes: at the september 22 protest in moroni, there were confrontations with the gendarmarie, deployed in the morning to attempt to defeat the protest, which was intended to be peaceful. busses transporting protesters to moroni were stopped in the middle of nowhere, and the passengers were stranded for hours. despite all this, more than 6,000 people, most of them young, participated in the protest against president assoumani azali. then, on september 22, it was larifou s turn to be arrested when he went to the gendarmerie to check up on his two friends. the ridja protest then clashed with the police when protester wanted to free the party s leader. ? intent to be peaceful? ? implies that it turned out to not be a peaceful protest, further implying violence on the end of the protesters.

sources: comoros; troops open fire on protest march africa news, november 27, 2003 thursday, 411 words, un integrated regional information networks comoros troops fire on protesters accused of trying to seize power agence france presse english, november 27, 2003 thursday, international news, 735 words comoros troops fire on protesters accused of seeking to seize power agence france presse english, november 27, 2003 thursday, international news, 490 words, gerard vandenberghe federal police hold five in comoros following clash with protesters agence france presse english, november 28, 2003 friday, international news, 535 words ;
notes: political tension simmering between leaders in comoros came to a head on wednesday when government troops reportedly opened fire on a group of demonstrators protesting the policies of the country s president, azali assoumani. president of grande comore island, abdou soule elbak, who led the march through the main street of the capital, moroni told said at least 15 people were injured during scuffles with soldiers. he told irin: there was absolutely no provocation from the marchers. we were only exercising our democratic right to protest against policies which we feel are detrimental to our country. the reaction of the army is unjustifiable. four of those injured are now in critical condition in hospital. i was walking in the first row, my hands crossed behind my head. the soldiers fired on innocent people, said elbak, whose entourage said between 3,000 and 6,000 people took part in the march. the government regretted that the situation should have taken such a bad turn , and called the shooting an unfortunate event which left some 15 people injured, inoussa said, quoting the statement. but we avoided the worst, he said, before quoting the statement again as saying that federal government troops had opened fire only after giving the usual warnings. the arrests followed unrest in the capital moroni wednesday in which troops shot and wounded at least 15 people after officials said a crowd led by elbak was on its way to the office of the federal president to seize power.

sources: comoros islanders demand lifting of opposition leader s house arrest agence france presse english, december 10, 2003 wednesday, international news, 196 words ;
notes: about 150 people demonstrated in the capital of the comoros islands on wednesday to call for the release of opposition leader and human rights activist said larifou, a french comoran who was detained in september. as well as chanting free larifou , the protesters called for the resignation of colonel azali assoumani, the president of the archipelago s federal government. security forces adopted a low profile during wednesday s demonstration, which took place without serious incident.

sources: police detain candidate as unrest mars comoro island vote agence france presse english english, 597 words, aboubacar m changama ;
notes: police arrested an election candidate sunday after violence in the comoros as people went to the polls to elect members to new parliaments on each of the three indian ocean islands. the candidate, issa gauda, was taken in for questioning in the capital moroni after a gang he had been seen with smashed up four polling stations, but officials otherwise reported that the poll was going smoothly. gauda was detained after about 50 men burst into polling stations, broke the plastic ballot boxes, tore up electoral lists and threw voting slips on to the floor. he had already upset the calm prevailing in moroni streets when he pulled his representatives out of one polling station soon after 11:30 am 0830 gmt , to protest at the voters register, an afp correspondent saw.

sources: comoros students throw up roadblocks to protest teachers strike agence france presse english, january 25, 2005 tuesday 1:51 pm gmt, 307 words ;
notes: hundreds of angry students threw up roadblocks of burning tires and large rocks in the capital of the comoros islands on tuesday, demanding government action to end a teachers strike that has closed schools. several streets in the capital were made impassable by the barricades and several shots were heard as police moved to clear the obstructions, according to an afp correspondent on the scene. on monday, police arrested several student protestors following a march through the capital during which incidents of vandalism were reported.

sources: shots heard as police break up student demo in comoros agence france presse english, february 28, 2005 monday 2:10 pm gmt, 269 words comoros; curfew imposed after demonstration leaves two dead africa news, march 1, 2005 tuesday, 427 words, un integrated regional information networks calm returns to comoros isle after one killed in student demo agence france presse english, march 1, 2005 tuesday 12:05 pm gmt, 193 words ;
notes: gunshots were heard on the streets of the comoros island of anjouan on monday as police moved to disperse a crowd of student demonstrators protesting a teachers strike, witnesses said. at least one person was injured when police broke up the protest and took down barricades of large rocks and burning tires the students had erected in the streets of the anjouan capital of mutsamudu, the witnesses said. comoros defense minister houmedi msaidie confirmed that there had been social disturbances on anjouan over unpaid wages that led teachers on the island to go on strike. according to abdul kamareddine, a teacher, the students were shot and killed on monday, allegedly by the police, after joining their teachers in a demonstration over months of unpaid salaries, which turned into violent confrontation. anjouan police commander ahmed salim said a teenager hit by an errant bullet had died when police fired into the air on monday to disperse the students who had erected barricades of burning tires and rocks to protest a teachers strike. the victim was not directly hit by the bullet, but was hit by a stray bullet, he said, adding that police had been forced to fire warning shots due to the presence of looters in the crowd. given the joint presence of both teachers and students, as well as the turnout from the previous month? s demonstration, this protest is believed to have at least 100 people.

sources: workers in comoros protest salary arrears, public sector reforms agence france presse english, september 8, 2005 thursday 4:05 pm gmt, 198 words ;
notes: hundreds of comoros government employees took to the streets of the capital moroni on thursday to demand payment of salary arrears and protest plans by the government to streamline the public sector. no violence was reported at the second street protest in a month, which came as the imf team held talks with officials on the status of a monitoring program signed earlier this year with the impoverished indian ocean archipelago.

sources: comoran capital at a standstill as taxis strike over petrol price hike agence france presse english, september 23, 2005 friday 4:00 pm gmt, 225 words one killed, at least 15 injured in comoros fuel hike protest agence france presse english, september 24, 2005 saturday 7:25 pm gmt, 245 words comoran president cuts import tax to alleviate fuel price increases ihs global insight, september 30, 2005, in brief, 297 words, catherine hunter ;
notes: burning tires and barricades blocked streets in moroni on friday as the comoran capital came to a standstill amid a strike by taxi drivers over plans to boost the price of gasoline on the indian ocean archipelago, witnesses said. by late morning most streets were impassable and many businesses, including those at the city s two main markets, had closed fearing possible violence while united nations employees were ordered not to take un vehicles outside local offices for security reasons, they said. the taxi strike was called earlier this week to protest government plans to raise the price of gasoline to offset higher world oil prices. one person was killed and at least 15 others injured in the comoros islands on saturday as protests against plans to increase fuel prices in the indian ocean archipelago turned violent, hospital officials said. doctors at moroni s el maarouf hospital said many patients sustained bullet wounds after police opened live fire. the protestors, who first took to the streets on friday, have paralysed operations in the capital after barricading streets with rocks and burning tyres, bringing the town to a standstill, an afp correspondent reported. angry protesters burnt at least five vehicles belonging to senior government officials and looted their houses, including the home of the vice president ben massound rachid. comoran president azali assoumani has announced a 40 cut in most import tariffs in order to cushion the effect of sharp increases in fuel prices that led to violent protests in the past week. given the reaction of the police and the government, as well as the blockage of the streets, this protest is believed to have over 100 people.

sources: protestors gather as comoros court set to certify poll results agence france presse english, april 20, 2006 thursday 4:00 pm gmt, 467 words ;
notes: supporters of the third place finisher in the weekend presidential primary on the coup plagued comoros islands staged a protest here thursday, fearing the country s highest court might disqualify their candidate from may elections. about 100 backers of ibrahim halidi gathered outside the indian ocean archipelago s constitutional court. the protestors chanted slogans to call for the speedy certification of provisional returns from sunday s primary on the island of anjouan as soldiers watched, but dispersed peacefully in the late afternoon.

sources: comoran sunnis call for shia ban agence france presse english, february 8, 2007 thursday 4:59 pm gmt, 202 words ;
notes: senior sunni clerics in the comoros staged a demonstration here on thursday, calling for shia islam to be banned in the indian ocean archipelago. about 60 religious leaders gathering in moroni also called for the expulsion of foreigners accused of spreading the shia version of islam. the clerics also called for the closure of establishments where shiite practices are taught and urged president ahmed abdallah sambi, who many say is shia but insists he is sunni, to intervene.

sources: minister hurt in clash with comoros demonstrators agence france presse english, march 7, 2007 wednesday 2:52 pm gmt, 163 words ;
notes: a government minister in the indian ocean archipelago of comoros was in a serious condition in hospital wednesday after being beaten by demonstrators near the capital moroni, hospital officials said. the incident happened in vanamboini, around 10 kilometres six miles from the capital, after security forces fired shots during a demonstration by locals against the siting of a rubbish dump in their area, wounding a youth. given the fact that the police felt it necessary to fire shots into the demonstration, as well as the fact that a man was then beaten, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: comoros: anjouan residents call for president s resignation bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, may 9, 2007 wednesday, 407 words ;
notes: some 100 protesters in wanyi phonetic , a small town near the anjouan airport, carried placards calling for peace and unity among comorans and particularly the resignation of anjouan president col bacar. many of the slogans were translated into english so as to be better understood by the many diplomats shuttling between anjouan and grande comores. we have had enough of bacar and we are asking him to step down from power because his mandate has expired. the majority of anjouan residents do not want to hear about bacar because he acts like a despot. we do not want the balkanization of our beautiful comoros. in his palace, in the middle of a forest on the edge of anjouan, president bacar said he was not worried about the demonstrations saying that they had been orchestrated by the central government of president ahmed abdallah sambi.

sources: comorans demonstrate over high cost of living bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, june 20, 2008 friday, 193 words comoros: ngazidja authorities said express concern over high cost of living bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, june 21, 2008 saturday, 263 words ;
notes: a peaceful demonstration took place on thursday morning, starting from the karthala hotel and ending at the independence square. the demonstrators expressed their anger over the high cost of life, the six month salary arrears and the perpetual fuel shortage. it is time to make sacrifices. let s have the courage to sacrifice small things so that there can be big changes in this country , deputy said mounir, one of the parliamentary representatives who marched with the trade unions suggested to the present crowd. according to said mounir, it is time to face this worsening inflation... ellipsis as published staying with arms crossed while the country is falling deeper into poverty should nolonger be part of the virtues of a peaceful comoran. in the face of the distress call made by the trade union group and the association of consumers yesterday thursday 19 june through their demonstration against the high cost of living, and questioning the union s and autonomous islands political authorities, the economic advisor and spokesman of the president of ngazidja has expressed concern over the situation and shares the demonstrators cause. the island s president, mohamed abdouloihabi, took note by ordering the cabinet to think about their respective sectors and to without delay start dialogue with social partners. given the involvement of major political figures as well as turnouts of previous protests with respect to these issues, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: protest in comoros over yemenia crash silence agence france presse english, july 16, 2009 thursday 1:21 pm gmt, 208 words ;
notes: relatives of victims of the yemenia air crash marched in the comoros capital moroni on thursday to protest against the lack of information from authorities, more than two weeks after the accident. around 300 demonstrators marched on the headquarters of the search operation to vent their frustration at a lack of information about the circumstances of the crash, which killed all but one of the 153 passengers and crew aboard. the marchers heard calls for the transport minister and the head of the island s civil aviation authority to resign.

sources: comores police fire tear gas at students agence france presse english, february 8, 2010 monday 6:35 pm gmt, 115 words ;
notes: tensions have been mounting over a five week old pay conditions strike by public sector teachers which has paralysed the school system. on friday, 1,500 school students demonstrated in moroni over the strike.

sources: comores police fire tear gas at students agence france presse english, february 8, 2010 monday 6:35 pm gmt, 115 words ;
notes: comoros security forces fired tear gas monday to disperse a demonstration by students in the centre of the capital moroni and arrested dozens of youths, police said. school students collected in the central independence square and police stopped them from gathering in the moroni high school to start a protest march. troublemakers then started commiting acts of vandalism, witnesses said, and more than 40 youths were arrested, said a police source, speaking on condition of anonymity. given how many students were arrested and how many came out on the previous friday, this protest is assumed to have more than 100 people.

sources: army restores calm in comoran island after violent protests bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, march 6, 2010 saturday, 167 words ;
notes: the army has restored calm in the town of fomboni, the administrative centre of the island of moheli in comoros, after violent protests against the extension by 18 months of president ahmed abdallah sambi s mandate. comoran privately owned news agency hzk presse reported on 5 march that hundreds of soldiers from the national army of development from ngazidja island arrived in moheli in the middle of the night as reinforcement for some 200 men stationed on the island. the army arrested dozens of people were arrested including women and the youth, added the agency. moheli s political class supported by opposition and denounced the decision to change the island s rotating presidency which previously made moheli the next island to lead on 26 may 2010. given that hundreds of soldiers were needed as reinforcements, this protest is believed to have at least 1000 people.

sources: hundreds protest against comoros president agence france presse english, april 9, 2010 friday 2:35 pm gmt, 280 words ;
notes: hundreds of protesters demonstrated friday in the comoros island of moheli against the extension of the term of the indian ocean archipelago s president. the protesters, mainly women and youths, gathered near the fomboni airport as the african union peace and security commissioner ramtane lamamra arrived for talks over the crisis sparked by the extension of the president s mandate. clashes between protesters and security forces in the centre of fomboni and a comotion at the venue of the au official s meeting saw the talks cut short. security forces later dispersed groups of stone throwing protesters who also blocked roads with trees and burning tyres, an afp correspondent reported.

sources: comoros: ex moheli president says court decision only way to resolve crisis bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, april 25, 2010 sunday, 581 words ;
notes: on friday night and yesterday, police clashed with demonstrators which saw several people injured. the clashes follow the arrest of five men and four men suspected of having poured sand on the airport s runway in the middle of the week. the nine people were finally released yesterday during the day. tentative steps toward a rapprochement between island administrations and the union government have been marred by violence on the island of moheli. according to reports carried by agence france presse afp , demonstrators took to the streets of fomboni, moheli on saturday 24 april in protest at the arrest of opposition activists accused of attempting to sabotage a visit by qatari emir sheikh hamad ben khalifa al thani. a standoff between local gendarmerie and the protestors degenerated to the extent that one individual was shot at point blank range and is currently hospitalised. given that clashes between police and protesters degenerated into shootings, this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

sources: 10 in ten the times south africa , may 27, 2010 thursday, economy, business & finance, 1001 words comoros; waiting game as crisis talks resume africa news, may 27, 2010 thursday, 379 words, radio france internationale paris ;
notes: fresh rioting broke out yesterday in the comoros after the archipelago s president appointed a new government on the eve of his original scheduled departure from office. youths on the island of moheli erected barricades on the main street and then pelted security forces. the political tensions in the comoros stem from president ahmed abdallah sambi extending his mandate by one year through a constitutional referendum. moheli islanders are demanding their turn at the presidency and protest marches have been growing in scale and intensity on the island during the last months. fresh rioting broke out on wednesday after sambi appointed a new interim government. given the widespread nature of the protest and the increasing intensity of it, this protest is assumed to have at least 100 people.

sources: comoros protest at fuel price increase agence france presse english, october 10, 2011 monday 11:28 am gmt, 96 words ;
notes: residents of the indian ocean archipelago of comoros heeded a protest monday against rising fuel costs, with shops and markets remaining closed. the strike in the impoverished country s capital moroni was organised by employers and consumer organisations angry at an eight percent hike in the cost of petrol and a 10 percent increase in diesel. this protest is believed to have at least 50 people, given the different organizations involved and the intention of the protest being two days long and the history of these types of protests involving a large number of people.

sources: tension reported in comoros as protests held over presidential poll results bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, march 16, 2016 wednesday, 320 words;
notes: strong political tension has been witnessed in comoros. campaigns for the second round of the presidential polls were to begin on monday 14 march but the head of state postponed it to tomorrow. several ministerial vehicles were burnt during a protest to contest the results of the first round. twenty of the 25 candidates are asking for a vote recount saying they do not accept the outcome of the votes from the constitutional court. there were no injuries in the recent incidents but the holding of the second round of the elections on 10 april could be put into question. anziza m changama reports.

protesteridentity: opposition demanding the re establishment of democratic institutions in protest at a planned july referendum on constitutional reform
sources: comoros opposition rallies against referendum, agence france presse english, june 2, 2018 saturday 4:02 pm gmt, 413 words, moroni, comoros, june 2 1999
notes: the comoros opposition on saturday demanded the re establishment of democratic institutions in protest at a planned july referendum on constitutional reform, which could allow president azali assoumani to seek re election. assoumani only took office in 2016 but wants to hold a fresh vote next year, two years early, so that he can remain in power beyond 2021 when his currently non renewable term would otherwise end. the referendum, scheduled for july 29, could change the current system which sees power rotate every five years between the archipelago s three main islands and allow azali to run for two fresh five year terms. friday saw demonstrations in several towns in the volcanic indian ocean archipelago off africa s east coast against the proposed poll, one of a number of controversial azali initiatives. he has suspended the constitutional court and also placed under house arrest opposition leader and predecessor ahmed abdallah sambi, a leading critic who has urged protests against the vote. friday saw a third a straight week of protests and clashes between police and opposition supporters shouting azali out after prayers at the al qasimi mosque in the capital moroni. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

notes: the comoros opposition on saturday demanded the re establishment of democratic institutions in protest at a planned july referendum on constitutional reform, which could allow president azali assoumani to seek re election. assoumani only took office in 2016 but wants to hold a fresh vote next year, two years early, so that he can remain in power beyond 2021 when his currently non renewable term would otherwise end. the referendum, scheduled for july 29, could change the current system which sees power rotate every five years between the archipelago s three main islands and allow azali to run for two fresh five year terms. friday saw demonstrations in several towns in the volcanic indian ocean archipelago off africa s east coast against the proposed poll, one of a number of controversial azali initiatives. he has suspended the constitutional court and also placed under house arrest opposition leader and predecessor ahmed abdallah sambi, a leading critic who has urged protests against the vote. friday saw a third a straight week of protests and clashes between police and opposition supporters shouting azali out after prayers at the al qasimi mosque in the capital moroni. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: comoros opposition rallies against referendum, agence france presse english, june 2, 2018 saturday 4:02 pm gmt, 413 words, moroni, comoros, june 2 2018
notes: the comoros opposition on saturday demanded the re establishment of democratic institutions in protest at a planned july referendum on constitutional reform, which could allow president azali assoumani to seek re election. assoumani only took office in 2016 but wants to hold a fresh vote next year, two years early, so that he can remain in power beyond 2021 when his currently non renewable term would otherwise end. the referendum, scheduled for july 29, could change the current system which sees power rotate every five years between the archipelago s three main islands and allow azali to run for two fresh five year terms. friday saw demonstrations in several towns in the volcanic indian ocean archipelago off africa s east coast against the proposed poll, one of a number of controversial azali initiatives. he has suspended the constitutional court and also placed under house arrest opposition leader and predecessor ahmed abdallah sambi, a leading critic who has urged protests against the vote. friday saw a third a straight week of protests and clashes between police and opposition supporters shouting azali out after prayers at the al qasimi mosque in the capital moroni. the secretary general of sambi s party, ahmed el barwane, was one of two people arrested there while another protest took place at mbeni, the home town of mohamed ali soilih, who azali defeated for the presidency two years ago. at mutsamudu, capital of the island of anjouan, one of three islands constituting the archipelago of some 800,000 people, police dispersed groups of youths demanding sambi s release. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions. note: the state response varies by location and includes all of the checked state responses
