sources: comoros police teargas opposition ahead of results, agence france presse english, march 25, 2019 monday 3:45 pm gmt, 598 words, moroni, comoros, march 25 2019; comoros president azali re elected in a landslide, agence france presse english, march 26, 2019 tuesday 8:57 pm gmt, 676 words, moroni, comoros, march 26 2019
notes: police fired teargas and rubber bullets monday to disperse more than 100 opposition supporters as comoros awaited the results of elections president azali assoumani is tipped to win, afp correspondents saw. two people were injured a protester and a plainclothes policeman when the group including several candidates began marching towards the capital moroni s independence square to protest alleged electoral fraud. the country is awaiting the results of sunday s presidential elections which the opposition claims was riddled with flaws. heavily armed soldiers were deployed to several key locations in the capital with orders to prevent unrest, interior minister mohamed kiki daoudou told afp. twelve people were injured as police fired teargas and rubber bullets at opposition candidates and supporters as they marched through the capital moroni protesting alleged irregularities.

protesteridentity: women planning to appeal for the presidential election results to be nullified
sources: comoros police arrest defeated presidential hopeful, agence france presse english, march 28, 2019 thursday 12:11 pm gmt, 424 words, moroni, comoros, march 28 2019
notes: police in comoros arrested defeated presidential hopeful soilihi mohamed on thursday, a campaign official told afp, as officers also broke up a women s protest march arresting 12 demonstrators. campaign official kamal eddin sindou confirmed the arrest of mohamed, who was named on wednesday as the head of an opposition coalition to challenge president azali assoumani s re election following sunday polls. those arrested on thursday were part of a march by roughly 100 women to the supreme court where they were planning to appeal for the results to be nullified. armed police dispersed them, and 12 of the protesters were arrested for unspecified crimes. we have had enough of what s happening. we wanted to deliver a memorandum to the supreme court but we weren t able to, march organiser samoa abdoulmadjid told afp. the police arrived and started rounding people up.

protesteridentity: opponents that say president azali assoumani s victory was rigged
sources: three killed in comoros as opposition and government face off, agence france presse english, march 28, 2019 thursday 7:00 pm gmt, 717 words, moroni, comoros, march 28 2019
notes: the indian ocean nation is in the grip of a political crisis following president azali assoumani s victory in sunday polls that his opponents say was rigged and led rivals to unite against him. protesters took to the streets of moroni s northern tp district, and the presidential palace at itsandra was locked down following the disturbances. note: the actual number of protesters was not included in the story, and is based on prior coding decisions

sources: demo over dropped charges against indian army officer agence france presse english, 334 words ;
notes: more than 500 people took to the streets of a central mauritian town to protest about a decision to drop charges against an indian army officer accused of sexual misconduct, witnesses said monday. the demonstrators, backed by church leaders and opposition parties, turned out saturday at curepipe calling on the government to provide security for its own citizens.

sources: two more killed, 30 police injured in rioting in mauritius associated press international, february 24, 1999; wednesday, international news, 391 words mauritius riots over singer s death the independent london , february 23, 1999, tuesday, news; page 14, 51 words calm returns gradually to mauritius agence france presse english, 259 words forty held after mauritius riots agence france presse english, 116 words ;
notes: police battling demonstrators angered by the death of a jailed reggae singer fatally shot two protesters and seriously wounded a third, a newspaper said wednesday. protesters rampaged through the mauritian capital for the third straight day, hurling firebombs at police stations and wounding 30 officers, the newspaper l express said. at least six of the officers suffered burns and other injuries tuesday night after demonstrators tossed firebombs at a police station in the capital, port louis. many mauritians assumed kaya was beaten to death by police. around 2,000 protesters in mauritius went on the rampage and ransacked three police stations after a reggae singer, kaya, who had been arrested for smoking marijuana, died in jail. three protesters were killed and several were wounded in the riots over the death in custody on sunday of popular reggae singer kaya. wednesday evening, incidents were reported in various parts of the island, notably triolet in the northwest, grande gaube in the north and quatre bornes, near the capital. police have denied using anything more deadly than rubber bullets and tear gas, and an autopsy was planned for agathe as well. some 40 people suspected of rioting or looting were remanded in custody in mauritius at the weekend after the indian ocean island was rocked by days of violent unrest.

sources: mauritius; riots break out over poor water distribution africa news, november 9, 1999, news, documents & commentary, 209 words, panafrican news agency ;
notes: residents of quatre bornes, a town 12 km south of port louis, blocked streets monday night to protest against poor water distribution in the area. used tyres were burnt and thrown on the streets while the people demonstrated violently against the authorities. the public utilities minister, rashid beebeejaun, in a televised message tuesday, assured the population the authorities would provide them with water till the end of december. given the population of the town and the ability of protesters to block streets and cause a significant amount of damage, this protest is coded as having at least 100 people.

sources: 400 protest against drug trafficking on indian ocean island associated press international, march 26, 2000; sunday, advisory, 295 words ;
notes: an estimated 400 people gathered sunday to protest growing drug trafficking and use on this indian ocean island known mainly for its beaches and knitwear. the national civic movement, a muslim organization which planned the rally, challenged the head of the island s police force to resign for his failure to halt the trafficking in cocaine, heroin and patent mood altering drugs. the ncm also called for the reinstatement of the death penalty, abolished a decade ago, to be applied to convicted drug traffickers.

sources: mauritius; mauritian fishermen end protest africa news, may 29, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 206 words, panafrican news agency ;
notes: fishermen in port louis have finally let go a ship they blocked after the government agreed to pay compensation of up to 50,000 rupees monthly for a period of six months to each of them. the 100 fishermen and their families had blocked the ship, pompeii at baie du tombeau, a coastal village near the capital, where it was conveying material for the laying of sewerage pipes. the demonstrators demanded compensation arguing that pollution from the sewage had decimated the fish population in the lagoons.

sources: mauritius; civil servants demonstrate against new government africa news, september 27, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 185 words, panafrican news agency ;
notes: hundreds of public officers demonstrated wednesday in port louis against the government s decision to cancel a 300 rupee monthly increase in wages offered to them by the outgoing government that lost the 11 september elections. the demands are about wages and also about wanting the new administration honoring a promise from the previous one, which falls under political process.

sources: mauritius; port louis civil servants protest against salary report africa news, november 6, 2000, news, documents & commentary, 218 words, panafrican news agency ;
notes: hundreds of civil servants staged a demonstration monday in port louis to protest against the recommendations of a salary report released friday, asserting that it was manipulated by the government. addressing the demonstrators, rashid imrith, president of the civil service trade union federation, asked prime minister sir anerood jugnauth to give a compensation of 1,000 rupees monthly to all public officers and to enquire into allegations that the salary report was manipulated by some members of the government. police tried to stop the demonstrators from marching towards the government house but to no avail.

sources: mauritius; recruitment: health care assistants want their jobs back... africa news, july 12, 2005 tuesday, 439 words, l express mauritius; civil service recruitment: health care assistants engaged in legal battle africa news, july 19, 2005 tuesday, 472 words, l express ;
notes: before settling in the garden, the hcas had protested in port louis streets after being welcomed by the police on what was supposed to be their first day at work. the police refused to let them in. they tried to convince the minister of health to give them their jobs but the latter insisted on an enquiry into the recruitment process. this is why some in despair, started their hunger strike. the 388 health care assistants hca , who received a letter from the new government stating they could not take up their jobs in the hospitals where they had been posted, want to take legal action. the newly elected government wants to investigate the way this recruitment was done before allowing the hcas to start work. they want to make sure the recruitment was not an electoral bribe . meanwhile, the 388 hca are at a loss. the 388 hcas who, after receiving their letters, turned up to discover their appointments had been frozen by the new government, seem reluctant to abandon hope even if they did stop their five day old hunger strike last tuesday.

sources: mauritius; tug of war between fishermen and minister africa news, august 22, 2006 tuesday, 222 words, l express ;
notes: mauritian fishermen, just like those in rodrigues, are very dissatisfied with the recent measure concerning bad weather benefits. after their general assembly where they expressed their frustration and anger towards the government, the 800 fishermen present walked to the office of the ministry of agro industry and fishing where they protested against the measure. instead of giving the same benefits to all fishermen of the island in case of bad weather, the new measure has divided the island into four regions. as a result, fishermen now obtain their allowance depending on the weather in their own region.

sources: mauritius: muslims protest against ban of loudspeakers in mosques bbc monitoring africa political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, april 11, 2007 wednesday, 386 words ;
notes: the rapid intervention police unit were ordered to disperse demonstrators at the government offices at around 1300 local time . the use of force was not necessary since the demonstrators fled the area while continuing shouting insults at the government offices. defying the ban by the police commissioner, the jamiat ul ulama led by maulana jamil chooramun maintained the protest. the organization protests the verdict rendered by the supreme court regarding the use of loudspeakers in mosques. the demonstration was peaceful but held in a tense atmosphere. between 200 and 300, including young people with masked faces, responded to the appeal to demonstrate.

sources: mauritian police disperse bangladeshi workers protests bbc monitoring south asia political supplied by bbc worldwide monitoring, march 23, 2009 monday, 220 words ;
notes: the police on sunday, 22 march, dispersed a peaceful demonstration by bangladeshis working in mauritius on contract when they were holding protest against the mauritian government s decision to terminate the work contract of some of them by 30 april 2009. mauritian news agency reported from the country s capital port louis that sunday afternoon some 200 bangladeshis gathered at the north bus terminal at the city centre. the gathering decided to walk up to office of the prime minister, navin chandra ramgoolam, and to the office of the minister of labour, jean francois chaumiere, to hand over letters of protest.

sources: mauritius suspends recruitment of foreign construction workers xinhua general news service, september 5, 2013 thursday 6:10 am est, world news; economic, 250 words ;
notes: mauritius has suspended the recruitment of foreign workers in the construction sector to expand domestic employment and avoid labor disputes. the decision comes in the wake of troubles caused by 600 bangladeshi workers at a textile factory in the southern parts of port louis. they organized demonstrations to protest against their working conditions and salary cuts. mohamed said the 15 bangladeshis arrested for disrupting public order were set to be deported on wednesday night, while 78 others had agreed to return to their country.

protesteridentity: former prime minister navinchandra ramgoolam supporters
sources: ex mauritius pm ramgoolam arrested: media reports agence france presse english, february 6, 2015 friday 5:28 pm gmt, 374 words;
notes: police in mauritius arrested former prime minister navinchandra ramgoolam on friday, media reports said, sparking angry demonstrations from supporters in the indian ocean island nation. ramgoolam, 67, who accepted defeat in parliamentary polls in december, was arrested and held in prison for questioning on friday afternoon, l express and le mauricien newspapers reported, quoting his lawyer. an afp reporter said scuffles broke out between his supporters and those of the government on the streets of the capital, but police separated the two sides britain s foreign office updated its travel information for mauritius, saying there had been reports of political demonstrations in port louis and advising its nationals to monitor local media and avoid all large crowds.
